column2: Prices of cotton in the domestic market moved irregularly last week and closed with mixed net changes. At the close of trading on Friday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were down 12 to up 35 points. In the preceding week the market had been down 15 to 44 points.

Lebanon's million and a half inhabitants and the half million who live on Cyprus have been unhappy examples this week-end of what happens when international conflicts come to a focus in small areas. It is as though a burning glass were turned upon them: hatreds, jealousies and fears burst into flame, and fuel to keep it burning is poured in from outside.

ST. LOUIS, June 15 (UPI) -- Harry Hanebrink; a .169 hitter, belted a two-run homer off Lindy McDaniel in the ninth inning today as the Milwaukee Braves gained an uphill 4-to-2 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 15 -- Technical assistance provided by the United Nations to under-developed lands was greater in 1957, both in quantity and quality, than in any previous year, according to a report published today.
Maritime strikes are tying up all East Coast and Gulf Coast shipping today.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 15 -- British authorities enforced Sunday quiet on Cyprus today with an all-day curfew in Nicosia and other cities. It was estimated that 140,000 persons, about a fourth of the island's population, were compelled to stay indoors.
The Times has performed a significant reporting job in the extensive article of June 9 on deteriorated housing conditions in Morningside Heights.
It was an alert taxi driver who first called this corner's attention to the red and white banners along our streets in place of those of green and white, which were the city's salute to spring.

UNITED NATIONS, June 15 -- Mr. Hammarskjold, decided tonight to leave for Beirut Tuesday after having studied reports throughout the day on the deterioration of the position of President Camille Chamoun.
Two old-time denizens of Prospect Park came to the end of their trails last night.
The Kudner Agency, Inc., has taken the first step in a business comeback following the loss of extensive General Motors Corporation billings.
PARIS, June 15 -- New indications of the relationship beween the recession in the United States and the situation in France are contained in the latest statistics on French employment.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Senate starts its final push on the labor bill tomorow in a stepped-up schedule that could give Alaska statehood before the week is out.

John E. Brady has been appointed director of advertising at American Airlines, effective June 23. The appointment was announced by Charles A. Rheinstrom, executive vice president for sales, who recently left a post as vice president at the J. Walter Thompson Company to rejoin the airline.
NEWARK, June 15 -- A $115,000 Federal grant has been approved to carry out a ten-year urban renewal study for Newark. The city administration will contribute $57,000 in services for the program.
Following are the members of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund panel that prepared the report on foreign economic policy:
PRINCETON, N. J., June 15 -- Dr. Robert F. Goheen, president of Princeton University, today urged members of next Tuesday's graduating class to realize the moral aspects of their liberal education.
Forty thousand Puerto Ricans participated yesterday in the annual fiesta of St. John the Baptist, patron saint of their home island.
PLAINFIELD, N. J., June 15 -- The Junior League of Plainfield will hold its first Cotillion here Wednesday evening at the Plainfield Country Club. Many dinners will precede the fete.

The idea that music can carry a message of peace and brotherhood in a sorely troubled world is appealing. Pablo Casals, concluding his triumphant music festival in San Juan, Puerto Rico, put forward a thought that is worthy of his humanitarianism and he proposed it in an appropriately musical form.

ARLINGTON, N. J., June 15 -- Alan Fleming of Chatham was the only seeded player eliminated today as Larry Schaffer of the Bronx led seven seeded players into the fourth round of the New Jersey State singles tennis championship at the Arlington Players Club.
The Union of American Hebrew Congregations adopted a record budget of $1,095,372 yesterday to continue and advance its programs of American Reform Judaism in the Western Hemisphere for 1958-59.

IMPROVING MANAGERIAL PERFORMANCE. By Virgil K. Rowland. 167 pp. Harper Brothers, $3.50. Since the end of World War II there has been a spate of books on improving management. This one appears to be more readable and interesting than many, Mr. Rowland, an officer of Detroit Edison Company, stresses a method of improving management's effectiveness by use of "group summary appraisal."
A new international system that would revolutionize trade in the free world was recommended yesterday in a report of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund.
PARIS, June 13 -- Feelings are running high in the Paris fashion world over disclosure of the controversial Gottlieb Gallup poll on the reaction of American women to French fashions.

Mayor Wagner will present medals to twenty-two firemen for heroism in 1957 at ceremonies tomorrow noon in City Hall Plaza. The next of kin of eight firemen who died in the course of duty will also receive medals.
One man was shot and killed and three persons were injured in Queens last night in the attempted abduction of a woman. Two of the injured were policemen who broke up the attempt.
LONDON, June 15 -- The Foreign Office said today that it had received communications from the Turkish and Greek Governments. It declined to discuss their contents.
PARIS, June 15 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle will go to Algeria again early in July for an on-the-spot study of the military situation there, authoritative sources said tonight.

FRANCORCHAMPS, Belgium, June 15 -- Tony Brooks, a 26-year-old dentist who abandoned his practice for the faster and more lucrative business of driving racing cars, easily won the Grand Prix of Europe today.

JANET LOUISE SCHUMACHER O'BRIEN can bake a cherry pie. She can sew a dress, fit slipcovers, do the housekeeping in her Bennett Avenue apartment for herself and for her husband, Patrick O'Brien, a Tipperary man.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Federal National Mortgage Association announced today that it would pay off in cash and would not re-fund $802,061,000 of notes under in "management and liquidating" operation due June 26. The money to pay off the notes will come from the Treasury.
Five American League teams -- the Yankees, Tigers, Indians, White Sox and Athletics -- beat the midnight trading deadline last night by swapping a total of thirteen players in three big deals.
ATHENS, June 15 -- Greece has broken the ties binding her militarily to Turkey. Her action severs a supporting link of the North Atlantic Alliance in Southeast Europe.

Fathers who exert a weak influence in family life by "indifference and neglect" are contributing to "the complex problem of juvenile and parental delinquency," Mgsr. Harry J. Wolff declared yesterday.

BERLIN, June 15 -- Col. Robert P. McQuail of the United States Army and Deputy Foreign Minister Otto Winzer of East Germany are to meet again tomorrow to discuss the release of nine army men and a helicopter being held by the Communist Government.
The steamship charter market held its own and even managed some gain in activity last week.

There are indications that the bill granting statehood to Alaska will finally come up in the Senate this week. Likewise, there seems to be a growing feeling that the chance of its adoption is getting better all the time. This is as it should be. Action should be taken now, and it should be favorable.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The mock atomic bombs are getting bigger and bigger.

MONTREAL, June 15 -- Pointe Claire Industrial Park in suburban Montreal will have as one of its tenants the Avon Products of Canada, Ltd., Canadian subsidiary of the American cosmetics company with headquarters near Chicago.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 15 -- A barricade of rolled barbed wire intended to separate clashing Greeks and Turks runs through the old walled city of Nicosia. It has become widely known here as the "Mason-Dixon line."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 15 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has bought Robert Lewis Taylor's new novel, "The Travels of Jaimie McPheeters."
Following is the text of the summary of the report on "Foreign Economic Policy for the Twentieth Century," prepared by Panel III of the Special Studies Project of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund, Inc.:

ED SULLIVAN devoted his variety hour last night to a filmed visit to the Brussels World's Fair. His program on Channel 2 was a mixture of samplings of world entertainment, a quick tour of the Fair, and a presentation of celebrities who did little more than take bows.
Five New York residents were among fifty-two young men and women who received Opportunity Fellowships from the John Hay Whitney Foundation.

BALTIMORE, June 15 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox moved out of the American League basement today behind the shutout pitching of Jim Wilson and Dick Donovan in a double victory over the Baltimore Orioles. The Sox won by 3 -- 0 and 4 -- 0.

" Nothing is more important than to bring about a conviction that a sustained and imaginative foreign economic policy is crucial (to the United States) from the point of view of our own self-interest and from the point of view of the peace and well-being of the entire world."
Ann Barlow, who is regarded by the New Dramatists Committee as one of its most talented members, will make her Broadway debut as a playwright early next year.

A SIGN of the new nostalgic mood in decorating is a revival of the lacy wicker furniture of the Victorian era. A new collection of reproductions, made in Hong Kong, can be found at Mayhew, 603 Madison Avenue, and Brancusi, 1001 First Avenue.
A recommendation that would have been regarded as highly revolutionary up to a few years ago highlights a report released yesterday by the Special Studies Project of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The capital was not condemning Sherman Adams today so much as it was psychoanalyzing him. How, it was asking, could he have accepted such favors from a prominent business man under surveillance in the Federal Trade Commission?

HORATIO NELSON, the most celebrated hero in the history of naval warfare, had only two ruling passions. Both were gratified so completely that one presumes he enjoyed a degree of human felicity as great as that granted to any man. One was for fame and glory. His spectacular victories and flamboyant personality guaranteed that he should be as famous as even he could wish.
LIKE the ardent baseball fan who rattles off the batting averages, the conscientious dieter can tell the calorie content of various foods at the drop of a tablespoon of heavy cream (49 calories).

A news story from East Hampton, in connection with the celebration of John Howard Payne's birthday on June 9, revives some of the hoary legends concerning Payne's birthplace and the writing of "Home, Sweet Home."
The Long Island Lighting Company (LILCO) will discontinue the retail sale of gas and electric appliances on July 1, it announced today.
The Anglican Bishop of Natal, South Africa, called his country's apartheid policy "a fossilized anarchronism" in a sermon yesterday at Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway at Wall Street.
Columbia University's president, Dr. Grayson Kirk, said yesterday that he believed no major institution would leave Morningside Heights because of neighborhood conditions.

Discrimination in employment on account of age becomes illegal in New York State on July 1. This is due to two amendments to the present law against discrimination, which were passed unanimously in the closing days of the last session of the Legislature and subsequently approved by Governor Harriman.

ABOARD THE SANTA ROSA AT SEA, June 15 -- This $25,000,000 vessel will be on time for the traditional welcome that is scheduled for her in New York tomorrow, Lewis Lapham, president of the Grace Lines, said today.
WARSAW, June 15 -- The East German Government has barred all road transit across its territory between Poland and West Germany in an effort to cut one line of contact between Germans.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., June 16 -- An opportunist Yale baseball team made the university's reunion memorable today by defeating Harvard's Ivy League champions, 5-3.

LONDON, June 16 (AP) -- Australia's Ashley Cooper, favorite for the Wimbledon tennis championship, withdrew on medical advice tonight from singles play in the Queens Club tournament. Earlier in the day, he won a second-round match from John Cranston of San Marino, Calif., 2 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 7 -- 5.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- William P. Rogers, the Attorney General, termed "disgraceful" today the failure of Congress to create additional judgeships in the Federal courts.

Although the departure of Don Newcombe from the Dodgers involved the biggest star of the many trading-deadline deals in the major leagues, the transaction was not altogether a surprise. Big Don, having difficulties on and off the field with the Los Angeles club, has been mentioned in trade talks for years.
CHICAGO, June 16 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
In one year Israel has markedly raised her technological and production efficiency, it was reported yesterday by David Rose, president of the American Technion Society.

MADRID, June 16 -- Rudolph von Ripper, World War II hero and American artist, opened a one-man exhibition of painting, etching, sculpture, rugs and jewelry here today at the Museum of Contemporary Art.
The National Linen Service Corporation yesterday reports for the nine months ended on May 31 a net profit of $2,742,953, equal to $1.23 a share on the common stock.

Salem Brosius, Inc., announced yesterday plans to enter the atomic industry supply field with the acquisition of Alloy Manufacturing Company, Inc., of Pittsburgh, Pa. Directors of both companies have voted favorably, on merger plans.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -The Supreme Court refused today to review the convictions of Martha Dodd Stern and Alfred K. Stern for contempt of court. The action appears to write finis to a bizarre case.
CAIRO, June 16 -- Gamal Abdel Nasser, President of the United Arab Republic of Egypt and Syria, has again loosened his reins on propaganda against the United States.

WHEN Danny O'Connell of the Giants saw the friendly fence in Los Angeles for the first time, he eyed it with a calculating glance and snickered. "If the Dodgers had any sense," he said, "they'd immediately make a trade with the Pirates for Frank Thomas. I shudder to think what a pull hitter like Thomas would do to Babe Ruth's home run record in this park."
John Stix has been engaged to direct "Sure Sign of Spring," the new musical by T. A. G. Hungerford (book), James Bredt (music) and Don Reid (lyrics).
LOS ANGELES, June 16 (UPI) -- Commissioner Ford C. Frick has disallowed a request to place Don Bessent, an ailing relief pitcher, on the disabled list, the Dodgers said today.

The Anaconda Company became the first of the "big three" copper producers to raise the price of refined copper yesterday. It advanced the price 1 1/2 cents a pound, to 26 1/2 cents, effective today, in the first change in primary copper quotations by a major producer since mid-January.

Assemblyman Joseph F. Carlino, Republican of Nassau County, last night called upon Governor Harriman to order a full-scale investigation of New York City by the newly organized State Crime Commission.

The Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland yesterday arranged to borrow $25,000,000 through a joint public bond offering and a loan from the International Bank for Recon struction and Development. A syndicate headed by Dillon, Read Co., Inc., is offering today $6,000,000 of the Federation's 5 3/4 per cent external loan bonds, due 1973, at 97.50 to yield 6 per cent.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare indicated today that the Administration would accept a cost-of-living increase in Old Age and Survivors Insurance benefits.

TRENTON, June 16 -- The Legislature gave its final approval today to bills that would extend unemployment benefits to thirty-nine weeks and ban the sale on Sunday of clothing or household or office appliances.
BONN, Germany, June 16 -- The West German and Austrian Governments completed today ratification of an agreement on the disposal of wartime German assets in Austria.

PARIS, June 16 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle began today an intensive study of France's international position preparatory to a series of diplomatic meetings that will begin June 29 with a visit to Paris by British Prime Minister Harold Macmillan.
OTTAWA, June 16 -- Despite the recession, Canada's rate of production, personal income and savings and gross national expendiure all showed an increase in 1957.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
pARIS, June 16--The Soviet LTnion and Britan are urging the Jnited States to do more for the expansion ofworld trade.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., June 16 -- Long considered too dangerous even for motorcycle patrolmen, the Cross County Parkway received a lower speed limit today and some steel-helmeted men on cycles to enforce it.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 16 -- One of Hollywood's oldest employer-employe relations has ended with the resignation of Sidney Franklin from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. The director-producer joined the studio in 1927 and was responsible for some of its greatest artistic and financial successes.

The upward trend in steel production that began late in April continued last week. Output reached a new 1958 high of 1,728,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
Putnam County pledged its four votes in the Republican State convention yesterday to Nelson A. Rockefeller. Despite the few votes involved, the pledge was regarded as politically significant.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- President Eisenhower disclosed today that his doctors wanted him to avoid Colorado's altitude because he had suffered a heart attack there.

Four companies have been added by the Securities and Exchange Commission to its so-called Canadian restricted list, bringing the total to 166. The new additions are Continental Mining Exploration, Ltd.; Glacier Explorers, Ltd.; Vanguard Exploration, Ltd. and Shoreland Mines, Ltd.
The State of North Carolina is planning to borrow $15,000, 000 in the bond market on July 16 to finance school construction.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today decided that the Government was not liable for compensation to gold mine owners because of the closing of their operations during World War II.
CHICAGO, June 16 -- Now that traditional styling is threatening unadorned, streamlined modern designs in popularity, manufacturers are scrambling for new ideas to dress up furniture.

Some travelers never seriously, consider their luggage until it's on the scales at an airport. More than one embarking passenger has exceeded the tourist baggage quota of forty-four pounds enforced by all overseas airlines. An additional twenty-two pounds is allotted to first-class passengers.
Percy Gale Jr., former director of the city's Bureau of Real Estate, was questioned for nearly an hour in the offices of Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday morning.

DAVID STIRLING brought a wild splendor to the theory and practice of war. He operated in North Africa when Rommel and the British drove each other back and forth in pavannes of blood and sand. His enemies were the Germans, the Italians and the middle-echelon bureaucrats at their headquarters desks in Cairo.
Directors of the Universal Products Company, Inc., yesterday voted to split the common stock on a two-for-one share basis. The company makes relay switches, mutuel totalisators and registry machines.
Cornelius Haagmans has been asked to do one more job before he retires for good -- sail the Netherlands' largest passenger liner across the Atlantic and back.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., June 16 (AP) -- After a one-day walkout today, iron workers in upstate New York prepared a full-scale strike for tomorrow. Meanwhile, the state moved to end a dispute that could make idle 30,000 construction workers.
PHILADELPHIA, June 16 -- Perfect June weather and an all-Beethoven program drew a crowd of 23,000 to Robin Hood Dell tonight for the opening concert of the 1958 summer series.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- The Supreme Court decided today that the Attorney General could not defer the deportation of six Chinese aliens who were in the country on parole. The Chinese say they fear persecution or death if sent back to Communist China.
A program to rehabilitate a deteriorating and overcrowded block in the Chelsea section of Manhattan was announced yesterday by Bernice P. Rogers, Deputy Commissioner of the Department of Buildings.
CINCINNATI, June 16 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals scored two runs in the ninth to tie Cincinnati and pushed across three more in the eleventh for a 6-5 victory tonight.

HAWORTH, N. J., June 16 -- Judy Frank of Old Oaks and Mrs. Phillip Cudone of the Forest Hill Field Club tied for the medal today in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's fifty-fifth annual championship.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Air Force ordered the development today of a space glider that would be boosted by powerful rockets and would soar around the earth at near-satellite speeds.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 16 -- Six Greek Cypriote mayors were invited today to confer with Archbishop Makarios in Athens on Britain's new plan for the future of Cyprus.
The Board of Education had some bad news yesterday for 4,000 seventh-grade pupils: They will not be promoted to eighth grade When the current school year ends June 27.
BEIRUT, June 16 (UPI) -- Premier es-Sohl charged today that the Cairo radio had inspired the looting, dynamiting and burning of his home in last week-end's fighting.

Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith and White, Weld Co., and associates are offering today $15,000,000 of Oklahoma Gas Electric Company 3 7/8 per cent first mortgage bonds, due in 1988, at 101 to yield 3.81 per cent.
ELMSFORD, N. Y., June 16 -- Dave Marr, the young Rockaway Hunting Club professional, led the Metropolitan District qualifiers for the National Professional Golfers Association championship today.
WHEN Rockwell Kent heard that the Supreme Court ruled yesterday that the State Department was wrong in denying passports to him and two others, he said:
The oft-delayed hearing of Transit Authority charges against thirteen subway employes accused of having led last December's eight-day strike got off to a slow start yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Supreme Court ruled, 6 to 3, today that employes and unions could legally include "hot cargo" clauses in their contracts, but that the unions could not enforce the clause in specific disputes unless the employer agreed.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, said today that the dairy provisions of a farm bill approved by the House Agriculture Committee last Friday would adversely affect the dairy industry.
An insurgent group lost last night in its attempt to weaken James G. Cross as president of the Bakery and Confectionary Workers International Union.
BERLIN, June 16 -- United States and East German representatives held an "inconclusive" meeting today in connection with nine United States Army men and a helicopter detained by East Germany.

The Fund for the Republic sought a way yesterday to convince the American Broadcasting Company that it should reinstate a recorded television interview with Henry Cabot Lodge, United States Ambassador to the United Nations.

Even though it was by the narrowest possible margin and avoided pinpointing the constitutional question, the Supreme Court's decision in two major passport cases yesterday marked an important step in safeguarding from arbitrary interference the American citizen's inherent right to travel.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The State Department made public today formerly undisclosed documents the Western Big Three Ambassadors had handed to Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Foreign Minister, during the current series of preliminary talks in Moscow on a heads-of-government meeting.
Restless Wind, a chestnut 2-year-old, won the colt division of the National Stallion Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday, scoring by a head over E. Leigh Cotton's First Minister.

New York and Chicago bankers have bemoaned the fact that their raw material -- deposits -- has grown less rapidly than that of banks elsewhere. As one explanation they cite legal hurdles against following their customers to the suburbs.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Sherman Adams agreed today to appear tomorrow before Congressional investigators and answer questions on his relationship with Bernard Goldfine, Boston industrialist.

Tennis under the lights at Forest Hills last night was far from the box-office success promoter Jack Kramer had envisioned. For Lewis Hoad it was a nightmare of foot faults and failure as the Australian youth suffered an unlooked-for setback against Tony Trabert.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -The Government suffered a major setback today in its effort to keep the $100,000,000 General Aniline and Film Corporation out of the hands of Interhandel, a Swiss holding company.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 16 -- The raging battle for Beirut eased today into sporadic rifle fire and explosions.

Announcement of the execution of Imre Nagy and three of his associates brought back in vivid memory the Hungarian revolt of 1956. It recalled thirteen days of courage and will that gave Hungary a momentary taste of more democratic government.
MOSCOW, June 16 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's latest letter to the Western powers called on them to commit themselves "definitely" on an East-West heads-of-government meeting.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, today called for the immediate resignation of United States Attorney Robert Tieken of Chicago. Mr. Tieken refused.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Charles Maylon of the Air Force, a former legislative aide to President Harry S. Truman, drowned yesterday when he fell from a motorboat into the Patuxent River. The general, who was 63 years old, retired from active duty in 1949.

BOMBAY, India, June 16 -Five persons were killed and fifty injured when policemen fired on striking dock workers in Madras today. There were no incidents in strikes paralyzing other major Indian ports.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, June 16 (AP) -- Generalissimo Rafael Trujillo said today the Good Neighbor Policy instituted by President Franklin D. Roosevelt and Secretary of State Cordell Hull was gone without hope of revival.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Observers here said tonight they viewed the execution of Imre Nagy as the gravest development in the Communist world since the Hungarian revolt of November, 1956.
PHILADELPHIA, June 16 -The Superior Court of Pennsylvania today ordered the question of service cuts by the Pennsylvania Railroad to be aired in the fall.

IF a woman succeeds as a buyer in a department store, she may not qualify as a psychologist, a Delphic oracle or an athlete, but talent in these three spheres will help. Any woman who spends thousands of dollars a year on clothes that other women buy must be equipped with certain unusual attributes.
TUNIS, June 16--The conclusion of an agreement for the evacuation of all French military posts in Tunisia except Bizerte is expected by tomorrow.

LONDON, June 16 (Reuters) -- Following is a summary issued in English tonight by Tass, Soviet News Agency, of a June 11 letter by Soviet Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev to President Eisenhower on a summit conference:

Although he had a five-inch advantage in height, a Frankie Ryff, a lightweight from the Bronx, turned in an unimpressive performance in defeating Tommy Tibbs of Boston in a ten-rounder at St. Nicholas Arena last night.

JOHN DALY, vice president of the American Broadcasting Company, is to be congratulated for taking a firm stand with regard to the Mike Wallace series of interviews presented in cooperation with the Fund for the Republic.
The State Commission Against Discrimination heard strong objections yesterday to a proposed regulation that would make it unlawful for an employer to require a job applicant to give his age.
Borough President James J. Crisona of Queens resumed his attack yesterday on the land purchase in Edgemere Park, Queens, that stirred a storm within the City Administration.
Columbia University announced yesterday the retirement of six faculty members, effective June 30. All will become professors emeritus July 1.
WASHINGTON, June 16--The Senate paused in its labor debate today and quickly approved legislation creating a national space agency and a powerful space policy board.

THE dome-like fall hats shown by Miss May for day are made of fluffy mousses, longhaired furs and shaggy texture fabrics. All look insulatingly warm, even though they are feathery light, and all, though big and important, roll up to pocket size.
Merged labor has had its stormiest sailing in the maritime trades.
HARTFORD, June 16 -- Howard Pyle, a special assistant to the President, urged tonight that the nation elect a "conservative" Congress in November.

LONDON, June 16 -- The Soviet Union and China, two giants of international communism, appeared to Western observers tonight to be preparing for some doctrinal pronouncement, probably affecting relations with the West and with Yugoslavia.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- a passage in President Tito's speech yesterday hinting that there are economic reasons for Communist China's virulent attitude toward Yugoslavia is receiving special attention from some observers here.
New York thoroughbred race tracks are about to make a pitch for the children's trade.

It was a dramatic and effective address which Yugoslav President Tito delivered Sunday. For explosive and long-lasting impact upon the international situation it promises at least to equal his speech in Pula in November, 1956. The repercussions of that latter speech, we may recall, are still being felt, since it has been frequently cited in the latest round of attacks other Communist-ruled countries have been directing at Yugoslavia.
In your column of June 10 you included a letter from David Mann making various complaints about Westchester County.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Supreme Court today overturned State Department regulations denying passports to suspected Communists and others of allegedly doubtful loyalty. The vote was 5 to 4.

AFTER giving us George Bernard Shaw's "The Philanderer" last month, the Downtown Theatre has now chosen to display another Shavian trifle. This time it is "You Never Can Tell," written by the irascible Irishman in 1897, when he was 41 years young.
LONDON, June 16 (Reuters) -- Hugh Goodson, chairman of a syndicate that built the 12-Meter Sceptre, Britain's challenger for the America's Cup, said today he was "confident" of the yacht's chances.

Thirteen persons were trapped for an hour and fifteen minutes yesterday morning in an elevator of the eleven-story building at 6 East Thirty-second Street, off Fifth Avenue. Some wept and prayed until rescued by the police.

Following the example set by the Soviet authorities in Potsdam, the Communist regime in East Germany has now also rebuffed the American demand for the release of the nine American Army men it captured ten days ago unless the United States agrees to negotiate with it on a Government-to-Government basis. This regime, which calls itself the "Government" of the "German Democratic Republic," is, of course, neither a government, nor German, nor democratic, nor republican.
The New York Philharmonic was welcomed home yesterday from a seven-week tour of Latin America as a "peerless emissary of goodwill."
BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 16 -- Now it is West Germany's turn. In celebration of its "national days" at the Brussels World's Fair today and tomorrow it is making a brief but decisive splash.
Northbound traffic leaving the Manhattan end of the Brooklyn Bridge will be detoured beginning at 7 A. M. today.

POCONO MANOR, Pa., June 16 (AP) -- Americans are still building up their savings, but at a much slower pace than a few months ago, the head of the United States Savings and Loan League reported today.

The board of monitors appointed by a Federal court to supervise the affairs of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters has named two fulltime staff members to investigate complaints of undemocratic practices and other abuses in the giant union.
PORT JEFFERSON, L. I., June 16 -- The Port Jefferson and Bridgeport Steamboat Company suspended its ferry service across Long Island Sound here this morning.
For the second straight year a nationally ranked bowling team will make an exhibition tour of the Far East primarily for the entertainment of the United States armed forces stationed there.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI) -- Senator Strom Thurmond opened today what was expected to grow into a large-scale attack by Southern Democrats on the bill passed by the House to make Alaska the forty-ninth-state.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Supreme Court will review a lower court decision holding that the Interstate Commerce Commission is without power to let three railroads end their passenger ferry service between New York and New Jersey.

CINCINNATI, June 16 -- A four-day deadlock over whether the 1,500,000-member American Baptist Convention should establish permanent headquarters in the Midwest or in Valley Forge was broken late today.
LONDON, June 16 -- Trading volume improved moderately in the stock market today. Prices in most principal groups rose steadily, if slowly.

Max Block and three lieutenants were accused yesterday of seeking to make a deal on pensions as a price for their resignation as leaders of two New York locals of the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 16 -- Former President Nereu Ramos was reported to be among twenty-one persons killed tonight in an airplane crash at Curitiba, capital o Parana State.

It is a pleasure to welcome Philippine President Carlos P. Garcia, who arrives this morning in Washington to be the guest of President Eisenhower and of the American people. President Garcia is no stranger to us, but this is the first time he has been here since assuming the Presidency.
MOUNT VERNON, Me., June 16 -- Fishermen who have fallen for the spinning craze have to rediscover, from time to time, that on windy days plug-casting is the best way to catch bass.
Net assets of the 144 mutual fund members of the National Association of Investment companies topped $10,000,000,000 for the first time on May 31 the trade association announced yesterday.

The Department of Air Pollution Control has issued its annual report for 1957, finding, in general, that progress was made last year in the never-ending battle to control smoke and other air contaminants. Unfortunately, progress necessarily was discouragingly slow, since the department has not yet been given adequate tools to do its work. The report came to the conclusion, for instance, that sootfall increased somewhat both in 1956 and in 1957.
PORTLAND, Me., Tuesday, June 17 -- Senator Frederick G. Payne was nominated for a second term yesterday by Republicans in the Maine primary.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- Bernard Goldfine, the Boston industrialist, denied in 1951 that he dealt in improper influence during former President Truman's regime.

As the Eighty-fifth Congress moves toward adjournment a reasonable question to ask is, "What's happened to Federal aid to help educate our youth for the space age?" The loud clamor and hand-wringing about America's educational needs which followed the orbiting of Sputnik I last fall has been replaced by seeming complacency and even indifference.
OAK RIDGE, Tenn., June 16 -A radiation incident at the Y-12 plant area here caused a stir, but no panic this afternoon.

A company with a net income of $8.58 from November through June is paying its stockholders a 6 per cent return on their investment.
MOSCOW, Tuesday, June 17 -- Former Premier Imre Nagy and Gen. Pal Maleter, who led the unsuccessful Hungarian revolt in the fall of 1956, have been executed.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Navy received permission today to take the first big step since World War II to match Soviet progress in oceanographic research.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. charged yesterday that the income tax evasion indictment returned against him had been procured in flagrant violation of the law.

TRICOLOR awnings at the southwest corner of Sixtysecond Street and Third Avenue proclaim an unusual new shop as distinctly French. It is Le Buffet Francais, 1048 Third Avenue. There galantines, palets, mousses and other prepared Gallic specialties await the shopper who would like to eat home after a hard day's work but who does not want to do any cooking.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -The Supreme Court declared invalid today a Chicago ordinance that in effect named Parmelee Transportation Company exclusive operator of railroad passenger transfer services in that city.

The strike of marine engineers on passenger and dry-cargo ships in East and Gulf Coast ports continued today despite the quick settlement yesterday of walkouts by seamen and radio operators.

The eleventh annual Blue Grass Ball will be held in the Persian Room of the Plaza on Sept. 25. The dinner dance, a benefit for the Travelers Aid Society of New York, will be sponsored for the fifth time by Elizabeth Arden.

The market price for a membership on the New York Stock Exchange soared yesterday. A seat was sold for $93,000, or $8,000 more than in the last previous sale, which took place on June 10. This was the highest price paid for a seat since Sept. 21, 1956.
Bernard Goldfine's pragmatical union of business, friendship and politicians is described in an exclusive interview appearing today in the June 23 issue of Time magazine.

A new "princess" in the American merchant marine, the Grace Line's $25,000,000 liner Santa Rosa, received a royal New York harbor welcome yesterday when she arrived on her delivery voyage.
LONDON, June 16 -- The Government gloomily conceded tonight that Greece as well as Turkey would reject Britain's plan to associate the two nations with Britain in the administration of Cyprus.
CHICAGO, June 16 (AP) -- Rye and near-by corn contracts rose on the Board of Trade today but other futures were weak under moderate liquidation.

Opponents of the Lincoln Square redevelopment instituted their sixth court suit yesterday in an effort to halt the $205,000,000 project.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Supreme Court held today that a taxpayer dunned for an alleged income-tax deficiency must pay the full amount claimed by the Government before he can challenge the claim in a suit for refund.

The conquest of Mount Everest by the 1953 British expedition has been told by three members of that team, Sir John Hunt, who led the expedition, and by Sir Edmund Hillary and Sherpa Tensing, who scaled the top of the mountain.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 16 -- Government forces began an all-out attack against Indonesian rebel positions in Northern Celebes this morning.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 16 -- Ticonderoga, the seventy-two-foot ketch manned by cadets of the New York State Maritime College, was loafing quietly as the apparent leader today in the Newport to Bermuda Yacht Race.

This is the time of sounds of summer. Early summer, that is; for some summer sounds change from month to month, and even from week to week. Now, for example, is the worried chirping of a mother English sparrow raising a brood (her second) under the eaves of the front porch.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- How Sherman Adams, a professional politician and in most other respects a realist, apparently became insensitive to the dictates off the high official standards he has required of others, and thereby badly injured the man and the cause to which he is supremely devoted, is a question that at this stage of the mystery produces no simple answer.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -Starting next Monday, more than 100,000 New York State workers who have exhausted their unemployment compensation benefits can draw up to $45 a week for thirteen weeks additional.
Bolivia took final steps here yesterday to put into effect a year-old agreement pledging resumption of interest payments on $56,278,000 of dollar bonds that have been in default since 1931.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -The clash between the United Mine Workers and organized medicine on group care moved into a new forum today.
DETROIT, June 16 (AP) -- The auto industry is continuing its measured production program, whittling away at dealer inventories.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- Dr. George Baehr, special medical consultant for the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York, said today that organized medical care programs lent themselves to supervision and control of quality and adequacy, while the "solo practice" of medicine did not.

Commodity futures closed irregularly on the New York exchanges yesterday. Copper, zinc, lead and wool rose; cocoa, potatoes and hides declined, and price movements for sugar, coffee, cottonseed oil and rubber were mixed.
Miss Elfrida Von Nardroff of Brooklyn Heights increased her record-breaking television quiz show winnings to $253,500 last night.
Some $3,000,000 a year in billings of the Mennen Company will move from McCann-Erickson, Inc., on Sept. 15.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- By a vote of 5 to 4 the Supreme Court rejected today a new assault on the Georgia County unit system. This is a method of counting votes that gives rural areas an advantage over cities.
WASHINGTON, June 16--The Senate voted today to continue the non-Communist oath requirement in the Taft-Hartley Law and to extend it to employers. The vote was 66-to-20.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The United States is discreetly urging Turkey and Greece to accept Britain's plan for Cyprus as a basis for negotiations, diplomatic informants said today.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., June 17 -- A carnival atmosphere will prevail at Belvedere, the home here of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Bronfman, from 2 P. M. until midnight on Saturday. On that day members of the Phelps Memorial Hospital Women's Auxiliary will move in with their benefit Hudson Valley Country Fair.
Music can make friends for this country where politicians fail, the two leaders of the New York Philharmonic declared yesterday.

A six-story apartment building and two five-story ones at 340-44-46 East Fourth Street were sold by the Carslyn Realty Corporation to the Barclay Land Corporation, an investing client of Richard S. Hull, attorney.
HARTFORD, June 17 -- Fred R. Zeller, State Controller, won the Republican nomination for Governor at the party's convention today.
A group of wealthy tenants at 25 Sutton Place went down to defeat yesterday in their fight to prevent Stavros Niarchos, their landlord, from starting eviction proceedings against them.
Civil rights decisions of the United States Supreme Court were praised last night by Judge Irwin D. Davidson of the Court of General Sessions.
At the 1955 national Governors Conference in Chicago, most of the forty-eight Governors received the equivalent of a woolen suit, compliments of Bernard Goldfine, industrialist.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Representative F. Edward Hebert, Louisiana Democrat, reported today that none of his Father's Day necktie gifts had been returned.
Mayor Wagner presented medals for heroism yesterday to twenty-one firemen and to the next of kin of eight who died in the line of duty in 1957.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- A prominent Federal Judge proposed today that a new set of lower Federal courts be set up to try personal injury cases.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 17 -- The British Governor of Cyprus urged the people of this island tonight to find a hopeful sign in the last-minute delay in London's new plan for their future.

Wall Street was feeling no pain yesterday. In fact, traders were in a most happy mood as prices rose for the fifth successive day to a new high for the year.

CHICAGO, June 17 (AP) -- Some grain traders are slowly arriving at the conviction that corn is not anywhere near the scarce commodity on the open market that it will be before the new crop is havested.

Hagerty, White House press secretary, relating to statements made in a newspaper column by Drew Pearson, and the text of a statement in reply by Mr. Pearson, issued through Mr. Pearson's office in Washington.

HAWORTH, N. J., June 17 -- Two matches between former champions highlighted the first round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's fifty-fifth annual championship today at the White Beeches Golf and Country Club.

The State Racing Commission gave its blessing yesterday to the new thoroughbred track policy of admitting children to the races when accompanied by parents or guardians. "It has the whole-hearted approval of our three-man commission," Ashley T. Cole, the chairman, said. "I have been agitating for the change for the past year."
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Administration opened its Senate campaign today for more centralized administration of the Pentagon.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- When things get hot and tangled at the White House, the man in greatest demand is likely to be the President's lawyer, Gerald Demuth Morgan. It Was to be expected that when Sherman Adams faced a Congressional investigating committee today, Mr. Morgan would be at his side to help him over the rough spots.

A thin dime believed to be worth more than $3,000 will be auctioned here tomorrow night.

RIDGEWOOD, N. J., June 17 -- The Ridgewood Chorale tonight presented a $30,000 band shell to this village. The 60x30-foot shell, with a 23-foot-high proscenium arch, was dedicated to the memory of Frank Kasschau, director of the women's singing group for many years until his death in 1944.

It is good to learn that plans are progressing rapidly for the forthcoming inventory of park, recreation, watershed and open-space reservations in the New York metropolitan region. Those planning the inventory are the thirty-three members of the Technical Committee on Recreation, all of them park or recreation directors in the region. The technical committee was set up by the Metropolitan Regional Council, of which Mayor Wagner is chairman.

PHILADELPHIA, June 17 (AP) -- A bone chip was removed successfully today from the injured right front leg of Tim Tam, increasing the possibility that the Kentucky Derby and Preakness winner might race again.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI) -- A way to measure the tiniest magnetic forces, which may shed light on the origin of the universe, has been perfected by two Commerce Department scientists, the department announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- "The Education of Sherman Adams," by Bernard Goldfine, reached a typical Washington conclusion in the Old House Office Building this morning. Mr. Adams, the Assistant to the President, pleaded innocent and guilty in the same act.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Prospects for an East-West heads-of-government meeting are fading behind a snowstorm of documents. This was the conclusion today at the State Department, where Secretary of States Dulles evaluated Moscow's publication of Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's letter to President Eisenhower last Wednesday and the publicationby the United States of 5,000 words of previously secret documents.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Senate-House conferees tentatively agreed today on a compromise foreign aid authorization of $3,021,400,000 in new money to operate the Mutual Security program for the fiscal year 1959 that begins July 1.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- Organized labor and organized medicine continued at odds today on the issue of free choice of doctors by members of group health plans.

Registration in New York City has decreased by a net of 7,185 since the last election because of deaths and removals of voters, the Board of Elections reported yesterday.
The State Commission of Investigation yesterday appointed two former assistant United States attorneys to fill key positions.

Youngsters in the Middle East may soon be chewing bubble gum and receiving elementary business training by trading baseball picture cards.

The first step toward legalizing bingo in this city was taken yesterday by the City Council.
Three taxicab drivers were arrested in Brooklyn yesterday on charges of holding up other hackmen. The police quoted them as saying they thought their fellow cab drivers would be easy prey.
The Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts announced yesterday its first gift from beyond the Greater New York area. It was $1,000 from the New Orleans Opera Guild.
A "basic formula" for ending the four-day strike of custodial and maintenance workers at zoos and museums here was announced last night by city and union officials.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- A civil antitrust complaint against Parke, Davis Co., major pharmaceutical producer, was dismissed today in District Court.
LONDON, June 17 -- The belief that the Soviet Union is recoiling from the idea of summit talks and may shortly break off negotiations on the matter is gaining ground in British diplomatic circles.

Sherman Adams concluded his formal statement before the House Subcommittee on Legislative Oversight yesterday with these words: "If * * * I have in any way so conducted myself as to cast any semblance of doubt upon such conduct, I can only say that the error was one of judgment and certainly not of intent."
BERLIN, June 17 -- The major political parties of West Germany united today in marking the fifth anniversary of the unsuccessful revolt in East Germany against Communist leaders.

Retailers were urged yesterday to place greater emphasis on men's furnishings and sportswear departments. These divisions include some of the best-selling and most profitable merchandise, according to Jack Lebowitz, men's sportswear buyer for R. H. Macy Co.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., June 17 -- The fear that newspapers are taking "calculated aim" at television was expressed here yesterday by the president of the National Broadcasting Company.
A two-day blood donation to the Red Cross will begin today at the New York Telephone Company, 11-31 Forty-sixth Road, Long Island City, Queens.

PORTLAND, Me., June 17 -- Senator Frederick G. Payne, Republican seeking a second term, and Gov. Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat seeking elevation to the United States Senate, were in leading roles today for the September election.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) -- House investigators heard today that Bernard Goldfine had made a $400,000 loan to a Boston newspaper, which later endorsed John F. Kennedy for Senator and Paul A. Dever for Governor. Both ran on the Democratic ticket.

On June 30 many residents of the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn and public spirited citizens from other districts of the city will gather at an open hearing before the City Planning Commission to protest the plan of Robert Moses to rip asunder the beautiful Bay Ridge home community with a broad motor expressway extending northward from the proposed Narrows bridge.

Tennis of the sheerest artistry, played at breakneck speed without quarter, provided royal court entertainment for 3,000 under the lights in the Forest Hills Stadium last night as Kenneth Rosewall defeated his fellow Australian, Frank Sedgman, 6 -- 4, 2 -- 6, 6 -- 3.

Bulls and bears among stock market analysts today differ mostly on timing. Nobody looks at the present as the start of a new bull market but hardly anybody agrees with anybody else in dating an eventual decline.
PITTSBURGH, June 17 (AP) -- Ted Kluszewski, Roman Mejias and Bill Virdon blasted triples in the second inning tonight as the Pirates scored five runs and went on to defeat San Francisco, 6 -- 1.

MOSCOW, June 17 -- If Muscovites read their papers with special interest today it was not only the substance of the news but its tone that prompted the interest. The tone was stern but confident on the major counts of Soviet foreign policy: relations with the West and relations with the rest of the Communist camp.

The State Superintendent of Insurance, Julius S. The New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that it hoped to take one of the city sociological trends in stride in a new public housing project in which all apartments would have at least four rooms.

Today's new film is "This Happy Feeling," a Universal-International comedy in Cinema-Scope and color, at the Mayfair (Seventh Avenue and Forty-seventh Street) and the Guild (Fiftieth Street, west of Fifth Avenue). Debbie Reynolds, Curt Jurgens, John Saxon and Alexis Smith have the principal roles.

THE moment of decision could no longer be postponed. No time was left for browsing, sampling and just staring at book jackets. If I didn't make up my mind soon I wouldn't be able to read whatever book I chose and to write a review of it in time for Wednesday's paper. All was quiet in the "Book of the Times" office.

Edward M. Gilbert, a director of Empire Millwork Corporation, and leader of the group that has been buying into E. L. Bruce Company, Memphis, Tenn., hardwood flooring concern, asserted yesterday that he represented "a controlling stock interest."

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The State Department denounced tonight the executions of former Hungarian Premier Imre Nagy and his associates as a "shocking act of cruelty" and put"fundamental responsibility" for the action on the Soviet Union.
CANTALOUPE and strawberries, two fruits now at their best, are teamed by the French chef, Escoffier, in a summer dessert, Fraises Chartreuse.

CAIRO, June 17 -- The United States was reported today to have rejected urgent proposals by President Gamal Abdel Nasser for secret joint action to settle the Lebanese crisis. [In Washington State Department officials said they had no knowledge of such a proposal.]

Harness Racing Commissioner George P. Monaghan will question dissident Yonkers Raceway stockholders today in his investigation of the management's controversial stock-split plan. The hearing will be in his office, 745 Fifth Avenue.

A NEW method of heating and cooling homes by separate room units that are individually installed and controlled is said by the manufacturer to cost about as much as heating or cooling the entire home by a single master unit.

WASHINGTON, June-17 -- The White House said today that President Eisenhower had accepted with thanks enough vicuna material to make a topcoat from Bernard Goldfine, Boston textile magnate and close friend of Sherman Adams.

PARIS, June 17 -- French Foreign Ministry sources expressed concern today over the evidence of a hardening Soviet attitude read into the announcement of the execution of former Hungarian Premier Imre Nagy and seen in the latest Soviet notes to the Western Big Three on negotiations for a summit meeting.
WARSAW, June 17 (AP) -- The 115 musicians of the Philadelphia Orchestra arrived in Warsaw today with loud complaints about the "intolerable run-around" they say they are getting in Poland.

LISBON, Portugal, June 17 -Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar called his Ministers to a special Cabinet meeting tonight to discuss the recent election and its aftermath. The decisions reached were not made public.

LOS ANGELES, June 17 (AP) -- The heavyweight champion, Floyd Patterson, will receive 50 per cent of the gate receipts and the challenger, Roy Harris, a flat $100,000 but the date of their proposed title fight remained a major problem today.
The serious shortage of college physics teachers could imperil the country, the American Institute of Physics warned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Four more states and the District of Columbia have signed up for temporary Federal aid to the long-term unemployed, the Labor Department announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Defense Department proposed today that the unified aviation agency now under consideration be manned by a new career service, similar to the Public Health Service or the Coast Guard.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Representative Francis E. Walter, introduced legislation today to overcome yesterday's Supreme Court decision limiting State Department controls over passports.
New machines are taking the starch out of corn. These have been developed in recent years, during which the hundred-year-old corn refining industry has experienced its greatest mechanical advances.
The Protestant Council of the City of New York is combining worship with close-order drill in an effort to combt juvenile delinquency.

GREENVILLE, Me., June 17 -- This day was a sort of study in transportation as it concerned fishing and bad weather. The results, as collated here tonight, were numb feet, sore muscles, exasperation, ten blueback trout and a big fat brookie. An analysis of results can wait until the Russians make their next move.
The Transit Authority said yesterday that it expected to end the fiscal year with a deficit of "over $10,000,000" -- not $8,500,000 as previously announced.

Along with such seasonal harbingers as second-quarter corporate tax payments and bond club outings, the arrival of student visitors appears to be established as a sure sign of the approach of summer on Wall Street.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Senate passed the Kennedy-Ives labor reform bill tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI) -- The Senate approved tonight a $1,556,220,600 substitute rivers and harbors bill for the one vetoed by President Eisenhower two months ago.
Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas called on educators and the press yesterday to provide leadership in strengthening civil rights.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 17 -- Henry Cabot Lodge denounced today the execution of Imre Nagy and three other leaders of the Hungarian revolt of 1956. The chief United States delegate to the United Nations said that it recalled "the darkest and bloodiest days of Stalin."

WARSAW, June 16 (UPI) -- Poland announced tonight that two scientists and a lawyer would represent the country as the proposed East-West experts conference on nuclear test detection in Geneva next month.
EVERY morning around sunup a giant truck from Piffard, a hamlet near Rochester, N. Y., lumbers into town with a load of bread, some of it baked to ninth-century formula.

All custom smelters quoted refined copper at 26 1/2 cents a pound yesterday. Although some smelters had sold metal at that level late on Monday, the price did not become general until yesterday. It represented a rise of 1/2 cent.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- President Carlos P. Garcia of the Philippines arrived here today for a three-day state visit.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 17 -- Dr. Charles Malik, Lebanese Foreign Minister, declared today that captured Syrian Army officers had admitted that the United Arab Republic had interfered in Lebanon's affairs.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- A "very irritated" President Eisenhower undertook today to find out whether the United States' exhibit at the Brussels fair was as bad as some critics were saying.
PARIS, June 17 -- The Institute of Public Opinion reported today that 54 per cent of the French people unreservedly approved the return to power of Gen. Charles de Gaulle.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 17, (UPI) -- Northern Ireland, Wales and Russia qualified tonight for the quarter-finals of the world soccer championship.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI) -- A member of Congress voiced "dismay" today at the "obvious glee" he said newsmen showed at the difficulties confronting Sherman Adams over gifts.
Thomas J. Curran spiked reports yesterday that he was about to resign as New York County Republican chairman because of ill health.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 17 (UPI) -- The Government radio declared tonight that the execution of former Premier Imre Nagy and three other leaders of the 1956 anti-Communist uprising should serve to "frighten" those who might still plan to smash the Communist regime.

KINGSTON, N. Y., June 17 -- More public housing and slum clearance for private redevelopment are needed to restore the Hudson Valley towns and small cities to their former prosperity, a conference of community officials heard today.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 17 -- The Lebanese Cabinet agreed today that President Camille Chamoun at his discretion might ask for international aid to keep peace in the country. No help has been requested thus far.

The strike of marine engineers on passenger and dry-cargo ships in East and Gulf Coast ports enters the third day today. It was reported that brief negotiations yesterday brought only limited progress toward a settlement.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- A big hole in history will be filled with the publication of all documents pertaining to the ratification of the Constitution and Bill of Rights.
Roles were reversed yesterday as a Waterfront Commission hearing into "phantom" operations on Brooklyn piers was resumed.

Copper, lead and zinc rose in active trading yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. Trading in the metals was influenced by strength in London and rumors that Congress might enact some type of subsidy program for nonferrous metals.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., June 17--Mrs. George Whitney gave a supper dance tonight at her home on Bacon Road to honor two granddaughters, the Misses Hope and Barbara Whitney. It was the first of the debutante parties of the Little Season on the North Shore.

LONDON, June 17 (UPI) -- American men hit a low in the seedings for the Wimbledon tennis tournament today. Barry MacKay of Dayton was the only Yank on the favored list and he barely made it in the No. 8 spot.

Members of the American Guild of Musical Artists last night contributed the music for a free outdoor concert in Washington Square. The event opened New York City's "Salute to Summer" festival. It was sponsored by the Department of Commerce and Public Events.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 17 -- At 3:15 P. M. today a Coast Guard plane homeward bound to Floyd Bennett Field reported by radio that the yawl Good News, manned by a crew of Californians, was eighty-five miles from Bermuda in the race from Newport.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Dr. Martha M. Eliot, former chief of the Children's Bureau, urged today that the ceilings of three Social Security programs administered by the Federal agency be raised to $25,000,000 each annually.

An authorized account of the official engagements of Queen Elizabeth II since her twenty-first birthday on April 21, 1947, has been complied by Brig. Stanley Clark. His aim is to show how diverse, difficult and arduous is the job of the Queen and how she has identified herself with every aspect of life in the British Commonwealth.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 17 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has scheduled as one of its "super" productions for next year a remake of another silent screen classic, "The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse." The original picture, released in 1921, made a star of the late Rudolph Valentino.

LOS ANGELES, June 17 -- The International Brotherhood of Teamsters and the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, tradiditional rivals on the West Coast, have reached an agreement to cooperate.
AJACCIO, Corsica, June 17 (Reuters) -- The police today used tear gas grenades in a fifteen-minute clash with leftwing demonstrators here. Two policemen were slightly injured by stones.
LONDON, June 17 -- Britain today postponed for forty-eight hours the public announcement of her plan for the future of Cyprus.
The Actors Studio released a statement yesterday intended to dispel the confusion created by a rumor that the organization planned to enter the Broadway producing field.
State Supreme Court Justice George A. Arkwright recommended yesterday that thirty-two persons be prosecuted for ambulance chasing in Brooklyn.

A "kitchen hand" who used sixteen Social Security cards and traveled by cab among the boroughs to collect at least $3,000 in unemployment insurance checks under different names made a big mistake Tuesday.
CONCORD, N. H., June 18 (UPI) -- Sherman Adams has traveled the road to fame and power but not to riches.

ALBANY, June 18 -- The New York Central Railroad won permission today to discontinue twenty-three trains on its West Shore Division between Weehawken, N. J., and Albany. The decision by the Public Service Commission means the abandonment of train service between West Haverstraw, N. Y., in Rockland County and Albany.

HAWORTH, N. J., June 18 -Judy Frank of Old Oaks and Mrs. Philip Cudone of Forest Hill, who tied for the qualifying medal on Monday, advanced to the quarter-final round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's fifty-fifth championship today.

LONDON, June 18 -- The Government's decision to grant bigger tax allowances for new plant construction stimulated the stock market today.

The oldest nonprofit medical-surgical insurance organization in the Northeast celebrated its twentieth birthday yesterday with the announcement that it was planning a pioneer project in the psychiatric field.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 18 -- Finisterre, the 38-foot yawl owned by Carleton Mitchell of Annapolis, Md., appeared virtually certain of being declared the winner of her second straight Bermuda trophy for best overall performance in the race from Newport tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- A new method of communication for the deaf-blind, recommended for world-wide use, was disclosed today by Mary E. Switzer, Director of the United States Office of Vocational Rehabilitation.

TRENTON, June 18 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner is considering calling the New Jersey Legislature into special session to complete what he terms "vital unfinished business."
WASHINGTON, June 18 -Some Republican state chairmen described Sherman Adams today as a political liability.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 18 -Lebanese security forces were alerted tonight for a possible rebel effort to seize Beirut's International Airport before the arrival of Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, at dawn tomorrow.

At Belmont Park yesterday the Rice color-bearer demonstrated that it's only the present that counts as he took the $23,350 Shevlin by a length and a half over Ned Brent's Fleet Feet.
The stock market took a breather yesterday after five successive sessions of advance. By and large, it was considered a technical reaction to the recent strength.

The twelfth annual Turf Charity Ball will be held on July 26 in the clubhouse of the Monmouth Park Race Track, Oceanport, N. J. This year the event will take the Brussels World's Fair as its theme.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -Eastern States Petroleum and Chemical Corporation of Houston, Tex., lost its appeal today for a larger oil import allowance.

Without any clear-cut goahead sign, some automobile stocks stepped on the gas yesterday and reached new highs for the year. At the same time the market in general moved lower after five trading days of upswing.
BOSTON, June 18 -- Federal Judge Charles E. Wyzanski Jr. withheld approval today of an offer by Bernard Goldfine to pay $325,000 to settle a stockholders' suit.

DUBLIN, Ireland, June 18 (AP) -- The Cornell and Pennsylvania track and field team got off to a good start tonight in a twoday meet at Dublin's new Santry Stadium. Cornell's Irvin Roberson sped to victory in the 220yard dash in 21.6 seconds.

ELGIN, Ill., June 18 -- Henry M. Margolis of New York asserted today that a dissident group that he leads had enough proxies to elect two directors to the nine-member board of the Elgin National Watch Company.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The payload of the next Vanguard satellite, whose launching is hoped for shortly, has been changed to include instruments that will record X-Rays from the sun. Thus it may help to verify the existence of a gigantic electric current that some authorities believe girdles the earth in space.

An interpretation of events that followed the nationalization of the Suez Canal is given by Michael Adams in his forthcoming book, "Suez and After: Year of Crisis." Mr. Adams, Middle East correspondent for The Manchester Guardian, gives an on-the-spot report from Amman, Damascus, Baghdad and Cairo.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -The president of Victory Carriers, Inc., which faces a shipbuilding contract default suit, testified today that two tanker construction projects had not been canceled.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -George Meany, union labor's chief spokesman, urged today that the House of Representatives "improve" and pass the Kennedy-Ives labor reform bill. The Senate approved it yesterday.

Union leaders got assurance yesterday that both the Democratic and Republican parties were opposed to state "right to work" laws. The assurances were conveyed to a conference on the union shop called by the combined labor movement.

A twenty-seven-year old record was shattered yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The Exchange announced that a short position of 5,795,105 shares existed at the close of business on last Friday.

IT seems to be a roundabout way to operate, but forty-four of America's top athletes will begin a pilgrimage to Moscow this week-end by first taking a gigantic detour to Bakersfield, Calif. That's where the Amateur Athletic Union will conduct its national track and field championships for the usual medals and for some unusual visas.

PARIS, June 18 -- The execution of four leaders of the 1956 Hungarian revolt has produced in France a wave of indignation almost as intense as that provoked by the Soviet Army repression in Budapest twenty months ago.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 18 -Cyprus endured more anxious hours of waiting today while a last-minute attempt was being made to forestall a new explosion over the island's future.
THE news in insect repellents this year is that more and more commercial products are becoming less repellent to people and more repellent to insects.
Specialists at the International Business Machines Corporation have taught an electronic computer to play a polite but aggressive game of chess.

Sales of the American-Marietta Company for the six months ended May 31 reached a record of $105,046,581, but earnings declined to $5,704,496 from $6,332,258 a year earlier, according to the report issued yesterday.

A five-story building containing fifty-nine apartments at 1503-05 Walton Avenue, the Bronx, was sold by Louis Zucker to an investment client of Samuel Shack, attorney. It is on a plot of 120 by 120 feet. The deal was negotiated by Bross Rubin Associates, brokers.
BINGHAMTON, June 18 (AP) -- Governor Harriman sought tonight to refute Republican charges that he had been too free in spending the state's money.

Mary Martin, Victor Borge, Perry Como and Phil Silvers will be among the stars of six special one-hour television programs to be sponsored during the 1958-59 season by the Pontiac Division of the General Motors Corporation.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 18 -- No new foreign concerns or individuals will be permitted to engage in trade between the islands of Indonesia under new regulations issued here today.
DOBBS FERRY, N. Y., June 18 -- School board members campaigning for a $600,000 addition to the public elementary school here have appealed to Cardinal Spellman for aid.
The One-time $7,000,000-ayear institutional advertising program of the General Motors Corporation has become virtually non-existent.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -With a broad grin, President Eisenhower reminded Washington newsmen and women today that some of them had given him heifers for his Gettysburg farm.

Two Socialist party officials were ejected by the police at 5:10 P. M. yesterday from the headquarters of the Soviet Delegation to the United Nations, 680 Park Avenue. They had entered to protest against the executions of former Hungarian leaders.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -The Administration is expected to propose an extra subsidy for small producers of lead and zinc, as part of its plan to subsidize production of four metals.

ALBANY, June 18--The Public, Service Commission granted fare increases today to the Staten Island Rapid Transit Railway Company. Commutation fares will cost 28 to 43 per cent more than present fares. One-way fares, in some cases, will be doubled.
Mayor Wagner says he has given "some thought" to a suggestion of combining the offices of City Administrator and Deputy Mayor. The idea is a bad one.

PITTSBURGH, June 18 (AP) -- Whitey Lockman looped a single to center in the tenth inning tonight to score Bob Schmidt from second as the San Francisco Giants gained a 2-1 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -Senate-House conferees put final approval today on a compromise foreign-aid authorization of $3,021,400,000 in new money for the fiscal year 1959, which starts July 1.

CHICAGO, June 18 (AP) --All grain futures except corn mustered support shortly before the close of the Board of Trade today and closed steady to firm.

CINCINNATI, June 18(AP) -Don Newcombe, with a brilliant six-hit pitching performance, went all the way tonight to his first victory this season, defeating the St. Louis Cardinals, 6 -- 1, in his first appearance as a Cincinnati Redleg.
President Theodor Heuss of the Federal Republic of Germany will arrive at La Guardia Airport at 6:30 P. M. today for a four-day visit.

Copper, lead and zinc futures continued active yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. Lead and zinc were strong, reflecting higher London prices and reports of a stockpiling or subsidy program. Copper declined in what was termed a technical reaction to recent strength.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 18 -- Americans were embattled on several fronts here today. The United States pavilion was bracing itself for defense against mounting criticism from Washington and a private Wild West show and rodeo were fighting to persuade the Belgian Government that its American employes should have labor permits so that scheduled performances could go on.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- The House Rules Committee by a one-vote margin today kept alive a bill that opponents say would cause legal chaos, but that proponents praise as the salvation of state laws.
LONDON, June 18 -- Britain's First Guards Brigade, comprising three of her finest infantry battalions, has been ordered to Cyprus.
Golfers of varying ability find themselves at home on a driving range as well as on a golf course.
WASHINGTON, June 18--President Eisenhower called Sherman Adams an "invaluable public servant" today and said Mr. Adams would stay on the job.

OTTAWA, June 18 -- The Canadian Government set out today to borrow $3,400,000,000. Donald Fleming, Minister of Finance, who told the House of Commons yesterday to expect a deficit of $648,000,000 in the present year, left tonight for Murray Bay, Que., to seek the support of investment dealers holding their annual convention there.
WASHINGTON, June 18--Yugoslav representatives appealed to Pentagon officials today for speedier deliveries of military equipment purchased in the United States.

Arthur Lief, American guest conductor of the Moiseyev Russian ballet now touring the United States, refused to tell a subcommittee of the House Committee on Un-American Activities yesterday whether he was a member of the Communist party.

BERLIN, June 18 -- United States representatives held a third conference today with East German representatives without managing to arrange for the return of nine United States Army men and a helicopter held by the Communist Government.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (UPI) -- Twenty persons asked a Federal court here today for an injunction to stop United States nuclear tests in the Pacific.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -The Administration, for reasons of economy, has drastically curtailed construction of research facilities for the Atomic Energy Commission.
ROCHESTER, June 18 (AP) -- Representatives of business and social agencies spoke out today against a state law to end hiring discrimination against older citizens.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic has rejected United States appeals to halt aid to rebel forces in Lebanon, diplomatic sources said today. According to these sources, Raymond A. Hare, United States Ambassador to Cairo, made the appeals in talks with President Nasser in late May and early June.

The five Democratic county leaders in this city met yesterday for an hour and a half to discuss campaign plans. The meeting was held in Carmine G. De Sapio's office as national committeeman in the Biltmore Hotel.

MINNEAPOLIS, June 18 (AP) -- Attorneys for two former Truman Administration officials convicted for conspiring to defraud the Government in a tax case said today they had new evidence on which to base a new trial.
Trans World Airlines, one of the country's "Big Four" air carriers, announced yesterday that it would lay off 1,000 employes. Executive salaries will also be cut 10 per cent in an economy drive.

The scroll and academic hood of an honorary Doctor of Laws degree were presented yesterday -- eleven years after the conferring of the award by Columbia University -- to General of the Army Douglas MacArthur.
The Iselin-Jefferson Company, Inc., textile concern, has announced a move from Worth Street, long the traditional center of the cotton goods market, to 111 West Fortieth Street.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Five members of the Supreme Court have now decided that Congress never authorized the Secretary of State to restrict the right of a citizen to peacetime "freedom of travel" on the ground that the citizen applying for a passport had refused "to be subjected to inquiry into * * * beliefs and associations," even though the "belief" suspected was in communism, and the "association" was with Communists and was documented.

A drop of 2,784,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end supplies were 190,241,000 barrels, compared with 193,025,000 a week earlier, and 191,317,000 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- (AP) -- The House approved today a compromise bill to authorize $1,500,000,000 of new water projects. It then plunged into an appropriation bill to provide $1,000,000,000 for constructing several similar projects.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Hawaii's bid for statehood ran into ahother indefinite delay in Congress today. It appeared that its chances for a final decision this year had evaporated.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 18 -- A reduction in the number of municipal courts and the establishment of larger, more efficient local courts was recommended today by a Rutgers University expert on government.

NEWARK, June 18 -- A judgment for $621,442 was entered today against the estate of John R. Cooney, former president of the Loyalty Insurance Group.

DARIEN, Conn., June 18 -The Board of Selectmen has established boundary lines for the inner harbor here at 100 yards offshore and has set a speed limit of five miles an hour within these limits.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (UPI) -- The number of persons working full or part time climbed to a record in 1957 as a growing population expanded the labor force. But so did the number of unemployed.

However, by the time Umpire Shag Crawford thumbed out Mayo, the latter had seen more than enough of his team's 3-0 defeat by the Los Angeles Dodgers.
