Y.) who so skillfully piloted its course through the Senate, adjusting it here and there, as better directions were proposed.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- The code of "impeccable" conduct President Eisenhower laid down for his Administration today can not be expected to keep the Democrats from raising a cry of Republican misconduct in the months ahead.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -The long-awaited proposals for tolls on the St. Lawrence Seaway were announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The House of Representatives, by a 345-12 vote, approved today legislation permitting the United States to share nuclear weapons secrets with close military allies. The legislation now goes to the Senate, where it is expected to be approved shortly despite some opposition.
The stock market was hit by a selling wave in the final half hour of trading yesterday.
The liner America became the key element yesterday in a maritime strike that has tied up American-flag passenger and cargo ships on the East and Gulf Coasts.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- By unanimous votes of both houses, Congress expressed deep indignation today at the Soviet "barbarism and perfidy" shown by the execution of Imre Nagy and other Hungarian revolutionary leaders.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 19 -- Brazil's President Juscelino Kubitschek strongly favors holding a conference of the heads of the governments of the Western Hemisphere republics instead of their foreign ministers, according to reports today in diplomatic quarters.
A proposal for merger of the Citizens Bank of Brooklyn into the Federation Bank and Trust Company, Manhattan, has been approved by directors of both institutions, it was announced yesterday.

DETROIT, June 19 (AP) -- Financial circles heard today that Chrysler Corporation was negotiating with a group of banks for a revolving credit line of $125,000,000 to $150,000,000. The credit would be used to finance forthcoming new lines of cars and for other corporate purposes.

Bernard Goldfine said, according to a news story in your issue of June 12, that on some occasions when entertaining Mr. and Mrs. Adams in Boston "the bills have been paid by one of my companies." Would it be fair to assume that bills so paid by a company are written off as a legitimate business expense?

Authorities were investigating last night the slaying of two underworld figures -- one in New York; the other in Boston. The New York police said the shootings had no connection, but noted that both men had been friends of the executed Elmer (Trigger) Burke, notorious gunman.

A big shakeout of speculators in new Treasury issues gave the Government bond market yesterday its most severe setback in months. The sensitive spot in the market was the new 2 5/3 per cent bond due in February, 1965, issued this month in exchange for Treasury debt due in June.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPI) -- The House overwhelmingly approved today an appropriations bill carrying $1,077,827,200 for public works construction in the next fiscal year. It was loaded with funds for projects that President Eisenhower did not request.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., June 19 (AP) -- Ray Senkowski, a 17-year-old junior from Hamtramck, Mich., today won the national scholastic tennis championship with a 7-5, 7-5, 6-2 victory over Frank Froehling, 16-year-old sophomore from Coral Gables (Fla.) High.

Bill Bros. Publications, Inc., publisher of Sales Management, Tide and other magazines, has leased two and one-half floors in the office building nearing completion at 630 Third Avenue at Forty-first Street. The lessee took 25,000 square feet and will consolidate its New York offices in the new building.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., June 19 -- A restored one-room schoolhouse beside the North Avenue cottage of Thomas Paine, the Revolutionary War pamphleteer, was dedicated today.

The aircraft carrier Valley Forge and ten other ships of a Navy anti-submarine task group arrived yesterday for a four-day stay. The Valley Forge docked at Pier 86, Hudson River at West Forty-sixth Street. Eight destroyers and two submarines berthed at the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPI) -- The House voted today to do something about the weather.

The New York Times has taken a consistent position in support of closer regional cooperation among the communities in the New York-New Jersey-Connecticut metropolitan area. An excellently written editorial of June 13 analyzed the proposal for a bi-state transit agency, taking issue with the Metropolitan Regional Council, which had opposed the creation of such an agency.

The Aluminum Company of America (Alcoa) plans to start producing aluminum in two new potlines at its Massena, N. Y., works this fall, completing the first phase of a modernization and expansion program there. A potline is a series of electrolytic production cells.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 19 -- The General Assembly's Special Committee on Hungary will meet Saturday to consider the execution of Imre Nagy and three of his associates in the Hungarian rebellion of 1956.

"Rice," a Japanese-made feature shown at the recent Cannes Film Festival, has been acquired for American distribution by Distributors Corporation of America. The Toei Production, directed by Tadashi Imai and photographed in color, stars Yuko Machizuki, Masaka Nakamura and Shinjiro Ebara. Its dramatic theme contrasts the primitive rural areas and the "Westernized" cities of Japan. The import is scheduled for late summer release.
THE Army may change a man but it takes a woman to change the Army.

TRENTON, June 19 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner signed bills today that raised the state tax on gasoline from 4 to 5 cents a gallon and imposed a new 1 3/4 per cent net-income tax on all corporations in the state.
The New York State Employes Retirement System will finance about half the cost of a $40,000,000 middle-income cooperative apartment development being built in the Howard Beach section of Queens.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Following is the text of the State Department's statement today on the execution of former Hungarian Premier Imre Nagy, as read to reporters by Lincoln White, department press officer:
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The Republican leader in the Senate called on President Eisenhower today to consider carefully whether Sherman Adams had damaged Administration policies for the future.
CHAMBERSBURG, Pa., June 19 (AP) -- Five conferences were created today in the area of the eastern district of the American Lutheran Church in preparation for a scheduled merger.
The earth satellite program is already giving promise of major scientific discoveries, Dr. Joseph Kaplan, United States chairman of the International Geophysical Year, said yesterday.
LONDON, June 19 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of Prime Minister Harold Macmillan's speech to Parliament today as he announced Britain's new plan for Cyprus and the text of the plan:

The grand jury investigating crime in Brooklyn public schools handed up another presentment yesterday. It urged a closer relationship among the police, the courts and school authorities on reports of students' conflicts with the law.
LONDON, June 19 -- Britain offered an "adventure in partnership" to Greece, Turkey and the people of Cyprus today as a solution to the future of that troubled island.

CLEVELAND, June 19 (AP) -- Vice Admiral Lyndon Spencer, president of the Lake Carriers' Association, said today that he was "disappointed at least" in the tolls proposed for the St. Lawrence Seaway yesterday.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 19 (AP) -- Stanford's Jack Douglas upset the first-seeded Ron Holmberg of Tulane, in the National Collegiate tennis championships today, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The involved tanker operations of Aristotle Socrates Onassis were spread on the record again today in a hearing of a special subcommittee of the House's Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee.
RUTHERFORD, N. J., June 19 -- A telephone hook-up from St. Mary's High School here to Hackensack Hospital let two seniors know what was going on at their graduation tonight.

WATERTOWN, Mass., June 19 -- A company that turned to research to stabilize the American canning industry has become the first in its field to help create a graduate fellowship in food technology at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

THE rapid change of the face of New York -- so rapid that even the taxi drivers can't keep up -- is effectively outlined in an exhibition at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- President Eisenhower today postponed decision on stiffer barriers to imports of lead and zinc, while Congress ponders his proposal for subsidizing domestic production of these and other metals.
Here is a cruise long overdue -- on New England's longest and greatest river.

TRENTON, June 19 -- The State Board of Control of Institutions and Agencies declined today to endorse a moratorium on executions pending action by the Legislature on two bills that would outlaw capital punishment.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The House Education and Labor Committee has adopted compromises to bring the $980,000,000 bill to promote science education in line with the views of President Eisenhower.

A State Supreme Court justice denounced labor leaders who "feather their own nests" yesterday when he upheld the right of two locals to secede from the Bakery and Confectionery Workers International Union.
LOS ANGELES, June 19 -- Four suits to block the city's stadium site contract with the Dodgers came to trial in Superior Court today.

SCOTCH PLAINS, N. J., June 19 -- Under a provision of a will dating back to the middle Twenties, more than 2,000 pupils in the kindergarten and the first five grades here received an ice cream treat today.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The United States Court of Appeals here held today that the Veterans Administration had no right to stop a wounded veteran's pension because he had been convicted of conspiring to overthrow the Government by force and violence.
The largest single stockholder in American Motors Corporation has been taking advantage of recent strength in the price of the stock to liquidate his holdings.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The Senate, in a surprise blow to the Eisenhower Administration and Congressional leaders, voted today to repeal Federal taxes on transportation.
ATHENS, June 19 -- The plan for solution of the Cyprus issue, announced in London today, was officially described here as "fundamentally unacceptable."

MOSCOW, June 19 -- An all-Soviet panel of arbitrators rejected today a $2,396,440 damage suit by an Israeli corporation whose contract for oil purchases here was canceled by Soviet agencies after Israel invaded Egypt in 1956.
Max Block ended his fight yesterday against quitting as head of two scandal-scarred locals of the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen here.

The situation in Lebanon seemed to improve slightly yesterday when U. N. Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold stepped out of his plane in Beirut. The rebels were able to turn the shooting off and on and, temporarily at least, they turned it off when the Secretary General arrived.

Five hundred and seventy-two parcels of real estate in Manhattan were sold in the first quarter of this year for considerations amounting to $48,887,271. The figures represent a decline in the number of sales and the dollar volume compared with the similar period of 1957 when 575 properties were disposed of for prices amounting to $66,063,853.

Employes of the Upper Manhattan office. Internal Revenue Service, 484 Lexington Avenue, will give blood to the Red Cross today. Blood will also be collected at the city's Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity in the Municipal Building and at Specialities, Inc., Syosset, L. I.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Senator Kefauver has been taking the floor at every Senate session since June 16 to count off the days before a prospective steel price rise sets in on July 1. His campaign has been similar to the department store ads that count off the shopping days before Christmas.

NEWARK, June 19 -- Newark embarked today on a pilot project in neighborhood rehabilitation and conservation. The program will be carried out citywide with a Federal grant of $115,678 and $57,839 in municipal funds. It is expected to be completed within twenty-one months.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- A toy-sized record player, demonstrated by the Library of Congress today, may make possible a tenfold increase in talking books for the blind.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 19 -- The Sultan of Jogjakarta is expected to be included in the Indonesian Government as a result of Cabinet changes that are likely to be announced this week-end.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 19 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold began talks today with United Nations observers and Lebanese leaders on means to bring peace to Lebanon. He began his task in a moment of special tension. As he arrived by air at 3:15 A. M. all security forces were on a special alert for an expected effort by the rebels seize the airport and other key points as proof of their strength.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower will meet with four Negro leaders at the White House Monday to discuss school integration problems, the White House said today.

THE polls will close on Sunday for candidates to the All-Star teams. But for the first time in a quarter of a century the fans won't do the voting, not even those fans who tenant the press boxes. The job will be done instead by a supposedly more qualified electorate -- the big-league managers, coaches and players.

Teachers and supervisors throughout the city school system have rallied to the financial support of an 84-year-old retired teacher who once was a leader in the fight to improve teachers' salaries and pensions.

BOSTON, June 19 -- One mystery about Bernard Goldfine is why he got involved at all in Securities and Exchange Commission troubles. Another is why it took so long for the S. E. C. to act -- under both the Truman and Eisenhower Administrations.
CHICAGO, June 19 (UPI) -- Research has shown that Salk anti-polio vaccine does not damage the brain, the American Medical Association reported today.
If the city is suffering from a recession, the current sales tax collections -- normally a sensitive barometer of economic conditions -- do not show it.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- A minority report by three Republican members of the Senate Banking Committee signaled a vigorous fight today to cut and remodel the huge Federal housing bill.
CHICAGO, June 19 -- Henry M. Margolis said today he would press immediately for a program to put the company back into the black.
A State Supreme Court Justice ruled yesterday that drivers who fail to answer traffic tickets should not be hired to hand them out to other drivers.

SEOUL, Korea, June 19 (AP) -- Two Cabinet ministers have submitted resignations and three Korean manufacturers are charged with fraud in a scandal over millions of cakes of harmfully adulterated soap bought for South Korea with United States aid funds.
The first big construction contract for the second deck of the George Washington Bridge was let yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.
Ken Rosewall, the former whiz kid from Australia, could have qualified as a tennis quiz kid last night. He had most of the answers as he defeated Rex Hartwig before 5,000 persons at Forest Hills.

An experimental comfort station for dogs was opened yesterday on Ninety-second Street and York Avenue. On hand to see how dogs took to it were Paul R. Screvane, Sanitation Commissioner, and officials of the Mayor's Com mittee to Keep New York City Clean.
QUANTICO, Va., June 19 -- Neil H. McElroy, Secretary of Defense, forecast today further reductions in the nation's combat forces, beyond these already planned.
Braniff International Airways, which celebrates thirty years of aviation today, has proved again the irrepressibility of statisticians on anniversaries.
Consumption and production of newsprint in May continued below year-ago levels, according to trade association reports issued yesterday.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 19 -- Britain's long-awaited program for Cyprus was presented tonight to this Crown colony.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- President Eisenhower received an Indian peace pipe today.

A NEW series called "Confession'' began last night on Channel 7. It brought before the cameras a criminal who had served many years in jail for various offenses. Although the program's announced motives were worthy, some of its sequences were unnecessary and ignoble.
COUNTESS MARA, the tie tycoon, has stepped off her narrow strip of haberdashery to venture into the wider world of shirts, socks and jewelry.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The Defense Department said today it planned to have in operation by the end of the year a radio-radar network that could detect even a silent satellite passing over the United States.

President Theodor Heuss of West Germany, who has been in this country since June 4, arrived at the Marine Air Terminal of La Guardia Airport early last night. He will be in New York until Monday morning, when he will sail for home.

BERLIN, June 19 -- Gen. Henry I. Hades, commander of United States Army forces in Europe, sent a new request tonight to the Soviet commander in East Germany for the return of nine American soldiers held there by Communist authorities.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The combination of Iraq and Jordan is officially known as the "Arab Union," not "Arab Federation," diplomats of the two nations explained today.

The fifth annual "New York Is a Summer Festival" season began yesterday, launched with the city's blessing through Mayor Wagner and with the pomp and ceremony of promotional flourish. The festival, which frankly goes out to recruit the prospective vacation visitor, betrays the self-assurance of success now. Statistics have proved that it works, and to the benefit of almost everybody.
"Derringer," a series that will be more of a "Southern" than a Western, has been assigned to Columbia Broadcasting System television's Thursday night schedule, starting next season.
DETROIT, June 20 (AP) -- The Chrysler Corporation announced today it was arranging a credit of $150,000,000. The move was rumored in financial circles yesterday.

If anybody could design a fair exhibit that would please all men then the millennium would be achieved, or the utmost in regimentation of thinking. Surely the anonymous business man whose letter is quoted in The Times of June 18 is entitled to denigrate the United States exhibit at Brussels, but the gentleman's selectivity and therefore his omissions should be weighed before arriving at a judgment.

The Graduate School of Banking, Rutgers University, graduated 287 members yesterday in its twenty-second class. The school is conducted on the New Brunswick, N. J., campus by the American Bankers Association in cooperation with the university.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The United States disclosed today that Canada had been added to the list of Western countries that would furnish experts for technical talks with the Soviet bloc on policing a nuclear test suspension.
Cocoa futures on the New York Cocoa Exchange fell the daily limit of 100 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on all contracts yesterday.
At least $20,000 in cash is missing from the Property Clerk's office in the Police Department.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Two members of the Eisenhower Cabinet went before the Senate Finance Committee today to urge a five-year extension of the Reciprocal Trade Program.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- New evidence of the extraordinary measures adopted by the Administration to force its version of a Pentagon reorganization bill through Congress came to light today.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved narrowly yesterday to close unchanged to 4 points lower. The decline equaled 20 cents a bale.

District Attorney Edward S. Silver's staff began yesterday the screening of testimony taken during the Brooklyn ambulance-chasing inquiry. Witnesses will be called to testify before a special grand jury next week.
Julius Manger Jr., chairman of the Manger Hotels, is a firm believer in big families -- at home and in his hotels.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 20 -- Del Miller, the squire of Meadowlands Farm, continued his virtual monopoly of the rich events at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. His Meadow Maid captured the $33,050 Devotion Pace.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., June 20 (AP) -- James C. Hagerty, White House press secretary and his wife were given a five-day stay at the Ponte Vedra Inn last year.
THE collection of bridal gowns Stem's is as traditional as rice and blue garters.

LONDON, June 20 (AP) -- Margaret Varner, an El Paso, Tex., physical education instructor well known as a badminton player, gained the women's singles final today in the Queen's Club tennis tournament.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Suburban and rural legislators today were called the main obstacles toward a sound governmental approach to problems of metropolitan areas.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 20 -- Relations and understanding between Indonesia and the United States are "improving," Maj. Gen. Abdul Haris Nasution said here today.

HAWORTH, N. J., June 20 -- For the second year in a row, Judy Frank of Old Oaks and Mrs. Philip Cudone of the Forest Hill Field Club, will meet in the thirty-six hole final of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship.

Directors of U. S. Industries, Inc. deferred dividend action normally due at this time yesterday on the common stock. The company paid 1 per cent in stock in April and 15 cents in March. Last Dec. 1 a stock dividend of 1 per cent and 15 cents in cash was disbursed, prior to which 25 cents quarterly was distributed.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Thanks to a submarine officer, Navy men can now ride from ship to ship in a boatswain's chair without danger of being drowned if the line should break. Lieut. Comdr. C. Danield Summitt received a patent for a safer chair this week.
TOKYO, June 20 -- Japan's recent conciliatory gestures toward Communist China received what amounted to a delayed rebuff today.
Rear Admiral John S. Thach, commander of the Navy's new anti-submarine Task Group Alpha, warned yesterday that the United States must be as alert to attack from the sea as from the air.
LOS ANGELES, June 20 -- An array of city officials testified in Superior Court today in a case aimed at blocking a grant of land to the Dodgers for a baseball park.
LONDON, June 20 (Reuters) -- New Zealand was all out for 47 runs today and forced to follow on 222 runs behind England in the second day of the second test match at Lords.

TODAY "Shop Talk", is aimed toward the only potential readers who can't talk back -- babies. Stores are full of presents to make their lives cheerier from the beginning, and in some cases, these gifts can ease a new mother's load.
The Public Service Commission heard an appeal yesterday by the Erie Railroad Company for permission to cut service in off-commuter hours and on holidays and week-ends.
DUBLIN, Ireland, June 20 (AP) -- Ron Delany, fresh from graduation at Villanova, ran an easy mile on a rain-soaked track at Santry Stadium tonight in 4:12.5.
WARSAW, June 20 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Orchestra completed its tour of Poland with a concert tonight in the 4,000-seat Palace of Culture.

The report of Joseph E. Seagram Sons, Inc., distillers, and its subsidiaries, including those not wholly owned, disclosed yesterday a net profit of $11,262,000 for the nine months ended April 30. This is after all charges, and $11,500,000 for taxes.

Like bird watchers suddenly rewarded for a long wait, students of the money market are resting happier today. For some months they have been puzzled by the fact that, contrary to theory, easier money had brought no appreciable drop in the turnover of money.
STRATFORD, Conn., June 20 -- They have captured everything except the greatness in "Hamlet," which was acted last evening in the American Shakespeare Festival Theatre.

ALBANY, Ga., June 20 (UPI) -- The Rev. Clennon King, Negro educator who fled his home state of Mississippi "for my own safety." vowed today to return regardless of any action that may be taken against him by authorities.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- President Eisenhower, paying a surprise visit to George Washington's home at Mount Vernon, Va., today quipped about a sword Washington had received as a gift: "Do you suppose they investigated him for getting a present?" He pointed toward an ornate sword given to the first President by Theophilus Alte, a German admirer.
PITTSBURGH, June 20 (AP) -- George Witt, recalled by the Pittsburgh Pirates from Columbus last Sunday, stopped the Los Angeles Dodgers, 2 -- 1, tonight on six hits for his first major league victory.

On the surface, the latest meeting of the Central Committee of the Soviet Communist party in Moscow was a placid event. The farm-price reforms outlined by Khrushchev last March were adopted after he had given a report on them, and two recent arrivals in the ranks of the Soviet elite were made alternate members of the Presidium.

Steel industry observers continued to seek grounds yesterday for forecasting whether steel prices would be raised on July 1. But nobody appeared to be turning up much convincing evidence one way or another.

Stockholders of the Bell Aircraft Corporation at the company's annual meeting held yesterday in Buffalo approved a mortgage loan of $3,500,000 to finance two building programs at the company's main Wheatfield plant near Buffalo and at its Bell Helicopter Corporation's main plant near Fort Worth, Texas.

SYRACUSE, June 20 -- Fifty-eight years after it last won the championship, Pennsylvania hopes to lead home nine other varsity eight-oared crews over a three-mile course on Onondaga Lake here tomorrow in the fifty-sixth regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association.
Eighteen thousand millinery workers, who were to begin an industry-wide two-week vacation period Monday, will instead take their holidays on a plant-by-plant basis.

The Eaton Manufacturing Company, Cleveland manufacturer of parts and equipment for the automobile, aircraft, farm implement, machine tool and other fields, plans to acquire the Fuller Manufacturing Company of Kalamazoo, Mich. Fuller makes transmissions, axles and clutches for autos and farm equipment.
GENEVA, June 20 -- The International Labor Organization was invited today to send fact-finding teams to investigate trade union freedom in the United States.

ANDOVER, N. H., June 20 -- Hopkins Pond is really Adder Pond, and it is not a pond but a great pond. It is Adder Pond on United States geological maps, but Hopkins Pond to people around here who know better because a man named Hopkins used to own it.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., June 20 -- Two parties were given tonight at country homes to present young women to society in the Long Island Little Season before they go to college and return for the formal introductions during the Christmas holidays.
Herbert Bayard Swope, one of the great reporters, and editors in this country a generation ago, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital. His age was 76.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The United States agreed today to lend up to $125,000,000 to the Philippines.
ANKARA, June 20 -- Ankara relaxed a bit today from its ferment over the Cyprus issue.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Following is the text of a joint United States-Philippines statement issued at the White House today at the end of the visit of President Carlos P. Garcia:

The nation's railroads have only started cutting back their costs hard, if some of their estimates to the Interstate Commerce Commission prove accurate. One hundred and ten big systems have given the I. C. C. estimates that their gross capital expenditures for additions and betterments to their roadway and equipment for 1958 will be $706,350,000.

QUANTICO, Va., June 20 -- President Eisenhower continued his campaign for Pentagon, reorganization today before 170 military and Government leaders who are here for top-secret national defense discussions.

A Park Department official said yesterday that no steps were being taken to cancel the appearance of the Shakespearean Festival Company at Central Park because of its producer's involvement with a Congressional investigating committee.
Three hundred yachts will be blessed by clergymen of three faiths tomorrow as they sail past Steeplechase Pier, Coney Island. The clergymen will be aboard a yacht 300 feet off the pier.
A persistent rain pelted President Theodor Heuss of West Germany at ceremonies yesterday officially welcoming him to New York.
A working model of a thermionic converter -- a device that produces electricity from heat -- has been developed by the General Electric Company's research laboratory in Schenectady.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 20 -- President Juscelino Kubitschek declared tonight that an inter-American conference "on the highest political level of the continent" was required to seek solutions for the "disease of under-development."

PARIS, June 20 -- Jacques Soustelle, a principal architect of the dissident movement in Algeria, said today that the "authentic and profound" reconciliation of the Moslem and European populations there was a dominant factor in the search for a solution of the Algerian problem.
Stocks came back smartly yesterday after the big selling wave late Thursday, This time -- unlike Thursday -- there was little surprise among professional and not-so-professional observers.

LE MANS, France, June 20 -- The astonishing thing about twenty-four-hour race, a world championship event for sports cars which begins here tomorrow afternoon, is that it has become the most celebrated auto race of them all.
A little - known Brooklyn freight railroad, covering only seven blocks along the East River waterfront, asked the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday for permission to abandon operations.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals ruled today that the Civil Aeronautics Board had no authority to regulate depreciation charges of air carriers except by adjusting or disallowing them in rate-making.
LOS ANGELES, June 20 -- A Navy doctor suggested today that undue concern with emotional factors could hamper man's venture into new realms of space.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Senate passed without dissent today a bill to continue some wartime tax rates but to repeal all Federal transportation taxes.
HANOVER, N. J., June 20 -- The high school teacher whose class stirred a controversy by some essays critical of the atomic bombing of Hiroshima has decided to adhere to her original decision to quit.

DENISON, Tex., June 20 (AP) -- A multi-million-dollar plant, said to be the first in the United States capable of continuous, automatic manufacture of asbestos-cement pipe, was dedicated by Johns-Manvile Corporation officials here today.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 20 -- The commander of Czechoslovakia's Army Political School complained today that young recruits were not showing proper interest in joining the Communist party.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- For the first time since late April, statistics for the unemployment compensation system failed to show a marked improvement this week.
WESTPORT, Conn., June 20 -- The Oak Ridge Farms worn the open jumper event in today's session of the Fairfield County Hunt Club horse show, with Acapulco.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- The Court of Military Appeals today outlawed all sentences of solitary confinement for servicemen.

BONN, Germany, June 20 -- The tenth anniversary of the West German currency reform was celebrated today. Full credit was given to the United States for having put West Germany on the road to recovery and prosperity.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- For the last eleven months more than 10,000 scientists in sixty-six nations have been giving the earth a physical examination.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Bernard Goldfine agreed today to testify July 1 before Congressional investigators.

Widespread concern on the part of citizens and professionals with the problem of juvenile delinquency in New York City leads me to believe that your readers may not be aware of a source of knowledge and information.
NEWARK, June 20 -- Users of public telephones may soon come face to face with a new style of instrument. It is different in both appearance and tone.

Former State Senator Julius A. Archibald was sworn in yesterday as New York's first Negro deputy county clerk. At the ceremony speakers hailed the Democratic party for its efforts in behalf of Negro rights.
RIO DE JANEIRO, June 20 -- Brazil expects to receive shortly loans, credits and refinancing totaling $424,000,000.
RANGOON, Burma, June 20 -- Premier U Nu said here today that because of the thin majorit held by the Government of Burma there would have to be national elections soon.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 20 -- George V. Allen, United States nformation Agency director and President Eisenhower's emissary to look over the United States showing at the Brussels World's' Fair, declined today to make comparisons between the American and Russian pavilions.
CAPE CANAVERAL, June 20 -- The Navy postponed early today its third attempt to launch a fully instrumented satellite.
American maritime labor has scored a major break-through in an area that heretofore has been virtually immune from union organization.

As an item of news the moon keeps recurring with the stubborn persistence of a repeating decimal. According to a recent statement by V. V. Dobronarov, a Soviet professor of physics, the moon, itself a satellite, will soon have a satellite of its own.

The Goldman Band, rained out Wednesday evening in what was to have been its opening outdoor concert of the season, played last night on the Mall in Central Park. Richard Franko Goldman conducted the performance, which opened the forty-first season of concerts presented in memory of Daniel and Florence Guggenheim.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 20 -- Nationalist China's Congress, the Legislative Yuan, completed adoption of a new press law today after two months of dispute between independent newspapers and the Government over the constitutionality of the measure.
Three men who were convicted of manslaughter in the deaths of two persons by wood alcohol poisoning were sentenced to prison terms yesterday in Bronx County Court.

BROOKLINE, Mass., June 20 (AP) -- Middle States, the defending champion, and New England won first-round matches today in the thirty-second annual Sears Cup tennis competition at the Longwood Cricket Club.

LONDON, June 20 -- The big double-deck red buses reappeared on the streets of London tonight after an absence of nearly seven weeks. The end of the strike of 50,000 busmen was signaled by resumption in part of the all-night services.

The result of a recent court decision is that New York City sales taxes are collected on Federal excise taxes, as well as on the actual cost of goods sold. This decision seems to have been made without any great deal of public awareness. Nor does there seem to be any great objection to this double taxation.
Thirty-five youthful dancers from the Philippines -- some of whom are playing hooky from school -- are traveling to places that were only names to them a little while ago.

PARIS, June 20 -- The fortress most menaced by General de Gaulle is a squat stone building situated on the verge of Paris' financial district. Perhaps aware of an incongruous location, it is carefully fitted with heavy doors and interior barriers of wire network.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The United States demanded tonight that the Soviet Union take "immediate action" to obtain the release of nine United States soldiers being held by East Germany. The demand was made at a half-hour meeting between Robert Murphy, Deputy Under Secretary of State, and Sergei R. Striganov, Soviet counselor.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 20 -- The International League for the Rights of Man asked today that Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold make a personal investigation of the proceedings against Povl Bang-Jensen, suspended United Nations official.
NEWARK, June 20 -- Essex County's Juvenile Court reported today that there had been a "slight decrease" in its caseload last year.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 20 -- The Yugoslav Government will protest the secret trial and execution of Imre Nagy, Hungary's revolutionary Premier, as a breach of faith.
Building Commissioner Bernard J. Gillroy announced yesterday that he had sent Mayor Wagner his resignation, to become effective Sept. 1.
TUNIS, June 20 -- The Governments of Morocco and Tunisia joined the Algerian insurgents tonight in condemning the policy of integration advocated by the Public Safety movement in Algeria.
PITTSBURG, June 20 (AP) -- A $1,000,000 libel suit -- the second in two days -- was filed today against David J. McDonald president of the United Steelworkers of America.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- Carpeting will continue to hold the floor in decorating schemes with its new patterns and colors as well as practical improvements, judging from the new collections being shown here.

MOSCOW, June 20 -- Moscow seemed convinced today that something momentous was happening to Soviet agriculture, but no one was able to assess fully Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's "new order" for the farms.

PHILADELPHIA, June 20 -- Entering the last of the ninth tonight, the Phillies and Giants were tied. Before long, Bill Rigney, the San Francisco manager, was fit to be, as he watched Ruben Gomez, with the bases loaded, walk Harry Anderson and force over the run that gave the home club a 5-4 victory.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission today authorized Eastern Air Lines to take part in the reopened hearings on Miami's TV Channel 10.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 20 -- Diplomatic circles here tonight heard reports that Dag Hammarskjold, United Nations Secretary General, had advised Lebanon against an immediate request for military assistance from the United States in Lebanon's quarrel with the United Arab Republic.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Federal buying of lead and zinc was demanded by a Senator today as a congressional hearing into various proposals to aid the mining industry ended.
Two stowaways who said their deed was inadvertent returned from France yesterday, disillusioned with travel.
The seventy - eight - foot Norwegian ship The Vikings reported in a radio message from sea yesterday that she was making good time toward New York.

One of the American educators who returned last week from a survey of the Soviet Union's school system commented that "I don't care what the Russians are doing -- I am worried about what we are doing."
DETROIT, June 20 (AP) -- Motor vehicle output this week in United States plants will be 81,359 cars and 17,026 trucks, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.
The Senate has voted down a temporary tax reduction proposal offered by Senator Paul Douglas and involving an estimated $6 billion in revenue.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 20 (AP) -- A few facts about the executions of former Premier Imre Nagy and his aides became known today but most of the details were still a mystery.

FANTASY wallpaper has been dreamed up by a company that usually designs props for department store display. The collection, called Etcetera Wallpapers, is now available through decorators at Resident Display, Inc., 155 Waverly Place. Prices range from $6 to $15 a roll.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Attorney General Rogers today announced a civil antitrust judgment against American Type Founders Company of Elizabeth, N. J., prohibiting any agreements on a division of markets for printing presses and equipment.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The Federal pay rise bill signed by the President today can be traced in more than one way to William Charles Doherty, who was nominated by a columnist recently as "Champion Lobbyist of Washington."

The six-story apartment house at 1725 Emmons Avenue, at Sheepshead Bay Road in Brooklyn has been sold by the Kassin Realty Corporation, which erected the building in 1929. The property is 167 by 97 feet and contains eighty-nine apartments and twelve stores.
Among the eight plays that he will be putting on this season at the John Drew Theatre in East Hampton. L. I., Ron Rawson has one aimed for Broadway and two for Off Broadway.
The largest single shift of Correction Department personnel in the last four years -- the period covering the administration of Commissioner Anna M. Kross -- was announced yesterday.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 20 (AP) -- Silky Sullivan returned in defeat today to the track where he won his first race many heart throbs ago. The big chestnut bay finished eighth in the $10,000 Hollywood Park feature, which was won by Warner Ranch's Aliwar.

OCEANPORT, T. J., June 20 (AP) -- Jerry Truman and Thomas Reggie Root were involved in spills today at Monmouth Park. Howard Grant, who rode Fifinella Miss, a $6.60-for-$2 chance, to victory in the featured fourth race, was suspended ten days, effective next Monday, by the stewards.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 20 (AP) -- Circuit Judge Walter B. Jones refused today to disqualify himself from hearing a contempt case against the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

President Carlos P. Garcia of the Philippines will arrive here tonight for three full days of activity. A ticker-tape parade will be held Monday along lower Broadway from the Battery to City Hall, where he will receive the city's official welcome from Mayor Wagner.
DETROIT, June 20 -- The Tigers continued their amazing mastery over Casey Stengel's front-running Yankees tonight.
A wide survey of the business methods and administration of the Board of Education will get started next week by City Administrator Charles F. Preusse.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 20 -- The twenty-first Newport-to-Bermuda yacht race finally was settled lake today when the committee of the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club ended its wrestling with the order-of-finish problem.

A CITY reader who asked where whole goose livers could be purchased will find them at Paprikas Weiss, 1504 Second Avenue, near Seventy-eighth Street. The livers, which are cooked and canned, are available in four sizes, ranging from a six-ounce tin for $4.50 to a one-pound twelve-ounce tin for $15.

Rain postponed last night's scheduled session of the round-robin professional tennis tournament at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens. As a result, the tournament, which was to have ended tomorrow afternoon, will conclude on Monday night.
LONDON, June 20 -- The volume on the stock market declined today but the price advance continued. However, gains were mostly small and many share groups had a good sprinkling of falls.
THE Columbia Broadcasting System performed a real public service yesterday by devoting a half-hour of its desirable evening time to a televised study in depth of the Hungarian tragedy.
PORT JEFFERSON, L. I., June 20 -- The ferry service across Long Island Sound from here, suspended last Monday because of a labor dispute, was resumed this afternoon.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 20 -- The weary people of Cyprus relaxed a little today and waited to see what the Greek and Turkish Governments would do about the new British plan for the island.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The index of average wholesale prices in primary markets rose 0.2 per cent to 119.0 per cent of its 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

NEWARK, N. J., June 20 (AP) -- A $5,000,000 damage suit has been filed against American Can Company and Metal and Thermit Corporation. The suit was filed in Federal Court here by Alexander Rogers of Anne Arundel County, Md., under the Clayton Anti-Trust Law.

He was one of the best-known newspaper men of our time, and although retired from the reporter's pursuit of news and the editor's direction of it for nearly thirty years, Herbert Bayard Swope of The World was the identity that recalls the memories on this day. He rode through life with a flourish of zest known to everybody, knowing everybody.

DARIEN, Conn., June 20 -- Plans for a $3,000,000 high school, the construction of which was held up for two town referendums, were approved last night by the Darien school building and planning committee.

A plot of land on the south side of Merrick Road, east of South Park Avenue, Rockville Centre, L. I., has been purchased by Harold Lewis, a shopping center builder. It will be improved with stores from plans by Wechsler Schimenti, architects.

Twenty-one stories by four new American writers will be published by Scribner in "Short Story 1" in September. The writers, chosen from among 228 who submitted almost 3,000 stories, are Richard Yates, Gina Berriault, B. L. Barrett and Seymour Epstein.

SYRACUSE, June 20 (UPI) -- Mike De John of Syracuse, apparently beaten midway in the fight, got his "second wind" and went on to win a unanimous ten-round decision over Bob Baker of Pittsburgh at War Memorial Auditorium tonight.

"So ended two of the richest, happiest years of my life," Carleton Beals writes on the last page of his fond, nostalgic and engaging memoir, "House in Mexico."* The house was in Coyoacan, then a somewhat sleepier suburb of Mexico City than it is today. The time, as near as I can make out, was at least thirty years ago, when a fresh tide of American interest in Mexico was rising.

WAUSAU, Wis., June 20 (AP) -- A Federal District judge found today that "paper transactions" of millions of pounds of surplus cheese in 1954 had been illegal. He ordered eight companies to repay $1,300,000 in so-called windfall profits to the Government.
ROME, June 20 (AP) -- Pope Pius XII today named Gregory Peter Cardinal Agagianian a member of the Congregation of the Holy Office, high governing body of the Roman Catholic Church.
MOSCOW, June 20 -- Several hundred Russians marched on the Danish Embassy this afternoon, smashed seven windows with stones and smeared slogans across its ochre facade with black paint.

BONN, Germany, June 20 -- West German and Hungarian demonstrators clashed with policemen tonight near Bonn, and in Munich during demonstrations against the Nagy executions. In Cologne, Hungarian and West German students rallied on a public square demanding "freedom and justice" for Hungary.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Senator J. William Fulbright said today that "aimless and feeble" Administration leadership and inertia on foreign policy were endangering world peace and Western security.

A policeman and two companions were arrested early this morning and charged with assault and robbery. They are accused of hitting a 75-year-old man over the head in his Lower East Side apartment and taking $361 from him.
Religious policies will be considered at two major meetings scheduled in the Midwest next week.

PITTSBURGH, June 20 (AP) -- District Judge Wallace S. Gourley today rejected a petition by a Penn-Texas Corporation stockholder to postpone a scheduled meeting of the board scheduled for Monday.

ALBANY, June 20 -- Charles Abrams, chairman of the State Commission Against Discrimination, said today that rules interpreting the new age provisions of the state's anti-discrimination laws would be made public by next Tuesday or Wednesday.

Alanesian and Willie Boland combined to stop Eddie Arcaro at Belmont Park yesterday. The crowd of 16,075 made Alanesian the favorite in the feature race, despite the fact that Master Eddie had won the three races immediately preceding the mileand-a-sixteenth event for fillies and mares.

CHICAGO, June 20 (AP) -- A fairly good demand, mostly by speculative traders, lifted all grain futures prices to levels equal to or higher than the previous closes on the Board of Trade today. Early dealings were mixed.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 20 -- Forestry areas of the Soviet Union cover about 1,700,000,000 acres. Vasiliev, Deputy Director of the Forestry Institute of the Soviet Academy of Sciences.

TEL AVIV, Israel, June 20 -- Israel has made a gesture to ease tension on Mount Scopus on the eve of a mediation visit by Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold of the United Nations.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 20 -- The Scala tonight presented the loudest "Tosca" in this reviewer's experience. CONCORD, N. H. -- All through the summer motorists driving through New Hampshire should be watching the signs in stores, newspapers and post offices for country auctions. Three narcotics squad detectives and a lawyer were arrested yesterday on charges of attempting to extort $1,500 from an electronics equipment salesman.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -The Administration and Congress took major steps this week toward internationalizing the atomic secrets that for so long have been regarded as a priceless national hoard.

Herb Elliott of Australia bettered the recognized world record for the one-mile run with a clocking of 3:57.9 at the National Amateur Athletic Union meet in Bakersfield, Calif., last night. Merv Lincoln of Australia was second as John Landy's mark of 3:58 was beaten the third time.
WASHINGTON, June 21 -Alaska's forty-two-year bid for admittance to the Union is scheduled for a showdown in the Senate next week.

PITTSBURGH, June 21 -- The Pittsburgh Pirates staged a sixrun rally in the fifth inning today and battered six Los Angeles pitchers for a total of fifteen hits and an 11-7 victory in the longest game at Forbes Field this season.

THE long series of divergent accounts of the crucial moments of the 1932 Democratic convention has most recently been augmented by John J. O'Connor's letter which appeared in the Book Review. On several important points Mr. O'Connor's recollection is in sharp conflict with memoranda and letters from eyewitnesses collected by my grandfather, William Gibbs McAdoo, copies of which I now possess.
BRESCIA, Italy, June 21 -The new, "safe-formula" Mille Miglia auto race claimed two victims today less than ten miles after the starting.

Cities and towns that have been dawdling over slum-clearance plans for which Federal funds have been earmarked are being warned by the Government that the aid will be withdrawn unless they move quickly.
MY wife and daughter like horses. We three belong to the tourist minority that enjoys such simple pleasures as visiting training tracks and horse barns.

THE game of bridge is unique among games in in several respects, but nowhere more so than in its "peculiar institution," the existence and practice of the professional bridge teacher. It would be incredible that anyone could hang out a shingle and earn a livelihood teaching rummy or poker or pinochle or even chess, but every larger community has its bridge teacher and a major metropolis has its dozens.

RUSSIA'S towering eighteenth-century poet-author, Alexander Pushkin, appears to have gripped the imagination of more than one moviemaker. As has been previously noted, the Italian company headed by Dine De Laurentiis currently is shooting "The Tempest,', which is based on Pushkin's "The Captain's Daughter," and, last week, it was learned that Harry Belafonte, who has added independent movie production to his singing and acting chores, now plans to film a biography of Pushkin.
BROOKLINE, Mass., June 21 (AP) -- New England won the Sears Cup today with a 6-3 triumph over Middle States in the thirty-second competition for the women's team tennis trophy.
Proposals for transit charges on the new St. Lawrence Seaway are receiving a mixed reception among shipping and industrial interests in this country and Canada.
SYRACUSE, June 21 -- Hail, all hail Cornell, not quite the champion of all as a year ago, but never greater than today in all the history of its unsurpassed rowing tradition.

A New York longshoreman has asked the United States Supreme Court to uphold his right to sue for injuries sustained on the pob. He is seeking a larger sum than the compensation award allowed under the Longshoremen's and Harbor Workers' Act.
DENVER, June 21 -- A pilot program for a national study of cancer symptoms and heredity has been approved by directors of the American Cancer Society. It will take five years.
WARSAW, June 21 -- Poland has refused to join in the Soviet bloc's excoriating of Imre Nagy since he was put to death.
DETROIT, June 21 -- The automobile industry is on the threshold of extended shutdowns for model change-overs but still is not sure whether it will have old or new labor contracts in the fall.

KINGSTON, N. Y., June 21 -- Bernard Tompkins, special prosecutor, announced yesterday that the state had screened prospective members of a grand jury that will investigate alleged kickbacks in Ulster County purchases.
ARCADIA, Fla. -- Rip-roaring rodeos are as much a part of the July Fourth tradition as fireworks here in the cattle country of central Florida.

CONCORD, N. H., June 21 -- New Hampshire has taken a good deal of pressure off stream fishing for trout by an intelligent program of improving pond fishing. Other Eastern states might well take note of it.

BALTIMORE -- Recent visitors to Fort McHenry, on Whetstone Point just out of Baltimore, may have glimpsed the fact-hunting team which is presently at work in connection with the National Park Service's Mission 66, unearthing old walls and battlements at the fort, long buried from sight and memory.

ERICH MARIA REMARQUE'S name is one that conjures in the public mind the hollow-eyed and haunted face of war's desperate futility. From his "All Quiet on the Western Front" thirty years ago to "A Time to Love and a Time to Die," which will have its dual premiere at the Mayfair and Little Carnegie Theatres on July 7, his single articulated theme echoes like a lost exhortation to peace on the loud winds of war.

"WHY don't you do something about the spate of depressing plays from Europe?" a truculent reader inquires. The question makes two false assumptions: one, that this department has either the authority or the power to do something about them; two, that this department does not approve of them.

WASHINGTON, June 21--Lawsuits, constitutional reform and political alliances with the suburbs were proposed today as ways in which cities might break the headlock that rural areas have on Legislatures across the nation.

Children's work on samplers -- the quaint and colorful embroideries that once taught the young the art of needlework and their ABC's -- will be on summer-long exhibition beginning tomorrow, in the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 21 -The Ellen Ann II, flying the colors of the New York Athletic Club, scored a triple victory today in the first annual predicted log cruiser contest against twenty-one other craft over a course from Atlantic Highlands to the Atlantic City State marina.
David Sarnoff's article brings to mind a story that is told about the campaign of 1888 when Benjamin Harrison ran against Grover Cleveland.
TEL AVIV, Israel, June 21 -Dag Hammarskjold interrupted his efforts to halt the Lebanese civil war today and turned his attention to the friction between Israel and Jordan over Mount Scopus.
MEXICO CITY, June 21 -- An election campaign marked previously by apathy is entering its final stages in increasing bitterness.
The B. T. Babbitt Company's coupon promotion with the Transit Authority has projected this time-tested marketing aid into the business spotlight.
A SATURDAY REVIEW cartoon pictured a caveman as saying to himself when a certain cavewoman passed by: "She makes me want to write something that sounds the same at the end of the lines."

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., June 21--Mr. and Mrs AlastairBradley AIartin of Guennol, Glen Head, and Mr. and Airs. G. Montagu A{iller of Afill River Road, Oyster Bay, gave a supper dance tonight at the Piping Rock Club to honor their debutante daughters, the Iisses Dorothy Bradley lVlartln and Wendell E. AiRier.

Temperatures last week averaging fifteen degrees cooler than in the corresponding 1957 week failed to depress department store sales to any great extent. The average temperature was seven degrees below the normal of 71. In addition, there was rain late in the week.
CHICAGO, June 21 -- Billy Pierce yielded only two singles and faced twenty-nine batters in a 1-0 Chicago White Sox triumph over the Baltimore Orioles today.

NO American going to the Soviet Union can fail to take a keen interest in Soviet schools, especially if he is in the academic field. Recently, during a month in Moscow and Leningrad, I visited some grade and high schools, as well as a Pedagogical Institute (teachers' college) in Moscow.

The Institute of Judicial Administration declared yesterday that elderly Federal judges had contributed to congestion and delay in the courts by refusing to retire. If they retired, the institute said, additional judges could be appointed.
BOSTON, June 21 -- The American Association of Theological Schools Fund, Inc., will make available next year more than 100 fellowships for theological study.
CLEVELAND, June 21 -Ninety-six of 250 Great Lakes ore carriers remain on the idle list and will not start this season unless there is a substantial increase in steel production.

THE chain reactions set in motion by a highly successful Broadway musical seem to go on endlessly, touching not only those who created the show but its various performers right down to the level of understudy.

A WHILE back a West Texas cattleman was asked about the weather out at his place. "We've been getting a right smart of rain here lately," he said, "but I don't believe we've ever had quite enough in any one year since Noah's Flood."

MILWAUKEE, June 21 (UPI) -- Joe Adcock said today he was willing to play the outfield if it would help the Milwaukee Braves win the National League Pennant. But the big first baseman doesn't like the idea.

WASHINGTON, June 21 -- A Federal judge's decision to allow Little Rock to suspend school integration was seen by Justice Department officials today as a major obstacle to integration in the Deep South -- and one the Federal Government might not be able to do anything about at this time.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 21 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff moved today to resolve a bitter three-cornered struggle for the nomination for United States Senator in advance of the Democratic state convention.
American Zionists were urged yesterday to abandon party divisions and form an all-inclusive Zionist organization. Its purpose would be to unify Zionist programs in the United States.

WESTWARD from New Orleans, across the mouth of a marshy bay opening on the Gulf of Mexico, stretch three narrow islands. In the quiet and commanding opening chapter of her first novel Shirley Ann Grau serenely fixes this setting, and then swings in on the centermost and largest of the islands -- four miles long, half a mile wide: Isle aux Chiens.
The Pacific American Steamship Association has elected J. Monroe Sullivan as vice president, with headquarters in Washington, Ralph B. Dewey, president, has announced.

A selected group of high school teachers of mathematics and science will take a new course this fall at New York University in advanced mathematical subjects including the study of the theory of relativity. Dr. Jacob T. Schwartz, Professor of Mathematics, who will give the course believes that high school students can take a much stiffer dose of mathematics than they are now receiving.
French-Americans, undaunted by rain, held their annual ceremony yesterday on Liberty Island. They put on their program under, rather than in front of, the Statue of Liberty.

PARIS, June 16 -- A year ago M. Dupont decided to flee from the noises of Paris. He was driven to desperation by the slamming of car doors late at night beneath his window, and the inappropriately timed and pitched voices of too-close apartment neighbors who got up too early and in too conversational a mood.

I NOTICED in the listing of the cast for "Ulysses in Nighttown" that one of the two narrators was Denis Johnston. It seems worth mentioning that Mr. Johnston, one of Ireland's leading playwrights, is a man who has been fascinated
David Schoenbrun traces the irresponsibility and impotence of succeeding French governments to the "system of an all-powerful Assembly divided against itself."
HAWORTH, N. J., June 21 -Judy Frank, a 23-year-old New Yorker, swept off with the women's metropolitan golf title again today.
ALGIERS, June 21 -- The AllAlgeria Public Safety Committee declared today that it was "indissolubly united behind General de Gaulle" and would continue its mission in a "totally unpolitical spirit."

"SUCCESS is a game of roulette," the pianist Artur Rubinstein once said. "Take it from a man who has played it a lot. One day a city or a nation doesn't know you're alive. The next day they're killing themselves to get near you."

SOUTHAMPTON, N. Y. -- Renewed interest on the part of local residents as well as members of this eastern Long Island village's summer colony has resulted in the restoration of many of the area's historic landmarks.

LONDON, June 21 (Reuters) -- England gained a 2-0 lead in the five-match cricket series against New Zealand today when it beat the tourists by an innings and 148 runs before a crowd of 25,000 at Lord's.
WASHINGTON, June 21 (UPI) -- The Defense Department said today that Bernard Goldfine's New England textile mills have been awarded more than $2,250,000 in military contracts over the last five years.

THERE is a shrewd and experienced old lady in "The Looking Glass Heart" who, though playing only a minor role in a three-decade drama with an appropriately large cast, says at one significant moment: "Well, fetch me the album.

PERHAPS the dominant literary theme of our century has been that of the terrible loneliness of human beings in a society increasingly diminished in emotional and moral values. Most of Herbert Kubly's stories share this theme.
Buying office executives reported last week that retailers, encouraged by the fall silhouettes, have spent slightly more than they originally intended during market weeks.
THE garden should be more than a "front parlor" landscape. The house is designed to utilize every square foot of area for complete family living; the home landscape deserves the same attention.

FAR better than words of eulogy for the late Edward Weston are his own pictures and excerpts from his daybooks in the beautifully produced special Weston issue of Aperture (Vol. 6, No. 1), just published.

The Rev. Donald Harrington yesterday compared the subversion of Communist materialism with the "crass commercial materialism" of the television networks that recently dismissed employes for refusing to testify on possible Communist connections.

THIS column is based on one couple's eating experiences during vacations spent regularly each summer in Western Europe. It is written in an attempt to record good restaurants and interesting dishes that are particularly worth recommending.
TUNIS, June 22 -- Ferhat Abbas, head of the Algerian nationalist delegation to the North African conference held here last week, denounced United States foreign policy in a newspaper interview today.

The national executive council of the Zionist Organization of America paid tribute yesterday to Secretary of State John Foster Dulles for his stand on "the grave threat against Lebanon and its independence."
Richard (Pancho) Gonzales and Kenneth Rosewall fought for an hour and twenty-five minutes yesterday in a thirty-six-game opening set before 8,000 onlookers in the Forest Hills Stadium.

LIMA, Peru, June 21 -- The Peruvian Government has announced several measures intended to arrest the worsening of economic conditions. They include a reduction of the automobile import quota from 6,400 to 4,500 cars yearly and a 200 per cent increase in duties on all luxury imports.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Neil H. McElroy, Secretary of Defense, tried today to reduce the impact of his public disapproval of Admiral Arleigh A. Burke's opposition to President Eisenhower's defense reorganization plan.
Seventeen commercial banks in the city will contribute a total of $1,225,000 to the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.

A Rockefeller Brothers Fund report on education declared yesterday that the nation must immediately take daring and aggressive measures to provide educational opportunities for the fullest development of every individual.

There is no place for personalities in the discussion of the proposals for the reorganization of the Defense Department. Secretary McElroy was, therefore, both right and kind last Saturday in emphasizing that his personal relations with the Chief of Naval Operations, Admiral Burke, were and would continue to be cordial and that the admiral had a right to his convictions and opinions.
Three home-bound motorists were killed and eleven other persons were injured in three early-morning accidents yesterday in Queens.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 22 -- Peggy Augustus' Little Sailor captured the working hunter championship of the Fairfield County Hunt Club horse show today with a ten-poin margin over Saxon Woods Farm's Naute Mia.

Carlos P. Garcia, President of the Phillipines, was greeted by Cardinal Spellman yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral. The President was accompanied by the Most Rev. Julio Rosales, Archbishop of Cebu, the Phillipines.
MILWAUKEE, June 22 (UPI) -Sal Maglie went seven innings and scattered five hits today to help the St. Louis Cardinals beat the Milwaukee Braves, 2 -- 1.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -Congress sets its sights this week on a late August adjournment despite a dozen controversy-filled bills awaiting action.

At the express invitation of our Secretary of the Army a delegation from Okinawa is now in this country to discuss possible modification of our method of acquiring and holding land in the Pacific outpost. The prior requisition procedure, to which there was objection, has been suspended pending a study. The Okinawan delegates are in this country to present their side of the case.

It was not at all unexpected that the decision by the United States Supreme Court in the passport cases, which held that Congress had not delegated to the State Department the power to refuse the issuance of passports to citizens of good moral character, would impel someone dissatisfied with the decision to take action toward the grant of such power.

MOSCOW, June 22 -- The downfall of a young man who got nearly everything he wanted in the Soviet Communist society because he was a soccer star set off a scandal here today involving "high-ranking patrons" of Soviet athletics.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., June 22 -- Ninety years ago a group of rowing enthusiasts in a newly formed recreation club held their first regatta. Though the succeeding regattas haven't been on an annual basis because of interruptions for wars and whatnot, the ninetieth anniversary rowing regatta of the now well-established New York Athletic Club took place today on Pelham Lagoon off Travers Island.
CHICAGO, June 22 (AP) -- The grain trade apparently came to the conclusion last week that it would have to scratch hard and deep for corn supplies to meet future commitments.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 22 (AP) -- Despite a boycott by t.en lnst{tutions over a discrimtnah issue, about. 1,000 delegates were present at the Lake Placid Club today for the American Alumni Council's forty-third annual conference.
Four accounts representing an estimated total of $1,600,000 a year will go to Honig-Cooper Miner, a West Coast agency, about July 1.
Ground was broken in the Bronx yesterday for the $270,000 Soundview Presbyterian Church.

There is no shortage of nurses. The shortage exists only in the salaries paid to nurses. Here lies the greatest contributing factor as to why so many registered nurses do not remain in their profession.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The nation's leading seismologists are in general agreement that it would be possible to establish an international inspection system that could detect most underground nuclear explosions.

Taiwan's pineapple industry, which was almost a total casualty of World War II, is beginning to climb back to its high pre-war rate of production. In 1938 the record pack was 1,679,000 cases. The present harvest of 1,200,000 cases just completed, is the largest in twenty years.
MOSCOW, June 22 (AP) -- A Soviet newspaper today praised an American conductor for refusing to,tell an American Congressional committee whether he was a communist.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 22 -- The Bolshoi Ballet, whose fame has spread across Europe and the seven seas, made its entrance into the festivities of the Brussels World's Fair tonight like a prima ballerina who knows that she is adored.

In action on the court, the world tennis champion, Richard (Pancho) Gonzales, is a formidable, inscrutable figure, almost foreboding to those who face his saturnine countenance and heavyweight blows across the net.
A $7,000,000 program for modernization and rehabilitation of Franklin D. Roosevelt (East River) Drive was announced yesterday by Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 22 -- A three-man United Nations committee reported today that it had ended private talks with the Government of the Union of South Africa on the status of South-West Africa.

HACKENSACK, N. J., June 22 -- Jerry Moss and John Capell of the University of Miami moved ahead of the field today to reach the fourth round of the Eastern clay-court tennis championships at the Oritani Field Club.
MAGINATIVE lamp shades crown one-of-a-kind lamps in new decorating studio called comus, which is located in an old carriage house, at 131 East 10th Street.
CLEVELAND, June 22 (UPI) -The Cleveland Indians swept a double-header from the Washington Senators, 4 -- 3 and 1 -- 0, today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 22 -- A further slackening of economic activity in private enterprise industrial countries was forecast in a report published here today.

New drafts drawn by United States exporters on Latin American importers dropped $6,800,000 in May, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. According to the bank's monthly survey of the draft experience of fourteen large commercial banks, new drafts drawn totaled $40,500,000 in May.
ATHENS, June 22 (Reuters) -Opposition parties denounced Premier Konstantin Karamanlis today for his "conciliatory" rejection of British constitutional changes in Cyprus.
SYRACUSE, June 22 -- Jim and Laverne Hellen of Levittown, L. I., won the Historic New York National Sports Car Rally that ended here today. Jim did the driving and his wife was the navigator.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 22 -- Plans for an international institute to protect private investors in foreign countries in the event of expropriation and to insure them against other risks have been worked out by Brazilian industrialists.
In an inflationary age at least one item has not gone up in price -- the greeting card. There is still a line of 5-cent Christmas cards in several colors, with a wreath and a jolly Santa.

BAKERSFIELD, Calif., June 22 (AP) -- A track and field team of Olympic Games caliber was selected by the United States today to compete against the Soviet Union in an international meet in Moscow next month.

Champion Ruttkay's Heir Apparent, a well-mannered silver and gray keeshond, owned by E. G. and Patricia Marcmann of Trappe, Pa., was named best in show at the Staten Island Kennel Club's nineteenth dog show yesterday.

STRATFORD, Conn., June 21 -- Since "A Midsummer Night's Dream" is more than three and a half centuries old, one must be cautious about rising absolutes. But on the basis of the exuberant performance staged last Friday at the Shakespeare Festival Theatre, this column with difficulty refrains from declaring that the "Pyramus and Thisbe" interlude has never been so well acted.

State Senator Walter J. Mahoney of Buffalo said yesterday that he would be "in the race all the way" if he decided to announce his candidacy for the Republican nomination for Governor. He said he would not declare his intentions before "some time in August."

March 12, 1956--Dr. Jesfls de Galindez, Spanish. eile,. agent of the Basque Cvernment in exile and leetm-ei at Columbia University, _ last seen about 9:30 P. M. outside a Fifty-seventh Street subway station.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -The Pentagon's attempt to cut off Army, Navy and Air Force self-promoting activities conducted through their separate public-relations and legislative-liaison branches is infuriating Senators.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., June 22 -- The peak period of the Long Island strawberry-selling season started here today when 4,322 crates were sold at the Riverhead auction block. Farmers, welcoming the berry-ripening sunshine, brought a total of 181 loads of carefully packed crates to the bustling auction; some of them made two or three trips. Bidding was brisk.

LE MANS, France, June 22 -- Phil Hill of Santa Monica, Calif., and Olivier Gendebien of Belgium, driving a 3-liter Ferrari, won the twenty-four-hour endurance race today, clinching the sports cars world championship for the Ferrari factory.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 21 -- United States and Canadian oil interests are seeking to form a company jointly with the Indonesian Government for the production of oil in Sumatra.

IN tranquil countryside the dreamer is likely to enjoy the long view and the broad sweep; to come to know humility in nature's vastness. The same fellow has a subconscious frustration as he wanders along the pavement. Man-made structures, a vociferous multiplicity of highly colored advertisements, prevent the long view; shatter dreams to fragments with their bids for attention.

The Rev. Adam Clayton Powell Jr. criticized both the Republican and Democratic parties yesterday and declared that the country "s morally bankrupt." He called for a "third force" of religious faiths to protect free men from discrimination.
The city's effort to reverse the rising trend of pedestrian traffic deaths enters its third phase today, when anti-jaywalking regulations become effective.
The appointment of Samuel Ratensky as director of the city's newly created Urban Renewal Board was announced yesterday by James Felt, chairman of the agency.

Msgr. Francis J. Lally, editor of The Boston Pilot, Roman Catholic weekly newspaper, declared last night that Catholic views against birth control should be regarded in the same light as some Protestant views on gambling and liquor.
