THE chemise will he seen on the streets of New York this summer, but it won't go near the water.

WHAT to do with a long, narrow room short of knocking down the wall has been the subject of many inquiries to this department. A New York apartment dweller recently asked advice on how to make a long, narrow bedroom look less like a ship's galley and more like a lady's boudoir.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Democratic leaders in Congress were planning strategy today to pass the Kennedy-Ives labor reform bill, or at least to bring it to a vote in the House of Representatives.

PARIS, June 22 -- Each French upheaval has its literary revolutionist. The Marquis de Condorcet played a role in 1789. Lamartine, the poet, featured the 1848 ruckus. And now, one century later, France's great novelist, Andre Malraux, returns flamboyantly to the political scene.
RIVERSIDE, Conn., June 22 -- Light airs harassed the skippers appearing today for the Riverside Yacht Club's program on Long Island Sound.

SPARKILL, N. Y., June 22 -A schoolboy plot to dislodge Balance Rock, one of Rockland County's geological heritages, was thwarted last night with the apprehension of twenty-one boys. Nearly all are members of the class that will be graduated tomorrow night from yack High School.

THE Isle aux Chiens lay in the Gulf of Mexico opposite a deep bayou and not far out from the Louisiana shore. About four miles long and a half mile wide, it had been inhabited by an inbred race of fishermen for 200 years. Part French and part Spanish with a dash of Negro, the islanders were a tough, hardy and primitive lot.

Bigness paid off for corporations in 1957, according to Fortune Magazine's latest annual directory of the nation's 500 largest industrial corporations. Published in the July issue, the Fortune survey shows that last year "was a much better year for the 500 largest companies than it was for the host of smaller companies."

KATONAH, N. Y., June 22 -- Never say that music lovers are effete. A ninety- minute rainfall failed to dampen the enthusiasm of a small but hardy audience gathered here for the open ing of the new Venetian Theatre at Caramoor.
Grants totaling $1,473,800 to aid education for nursing were announced yesterday by the Sealantic Fund. They were made possible by a special gift to the fund by John D. Rockefeller Jr.

Two groups of workers will become eligible for unemployment insurance benefits today. One is made up of long-term jobless who will qualify for additional payments under a new Federal law. The other consists of workers previously ineligible for benefits because they had not worked twenty weeks in the last year.

LONDON, June 22 -- Australia was an overwhelming favorite to capture the men's singles title and Althea Gibson of New York was an even choice to retain the women's crown on the eve of the All-England tennis championships, which open at Wimbledon tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA, June 22 -A couple of fellows named Willie -- Kirkland and Mays -- played major roles in the 5-4 overtime victory the San Francisco Giants registered over the Phillies at Connie Mack Stadium today.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -Labor celebrates one anniversary and mourns another in the next few days.
THE special program in observance of Ed Sullivan's ten years on television last night over Channel 2 was a memorable triumph.

Now, as the new fiscal year approaches, public officials and private citizens alike echo the pulse of the land by pointing to the necessity for solution of vital defense problems, the success of which depends upon the expenditure of money.

Seven policemen and a number of pickets were injured yesterday when Hungarian refugees demonstrating before the headquarters of the Soviet delegation to the United Nations attempted to break through police lines.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 22 -Diplomatic sources said today that Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold would ask President Gamal Abdel Nasser to close the Syrian border to prevent the flow of arms to Lebanese rebels.

The American Civil Liberties Union chided the Fund for the Republic yesterday for charging the American Broadcasting Company with censorship because A. B. C. canceled one of the fund's television programs
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The railroad industry thinks the tolls on the St. Lawrence Seaway -- a competitor to some roads -- should be higher than those proposed last week.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- Predictions that only a half-dozen states would agree to the payment of temporary Federal aid to their long-term unemployed have been upset already.

The active merchant fleet 'under the United States flag comprised 937 vessels of 1,000 gross tons and over on the first of this month, according to a monthly compilation by the Maritime Administration. The total represents a drop of fifteen ships from the number active a month earlier.

An American edition of the Right Honorable Malcolm MacDonald's book, which combines travel impressions and personal history, will be published July 21 by Knopf, entitled "Borneo People." Mr. MacDonald, whose many diplomatic assignments have included sojourns in Southeast Asia, is the son of the former Prime Minster Ramsay MacDonald.

After playing for several months in Europe and the Middle East, the Dave Brubeck Quartet returned to New York Saturday night at Loew's Sheridan Theatre, Seventh Avenue at Twelfth Street, to do battle with a recalcitrant amplifying system and a well-worn piano.

General Telephone Company of Ohio announced over the week-end acquisition of all assets of Ohio Consolidated Telephone Company and the Chesapeake Telephone Company as of June 20. Financing involved in the acquisition included an issue of $4,987,000 of first mortgage bonds, 4 1/4 per cent series due 1978, in exchange for a similar principal amount of first mortgage bonds of Ohio Consolidated Telephone held by seven institutional investors.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -John Foster Dulles invoked the spiritual faith of Americans today in support of the Administration's foreign aid program.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 22 -- The sound of hoarse chanting and clapping in rhythm came startlingly through the loudspeakers of Prague's radios. It seemed almost impossible that such a sound of organized applause could be made in a city so sedate.
PURCHASE, N. Y., June 22 -- Three thousand Scots, Scots-Americans and their friends gathered at the Blind Brook Polo Club today for the first National Scottish Games.

DETROIT, June 22 -- It took the Yankees only a couple of minutes today to bring to an end the magic spell of Detroit pitching and, at the same time, put the rest of the American League in its proper place.

Inga Swenson, now portraying Ophelia in "Hamlet" and Helena in "A Midsummer Night's Dream" at the Stratford, Conn., festival, will play the pivotal role in the Broadway production of "A Swim in the Sea."
WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI) -- Four Negro leaders will take up with President Eisenhower tomorrow a Federal Judge's suspension of school integration in Little Rock, Ark.

PITTSBURGH, June 22 -- Steel mills are pushing production to fill orders that have been promised for shipment this month. Price hedge buying -- which broke out some weeks ago -- was accentuated by exceptionally low inventories. Even with the heavier flow of steel to many customers, most manufacturers do not have enough steel on hand properly to weather a possible upturn in business.

Little Rock's difficult experiment in the integration of students of the white and Negro races in the public schools will be interrupted for at least two and a half years if an order issued by United States District Judge Harry J. Lemley on Saturday is sustained. Judge Lemley based his decision on "the unfortunate racial strife and tension which existed in Little Rock during the past year and still exists there."

Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. announced yesterday that he had invited Councilman Earl Brown, his opponent in the Democratic primary, to attend a rally Sunday to protest the granting of a delay in school integration at Little Rock, Ark.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- New documents have come to light connecting Gerald Lester Murphy, an American flier, with the disappearance of Jesus de Galindez.
A report of progress in the plan to eliminate eleven grade crossings in Queens and a demand for prompt action on a similar program in Staten Island were made yesterday by Robert Moses.
The steamship charter market clung last week to an index level reached early this month, but only after strong assists from West Coast lumber cargoes and sugar from Cuba to Japan.

World Mental Health Year will be held in 1960. It will follow the pattern of the International Geophysical Year and be sponsored by 108 mental health and other professional societies in forty-three countries.

Hayden Hall, a seven-story residential hotel at 117 West Seventy-ninth Street, has been purchased by Benjamin Bogart and associates, hotel operators, for cash over a purchase money first mortgage of $160,000. The buyers leased the property to the Hayden Seventy-ninth Street Corporation, Samuel Gertel, president.
PARIS, June 22 -- A loan floated by the government of Gen. Charles de Gaulle has brought about ten tons of gold into the Bank of France during the first week.
Four film strips produced to present and interpret the delinquency-prevention programs of the New York City Youth Board were announced yesterday.
Mayor Wagner almost -- but not quite -- eliminated himself yesterday as a possible Democratic candidate for United States Senator this year.

BRESCIA, Italy, June 22 (UPI) -- Luigi Taramazzo and Giuseppe Gerini, two relatively unknown drivers, won Italy's famed and tamed Mille Miglia today in a drastically slowed-down race that claimed two lives despite numerous added safety features.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 22 -- A new storm was brewing today for the United States pavilion at the Brussels World's Fair.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -Following are the votes of the members from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended June 21.

MELBOURNE, Australia, June 22 -- The forthcoming series of British-Australian tests of long-range missiles probably will last four or five years, the Australian Supply Minister, Athol G. Townley, said today.
Thirteen new films are to arrive in local theatres this week. The programs follow:

Cotton futures prices ran an irregular course last week on the New York Cotton Exchange. In the second successive week of mixed trends, active contracts at the close on Friday were 45 cents a bale higher to $1.55 lower.
BREWSTER, N. Y., June 22 (AP) -- A summer camp to accommodate persons from 3 to 93 was dedicated here today.
Following are the members of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund panel that prepared the report on education and the future of America:
ANYONE who tells you that the only show at the Jones Beach Marine Theatre this summer is "Song of Norway" is either ignorant of the facts or willfully misleading.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 22 -- Vera Miles has accepted an invitation from Warner Brothers to co-star with James Stewart in "The F. B. I. Story." Mervyn LeRoy, director, plans to put the dramatization of Don Whitehead's factual book before the cameras next month.
Morris L. Ernst last night stood by his report, which in effect absolved Generalissimo Rafael L. Trujillo's Dominican regime of any role in the disappearance of Jesus de Galindez.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 22 (Reuters) -- Czechoslovakia's Communist party announced tonight that the army and security organs would be strengthened to improve defense and "wipe out all attempts" at impeding the party's program.

THE knit dress was never obsolete but for a good many years it was as exciting as a dish of oatmeal. College girls knitted them, old ladies doted on them and designers didn't bother much at all with them.
Cardinal Spellman yesterday rejected a school board's, appeal to intercede in a controversy over land for school expansion in Dobbs Ferry, N. Y.
The faculty of Newtown High School in Elmhurst, Queens, will assemble at the Fifth Avenue Hotel tonight to honor a colleague, George H. Schoettle.
The underlying cause of all the problems that have ever troubled mankind is "cynicism towards the worth of the individual," the Rev. Hampton Adams said in a sermon here yesterday.
The annual series of weekly summer band concerts in Battery Park opens tomorrow at noon.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, June 21 -- Alaskans who have spurred the fight for statehood began seeing bogey men this week-end as the Senate prepared to debate the bill already passed by the House.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 22 (AP) -- The father of Minnijean Brown, Negro girl expelled earlier this year from Central High School, shot and killed a man early today, the police reported.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., June 22 -- Dick Sykes made it two straight for the week-end in the Lightning Class as the Manhasset Bay Interclub championship series was sailed in light winds today.

WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The chairman of the House Legislative Oversight Subcommittee held out the possibility today that Sherman Adams, the Assistant to the President, might be recalled for further testimony.
President Carlos P. Garcia of the Philippines urged on the United States yesterday an expanded program of educational aid for Southeast Asia.
"SUNRISE SEMESTER," the pre-breakfast exposure to the arts, appears to have a second hit on its hands.
The First National City Bank has leased the ground floor and basement space in the new apartment building at the northwest corner of the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) and Twenty-third Street.

WHEN Big Ed Walsh pitched the Chicago White Sox to two victories in the 1906 world series, they were known as the Hitless Wonders. And not without cause. The leading better, Frank Isbell, clouted a rousing .279. No outfielder was over .230 and one infielder was as low as .175.

In an editorial published in The New York Times on June 18 you made certain comparisons between Gen. Charles de Gaulle and Winston Churchill. At the same time you neglected to make an important distinction. Winston Churchill came to power through democratic processes.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -- The National Housing Conference called tonight for a joint Congressional study of shortages in housing and community facilities.

The Mauro, Jackson Fox Mortgage Company, a new realty concern, has opened an office at 368 South Oyster Bay Road, Hicksville, L. I. James Fox, president, has been a broker for forty years under the name of James Fox Realty.
BONN, Germany, June 22 -The United Arab Republic threatened today to send volunteers to aid Lebanese rebels in the event of "all-out armed aggression" in that country.

LONDON, June 22 -- The stock markets responded favorably last week to a reduction in the bank rate and to other signs that the Government was ready to encourage, however cautiously, industrial expansion.

ADEN, June 22 -- Arab discussions in London concerning the possible federation of all sheikdoms of the Western Protectorate of Aden have produced an outcry here and in Yemen from those who regard Aden as "Southern Yemen."
CAIRO, June 22 -- Dag Hammarskjold flew here today to talk with the man who has been accused of fomenting the rebellion in Lebanon -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic.
BOSTON, June 22 -- The preprimary convention of Massachusetts Democrats ended amid punches and pandemonium at 2:30 o'clock this morning, with half its business unfinished.
FLINT, Mich., June 22 (AP) -- Ted Kroll of Sarasota, Fla., knocked the United States Open champion, Tommy Bolt, out of the lead today at the 54-hole mark in the $52,000 Buick open golf tournament.

CLEVELAND, June 22 (AP) -Sunday observance laws are a greater threat to personal liberty now than at any time since the "blue law" era of America's Colonial days, the forty-eighth world conference of the Seventh Day Adventist Church was told today.
Horace W. Schmahl, a private detective here, denied last night that he had any connection with the Galindez case.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 22 -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People will ask United States District Judge Harry J. Lemley tomorrow morning to suspend his order permitting segregation at Central High School while his decision is appealed.
Seattle, Wash., is planning to sell $6,000,000 of water revenue bonds on July 8. Dated July 1, 1958, the obligations will come due on July 1 from 1959 to 1968.

IT is pointed out in the preface to Mrs. Wilma R. LaSasso's new "All Italian Cookbook" (Macmillan, 268 pp:, $4.50) that more than 20,000,000 Americans trace their lineage to Italy. The author asked Italian-Americans for the recipes that she presents in her book.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 22 -- The Yugoslav public was told tonight that Imre Nagy, former Premier of Hungary, had been put to death as "a horrible warning" to all those who opposed restoration of Stalinist methods in Eastern Europe.

TEHERAN, Iran, June 22 (AP) -- A National Iranian Oil Company spokesman announced today an agreement between N. I. O. C. and the Saphire Petroleums, Ltd., under which Iran is expected to receive 75 per cent of the net profit.
The touchy subject of reparations for Jewish victims of Nazi persecution was discussed yesterday between President Theodor Heuss of West Germany and American Jewish leaders.
The confused state of union affairs of the steamship office workers in the Port of New York will go to the National Labor Relations Board next month for an attempt at clarification.
Some 400 pleasure craft that sail the bounding main off Coney Island received the blessing of three water-borne clergymen yesterday.

The pianist Artur Rubinstein was quoted recently on the great subject of how life should be lived. The mention of vitamins evidently set off his remarks, as vitamins well might in the case of a man who lives life in the large.
ARLINGTON, N. J., June 22 -- George Ball of Woodhaven, Queens, won the New Jersey tennis singles championship and share of the doubles title today at the Arlington Players Club.
AMSTERDAM, June 22 -- The rally in the stock market continued last week.
Your newspaper of June 13 contained a letter from F. S. Berger relating to the damaging of trees by erectors of buildings along Third Avenue.
A FRIEND has described John William Gardner as an intellectual with such tremendous energy and dedication to the world of ideas that he sometimes finds the rest of the world an inconvenience.
TUNIS, June 22 -- Tunisia, Algeria and Morocco, lands that form El Maghreb Kebir el Arabiya (the Great Arab West), have one element in common that predominates over all others -- France.
The city and the New York Central Railroad have reached an agreement under which the city will refund about $2,500,000 of the special franchise taxes paid by the railroad in the last sixteen years.
WARSAW, June 17 -- Poland has dropped 130,000 workers from overloaded industrial payrolls.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- The Justice Department is making an investigation of United States Attorney Robert Tieken's conduct in office, Assistant Attorney General Malcolm Anderson told a House Judiciary subcommittee today.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- Resentment appeared to be building in Midwest Congressional circles today over President Eisenhower's week-end transfer of supervision over the St. Lawrence Seaway to the Commerce Department.

PARIS, June 23 -- Political figures of the Western alliance have expressed their hopes and doubts about France's future role in Europe and North Africa in the latest edition of Western World, the international magazine. The magazine seeks to promote unity in the Atlantic community.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 23 (UPI) -- Favored Brazil meets France and Sweden takes on the defending champion, West Germany, tomorrow in the semi-final matches of the World Cup soccer tournament.

Like the man caught with a butt in his hand in front of a no smoking sign who excused himself because the sign didn't say "positively," the public is still unconvinced, in spite of Mayor Wagner's repeated statements, that he is not a candidate for the United States Senate. The Mayor's latest disavowal, made on a Sunday television press conference, produced the headline: "Wagner Shuts Door to Senate -- Almost."

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Supreme Court held today that the Jones Act's three-year statute of limitations must be applied to both Jones Act and unseaworthiness counts when an injured seaman brings both in a single suit.

MADISON, Wis., June 23 (UPI) -- A Columbia University sceintist said here today that two chemical compounds had been developed that blocked the lethal action of nerve gas poisons on mice and other animals.
JERUSALEM (Israeli sector), June 23 (Reuters) -- Israel has agreed to reopen all day -- instead of four hours daily -- a road through her enclave on Mount Scopus, it was announced today.

ALGIERS, June 23 -- A nationalist rebel leader standing trial for his life here today declared that Premier Charles de Gaulle's presence as head of the French Government inspired hope for a fair solution to the struggle between the Moslem nationalists and the French forces.

The establishment of economic development corporations to help build free economies in Asia, Africa and Latin America was proposed last night by Eric Johnston, chairman of President Eisenhower's Committee for International Economic Growth.

LITTLE ROCK, June 23 -- Federal District Judge Harry J. Lemley today denied a motion that he delay execution of his order suspending integration at Little Rock's Central High School while his decision is appealed.
The City of New York and the Republic of the Philippines traded compliments and honors yesterday.
Belmont Park split its filly-and-mare feature, the Juniper Valley Handicap yesterday with C. V. Whitney's Magic Forest taking the first division and Audley Farm's Jodi the second.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that the Selective Service Act did not compel an employer to restore a returned veteran to a promoted position in a seniority capacity he might have achieved had he not gone into the armed forces.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- Strong support for a five-year extension of the Reciprocal Trade Law was voiced today by the nation's largest farm organization and by Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture.
The American Federation of Musicians issued orders last night for "informational picketing" of motion-picture theatres showing two hit films.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation has been investigating for the last two weeks a "frightening incident" in which a labor writer was reported to have approached a woman juror in the Hoffa wiretap conspiracy case.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Representative Charles O. Porter, Democrat of Oregon, challenged Morris L. Ernst today to give "objective scrutiny" to newly disclosed documents in the case of Jesus de Galindez.

The American Institute of Electrical Engineers announced yesterday that L. F. Hickernell of Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., had been elected president. Mr. Hickernell is vice president in charge of engineering for the Anaconda Wire and Cable Company at Hastings-on-Hudson, N. Y.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- If the higher Federal courts overrule District Judge Lemley at Little Rock, Ark., before the beginning of the next term at Central High School, there are certain to be social and political consequences beyond the scope of reliable forecast.

Dick Ruffino's three-run homer in the first inning plus a two-run outburst in the eighth enabled Martin Van Buren High of Queens to gain its first city Public Schools Athletic League baseball crown yesterday. Van Buren defeated Curtis High of Staten Island, 5 -- 3, at Ebbets Field in the league finale.
PHILADELPHIA, June 23 -- A new tabloid newspaper, staffed by striking news room and clerical employes of The Philadelphia Inquirer, went on sale at news stands here today at 10 cents a copy.
MOSCOW, June 23 -- Hundreds of Muscovites hurled stones, bricks, sticks, pieces of iron, incendiary rags and bottles at the West German Embassy today.

CLEVELAND, June 23 (AP) -- "Radio and television are divinely directed inventions," Pastor Elmer Walde of Washington told the Seventh-Day Adventists' forty-eighth Quadrennial General Conference today.
Two commentators on national affairs criticized yesterday this country's practice of sending diplomats abroad who cannot speak foreign languages.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Territory of Alaska renewed in the Senate today its forty-two-year-old bid to be admitted to the Union.
A preliminary examination of seismic records from the South Pole and Byrd Station indicates that the Antarctic continent, beneath its heavy mantle of ice, is a generator of earthquakes.

A Federal jury last night acquitted James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, and two other defendants of charges that they had tapped the telephones of union subordinates in Detroit.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 23 -- In 1957, some phases of the Latin American economy registered gains over 1956, the Economic Commission for Latin America reported today.

OTTAWA, June 23 (UPI) -- The Value of Canada's output of goods and services in the first quarter of 1958 was $31,676,000,000, almost unchanged after seasonal adjustment from the last quarter of 1957, the Bureau of Statistics reported today.

WINNIPEG, Man., June 23 (Canadian Press) -- Duff Roblin, whose Progressive Conservatives won last week's Manitoba general election in the party's first big test since he became leader, accepted a call today to form a new government.
A New York County grand jury charged two former officials of the Nassau Management Company yesterday with conspiracy and receiving kickbacks from a contractor.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Supreme Court refused today to consider a claim by five railroads that New Jersey is unconstitutionally discriminating against them in taxing their property.
The Appellate Division in Brooklyn agreed yesterday to let the Rev. Dr. John Howard Melish continue to live in the rectory of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn Heights.

The Bureau of Motor Vehicles announced yesterday the suspension of the driving privileges of a Queens woman who killed a young girl and injured her younger sister last week while taking a driving lesson.
GRANADA, Spain, June 23 -- American visitors are flocking here by car, train and plane to hear great music in one of the world's loveliest settings.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (UPI) -- Twenty-three nations banded together today in a coffee commodity organization designed to pull Latin America out of an economic crisis caused by coffee surpluses and sagging prices.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 23 (AP) -- Bernie Magnussen of Stanford and Phil Rodgers of Houston shot 2-under-par 69's today and led the first day of qualifying in the sixty-first National Collegiate golf tournament.
LONG BRANCH, N. J., June 23 -- Legal procedures may take until the latter part of August before six former Army employes can resume work at Fort Monmouth, an attorney said today.
PHILADELPHIA, June 23 -- Two top Soviet Russian engineers, who came here to attend a convention, were banned today by the Department of State from industrial plants in this area.

Mrs. Sigourney B. Romaine, chairman of this year's Grosvenor Debutante Ball, has been holding meetings to plan the event. The fete, a benefit for the Grosvenor Neighborhood House at 321 East Forty-ninth Street, will take place in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on Nov. 29.

TRENTON, June 23 -- Legislation was urged today to do away with the conviction of parents in cases involving child neglect until every effort had been made to keep the home intact. The proposal was made in a report to the State Board of Child Welfare.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 23 -- The president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association said today the nation's newspapers were caught in a squeeze between increasing costs and shrinking advertising linage.

Alex Kellner, Turk Lown and Vito Valentinetti, three journeymen pitchers with mediocre records this season, changed uniforms yesterday in a series of $20,000 waiver deals, United Press International reported.
CHICAGO, June 23 (UPI) -- Mother Hubbard would find Benjamin Green-Field cupboard conspiracy bare today as she wanted a hat.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Senator Richard B. Russell demanded "clear and unequivocal" assurance from Neil H. McElroy today that military men will not be punished for giving Congress their candid opinions on Pentagon reorganization.
LONDON, June 23 (Reuters) -- Arthur Horner, chief of the National Union of Mineworkers and leading Communist in the British labor movement, denounced today the execution of Mr. Nagy.
TRENTON, June 23 -- Unemployment and temporary disability benefits in New Jersey were extended today from twenty-six to thirty-nine weeks, retroactive to last Oct. 1.
Steel production is expected to decline this week for the first time since late April.
CHICAGO, June 23 (AP) -- Butcher hog prices were as much as 50 cents higher today and again at a $25 top which for the second time within a week equaled that paid on July 14, 1954.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Government confirmed today what many business men had believed all along -- people saved more of their cash in the first quarter of this year.

A new volume of World War II reminiscences by a member of the topmost echelon will be published in November by Holt. Entitled "Wedemeyer Reports," it has been written by Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer. He tells of the Allied invasion of Europe, the war in the Pacific Theater and American policy in Asia.

PARIS, June 23 -- The European Assembly, meeting in Strasbourg, adopted tonight a resolution expressing its satisfaction with the United States-European agreement for financing reactors in Europe. The Assembly represents the parliaments of the six nations forming the European Atomic Energy Community, the European Economic Community and the European Coal and Steel Community.
LOS ANGELES, June 23 (AP) -- Cheryl Crane went to a lawyer's office today to tell how she had killed her mother's suitor, John Stompanato.
The Music Research Foundation, Inc., will benefit from a "moonlight" garden party to be held on the John Ohl estate in Sands Point, L. I., on Friday evening.
Embroiled in a welter of lawsuits, the proxy fight for control of Penn-Texas Corporation is unresolved seven weeks after the adjournment of the annual stockholders' meeting.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Tuesday, June 24 -- The Navy postponed early today its third attempt to launch a fully instrumented Vanguard satellite.

CAIRO, June 23 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic was reported today to have expressed conditional willingness to intercede with the rebels in Leb anon. The nation's intercity truck operators experienced a 5.6 per cent drop in their tonnage of goods hauled in the first quarter this year.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- A personal letter from the President of Argentina was presented to President Eisenhower today by the new Argentine Ambassador, Dr. Cesar Barros Hurtado.

MAX CONRAD is one of a vanishing breed of old-time free-wheeling fliers. Yesterday he landed a single-engine plane in Palermo, Sicily, after a non-stop flight of 4,440 miles from New York in 32 hours 55 minutes.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today for quick approval of United States cooperation in a new agreement on atomic-power development in West Europe.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 23 -- A bomb, apparently placed by rebels, killed at least four persons and injured many others here today.
New Yorkers have so taken to the use of vending machines in the last ten years that the city Health Department has moved to safeguard the public's stomach.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Treasury bill rate went above 1 per cent this week, the Treasury reported tonight.

The election of Wright A. Parkins and Erle Martin as directors of United Aircraft Corporation was announced yesterday. The company also announced the formation of two new divisions, the missiles and space systems division and the Norden division.

The Red Cross collected 463 pints of blood Friday from donors here. Members of the New York City Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity gave 210 pints toward the total.

The pending borrowing of the High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community in this market will aggregate $50,000,000, according to an announcement yesterday by the bankers handling the deal, Kuhn, Loeb Co., First Boston Corporation and Lazard Freres Co.
As summer approaches newspapers have been reporting expected new outbreaks of juvenile delinquency. There has been some talk of cracking down and getting tough with delinquents.

The backlog of General Intrument Corporation is a record $22,000,000, Martin H. Benedek, chairman, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday in the Robert Treat Hotel, Newark, N. J. The company manufactures electronic devices.

STEAKS, chops, spareribs and a whole beef tenderloin -- all of top quality -- are included in a new assortment of frozen meats chosen especially for al fresco grilling by the Pfaelzer Brothers of Chicago. Suburbanites -- and also city dwellers who have outdoor cooking facilities and a home freezer -- can order this package, which will be air-freighted to them for $48.50.

Earnings of May Department Stores Company, which operates a chain of stores, in the quarter and twelve months ended with April were below 1957 levels, the report issued yesterday disclosed. Sales for the quarter were off slightly but were higher in the twelve-month period.

DETROIT, June 23 (AP) -- George Susce scored his first victory of the year today as the Detroit Tigers beat the Baltimore Orioles, 3 -- 1, with the help of Gail Harris' home run.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 23 -- Mayor Wagner has designated Public, School 82, First Avenue at Seventieth Street, for use by the United Nations International School this fall, it was learned today.
Robert K. Christenberry, Acting Postmaster of New York, acknowledged yesterday that two weeks on his new job had convinced him that he had been "guilty of malpractices" as a business man.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to review a decision that deportation of an alien does not violate the constitutional rights of his wife.

DETROIT, June 23 (AP) -- The automobile industry built a few more cars last week than in the preceding week -- 82,969 units against 78,163. In the comparable 1957 week 118,805 cars were built. So far this year 2,139,485 cars have been made, compared with 3,245,595 in like 1957.

NEW DELHI, India, June 23 -- India and United States signed a $57,000,000 loan agreement today allocating surplus agricultural commodities to India.
BROOKLYN is having its own Shakespeare festival this season with background music from "Lohengrin." Abraham Straus is showing a bridal collection inspired by "A Midsummer Night's Dream."

CHICAGO, June 23 (AP) -- Liquidation and profit taking gathered speed in the final few minutes of dealings on the Board of Trade today and prices closed steady to weak after some early tendency toward firmness.
NEW HAVEN, June 23 (AP) -- A distinguished group of forty-two mathematics teachers gathered here today to try to solve the problem of getting better math students from secondary schools.
A wage contract that had been agreed upon with the American Merchant Marine Institute last week was renegotiated yesterday by the American Radio Association. The union won added benefits.
The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company of America attained record sales and earnings for the seventh consecutive year in the fifty-two weeks ended Feb. 22, the report issued yesterday disclosed.
The Todd Shipyards Corporation of Alameda, Calif., has submitted the low bid for the modernization of four American President Lines Mariner-class dry-cargo ships.
ALBANY, June 23 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller conferred with Albany County Republican leaders today, but still declined to say whether he was a candidate for Governor.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Republican National Chairman challenged Senate Democrats tonight to come out from behind the "Congressional Fifth" and testify on whether they had exerted influence on Federal regulatory agencies.

Abe Burrows is writing the book for the musical version of Jane Austen's "Pride and Prejudice." He will be using as source material, in addition to the novel, Helen Jerome's dramatization and the film adaptation. Mr. Burrows will also direct.
CHICAGO, June 23 -- The American League's insurrectionist movement, which flares off and on, was back in business tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- A long-standing and controversial feature of Federal water resources law was upheld in broad terms today by the Supreme Court.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 23 -- The World Medical Association accepted here today the first applications from physicians who want to store their medical credentials in a central repository.
JAKARTA, Jan. 23 -- Indonesian rebel forces in the beseiged city of Menado continued today to put up tough resistance to attacking Government troops.

BELO HORIZONTE, Brazil, June 23 -- President Juscelino Kubitschek said today that, in underdeveloped countries like Brazil, the Government must spearhead industrialization because there is not enough private capital to do the job.
HUNSTANTON, England, June 23 (AP) -- The elimination of Mrs. Maurice Glick of Baltimore today left Mrs. Frank Stranahan of Toledo as the lone American in the British women's golf championship.
" Behind Closed Doors," a weekly filmed series dealing with espionage cases, will be presented over the National Broadcasting Company television network next season.
MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 23 -- All seeded players won their opening matches as the women's New York State tennis championships began at the Beach Point Club today.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Despite the United States recession, the rest of the world added to its gold and dollar reserves at a near record rate in the first quarter of this year, as a result of transactions with this country.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 23 -- The Yugoslav Government registered a vigorous protest today against the secret trial and execution of Imre Nagy and his associates.

The Turkish Press Attache's letter on Cyprus carried in your issue of June 18 is an awkward and almost pathetic attempt to justify a policy of communal violence, inspired from Ankara and threatening to engulf that hapless island.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 23 (AP) -- Dr. Norman P. Auburn, president of the University of Akron in Ohio, called tonight for perfection of what he termed an E for Education bomb.

ANDOVER, N. H., June 23 -- Nothing makes an outdoor type feel so strong and so hardy as the knowledge that he has endured stoically a rude knock and thereby earned the applause of his companions. A visible bruise or cut, casually dismissed as a mere trifle, is a badge of honor.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation asked yesterday in a brief filed in District Court, Southern District, that the Government's suit against the merger of Bethlehem and Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company be dismissed.
The Territory of Hawaii has designated July 22 for the sale of $12,500,000 of highway revenue bonds. The securities will come due serially from 1960 to 1988.

RANGOON, Burma, June 22 -- Premier Nu was deposed as president and expelled today from Burma's controlling political party, the Anti-Fascist People's Freedom League. Nine political followers were expelled with him by the Supreme Council of the party.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N. Y., June 23 -- The "last week and a half" has been one of the four "toughest" periods he has seen as President Eisenhower's press secretary, James C. Hagerty said last night.

PARIS, June 23 -- French and Chinese Nationalist officials hinted today that rumors of imminent French recognition of Communist China might have been started by persons interested in achieving that result.
MILWAUKEE, June 23 (AP) -- Carlton Willey, in his first major league start, held San Francisco to six singles tonight as the Milwaukee Braves scored a 7-0 victory over the second-place Giants.
CINCINNATI, June 23 (UPI) -- Brooks Lawrence pitched a six-hitter to gain his fifth victory of the season tonight and give the Cincinnati Redlegs a 6-1 decision over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

Custom smelters of copper reduced their price 1 cent a pound yesterday, to 25 1/2 cents. As a result, refined copper was being quoted at three different levels in major markets here. Most of the primary producers, including the two largest domestic miners -- the Kennecott Copper Corporation and the Phelps Dodge Corporation -- were still quoting 25 cents a pound, as they had since last Jan. 13.
The Pharma-Craft Corporation has moved its Coldene Stick Chest Rub account to Cunningham Walsh, Inc., from the J. Walter Thompson Company.
FLINT, Mich., June 23 (AP) -- Bill Casper Jr. won the $52,000 Buick open golf tournament today.
DETROIT, June 23 -- A wildcat strike of about 400 workers disrupted production of Redstone and Jupiter missiles today at the Chrysler Corporation's missile plant near here.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 23 -- Among the numerous "systems" designed -- some hope -- to cash a winning mutuel ticket at a harness racing track is the one that dictates "bet the oldest horse in the race." Those who went along with that theory tonight caught the winner of the featured Old Westbury Class A mile pace.
WHITE PLAINS, June 23 -- New shopping centers in Westchester are creating so many municipal problems that a meeting to consider remedies has been called for next Monday night.

The extraordinary mystery of the disappearance from New York in March, 1956, of the Spanish-Basque scholar, Jesus de Galindez, now emerges as more sinister but a little less mysterious than before. Impressive evidence, reported yesterday in this newspaper in a Washington dispatch by Anthony Lewis, links Galindez to the missing young American pilot, Gerald Murphy, and in so doing more than ever points the finger of suspicion at the Dominican Republic.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's message to Congress on an agreement between the United States and the European Atomic Energy Community (Euratom):
GLENDALE, Calif., June 23 (UPI) -- The racing world paid its final tribute today to Jack Westrope, who died last Thursday after being thrown by a horse during a race at Hollywood Park.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (UPI) -- Representative Albert W. Cretella, Republican of Connecticut, today put before the House a "compromise" plan for settling a dispute over bringing professional sports under the antitrust laws.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- At least a dozen prominent United States scientists will advise the Western delegation at the forthcoming Geneva talks on policing a nuclear test ban, officials said today.
Jaywalkers continued on their uninhibited ways yesterday as the city's pedestrian protection law went into effect.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 23 -- The stage was being set today at the Paramount studio for a new kind of production activity -- oil drilling.
A former member of a Nazi slave labor camp was sentenced yesterday to Sing Sing Prison for a twenty-year-to-life term for the fatal stabbing of his former wife in Brooklyn.
President Theodor Heuss of West Germany sailed for home yesterday after a twenty-day visit to this country. He expressed thanks for United States friendship and hospitality.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- The Supreme Court, citing the adage that every man's home is his castle, freed a man today described by a dissenting justice as a wholesale narcotics violator.

TORONTO, June 23 -- Owners and managers of office buildings in large cities across the continent are beginning to worry about the day, which many believe is not far off, when they will no longer have full or almost-full occupancy of their structures.

PITTSBURGH, June 23 (UPI) -- The St. Louis Cardinals capitalized on shoddy defensive play by the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight for a 7-5 victory. The Cards sewed up the game with three runs in the eighth inning.
Richard (Pancho) Gonzales won the round-robin Tournament of Tennis Champions for the second successive time in the Forest Hills Stadium last night.

TAIPEI, Formosa, June 23 (AP) -- Vice Admiral Austin K. Doyle the top United States commander on Formosa, rallied to the defense today of Admiral Burke. Admiral Doyle conceded that he was sticking his neck out.
A Federal judge in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that the Federal and state governments had a legal right to spray Long Island areas with DDT from airplanes to cope with the gypsy moth menace.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The National Housing Administrator took issue today with Democratic Senators who sought to give local housing authorities power to raise family income limits for public housing eligibility.

Directors of the Hercules Motors Corporation took no action yesterday on the common stock dividend normally payable July 1. The last payment was 20 cents on Sept. 1, 1957. On the Big Board the stock closed at 15 1/8, down one point on the day.

After a twenty-day tour of this country President Theodor Heuss has sailed for his homeland. He came here as the first German head of state to pay us a formal visit of state. He came also on what he termed a personal journey of discovery. On both counts the visit proved to be a signal success.

GENEVA, June 23 (Reuters) -- The seventy-nine-nation International Labor Organization conference today adopted a convention and a recommendation caling on members to eliminate discrimination in the employment of workers.
Governor Harriman called upon President Eisenhower yesterday to speak out against racial discrimination.
LONDON, June 24 -- Five maverick Conservative members of Parliament headed back toward the party herd tonight.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. has filed suit in United States District Court, Wilmington, Del., charging the Phillips Petroleum Company and a subsidiary, Phillips Chemical Company, with infringing on a du Pont patent on linear polyethylene plastic.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads today estimated that rail freight loadings in the third quarter of this year will be about 13 per cent below the 1957 level.
The International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday the election of William H. Moore and Bruce Bromley as directors. They will fill vacancies on the board.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 24 (UPI) -- The Government granted a blanket pardon to political prisoners today and invited political refugees to return home to take part in next month's parliamentary elections.
ALEXANDER SMALLENS, beginning his twenty-fifth season as a conductor at Lewisohn Stadium, led an all-orchestral program last night.

Futures prices closed generally higher yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Cocoa, cottonseed oil, copper, lead, zinc, wool and soybean oil rose; sugar and hides declined, and price movements for coffee, potatoes and rubber were mixed.

The Shubert theatre enterprises yesterday failed to obtain a court modification of a consent judgment involving disposition within two years of their interests in twelve theatres in a number of cities.

CINCINNATI, June 24 UP) -- Los Angeles' last-place Dodgers dropped the Cincinnati. Redlegs to fourth place in the National League tonight by a twilight-night "program, 13 -- 10 and 7 -- 2, both in extra innings.
Leonard W. Hall of Oyster Bay, L. I., will resume his upstate quest for support for the Republican nomination for Governor today.

GENEVA, June 24 -- The Soviet Union has invited the International Labor Organization to conduct a first-hand survey of Soviet trade union practices. This was announced today by David A. Morse, the labor agency's director general.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 24 (UPI) -- Donald M. (AB) Justice of Oklahoma State fired a 3-under-par 68 for a 139 today to take the early lead for the medal in the National Collegiate golf tournament. However, he shared the spotlight with a course record-equalling 67 shot by Tommy Aaron of Florida.

VICTORIA, B. C., June 24 (Canadian Press) -- The British Columbia Government took over Black Ball Ferries Ltd today to prevent a seamen's strike and maintain a sea link between Vancouver Island and the mainland.
ALGIERS, June 24 -- Europeans here commented that Premier Charles de Gaulle's policy for Algeria described today was a far cry from their own convictions and hopes.
PARIS, June 24 (AP) -- The French Finance Ministry disclosed today details of a fiscal amnesty on repatriation of French foreign investment holdings.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 24 -- There is nothing new under the sun. In an incredible guest appearance with the New York Philharmonic at Carnegie Hall last March, Danny Kaye did a wonderfully zany take-off on a virtuoso conductor. In Brussels tonight the Chamber Opera Theatre of Buenos Aires performed a little intermezzo by Cimarosa written well over a century and half ago, which poked genial fun at a bumbling, pompous maestro.
Big industrial concerns are anxious to get easier terms for writing off the cost of machinery or plant expansion, but they are only lukewarm toward a five-year write-off proposal in the tax laws.
"WIN WITH A WINNER" could turn into a better show than its initial outing on Channel 4 indicated last night.

The St. Paul Building on Broadway at Ann Street is definitely coming down within three months to make room for a modern skyscraper. The three heroic figures by the famous sculptor Karl Bitter which are featured over the entrance portal are to be rescued and saved for posterity through the wisdom and civic pride of the owners of the property, the Western Electric Company.

Whales will fly for the first time soon. Two are booked for a trip from Alaska to the Aquarium at Coney Island within forty-eight hours. The baby mammals, of the Boluga variety, weigh about 500 pounds each and are about eight feet long.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., June 24 -- Federal District Judge Justin C. Morgan ruled against the Tuscarora Indians today in their attempt to halt appropriation of 1,383 acres of their reservation for a Niagara power project storage reservoir.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 24 -- A program for rehabilitation of the motion-picture industry was proposed today by Irving Bernstein, associate research historian of the Institute of Industrial Relations, University of California at Los Angeles.
Stocks moved irregularly down yesterday in moderately active trading. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was 2,560,000 shares, compared with 2,340,000 on Monday.
Princeton was moved up to fourth and California was dropped to fifth in the official placings of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association's varsity race following a review of the films yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 24 (UPI) -- Favored Brazil and host Sweden qualified today for the final of the World Soccer Cup. Brazil beat France, 5 -- 2, and Sweden defeated Western Germany, the defending champion, 3 -- 1.
NEWARK, June 24 -- The Prudential Insurance Company of America announced today plans for a twenty-story, $12,000,000 headquarters in downtown Toronto.
COLUMBIA, S. C., June 24 (AP) -- Ernest F. (Fritz) Hollings, a Charleston lawyer, won a smashing victory today in the Democraatic primary for Governor of South Carolina.

CAPE CANAVERAL, June 24 -- The Navy claimed success this morning in an experiment with the components of its Polaris missile. It tried to forget last night's failure with a water-logged Vanguard satellite-bearing rocket.
RYE, N. Y., June 24 -- The Chrysler Corporation tonight dedicated a school for its dealers in nine northeastern states.

Angier Biddle Duke, president of the International Rescue Committee, last night called on President Eisenhower and Congress to support in a practical way the designation of 1959 as World Refugee Year.
Cotton futures moved 15 points up to 15 points off in active trading on the New York Cotton Exchange.
A basic real estate tax rate of $4.16 for each $100 of assessed valuation of property was set yesterday by the City Council for the fiscal year beginning next Tuesday.
Offerings of corporate debt securities amounting to $47,000,000 are being made to investors today.
Another act in a corporate drama that began almost a year ago was played yesterday when Leopold D. Silberstein, president of Penn-Texas Corporation, resigned.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- In 1942 a young and wealthy North Carolinian named Gordon Gray declined an officer's commission and enlisted in the Army as a private. Seven years later he became Secretary of the Army in the Truman Administration.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 24 -- Ramac knows, and Adlai E. Stevenson is here to prove it.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Two leading university economists, writing in early April, told Congress the nation was probably in for a major depression. Their views were disclosed today by the Senate Finance Committee.
BUFFALO, N. Y., June 24 (AP) -- A compromise in a legal dispute over the sale of Spokane International Railroad to Union Pacific Railroad was approved here today in New York State Supreme Court.
The Transit Authority announced yesterday that it would spend more money -- and lose more -- in the next fiscal year than ever before in its five-year history.

PARIS, June 24 (UPI) -- Premier Charles de Gaulle and Gen. Lauris Norstad, Supreme Aliled Commander, Europe, reviewed France's role in the Western alliance today amid reports that General de Gaulle wanted a greater voice in Atlantic pact strategy.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Following are excerpts from the testimony today by Edward N. Gadsby, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, before the House Subcommittee on Legislative Oversight:
The Red Cross blood bank received 394 pints from donors in the metropolitan area yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (UPI) -- The House of Representatives, overriding complaints that it was wasting millions of dollars on new offices, voted $95,942,113 today to finance its operations in the fiscal year that begins July 1.
MOSCOW, June 24 (UPI) -- The Soviet Government sent workmen to clean and repair the mob-wrecked West German Embassy today and said it would foot the bill. But there was no apology.

A distinguished cuisine, attentive but unobtrusive service and pleasant surroundings are the factors that ultimately contribute to a restaurant's reputation. There is a felicitous fusion of these elements in the new Dorchester restaurant, which opened recently at 110 East Fifty-seventh Street.

It was eight years ago today that the Communists staged their murderous assault upon the free Republic of Korea. Much has happened in those eight years and this is, therefore, a good time for taking stock.

The courteous and pleasant formality of new Ambassadors presenting their credentials to the President of the United States is usually on the colorless and perfunctory side. There was an exception to this rule on Monday when Dr. Cesar Barros Hurtado became Argentina's new envoy to Washington.
ALGIERS, June 25 -- The French Army said today that its position in the Algerian war was more favorable than ever despite a recent rise in rebel activity.

An examination of the present status of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization will be published July 9 by Harper for the Council on Foreign Relations. The title will be "NATO and the Future of Europe." The volume has been written by Ben T. Moore, a former official of the State Department and now associate director of the Twentieth Century Fund.
BATON ROUGE, La., June 24 (UPI) -- With only one voice in opposition, the Louisiana Senate passed six school segregation bills today.

PARIS, June 24 -- When Dulles arrives next week for his first tour of the political horizon with General de Gaulle he will find that horizon for the most part pleasantly bland. The new French Government is sticking faithfully by its treaty obligations including, above all, the North Atlantic alliance.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly today to exempt most aspects of the major professional team sports from the antitrust laws.
Two new issues of debt securities of the High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community are being offered today to investors here and abroad.

TORONTO, June 24 (Canadian Press) -- Difficulties in foreign exchange and trade are formidable, but there are signs of future developments holding great promise, Henry Borden, president of Brazilian Traction, Light and Power Company, said today at the company's annual meeting.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 24 -- Information available here tonight left the situation in the North Celebes battle between Government and Indonesian rebel forces in a state of considerable confusion.

United States Attorney Paul W. Williams refused yesterday to identify the labor writer whose telephone call to a woman juror caused her to be dropped from the jury trying the Hoffa wiretap conspiracy case.

BRIG. GEN. MILTON SMITH LITTLEFIELD, "a good soldier" in the opinion of his superior officer, William Tecumseh Sherman, was one of the handsomest men who served in the Union Army. For a few years after the war he was one of the most admired and despised, popular and hated, wealthy and influential men in North Carolina and Florida.
FARGO, N. D., Wednesday, June 25 -- Senator William Larger won Republican renomination for a fourth term early today.

LONDON, June 24 -- Gov. Sir Hugh Foot of Cyprus arrived tonight to report to the Government on the islanders' reaction to the new British plan for governing the island. He will also consult with colonial authorities on implementing the plan.
WASHINGTON, June 24--Soviet charges of United States-British intervention in Lebanon are an obvious attempt to divert attention from the execution of Imre Nagy, State Department officials said today.
A pro-celebrity competition today will serve as a prelude to the $50,000 Pepsi golf tournament at the Pine Hollow Country Club, East Norwich, L. I.

A second major brewery announced last night that it would shut down because of a labor dispute. The announcement was accompanied by mounting indications that all the city's major breweries would suspend operations by Friday.
The transactions of Louis E. Wolfson in shares of the American Motors Corporation were brought to a halt yesterday by action of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, June 25 -- The Soviet Government cleared the way today for the start of a meeting in Geneva next Tuesday between Eastern and Western experts on the detection of nuclear weapons tests.
LOCUST VALLEY, L. I. -- A tired Tommy Bolt, the United States Open golf champion, failed to complete his round in a charity pro-amateur tournament today.

NEWARK, June 24 -- The Board of Education voted tonight to dismiss two teachers who had used the Fifth Amendment in reply to questions about Communist affiliations in appearances theree years ago before the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

OTTAWA, June 24 (Canadian Press) -- Fast-moving demolition crews wil have less than forty-eight hours in which to remove equipment along twenty-five miles of the old Cornwall and Williamsburg canal systems before the historic channels disappear beneath the St. Lawrence Seaway.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (UPI) -- A Senate-House conference committee reached agreement today on a $1,556,225,600 river and harbor authorization bill. It would replace a measure vetoed three months ago by President Eisenhower.

The Columbia Broadcasting System announced last night that a Long Island woman had in effect repudiated an affidavit attributed to her in the Morris L. Ernst report on the disappearance of Dr. Jesus de Galindez.

The Arabian American Oil Company plans capital expenditures this year of $63,000,000, according to the company's report on operations for 1957 to the Saudi Arabian Government. This would compare with expenditures of $56,000,000 in 1957.

The public is an innocent bystander in the recent talks between the Transport Workers Union, the Motormen's Benevolent Association and the peacemakers who are trying to bring the M. B. A. into a merger with the T. W. U. Yet the public does have an interest in this effort, and it seems to us that everybody will be better off if the peace effort succeeds.

NEW HAVEN, June 24 (AP) -- A Federal judge today invited Governor Foster Furcolo and other high Massachusetts officers and officials of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad to meet in his chambers tomorrow on the Old Colony line case.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 24 -- The Soviet Union demanded today that the United Nations Trusteeship Council call a halt to United States nuclear weapons tests in the Pacific.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 24 (AP) -- A candidate for Governor and a one-time campaign treasurer denied today knowledge of an alleged $20,000 pay-off in Teamster Union funds to Judge Raulston Schoolfield.
CHICAGO, June 24 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- Aristotle S. Onassis told legislators today that a previous hearing had cost him $2,000,000.

JOCKO CONLAN is an umpire who was educated in the Bill Klem school. That means he had the best tutelege any arbiter could get because there never was anyone like the self-styled Old Arbitrator, the man whose proudest boast was: "I never missed one in my life."
HARTFORD, June 24 -- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff failed today to win a no-primary pledge from the three candidates for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator.

MONTAUK POINT, L. I., June 24 -- These are the times that try the souls of all salt-water fishermen who cannot kick the habit. The season has been crouched to jump for so long that it has baggy pants, but it can't get off the ground. Wise old heads are so nervous that they have almost stopped making predictions.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Opponents of Alaskan statehood challenged the constitutionality of admission legislation in Senate debate today.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission swore today that there was "no shred of evidence to suggest" Bernard Goldfine, the Boston industrialist, had received preferred treatment from the agency because of his friendship with Sherman Adams.
President Carlos P. Garcia of the Philippines yesterday advocated an economic offensive in the Far East to deal with Communist encroachments.

MOSCOW, June 24 -- The Soviet Union accused the United States Government and the New York police today of having encouraged "rowdyism" and "hooliganism" against the headquarters of the Soviet delegation to the United Nations.

LONDON, June 24 -- According to British officials and diplomats, events in Lebanon are moving in favor of President Nasser's United Arab Republic. Lebanon was described as "drifting" slowly out of the Western sphere of influence toward Pan-Arabism.
BOSTON, June 24 (AP) -- Dr. Paul Dudley White said today the heart of the late Clarence DeMar was not damaged at all by more than 200 long-distance races, including scores of marathons.

WASHINGTON, June 24 (UPI) -- The Senate Agriculture Committee unanimously approved a pared-down farm bill today granting the Administration's requests for lower price supports and more planting freedom for farmers.

DOBBS FERRY, N. Y., June 24 -- By a vote of 1,381 to 1,158 the electorate of this Hudson Valley village today turned down a $600,000 school expansion plan. The issue had stirred bitter local controversy. When the results of the voting were announced tonight those who had fought the proposition staged a horn-honking automobile parade through the center of town.

A recent item in the paper announced a joint project of the New York Subways Advertising Company, the Greenwich Village Association and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The project was to put reproductions of famous paintings in subway stations. It was explained that the paintings would be used to fill the spaces where advertising posters had been taken down, after the contracts for the advertisements had expired.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- The country's Better Business Bureaus were urged today to enlist in a campaign of teaching the public how to spot "gyp" advertising and what to do about it.
CHICAGO, June 24 -- Mickey Mantle ended his home run drought tonight and the blow produced some explosive results.
LAVISH praise is due the bridal collection at Rosette Pennington for its refreshing simplicity.
Fifty crew members of the oil barge and Swedish freighter that collided this morning in the East River jumped for their lives to decks of rescue vessels or into flame-covered waters.
OTTAWA, June 24 (UPI) -- Canada's imports from the United States continued to decrease in May, while those from the United Kingdom continued to increase, the Government revealed today.

James R. Hoffa, who has spent a good part of the last year in Federal courtrooms and Senate hearing chambers, now has a chance to demonstrate whether he really means to clean up the giant International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
LONDON, June 24 (AP) -- Spider Webb, a middleweight contender from Chicago, and Hogan (Kid) Bassey of Nigeria, the world featherweight champion, won bouts tonight on the same program.

Copies of forty volumes from the Tibetan Tripitaka, recently reprinted in Japan, will be displayed today at a ceremonial tea and reception at the American Buddhist Academy, 331 Riverside Drive, near 106th Street.
DETROIT, June 24 -- Officers of the United Automobile Workers acted today to end the wildcat strike at the Chrysler Corporation's missile plant near here.

BELO HORIZONTE, Brazil, June 24 -- The United States delegation to the International Investments Conference here described today as premature plans for multilateral agreements for the protection of investments in foreign countries.
LONDON, June 24 -- According to information here, Ceylon is threatened by an explosion of religious hatred and nationalist ambitions worse than the one that recently caused 300 to 500 deaths.

MILWAUKEE, June 24 (AP) -- Warren Spahn, backed by the home runs of Ed Mathews and Joe Adcock, stopped the Giants on three hits tonight as the Milwaukee Braves went 3 1/2 games in front in the National League race with a 2-1 victory that dropped San Francisco into third place.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 24 -- The time has come to assume that viruses are responsible for most kinds of cancer and to execute research accordingly, a Nobel Prize winner suggested here today.
A performance by the Blue Hill Troupe, Ltd., amateur Savoyards, at the Pequot Library in Southport, Conn., on Saturday evening will benefit the work of the library.
The United States Steel Corporation has decided to proceed with a public offering of $300,000,000 of sinking fund debentures -- one of the largest ever made by an industrial company.

The Southern Railway reported its net income yesterday for the first five months this year at $11,303,223, equal to $1.55 a common share. In the corresponding period of 1957 the net was $13,970,166, or $1.95 a common share.

CAIRO, June 24 (AP) -- An Egyption court of appeals has revoked a thirteen-month jail sentence given United States archeologist, Charles Arthur Muses on charges of trying to take antiquities out of Egypt illegally.

ATHENS, June 24 -- Foreign Minister Evangelos Averoff- Tositsas said tonight that "tension between Greece and Turkey poses the question of the redployment and reorganization of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization commands in the southeast in the very near future."
TRENTON, June 24 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner rebuked the now-recessed Assembly today for the first time.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Consumer prices pushed upward to another record in May.

Seymour Shapiro resigned yesterday from the Urban Renewal Company, Inc. At the same time he asserted his innocence of Charges that he had received kickbacks from a contractor while he was an officer of the Nassau Management Company.

A LITTLE short of 165 years ago, Thomas Benger, a Bucks County, Pa., horse-breeder brought to New York by rail and ferry the swift stallion Messenger, for whom the $100,000 annual Messenger Stake, a harness race, is named.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., June 24 -- Mrs. Bernard Freeman of the Inwood Country Club posted a 39, 40 -- 79 to take a one-stroke lead in the women's Long Island Golf Association 54-hole medal play championship at the Hempstead Golf Club today.
LONDON, June 24 -- The stock market here turned dull today after a week or more of rising prices and there were widespread small losses.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 24 -- The American Federation of Musicians announced the signing today of a five-year contract with Desilu Productions, Inc., to use "live" musicians in the recording of scores for television films.

The semi-annual report of the Avco Manufacturing Corporation disclosed yesterday an increase of 19 per cent in the consolidated net income in the six months ended May 31. The profit was $6,210,485, compared with $5,232,621 a year earlier.
Six new films open at local theatres today.
RANGOON, Burma, June 24 -- Premier Nu appealed tonight to the insurgents still fighting in the jungles against the Burmese Government to "come out into the light and lay down your arms."
Mayor Wagner told a meeting of leaders of Flushing, Queens, yesterday that a lack of good home life and the absence of religious training were the two causes of juvenile delinquency.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 24 -- The steep and isolated valleys of the Shouf are just three wrecked bridges, several ambushes, and an hour's tortuous mountain driving east of the coast road from Beirut to Saida (Sidon).
RIVERHEAD, L. I., June 24 -- Long Island potatoes were planted this spring in 49,172 acres of farm land by 670 of the 711 remaining farmers on the island, a state survey reported here today.

Picketing by steamship office workers belonging to Local 153 of the Office Employes International Union halted operations at the Pan-Atlantic Steamship Corporation's Port Newark terminal for three hours yesterday.
A freighter and an oil barge collided in the East River shortly after midnight. An explosion and fire that followed set the roadway of the Manhattan Bridge ablaze.
WARSAW, June 24 -- A heavy sense of rising pressures and quickly approaching decisions dominated political Warsaw today.

TORONTO, June 24 -- The disappearance of elevator operators from office skyscrapers appeared more certain than ever today. Building owners and managers reported overwhelming public acceptance of the practice.
MOSCOW, June 24 -- The Soviet Union charged again today that the United States and other Western powers were preparing for armed intervention in the internal affairs of Lebanon.
NEWARK, June 24 (AP) -- A Ridgefield, N. J., appliance store seeks $750,000 damages in an antitrust suit aaginst the Radio Corporation of America and five distributors.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24 -- Four thousand members of the group that has probably done more than any other to influence the eating habits and cooking procedures of Americans in the last half century gathered here today for their forty-ninth annual meeting.

ROME, June 24 (UPI) -- Carmine de Sapio, New York Democratic party leader, told Italian emigration officials today that he would do all he could to bring about reunions of Italians with relatives in the United States.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) -- Foreign trade organizations told the Senate Finance Committee today that the reciprocal trade extension bill as passed by the House was too restrictive.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy, overruling Administration objections, approved today a large-scale expansion in plutonium production and basic nuclear reseach.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 24 -- Althea Gibson of New York strode majestically on the Center Court today and slaughtered Australia's pert Margaret Hellyer, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 2. The execution was quick and merciless.

THERE was a cake and twenty-eight candles. But it wasn't anyone's birthday. However, twenty-eight separate "birthdays" had taken place some time before, "birthdays" that united twenty-eight children and fifty-six parents in a new life together through adoption.
LONDON, June 24 -- A survey by the Federation of British Industries published today showed that many business men were less optimistic about economic conditions than they were a few months ago.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 24 -- Nyland Hanover, a 4-year-old bay horse owned by Cleo A. Young of Timmonsville, S. C., took the featured Boys Club event at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Driven by Clint Hodgins, Nyland Hanover paced the mile in 2:04.

An advance in finishing corduroy, a cotton fabric often fashioned into work and casual clothing, was announced yesterday by the innovator, Rubin Levine, president of Rubin Levine Co., Inc., textile converter.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Eight members of the House Education and Labor Committee got after their chairman today to hurry action on a bill requiring all welfare and pension funds to make full public reports on their financial activities. The Senate passed the bill April 28.
Australia, the world's largest wool grower, is cooling to its own product, according to F. G. James, retiring chairman of the Australian Knitting Industries Council.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 24 (Reuters) -- A controversy about mixed bathing in open-air swimming pools increased in intensity today.
The role of labor unions in education and health was praised yesterday by Governor Harriman. He urged a joint effort by labor and management in the area of preventive medicine.

THERE goes the bride at Bloomingdale's. Since wedding guests must stare at the bride's back during most of the church ceremony, this store has wisely concentrated on backs in its fall wedding fashions.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 24 -- If the United Nations does not act quickly for peace in Lebanon, President Camille Chamoun is expected to ask the West for troops to help restore order.

Bold Ruler's trainer, Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons, will run the 4-year-old colt in today's Stymie Handicap at Belmont Park. The 83-year-old trainer yesterday was faced with the decision as to whether he would "go" in the Stymie or in Saturday's Roseben.
The Executive and Legislative branches of the Government were in conflict again yesterday about control of the nation's military forces.
BOSTON, June 24 -- The Rev. Dr. Ray E. Phillips, a social service worker in South Africa since 1918, was elected today as moderator of the General Council of the Congregational Christian Churches.

Arrangements have been completed for the annual Summer Day Country Fair to be held tomorrow on the grounds of the St. Johnland Home for the Aged at Kings Park, L. I. Proceeds will go to the home, a ninety-two-year-old nonprofit, nonsectarian institution.

The Bulova Watch Company, Inc., in its fiscal year ended March 31 had a net income of $2,232,738, equal to $1.15 a share on 1,949286 shares outstanding. Net income in the preceding fiscal year was $3,401,068, or $1.74 a share. Earnings before taxes were $4,157,738, compared with $7,081,068.
The Flintkote Company is expanding its building materials business into Utah with the acquisition of the Utah Lime and Stone Company.

Unions representing television performers appeared before the National Labor Relations Board here yesterday to discuss a proposal for a referendum that would cover jurisdiction over taped commercials.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- Gordon Gray, Director of the Office of Defense Mobilization, was named today to succeed Robert Cutler as President Eisenhower's Special Assistant for National Security Affairs.
We wish to congratulate you on the fine editorial of June 18 on the Blue Cross rate increase.
Smog stopped the Rikers Island Ferry as well as flights to and from both major airports here yesterday.
STRATFORD, Ont., June 24 -- In its contest with "Henry IV, Part I," the Canadian Shakespeare Company emerges as victor, scoring by the point system.

The Consolidated Edison Company has offered to supply two extra roadways on the heavily traveled Queensboro Bridge if the company is permitted to string power cables under the bridge, the Department of Public Works reported last night.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The State Department disclosed today that it would no longer require passport applicants to answer form questions about Communist party membership.
BOWLING GREEN, Ohio, June 24 -- Agreement among the states to permit qualified teachers to serve throughout the country was urged here today.

Operation off a successful "scuderia" (sports car racing stable) can be expensive. One way to cut the cost is to recruit a number of young executives who hold competition licenses -- say nine or ten -- add an expert mechanic and look around for some machinery.
JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, June 24 -- The United Jewish Appeal opened here tonight its first national assemblage outside the United States in its twenty years.
SYRACUSE, June 24 -- The Conference of Republican State Senators asked Governor Harriman today to call a special session of the Legislature to pass a labor-management practices bill.
Permit me to express a minority view regarding the almost universally recognized need to increase international monetary liquidity.

PARIS, June 24 -- Andre Malraux, Government spokesman, said today that France, under Premier Charles de Gaulle, had regained her sense of mission -- to reconcile Frenchmen with each other and with the North African Moslems in a major renaissance.
A favorable climate for the textile industry in the rest of this year was predicted yesterday by A. W. Zelomek, president of the International Statistical Bureau, Inc.

Labor Commissioner Harold A. Felix made public yesterday rules to be followed in the certification of civil service unions under the city's "Little Wagner Act." The rules implement an executive order signed by Mayor Wagner three months ago that extends to municipal employes many of the union rights enjoyed by workers in private industry.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 24 -- Patricia Stewart of Kew Gardens, Queens, who heads the draw; Bonnie Mencher of Forest Hills, Queens, seeded No. 5, and Carolyn Liguori of Brooklyn entered the quarter-final round of the women's New York State tennis championship at the Beach Point Club today.

WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Administration failed to make peace today with Senator Richard B. Russell in the dispute over the military chiefs' right to testify with impunity against President Eisenhower's Pentagon reorganization program.
WASHINGTON, June 24 -- The Premier of Afghanistan, Prince Mohammed Daud, was entertained by President Eisenhower today at the start of a three-day official visit.
Two thousand miles of white paint -- in most places long ribbons of it -- make one of the most versatile and least expensive control methods used by Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley.
Walter J. Sheerin, president of the Uniformed Firemen's Association, denied yesterday that there was any unwarranted "absenteeism" in the department.

Congratulations on your June 19 editorial calling for voting machines in the Aug. 12 primary in contested areas such as the Seventeenth Congressional District. This is a public service. Few things are as important as safeguarding the secret ballot.
