WASHINGTON, June 24 -- President Eisenhower's special envoy to the Brussels World's Fair reported back today with generally favorable views. However, he recommended changing some features of the United States exhibit that have been criticized by American tourists and members of Congress.

Defeat finally overtook Richard (Pancho) Gonzales last night in the final singles match of the $15,000 round-robin tournament of champions at Forest Hills, Queens. Never theless he finished on top and received first prize money of $3,000.
Some 13,000 students were graduated yesterday from the city's academic and vocational high schools.

CHICAGO, June 24 (AP) -- Grain futures encountered good buying support in the final few minutes on the Board of Trade today. Almost all grain contracts finished with gains after absorbing moderate selling.

A thunderous explosion and spectacular flames shooting more than one hundred feet into the air attracted thousands to the East River shorelines of Brooklyn and Manhattan early this morning. The entire skyline of lower Manhattan was illuminated by the blaze.
Maryland borrowed $25,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance road building.

WILMINGTON, Del., June 24 (AP) -- Miss Lydia C. du Pont, 50 years old, of near-by Point Lookout Farm, was killed today in the collision of an automobile and a truck about six miles west of Wilmington.
Many of the nation's retailers are not buying slogans such as "Buy Now" or "Operation Upturn."

NEW ORLEANS, June 24 -- Andrew H. Berding, Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs, said yesterday that Soviet censorship of dispatches from foreign correspondents in Moscow had become "increasingly severe and arbitrary" in recent weeks.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 25 -- First Mate, a six-time winner in 1957, but virtually out of sight this year, won the featured Class A mile pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. The 6-year-old chestnut gelding, blanked in five previous outings this season, triumphed by three-quarters of a length in a creditable 2:04 4/5 clocking.
ZURICH, Switzerland, June 25 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Orchestra received a standing ovation in Zurich's Concert Auditorium last night.

ONE of the most uncompromising task-masters in college football is Paul (Bear) Bryant, now of Alabama. Some of the boys were talking about him the other day and attributing much of his success to the rigorous way he or enforces discipline. He demands unquestioning obedience. He gets it, too.

This is the time of year when most of us participate in the secular ritual of sunbathing. During the next few weeks our sun, a dwarf star only 865,400 miles in diameter and about 93,000,000 miles away, will pour out radiation at its usual rate.
More than $56,000,000 in new corporate and utility debt and equity securities are being offered to investors today. The issues are:
YORK HARBOR, Me., June 25 (AP) -- Winners of national prizes in the annual Garden Club of America competitions were announced at the group's annual meeting tonight.

These are times that try trainmen's souls. The kids are leaving for camp this week. In seven days starting today, 33,000 youngsters will pass through -- and the term is used loosely -- Grand Central Terminal. Another 4,000 will ruffle Pennsylvania Station.

EAST NORWICH, L. I., June 25 -- Billy Casper Jr. of Apple Valley, Calif., equaled the course record of 67 at the Pine Hollow Country Club today and about an hour later Bob Rosburg of Palo Alto, Calif., also tied the mark.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPI) --The House Banking Committee approved a bill today to permit $250,000,000 in Federal funds to be invested in small businesses through privately-owned investment corporations. The vote was 17 to 4.

The Pennsylvania Railroad reported yesterday another deficit for last month. The carrier announced a net loss for May of $4,637,500. It brought the deficit for the first five months of 1958 to $24,264,400.

" CONSCIOUSESS IN CONCORD,"* by Perry Miller, is the best book about Thoreau I have read since Brooks Atkinson's "Henry Thoreau, the Cosmic Yankee." It includes the strayed journal Thoreau wrote in 1840-41, now in the Morgan Library. Teeing off from that small, immortal mound of gnomic lore, Mr. Miller drives deep into the world where Thoreau led, as he famously said the mass of men lead, lives of quiet desperation.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- A nation-wide study of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, commonly known as Lou Gehrig's disease, is under way. The aim is to learn what causes the mysterious neurological disease that killed Mr. Gehrig, the baseball star.

Electric Bond and Share Company looks for 1958 net income "within a few cents of the total for 1957," George G. Walker, president, said at the annual meeting yesterday in 2 Rector Street. The company reported last year net equal to $1.46 a share, the highest for twenty-six years.
PARIS, June 25 -- Foreign Minister Maurice Couve de Murville declared today that France did not intend to alter her foreign policies radically.
CHICAGO, June 25 -- The role and responsibility of religion in the area of mental health has become a major concern among the leaders of this country's major faiths.
Stocks rose yesterday. The advance was general and sustained throughout most of the trading session. In the last half hour there was some profit-taking.
CHICAGO, June 25 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

EAST NORWICH, L. I., June 25 -- Big league golf came to the Pine Hollow Country Club today. Only four years ago Jerry Wolk, the owner with Irv Fagenson, gave the order to begin construction of the golf course. A year later the first Club members played.

Your editorial of June 23 entitled "In the Defense Controversy" misses the point at issue as to Admiral Arleigh Burke's testimony before the Senate Armed Services Committee, in which the Chief of Naval Operations expressed frankly his disagreement with two sections of President Eisenhower's reorganization plan.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Thursday, June 26 (AP) -- The General Electric Company announced today it was developing a radically new rocket engine capable of launching a satellite weighing as much as ten tons.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 25 -- Eight Middle Eastern countries have registered gains in production and in income over the last five years, the United Nations said today in its annual survey of the area. Government expenditures on development have risen so rapidly, however, that deficits have resulted in most instances.
NEWARK, June 25 -- The Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today to increase intrastate fares by 3 cents.
" HE'S a real rock in a tight pinch." That is a seaman's assessment of Capt. George Whisler Holtzman, the Coast Guard's Acting Captain of the Port of New York.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The United States accused the Soviet Government today of having organized the demonstrations in Moscow against the Danish, West German and United States Embassies.

Dewey Carver, realty investor, announced preliminary plans yesterday for a twenty-five-story store and office building at Church and Murray Streets. He bought the property there two years ago from Columbia University.

Major Alexander P. de Seversky called yesterday for a single department of air and space. He said integration of the programs now conducted separately by the Armed Services was the only sound strategy for nuclear war.
HACKENSACK, N. J., June 25 -- Construction of the second stage of the Bergen County trunk sewer system got under way today with a ceremony at River Street and County Place here.
CHICAGO, June 25 (AP) -- Corn futures contracts moved toward new high prices for the season in all deliveries on the Board of Trade today, while wheat came close to new lows.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 25 (AP) -- A 14-year-old girl with her heart opened was awakened on the operating table to demonstrate the value of hynotism in surgery, a physician told the American Medical Association today.
A NOTE for prospective brides: The house of Valens, famous Brussels couturier, is reviving the tradition of the "flowering hearts" for Belgian weddings.

The number of unemployed workers in the state receiving insurance benefits declined last week to 416,500, the year's lowest since Feb. 14. The drop was 7,900, compared with the previous week, but last week's figure was 89 per cent above the same period in 1957.
BOWLING GREEN, Ohio, June 25 -- Efforts to raise the level of the nation's school programs must place high priority on obtaining better trained, more knowledgeable teachers.

MOSCOW, June 25 -- The Soviet Union declared tonight that it would not take part in talks on means of detecting tests of nuclear weapons unless the United States agreed that the immediate cessation of such tests was the "goal."

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The United States Government made it clear today that it would leave to the Soviet Union the onus of breaking off the imminent Geneva talks on measures to police a nuclear test ban.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Senate leaders remained firm tonight in their prediction that the Territory of Alaska would be admitted as the forty-ninth state.

ALTHOUGH weather prophets predict a moderately cool summer, the arrival of the season inevitably brings to mind top-of-the-stove cookery. A somewhat neglected dish and one that is admirably suited to mode of preparation is fresh or smoked beef tongue. It is the basis for a multitude of delectable dishes and is equally delicious hot or cold.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPI) -- The House of Representatives voted 389 to 2 today to charter a group known as the Veterans of World War I.
A 10,000-ton Liberty ship anchored in New York harbor is in danger of being "torpedoed,'' Mrs. Betty H. Donnelly, secretary of the Maritime Educational Commission, reported yesterday.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 25 -- Roswell G. Ham Jr., 39-year-old Westport author, was acquitted today of arson after a judge had said he could not conscientiously find the defendant's actions those of a responsible person.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- The comments of key Senators indicated today the odds were against Senate action this year on a House-passed bill to exempt major professional team sports from the antitrust laws.

Robert Moses states that the Seventh Avenue approach for the proposed Narrows bridge is the only route approved by the Federal Bureau of Highways, therefore the only one that the Federal Government will subsidize at 90 per cent of cost.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 25 (AP) -- The biggest difficulty in Lebanon's crisis seemed today to be that no avenue of compromise was apparent. Various disparate groups of rebels seem to want all or nothing. They appear willing and ready to see their little country torn apart rather than give an inch.
Municipal Concerts, Inc., a new organization headed by Dr. Edwin Feigin, will present four huge outdoor concerts during August in cooperation with the Department of Parks.

Confronted with direct and indirect aggression by President Nasser's Soviet-backed United Arab Republic, the embattled Government of Lebanon has appealed to the United Nations for help. In a formal request to Secretary General Hammarskjold in Beirut, Lebanese Premier Sohl has called for a United Nations emergency force to seal off Lebanon's frontiers against further infiltration of Egyptian and Syrian "volunteers."

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed that in the week ended Wednesday, June 18, there were:

LOS ANGELES, June 25 (AP) -- An executive with a closed-circuit theatre television corporation was named today to replace Al Weill as promoter of a heavyweight title fight between Floyd Patterson and his challenger, Roy Harris.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Discount houses were praised by the Justice Department today as providing "a type of competition in the best traditions of our economy."
SAN FRANCISCO, June 25 -- None of a group of 335 individuals exposed to radar beams has suffered any ill effects, the A. M. A. was told today.

PARIS, June 25--Premier Charles de Gaulle took the first tentative steps today to restore a measure of civilian control over the military forces that have been supreme in Algeria since the May 13 uprising.

The election of Reginald R. Lawrence and Gilbert W. Fitzhugh as vice presidents of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company was announced yesterday by Frederic W. Ecker, president. Both were formerly second vice presidents.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Among those who have announced their retirement from Congress are members who are known to the American people for exceptional service, for their ability to stand out from the legislative mass, or for some other reason that has made them famous, or at any rate conspicuous.
A SECOND Shavian Festival entered the off-Broadway lists last night when "Mrs. Warren's Profession'' was revived at Second Avenue's Gate Theatre, six blocks north of "You Never Can Tell."
WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- The Senate Commerce Committee today approved a bill to create a new Federal aviation agency to regulate all air traffic. both civil and military.

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 25 (AP) -- The Brookfield Farms' undefeated Intentionally won the $26,250 Tyro Stake for 2-year-old colts and geldings at Monmouth Park today. The previously-unbeaten Easy Spur, owned by the Spring Hill Farm, was second, a length and a half back of the winner and two in advance of Reginald N. Webster's Royal Anthem.
Except for some delays in BMT subway service, traffic on the fire-damaged Manhattan Bridge operated normally yesterday.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 25 -- A Cambodian royal proclamation reported today that troops from neighboring South Vietnam had invaded and occupied several Cambodian border villages.
Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., yesterday confirmed reports that the company would move its headquarters from 666 Fifth Avenue to the West Coast.

WASHINTON, June 25 -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People is expected to move tomorrow for emergency Supreme Court action on the school integration case in Little Rock, Ark.
PHILADELPHIA, June 25 (AP) -- A Purdue University poll shows that high school students rate engineers high and scientists mighty low.

These menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are intended to balance appetite appeal with convenience for the family cook. Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe. Add bread and beverage as desired, unless specified.

Directors of Alco Products, Inc., Schenectady, N. Y., heavy equipment manufacturer, have authorized the redemption of the remaining 37,000 shares of preferred stock outstanding. The redemption price will be $115 a share, plus dividends accrued to Aug. 8, the redemption date.

Commodity futures closed irregularly higher yesterday on New York exchanges. Cocoa, wool, world sugar positions, copper, zinc and rubber rose; cotton seed oil, domestic sugar contracts - and coffee declined, and price movements for potatoes, soybean oil, hides and lead were mixed.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPI) -- A twelve-year-old boy has sent the Government a plan to rocket a man into space for two weeks. Scientists have said the plan is theoretically sound.
CHICAGO, June 25 -- "Ah, there, I see we're all here," said Casey Stengel, one manager who believes in open covenants openly arrived at. He really doesn't care where he holds a news conference.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- President Eisenhower has again rejected the suggestion of Senator Kefauver that he call a meeting of steel management and labor to discuss wages and prices.

The city's five breweries moved closer yesterday to a complete shutdown. One was already shut; a second stopped operations; a third said it would follow today, and the indications were that the two remaining would announce suspension of activities today.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 25 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion gave 500 United Jewish Appeal campaigners tonight a forecast of the future of Israel.

WARREN, Ark., June 25 (AP) -- Negotiations are being completed for the sale of the Bradley Lumber Company of Arkansas, Warren, for $20,000,000 to Potlatch Forests, Inc., of Lewiston, Idaho, it was reported yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, June 25 (AP) -- A Federal court today paved the way for the end of passenger service on the Old Colony Line, but there were indications this might not hap pen. District Judge Robert P. Anderson ordered Massachusetts not to interfere with plans of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad to stop service on the 10,000-commuter line in that state.
SYRACUSE, June 25 -- Republican State Senators decided today to make court reform a major issue in the fall campaign.
A $16,000,000 cement plant was put into full operation yesterday by the Lake Ontario Portland Cement Company, Ltd., on a ridge just outside Picton, Ont.

MONTAUK POINT, L. I., June 25 -- Nothing in nature happens without sound reason. There are sound reasons why no swordfish showed up in this neighborhood today, while school tuna were getting Jersey fishermen into a frenzy.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 25 -- Communist China was accused here today of plain bad manners toward the departing Yugoslav Ambassador in Peiping.
FARGO, N. D., June 25 -- Senator William L. Langer was overwhelmingly renominated by Republican voters yesterday for a fourth term.
MINEOLA, L. I., June 25 -- The Nassau County Board of Elections proposed today that a county-wide referendum on bingo be held at the general election Nov. 4.

" It looks as if some stock buyers think they have discovered uranium in tobacco," one broker grumped yesterday, commenting about the recent strength in Lorillard common. The stock had risen in price from 58 about three weeks ago to a high of 70 yesterday, only to drop back to close at 67, down 5/8 for the day, last year the stock ranged from 15 5/8 to 34.

The nation's gasoline stocks declined 2,268,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, supplies were 187,973,000 barrels, compared with 190,241,000 a week earlier and 189,225,000 a year ago.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 25 -- Spokesmen for the United States, British and French delegations said they would not decide their next move on the Lebanese question until they had considered the recommendations of Dag Hammarskjold, the United Nations Secretary General.

ROME, June 25 -- Amintore Fanfani, political secretary of the dominant Christian Democratic party, undertook today to try to form a new government. He expects to have a list of Cabinet ministers ready "within a few days," which is taken to mean next week.
Take it from James J. Lyons, Borough President of the Bronx, it is easier to get to a race track than to a ground-breaking ceremony.

The City Council has fixed a basic tax rate of $4.16 for each $100 of assessed valuation to help finance the city's $1,991,952,986 expense budget for the 1958-59 fiscal year beginning July 1. Assessable local improvements bring the rates in the various boroughs to a range of $4.21 to $4.24, and the rate increases to an average of 15 cents over the current year.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- The National Association of Life Underwriters today opposed further extension of the Social Security program. The association argued that extension would be economically unsound.

Alfons Landa, new president of the Penn-Texas Corporation, entrenched his group more firmly yesterday by announcing the appointment of Robert C. Finkelstein, a dlirector, as assistant to the president.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 12 points (60 cents a bale) up to 7 points (35 cents a bale) off yesterday. Trading volume was moderate.

LOS ANGELES, June 25 (UPI) -- Pierce Works, an attorney for the Los Angeles Dodgers, said today the "phantom oil rights issue" had been injected into the Chavez Ravine contest although the ball club never had more than a voice in how one-half of the oil revenue would be spent.

LIVERPOOL, England, June 25 (AP) -- A lashing rain and a man six years his junior combined to defeat 56-year-old Gene Sarazen of Germantown, N. Y., in the world senior professional golf championship today.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Military experts at the Pentagon are strongly averse to a United States military involvement in Lebanon. Defense Department sources said today that if a United Nations police force were sent to seal Lebanon's frontiers protectively, it should be manned by personnel of smaller countries.
The court-appointed monitors supervising the International Brotherhood of Teamsters took their first comprehensive steps toward a clean-up of the giant union yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. William M. Creasy, chief of the Army Chemical Corps for more than four years, has submitted his application for retirement on Aug. 31.
The recession confronts sayings banks with problems of maintaining deposit growth, asset quality and earning power, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks said yesterday.
ALBANY, June 25 (AP) -- Governor Harriman has ordered the State Police to create a fifty-man unit, similar to the Federal Bureau of Investigation, to attack crime anywhere in the state.

PHILADELPHIA, June 25 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury began an investigation today into reported shakedowns in the settlement of labor disputes. Two of three witnesses summoned by the jury declined to answer most of its questions.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Following is a chronology the White House made public today, in the form of extracts from correspondence and other data, on the proposed meeting of nuclear experts from the East and the West in Geneva:
BEIRUT, June 25 -- President Camille Chamoun said today that Lebanon would not ask for foreign military aid outside the provisions of the United Nations Charter.
Modern housing projects were described here last night as "bleak towers, which stretch on to infinity."

BOSTON, June 25 -- The Board of Home Missions of the Congregational Christian Churches voted today an appropriation of $100,000 to complete a fund drive for the Flint-Goodridge Hospital in New Orleans.

It was moving day yesterday for Pan American World Air-ways at the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens. Its entire local operation was moved some two miles across the field to a new $15,000,000 hangar -- the largest on the airfield.
MOSCOW, June 25 -- A placard-bearing, fist-shaking but, on the whole, good-natured crowd of more than 2,000 persons demonstrated today outside the United States Embassy.

The Downtown - Lower Manhattan Association said yesterday that the widening of Fulton Street from river to river was essential to the city's traffic pattern and to the ultimate redevelopment of the entire area south of City Hall.

The Boeing Airplane Company registered yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission two issues totaling $90,597,600. Most of the money will be used to reduce bank loans, of which $115,000,000 were outstanding on June 16.

Like so many athletes before him, Frank Gifford, the blithely audacious halfback of the New York Giants, has long been convinced that he can go off to Hollywood and get a job as a movie hero. He is handsome and charming.
The Columbia Broadcasting System will televise Pierre Boulle's "Face of a Hero" next season before the story makes its debut as a Broadway stage play.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 25 -- Experiments in the combat organization are being made to test the value of the new pentomic divisions, Wilber M. Brucker, Secretary of the Army, said here today. The pentomic divisions are organized to meet the needs of ground troops in nuclear warfare.

THE Metropolitan Museum will open today an exhibition of prints by the seventeenth century French artist Jacques Callot and the nineteenth century French painter, sculptor and printmaker Honore Daumier.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 25 (UPI) -- Phil Rodgers shared the medal with Donald (Ab) Justice of Oklahoma State and paced his Houston team to its third straight national collegiate golf championship today.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission ordered the American Telephone Telegraph Company today to cut its rates for privately leased telephone circuits by about 15 per cent.
BOSTON, June 25 (AP) -- Federal Judge William T. McCarthy said today that he had never been "pressured" or asked to do favors for Bernard Goldfine, New England industrialist.
BELINGWE, Southern Rhodesia -- This is a story for every small boy -- or former small boy -- who ever came home with a pocketful of pretty stones.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Neil H. McElroy bowed to Senator Richard B. Russell today and offered written assurance that no military chief would be punished for opposing President Eisenhower on Pentagon reorganization.
The State Division of Housing is pushing the sale of apartments in a cooperative project to speed the construction of 342 units for middle-income families.

Collision and flames on the East River early yesterday set off an unrehearsed rescue operation which will long be remembered for courage, efficiency -- and success. When the freighter Nebraska crashed into the gasoline carrier Empress Bay at 12:22 A. M. there were fifty-one persons on board the two crafts. That forty-nine of them were saved from the resulting holocaust was a man-made miracle.

Schenley Industries, Inc., distillers, increased its net to $10,597,530 in the nine months ended May 31 from $8,713,207 in the corresponding period last year, Lewis S. Rosensteil, chairman and president, reported yesterday.
LONDON, June 25 (Reuters) Following is a translation of a Moscow radio broadcast on the note sent today to the United States Government concerning the Geneva nuclear tests conference:
The present Basque representative-in-exile here asserted yesterday that he had been misquoted in the Morris L. Ernst report on the disappearance of Jesus de Galindez.

The Federal Maritime Board will start hearing oral arguments in Washington July 8 on a decision by a board examiner to give truck loading and unloading rights in the Port of New York exclusively to terminal operators.

It's a rare day in June, or any other month, when the applause for a race horse exceeds the raucous exhortations for that horse to win. When Bold Ruler had a six-length lead in the stretch at Belmont Park yesterday, the majority of the 19,481 spectators actually clapped their hands in appreciation.

BASLE, Switzerland, June 25 (AP) -- Shareholders of Interhandel Corporation, owner of General Aniline and Film Chemical Company, elected new directors today, reflecting the new interest of the Swiss "big three" banks in the corporation.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- A House committee today accused the International Cooperation Administration of "inadequate, indifferent and incompetent'' handling of foreign aid projects.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Defense orders picked up again in May after a slight letdown in April, Pentagon officials reported today.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 25 -- President Sukarno named an army colonel as one of his Ministers in a shuffled Indonesian Cabinet today.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 25 (AP) -- A United States District Court jury has returned a verdict in favor of the Union Carbide Corporation, which was accused in a $1,584,000 Civil suit of violating the Sherman Act.
The fourth November, 1957, grand jury that has been investigating the Department of Buildings was extended yesterday to November, 1958.

Deere Co., second largest maker of agricultural equipment in the nation, plans to revamp its operating structure "in order to keep abreast of the needs of the business," William A. Hewitt, president, announced yesterday.

The American Radio Association signed a memorandum of understanding yesterday with the American Merchant Marine Institute for a new three-year contract covering radio operators aboard 205 freighters and passenger ships.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Congressional investigators heard today that Treasury Department officials had sought information from the Securities and Exchange Commission on a case against Bernard Goldfine, New England industrialist.

MILWAUKEE, June 25 (AP) -- The San Francisco Giants seized on a double error by the Braves, and, with Ray Jablonski and Orlando Cepeda supplying key hits, shoved over five runs in the sixth inning tonight to sweep to a 10-2 victory over Milwaukee.

MICHAEL will never tell. If a countess living in Connecticut or a sedate young matron in the East Sixties wants to sell him some of her Paris or Italian originals, her name will not be disclosed. It's a matter of principle, and Michael, the owner of Resale Associates at 1041 Madison Avenue, is a man of many principles.

TEXTILE paintings by Marius Sznajderman, which depict brilliantly colored semi-abstract scenes, are on view through July 11 in the Art Gallery of Teachers College at Columbia University. The exhibit is open Monday through Friday from 9 A. M. to 5 P. M.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- In the Senate Mr. Langer is famed for thorny independence. His nickname, "Wild Bill," connotes a violent explosiveness that has decreased in recent years, but it still sums up his basic approach to politics.

STRATFORD, Ont. June 25--With the production of "Much Ado About Nothing," which opened at the Festival Theatre last evening, Michael Langham reaches first rank as director. He is master of both play and stage in a brilliant performance, which presents Eileen Herlie as Beatrice and Christopher Plummer as Benedick.
WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- A House Merchant Marine and Fisheries subcommittee today approved two Senate-passed bills designed to conserve ducks and other wildlife.
The Republic of Korea will honor tomorrow afternoon a second member of the crew of the Moore-McCormack Lines freighter Meridith Victory.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- A biography that cost the carpenters' union $310,000 was in large part lifted bodily from other books, a college professor testified today before the Senate Rackets Committee.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- A woman physician who has just returned from a month's tour of the Soviet Union reported today that the Russians are making wide use of the products of human and animal blood.

Two men were missing and presumed dead yesterday in the early-morning collision of a Swedish freighter and a petroleum tanker in the East River. Six of the thirty-five injured were still in hospitals last night.

I would like to second the comments made by Leonard Bernstein concerning the function of culture in inter-American understanding. There is no doubt such tours as that of the New York Philharmonic can contribute greatly to this idea.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- The Adams case has focused attention on that largely anonymous but immensely powerful staff that serves the President in the White House.
A Brooklyn man who snatched an injured baby robin from a cat has rigged up a scheme whereby the robin's mother has visiting privileges and feeds the baby every day.

An Ivy League lawyer has outstayed a racetrack executive in bargaining for some stock. As a result, Princeton University is almost half a million dollars richer. The bene ficiaries of the university lawyer's stubborness will be deserving students who will receive scholarships from the stock proceeds.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 25 -- America exports all sorts of things, practical and idealistic, but opera has been low on the list. It was a surprise, therefore, to Europeans in the audience at the American Pavilion Theatre on the World's Fair grounds tonight to discover that the United States could present as powerful a native product as Carlisle Floyd's "Susannah."

LONDON, June 25 (UPI) -- The royal limousine of Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, collided with a taxi today while he was en route to a motorists' meeting to plead for fewer accidents on Britain's "rather antique" roads. Both cars were damaged slightly but no one was injured.
WHITE PLAINS, June 25 -- Motorists received assurance today from the Westchester Parkway Authority that it had not been making empty promises.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Senator George D. Aiken, Republican of Vermont, called today for closer ties with Canada and for a greater understanding of her problems by Congress and the American people.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- The' National Neurological, {Research Foundation today 'granted awards of from $10,000 io $12,000 a year for five years to three scientists to study the field of ailments related to neurology.
LONDON, June 25 -- The passage of time has not cooled the bitter anger Britons feel at the execution of Mr. Nagy and his associates.
The relative calm that has prevailed along Madison Avenue in recent weeks gave way yesterday to renewed account-switching, as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, June 25 (AP) -- Two visiting Russian scientists went on a moonlight cruise into forbidden waters of the Delaware River last night. Their excursion boat sailed hard by the warships at the Philadelphia Naval Base.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., June 25 (AP) -- A witness told the Tennessee Senate today he knew nothing about $20,000 allegedly paid from the Teamsters Union funds to "fix" cases in Judge Raulston Schoolfield's court at Chattanooga.
The International Ladies Garment Workers Union announced yesterday that it had appropriated $2,000,000 and reshuffled its high command in a move to curb racket influence in the dress industry.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Senator George D. Aiken, Republican of Vermont, called today for closer ties with Canada and for a greater understanding of her problems by Congress and the American people.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) -- The' National Neurological, {Research Foundation today 'granted awards of from $10,000 io $12,000 a year for five years to three scientists to study the field of ailments related to neurology.
LONDON, June 25 -- The passage of time has not cooled the bitter anger Britons feel at the execution of Mr. Nagy and his associates.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Thursday, June 26 -- The Navy failed early this morning in an attempt to put another Vanguard satellite into orbit.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPI) -- Representative Usher L. Burdick, 79-year-old North Dakota Congressman, has changed his mind about trying to annul his marriage to his 30-year-old former secretary. No reason was given for the change.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 25 -- The American Federation of Musicians is attempting to work out at least a partial settlement of its strike against major motion picture studios before facing a test of strength next month with a rival known as the Musicians Guild of America.
GENEVA, June 25 -- The International Labor Organization voted overwhelmingly today to expel all delegates of Hungary from its current conference.
ALBANY, June 25 (AP) -- Drinking apparently caused the death of more than half the drivers killed in one-car crashes in Westchester County over a recent eight-year period.

LAUREL, Md., June 25 (AP) -- Sharpshooter, winter book favorite for the $110,000 Hambletonian at DuQuoin, Ill., in August, tonight won both heats of the $10,791 Reading (Pa.) Futurity at Laurel Raceway.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 25 -- Barry MacKay, the only American rated capable of winning the men's title at Wimbledon, reached the third round today. With tape fluttering from his blistered serving hand, he disposed of a part-time British player, Eric Bulmer, 6 -- 1, 9 -- 7, 6 -- 2, then hurried to Jack Kramer, the professional tennis promoter, for advice.
The Aquarium at Coney Island, which has the most varied collection of sea mammals in the world, found itself yesterday with a most unusual collection of sea mammal troubles.

WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPI) -- Representative Oren Harris acknowledged today that he recently wrote a letter asking the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission about a pending Arkansas radio station dispute.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 25 -- The three-week political crisis ended today with the formation of a Social Christian (Roman Catholic) minority Government with Gaston Eyskens as premier.

The winners of two literary prizes were recently announced. Stanley J. Kunitz of New York received the University of Chicago $500 Harriet Monroe poetry award. He is the author of two volumes of verse, "Intellectual Things" and "Passport to the War." His third, "Selected Poems," will be published in the fall.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Tuberculin tests for tuberculosis instead of compulsory X-ray programs in school health services were recommended today by three Federal agencies.
Paul Robeson, who for the last eight years has been denied a passport, will be able to leave for London within a fortnight to fulfill stage, concert and television commitments there.

BOSTON, June 25 (AP) -- Promised Land, a gray colt that enjoys distance tests, staged another of his patented stretch drives in pulling away to an easy victory in the twenty-fourth running of the $56,700 Massachusetts Handicap at Suffolk Downs today.
The City Housing Authority has moved to withdraw all its employes from the city's Career and Salary Plan.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 25--Lebanon asked the United Nations today to seal this country's land and sea frontiers with armed force and stop the flow of war supplies to Lebanese rebels from the United Arab Republic.
CHICAGO, June 25 (UPI) -- Rory Calhoun of White Plains, N. Y., used a punishing body attack tonight to gain a unanimous decision over Bobby Boyd of Chicago in a ten-round middleweight bout.

HACKENSACK, N. J., June 25 -- Sid Schwartz, New York; Larry Schaffer, Bronx, and Don Thompson, Jackson Heights, Queens, entered the quarterfinal round of the Eastern clay court tennis championship today.
DETROIT, June 25 -- A wildcat strike at the Chrysler Corporation's missile plant in nearby Sterling Township was called off tonight.

Binghamton, N. Y., borrowed $7,739,000 in the bond market yesterday for water and sewer improvements. The money was raised by the sale of general obligation due from 1959 to 1978 to a syndicate headed by Harriman Ripley Co., Lehman Brothers and Salomon Brothers Hutzler.
Once again, this time in Lebanon, the United States is faced with a situation in which use of military force to restore stability may bring only instability.
TORONTO, June 25 -- A countermarch of population from the suburbs back to the large cities was foreseen today.

Haiti has developed an unhappy faculty in recent times of distressing her best friends in the hemisphere. The way the Duvalier regime has permitted the literal destruction of the opposition press is a case in point. In addition, the homes of foes of the regime have been machine-gunned and a number of opposition leaders have been arrested for no other crime than being in the opposition.

The Government has flinched, up to the present, from taking decisive action to get the nation's economy off dead center, where it now is. It has taken this negative attitude despite the fact that the decline in industrial production has already amounted to 14 per cent, as compared with the extreme decline of 10 per cent that marked the recessions of 1948-49 and 1953-54.
PHILADELPHIA, June 25 -- An agreement was reached tonight on settling a strike of more than 500 delivery truck drivers at the Philadelphia Bulletin and The Philadelphia Inquirer.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- United States Government specialists believe the execution of Imre Nagy may have turned the tables in the East-West propaganda war in favor of the West.
LONDON, June 25 -- The stock market was subdued today and although Government securities and industrial stocks rallied modestly there were widespread small net losses in many sections.

Two soloists played under the gibbous moon that hung over Lewisohn Stadium last night. Aldo Parisot was heard with the Stadium Symphony in the Boccherini 'Cello Concerto in B flat, and Stell Andersen appeared after intermission to take on the Grieg Piano Concerto.
PARIS, June 26 -- The Government has prevented the appearance of two weekly newspapers containing articles critical of it and deemed to endanger the security of the state.

Buyers of United States Government securities were more sure of themselves yesterday. After steadying Wednesday following two days of sharp decline, the market showed strength all along the line yesterday.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 26 (AP) -- Phil Rodgers beat Maryland's Deane Beman on the eighteenth hole today and led the imposing Houston delegation into the third round of the National Collegiate golf championship.

ROME, June 26 -- Premier-designate Amintore Fanfani made certain today of being able to form a two-party Government based on collaboration between his Christian Democrats and the Democratic Socialists.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- The House of Representatives passed and sent to President Eisenhower today a bill to require automobile manufacturers and dealers to display the suggested retail price of new cars.

A committee supporting Paul W. Williams for Governor wrote to all members of the Republican State Committee yesterday urging his nomination. The letter described him as the "man who best measures up to the job."
A new two-year community college in Queens was approved in principle yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

When the Moiseyev Dance Company from Moscow closes its American tour at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night, it will have grossed $1,600,000. This is thought to be a record for any theatrical attraction.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 26 -- Military headquarters said tonight that Government troops had won full control of the Indonesian rebel capital of Menado.

LONDON, June 26 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan declared tonight his willingness to negotiate changes in the British plan for Cyprus. He added that failure to find a solution for the strife-torn island was unthinkable.
The Southern Advertising Agency, Inc., will close its doors in Miami at the end of the month, following its loss of the National Airlines account.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 (UPI) -- An official of the American Medical Association criticized today highly organized sports for children, such as Little League baseball.
The youthful office photocopy industry is thriving on the recession.
NASHVILLE, June 26 (AP) -- Judge Raulston Schoolfield denied ten impeachment charges today.

The Metropolitan Sanitary Water District of Greater Chicago is planning the sale of $15,000,000 of bonds on July 10. The obligations will be dated Aug. 1, 1958 and will come due serially on Jan. 1 from 1960 to 1978.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- A television rating expert said today he could measure preferences for television shows as acurately as a dairy could test a tank car of milk with a halfpint sample.
BOSTON, June 26 (UPI) -- Mr. Choate issued this statement today:

SARANAC INN, N. Y., June 6 -- The executive committee of the New York State Bar Association adopted a resolution today opposing the Butler-Jenner bill to curb the powers of the United States Supreme Court. The bill, it declared, would impair the power of the court to preserve the rights of individuals.
PORTLAND, Me., June 26 -Vice President Richard M. Nixon asserted today that members of Congress had a duty to intervene with Federal agencies in behalf of their constituents.
The spirit of Leif Ericson and the specter of press agentry sailed up New York Harbor yesterday.

"Guests of the Nation," hailed by critics when it was given for one performance at the Theatre de Lys on May 20, reopened for a regular run last night at the Theatre Marquee, 110 East Fifty-ninth Street.
Two debates between rival contenders for the Republican Congressional nomination in the Seventh District have been agreed upon, it was announced yesterday. Others may be arranged later.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -Following are excerpts from the testimony today of John Fox, publisher of the defunct Boston Post, before a House inquiry and a statement in reply by Sherman Adams, the Assistant to the President: ...
"Li'l Abner," the long-run musical hit at the St. James Theatre, will preface its projected national tour next fall with a night-club engagement.
The New York Central Railroad experienced a loss of $3,940,259 in May and a $24,590,550 deficit for the first five months of this year, the report, issued yesterday, showed.
STRAITS OF MACKINAC, Mich., June 26 (AP) -- Michigan touched off a three-day celebration today to dedicate the newest of the world's big bridges.

Many of us who are concerned with problems of older people regret deeply the decision of New York State Senator Thomas C. Desmond to resign from the Senate. This probably means, of course, that he will not continue as chairman of the New York State Joint Legislative Committee on Problems of the Aging.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 26 -- Nick Pietrangeli, a rubberfaced Italian with a touch of genius in his tennis racquet, pried open the first crack in the all-England championship seedings today. He took Luis Ayala of Chile, No. 5 in the rankings, and bedeviled him with a subtle variety of pace and length to win, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3, before a sell-out crowd on Wimbledon's Center Court.
LIBSON, Portugal, June 22 -Gen. Humberto Delgado, defeated Opposition candidate for President of Portugal, is continuing his campaign against the Government of Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Sherman Adams branded as "preposterous and malicious" tonight the sworn testimony of John Fox before Congressional investigators. He did so in his first formal appearance before reporters since he came to the White House as President Eisenhower's chief of staff five and a half years ago.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 26 -Darn Safe, the powerful 7-yearold gelding belonging to the Hayes Fair Acres Stable of Duquoin, Ill., trotted a race that was in keeping with his name at rainy Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

"Considerable progress" was reported yesterday after six hours of negotiations in the strike of announcers and disk jockeys against radio station WINS. The optimistic report was made by Jacob R. Mandelbaum, Commissioner of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- A coalition of Republicans and big-city Democrats dealt the House farm bloc a severe defeat today and gave the Administration a victory.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -The United States informed the Soviet Union today that its technical experts would be in Geneva Tuesday, as agreed, to begin talks on measures to police a ban on testing of nuclear weapons.

WESTOVER AIR FORCE BASE, Mass., Friday, June 27 -- A huge jet tanker of the Strategic Air Command, seeking to set a new record for crossing the Atlantic Ocean, crashed in flames early this morning. Fifteen persons, including six newsmen, were reported killed.

It is well to keep reminding ourselves that the heart of France's crisis of the regime is Algeria. This is sometimes forgotten by foreigners and evaded by Frenchmen, even though no day goes by without news from or about Algeria.

The Stanley Warner Corporation, in a letter to be sent today to stockholders of Cinerama Productions Corporation, a holding company, is offering to exchange the common stock, which it owns in Cinerama, Inc., for Cinerama Production shares of a share-for-share basis.
OTTAWA, June 26 (AP) -- The Triton Steamship Company, Ltd., was ordered today to pay $39,350 and $17,182 in interest for the loss of use of a tanker involved in a collision at sea.
LOS ANGELES, June 26 (AP) -- The State Athletic Commission approved today the heavyweight title fight between Floyd Patterson, the champion, and Roy Harris at Los Angeles on Aug. 18.
An honor patrolman was charged last night with the theft of more than $27,000 from property safes in police headquarters in Manhattan and the Bronx.

We've become accustomed to him now, and it didn't make much news yesterday when Robert Moses was reappointed by Mayor Wagner to "another," the fifth, six-year term as chairman of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority. If he hadn't been reappointed, what news that would have been! For this is a man no Mayor would try to do without.

The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation announced yesterday it had put into operation a continuous-weld pipe mill at its Aliquippa (Pa.) Works, capable of producing welded pipe from 1 1/4 inches through 4 inches in diameter.

MOSCOW, June 26 (AP) -- The Soviet press denounced today the idea of a United Nations police force for Lebanon as "foreign intervention" and a threat to peace. It warned that the Soviet Union would not stand idly by in such an event.
Carlos Ortiz of the Bronx will meet Johnny Busso of Astoria, Queens, in the ten-round lightweight feature bout of tonight's boxing show at Madison Square Garden.

The House of Representatives acted wisely and decisively when it adopted, by voice vote, a liberal bill to exempt some of the non-business and strictly sport phases of professional sports from antitrust legislation. The Senate will be well advised not to bury this measure under prolix committee operations but to let it come out promptly and be approved.
The Transit Authority has proposed the elimination of one conductor from BMT and IND trains that now have two.

For a change yesterday, Wall Street had plenty of news to digest -- mostly bullish -- and, as a result, stocks scored a rather broad advance. The main rise on the New York Stock Exchange came in the final thirty minutes of trading.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) -- A House subcommittee questioned today whether the Air Force needed 480 woman stewardesses in its Military Air Transport Service to support the Strategic Air Command.

MIAMI, Fla., June 26 (AP) -Theodore A. Davis Jr., ousted as president of the New York Trust Company after being indicted for fraud, has had the indictment dismissed. However, the possibility of its reinstatement hung over him today.
TRIPOLI, Lebanon, June 26 -The rebel leader in this city near the Syrian border said today he expected outside help if there was any "attack" on Lebanon.

IT is almost impossible to keep track of the host of fish and game laws enacted by the Legislature at each session, but The Conservationist, the organ of the State Conservation Department, takes a crack at summarizing what it considers the most important of the latest batch.

WHILE most fruits and vegetables continue to reach the New York market in heady proportions, there is a marked decline in supplies of fresh asparagus. Although this "grass of epicures" is still inexpensive and available at several outlets, homemakers may expect the last shipments to arrive this week and next.
BOSTON, June 26 -- Workers for desegregation in education should not be "dismayed" by recent setbacks, a church leader in the field of race relations said here today.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The United States regards "with grave concern" the prolonged detention of nine Army men who made a forced helicopter landing in East Germany June 7.
The Board of Education yesterday adopted a capital budget of $105,699,999 for new school construction and related expenditures in 1959.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- A move to oust Godfrey P. Schmidt, a New York lawyer, as one of three court-named monitors over the Teamsters union was turned down today.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -Repeal of the 3 per cent Federal tax on freight transportation was assured today as part of a Senate-House compromise on extension of wartime taxes. The compromise did not include cancellation of the passenger transportation levy.
Nearly seventeen hours of continuous negotiations proved to be unproductive in an attempt to settle the dispute that has already closed three breweries here.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Administration announced today new rules designed to permit greater flying safety and wider use of the nation's crowded air lanes.

ELMSFORD, N. Y., June 26 -Fourteen Greenburgh taxpayers reported today their withdrawal of a suit to prevent the town's building, an incinerator on a forty-acre site bordering the New York State Thruway and Taxter Road. The plaintiffs' homes and estates are near the site.

The rocket of Sputnik I, which the Russians once said had been recovered and with-held by the United States, is now thought to have fallen somewhere along a line from the Soviet Union to Communist China.

An exiled Dominican editor said yesterday that he believed he had been the target of an airplane kidnap plot similar to that suggested in the disappearance of Jesus de Galindez. He said the plot took place in June, 1956.
CHICAGO, June 26 -- The American League's phantom pennant race once again receded from view today as the soaring Yankees scored a few more direct hits on their hapless rivals below.
EAST NORWICH, L. I., June 26 -- Arnold Palmer, who displayed a master's touch on the greens, carded a course-record 66 in the opening round of the Pepsi golf championship today.

WASHINGTON, June 26. (UPI) -- The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations urged today a vast expansion in Social Security benefits. It called on the House Ways and Means Committee to approve a bill sponsored by Representative Lime J. Forand, Democrat of Rhode Island, to increase benefits and raise Social Security taxes.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- A $55,000 grant to the Library of Congress today by the Council on Library Resources, Inc., will make possible a one-year, 1,000-book test of what librarians call "cataloguing in source."
RANGOON, Burma, June 26 -- Reports today of a series of guerrilla raids and atrocities in outlying areas made it doubtful that Premier Nu's appeal for mass surrender would be heeded enthusiastically.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Normal judicial process and public policy are deeply correlated in the situation created by the direct appeal to the Supreme Court today by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People from the thirty-month suspension of Little Rock high school integration granted by Federal District Judge Lemley.
ORIGAMI is the Japanese name for an ancient art. "Ori" means to fold; "gami" means paper. Chinese and Japanese began to develop origami as an art form before Christ was born.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today that it had staked out a danger area around Johnston Island in the Pacific because of the forthcoming tests there of short-range missiles with nuclear warheads.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 26 -- The first official word of President Tito's decision to seek expanded credits from the West was communicated to the Yugoslav Parliament today.

The Federal Reserve System made its biggest purchase of Treasury ninety-one-day bills in two years in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This helped raise net free reserves of member banks to the highest level in three-and-a-half years.

The 15,000-ton liner Santa Rosa sailed on her maiden voyage yesterday with a handsome silver tea and coffee service for her passenger lounge. The service was presented shortly before the noon sailing to Lewis Lapham, president of Grace Line, Inc., by Madoe M. Pease, president of the American Institute of Marine Underwriters.

Double trouble dogged Mayor Wagner on a trip to Charleston, W. Va. His plane lost a four-foot section of a wing flap in turbulent weather. Then, a breakdown of the radar system at Washington's airport prevented a substitute plane from taking off.
Correction Commissioner Anna M. Kross announced yesterday that Rikers Island would no longer accept self-committed narcotics addicts for treatment.
The blockfront on the east side of Third Avenue between Eighteenth and Nineteenth Streets has been purchased for investment by a client of Roy Berlin, attorney.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 26 -- Adlai E. Stevenson has looked at the United States exhibit at the Brussels World's Fair and pronounced it good.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) -- The House swiftly passed a bill today to extend the President's expiring emergency powers to deal with civil defense crises in case of enemy attack.
The 18,000-ton liner Atlantic faces an uncertain welcome today when she returns here on her maiden voyage.

The Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation reported yesterday that its consolidated net income for the fiscal year ended April 30 was $2,423,299, against $2,529,664 in the preceding fiscal year.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 26 -- The Connecticut race for the Democratic nomination for Senator centered on two of the three candidates today as the party prepared for its convention tomorrow and Saturday in Hartford.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -Gen. Clifton B. Cates, former Marine commandant, denounced the Pentagon reorganization bill today as perilous to the country and to the Marine Corps.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -The Senate rackets committee disclosed today that it had information that a conspiracy case against officials of the Carpenters' Union had been fixed in Lake County, Ind. The committee will question James R. Hoffa about it next week.
