NEWLY moved to the swiftgrowing decorating center of town is I. D. G. (International Designers Group). Formerly situated uptown, this showroom which specializes in aesthetic yet functional accessories, is now at 58 East Fifty-eighth Street. All items in the showroom are available through decorators and some can be found in stores.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) -- The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and Western Union Telegraph Company asked the Federal Communications Commission today for increases in their teletype service rates.

The Greyhound Corporation is prepared, if necessary, to ask the Supreme Court to order the City Planning Commission to hold a public hearing on its proposed $10,000,000 bus terminal on West Thirty-fourth Street.
BONN, June 26 -- The German Federal Bank announced a reduction of the discount rate from 3 1/2 to 3 per cent today. The cut is effective tomorrow.
The Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn announced yesterday that it was undertaking a $15,000,000 accelerated development program "to strengthen the education of scientists and engineers."

LONG BRANCH, N. J., June 26 -- The Hazard Hospital, which for years has cared for thousands of patients who could not afford to pay, was ordered sold last night by its board of directors. The decision followed a long period of financial difficulty.

MILWAUKEE, June 26 (AP) -- Don Drysdale drove his first homer of the year and tamed the Braves on eight hits tonight as the last-place Los Angeles Dodgers triumphed, 4 -- 1. The defeat trimmed Milwaukee's lead in the National League to a game and a half.
SAIGON, Vietnam, June 26 (AP) -- South Vietnam accused neighboring Cambodia today of complaining of an invasion while her troops actually were trying to take Vietnamese territory.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -Prince Mohammed Daud, Premier of Afghanistan, appealed to the press of all countries today to understand his country's neutrality.
DALLAS, Tex., June 26 (UPI) -- This city's 141 public schools will remain segregated during the next school year, it appeared certain today.
BERLIN, June 26 (AP) -- The French Army has banned the showing of the American movie "Paths of Glory" in the French sector of West Berlin.
BOSTON, June 26 -- A special Legislative Railroad Commission worked today on a bill that would continue commuter service on the Old Colony division of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad.
George V. Allen, director of the United States Information Agency, predicted here yesterday that propaganda would be the decisive factor in determining the international use of nuclear weapons.
Louis S. Rothschild, Under Secretary of Commerce for Transportation, predicted yesterday that Congress would vote legislation creating a new Federal Aviation Agency before adjournment this year.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- An alien from Iraq asked the courts today to stop his deportation to that country because, he said, he would be subject to persecution as a Jew.

BOWLING GREEN, Ohio, June 26 -- A drastic overhauling of programs for teacher education programs was urged here today by Dr. John I. Goodlad, director of a center for teacher education of the University of Chicago.

LONDON, June 26 -- Thirty Soviet fishermen invaded British soil last night in pursuit of an Estonian who escaped from one of their trawlers. The British Government is expected to protest the incursion.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) -- A Pennsylvania school superintendent urged the Senate Education subcommittee today to approve Federal aid for schools in areas where defense projects caused heavy enrollment increases.

PARIS, June 24 -- The recent agreement for United States aid in developing nuclear power in Europe is regarded here as supplying the much-needed backing for the whole program of European union through a partial pooling of national economies.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 26 -- The American Federation of Musicians is planning a world conference of musicians organizations to help combat loss of employment that has resulted from the use of "canned" music. The A. F. M. also will seek to prevent future competitions among musicians of different countries in the event of difficulties with employers.
EAST NORWICH, L. I., June 26 -- Tommy Bolt strode into the locker room at Pine Hollow today, still wearing the halo of his new, sweet-tempered amiability. It didn't seem to fit too naturally.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- The House Education and Labor Committee asked its special Labor subcommittee today to reconsider a mass resignation, given "not in anger but more in despair."

WORLD leaders make headlines with their speeches at college commencements. High school graduates make news in terms of awards received and scholarships won. However, for thousands of parents and children throughout the city this week, nothing was more important than an event that, officially, does not exist -- graduation from grade school.
BUFFALO, June 26 (AP) -Donald A. Quarles, Deputy Secretary of Defense, said tonight the Defense Department would review the Navy's Vanguard program.

BONN, Germany, June 26. -Reginald Maudling, British Paymaster General, said today Britain could agree only to a 10 per cent tarrif reduction if Europeans considered a cut would facilitate the establishment of a free-trade area.
Mrs. Martha Hinrichsen was back in Upper Manhattan Magistrates' Court yesterday to ask the judge to let her keep all forty-six of the dogs she has taken in as guests.
A Federal investigation will begin today into the East River crash that sank a harbor tanker, Wednesday morning, and cost the lives of two seamen and set the river afire.
The foreman of a demolition crew had a narrow escape yesterday when a brick wall collapsed on him. He was saved by the combination of a wooden safety "bridge" and a parked truck.

BOSTON, June 26 -- A former ragtime pianist, a former newspaper publisher, a former columnist and a financier dwell together in a big house in Fairfield, Conn. They all answer to the name of John Fox, the bustling Bostonian who testified today in Washington on his connection with Bernard Goldfine, a friend of Sherman Adams.
Prize fighters, like writers and most pickpockets, must stand alone. If things go wrong, they cannot blame the secretary or the assistant sales manager, or hire a new advertising agency.
PHILADELPHIA, June 26 -Nearly 300 striking truck drivers of The Philadelphia Inquirer ratified an agreement today to end a twenty-seven day walkout.
Roy Campanella, the paralyzed Dodger catcher, declined with thanks yesterday the offer of Governor Harriman to put him on the State Athletic Commission as a deputy commissioner.

ADEN, June 26 -- About a third of the "regular army" of the state of Lahej has deserted to Yemen with arms and ammunition. The desertion occurred on the eve of the greatest Moslem festival of the year here.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) -- Representative Otto E. Passman, Democrat of Louisiana, disclosed tonight that the House Appropriations Subcommittee had reduced President Eisenhower's foreign aid program by an additional total of $482,500,000.
Three new films, including two imports, will open in local theatres today.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today ordered a suspension of trading in shares of Trans Continental Industries, Inc., on the American and Detroit Stock Exchanges. The commission said it had acted to prevent "fraudulent, deceptive or manipulative acts or practices."

SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 -The association's House of Delegates voted today to start an educational campaign dealing with the relationships between the medical profession and the medical care programs of the United Mine Workers of America.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 26 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said on his return from Lebanon today that the United Nations observation group there had "got off to a very satisfactory start, indeed."

WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today approved a 30 per cent increase in mail hauling rates for fourteen major Eastern railroads, effective Sept. 1. The L C. C. also authorized retroactive increases of 30 per cent from Nov. 1, 1957, to Aug. 31, 1958; 25 per cent from Nov. 1, 1956, to Oct. 31, 1957, and 20 per cent from July 3, 1956, to Oct. 31, 1956.

"Goodwill Night at Yonkers Raceway" on Oct. 15 will aid Goodwill Industries of New York. Mrs. Norman S. Woolworth is honorary chairman of the benefit committee, which has taken over the raceway pavilion for the evening.
Harry Bridges has been rebuffed in an effort to establish a beachhead in the Port of New York.
Former President Herbert Hoover was cited yesterday by the New York Rotary Club for "his devotion to duty and his incomparable contributions to mankind."

GENEVA, Switzerland, June 26 (Reuters) -- A general contraction in world trade has been touched off by the recession in the United States, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe reported today.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., June 26 (AP) -- A plan of the Administration for construction of six atomic energy power plants in Europe "sounds incredible" and threatens the United States coal industry, Joseph E. Moody said today.

CONCORD, N. H., June 26 (AP) -- A former state bank commissioner was arrested today and accused of juggling the books in a bank that the state closed less than a month after he had resigned as president.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- Senator William F. Knowland's fiftieth birthday was observed in the Senate today. A round of bipartisan speeches hailed him for his "integrity, his convictions and his courage."

ALBANY, June 26 -- The State Commissioner of Health said today that the use of orally administered anti-poliomyelitis vaccine should not be permitted in the state until its safety had been demonstrated through comprehensive testing.

The case involving the purchase by the city of land for one and a half million dollars more than the assessed valuation -- or about fourteen times more than the value of land the city received for adjacent and better land (which is the concern of the taxpayers) -- has been received with dead silence.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- President Eisenhower told Congress today the United Nations had a record of solid achievement in 1957 in dealing with a series of grave issues which threatened world peace.
Frank A. Zelano, a founder and strike leader of the Motormen's Benevolent Association, quit yesterday as a member and officer of the union.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 26 -When the armed services want a reserve officer called to active duty they should contract with him for a definite period of service, Representative Overton Brooks told the Reserve Officers Association here today.
Some of the key items of the new uniform rules of the road that go into effect Tuesday in New York State are:
Paul Robeson and Corliss Lamont received passports yesterday after struggles that had been going on since 1950 and 1951.
A NEW collection of specially designed African mahogany "holsters" complete with knives makes it convenient and safe to store cutlery on kitchen counter tops or on near-by walls.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce, supporting a fiveyear extension of the Reciprocal Trade Law, said today that this country gains from foreign trade.
Two large brokerage houses installed closed-circuit television systems yesterday to watch the stock market.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -The Atomic Energy Commission announced today the completion of an experimental reactor to be used in research on a nuclear-propelled rocket.

CLEVELAND, June 26 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians dropped Bobby Bragan as manager tonight and hired Joe Gordon, a former Indian and New York Yankee second baseman and now an insurance salesman in Sacramento, Calif.

Directors of the Commercial State Bank and Trust Company of New York and the Bank of North America approved yesterday consolidation of the two banks into an institution to be known as Commercial Bank of North America.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -John Fox, Boston lawyer, testified to a House subcommittee today that not long after President Eisenhower's first election, Sherman Adams had "arranged a private conference between the President and Mr. Goldfine."

WASHINGTON, June 26 -The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy reached a compromise today on legislation permitting atomic weapons secrets to be shared with North Atlantic Treaty Organization allies.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 26 (Reuters) -- Col. George Grivas, leader of the E.O.K.A., the Greek Cypriote underground terrorist group, rejected tonight the British plan for the future of Cyprus as "a new monstrosity."
MADRID, June 26 -- The popular Mayor of flood-battered Valencia has recently unleashed a scathing attack on the regime of Generalissimo Francisco Franco for apathy, inefficiency and ineptitude.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 26 -Lebanese official circles expect a major attack by rebels in this capital within twenty-four hours.
From the class standpoint, there were two feature races at Belmont Park yesterday. From the form standpoint, matters resolved down to a standoff as one favorite won and the other finished second.
DETROIT, June 26 -- Normal production at Chrysler Corporation's missile plant resumed today.
Stockholders and directors of Smith-Corona, Inc., and Marchant Calculators, Inc., approved a merger of the companies yesterday. The new concern will be called Smith-Corona Marchant, Inc.

The gall of Russia in Hungary and East Germany should once and for all awaken us to the fact that there never was any intention on the part of the Reds to keep their word. Over these many years we have stood aside and watched them cheat, lie and murder.

TORONTO, June 26 -- Office building rental rates, which began a steady rise just before World War II, are continuing their upward pattern. A 5 per cent increase for 1957 over 1956 was reported in a survey issued today, and present indications point to a similar increase this year.
LONDON, June 26 -- Price movements in the stock markets were hesitant today with losses predominating in most groups, particularly among industrials.
LONDON, June 26 -- Nine out of every ten razor blades and two out of every five cars sold in this country are made by English concerns financed by American industry.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- No time was lost today in producing Sherman Adams' denials to new statements about his dealings with Bernard Goldfine.
WASHINGTON, June 27, (UPI) -- A bill to aid the railroads sailed through the House today by a vote of 348 to 2.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, June 26 -- The World Bank has expressed a willingness to extend $5,000,000 in foreign exchange credits to finance the construction of a large hydroelectric project here. Fin ance Minister Alfredo Hernandez said today.

The superliner United States is at sea today with the largest eastbound passenger contingent she has ever carried. One of the regular-size cabins in first class is contributing to the load by accommodating five passengers under an emergency arrangement.

WARSAW, June 27 -- A few weeks ago there were joint Polish-Soviet military maneuvers, announced as such, as part of a Warsaw Pact exercise. There are two and a half or three divisions of Soviet troops in Poland under the terms of the Warsaw Pact.

A sudden right turn by the harbor tanker Empress Bay, carrying her across the bow of the Swedish freighter Nebraska, caused the two ships to crash. That was the testimony given yesterday by the pilot and the master of the freighter.

STANTON, Del., June 27 (UPI) -- Cavan, the Irish-bred winner Of the Belmont Stakes, continues his belated bid for the 3-year-old championship at Delaware Park tomorrow in the $47,900 Leonard Richards Stakes. Eleven have been named land, if all start, the race will be worth $35,000 to the winner.

FISHERMEN of the New York metropolitan area are again passing up some of the best trout water in the state, although it is the nearest, and again it is unaccountable. That is particularly so since Catskills trout fishing has been poor lately.

Now that the City of New York has been forced to grant a tax refund to the New York Central Mayor Wagner would do well to consider the ruinous effects of city real estate taxes on railroad passenger service here.
PHILADELPHIA, June 27 (AP) -- Tim Tam, 1958 Kentucky Derby and Preakness winner, is getting lots of fan mail, particularly from the ladies.
The economy should improve in the second half of this year, the nation's bankers believe.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Five more United States scientists left today for the Geneva talks on means of detecting nuclear weapons tests. Meanwhile, the State Department awaited definite word from Moscow on the attendance of Soviet experts.

TOKYO, June 27 -- Gisen Sato, new chief of Japan's slowly growing military establishment, is listed in the Japanese Who's Who as a Buddhist priest. Mr. Sato, a smiling man, dressed nattily today in a light blue suit with a faint check, sees no conflict between his new duties and his status in Buddhism, a creed devoted to nonviolence and peace.
EAST NORWICH, L. I., June 27 -- Interest in the Pepsi golf championship centered chiefly on two men today.
Contributory responsibility in the killing of 15-year-old Michael Farmer by a youth gang last year was charged to the city yesterday.
DETROIT, June 27 (UPI) -- A wildcat strike in one department today closed three. Chrysler auto plants and forced the lay-off of 2,800 day-shift workers.
BONN, Germany, June 27 -The West German Federal Bank today took a further step in making the Deutsche mark a completely free currency.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -The Office of Defense Mobilization announced today that it had refused to authorize loan guarantees for two pipelines, from Texas to New Jersey and from Texas to California.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., June 27 (UPI) -- Basil Brewer, publisher of The New Bedford Standard-Times, confirmed today that he used his influence to persuade a former Boston newspaper publisher to support the candidacy of John F. Kennedy for the United States Senate over Henry Cabot Lodge in 1952.

LONDON, June 27 -- Reports of Soviet troop movements in and around Poland have aroused fears among United States and British diplomats that the Soviet Union is about to bring military pressure on the Gomulka regime.
Mme. Chiang Kai-shek said yesterday that world communism was "on the offensive" and the free world should stop rewarding neutralists.

There were, in all, forty-nine dogs -- "my babies" to Mrs. Martha Hinrichsen. She kept them in her four-story brownstone house at 78 West 105th Street. Mrs. Hinrichsen, who is 65 years old and tiny, used to rent the rooms. But now all the rooms are full of dogs.
PHILADELPHIA, June 27 -- Some 500 truck drivers of The Philadelphia Bulletin and The Inquirer remained idle today despite ratification of an agreement to end their strike, which began May 30.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Following is the text of a joint United States-Afghan statement issued at the White House today after Premier Daud of Afghanistan had visited with President Eisenhower:

BEIRUT, June 27 (AP)--Jet planes, artillery and armored cars thundered into action today against rebel forces slashing at Lebanon's hard-pressed Government. An army communique said rebel attacks had been stopped on four fronts in a new spread of fighting.
BONN, June 27 -- The Soviet Union apologized to West Germany today for an attack on the German Embassy in Moscow Monday, a Government spokesman announced.
A minor automobile accident on the East Side caused a near-riot last night and sent three people to the hospital and three others to jail.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 27 -- Anna Dares, a consistent racer as a juvenile, scored the most important victory of her career tonight when she captured the $24,950 Dream Trot for 3-year-olds at Roosevelt Raceway.

A "suitable facility" to treat narcotics addicts who are seeking a cure should be provided in New York City, Oren Root said yesterday. He is chairman of the New York Joint Legislative Committee on Narcotic Study.
ROSELLE, N. J., June 27 -Chris M. Wagner of 12 Lockwood Drive, a reporter on The Elizabeth Daily Journal twenty-five years, was found dead yesterday in his parked car. His age was 68.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -The House of Representatives accepted repeal of the 3 per cent Federal tax on freight transportation today and sent to the White House a one-year extension of all other corporation and excise taxes.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 27 -- Experiments designed to obtain a safer and more efficient air traffic control have begun at the new National Aviation Facilities Experimental Center, which formally took over the Navy Air Base near here today.
BOWLING GREEN, Ohio, June 27 -- Present concepts of teaching date to the Stone Age and it is high time that they were discarded, Dr. Margaret Mead declared today.

A four-story building containing thirty-two four-room apartments at 1444 Forty-third Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by Sol Insel and Lorraine Newman to an investing client of Irving Bira, the broker in the transaction.
CHICOPEE FALLS, Mass., June 27 (AP)--The $3,000,000 jet stratotanker crashed and exploded seconds after take-off.
Mayor Wagner has tentatively chosen James A. Roe Jr. and Assemblyman Bernard Dubin both of Queen, for appointments as City magistrates.

Two more breweries shut down yesterday, bringing to a halt all beer production in the city. Altogether, five breweries have closed since Tuesday in a contract dispute with seven locals of the Teamsters Union.

DUBLIN, June 27 (UPI) -- Philomena Garvey, ten-time women's Irish golf titleholder and 1957 British open champion, may not play for Britain's Curtis Cup team Aug. 8-9 at Newton, Mass., because she refuses to wear the Union Jack on her blazer.

OXFORD, England, June 27 -- It would be sheer insanity for the United States and Britain to sponsor a military intervention in Lebanon without specific U. N. authorization. Such intervention could have no sensible strategic objective comparable even to the ill-fated Suez adventure.

NEWARK, June 27 -- Riders on three railroads began paying increased fares at 2 A. M. today after the Interstate Commerce Commission failed to act to prevent a rise in ferry fares between New York and New Jersey.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department reported today that domestic consumption of cigarettes was at a record high.
LONDON, June 27 -- The British Foreign Office described tonight as a "deliberate frame-up" the circumstances that led to expulsion of a British diplomat from Czechoslovakia.
GENEVA, June 27 -- Three United States delegates to the forthcoming technical talks on nuclear test detection arrived today by plane from New York.

Six newsmen, assigned to cover what might have been a record-setting flight to London and back, were among the fifteen persons killed early yesterday in the crash of a jet tanker near the Westover Air Force Base in Massachusetts.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- Dr. Donald A. Flanders, brother of Senator Ralph Flanders, Republican of Vermont, and director of the Applied Mathematics Division at Argonne National Laboratory at near-by Lemont, was found dead today in his Chicago home.

BONN, Germany, June 27 -- The lower House of Parliament approved provisionally today a $2,380,000,000 defense budget providing for a one-third increase in the West German armed forces during the next fiscal year.

Nine members of the International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, Inc., moved in Federal Court yesterday to enjoin the organization from holding its annual convention until their Local's delegates are elected by members.
BOSTON, June 27 -- Communism is ready to support education in Asia and Africa if Americans fail to do the job, the Rev. Dr. Alford Carleton of the Congregational Christian Churches asserted today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 27 -- The Lebanese Government charged today that the running of guns and armed partisans into Lebanon was continuing despite the presence of a United Nations observer team along the Syrian border.
Development of three new heat-treatable titanium alloys expected to find wide use in advanced aircraft has been announced by the Crucible Steel Company of America.
Six hundred high school teachers from the metropolitan area will have time off at school expense, beginning in the fall, to learn newer concepts of mathematics.

CHICAGO, June 27 (AP) -- Milling and baking interests continued buying wheat far ahead of immediate requirements today. This activity almost exclusively sent prices substantially higher, although the gains were trimmed slightly just before the close of the Board of Trade.

EASTCHESTER, N. Y., June 27 -- The Japanese mission to the United Nations taught the town of Eastchester today that the distance between two points should be measured as a crow flies and not as an automobile travels.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today formally nominated Charles C. Finucane of Spokane, Wash., to be an Assistant Secretary of Defense.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 27 -- Only one man reached the round of sixteen today in the all-England lawn tennis championships. A driving rain delayed, interrupted and finally washed out play as a gloomy crowd of 20,000 moped around the sodden lawns until supper time.

M'GUIRE AIR FORCE BASE, N. J., June 27 -- A concrete blockhouse crammed with electronic gear was dedicated here today. It was the first step in the establishment of a new $1,000,000,000 national air-defense system.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon today pinned the highest Boy Scout award -- the Eagle Badge -- on James W. Stewart, a grinning, 14-year-old lad from Westfield, N. J.
ALREADY the chemise has crossed the Pacific to be seen here and there on the streets of Tokyo. But in Japan the chemise will never assume the importance of the kimono.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (UPI) -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People urged Congress today to pass new civil rights legislation to "prevent future mob violence on the desegregation front."
BOSTON, June 27 -- The House Special Subcommittee on Legislative Oversight was accused by a Boston publisher today of "smear and run" tactics in having permitted John Fox to testify.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- The Senate Interior Committee approved today a liberalized version of the Administration's stabilization program for domestic production of lead, zinc, fluorspar and tungsten.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 27 (Reuters) -- The Cambodian Government ordered large troop reinforcements into action today to fight an alleged invasion from neighboring South Vietnam.
LONDON, June 27 (Reuters) -- The Iraq Petroleum Company said today that the export of crude oil from Iraq to the Mediterranean was back to normal.
MEMPHIS, June 27 (UPI) -- A three-judge Federal court panel rejected today a suit to eliminate segregated seating on city buses in Tennessee.

The City Housing Authority unanimously absolved its budget coordinator of misconduct and reinstated him to his job with back pay yesterday. The coordinator, Sidney Schackman, was suspended Jan. 30 on charges of misconduct in his relationship with the Nassau Management Company, Inc.

In your profile published June 6 of Dr. Theodor Heuss, the President of West Germany, you indicated that Dr. Heuss was one of the handful of Deputies who refused to vote for the enabling act that made Hitler a legal dictator. This statement is not correct.

Only two Yankees were rated highly enough by the player-voters to win a starting spot on the American League's All-Star team, which will tangle with a National League outfit for the twenty-sixth time this year.
The Town and Country Club, one of the largest cabarets in the metropolitan area, filed a bankruptcy petition yesterday in Federal Court in Brooklyn. The club is at 2544 Flatbush Avenue.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., June 27 (UPI) -- A Snark guided missile, launched by the Air Force's first Strategic Missile Squadron, sped on a 5,500-mile practice mission today to close out a busy week at this test center.
ALGIERS, June 27 -- French troops and nationalist rebel forces clashed near the Tunisian border early yesterday in the heaviest fighting since the end of April.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Labor Department reported today that insured unemployment had declined for the ninth consecutive week. But the Commerce Department sought to cushion the impact of larger unemployment figures to come.
HARTFORD, June 27 -- Senator John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, said tonight that the Lebanon crisis found the United States "once again on the brink of war."
Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church in this country and prelates of Anglican communions in other countries will converge on England in the next few days for the Lambeth Conference.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The United States assured Afghanistan today of continued economic aid.
New Jersey school districts sold bond issues totaling $3,103,000 Thursday night.
The Board of Regents has decided to televise educational programs for the New York City area starting in September over station WPIX instead of WOR-TV as originally planned.

The first of a three-volume narrative on the development of Japanese civilization by Sir George Samson will be published in November by Stanford University Press. It will be called "A History of Japan, To 1334."

In the many excellent and thoughtful pieces that were written about the death of Herbert Bayard Swope it was duly recorded that he won the first Pulitzer Prize for reporting in 1917. Some of the obits carried the additional intelligence that The New York World won two Pulitzer Prizes for public service under his leadership in 1922 and 1924.

CLEVELAND, June 27 (AP) -- The Seventh Day Adventists concluded the business portion of their forty-eighth quadrennial world conference today after taking action aimed at strengthening radio and television work.

WHITE PLAINS, June 27 -- Construction of a $1,350,000 Methodist church of contemporary design was begun here this week. It will be the new home of the Memorial Methodist Church, which has sold its 1903 building on Main Street, in the heart of the downtown shopping centre, for $850,000.

A stockholders suit was filed yesterday in Federal Court here against thirty-six officers of the Norden-Ketay Corporation and Lehman Brothers, investment banking concern. The defendants were charged with having used a "scheme" to sell the plaintiffs the stock, for which they paid $14 a share and which now has a market price of $2.75 a share.
WARSAW, June 27 -- Shipments of relief supplies from Roman Catholic organizations in the United States are being held up at Polish docks.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- John Fox quoted Bernard Goldfine today as having said he had bought a house in Washington for Sherman Adams and had sent checks to Mr. Adams at regular intervals over a long period of time. Mr. Fox's statement drew angry denials from the White House.
FOR most women in New York, shopping in the stores is a pleasurable business and bargains are frequent.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Someone once asked Premier Mohammad Daud's predecessor in office, his uncle, Mahmoud, why Afghanistan accepted aid from the Soviet Union. In reply the Afghan Premier recalled that, according to the precepts of the Moslem religion, a man may not eat pork unless he is starving.
DETROIT, June 27 -- George Romney, president of the American Motors Corporation, praised today the action of the Securities and Exchange Commission regarding stock transactions of Louis E. Wolfson.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, June 27 (AP) -- Hungary refused today to answer a United Nations request for information on the recent executions of former Premier Imre Nagy and three other leaders of the 1956 Hungarian revolt.
Milton M. Bergerman announced yesterday the addition of seven members to the executive committee of the Citizens Union, which he heads. The union is a non-partisan civic organization.

After a night's postponement, the moon shone strong and clear, the wind blew sweetly over Lewisohn Stadium, and a fair-sized audience turned out to greet Guiomar Novaes. The Brazilian pianist was making her debut with Stadium Concerts. This is the first season that she has ever appeared on the summer circuit.
Top business executives, influenced by the economic downturn, are going in more for how-to-do-it courses and less for instruction that pays off in the future.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 -With the belated blessing of the State Department, two Soviet scientists visited a tech-Soviet scientists visited today a technological laboratory from which they had been barred by international red tape.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 27 (UPI) -- Premier Sami es-Solh made a statement to United Press International today denying that he had officially asked that a United Nations police force be dispatched to Lebanon. The request was reported to have been made to Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The House Appropriations Committee slashed $872,000,000 today from the President's request for foreign aid funds, including $325,000,000 from the request for the new development loan fund.
High-fidelity fans will hear their first network radio stereophonic programs from next Thursday through Sunday, July 6, over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- Farm prices ended a six-month advance in the month ended June 15, dropping about 3 1/2 per cent. New crops of some products started moving to market in volume to ease scarcities and pull down prices. The declines reported today by the Department of Agriculture were chiefly in vegetables, wheat, cattle and potatoes.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., June 27 -- Easterner, the Boston candidate to become defender of the America's Cup, slid into the quiet waters of Little Harbor tonight on the impetus of a little girl's launching blow.

The avalanche of cases that has inundated the Federal courts has so clogged their calendars that in the Eastern District of New York it now takes almost four years to wind up a civil case and in the Southern District the average time is 28.8 months. For all the Federal District Courts in the country the median figure is 14.2 months.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., June 27 -- Ready or not, Monticello Raceway opened for business on schedule tonight. Business was good, too, even though conditions inside and outside the new harness racing track were not. A crowd of 6,350 wagered $252,963.

Idun is just as good as ever, as she emphatically demonstrated before 19,091 fans at Belmont Park yesterday. The filly, who runs for Mrs. C. Ulrick Bay, sped to a three-length victory over Countess Marcy in a six-furlong sprint. There were a half-dozen 3-year-old fillies in the race in which Idun, carrying top weight of 121 pounds, was timed in 1:11.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -An inter-American educational conference took steps today to deal with the problems of illiteracy, lack of schools and low teacher standards in the American republics.
The Kroger Company, the nation's third largest retail food chain in sales, increased its earnings 12 per cent in the 24 weeks ended June 14. Sales were up 9 per cent.

Reports of border incursions on the frontier between Cambodia and the free Republic of Vietnam, with an accompaniment of charges and countercharges, stem from a local situation, not an international crisis. The frontier between the two countries is by no means clearly defined and trespass is easy. More than that, there are occasional wandering groups at odds with authority that might well seek refuge one way or the other.

There was a disconcerting note in the paper the other day. Out in an agricultural station, it said, efforts are going forward to breed a hog shaped like a cigar. Long, lean and low hogs are being assembled for this purpose, and through a combination of propinquity, nature and the Mendelian law, there no doubt will emerge a perfect panatela.

The New York Public Service Commission announced yesterday that permission had been granted to the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad to increase passenger fares within the state 5 per cent, effective next Tuesday.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 27 (Reuters) -- Interior Minister Rudolf Barak said today that Western espionage was increasing its activity in Czechoslovakia.
LONDON, June 27 -- Two United States Air Force jet tanker airplanes swept over London today after a record-breaking trans-Atlantic flight that started in tragedy.

NORTH HILLS, L. I., June 27 -- Sybil Wolfensohn, Engineers, shot 82 -- 9 -- 73 to win the Rosalie M. Knapp Trophy in an 18-hole play-off with Mrs. Alan A. Ryan, Creek, who had 84 -- 5 -- 79 at the Links Club today.
DETROIT, June 27 (AP) -- Ford's return to full production will raise automobile output 9.6 per cent this week, Ward's automotive reports said today.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 27 (Reuters) -- The Yugoslav Government accused the Chinese Communist Government today of "crudity" and of abandoning "traditional Chinese politeness."
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Maurice A. Hutcheson, president of the Carpenters Union, refused to tell a Senate committee today whether he had used union funds to fix an Indiana conspiracy case against him.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Senate rejected today a compromise to give the Territory of Alaska a commonwealth status instead of full statehood. The vote was 50 to 29. The proposal was made by Senator A. S. Mike Monroney, Democrat of Oklahoma.
Because of the Fourth of July holiday, the pace of new offerings in the capital market will be somewhat slower in the week ahead than it has been this month.

PARIS, June 27 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle said tonight that before the end of this year the problems of the Algerian rebellion, economic imbalance and governmental instability would be solved or on the way to solution.
Paul Hartman, dancing satirist, has been signed for a featured role in the forthcoming comedy "Drink to Me Only," by Abram S. Ginnes and Ira Wallach.
Jean H. Jackson, the 35-year-old patrolman who has confessed to stealing almost $30,000 from the Police Property Clerk's offices, was held in $25,000 bail yesterday in Felony Court.
CHICAGO, June 27 -- A leading Reform rabbi predicted here today that Orthodox Judaism would deteriorate into a "dissenting minority sect."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 27 -- Moslems here turned an important great religious festival into a political demonstration against the Government today. The heavy rebel attack expected by Government quarters for two days had not taken place up to tonight, but the holiday was used to take a public stand against President Camille Chamoun and his Government.

SARANAC INN, N. Y., June 27 -- Chief Judge Albert Conway of the State Court of Appeals today reported that "substantial progress" had been made by the state judicial conference in preparing a plan for reorganization of the state's courts.
MEXICO CITY, June 27 -- Negotiations for a multi-million-dollar loan to construct a 500-mile natural gas pipeline from the Gulf Coast to Mexico City are near completion.

The kind of defamatory testimony that the House Subcommittee on Legislative Oversight permitted the Boston entrepreneur .John Fox to spread upon the public record yesterday and Thursday about Sherman Adams could on the face of it convince no impartial person that the Assistant to the President had actually done any of the outrageous things of which he was being at second hand accused.
In a swiftly paced duel between rising local lightweights, Johnny Busso handed Carlos Ortiz the latter's first professional defeat at Madison Square Garden last night.

Hectic buying was set off yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange when a rumor was circulated on the trading floor that Brazil was negotiating the sale of cocoa to the Soviet Union and her Satellites. Final prices rose 71 to 100 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 643 lots.

The embattled Tuscarora Indians won a temporary victory yesterday in Federal Court. The New York State Power Authority was restrained at least until Thursday from clearing timber or buildings from the Tuscarora reservation near Niagara Falls for a projected reservoir.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Following are the texts of a letter by Representative Joseph P. O'Hara, Republican of Minnesota, to Sherman Adams, the President's Assistant; Mr. Adams' reply; a statement by James C. Hagerty, the White House press secretary, and a statement tonight by Mr. Adams:
CHICAGO, June 27 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Walter Hough of Valley Stream retired yesterday after fifty-one years as a bank clerk and thirty-two years as a Long Island Rail Road commuter. Mr. Hough, who is 65 years old, said he had been happy with his job and happy with the railroad.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -The Army today awarded contracts totaling nearly $80,000,000 for medium tanks and more than $44,000,000 for new missiles and missile site construction.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (UPI) -- Organizations representing physicians and dentists came out today against a bill to provide free medical and hospital care for persons who receive Social Security benefits.
WHILE the fashion war rages topside over the chemise, the trapeze and the Empire line, undercover agents are quietly reshaping the body beneath these new silhouettes.
John A. Ward, in a letter printed June 18, raises a number of objections to the proposed Narrows bridge and the approach to the bridge in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn These objections deserve answer.
PITTSBURGH, June 27 -- A ruling that Roman Catholic lawyers must consult the diocese on all divorce cases they handle is being promoted here after having been fairly dormant for eight years.
LOS ANGELES, June 27 (AP) -- Murray Rose of Australia defeated Tsuyoshi Yamanaka of Japan in the 1,500-meter free-style race at the international swimming meet tonight.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 27 -- Government troops consolidated their positions in the environs of Menado today following their capture of the rebel capital at the northern tip of the Celebes yesterday.

The five-story business building at 79-81 Park Place, northwest corner of Greenwich Street, has been purchased by the Sterling Investing Corporation. The property is 53 by 43 feet and is assessed at $50,000. It is a block west of the southwest corner of Church and Murray Street where Dewey Carver, realty investor, has assembled a plot for improvement with a twenty-five-story office building.
There was much rejoicing on the sidewalks of New York yesterday as the city's schools closed for the summer. But there were tears, too, as 39,340 youngsters learned that they had not been promoted.
KANSAS CITY, June 27 -- The Yankees tonight moved with characteristic effectiveness to squelch another uprising in the ranks of the downtrodden American League.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 27 (UPI)--The all-England ten...
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Following are excerpts from the testimony at today's session of the Special House Subcommittee on Legislative Oversight:
LONDON, June 27 -- Two Soviet Embassy officials flew to the Shetland Islands today to see the commodore of the Soviet fishing fleet from which an Estonian fisherman fled Wednesday night.

The Canadian National Railways in May broke into the black after reporting losses in each of the first four months of this year. The system reported a net operating income of $694,000. In May of 1957 net operating income was $3,065,000.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 27 (UPI) -- A toymaker announced today that he was giving one of the world's biggest toy stores to its best customers -- the children of Denmark.

WASHINGTON. June 27 (AP) -- Senator John W. Bricker, Republican of Ohio, said today that he had sent a character-reference letter to an attorney accused by the Securities and Exchange Commission of having given false and misleading testimony.

A CALORIE-conscious reader, Mrs. Ellen Lind of New York City, would like to know how the caloric content of foods is determined. She wonders because she has often noted that different charts vary as to the number of calories in the same quantity of the same food.
DETROIT, June 27 (AP) -- Fay Crocker of Montevideo, Uruguay, established a record for United States Women's Open play today but her five-under-par 68 failed to dislodge Mickey Wright from the lead.

CHICAGO, June 27 (AP) -- Lefty Billy Pierce of the White Sox pitched eight and two-thirds innings of perfect ball against the Senators tonight, but lost his bid for a pitching masterpiece when Ed FitzGerald hit a pinch double to right field. Chicago defeated Washington, 3 -- 0.
HAVANA, June 27 -- Cuban rebels kidnapped ten Americans and two Canadians last night from a mining company's property on the north coast of Oriente Province.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Gov. Milward L. Simpson of Wyoming urged the Senate today to approve legislation to preserve the National Guard in the Administration's military reorganization program.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- The State Department said today the engineers kidnapped by the rebels last night were taken to the hills in southeastern Cuba. The rebels were commanded by Raoul Castro, brother of rebel chief Fidel Castro, according to the State Department.
William Richter, a lawyer, won reinstatement of his state notary public license yesterday after defending an affidavit in the Morris L. Ernst report in the Jesus de Galindez case.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (UPI) -- Meade Alcorn, Republican National Chairman, conceded today that it was perfectly all right for members of Congress to seek help for constituents from Federal agencies.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower will send a new letter to Soviet Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev this week end emphatically rejecting Moscow's charge that the United States was sabotaging a summit conference, informed sources said tonight.

PEIPING, June 27 (Reuters) -- Renewed resistance of Chinese rule in Sinkiang, central Asian province where most of the population belongs to the Uigur racial minority, was disclosed here today by Jenmin Sihpoo (The People's Daily), newspaper of the Chinese Communist party.
A 19-year-old boy who with two companions had been beating a 62-year-old woman and another youth was shot and killed last night by an off-duty patrolman in Brooklyn.
MANY Americans don't dream of dwelling in marble halls -- they build them and move right in.

A group of college students engaged in some heavy summer cerebration Thursday. They spent the day pondering Advanced Skelly, Elementary Potsy, Hopscotch I and Hopscotch II. Paddle tennis, boxball, basketball, volleyball, shuffle board and sack racing relieved the heavy academic pressures.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower's air safety chief said today that stringent new flight controls adopted by military and civilian aviation had reduced the possibility of mid-air collisions.

Two boxes of firecrackers exploded yesterday in the shoeshine parlor of a man who had been arrested recently on a charge of possessing fireworks. He was injured, as were a 21-month-old boy and at least two other persons.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Average wholesale prices in primary markets rose 0.1 per cent to 119.1 per cent of their 1947-1949 level during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

BERLIN, June 27 -- The eight officers and a sergeant of the United States Army who are detained in East Germany will receive mail and packages through an arrangement between the American and German Red Cross organizations.
The retiring dean of the Princeton University Graduate School, Hugh Stott Taylor, was appointed the first president of the Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation yesterday.
Stocks rose yesterday for the third day. The gains were far from spectacular, but they were steady throughout the day.
The split in transit labor widened yesterday with the report that the Motormen's Benevolent Association would withdraw from the United Transit Employes Council.

George Leggett, the 20-year-old "fuehrer" of the United Nordic Confederation, a band of eight juveniles with Nazi-like ideas, was indicted yesterday in Queens County Court. He faces four counts of burglary, three of petit larceny and one of illegally possessing firearms.

HACKENSACK, N. J., June 27 -- A jury in Bergen County Court today found Joseph Matule and Frank Sogorka not guilty of conspiring to extort $1,000 from a contractor. Each is a former Mayor of Fair Lawn.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- A retired New York manufacturer received a patent this week for a trouser remover. He regards it as a boon to all wearers of trousers and slacks, including women, who have trouble leaning over.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 27 -- Mr. Lodge declared today he would make no comment on the testimony of Mr. Fox except to say his record should speak for itself.

Two new films, both imports, will open at first-run theatres today. "Guendalina," an Italian-made drama with Jacqueline Sassard, Raf Vallone and Raffaele Mattioli, is at the Plaza (Fifty-eighth Street near Madison Avenue).
BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 27 -- The Yugoslavs have come to the Brussels World's Fair intent on showing their pride in their independence and integrity as a people.
MOSCOW, June 27 -- No evidence developed here today on whether the Soviet Union would send its delegation to Geneva.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 27 -- President Carlos P. Garcia of the Philippines made a tour of the Twentieth Century-Fox studio and visited stages where pictures were in the process of filming.
The Navy received eleven bids yesterday for the scrapping of its famed World War II aircraft carrier, Enterprise.

The Western Union Telegraph Company continued to feel the recession in May, according to the monthly statement issued yesterday. Gross revenues and net income for the first five months of this year and for May trailed the 1957 levels by sizable margins.
LONDON, June 27 -- A recovery in sterling helped British Government bonds advance in the stock market today. Elsewhere prices drifted lower with little to tempt buyers.
HARTFORD, June 27 -- The Democratic State Convention opened tonight with prospects of a bitter floor fight for the nomination for United States Senator.

It seems only yesterday that the Franklin D. Roosevelt (East River) Drive was just about the last word in urban traffic arteries. But the continuing growth of the city and the ever-increasing number of vehicles, along with other factors, have made this vital road inadequate, and the time has come to do something about it. The city has announced a $7,000,000 program for modernization and rehabilitation.
SAIDA, Lebanon, June 28 -Rebels rule the old quarter of this ancient Lebanese seaport, but law and order prevail.

IN general, the shipping tolls proposed for the Seaway, as announced by the United States and Canadian toll committees on June 12, are lower than had been expected, lower than those of either the Panama or Suez Canals. The reaction to this fact has been both favorable and unfavorable.

LONDON, June 28 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan declared today that "the blatant perfidy of the Communists" in their treatment of Imre Nagy had made it even more essential that any agreement with them be fully guaranteed.

Volume held up well on the New York commodity exchanges during the first half of this year, despite the recession. The only market that registered a sharp decline in trading from the first half of the two preceding years was the Produce Exchange, where cottonseed oil and soybean oil are traded.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 28 -- Miriam (Mimi) Arnold was a giant-killer on the Center Court today. The tiny Californian caught 6-foot Christine Truman far off balance and cut her down to size, 10 -- 8, 6 -- 3, in the most notable upset of the All-England lawn tennis championships to date.

CINCINNATI, June 28 -- Manager Fred Haney of the Milwaukee Braves today named his ace starter, Warren Spahn, and his star relief hurler, Don McMahon, to the National League mound staff for the All-Star Game at Baltimore July 8.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- George V. Allen, director of the United States Information Agency, said today in a formal report to President Eisenhower that the United States exhibit at the Brussels World's Fair was making a generally good impression on Europeans.
Corporate bond underwriters are cautiously betting that the depressing effect of speculative liquidation in Government issues is ending.
THOSE serious music lovers and record buyers who like to make their own comparisons will no doubt be overjoyed to know that four versions of the Brahms Second Symphony have recently arrived.

President Eisenhower asked Congress last week for speedy approval of an international agreement between the United States and the European Atomic Energy Community, known as Euratom, which, the President said, "will be a first step toward mutually beneficial cooperation in the peaceful application of atomic energy between this new European Community and the United States."

CHICAGO, June 28 -- Round Table scored his eighth stakes victory of 1958 convincingly today, taking the Arch Ward Memorial at Arlington Park to earn $33,000 and become racing's second highest moneywinner in history.
UNITED STATES railroads see the development of the St. Lawrence Seaway turning out just as they had forecast.
The newsprint industry is still in low gear after almost a year of steady declines in production and consumption.

Today marks the start of Safe Boating Week, according to proclamation by President Eisenhower. Therefore, it was timely that a new and fascinating item of safety and survival equipment was unveiled last night.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 28 -- Ten years ago today a startled world heard the news that Marshal Tito's Yugoslavia had been read out of the Communist fold.
THE new St. Lawrence Seaway will open a wide, new door to one of the busiest shipping areas in the world.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., June 28 -- Gangster, a bay gelding owned and ridden by Ralph Petersen of Glen Head, L. I., won the green working hunter championship with 11 points at the Helping Hand horse show today.

The various parts in the America's Cup defense picture became more closely knit last week. There were developments for each of the three new Twelve-Meter yachts that, with the 19-year-old Vim, are the candidates to defend yachting's foremost prize against England's challenge.
Bowling will be in vogue this summer if the American Machine and Foundry Company has its way.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 28 -- Patricia Stewart of Kew Gardens, Queens, and Carole Wright of Brooklyn reached the final round of the women's New York State tennis championships at the Beach Point Club today.

PARIS, June 28 -- French observers see the recent shifts of Soviet policy primarily as an effort to check the current of liberal "revisionism" that set in throughout the Soviet sphere beginning in 1955 and threatened to shake the Kremlin's hegemony.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- The Government announced today the first allocation of Federal funds under the new emergency program for loans to provide unemployment payments to jobless workers whose benefits have expired.

Dr. Tibor Nyilas, a debonair New Yorker who, by his own description, is a middle-aged man with "aggressive" tendencies, was saying the other day that it's too bad this town has so few legal outlets for middleaged men with aggressive tendencies.
Soviet Armenia, where a United States plane was forced down Friday, was one of the most tightly sealed-off areas of the Soviet Union in the last years of Stalin's reign.
A two-year research project that uses electronic computers to analyze business cycles has been approved by the National Science Foundation and the International Business Machines Corporation.

THE next sixty-four days that will bring us through Labor Day, should provide answers to several questions that are putting deep furrows in the brows of motion picture producers and theatre operators alike.

IN Emil Schulthess' color photographs on view through Labor Day in the Corner Gallery at the American Museum of Natural History, color is an inherent, descriptive part of the subject, giving it life and atmosphere which all but disappear when reproduced in black and white.

HOUSTON, June 28 (AP) -Lloyd M. Bentsen Jr., president of Consolidated American Life Insurance Company, announced today the purchase of Lincoln Liberty Life Insurance Company of Lincoln, Neb. The price was $7,000,000.

CLEVELAND -- A side effect of the St. Lawrence Seaway, and not so much to the side, at that, because of its long-range significance here and abroad, is the transformation of public opinion in the Great Lakes states from a solid isolationism and high tariff-ism to one leaning toward One World internationalism and, at least, freer trade.
LONDON, June 28 -- One afternoon last week an armored car of Lebanon's army moved leisurely into position and lobbed a few shells down one of Beirut's narrow, sun-baked streets at some rebel snipers.

Visitors to Spain interested in rehabilitation of the handicapped are struck immediately by two facts: One is the tremendous need for services. The second is evidence of a sincere and growing interest in developing such services.
GENEVA, June 28 (Reuters) -- Western scientists gathering here for the East-West nuclear test detection talks determined today to "go it alone" if the Communists boycotted the session.

PROPAGATING plants in the home garden by means of cuttings, layering and even seed is a practical phase of gardening. Home propagation can come to the rescue when the budget for nursery stock is exhausted.

THIS vigorous and rigorously professional account of a British convoy battling through the Arctic to Russia during World War II begins with a long fighting quote from Admiral Lord Nelson. Most of the characters in the novel that follows perform as though they'd learned it by heart.

ALGIERS, June 28 -- Leaders of the Right-wing Europeans here are hoisting storm signals. They are preparing their followers for Premier de Gaulle's second visit to Algeria next Tuesday by telling them that the trend in Paris is running against Algerian interests.

When a given group asks the Federal Government to reduce the aid it provides for that group, it is a startling development. That is what the growers of extra-long staple cotton, called Supima, have done. For the second time in four years they have demanded that Congress reduce the price supports available on their product.

DETROIT, June 27 -- A group of Detroit physicians reported today that they had tested successfully a four-in-one vaccine that immunizes children simultaneously against poliomyelitis, whooping cough, diphtheria and tetanus.

The writer, who now lives and works in London, produced and did the script of "The Key" (see photo at left) and was responsible for the scenarios of such Hollywood-made films as "High Noon," "The Men" and "Home of the Brave."

INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 28 (AP) -- Annie-Lu-San scored a repeat victory in the $38,700 Vanity Handicap at Hollywood Park today, defeating eleven other mares and fillies for the mythical distaff championship of the meeting.

Department store sales in the nation in the week ended June 21 were 9 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board has reported. There was a drop of 1 per cent a week earlier.

A PROLIFIC interpreter of historical events, Vardis Fisher has done an excellent job of humanizing the Lewis and Clark Expedition in this new novel. It is an almost dayby-day and Indian-by-Indian account of the daring trip. slave girl who guided the explorers over the mountains and contributed to the success of the expedition, is the heroine of the story.
LONDON, June 28 -- Britain has sent a strong protest to the Soviet Government over the landing of about thirty Soviet seamen on the Shetland Islands Wednesday night.

A gigantic submerged "river in the sea," 250 miles wide and 1,000 feet deep, has been mapped by scientists of the University of California's Scripps Institution of Oceanography and the Pacific Oceanic Fishery investigations of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service.

RARE is the year in which Ireland fails to produce at least one fresh talent in the field of fiction. Anthony C. West may live in Wales; he may write of New York during Prohibition or of farmers in Canada today; yet, no matter where his imagination takes him, the eight stories in this volume are as Irish, and a couple of the best as powerful, as those of Liam O'Flaherty.

SIR THOMAS BROWNE observes that "it is the common wonder of all men, how among so many millions of faces there should be none alike." The same might be said of the myriad meanings conveyed by large words, notably Beauty.
WARSAW, June 28 -- Poland's Communists abandoned weeks of painfully held political aloofness today and joined the Soviet bloc's battle against Yugoslavia.
JEFFERSON, N. H., June 28 (UPI) -- A Federal prosecutor called today for laws that he said would help enforcement officers to fight organized crime.
Hank McCabe turned in his badge and revolver last week after twenty years as a deputy United States marshal in the Southern District of New York.

The rose -- a star on the landscape during June -- now must share the spotlight with the bright-faced annuals. Early summer also is a fine time to see the stately Madonna lilies, tree lilacs and Japanese honeysuckle vines. In addition, there are many flowers high overhead -- catalpas, lindens and smoke trees are in bloom in the New York City area. Along the parkways mountain laurel, viburnems and hawthorns call to motorists.

AS in an earlier book, "The Eagle of the Ninth," Rosemary Sutcliff paints here a colorful and convincing picture of Roman Britain, this time in the latter part of the third century. The story begins during the rule of Carausius, and centers on Justin, newly come to Albion to take up his post of junior surgeon.

BOSTON, June 28 -- A resolution calling for "immediate and unconditional cessation of atomic weapons testing for a trial period" was rejected today by delegates to the fourteenth biennial meeting of the General Council of Congregational Christian Churches.
LONDON, June 28 -- Alfred Noyes, poet who probably was best known for his ballad "The Highwayman," died today in a hospital on the Isle of Wight. He was 77 years old.

A tall, lean New Yorker, who admits he doesn't know much about the fight game, returned to Manhattan yesterday from his chosen land -- Los Angeles -to continue his promotion of the next world heavyweight championship fight.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 28 -Millions of Turks forgot Cyprus, high prices and shortages today to celebrate the "Feast of Sacrifice," Kurban Bairam, a four-day Moslem holiday combining prayer and festivity.

MOST persons here agree that the 1958 Biennale -- the twenty-ninth in the series of international art exhibitions held in Venice every second year -- is a disappointing one. Disappointing certainly not for lack of size or generosity of international scope but for the feebleness of some national efforts and because of the absence of the historical documentation of modern art that so conspicuously enriched recent post-war Biennales.
ST. LOUIS, June 28 (AP) -Martin (Bo) Toft, a University of Missouri outfielder, signed today with the Boston Red Sox for a bonus he said was "between $35,000 and $40,000."

It started in Paris, it took New York by storm, now it's sweeping the whole country, this rage for colorful eye make-up. A PREPARED Kodachromeprocessing service providing for direct mailing and return is announced by Eastman Kodak Company. Special mailing bags will be sold, at the present processing cost, for the various Kodachrome sizes, 8mm and 16mm movie film and 35mm and 828 still film.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., June 28 -- Furiously scribbling notes as if they were Washington correspondents at a Presidential news conference, 250 high school and college coaches attended a four-day sports clinic here this week and learned, among other things, that smoked salmon is the proper name for lox.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI) -- Secret documents published by the State Department today said Britain gave the Soviet Union a "half promise" in 1941 that Moscow could dominate Eastern Europe after World War II.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, June 22 -- Dr. Joseph B. Wolffe, a heart specialist, has set up a scientific link between Prague and Moscow in a town near Philadelphia.

ALMOST any discussion of the Washington gift problem comes back to the 12-pound ham. A member of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation told a Senate subcommittee in 1948 that he would accept a 12-pound ham as a gift but not a 13-pound ham. Some scoffed, but others felt this got to the heart of the matter.

YARMOUTH, Nova Scotia -- Resumption of a historic sea service between Boston and this port is scheduled to begin tomorrow when the S.S. Yarmouth sails from Boston for here after a lapse of four years.

NEW DELHI, India, June 28 -- The Government and the responsible section of public opinion in India have not liked many things that have happened in the Soviet Union in recent weeks.

KUTZTOWN, Pa. -- The festivities of the Pennsylvania Dutch people, which have been growing year by year in popularity, so that this summer several hundred thousand visitors from all parts of the Union are expected to attend, begin next Wednesday here with the fiveday-long ninth annual Dutch Folks Celebration.

The Eisenhower-Adams-Goldfine incident, handled copiously, intelligently and with editorial conviction by The New York Times, has ramifications reaching the lowest level of public and private business. How can any boss, whether in the public or private service, expect his staff to be scrupulous in this matter of accepting gifts except as he sets an example?

Factory-new station wagons may "purr," but they do not ordinarily mew. But one was mewing on the Avenue of the Americas last night. About fifty passers-by gathered. The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals was called.

The stimulating report on the mounting crisis in education published by the Rockefeller Brothers Fund is a challenge to the American people to take action before it is too late. It is already later than most of us are willing to believe.

NEW YORK Yankee press agents have been spreading the word around all these years that Yankee fans are the smartest, happiest, tallest, best-dressed, best-fed, bestscrubbed fans in the major leagues. Yankee athletes are portrayed as admirable nonsmoking family men who never get parking tickets and rarely get into brawls at the Copacabana.

THIS swiftly paced novel, set against the Budapest uprising of 1956, follows the fate of 15-year-old Pal Petofi who in six days of battle, confusion and death experiences more than the average man in a lifetime. We first watch the futile attempt

FOR THIS WEEK: Control rose powdery mildew with acti-dione. . . . Continue harvesting strawberries. . . . Spray pachysandra plantings with DDT or malathion to ward off leaf-tying caterpillars. . . . Water plantings under roof overhangs; rain does not always get to them. . . . Pinch off faded blooms from annuals and perennials to prevent seed formation and encourage flowering.

PHILADELPHIA, June 28 (UPI) -- The Philadelphia Phillies made a triple play today, but five-hit pitching by Sal Maglie and a grand slam homer by Gene Green helped the St. Louis Cardinals to an 8-1 victory.

WHATEVER Frenchmen a month ago hoped or feared Charles de Gaulle would do as Premier, they were agreed on at least one thing. His long years of bitter opposition to the Fourth Republic and his return in the wake of a nationalist "coup" in Algiers guaranteed his being a strong man who would move fast, step on toes and generally take striking and unorthodox action on all fronts.

LIVING in Ireland is a little like being perpetually mulled. The moist air and constant rain muffle sounds, blur edges, gloss faults. The dividing line between fact and fancy, humor and tragedy, good and evil grows hazy and indistinct.

WITH authority, insight and precision of analysis, Loren Eiseley has traced evolutionary thought and discovery from the Renaissance to the end of the nineteenth century and beyond, explaining not only the achievements of Charles Darwin and Alfred Wallace but the antecedent achievements which made them possible and the subsequent achievements which confirmed and clarified them.

MOSCOW, June 28 (AP) -Bobby Fischer, the 15-year-old whiz kid of American chess, has had little trouble with the complicated maneuvering at Moscow's Central Chess Club but he has become ensnarled in some Soviet red tape.

NANGAL, India, June 22 -When the monsoon breaks over northern India in a few weeks, the mighty Bhakra Dam on the Sutlej River in East Punjab will start storing the flood waters. That will mark the beginning of a new era of prosperity for the people of Punjab and Rajasthan.

The U. S. Supreme Court on May 31, 1955, ordered those District Courts which had heard school segregation cases "to take such proceedings and enter such orders and decrees * * * as are necessary and proper to admit [Negro pupils] to public schools on a racially nondiscriminatory basis with all deliberate speed * * *."

IN 1954, when Louis L. Lorillard, George T. Wein and fellow enthusiasts decided to stage a summer jazz festival at Newport, R. I., they seemed like daring innovators. Yet look what has happened since.
MOST Americans while on trips in their own land, fail to take advantage of the truly American foods of the country.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 28 -- Henry (Hank) Enos' Luders16 Bantam beat Souther (Chick) Whittelsey's Interlude by three and a half minutes in the Eastern fleets Y. R. A. championship regatta at Indian Harbor Y. C. today.

KANSAS CITY, June 28 -Whitey Ford, ace southpaw of the Yankees, gained his 100th victory as a major league pitcher tonight as Casey Stengel's Bombers flattened the Athletics, 8 to 0. This was their second straight triumph in the three-game series.

A TWENTY-ACRE area of submerged land just north of the present harbor entrance has been enclosed by 1,900 feet of heavy steel sheet piling bulkhead to build up the equivalent of an additional pier to serve Seaway trade.

MASSENA, N. Y. -- The St. Lawrence project is expected to generate enough tourist interest to bring at least half a million people to the power dam area this summer. Five years from now, it is believed, attendance will run to several million a year.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., June 28 -- At noon on Tuesday, Mrs. Homer L. Ferguson of Warwick and Mrs. P. W. Hiden of Newport News will cut ribbons in a ceremony at Sixty-fourth Street and Huntington Avenue overlooking the James River.
The nation's stores, big and little, department, specialty, food, supermarket or whatever, are presenting a new face to the buying public.
A typical news program beamed to the West by the Moscow Radio last week -- specifically on Friday, June 27 -- led off with these items:
EAST NORWICH, L. I., June 28 -- Once again Arnold Palmer paid little heed to par in the Pepsi golf championship.
WESTBURY, L. I., June 28 -- Duane Hanover, the "old reliable" among the free-for-all campaigners at Roosevelt Raceway did it again tonight.

MANCHESTER, Vt. -- For a hundred years Vermont developed slowly as a tourist attraction, carefully and hesitantly in its old-fashioned way. But in the last three or four years the pace has quickened, a number of sophisticated (but small) resort centers have developed and more than a hundred new motels have sprung up everywhere along the state's main roads.

NEWARK, June 28 -- The Federal Housing Administration has been called upon to refuse to guarantee mortgages on New Jersey's Levittown unless the agency was "affirmatively satisfied" that the builder planned to abandon his "announced" policy of discrimination.

RANGOON, Burma, June 28 -- Premier Nu will ask President Win Maung to dissove Parliament early in September sources close to the Premier disclosed today. Under the Burmese Constitution a national election must follow Parliament's dissolution within sixty days.

TOKYO, June 23 -- A joint Japanese-French survey of extreme ocean depths off the coast of Japan, begun last week, has brought new scientific light on a world of perpetual darkness where strange plantlike life exists in hitherto unsuspected currents.

The United Seamen's Service recorded one of the most successful years in its history in 1957, Vice Admiral E. L. Cochrane, U.S.N., retired, president of the organization, reported last week. Its net operating deficit amounted to $25,370, he said.

Non-agricultural employment in Illinois in May was 4,900 below the April level and 206,800 less than in May, 1957, the State Employment Service has reported. The May total was 3,288,300. Manufacturing industries, with 1,091,400 employed in May, showed a decline of 17,600 from April and 164,700 from the 1957 figures.
THIS Steel City looks to the approaching reality of the Seaway in terms of a number of questions that still need an answer.

WORK was started here this spring on a 120-acre public marine terminal for which the initial outlay will be $10,000,000. The terminal is on the western side of Duluth-Superior harbor near the Interstate bridge which connects Duluth with Superior, Wis.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI) -- The pilots will welcome the jetliners -- but with fingers crossed.

LONDON, June 28 -- Eric Page Bedford, former second secretary of the British Embassy in Prague, who was expelled by the Czechoslovak Government, said today that the accusation against him was a frame-up.
WHITE PLAINS, June 28 -- Scholarly planning is gradually supplanting political maneuvering and guesswork in the development of new shopping and office districts in Westchester County.

The economy swings into the second half of the year this week, and the chips will be down. In the months ahead, the big question remains to be answered: Is the worst recession since World War II drawing to a close? The decline has lasted almost a year. Last August, key barometers began to fall in earnest, although signs of a downturn were evident well before then.
There are times when race chairmen would welcome a wind machine powerful enough to produce all-out competition in the programs of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound.

An interesting period-piece, the Brecht-Weill Rise and Fall of the City of Mahagonny, has arrived in a three-disk set from Columbia. "Mahagonny," which had its first performance March 9, 1930, in Leipzig, and reached Berlin two years later, is set, supposedly, in the United States.

ONE recent Sabbath a city brownstone dweller went for a stroll in Central Park in search of sunshine and scenery. The sun was there, all right, but for the most part it glinted off Wyatt Earp Specials, Lone Ranger 32's, Hideaway Derringers, futuristic pistols (with death rays in three colors) and a totally new species of rifle that, not content with merely winging its victims, would settle only for complete disintegration.
HARTFORD, June 28 -Thomas J. Dodd, a former United States Representative, won the Democratic nomination for United States Senator today.

FUCHSIAS are widely grown on the West Coast where they lend dramatic beauty to gardens. Home owners have ingeniously trained them in espalier fashion, or the plants may be seen cascading from hanging baskets on porches and terraces.

MONZA, Italy, June 28 (AP) -A new twelve-cylinder Ferrari driven by Luigi Musso of Italy today won the pole position for tomorrow's 500-mile race against a brilliant field of Indianapolis aces and American cars.
