A warning that profligate spending for education in the United States may bring tax increases up to $9,000,000,000 by 1970 is contained in a study published yesterday by the Institute for Social Science Research in Washington.
IF, as even the stubborn romantic must at last concede, the prospects for building new legitimate theatres have receded beyond the point of vision, then it is necessary to make do with what we have.

THIS year's thirty-second world festival of the International Society for Contemporary Music not only lacked the sensational climax provided at last year's Zurich event (the stage premiere of Schoenberg's "Moses and Aaron"), but also there was little in the nature of its programs to attract an international public.

A tiny Californian, Miriam (Mimi) Arnold defeated Christine Truman, young British star, yesterday in the most notable upset of the all-England tournament. The scores were 10 -- 8, 6 -- 3. Barry MacKay, Budge Patty, Gardnar Mulloy, Althea Gibson and Mrs. Margaret Osborne du Pont were the other American victors.
New fashions and colors have stirred considerable interest in the fall styles, and retailers have been buying with enthusiasm, according to reports from resident buying offices.
LOS ANGELES, June 28 -Jon Henricks of Australia barely defeated Makoto Fukui of Japan in the 200-meter freestyle tonight as the international swim meet went into its second evening of competition.

The country's purchasing agents, who buy the materials and supplies that are made into all types of goods, are getting more cheerful with each passing month. For the third month in a row they indicate increasing optimism over the outlook.

Disagreement among scientists and science teachers as to what should be taught in the classroom was disclosed last week in a report by the Science Manpower Project of Teachers College, Columbia University.

ARTISTIC and literary movements are usually characterized in their early years by an ambitious program, by a youthful ambition to impose theories on the world, and even to change and modify the world by means of a particular vision.

THE final curtain comes down tomorrow night on one of the legitimate theatre's most noteworthy seasons in years. The 1957-58 term, according to the critics, was high in artistic content and imaginative in scope -- truly a vintage year.

Art auction galleries had no need during the season just ended to exhort the public to "buy now." As the records of the Parke-Bernet Galleries here show, collectors and dealers bought heavily, and at fancy prices.

TIME was when a career novel almost invariably whisked its protagonist through a dazzling variety of experiences leading him or her in very short time up the success ladder. Now, judging by some recent examples, the pattern is more realistic -- and a refreshing change it is too.

TOKYO, June 28 -- The execution of Mr. Nagy and his associates has had a profound effect upon public opinion in Japan. Even the Left-wing circles, usually tolerant of Communist excesses, have been estranged, at least temporarily, from their more radical political allies in the general outburst of indignation over the Hungarian tragedy.

MONZA, Italy, June 28 -- The so-called Race of Two Worlds -Indianapolis cars against European machines -- will be disputed here tomorrow. More than $80,000 in prize money will be distributed and more than 100,000 spectators will cheer what is likely to be the fastest race of all time, average speeds approaching 170 m. p. h.

BUFFALO'S dream of becoming a world port with the advent of the St. Lawrence Seaway is a conditional one. Two factors hold the key to the dream: (1) Federal funds for harbor deepening and (2) the economic benefits of the Seaway to the city.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., June 28 -- The Brielle Anglers walked off with the top two trophies today in the second annual Greater Atlantic City tuna tournament.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 28 -- Gov. Orval E. Faubus picked up new support this week in his bid for a third two-year term as a result of a Federal court order suspending school integration here until 1961.
The aluminum industry was beginning to feel dangerously neglected last week, as the Senate Interior Committee approved proposals to help other ailing metals with price supports and stockpile buying.

TO speed up the Job of painting wire fences, an ordinary paint roller and tray will do the work much faster than a brush. Buy one of the special deep-pile lamb's wool covers which are sold for this purpose in all paint stores.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -Since the 1954 and 1956 decisions declaring school segregation unconstitutional and ordering its end "with all deliberate speed," the Supreme Court has deliberately steered clear of the school controversy. It has left the complex problems of implementing the decisions to be worked out by the lower courts.
IF "The Ghost of Follonsbee's Folly" were presented on TV, it would be rated as a situation comedy, and a very good one too.

CROSS RIVER, N. Y., June 28 -- A farmer has asked Governor Harriman to call an immediate session of the Legislature, if necessary, to stop state troopers from "harassing" him and other farmers with vehicle and traffic law technicalities.
HACKENSACK, N. J., June 28 -- Sid Schwartz, New York, and Jerry Moss, University of Miami, scored straight-set victories today to gain the final round of the Eastern clay court tennis championships.
Of all the chicken-today-and-feathers-tomorrow industries, railroad car building probably comes up most often with its mouth full of feathers.

OCEANPORT, N. J., June 28 (AP) -- Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs' Searching, under top weight of 120 pounds, circled the leaders entering the stretch to win the thirteenth running of the $28,850 Molly Pitcher Handicap for fillies and mares today at Monmouth Park.

The New York Public Library's Main Reading Room in the Fifth Avenue and Fortysecond Street building, will remain open from 1 to 10 P. M. on Friday, Independence Day. All other divisions will be closed, and all neighborhood branches.

WITHIN the next month the prolific and stimulating production team of Hecht-Hill-Lancaster will be substantially, if temporarily, British-based. Harold Hecht is already established to produce his first film here, George Bernard Shaw's "The Devil's Disciple," which will go on the floor at the A. B. C. studios at Elstree in mid-July.

WOULD television viewers enjoy reading detailed reviews of new programs before they went on the air rather than after? Would they respond to a reviewing system that would enable them in the morning to have some clue whether the evening's schedule of video contained a glorious triumph that should not be missed or a routine presentation that could be overlooked?
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Leaving out the never-ending task of gradually reducing tariff barriers to world trade, observers here generally identify three distinct "problems" in the free world economy.
BELGRADE, June 28 -- The Yugoslavs, who have long been clamoring for a summit conference, are more dismayed than they care to admit over the latest turn of events in Moscow and Peiping.

CHICAGO, June 28 -- The Commission on Jewish Education announced here today a "master plan" of religious instruction designed to offset what it described as an increasing concentration on scientific studies.
EXHIBITIONS of photographic prints in blackand-white and in color on various themes are announced by local and other galleries.
The elimination of political leaders' names from Soviet geography has been going on apace, giving a "new look" to the map of the Soviet Union.

MEXICO CITY, June 28 -The United States Embassy here and its consular personnel have been alerted to the possibility that one or more North American Communists now residing in Mexico may soon apply for United States passports.

OTTAWA -- Of all the industries and groups anticipating big benefits from the opening of the St. Lawrence Seaway, the United States steel industry has the highest hopes and perhaps the most justification for them.
CHICAGO, June 28 -- The Illinois State Bar Association assailed today a Senate bill designed to limit the jurisdiction of the United States Supreme Court.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 28 -Rebel forces made an all-night attack on the northern port city of Tripoli and almost succeeded in breaking the Government defense lines last night.

THIS week the twenty-sixth annual Jacob's Pillow Festival, near Lee, Mass., will get under way with Ted Shawn, its founder, also at the helm as director. Performances will be given Tuesday, Wednesday, Friday and Saturday evenings at 9, and Thursday, Friday and Saturday afternoons at 4.
MONTAUK, L. I., June 28 -Judge Harold R. Medina declared here today that he would rather see every Communist in America go "scot free" than to surrender any part of the Bill of Rights.

WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., June 28 (AP) -- William Sadler of St. Catherines, Ont., won the annual Glen Classic sports-car race today in a car of his own design.

Rain and cool weather deterred Kansas City shoppers last week and retail trade barely managed to hold its own with volume a year ago. The bright spot in the district was Oklahoma, where the wheat harvest has been completed and the grain is moving to market to produce income for the growers.

TWO masters of French graphic art are represented in a newly opened summer show at the Metropolitan Museum -- Jacques Callot (1592-1635) and Honore Daumier (1808-79) -- both of whom found material in the civil and military unrest of their respective centuries so that the current exhibition has an odd angle of timeliness to link their work with France of today.

OTTAWA -- A major factor in the smooth flow of relations between Canada and the United States has been the Treaty of 1909 providing for the joint use of boundary waters and the streams that cross that border.

Red God of the Cain Hoy Stable had a four-length margin over the Greentree's Stable's Cohoes at the finish of the $27,700 Roseben at Belmont Park yesterday. It wasn't until several minutes after the sevenfurlong fixture had been run, though, that the accomplishment of the 4-year-old son of Nasrullah was declared official.

The United States now has to make a choice between two disagreeable alternatives in the crisis in Lebanon. One is to stand by while the pro-Western Government of Camille Chamoun is forced out of office. The other is to join Britain in sending enough troops to stop the intervention of the United Arab Republic and permit the Lebanese to decide on their own Government.

Flota Mercante Grancolombiana, Ltda, is contributing importantly to the development of trade between South and Central America and the United States and Canada, Dr. Alvaro Diaz, president of the Colombian - Ecuadorian shipping venture, asserted yesterday.
The newest of the Pentagon's agencies is now in business and a going concern.
BOWLING GREEN, Ohio, June 28 -- The nation's high school students may not be aware of it but they face "more demanding, more challenging" school programs.
NEWARK, June 28 -- A statewide study of New Jersey's municipal police departments found that in "many instances" poor management caused "inefficient, uneconomical and unsatisfactory service."

These Vassar girls seem to have emerged from one of the "Big Seven" women's colleges with very little awareness either of their own potentialities or of the needs of the society in which they live. There is scant indication, for example, that they will contribute much toward relieving our shortage of scientific and professional manpower.

THE loss of areas of bark from the trunks of trees is a common and often very serious type of damage. It matters little whether the injury was inflicted by an animal, lawn mower, delivery truck or child.
A rabbi and his son discussed the younger generation yesterday in a special service conducted by recent school and college graduates at Congregation Shaaray Tefila, Far Rockaway, Queens.

The steel operating rate in the Cleveland-Lorain district climbed to 48 per cent of capacity in the week ended June 21, a gain of 22 points above the recent low of 26 per cent five weeks ago. Although production has risen sharply, the firmness of the expanded level is being questioned by district steel officials.

NEWARK, June 28 -- An agreement between the North Jersey District Council of Ironworkers and three groups of contractors has been reached. The pact, providing a 54-cent-hourly package increase over a three-year period, eliminates a threat by the ironworkers to strike Tuesday, when the current pact expires.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI) -- Paul M. Butler, Democratic National Chairman, said today "the mere fact that President Eisenhower is a military man does not make him the only person competent to judge what is needed in our military establishment."
A major irony of present monetary policy lies in the fact that a device the Federal Reserve long has sought to abolish is providing the major impetus to recovery in the private sector of the economy.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 28 (UPI) -- Johnny Konsek, the Big Ten champion, and Phil Rodgers gained the National Collegiate golf final today.

A report by the Rockefeller Brothers Fund, which took as its basic thesis the concept that all men are not equally endowed with the capacity to learn and should not be educated as though they were, provoked some debate in education circles last week.

This city is filled with institutions of one kind or another -- commercial, educational, charitable, public, private, old and new -- any one of which might serve to illustrate Emerson's astute observation that "an institution is the lengthened shadow of one man."
CHATTANOOGA, June 28 (AP) -- Alex Olmedo and Grant Golden gained the men's singles final of the Tenessee Valley invitation tennis tournament today.

The announcement that the forty-second annual conference of the International Labor Organization now meeting in Geneva has adopted by an overwhelming vote a convention aimed at eliminating discrimination in employment is welcome evidence that the international effort to define and protect human rights is recovering its original impetus.
WITHIN ninety days the automobile industry will gamble more than a billion dollars on its new cars -- the 1961 models that will not appear in dealers' showrooms until twenty-seven months from now.

LONDON, June 28 -- Although they think it is too early to be certain, British experts on Soviet behavior feel that recent events in the Soviet Union and its European satellites presage the return to the open hostility to the West of the "cold war."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 28 -- Three islanders from the South Pacific will fly here Monday to tell the United Nations about life in Western Samoa.

TORONTO, Ont. -- Harnessing the St. Lawrence River at the great power dam, between Barnhart Island on the United States side and the Canadian shore about two miles upstream from Cornwall, marks the end of an era in Ontario.
With the weather only a degree below normal, stores in the New York area did rather good business last week. Observers estimated that sales were 2 to 3 per cent above the 1957 level.

PREPARATIONS for the opening of the Seaway have been under way for almost five years here and currently in progress is a $7,000,000 public wharf extension. Plans have also been laid for an additional four miles of warehouses and docks on the inside of the sandstrip which encloses the harbor.

THE portable quarter-inch electric drill, most frequently used of all power tools, owes a great deal of its popularity to the wide selection of accessories and attachments available, which enable the tool to be used for dozens of other operations besides that of simply boring holes.

IT is an odd arrangement for a major opera company like Milan's La Scala to come to Brussels for the World's Fair and to present two operas and three concerts. But the reasons are easy to guess. The cost of transporting sets and costumes is high and the difficulties of mounting productions designed for a modernized theatre like La Scala on stages of different proportions and less modern equipment are formidable.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., June 28 -- Officials of the Sullivan County Racing Association, the sponsor of the seventy-four-night harness racing meeting that started last night at Monticello Raceway, conceded tonight that there were bugs to be eliminated, kinks to be removed and wrinkles to be straightened out.

Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev appears to have failed to get approval for all the agricultural changes he proposed in his speech at last week's meeting of the Soviet Communist party's Central Committee.

A CARAVAN of vehicles which will include the Post Office Department's earliest highway postal truck (vintage of 1941) will proceed westerly from Tipton, Mo., on Sept. 16 and will follow as closely as possible the Rainbow Trail taken by the Butterfield Overland Mail to the Pacific Coast in 1858.

TO overtake and surpass the United States is the new national slogan of the Soviet Union. It is specifically Khruchchev's slogan. It has nothing to do with Marxism or Leninism or any form of ideology. It is concerned only with material progress. And it has a strictly limited purpose: to raise morale and root out Russia's deep-seated inferiority complex in the face of Western material achievement.

THE SLOT is a strip of water between Guadalcanal and the Savo Islands: in late 1942, it swarmed with Jap ships pouring in to reinforce Guadalcanal and bombard Henderson Field. When big stuff came down, the depleted United States Navy usually managed to scrape up some cruisers and destroyers to counter, but the job of harrying the supply line frequently fell exclusively to the little motor torpedo boats, the PT's.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Congress is about to engage in a long and intensive adjournment drive in the hope of getting out of town by mid-August. The July Fourth holi days next week-end will probably mark the final pause before what is known here as adjournment fever sets in.
WARSAW, June 25 -- The Soviet Union is again running into trouble getting one of its favorite publication projects, a new international Communist magazine, to the printer.

SARANAC INN, N. Y., June 28 -- A legal expert said today that the major task of the New York bar in the next three years should be the revision of the state's Civil Practice Act and rules of civil procedure.
CENTRAL CITY, Colo., June 28 -- This little mining town in the Rockies, forty miles west of Denver, polished its golden past today to open the twentyseventh annual summer opera festival.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 28 -- Millions of Brazilians will take two hours off tomorrow to listen to the final game of the soccer world championships in Stockholm, where Brazil is playing Sweden for the title.

WARSAW, June 28 -- Poland reacted with a sharp and extremely personal sense of shock -- mixed with fear -- to the death of Imre Nagy. Ever since the execution was announced there has been a brooding pessimism in this capital.

MONTPELIER, Vt. -When the switch is thrown for the production of commercial power from the St. Lawrence in September, the shock will be felt with no greater sense of anticipation anywhere than in the state of Vermont.

The most recent incident involving United States aircraft and Soviet bloc territory occurred last June 7, when a helicopter became lost on a training flight and ran out of gasoline over East Germany, landing near Zwickau. Eight officers and a sergeant were seized by the East Germans. They are still being held.

A DEEP-WATER wharf for this port is announced by the Canadian Federal Public Works Department as part of its "immediate planning program." Cost of the project is estimated at between $3,000,000 and $4,000,000.

A HIGH suspension bridge stretching 3,500 feet across the St. Lawrence, from a point just east of Massena, N. Y., to Cornwall Island (the highway will continue to the Canadian mainland) is the last major job in the Rapids section for the U. S. Army Corps of Engineers.

For the first two weeks of its run in Washington, "The Adams Case" had one star -- Sherman Adams -- and a supporting cast. Last week the members of the supporting cast became co-stars with Mr. Adams. The new co-stars are the House subcommittee members who broke the case on June 10.
ADVANCED mathematics is seldom of great value in bridge. Few -- very few -of the leading players know anything about mathematics, never having had time to learn two such complicated fields so well.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., June 28 -- The sixth annual Huckins predicted leg cruiser contest was won by a past commodore of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club, Russell T. Branch, in his forty-six-foot Chris-Craft Vagary III. His percentage of accuracy was 99.1375.

There may be merit in the proposal at the Regional Traffic Court Conference at New York that a drivers should have medical examinations. But the speaker's lumping of the senile, the feeble-minded and epileptics together shows an unfortunate lack of discrimination.

HONOLULU, June 28 (UPI) -- The "for sale" sign was pulled down from the ketch Golden Rule in the Honolulu Yacht Harbor today. This ended a pacifist-sponsored attempt to dramatize a protest of continued nuclear weapons tests.
ALGIERS, June 28 -- Revolutions devour their children, and the Algerian uprising of May 13 is no exception.
TRENTON, June 28 (AP) -- The State Supreme Court abolished today the 191-year-old distinction between lawyers and counselors in New Jersey.
CAIRO, June 28 -- Once again we see an East-West crisis over Hungary coinciding with a crisis in the Middle East. The result is to divide the attention of most of the world.

CHICAGO, June 28 -- Manager Casey Stengel today picked fifteen American League players with All-Star Game experience to complete his twenty-five man squad for the annual contest against the National League's stars on July 8.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- The Soviet Union again asked the United States today for an "unequivocal" commitment on suspending nuclear weapons tests prior to agreement on measures to police a test ban.

BONN, June 28 -- Chancellor Adenauer and his associates hold the view that the Hungarian executions are related to three factors: Internal problems in the Soviet Union, internal problems in Red China, and Chinese pressure on the Soviet Union to reassert control over the European satellites.

STRATEGICALLY situated at the western terminus of the St. Lawrence River canal system, only sixty miles east of Lake Ontario, this community of 5,000 expects to become a busy deep-water port when the Seaway opens, serving Ottawa, the Ottawa valley and eastern Ontario in general.
PARIS, June 28 -- The Government of Premier Charles de Gaulle appeared today to be heading toward a showdown with still defiant military and civilian dissidents in Algeria.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Sunday, June 29 (AP) -- Hungary and Bulgaria declared today they would work for good relations with Yugoslavia despite differences over methods of communism.

NEW YORKERS who are inclined to dismiss inland New Jersey as a conglomeration of drab suburbs, truck farms, swamps and pine barrens, need to broaden their horizons. A day's drive in the right direction will bring a new revelation.

Moore-McCormack Lines said last week that the installation of anti-roll stabilizers on two new liners, the Brasil and Argentina, was "almost superfluous," since they would operate on the "smoothest longdistance route in the world."

PETRA, Majorca -- This sprawling community of 5,000 where Junipero Serra, founder of California's historic chain of Spanish missions, was born in 1713 has a problem common to all small towns that are faced with a coming tourist boom.

THE most refreshing and relaxing new additions to today's home are waterbearing decorations -- the splashing fountain or quiet pool. The popularity of these coolest of decorations may be traced, possibly, to American tourists. In Europe and the Latin-American countries, they have been impressed by the spectacular public water displays or beguiled by romantic pools and fountains in private homes and patios.
THE modern gardener no longer need put his greenhouse "away in mothballs" for the summer. With air-conditioning he can make it useful even during the hottest weather.
MILWAUKEE, June 28 -Carlton Willey pitched his second victory in a week for Milwaukee today. His four-hit, 7-3 conquest of Los Angeles broke a nine-game Dodger winning string against the Braves.

A SIXTY - FIVE - ACRE water-front site recently purchased from the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway Company is being developed by the Toledo-Lucas County Port Authority and the first phase should be completed by next May.

LINZ, Austria -- One of the tourist's biggest pleasures is finding some wondrous place which apparently has been overlooked by throngs of other tourists. God cannot be "adequately" loved by any person who harbors hate for his neighbor, the Rev. Francis X. Duffy declared yesterday in the sermon at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
MANY inquiries have come to this department on how to make the television room more attractive without eliminating TV altogether.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 29 -- The critical battle for Tripoli was stepped up last night and continued today.

Tennessee Williams said yesterday that his final and considerably revised draft of "Sweet Bird of Youth" was back from the typists and that the play would be scheduled for rehearsals early in January.
STOCKHOLM, June 29 (UPI) Favored Brazil won the World Soccer Cup today by beating the host nation, Sweden, 5 -- 2, with a dazzling display of football wizardry.
THE Moiseyev Dance Company of Moscow scored a resounding hit last night in its appearance on the "Ed Sullivan Show" over Channel 2.

The Regional Traffic Court Conference held recently in this city was told by an official of the State Citizens Council on Traffic Safety that the courts have tended to become "soft" in adjudicating all offenses, including traffic violations. The opinion was expressed that until it becomes politically expedient for government to take corrective action the traffic problem will grow progressively worse instead of better.

TO undertake a really big fireworks show in town, R. H. Macy executives have come to know, is to invite burial under mounds of municipal directives, permits, insurance policies, communiques, local and international correspondence.

MILWAUKEE, June 29 (AP) -- A four - hit performance by Henry Aaron, including his second grand-slam home run of the season, sparked the Milwaukee Braves to a 10-6 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 29 -- The Brazilian Government has decided to continue supporting coffee prices in the crop year that starts Tuesday but has abandoned the practice of buying it immediately from growers if export quotations are unsatisfactory.
Ralph W. Whelan, coordinator of the city's summer campaign against juvenile delinquency, announced yesterday that 200 private agencies would cooperate with the municipal program.

Cuban military intelligence has disclaimed knowledge of a landing in Cuba by Gerald Lester Murphy, an American pilot, at the time of the disappearance of Jesus de Galindez. Such a landing was alleged in the Morris L. Ernst report on the Galindez case after reports that Mr. Murphy had spirited Dr. Galindez to the Dominican Republic in his plane.
The economic ripples from a single contract to build an American merchant ship spread across the country, the Committee of American Steamship Lines contends.
A proposal for a $3,917,000 cooperative housing project in the Bronx, to be aided by a city loan and tax exemption in part, was announced yesterday by Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa.

The one-story taxpayer building containing twelve stores and occupying a plot 100 by 100 feet at 761-69 East Tremont Avenue, the Bronx, has been sold by the estate of Samuel Baumann. It is a corner parcel and also is known as 1968-76 Prospect Avenue.

The Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy took the first step last week to increase the nation's production of fissionable materials for weapons. It authorized, despite economy objections by the Administration, construction of a $145,000,000 reactor to produce nuclear explosives.

A $5,000,000 gift to Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts from John D. Rockefeller Jr. was announced yesterday. The center, of which Mr. Rocke feller's son, John D. Rockefeller 3d, is president, will be built within the Lincoln Square redevelopment on Manhattan's West Side. It will lie between Sixtieth and Seventieth Streets, west of Columbus Avenue and Broadway.

I read with interest in The New York Times on June 21 the story "Sideline Cabbies Get Green Light," in which Commissioner McElroy contends that 35,000 to 40,000 licensed drivers are needed and that he will now issue additional licenses for part-time drivers.
Governor Harriman wrote off State Senator Walter J. Mahoney yesterday as a serious contender for the Republican nomination for Governor this fall.
AMSTERDAM, June 29 -- Industrial orders at the end of March were well below those a year ago, it was announced today.

Your editorial on June 26 pointed out clearly that in fixing the new basic tax rate, the highest in city history, injustice is done to the real estate owners in those boroughs whose real property is assessed close to 100 per cent of full value, as against Queens and Richmond, where the assessment respectively is only 76 per cent and 64 per cent of full value.

SOMEONE made a mistake. Although the reviewers had been invited to inspect the "Aquacircus" in its premiere performance at the Flushing Meadows amphitheatre last Friday night, there was no need for them.
Contract awards for future construction in the United States, usually considered a reliable indicator of economic trends, show that the business recession may have turned onto an uphill road.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 29 -- Dr. Charles Malik, Lebanese Foreign Minister, said today there was a good chance his Government could deal with the rebellion if the border was sealed off to halt illegal aid from the United Arab Republic.
RICHMOND, Va., June 29 -- A toll road that will eliminiate a north-south bottleneck opens here tomorrow.
JERICHO, L. I., June 29 -- A three-goal rally in the closing chukker enabled Meadow Brook to turn back the Anahuac Polo Club of Mexico City, 9 -- 8, at the Meadow Brook Club today.

BUENOS AIRES, June 29 -- Vice President Alejandro Gomez has hinted that the Administration is willing to relax certain nationalistic stipulations in order to attract foreign exploitation of Argentine oil.

EAST NORWICH, L. I., June 29 -- As they sat in animated conversation in a corner of the locker room today, they looked no different to the casual eye from any of the other golfers at the Pine Hollow Country Club, where the richest of local charity tournaments was heading toward its conclusion.

In a strictly physical sense visibility and distance may be said to be inversely correlated. That is to say, the farther away a given object is from the viewer the more difficult it is for him to see it.
GREENWOOD LAKE, N. Y., June 29 (AP) -- Art Longsjo gained his fourth straight bicycle-racing crown in the Eastern states road championship today.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The Supreme Court's response to the request for emergency review of the order suspending school integration in Little Rock will probably be made known tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The Lebanese crisis has confronted United States policymakers with a basic foreign policy question to which they have as yet devised only fragmentary answers.
The International Bank for Reconstruction and development (World Bank) has arranged with the Central Bank of West Germany to make its first borrowing of Deutsche marks.
WARSAW, June 29 -- Wladyslaw Gomulka and his Polish Communist party found themselves today facing a whole range of critical problems as a result of their concessions to Soviet political discipline.

Domestic cotton prices were irregular last week, but closed somewhat firmer. At the close of the market on Friday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 8 to 30 points for the week. The market was up 9 to down 31 in the preceding week.
I was amazed to read on page 78 of Morris L. Ernst's whitewash report prepared for Dominican dictator Trujillo that "a search for [Francisco] Abrisketo [sic] might be of interest * * *."

BEDFORD VILLAGE, N. Y., June 29 -- The Churchill Farm's Warranty captured the working hunter championship and Sahri, owned and ridden by Mrs. Philip Hayes of New Canaan, Conn., earned the open jumper tricolor at the Bedford Horse Show today.

Jennie Tourel will sing four arias tonight when she replaces Elisabeth Schwarzkopf as the soloist at the Lewisohn Stadium. The arias will be "Dido's Lament," from Purcell's "Dido and Aeneas," "Voi che sapete," from Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro," "Una voce poca fa," from Rossini's "The Barber of Seville" and "Adieu forets," from Tchaikovsky's "Jeanne d'Arc."
The floors in the new thirty-eight-story Seagram Building at 375 Park Avenue at Fifty-second Street have been leased by the Bethlehem Steel Company, the nation's second largest producer of steel.

Fifty years ago a young Brooklyn pupil, Stephen S. Abbate, took a temporary summer job with a shipping concern, Funch, Edye Co, This venture started him on a half-century career in the shipping industry.

Warm breezes wafted over New York and most of the nation yesterday from the Canadian border. Except for light rains in the Pacific Northwest and a few showers that skipped over the Great Plains, the sunshine overflowed upon resorts everywhere.
ATHENS, June 29 -- Michael Pissas, secretary general of the Cyprus Labor Confederation, has accused Greek Cypriote Communists of collaboration with the British and treason in a report just released.

ANKARA, Turkey, June 29 -- Dr. Fazil Kucuk, firebrand for the Turkish cause in Cyprus, will return to his island home in a few days to carry on the "peaceful struggle" and resume the practice of medicine.
A TALENTED upstart and a member of Seventh Avenue's old guard have been chosen to receive 1958 Coty Awards, fashion's highest accolade.

LANGHORNE, Pa., June 29 -- Bill Homier of Pacoima, Calif., won the 100-mile national championship midget auto race here today. The 39-yearold West Coast driver completed the 100-lap race on the circular dirt one-mile track at a speed of 92.623 miles an hour.

PARIS, June 29 -- Leaders of France's electronics industry have decided to establish new research centers, laboratories and factories and to expand their contacts with similar industries in five other countries.

Lower yields on income-producing assets and rising operating costs are squeezing profit margins for the larger New York City banks according to Chandler Robbins, vice president of M. A. Schapiro Co., Inc., bank securities dealer.
FARMINGDALE, L. I., June 29 -- Contracts totaling more than $6,284,000 have been awarded 604 Long Island business concerns in the last five months, the Republic Aviation Corporation reported today.

A 70-year-old Brooklyn woman, who waited for approaching automobiles to pass before crossing the street, was killed yesterday by a car that, according to the police, backed into her as she stepped off the curb.

A GROUP of French fashion designers has forsaken Paris and haute couture in the last few years for America's wholesale fashion center -- bustling Seventh Avenue. These young men believe that fame, fortune and fulfillment are to be found in New York's hectic, aggressive, over - crowded dress industry.

IN summer, the woman who works and wants to entertain at a week-day dinner has a special problem. When temperatures soar, cooking dinner in a hurry in a small apartment can be hectic. If the range has been heated for any length of time, the apartment may be unbearably hot.
A traffic-safety program for teen - agers and pre - driving youngsters was announced yesterday by the Boys Club of America.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The long fight over a labor bill in the Senate recently produced a classic illustration of Lyndon B. Johnson's mastery of the art of legislating in an evenly divided house.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 29 (UPI) -- Phil Rodgers gave the University of Houston its second clean sweep of the National Collegiate golf championship today, whipping the Big Ten champion, Purdue's Johnny Konsek, 8 and 7.

A coalition of Republicans and big-city Democrats in the House has dealt the farm bloc in Congress its second major setback within the past three months. By a vote of 214 to 171 it rejected the farm-bloc-sponsored measure that had been reported out of committee with a majority of more than two to one.
BONN, Germany, June 29 -- Roman Catholics are not bound by church teaching to reject nuclear weapons, Bishops of North Rhine-Westphalia declared in a pastoral letter today.

The sensational cases of kidnapping by Cuban rebels in Oriente Province will undoubtedly do the anti-Batista cause more harm than good. They demonstrated (what must have surprised Americans) that Fidel Castro and his 26th of July Movement, and not the Havana dictatorship of President Batista, still have the upper hand in the eastern third of Cuba.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 29 -- Thanks to a late westerly breeze, four of the ten classes finished in the Indian Harbor Yacht Club's program today.

Harry S. Ashmore, executive editor of The Arkansas Gazette, predicted here last night that the recent Federal Court order permitting Little Rock schools to delay racial integration until 1961 would be reversed on appeal.
John W. Gardner, head of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund panel that reported a week ago on the nation's needs in education, indicated yesterday that he favored increased Federal aid.
The Soviet Union's effort to diffuse culture among the 200,000,000 people in its vast territories is prodigious.

The death of Alfred Noyes is a loss to Americans as well as to Britons. Indeed, there are thousands of Americans who would be inclined to feel that Mr. Noyes, though eminent as an English poet, belonged to us just as much as he did to his native land.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon predicted today that President Eisenhower would stand by Sherman Adams unless House investigators developed proof of wrongdoing by the Assistant to the President.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 29 -- The Central Committee of the Yugoslav League of Communists has decided to publish its own account of the conversations last August between President Tito and Soviet Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev, reliable informants disclosed tonight.
AACHEN, Germany, June 29 (AP) -- Capt. Piero D'Inzeo today won the championship event at the Aachen international horse show when he sent his mount, On The Rock, over the course in 128.7 seconds.
NEW HAVEN, June 29 -- On of the world's most powerfu high energy beam electron linea accelerators will be installe here, Yale University disclose today.

HAVANA, June 29 -- Officers of the United States Navy base at Guantanamo Bay were reported today to have made contact with the Cuban rebels to arrange for the release of twenty-eight Navy and Marine personnel kidnapped Friday near the base.

KANSAS CITY, June 29 -- Harry Craft's Athletics kept alive a flicker of hope in the American League today as they suddenly whirled about and routed the lordly Yankees, 12 -- 6, before a roaring crowd of 30,606.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Alaskan statehood and foreign aid are scheduled to occupy Congress this week before its brief Fourth of July recess.
ON Channel 4, Steve Allen's answer to the Moiseyev troupe last night was a variety show with a cast that included Don Adams, Dorothy Collins, Oscar Levant, Tony Bennett and a child trumpet player.

For an investor with a tidy mind and a nimble pencil, formula planning can be a made-to-order approach to the stock market. This book details about a dozen of the best known plans, ranging from quite simple to highly technical.

Congressional committees in this country have not been so scrupulous. Thus the House Special Subcommittee on Legislative Oversight has been giving a field day to John Fox. financier, former publisher and occasional pianist, who has been telling stories about Bernard Goldfine and Presidential Assistant Sherman Adams.

Two hundred and fifty sentimentalists with their hearts in the past turned time backward yesterday on a seven-hour rail tour of Brooklyn and Queens. They rode down memory lane in a six-car wooden El train with wide open windows, open platforms and hand-operated gates.

CLEVELAND, June 29 -- A substantial reduction in the desired class size of elementary schools was recommended here today as the National Education Association opened its ninety-sixth annual convention.

Two books commemorating the independence of two nations will be published during the first week of August. Public Affairs Press of Washington will issue on Aug. 1 "Waging Peace: The Swiss Experience." The author, William Bross Lloyd Jr., traces the role of conciliation and mediation in the unification of the cantons of Switzerland.

GENEVA, June 29 -- Seven members of the Soviet delegation to the East-West conference on policing a nuclear test ban arrived by air tonight. They declined to say whether they would participate in the technical talks, scheduled to begin Tuesday.
The Florists' Telegraph Delivery Association has decided to transplant its $2,500,000 account after sixteen years of growth at Grant Advertisings, Inc.
Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and associates are offering today $10,000,000 of 4 1/2 per cent first mortgage bonds of Orange and Rockland Utilities, Inc., due in 1988, at 102.50 to yield 4.35 per cent.
PHILADELPHIA, June 30 -City Solicitor David Berger said today that Philadelphia might ask the Supreme Court to rehear the case.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -Speaker Sam Rayburn rejected today a Republican attempt to have the House of Representatives investigate the conduct of the subcommittee that has been investigating the relations of Sherman Adams and Bernard Goldfine.
BERLIN, June 30 (AP) -- East Germany disclosed today that the Communist parties of Western and Central Europe held secret meetings in East Berlin extending from last Friday to yesterday.
LACK of adult supervision has been responsible for most drownings of children under 10 years of age.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- The Senate Judiciary Committee approved a bill today that would open the way to United States citizenship for 31,000 Hungarians who fled their country when the Russians smashed the 1956 revolution.
WARSAW, June 30 -- Poland's Peasant party is warning that any attempts to return to strict Government control of farming could lead to farmer resistance.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 30 -- Barry MacKay is the last American left in the men's singles at Wimbledon. Unleashing thunderbolts from his service, he battered Ramanathan Krishnan of India into submission, 6 -- 3, 11 -- 9, 6 -- 2, to enter the quarter-finals of the all-England lawn tennis championships.

The technical government crisis in Italy, following upon the general election of May 25-26, can now be considered ended. Amintore Fanfani, secretary of the dominant Christian Democratic party, is announcing today his acceptance of the charge to form a new Government and he will present his Cabinet to President Gronchi at the same time.

BALTIMORE, June 30 -Pleased at what they saw in the West from their lofty position in the American League flag race, the Yankees arrived today prepared to meet any insurrections developing along the Eastern seaboard.

TelePrompTer Corporation yesterday bought the closed circuit theatre television rights for the heavyweight championship fight between Floyd Patterson and Roy Harris for a minimum guarantee of $210,000.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, June 30 -- Alaska took its first step toward statehood in 1867, but it is a safe bet that no resident -Eskimo, Indian, Aleut or white man -- knew or cared.

Less pollution in some bathing areas was reported yesterday by the city Department of Health. However, all of the city's fourteen beaches remained in the same sanitation classifications they have held for the last ten years.
Admitting Alaska to the Union will mean the first change in the number of stars in the flag since 1912, when New Mexico and Arizona became states.

PARIS, June 30 -- Abel Bonnard, French poet and former member of the French Academy, who was condemned to death in absentia for collaboration with the Nazis, returned to France today after fourteen years of exile in Spain.

SPRINGFIELD, N. J., June 30 -- A plan to rebuild Route 22 instead of constructing a new Federal freeway was called impractical today. The idea was termed economically unfeasible and impractical from an engineering point of view by Otto H. Fritszche, chief engineer for the State Highway Department.
Three new midtown office buildings--on Fifth, Madison and Park Avenues--have won the architectural competition held annually by the Fifth Avenue Association.
TRIPOLI, Lebanon, June 30 -- A Lebanese Army spokesman said today the back road supplying arms to the rebels in Tripoli had been cut. Quiet lay over the shuttered city after the firing of last night.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 30 -- World food production registered "steady and in some cases remarkable" progress in 1956, the Food and Agriculture Organization reported in its 1957 yearbook, published today. The report puts the index of total production at 117 for the year, against 114 in 1955.

MASSENA, N. Y., June 30 -- Surging waters of a mighty man-made flood will cascade across hundreds of square miles of Canada and northern New York tomorrow morning to start a new era of growth in transportation and industry.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, June 30 -- Non-Cacuasion aborigines debate on the floor of Alaska's Territorial Legislature, become spark plugs in Chambers of Commerce and draw pay as agents of labor unions.
TRENTON, June 30 (AP) The cost of living goes up in New Jersey tomorrow for motorists, South Jersey households and corporations.
WHITE PLAINS, June 30 -Herbert C. Gerlach, who suffered a heart attack on April 15, resumed active chairmanship of the Westchester Republican County Committee today.

The St. Lawrence Seaway not fulfill the Congressional mandate that it be a completely self-supporting waterway with the currently proposed toll structure, it was charged yesterday.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 4 to 22 points yesterday. One point equals five cents a bale.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., June 30 -- Six baby swans and their parents have turned up on a stream that winds through the Village Nature Trail area here.

THE deluge of games promised for this summer on television began yesterday with four premieres. There were also two new soap operas and a refurbished Alan Freed. The attractions covered a total of four hours during the daytime.

STANTON, Del., June 30 (UPI) -- Eldon Nelson put on one of the best riding performances in the history of thoroughbred racing at Delaware Park today when he booted home six straight winners, beginning with Sun Bolt in the third race.

McCutcheon's, the line shop that opened at 748 Broadway in 1855, made conservative progress yesterday. It moved quietly from 609 Fifth Avenue, at Forty-ninth Street, to a modest, well-appointed shop at Sixteen East Fifty-second Street.

OGDEN NASH was once asked to write an introduction to an anthology of bits and pieces by P. G. Wodehouse. He wrote it. The introduction, unabridged and without footnotes, read, if memory serves, as follows: "The work of P. G. Wodehouse needs no introduction."
WASHINGTON, June 30 -The House voted tentatively today to overrule a fifteen-year-old Supreme Court doctrine designed to ensure prompt arraignment of Federal criminal suspects.

Sixty years ago today the United States Army, fighting the Spaniards in Cuba, won the battle for San Juan Hill. The victory, followed by the destruction of the Spanish fleet off Santiago harbor two days later, determined the outcome of the war, and marked the beginning of this country's ascendency to a world power.

The New York Telephone Company has set a deadline of 11 A. M. on July 9 for the acceptance of bids on its offering of $65,000,000 of refunding mortgage bonds, due in 1993. Park Commissioner Robert Moses came under heavy attack at City Hall yesterday as Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, residents opened a last-ditch assault on the so-called Seventh Avenue approach route to the $300,000,000 Narrows Bridge.

Buzz Fazio of St. Louis, the defending champion in the world endurance bowling classic, issued a tip or warning after winning last year. Shareholders of Trans Continental Industries, Inc., approved yesterday the management plan to obtain control of United Profit Sharing Corporation.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities today abandoned plans to subpoena Cyrus Eaton, Cleveland industrialist, for questioning about his charges that Government agencies were "snooping" on the American people.

Net income of Middle South Utilities, Inc. and its subsidiaries for the twelve months ended May 31 rose to $20,681,284 from $17,612,659 a year earlier. The income is equal to $2.57 a share on 8,050,000 shares outstanding compared with $2.32 a share on 7,598,106 shares.

LONDON, June 30 -- The Government conceded today that Britain's textile industry was in a bad way, but it refused to restrict textile imports from commonwealth countries.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 30 -- Richard Chapman, a former United States and British Amateur champion, played the Garden City Golf Club for the first time in twenty-five years today. Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. disclosed yesterday that he had been able to walk into a firehouse and sneak out the journal book under his coat.
The Theatre Guild is drawing up plans for a Broadway musical adaptation of "He Who Gets Slapped," Leonid Andreyev's drama set against a circus background.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- It probably will be five or six months before Alaska officially enters the union.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that an employer who distributes anti-union literature in his plant might still enforce a rule barring employes from handing out literature on company property.

Washington, June 30 (AP) -Sherman Adams, the Assistant to President Eisenhower, and Gerald Morgan, the President's special counsel, have conferred by phone during the last two or three weeks with an attorney for Bernard Goldfine.
New financing June dropped to the smallest total for the month since 1955.
A SURVEY of specialty food stores here discloses a wonderful assortment of gourmet items for summer months.

Vacancies in Manhattan office and loft buildings have increased over last year.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -Profits of manufacturing corporations in the first quarter of this year were the lowest, in relation to sales, of the entire postwar period, the Securities and Exchange and Federal Trade Commissions reported today.

THERE always has been one aspect of the voting for the All-Star teams that has puzzled the electorate. WASHINGTON, June 30 -The Supreme Court struck down as unconstitutional today California's procedure for enforcing a state law that requires loyalty oaths to obtain tax exemptions.

DETROIT, June 30 (UPI) -For the second working day in succession, 5,400 workers at two Plymouth plants were sent home today because of a dispute in the Plymouth body plant, trim department.
A SUBMERSIBLE automatic coffeemaker will be available here about July 20.

Cochran Foil Corporation, a subsidiary of the Anaconda Company, has purchased the Continental Can Company holdings in Cochran Continental Container Corporation of Louisville, Ky., for an undisclosed amount of cash. Cochran Continental Container was formed jointly by Cochran Foil Company and Continental Can in July, 1956, to make and distribute rigid foil containers for baking and frozen food industries.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- A bill intended to reduce the case load of Federal courts won approval of the House of Representatives today by voice vote.

Horse players, as everyone knows, are dedicated to fresh air and the improvement of the breed. That is why, according to New York State Racing Commission figures, there has been $2,500,000 worth of uncollected pari-mutuel tickets on thoroughbreds since 1940.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 30 -The Government sent rocketfiring jet fighters against rebels in the hills only seven miles from Beirut International Airport today. At the same time, the Tripoli command reported it had cut the main rebel supply line into that city.

JENNIE TOUREL, who sang in Aspen, Colo., on Sunday night, last night sang at the Lewisohn Stadium. Fulfilling the second engagement meant sitting up all night through a hectic journey, but the mezzosoprano did it to help Stadium Concerts out of a tight spot.

The city's ambitious tree-planting program to beautify Third Avenue has been jeopardized by the neglect of property owners. Surveys being made by the Department of Parks and the Manhattan Borough President's office show that many of the 1,098 London plane trees planted along the avenue two years ago are already dead.
A housewife bought three cans of a scouring powder yesterday at an East Side grocery, and received three coupons good for one subway token.
RYE, N. Y., June 30 -- Herman Barron of Fenway took pro individual honors with 33, 34 -- 67 in the pro-amateur golf tournament for the benefit of the United Hospital of Port Chester, N. Y., today.

CHICAGO, June 30 -- A survey of twelve major industries has found that business leaders view the next six months with some foreboding, although they discern many favorable signs. Views on their specific areas range from moderate optimism and even contentment to near despair.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 30 -President Camille Chamoun, who is a principal target of the rebellion in progress here since May 10, said today that he could not be re-elected.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, June 30 -- The nation's educators were warned here today that "time is running out" on Federal aid for education.

CHICAGO, June 30 -- The Secretary of the Army declared today that it was illogical to believe that the Soviet Union would intentionally start a nuclear war and thus "invite almost certain destruction."

Count that evening lost in the Soviet theatre when something spectacular does not happen in it. At the opera, the play, the ballet -- in Moscow, Leningrad or any other city -- it is a rare performance that does not knock the eye out with some startling effect.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 30 -- The Netherlands Government said today a limited number of troops would be sent to Dutch New Guinea.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., June 30 (AP) -- Government action to discontinue testing and stockpiling of nuclear weapons headed a Charter for Christian Action adopted today at the national meeting of United Presbyterian Women.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 30 -- Balletomanes could really go mad in this town these days. Their problem is which ballet performance to attend.
Higher steel wages became effective at 12:01 A. M. today, but major steel producers maintained silence on how soon higher prices would follow.

Swelled by the largest retirement of public utility issues since January, 1955, bonds called for redemption in June before maturity rose to $155,984,000 from $47,808,000 in May. This was the largest total for any month since April, 1956. Some $19,234,000 in bonds were redeemed in June, 1957.
A history of printing in the forty-eight states goes on display today in the main lobby of the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) James R. Hoffa, Teamsters Union president, said today that his union strongly opposed a broad labor control bill passed by the Senate and now before the House.
A new traffic rule banning U-turns in all business and industrial districts across the city will go into effect today.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- The Government filed an antitrust suit today accusing the White Motor Company of Cleveland of unlawfully restraining competition in the sale of heavy duty trucks and parts.

Your editorial of June 26 entitled "Crisis in Lebanon" seems in many ways to contradict the article by Hanson Baldwin "Paradox of Intervention" and your news story in the same issue. Furthermore, it reveals a basic misunderstanding of the problem of Lebanon and a confusion regarding the genesis and direction of a new movement of Arab nationalism.
YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N. Y., June 30 -- A rapid expansion of industry in the northwest corner of Westchester was forecast here today by business leaders and civic planners of the county.

MILWAUKEE, June 30 (AP) -The Milwaukee Braves concentrated their scoring with ten hits in two innings tonight, walloping the Cincinnati Redlegs, 9 -- 2. Warren Spahn, the Braves' ace southpaw, became the first National League pitcher to score ten victories this season.

The stock market plodded along a slow upward course in the first half of this year. The New York Times combined average of fifty representative stocks closed the period at 290.47 for a net gain of 22.45 points. It rose 6.57 points in June.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 30 -- Attorneys for William Wyler, director, filed suit today in Los Angeles Superior Court against Samuel Goldwyn. They asked for an accounting by the producer of earnings from the 1946 picture, "The Best Years of Our Lives," and a declaration by the court of Mr. Wyler's contract rights.
THE wonderful quality about a Tatiana hat is that once it goes on a woman's head it ceases to spell out the designer's name and begins to shout the praises of the wearer.
Deputy Police Commissioner Robert J. Magnum, who was reprimanded last fall for countermanding a friend's traffic arrest, resigned yesterday to do political work.
CLEVELAND, June 30--The 1958 "School Bell Awards" for outstanding interpretation of education by communications media were presented tonight at the National Education Association's annual convention.
TRENTON, June 30 -- Representatives of three organizations today urged a limited sales tax in New Jersey.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Federal tax collectors, armed with a new law effective at midnight, are preparing a crackdown on business men who pocket taxes withheld from their employes' pay.
HAVANA, June 30--Two more Americans were kidnapped today by the Cuban rebels, bringing to forty-four the number of North American servicemen and civilians seized since last Thursday.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -Frank Costello today lost his third effort to set aside a 1954 conviction for evading $28,532 in Federal income taxes.

THE new furniture best-seller, the storage wall, was conceived thirteen years ago to meet a publisher's deadline. George Nelson, typing against time, had to create his own copy when, 5,000 words short of finishing a book on home furnishings, he started the final chapter, "Closets."

HONOLULU, T. H., June 30 -- Hawaii responded joyfully today to the news that the United States Senate had passed the Alaskan statehood bill. The territory seemed almost as pleased as if Hawaii itself had been granted statehood.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- The pilot of the jet trainer that collided with an airliner near Brunswick, Md., May 20, acknowledged today that he has been involved in at least two previous plane collisions.

The six Republican State Senators from this city joined yesterday in urging Mayor Wagner "to use the full resources of his office to bring about a revision of the city's Charter at the earliest possible date."
BOSTON, June 30 -- The State Department and Secretary of State Dulles were urged today to reappraise relationships between the United States and "the people of mainland China."

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., June 30 (UPI) -- James M. Symes, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, said today that the carriers want to fashion a "new look" to passenger operations and stop running nearly empty passenger trains.

The new outburst of rebel activity in the hills around Beirut only serves to focus attention on the extremely cautious approach of both the United Nations and the United States in the Lebanese crisis. Mr. Hammarskjold's report yesterday on the machinery of the U. N. observers' force doesn't throw much additional light on the situation.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
Thomas K. Finletter said last night he hoped the AdamsGoldfine case would not become an issue in the 1958 election and so divert Democrats from the basic issues before the state and nation.

The United States Trust Company of New York, fearful that some disaster might waterlog its hoard of some six billions in stock and bond certificates, is building the main vault in its new quarters at 45 Wall Street like a submarine.
CAMDEN, N. J., June 30 (AP) -- Seven thousand five hundred employes of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation worked today under a new contract ratified in two days of secret balloting.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Effective tomorrow the Post Office Department will start collecting a 5-cent penalty charge for delivering mail on which postage is due.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -Following is the text of a United States aide-memoire on the technical talks in Geneva delivered to the Soviet Government today:
ATLANTA, June 30 (AP) -Gov. Marvin Griffin issued an executive order today intended to prevent National Guardsmen from carrying out orders of the Federal Government unless he approved.
PEIPING, June 30 (Reuters) -- Communist China threatened today to cut its only diplomatic link with the United States, the ambassadorial talks in Geneva.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court rejected today a challenge by Harte-Hanks Newspapers, Abilene, Text., to the Government's use of its records in a grand jury investigation at Dallas.

CHICAGO, June 30 (AP) -- The largest winter wheat yield of record began hitting the market in heavy volume today and Board of Trade prices sagged as much as 2 3/4 cents a bushel on the near-by futures contracts.

BOSTON, June 30 (AP) -- The State Railroad Commission today filed a bill in the State Legislature for a $900,000 contract for the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad to continue passenger service on the south shore lines of the Old Colony Railroad for one year.

In the first change of ownership since it was built in 1927, the six-story apartment house at 285 Mott Street has been sold by the Marsic Realty Corporation, Robert Sica, president. The buyer was the Mott Street Realty Corporation, an investing client of Morris Klausner, attorney.
MOSCOW, June 30 -- The Soviet Union announced formally tonight that its delegation of scientists would participate in the Geneva talks.
" Small World," an Edward R. Murrow and Fred W. Friendly venture into far-flung chitchat, will make its debut on Columbia Broadcasting System television next season.

The bus that vanished Sunday from the Port Authority Bus Terminal turned up yesterday 1,000 miles away. What had been scheduled as the 5:45 P. M. Greenville Express developed suddenly into an unscheduled, overnight trip to Dubuque, Iowa.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, June 30 -- Alaskans were stunned today by the realization that Congress had finally invited them to become "first class citizens."

GENEVA, June 30--The Soviet Union agreed today to enter into technical talks with the West on the detection of tests of nuclear weapons. As a result, talks between scientists of four Western and four Communist nations will begin here tomorrow afternoon in a conference room in the Old League of Nations headquarters.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 30 (Reuters) -- Governor Sir Hugh Foot eased up tonight on the tight restrictions he clamped on Cyprus after a violent wave of inter-racial riots between Greek and Turkish Cypriotes.
The police started a drive yesterday to win jaywalkers to the side of the city's new pedestrian protection law.
An unusually cold June came to an end yesterday, the second day of a heat wave that showed no indication of ending before tomorrow.
SPOKANE, June 30 (AP) -Bobby Bragan was hired today to manage seventh-place Spokane of the Pacific Coast League in a sort of musicalchair arrangement.
RABAT, Morocco, June 30 -The United States air bases in Morocco are in danger of becoming political footballs.

LONDON, June 30 -- Prices proved sensitive to light selling in the stock market today and generally drifted lower in quiet trading. British Government securities alone remained firm with a handful of small rises; most gilt-edge issues were unchanged.
Nelson A. Rockefeller announced his candidacy for Governor yesterday. He said that if nominated he would "leave no stone unturned" to win election.
The United Transit Employes Council voted last night to continue Frank A. Zelano as the organization's president.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -State Department officials said today the Cuban rebels appeared to be attempting, by kidnapping United States citizens, to force the United States to impose a more complete curb on assistance to the Batista Government of Cuba.

Steel production is scheduled to drop this week to the lowest level in seven weeks, reflecting curtailment for the July 4 holiday, the beginning of some plant-wide vacations in the industry, and a lower trend in order bookings recently.

ST. ANNE'S ON THE SEA, England, June 30 (AP) -- Peter Thomson, a former champion, fired a spectacular course record 63 and Frank Stranahan, the chief American hope, scored a 3-under-par 68 today in the first qualifying round of the British Open golf championship.

PARIS, June 30 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle and Prime Minister Harold Macmillan ended their mutual diplomatic reconnaissance today with assertions of intent to pursue close cooperation in world affairs.
Teams from the Fencers Club and the Michigan Division retained crowns last night as the second session in the sixty-third National Fencing Championships was completed at the Commodore Hotel.
Robert J. Caverly, vice president of Hilton Hotels Corporation, has been appointed vice president and general manager of Hilton Hotels International, a subsidiary.
LONDON, Tuesday, July 1 -The Soviet Union proposed negotiations with Yugoslavia today on $285,000,000 in credits that the Kremlin had suspended.
A Pennsylvania man described as a "fixer and promoter" was indicted yesterday on charges of stealing $74,000 from the New York State Federation of Labor.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 30 -- The Columbia Broadcasting System's Los Angeles television station, KNXT, will assume an editorial position on a controversial subject for the first time in August. The subject to be treated in an hourlength program tentatively titled "Thou Shalt Not Kill?", is capital punishment.

The realm of public information yields little information on the Hydril Company, which Servel, Inc., is negotiating to buy for an undisclosed amount of cash. (Nothing is final yet, according to an official of Hydril.)
The recession has seriously depleted the financial resources of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, according to the annual report of the organization made public yesterday.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, June 30 -- Alaska has had its ups and downs industrially.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 30 (UPI) -- President Chiang Kaishek accepted today the resignation of Premier O. K. Yui and appointed Vice President Chen Cheng to succeed him in Nationalist China's second most powerful post.

Nelson A. Rockefeller's announcement of availability for the Republican nomination for Governor of New York is not unexpected. The intimations over a period of months that he might become a candidate have prompted widespread, unsolicited encouragement, much of it even coming from professional political leadership, which saw in him a better prospect for November victory than might be found in state officeholders or others frequently "mentioned" as possibilities.
The tide of children from the city to the country ran strongly again yesterday, carrying nearly 10,000 youngsters to camp by train, bus and private automobile.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, June 30 -- Where Ernest Gruening is, there is controversy. He has thrived on it most of his seventy-one years. Political party lines in Alaska are meaningless when the subject of this New Deal Democrat with a sleepy look, sly smile, ready wit and pungent speech comes up.

Directors of The Pennsylvania Exchange Bank have elected Byron L. Harrison president and chief executive officer. They also have elected Ira Hirschmann chairman of the board and Thomas J. Reedy, former president, as a director and executive vice president.

A former marine engineer theorized yesterday an that unidentified third ship may have been the innocent cause of the 1956 collision between the Italian liner Andrea Doria and the Swedish liner Stockholm.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -Following is the text of the Supreme Court order in the Little Rock case:
HAVANA, June 30 (UPI) -- A rebel broadcast today said the mining men seized at Moa Bay "certainly will not be harmed."
High summer temperatures dried up the beer supply in many taverns yesterday as city and state mediators sought unsuccessfully to end the shutdown of metropolitan breweries

A preview performance on Oct. 14 of "The Girls in 509" will benefit the U. S. O. Fund of New York, Inc. The Howard Teichmann comedy, starring Dorothy Gish and Imogene Coca, is scheduled to open at the Belasco Theatre on Oct. 15.
CARACAS, Venezuela, June 30 -- The Venezuelan Government has contracted to borrow $250,000,000 abroad, it was announced tonight by the Minister of Finance, Dr. Jose Antonio Mayobre.
TOKYO, June 30 (AP) -- Two more symbols of the United States occupation of Japan disappeared today.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -Lewis L. Strauss continued to insist in a farewell news conference today that it would be to the disadvantage of the United States to halt nuclear tests.
In this age when the accent is on a return to the land, be it a mere patch of artificially stimulated earth in suburbia, we are apt to forget the importance of city-lore and the ways of our fathers.

Commodity futures closed generally lower yesterday in dull and featureless trading on the New York exchanges. Coffee, cottonseed oil, zinc, lead, sugar, soybean oil and wool declined; copper and rubber rose, and price movements for cocoa were mixed.

The Railway Express Agency unveiled a new semi-automatic sotring and conveying device at its terminal in Long Island City yesterday. The device, unnamed except by loaders and markers who call it "sputnik," has been in operation a month and has passed its first big test -- the dispatching of bundles for children going to summer camp.
A threatened strike of 2,200 employes of 145 Safeway Food Stores in the metropolitan area was averted last night.
Sidney Schwartz ran into stiff opposition in his first match in the New York State tennis championship, which started yesterday at the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club in Bayside, Queens.
Eddie Lynch of the West Side, a special pet at the St. Nicholas Arena, pleased his vociferous adherents last night by taking a unanimous decision from Tony DiBiase of Astoria, Queens.
Employes of the Brooklyn Borough Gas Company went on strike yesterday, but service to 105,000 families in the Coney Island section remained normal.
The Fund for the Advancement of Education has made a grant of $13,000 to Bard College, it was announced yesterday.
OKLAHOMA CITY, June 30 (AP) -- Eleven Democrats and four Republicans make up the field for their parties' nominations for Governor in tomorrow's Oklahoma primary election.
EL PASO, Tex., June 30 -- The Army today unfurled one of the most elaborate field demonstrations in its history to spotlight its activities in the realm of rocketry.

Production has begun at the Ormet Corporation's $55,000,000 alumina plant at Burnside, La., thirty miles downstream from Baton Rouge on the Mississippi River, the company announced yesterday. Alumina is an intermediate material obtained from bauxite ore which is reduced in electrolytic cells into aluminum.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Supreme Court held today that a witness had no right under the Federal Constitution to refuse to testify before a state grand jury because his answers might lead to a Federal prosecution.

DETROIT, June 30 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers scored three runs -- two unearned -- in the ninth inning and defeated the Kansas City Athletics, 7 -- 6, today at Briggs Stadium. Detroit trailed, 6 -- 4, going into the ninth.

WESTBURY, L. I., June 30 -All other things -- condition, racing luck, etc. -- being equal, the most important factor in harness racing is the post position. Invariably, standardbreds starting from the No. 1 slot win the most races at a meeting. Roosevelt Raceway, where the third annual Messenger Stake will be contested Friday night, is no exception.

Business in the metropolitan area has suffered to some extent from the recession, but for the most part it has held its own in the first half of 1958, the Commerce and Industry Association of New York reported yesterday. The outlook is for some improvement in the next six months.

The Frozen Food Distributors Association of Greater New York, six of its members and five individuals were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of criminally violating the Sherman Act.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -"My wife and I often talked about it," Alaskan Delegate E. L. Bartlett said today, "and we agreed that on a day unknown, at a time uncertain, when it was least expected wham, the bill would go through."

Many complaints are heard these days about the failure of our Government to clarify our "true intentions" so that governments and peoples -- from Asia to South America -will understand. A Times editorial on June 23 discussing "Our Position in Okinawa" illustrates the difficulty.

MOSCOW, June 30 (UPI) -Mitchell Wilson, among the most popular living American authors in the Soviet Union, received today a total of $15,100 in royalties in a rare outburst of generosity by the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, June 30--By a vote of 5 to 4 the Supreme Court ruled today that a suspected criminal in the hands of state authorities does not have a constitutional right to see a lawyer before he is questioned by the police.

The charge of the Rough Riders up San Juan Hill, with Theodore Roosevelt at the head of the cavalry brigade, will be marked today on its sixtieth anniversary. A ceremony will be held at the brownstone house at 28 East Twentieth Street where Roosevelt was born.

MOSCOW, June 30--The United States Ambassador handed to the Soviet Foreign Ministry today a note asking for the prompt release of the crew members of an Air Force plane forced down in Soviet territory.
DETROIT, June 30 (AP) -- The automobile industry wound up the first half of the year today with one maker through with 1958 model production and others preparing to finish next month.

CHICAGO, June 30 (UPI) -A golf club manufacturer and four sporting goods companies were charged with conspiring to fix prices and restrain trade, in an indictment returned today by a Federal grand jury.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The highest military officials have testified that the strategic concept for the defense of Alaska will not be changed by her attainment of statehood.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower and Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, Shah of Iran, discussed critical issues "of interest to both countries" at a two-hour White House meeting today.

A conference that could lead to a break in the twelve-year-old disarmament deadlock begins today in Geneva. This is the conference of nuclear experts from the West and the East, called on President Eisenhower's initiative to study the possibility of devising an effective inspection system to detect nuclear explosions, as a preliminary to a possible agreement on ending or suspending the testing of nuclear weapons.
Stocks closed irregularly higher yesterday after a mild sell-off in the final thirty minutes.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower signed today a bill authorizing him to give a maximum of $3,675,592,500 in foreign aid to this country's free-world allies during the twelve months beginning tomorrow.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 30 (AP) -- The office of Attorney General John Patterson said today that it would continue its fight to keep the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People from operating in Alabama.
Testimony given to Coast Guard investigators yesterday furnished additional details of the crash in the East River last Wednesday between the Swedish freighter Nebraska and the tanker Empress Bay.

WHITE PLAINS, June 30 -After listening to fervid pleas not to take "the first and irrevocable step in municipal suicide," the Common Council tonight reserved decision on a rezoning proposal to permit construction of a new shopping center.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- A $100,000 contempt fine imposed by Alabama when the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People refused to disclose its list of members in the state was struck down today by the Supreme Court.

The plight of the 6,500 retired teachers who are forced to eke out an existence on $1,600 a year or less, as reported in The New York Times on June 20, presents a challenge to the conscience of our community.

RANGOON, Burma, June 30 -- Underground Communist insurgents in Burma have demanded to be integrated into the ranks of Government armed services as a condition of surrender, a spokesman for the Burmese Army disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to review an arrangement whereby Girard College in Philadelphia has continued as a school for white orphans only.

There are, I believe, a great number of readers for whom you do not speak in your editorial of June 25 belittling the work of the House Un-American Activities Committee. It is not possible to know how many but, by the same token, it is not possible to know how many or how few are those whose views you reflect.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, June 30 -- Alaska politicians snort at the old slogan, "As Maine goes, so goes the nation." Alaska itself, in the territory's opinion has provided a better political barometer during its forty-five years of voting for territorial legislators and its Delegate to Congress.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -President Eisenhower Signed today legislation extending corporation income and most excise taxes at their present levels for another year, but repealing transportation taxes amounting to about $500,000,000 a year.

THE Metropolitan Museum is opening to the public today in its special exhibition galleries a loan show that should provide New Yorkers and out-of-town visitors with an attraction to visit and revisit during an unusually lean summer in the art field.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -The Senate approved tonight the admission of Alaska as the forty-ninth state in the Union. The vote was 64 to 20.
The world's newest shipyard, which will introduce modern shipbuilding to Greece, will begin operating within a fortnight, Transoceanic Marine, Inc., announced yesterday.
Rockets stained the moon red, men reached from ladders for galaxies and nebulae drifted a few thousand lights years off course for several hours Monday night and early yesterday morning.
FAIRBANKS, Alaska, July 1 -- Alaskans could take time out from celebrating the statehood vote to point to their Governor as animate proof that this Far North territory is the land of opportunity.
