Commodity futures closed irregularly lower yesterday in dull and generally featureless trading on the New York exchanges. Cottonseed oil, copper, zinc, lead, burlap and rubber declined; cocoa, the domestic sugar months, hides and wool rose, and price movements for coffee, the world sugar contract and potatoes were mixed.

Premier Charles de Gaulle's chances of remaining in power are appraised by Richard Barron in "The Political Parties of Modern France." Mr. Barron, a member of the Woodrow Wilson Department of Foreign Affairs of the University of Virginia, has based his book on documentary research and on first-hand observations in France.

Alaska's impending statehood has upset the flag-making industry. The industry is finding it harder to sell forty-eight-star flags and almost impossible to make the public realize there will not be any forty-nine-star flags for many months.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- A private engineering analysis of the impact of the Seaway on lakes shipping concludes that bulk cargo ships now in use face stiff competition.
James R. Hoffa's new role as a waterfront peacemaker was enhanced yesterday.
Operators of the Fablan Hotel will begin a legal fight today against a ruling by the State Rent Commission that the 124room West Side residence is a rooming house and subject to rent control.

Sales of the eight major department stores in the New York metropolitan area last month continued to show an increase above the 1957 level. The rise for June was 3 per cent, against 1 per cent a month earlier, according to a survey yesterday by The New York Times.
Manhattan's new truck route from the Manhattan Bridge to the Willis Avenue Bridge to the Bronx is to be in full operation in about eight months.

Plans for adding a floor to the one-story taxpayer building at Queens Boulevard and Sixty-second Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens, have been announced by Harry Canelstein, New York and Florida real estate investor.

A giant machine described as the widest stretcher for aluminum plate in existence has been put into operation at the Davenport, Iowa, plant of the Aluminum Company of America, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -Western nations are about ready to lift from 30 to 50 per cent of existing controls on strategic shipments to the Communist bloc.
TOKYO, July 1 -- High official sources disclosed tonight that Premier Nobosuki Kishi would like to visit Washington in November in conjunction with a tour of South America.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today the United States would never yield to blackmail to obtain the release of Americans held hostage abroad.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 1 (UPI) -- The "new" Silky Sullivan scored his first victory in some four months today, capturing the $7,500 San Clemente at Hollywood Park by two lengths.
Edward Bouchee, the Philadelphia Phillies' first baseman, was restored to his club's active list yesterday by Ford Frick, the commissioner of baseball.
TOKYO, July 1 -- Japanese newspapers gave their lead headlines today to the final action of the United States Senate voting statehood for Alaska.

ROSLYN, L. I., July 1 -- The Air Force announced today that it would shut down the Roslyn Air Force Station here "early in 1959." It said it would transfer the Twenty-sixth Air Division (Defense) and the unit's 220 men from the Roslyn base to Syracuse.
The Northern Ontario Natural Gas Company has arranged to borrow $12,000,000 privately from institutional investors in the United States and Canada.

LONDON, July 1 -- Darwin's theory of evolution was nearly overlooked by the British. When the famous paper on the subject was read to the fellows of the Linnaean Society of London one hundred years ago today, Prof. Thomas Bell, the society's president then, ignored it.
All parties to the legal controversy over the Lincoln Square redevelopment project agreed yesterday to have both pending lawsuits heard next Tuesday by the same judge.
Memphis, Tenn., is planning to sell $10,000,000 of water revenue bonds on July 15. The securities will be dated July 1, 1958 and will come due serially on July 1 from 1960 to 1988.

TORONTO, July 1 (Canadian Press) -- Dominion Steel and Coal Corporation, Ltd. (Dosco) intends "to proceed at the appropriate time with construction of a cold-rolling mill" in the Montreal area, according to the current letter to shareholders of A. V. Roe Canada, Ltd.
THE quiz games continue to pour forth on television; last night's new one was called "Bid 'n' Buy" over Channel 2. It needs work.
MOSCOW, July 1 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's "new order" for Soviet agriculture went into effect today, the first anniversary of his equally sweeping reorganization of industrial management.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today that he believed the presence of United Nations observers in Lebanon was achieving "some results."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 1 -- Anatoly F. Dobrynin, ranking Soviet member of the United Nations Secretariat, took office today as Under Secretary for the Department of Political and Security Council Affairs. He had previously been an Under Secretary Without Portfolio.
Jean H. Jackson, the 35-yearold honor patrolman who has confessed to stealing nearly $25,000 from the Police Property Clerk's offices, was indicted yesterday.
The city summer schools have closed their doors to 7,000 high school students who sought admission. Most of them were attempting to improve their standings through advanced studies.
GUANTANAMO, Cuba, July 1 -- Rear Admiral R. B. Ellis, commandant of the Guantanamo Naval Base, said tonight a United States vice consul was believed to have reached a rendezvous with Cuban rebels.
Stocks closed irregularly higher yesterday. It was a so-so market.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -Representative Charles O. Porter added new pieces today to the Galindez-Murphy puzzle.

GOSHEN, N. Y., July 1 (AP) -Anvil Chorus, a brown colt owned by the Arden Homestead Stables of Goshen, won the $13,050 E. H. Harriman Challenge Trophy 2-year-old trot in straight heats today on the Grand Circuit card at Historic Track.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The final moments of the Supreme Court session yesterday included an extraordinar debate from the bench that still had observers buzzing today.

It is now obvious that Fidel Castro and his rebels in Oriente Province, Cuba, are carrying out a widespread campaign of kidnapping Americans. Since last Thursday, when ten American and two Canadian engineers were captured at Moa Bay on the north shore, forty-five Americans and three Canadians have been seized. The latest outrage was the kidnapping of four Americans from a United Fruit sugar plantation early yesterday morning.

LISBON, Portugal, June 30 -Premier Antonio de Ouveira Salabar, Portugal's dictator, told his countrymen tonight that all existing restrictions would continue and new ones, including heavy taxation, would be added.
Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt yesterday promoted his trainer, Bill Winfrey, to the post of general manager of the Vanderbilt thoroughbred holdings.

The latest addition to the growing mutual funds field made its bow yesterday. Known as Townsend U. S. and International Growth Fund, Inc., it is described as a "non-diversified special situation fund with leverage potential."
BALTIMORE, July 1 -- Mickey Mantle snapped out of his batting slump today to hit two home runs, one before, the other after sunset.
CANNES, France, July 1 (AP) -- Harry S. Truman spoke out today on the Sherman Adams case.
MASSENA, N. Y., July 1 -St. Lawrence seaway operators face a long, hard fight to produce sufficient traffic for the new $471,000,000 waterway.

ROME, July 1 -- Amintore Fanfani, the political secretary who led the dominant Christian Democrat party to victory in the general election of May 25 and 26, became Premier of Italy today at the head of the nineteenth post-war Italian Cabinet.

Although Premier de Gaulle must still demonstrate his ability to solve France's most pressing problems, especially the toughest problem of them all -- Algeria -- it is gratifying to note that some of the anxieties aroused by his accession to power have proved to be unjustified. This is true regarding the fears of a French drift toward dictatorship, and it is equally true regarding France's relations with her allies.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The volume of consumer installment credit outstanding declined in May for the fourth consecutive month, but less than in the other three months, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -Senator Lister Hill, Democrat of Alabama, urged "a dynamic program of international medical research" in presenting a plaque today to Surgeon General Leroy E. Burney as president of the World Health Assembly.
Tony Vincent and Sidney Schwartz scored decisive victories in the New York State tennis championship yesterday.

Nicolas Arroyo, Cuban Ambassador to the United States, presented a bronze medal of the Cuban Government yesterday to 79-year-old Dick Shanafelt, one of twenty-four surviving members of Theodore Roosevelt's Rough Riders. It was the sixtieth anniversary of the Battle of San Juan Hill.
SAIGON, Vietnam, June 30 -The excitement caused by the charges last week in Pnompenh of a South Vietnamese invasion of Cambodia has subsided here.
Lennen Newell, Inc., has merged with one agency and is arranging to take over another.
HAVANA, July 1 -- Four more Americans were kidnapped last night by the Cuban rebels, bringing the total of abducted United States citizens to fortyfive. Three Canadians also have been kidnapped.
What may prove to be an important oil discovery has been made in Libya by the Ohio Oil Company and its partners, the Amerada Petroleum Corporation and the Continental Oil Company.
MASSENA, N. Y., July 1 -A new lake came into existence just north of here today, bringing closer to completion the St. Lawrence Seaway and hydroelectric power development.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI) -- Neil H. McElroy, Secretary of Defense, indicated today that the Administration would drop its fight for a so-called "insubordination" clause in its defense reorganization plan if Congress would restore two other provisions.
WHITE SANDS MISSILE RANGE, N. M., July 1 -- The Nike Hercules, the nation's new "city-defender" anti-aircraft rocket, was demonstrated publicly for the first time today.

Dr. Detlev Bronk and especially Dr. Linus Pauling have shown poor judgment in accepting appointments to the Soviet Academy of Sciences. It is doubtful that such appointments will do much to improve international scientific communications.

In a rapidly changing world, alive with possibilities, it is an amusing pastime to conjure up visions of the future. What will things be like in the year 2000, for example? The question sets the mind free to wander in fields of imagination.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 1--Debate here today was as hot as the weather. The question was--"Should New Rochelle build a thirty-acre public swimming resort on Long Island Sound?"

Metals price trends were mixed yesterday. Another major copper producer advanced its refined copper price 1 1/2 cents a pound, to 26 1/2 cents, while producers and smelters of lead trimmed their prices one-half cent a pound, to 11 cents.
FIRE ISLAND, L. I., July 1 -- The ocean, it seem, is not big enough for a few surf-casters here who take fierce pride in calling themselves "natives."

MOSCOW, July 1 -- The Soviet Government has been stung by Yugoslav charges that it does not fulfill its international obligations and is, therefore, trying, to prove the Yugoslavs wrong before a watching world.

GENEVA, July 1--The East-West technical talks on the detection of nuclear explosions opened today on a note of harmony. Both sides sidestepped the political issue of suspending tests of nuclear weapons.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 1 -- The salary minimums and working conditions for all directors employed in the making of theatrical and television motion pictures are embodied in a single contract for the first time under an agreement concluded late today.

PITTSBURGH, July 1 -- Steel companies skipped pay rises for their management workers for the first time in years today. They put into effect the third and last installment of a pay increase of up to 13 cents an hour for members of the United Steelworkers Union.

BATNA, Algeria, July 1 -Premier Charles de Gaulle came to the town where the first shots of the Algerian rebellion were fired and told a cheering crowd today: "The work we have done together is immense. From what I have seen here, I know that the future is ours."
The cotton futures market closed 3 points (15 cents) higher to 4 points lower, with trading rather slow on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday.

New Yorkers will soon be able to leave clothes in subway lockers and have them dry-cleaned while they are at work. The Transit Authority yesterday approved an agreement for the installation of a sixteen-unit locker by Art Craft Tailors, Inc., in the Church Avenue station of the IND subway in Brooklyn.

Directors of the American Viscose Corporation yesterday declared a 25-cent dividend on the common stock, payable Aug. 1. This is half the previous quarterly payments of 50 cents. Harry L. Dalton, vice chairman, attributed the reduction to lower earnings.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1 (AP) -- The United States Third Circuit Court of Appeals said today the Federal Power Commission could not bargain away its power with any utility in setting fair and reasonable rates.
A witness testified under oath yesterday that she "believed" the Morris L. Ernst report on the disappearance of Jesus de Galindez contained deliberate falsification.

This is the zero hour for labor reform legislation. The Kennedy-Ives bill, which the Senate passed with but one negative vote, has now gone to the House for action. But what that will be depends on maneuvers now under way and the pressures they will eventually build up. There are also factors of inertia that could stymie any action at all before Congress adjourns.

WESTBURY, -L. I., July 1 -The racing program at Roosevelt Raceway tonight was marred by a spectacular accident in the seventh race. although four horses and drivers were directly involved and the other four sulkies were in some manner a part of the scene, no one was seriously injured.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Republican leaders reported today that President Eisenhower agreed with them that Hawaii should be admitted to the Union before the Eighty-fifth Congress adjourned.

Adoption by the New Jersey Legislature of a more stringent Sunday closing law, and the earlier failure of the New York Legislature to adopt the Asch-Rosenblatt bill permitting a fair Sabbath law in New York City, emphasize the need for sober public consideration of the misconceptions responsible for embedding into public policy injustice to the adherents of certain religious faiths.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- Dinah Shore was admonished today to sing "My Old Kentucky Home" the way Stephen Foster wrote it -- or not at all.
The Jacob Ruppert Brewery broke away yesterday from the rest of the brewing industry in the city and made its own peace in the dispute that has shut five plants since last week.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 1 (AP) -- The Nationalist Government is holding two United States civilians on suspicion of complicity in smuggling $250,000 worth of heroin into Taiwan (Formosa).

NYACK, N. Y., July 1 -Nyack's Old Broadway Theatre was relit tonight after twenty-five years in the dark. "Midsummer," a Vina Delmar play, was presented in the reconstructed building, now called the Tappan Zee Playhouse.
The Western Union Telegraph Company asked yesterday for rate increases totaling $9,800,000 a year in revenue.
EAST LANSING, Mich., July 1 (AP) -- President Eisenhower's Civil Rights Commission is making no recommendations on the school integration case in Little Rock, Ark.

EL MUKHTARA, Lebanon, July 1 (UPI) -- The rebel leader Kamal Jumblatt warned today that the Lebanese insurgents would accept foreign volunteers -- even Soviet and Chinese technicians -- in the event of Western military intervention in this revolt-torn country.

These menus, which appear each week, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are designed to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

AACHEN, Germany, July 1 (UPI) -- William Steinkraus of Westport, Conn., guided his mount First Boy to victory in the Phillips Prix jumping event at the fifth day of the Aachen International horse show today.

LE HAVRE, France, July 1 -- If the Gaullist revolution has accomplished, nothing else so far it has at least laid bare the myth of French Communist might. Throughout the post-war era the party of Thorez and Duclos has been a powerful factor.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -President and Mrs. Eisenhower celebrated their forty-second wedding anniversary tonight with dinner and a Potomac River trip aboard the cruiser Barbara Anne.

A six-story apartment building containing a self-service elevator at 1854 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by Max Gross. The buyer was an investing client of Saul Siller and Judah Rosner, brokers in the sale.

WASHINGTON, July 1--The Administration began an all-out drive today to restore $600,000,000 cut from the foreign-aid bill by the House Appropriations Committee. But the Democratic leadership in the House let it be known indirectly that the effort would probably not receive bipartisan support.
SAN JUAN, P. R., July 1 (AP) -- Gov. Luis Munoz Marin sent messages today congratulating Alaskans on winning Congressional approval to become the forty-ninth state.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -Efforts to end charity rackets will be ineffectual unless the Government steps in, a New York expert testified today.
Some lively bidding recently for the American rights to one of Europe's controversial dramas, "The Trial of Jesus," was ended yesterday in producer Warner LeRoy's favor.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI) -- J. Edgar Hoover today branded as "slanderous, violent and hateful" charges that the Federal Bureau of Investigation uses Gestapo-like tactics.
AIN AB, Lebanon, July 1 -Rebel Druse clansmen were driven out of this village overlooking Beirut today after three hours of house-to-house fighting.

LONDON, July 1 -- Stock market prices moved unevenly today. British Government Securities continued to improve and oil shares rallied. But industrials generally were dull, although some took a turn for the better in the afternoon.
MOSCOW, July 1 -- The Soviet Union protested today against a speech by Attorney General William P. Rogers that it said contained "hostile and slanderous falsehoods."

John Frederics has gone native. Tropical Cuba was the inspiration for his lively group of fall hats. Mr. Fred believes that this season's millinery should be bold and important, not relaxed in shape and quiet in color and conception.

TORONTO, July 1 (UPI) -Canada won the international professional-amateur competition for the Carling Cup for the second straight year, today by defeating the United States, 6 1/2 points to 5 1/2, at the St. George Golf and Country Club.

CLEVELAND, July 1 (AP) -The United Rubber Workers and Goodyear Tire Rubber Company and the B. F. Goodrich Company agreed tonight on 8cent hourly pay rises and postponement of pension and insurance plan changes until next spring.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -James R. Hoffa made his first direct move today against one of his allies involved in charges of racketeering in the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
Two Brooklyn "thrill killers" were sentenced yesterday to ten to twenty years in prison after pleading guilty to first-degree manslaughter.

STOCKINGS of rainbow hues have been accepted now for many months. And there is nothing more alluring than feminine legs prettily turned out in something other than the conventional go-with-everything neutrals.
TUNIS, July 1 -- A small but growing number of French Foreign Legionnaires in Algeria, probably about five men a week, are reported to be deserting to the Algerian nationalist rebel forces.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 1 -- Althea Gibson miraculously found her championship form when she needed it most today. Trailing, 2 -- 0, in the third set, she ran off six games in a brilliant streak to subdue Britain's stubborn Shirley Bloomer, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 8, 6 -- 2.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Secretary of State Dulles complained at his news conference today that the Soviet Union was making exchange of information with the United States "very difficult." [Question 19, Page 8.]

WHEN Edwin D. Shaw was fourteen years old and just out of Public School 2 in Brooklyn's Bay Ridge district fifty-one years ago, he got a messenger's job with S. B. Chapin Co. in Wall Street. It got to be a common thing for him to walk the streets or to ride the subways carrying awesome amounts in stocks and bonds.
The temperature soared to 90.3 degrees at 4:50 P. M. yesterday to make it the hottest day of the year.

The Waterfront Commission hearing into an alleged "phantom" hiring racket on Brooklyn piers was adjourned yesterday until July 16, to permit defense counsel to arrange for the appearance of certain witnesses. The bi-state agency has charged that Anthony Del Mar, a hiring agent for the Turner Blanchard stevedoring firm, participated in the hiring of men who were paid longshore wages although they did no work.
BRASILIA, Brazil, June 30 -- A gleaming palace of white marble, glass and aluminum in daring design was dedicated today as the future seat of this nation's Government.
Net operating earnings of several New York City banks were higher than those for last year, their statements of condition for the six months ended June 30 revealed yesterday.

ST. ANNE'S-ON-THE-SEA, England, July 1 (UPI) -- Fiftysix-year-old Gene Sarazen and Monte Bradley, an Army private from Texas, were the only United States entries who qualified today for the British open golf championship.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 1--The Government of Premier David Ben-Gurion accepted today the resignation of two Cabinet members of the National Religious party, who refused to accept its definition of a Jew.
Only two former team members were named to the women's Curtis Cup team for 1958 by the United States Golf Association's women's committee yesterday.
A group of Bayside home owners lost their fight yesterday to bar the relocation of a house in their neighborhood. Their application was denied in Queens Supreme Court by Justice J. Vincent Keogh.
The Champion Paper and Fibre Company and its subsidiaries yesterday reported a decline in earnings for the fiscal year ended March 31, despite an increase in sales.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 1 -President Camille Chamoun conferred simultaneously today with the United States, British and French Ambassadors on Lebanon's crisis.
The Cuban Government's drive to crush the rebellion led by Fidel Castro in Oriente Province has collapsed in failure, according to information from travelers recently in eastern Cuba.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- A Buffalo business man held fast today to testimony that his presence at a hoodlum conclave last year, which was broken up by the police, was pure happenstance.
A multicolored fireworks display illuminated the city's skyline for thirty-six minutes last night in a salute to the 100th anniversary of R. H. Macy Co., Inc.

The leading people in the performing arts are among the Soviet Union's elite. Like the principal figures in the Government, the important party officials, the indispensable scientists and technicians, they enjoy the best living conditions the country has to offer.

Uris Brothers, builders, who plan an office building in the blockfront on the west side of Park Avenue from Fiftieth to Fifty-first Street, have taken title to Finland House at 39-45 East Fiftieth Street The six-story building is on a plot 80 by 100 feet. The purchase gives the site a frontage of 155 feet on Fiftieth Street.

IT happened in 1942, the season in which Joe (Flash) Gordon of the Yankees was named the most valuable player in the American League. The batter slashed a grounder through the hole between first and second, an obvious hit from the moment the ball left the bat. The acrobatic Gordon floated to his left and flagged down the drive, although he couldn't hold it.
Marshall Clark, former director of advertising for the Scott Paper Company, will join Ketchum, MacLeod Grove, Inc., July 14, as manager of its office here. He has also been elected a vice president.

THE forty-ninth state-to-be is the do-it-yourself homemaker's paradise. In Alaska many a woman pitches in to help her husband build their home and then settles down to practice her cooking, on which her social reputation, in large part, will rest.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -The Army announced today the award of contracts totaling nearly $85,000,000 for anti-aircraft missile work.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -The Army is restoring full security clearance to Col. John C. Nickerson, missile officer convicted last year of leaking military secrets. It is also letting him out of the job to which he was banished.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI) -- The French Government's atomic energy establishment and three French physicists filed suit in Federal Court today claiming a patent on the basic principle of nuclear reactors.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, July 1 -- Pandemonium in the Gold Rush tradition gave way to Alaskan soul-searching today.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 (AP) -- The Firstamerica Corporation announced it was in business today as an independent bank holding company, taking over the $3 billion banking empire of the Transamerica Corporation.
A Bronx crowd that had been drenching passing motorists with water from an open hydrant beat and stabbed an offduty policeman who sought to shut off the stream.
LONDON, July 1 -- The Chinese Communist Government has suddenly and without explanation tightened restrictions on the movement of foreign diplomats in Peiping.

ACCORDING to a recent dispatch in these pages, the Federal Government is spending $740,000 for the observance in 1959 of the sesquicentennial of the birth in a Kentucky log cabin of Abraham Lincoln No special funds were set aside, no special observances were planned this year (except a small exhibit at the Library of Congress) to mark the sesquicentennial of another historic Kentucky birth, that of Jefferson Davis in 1808.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Following is the transcript of Secretary Dulles' news conference, as released today by the State Department:
The extent to which automobile production declined during the first six months of this year below the 1957 level was pointed up in figures issued yesterday by leading manufacturers.

The Canada General Fund, Ltd., reported yesterday a 12.7 per cent rise in net asset value a share in its third fiscal quarter ended May 31. Net assets were $78,312,770, equal to $12.15 a share, against $70,195,430, or $10.78 a share, a year earlier.
WITH at least sixty types of paint to choose from, paint dealers are in a dilemma when a homemaker blithely ask for "a gallon of some green paint."

James D. Norris, chairman of the board of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, has been sought since early last month by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan for questioning before the grand jury investigating racketeering in boxing.

The appointment of Paul O'Shea of Port Chester, N. Y., one of America's leading race drivers, as sports car director of the Studebaker - Packard Corporation, was announced yesterday. This led to a great deal of speculation in sports car circles.
LINCOLN, Neb., July 1 (AP) -A strike halted bus service by American Trailways today in a twenty-nine-state area from New York to California.
VALLEY STREAM, L. I., July 1 -- Five thousand persons attended a band concert here tonight on the Village Green on the hottest day of the year.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The State Department said today that it was processing visas at a rate of 300 a day under the immigration law authorizing issuance of 14,556 special non-quota visas to fugitives from Communist areas now in the Middle East.
American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., reported yesterday gains in corporate and consolidated net income for the first quarter and for twelve months ended March 31.
A campaign to eliminate unethical advertising practices by automobile dealers through public exposure was begun yesterday by the Better Business Bureau here.
A warning against exploitation of Alaska's imminent statehood by unscrupulous stock promoters was sounded yesterday in by Louis J. Lefkowitz, State Attorney General.
HAMILTON, N. Y., July 1 -A top troubleshooter for the State Department expressed special interest here tonight in apparent conflicts between Communist China and the Soviet Union.

Your recent article reporting the dangerous growth of cancerous slums in the Columbia-Morningside area effectively analyzed the causes of blight and gave well-deserved praise to the efforts of neighborhood institutions to combat it.

A new electric tray-serving table, mounted on wheels, folds flat for easy storage. Designed for keeping food warm in the living room or on the patio, the table has a top shelf of shatterproof radiant glass that measures 28 by 16 inches.
A number of personnel changes, to take effect Aug. 1, were announced yesterday for Macy's New York by Elliot V. Walter, president. Macy's New York operates the local store and its suburban branches.
HONOLULU, July 1 (AP) -- A Coast Guard cutter stopped the Phoenix, a yacht, after it sailed today into the American nuclear testing zone in the mid- Pacific.

MACON, Ga., July 1 (AP) -Judge W. A. Bootle has ruled in favor of the defendant Columbus Fiber Mills Company, Inc., in a patent infringement brought by the Chicopee Manufacturing Corporation in United States District Court, on socalled puffed fabrics used for auto seat covers.

CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- Continued hedging and moderate liquidation weakened wheat futures prices again today on the Board of Trade. Other grains rallied from early weakness and most of them finished with gains.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 1 -- If "The Music Man" had the seventy-six trombones he sings about he still couldn't compete with the twenty-four drums from Africa's Urundi.
CLEVELAND, July 1 -- Educators were told today that they had to distinguish between constructive critics of schools and troublemakers.
IN "John Turner Davis," Horton Foote's quiet, discursive style is illuminating and affecting.

The fourteen-story apartment house at 271 Central Park West at Eighty-seventh Street has been purchased for investment by Joseph Schlang, real estate broker and managing agent with offices at 27 William Street. The plot is 75 by 100 feet. Mr. Schlang said he bought the building because its apartments of eight and nine rooms were becoming more and more in demand in Manhattan.
Again the United States Supreme Court has proved itself to be the towering citadel of American liberty. Monday's decision on freedom of association is one more case to prove the point.

Daniel Magay of Hungary retrained his national saber championship last night at the Hotel Commodore. Magay kept his title by checking Dr. Tibor Nyilas of the New York Athletic Club, 5 -- 3, in a fence-off.

The New York Telephone Company's $42,900,000 tax refund suit against the Federal Government has been settled for $1,000,000, it was announced yesterday by Morton S. Robson, assistant United States Attorney in charge of the civil division.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Record farm subsidy payments -not defense or anti-recession spending -- are expected to push the Federal Government's expenditures to a peacetime peak in the 1959 fiscal year, which began today.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, July 1 -- Bound together in the long bipartisan fight for statehood, Alaska Republicans and Democrats now are squaring off for a slugging match in the organization of the forty-ninth state.
PARIS, July 1 -- Jews who formerly lived in Egypt and Syria are now forbidden to reenter the United Arab Republic, the European director of the American Jewish Committee asserted here today.
New York Republicans swarmed aboard the Nelson A. Rockefeller bandwagon for Governor last night.
The Governor of one of the Union's oldest states -- New York -- and a former Governor of a state-to-be -- Alaska-toclaimed yesterday the approval of Alaskan statehood.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI) -- The House Education Committee informally approved today a compromise version of President Eisenhower's aid-toscience program. Its cost was estimated at about $660,000,000 over a four-year period.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -The Senate late today passed by a vote of 41 to 18 a Government subsidy bill authorizing construction of two new superliners.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 1 -- Prospects for an early development of friendly relations between Cambodia and South Vietnam do not look particularly encouraging here at the moment.
The evening performance on Nov. 5 of "The MarriageGo-Round" will benefit the West Side Day Nursery, which is celebrating its seventyfifth anniversary this year.

Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh announced yesterday that he had committed to Rikers Island for treatment a 23-year-old narcotics addict under the Code of Criminal Procedure rather than under the Public Health Law.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP)--The Post Office Department made service changes today as a preliminary to pending rate increases. The 4-cent letter and 7-cent airmail rates are effective Aug. 1.

THE fourth season of summer "evenings by the river" concerts presented by the Lower East Side Neighborhoods Association opened last night at the East River Park Amphitheatre. Rose Bampton was soprano soloist with the L. E. N. A. Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Wilfrid Pelletier.

JERSEY CITY, July 1 -- A shift in the balance of power in this city's Board of Education tonight resulted in dismissals of seventy-four employes in nonteaching classifications in the city's school system.

Bells have been ringing and horns tooting in Alaska, all the way from Kodiak to Barrow and from Juneau to Nome. The victory has been won. After forty-six years as a territory Alaska now joins the congregation of the states -- or will do so once President Eisenhower puts his expected signature on the statehood measure that has just passed the Senate.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Department of Agriculture researchers have developed a wash-and-wear finish that can be applied to completed cotton garments by dry cleaners.

New issues of corporate securities totaling $41,576,000 will be offered to investors today. The transactions are intended to finance expansion of a public utility and a grocery chain, and to help a Western railroad buy new freight-carrying equipment.
HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., July 1--The Mark Stuarts, senior and junior of Winged Foot, today won the Metropolitan Golf Association's father and son championship for the second straight year.
CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

THE fourth season of summer "evenings by the river" concerts presented by the Lower East Side Neighborhoods Association opened last night at the East River Park Amphitheatre. Rose Bampton was soprano soloist with the L. E. N. A. Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Wilfrid Pelletier.

JERSEY CITY, July 1 -- A shift in the balance of power in this city's Board of Education tonight resulted in dismissals of seventy-four employes in nonteaching classifications in the city's school system.

Bells have been ringing and horns tooting in Alaska, all the way from Kodiak to Barrow and from Juneau to Nome. The victory has been won. After forty-six years as a territory Alaska now joins the congregation of the states -- or will do so once President Eisenhower puts his expected signature on the statehood measure that has just passed the Senate.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Department of Agriculture researchers have developed a wash-and-wear finish that can be applied to completed cotton garments by dry cleaners.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -Bernard Goldfine deducted from his income tax as business expenses at least some of the gifts he made to Sherman Adams, the Assistant to the President, and other officials, it was learned tonight.
Testimony at variance with earlier depositions about the collision between the Swedish freighter Nebraska and the tanker Empress Bay was given to Coast Guard investigators yesterday.
HEWLETT HARBOR, L. I., July 1--The Mark Stuarts, senior and junior of Winged Foot, today won the Metropolitan Golf Association's father and son championship for the second straight year.
CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Following are highlights of President Eisenhower's news conference today:
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today accused Revlon, Inc., of conspiring with seven other companies to fix illegally prices for refillable lipstick cases.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) -Key Democratic leaders said today they saw little chance, that Hawaii would follow Alaska into the Union this year andI give the Republic fifty statesq But some thought chances were( good1 for action next year.
DALLAS, Tex., July 2 (UPI) -- More than 500 Continental Bus Lines employes walked out today, disrupting service from Denver to Houston.
HAVANA, July 2 (AP) -- One of the freed men, the Canadian engineer, Edward Cannon, said Raul Castro promised no more foreigners would be kidnapped.
Bill collectors are having a harder time of it than they were three months ago, according to the American Collectors Association.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N. Y., July 2 -- Calling his shot, Willie Turnesa holed an eighteen-foot chip on the eighteenth hole that enabled his team to score a repeat triumph in the British Victory amateur best-ball tournament today.

VIRGINIA BEACH, July 2 -- Although it soon will be 100 years since the War Between the States, that tragic chapter in the nation's history has not been -- nor can it ever be -- forgotten. The principles for which it was fought by both sides, the sacrifice, heroism and tragedy that it embodied are inextricably integrated into the fabric of our heritage.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 2 (AP) -- J. Howard Edmondson, virtually unknown politically six months ago, registered one of Oklahoma's biggest political upsets today by taking the lead in the Democratic race for Governor.

LONDON, July 2 -- Britain told Communist China today that the United Nations Governments concerned were prepared to withdraw their remaining forces from Korea when the conditions for a lasting settlement laid down by the United Nations General Assembly were fulfilled.

HOLLYWOOD, July 2 (UPI) -- Don Jordan of Los Angeles moved into welterweight contention tonight by scoring an upset ten-round split decision over Isaac Logart in a nationally televised fight at Hollywood Legion Stadium.
The New York Central Railroad apparently has accepted the adage: "You Can't Beat City Hall."

Electric power production last week fell to 11,757,000,000 kilowatt hours from 11,941,000,000 in the preceding week, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. The figure for the week ended June 29, 1957, was 12,111,000,000 kilowatt hours.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 2 -- The mass suspension of 1,200 pupil troublemakers by the New York City Board of Education last February was criticized today at the ninety-sixth annual convention of the National Education Association.

TRENTON, July 2 -- New Jersey officially ended today its four-year investigation into the activities of former Gov. Harold G. Hoffman, who admitted he embezzled $300,000 in state funds. He died June 4, 1954.

In the original budget for 1958-59, the fiscal year that began this week, total expenditures were placed at $73.9 billion. The revised figure, based on the outlook as of July 1, is $78 billion, "or perhaps a little less," according to our Washington bureau.

CHAPPAQUA, N. Y., July 2 -- New Castle, a northern Westchester town experiencing more "growth shock" than most suburbs, has its first master plan for future development. It was adopted by the Planning Board last night after three years of preparation.
BALTIMORE, July 2 -- The Yankees, who gave up one "Barber" recently when they dropped Sal Maglie from their roster, seem to have acquired another one.
DETROIT, July 2 (AP) -F. Jordan Schanbeck, general manager of the Ford Motor Company's Marine Division, drowned last night when he fell from a yacht in Lake St. Clair. He was 43 years old.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- President Eisenhower sent Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev an angry letter today blaming the Soviet Union for disrupting preparations for a summit conference.
The stock market rose irregularly yesterday. Wall Street was in a pre-holiday mood and trading slackened. Most price changes were in fractions.
ALBANY, July 2 (AP) -- A jury that banned John O'Hara's "Ten North Frederick" lost out in court today.

A commendable phase of the 1957 activity of the commerce division of the Department of Commerce and Public Events, as outlined in its annual report, was the division's continuing effort to attract new business to New York City and to hold business already here. Last year the unit began a new service to advise local enterprise on problems connected with operating or opening small business establishments.

Columbia University announced plans yesterday to provide housing for married graduate students by September, 1959. Teachers College, an affiliate of the University, is the only unit that has such accommodations now.
The white collar workers of the Grancolombiana Steamship Company -- with assistance from longshore workers -- brought company operations to a stand-still yesterday.

The American Civil Liberties Union yesterday joined the protest against plans to bar Negroes from a new Levitt housing development to be built in Burlington County, New Jersey. The housing is planned by William Levitt, builder of Levittowns on Long Island and in Pennsylvania.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- Gen. Robert E. Wood said today that Sherman Adams "has always seemed to me a most objectionable type -- arrogant, opinionated and arbitrary." He demanded that the Assistant to the President resign immediately.

Futures prices closed generally higher in dull and featureless trading yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Cocoa, the domestic sugar contract, cottonseed oil, copper, potatoes and hides rose; the world sugar months, zinc and lead declined, and price movements for coffee, wool and rubber were mixed.
MASSENA, N. Y., July 2 -- One of the lift locks of the United States Seaway project in the International Rapids section of the St. Lawrence River was used for the first time today.
The Smith College singers were honored by the American Heritage Foundation yesterday afternoon for their work as "ambassadors of goodwill" on five summer singing tours of Europe.
Bond issues totaling $12,075,000 were posted for sale yesterday by drainage districts in Michigan. The borrowings will take place on July 24.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 2 -- The Brazilian press today echoed with approval Secretary of State Dulles' rejection of an inter-American heads-of-Government conference without thorough diplomatic preparation.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Bernard Goldfine confirmed tonight that he had charged off as business expenses on income tax returns his gifts and favors for Sherman Adams.

GUANTANAMO, Cuba, July 2 -- An American released by the Cuban rebels last week after a brief period of capture attributed his freedom today to the gift of persuasion he learned in two and a half years of recruiting duty in Meriden, Conn.

In his column published June 28, protesting against hitting at mosquitoes with hammers, C. L. Sulzberger happily hits the nail on the head. No statement could be saner than his opening sentence: "It would be sheer insanity for the United States and Britain to sponsor a military intervention in Lebanon without specific U. N. authorization."
LONDON, July 2 -- The stock market was quietly confident today and in many sections gains outnumbered losses, but tournover as a whole remained small.

Thousands of young people have been graduated from our city colleges in the last few days. They have received this education free at the hands of a generous city. And it is not easy for New York City to foot the bill for 81,000 students. It is growing less so as city costs climb.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 2 -- Lebanon's quarrel with the United Arab Republic may doom the chances of Dr. Charles Malik, Lebanese Foreign Minister, to become the President of the next General Assembly.
WARSAW, July 2 -- Poland appointed today Tadeusz Galinski, a veteran Communist party editor, as Minister of Culture, one of the most ticklish jobs in government.
CHICAGO, July 2 (UPI) -- Willie Mays, Ray Jablonski and Bob Schmidt hit home runs today to lead the San Francisco Giants to a 5-2 victory over the Chicago Bubs.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 2 -- There will be an all-Australian tennis final at Wimbledon for the third year running. Ashley Cooper won in a walk today and Neale Fraser made it after the fight of his life.

HAMILTON, N. Y., July 2 -- Thomas K. Finletter, former Secretary of the Air Force, called today for the United States to take the lead in encouraging the United Nations to work directly toward a solution of the Lebanese situation.
The city baked in summer heat yesterday that promised to linger through today and the holiday tomorrow.

The successful creative artist in the Soviet Union is a prophet with great honor in his own country. A grateful Government showers rewards, material and otherwise, on him. It also lavishes constant attention on what he produces. Therein lies his problem.
RAILROADING is the career and the hobby of Alfred Edward Perlman, who has been working on the railroad since he was 16 years old.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Officials of the Internal Revenue Service refused to discuss the tax affairs of Bernard Goldfine today, except to say that the White House had not asked for -- and the service had not volunteered -- a report on them.
KEARNY, N. J., July 2 -- An explosion in a transformer here this afternoon cut off power to 400,000 consumers in Bergen and Hudson Counties and caused delays to many homeward-bound commuters.
NOT even Greek goddesses can hold out against the rage for slimming.
LONDON, July 2 -- The gold and dollar reserves held by Britain as central banker for the sterling area rose again last month.

Chayym Zeldis, who recently returned to New York after spending more than ten years in Israel, has won the $250 John Day Novel Award for his novel-in-progress entitled "Streams in the Wilderness." He has been studying at the New School, whose Creative Writers Fund joined with the publisher in establishing the John Day Novel Award.

In parallel notes addressed to Soviet Russia the Western powers have declared again that they still hold a summit meeting to be desirable and that they will not relax their efforts to seek tolerable settlements. But they also make it plain that they will attend such a meeting only on two conditions.

SIDI - BEL - ABBES, Algeria, July 2 -- At an isolated French Army outpost is surrounded by rebel territory Premier Charles de Gaulle today gave Algerian Moslems his word of honor that they would get full equality about twenty miles from the with Europeans.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- President Eisenhower said at his news conference today that his talks with Prime Minister John Diefenbaker of Canada next week would cover many of the economic problems troubling United States-Canadian relations.

Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) cautiously announced plans yesterday to increase its holdings in Humble Oil and Refining Company. It said it would file as soon as possible a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the issuance of 10,850,000 additional shares of its $7 par value capital stock, authorized but unissued.
CHICAGO, July 2 (AP) -- Hedge selling eased considerably in wheat futures trading today and prices advanced on a resumption of a moderate demand for flour.

FRENCH gourmets -- and nearly all Frenchmen regard themselves as such -- are viewing with reserve a relatively new development in Parisian restaurants: American-style, stand-in-line-with-a-tray cafeterias.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- On its final opinion day this week, the Supreme Court touched again on an old problem troubling to laymen, lawyers and judges alike -- the differences in the application of the United States Constitution to the Federal Government and to the states.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- The Government moved today against Automatic Canteen Company of America, Chicago, the country's biggest vending machine operator. It ordered the concern to divest itself of fourteen subsidiary companies and to refrain from acquiring any vending machine manufacturer for the next ten years.
AACHEN, Germany, July 2 (UPI) -- Fritz Thiedemann of Germany won the 1958 European jumping championship of the Aachen international horse show astride Meteor today. He had 106 points.
Frank Froehling registered the first upset in the New York State tennis championship yesterday.

HONG KONG, Thursday, July 3 (AP) -- Communist China criticized today the idea of resuming talks with the United States in Warsaw instead of Geneva. Peiping accused Secretary of State Dulles of being inconsistent.

The patent of the United States Plywood Corporation on Weldtex, a striated plywood panel, has been infringed upon by the Georgia Pacific Corporation, according to a decision by the Circuit Court of Appeals here.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 2 -- A fire of uncertain origin, reportedly accompanied by a series of explosions, destroyed Sound State 8 at the Samuel Goldwyn studio early this morning. The stage had been set to represent Catfish Row in Mr. Goldwyn's production of "Porgy and Bess."
HELSINKI, Finland, July 2 (UPI) -- A Finnish athlete was injured today when Harold Connolly's hammer got away from him in a track meet here.
MASSENA, N. Y., July 2 -- Turbines began test spins in the new $650,000,000 St. Lawrence River power project tonight, two days ahead of schedule.
WESTBURY, L. I., July 2 -- Paul Vineyard rated So Long's Lad neatly to win the Vacation Time Pace that headlined the program at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

The retrial of Henry W. Grunewald, asserted Washington influence peddler, and two others on tax-fixing conspiracy charges ended yesterday when a Federal Court jury reported it was hopelessly deadlocked after three days of deliberation.

Trans World Airlines, Inc., has a new president. He is Charles S. Thomas, former Secretary of the Navy, who was elected by the airline's board yesterday. The announcement was made by flier-industrialist Howard Hughes, president of the Hughes Tool Company, of which T. W: A. is a subsidiary.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 2 -- Dr. Subandrio, Indonesian Foreign Minister, said today that the dispatch of Dutch troops to West New Guinea (West Irian) would increase tension between Indonesia and the Netherlands.
AUDUBON, Iowa, July 2 (AP) -- A thunderstorm struck this southwestern Iowa area early today causing heavy loss of life and vast property damage. More than thirteen inches of rain fell in a few hours.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The House of Representatives handed President Eisenhower a smashing defeat today on the foreign aid bill. The action came within hours after he had made a personal appeal for restoration of funds cut by the House Appropriations Committee.
HARTFORD, July 2 -- Delegates from twenty-two countries convened here today for the start of a nine-day world assembly of Congregationalist and allied church leaders.

GENEVA, July 2 -- The Soviet bloc's scientific delegation gave further encouraging signs today that it was prepared to engage in serious technical discussions with the West on the feasibility of detecting atomic tests.

The New York Central Railroad warned yesterday it was ready to end all commuter service into Grand Central Terminal and abandon the terminal itself unless the state and its communities helped the road to overcome mounting operating losses.
AIN AB, Lebanon, July 2 -- This mountain village in an olive grove was embattled in a miniature civil war today.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Among the decisions announced by the Supreme Court Monday before it adjourned for the summer, those in which the justices repulsed what they held to be an invasion of free speech in California were outstanding as illustrations of the court's construction of the range of civil liberties.

HAVANA, July 2 -- In Santiago de Cuba, capital of Oriente Province, the Urgency Court sentenced Javiar Pazos and Armando Hart today to five months of imprisonment for collaborating with the Castro rebels. Javiar is the son of Felipe Pazos, a former president of the National Bank of Cuba during the Carlos Prio administration.

The First National City Bank of New York reported yesterday combined net operating income of the bank and its affiliate, City Bank Farmers Trust Company, for the six months ended June 30 at $29,835,000 or $2.49 a common share. In the same period last year the bank earned $28,760,000, or $2.40 a share.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 2 -- James Mason will star in a series of half-hour filmed melodramas to be based on the Graham Greene novel "The Third Man." The producer will be National Telefilm Associates.

KHARTOUM, the Sudan, July 2 (Reuters) -- The Sudan started diverting waters of the Nile River yesterday into a new irrigation project without waiting for the consent of the Government of the United Arab Republic.
The transfer of New York City's Byram Lake in northern Westchester County to Mount Kisco was completed yesterday.
Bertram T. Grant, a New York State boxing judge, was indicted yesterday on charges of accepting bribes to influence his decisions in major boxing matches here.
Following is the text of a memorandum to Mayor Wagner from Alfred E. Perlman, president of the New York Central System:
A report of a meeting held by the Joint Emergency Committee to Close Washington Square Park to Traffic in The Times of June 26 quotes several speakers as condemning urban renewal projects.

In approving a two-year community college for Queens the Board of Estimate has taken a necessary step to help alleviate a growing shortage of higher educational facilities in this city. The Queens Community College will help hundreds of qualified boys and girls attain a low-tuition-cost education and the city will have a community college in each of its five boroughs as a result of the Board of Estimate's action.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 2 -- Lebanese official circles believed today that the Government had broken the back of the rebel offensives against Tripoli and the Beirut airport.
COLUMBUS, Ga., July 2 (AP) -- A Negro dwelling on the fringe of a white neighborhood was blasted early today. None of the five occupants was hurt.

ATHENS, July 2 -- A Foreign Ministry spokesman said today that the Government would favor a United Nations mandate over Cyprus pending settlement of the dispute over the British Crown colony's future.
AN audience of 6,000 assembled at Lewisohn Stadium last night for an all-Tchaikovsky concert. It was led by Pierre Monteux and had Ruth Slenczynska as the soloist in the B flat minor Piano Concerto.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed that in the week ended Wednesday, June 25, there were:

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 2 -- Any visitor to the Brussels World's Fair today who did not know that the United States had begun its three "national days" was deaf or blind or sealed up in one of the huge globes of the Atomium.
CINCINNATI, July 2 (UPI) Frank Thomas of the Pittsburgh Pirates today was named the National League's player of the month for June.
TRIPOLI, Lebanon, July 2 (UPI) -- Communist-dominated rebel forces in Tripoli's El Mina dock area asked for a ceasefire today. They agreed to Lebanese Army demands to put away their arms.

Indications of a substantial rise in trade this year between the East European Soviet bloc and Latin America, although still short of previous peaks, were noted yesterday in an analysis by the Chase Manhattan Bank.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 2 (UPI) -- Hakuchikara, the champion thoroughbred of Japan, made his American turf debut today at Hollywood Park but finished last among nine horses in the featured Fireworks Show Purse.
Robert Herridge, producer who left WCBS-TV's "Camera Three" for a career in night-time network drama, will return to the scene of his first television success next month.

Russia is producing several of the most advanced forms of plastics and synthetic rubber such as are being developed commercially in the United States and their quality is good, an internationally known polymer scientist reported yesterday.
GOSHEN, N. Y., July 2 (AP) -- Sharpshooter scored two close victories today in the Dickerson Cup test for 3-year-old trotters on the Grand Circuit and at Historic Track.
Custom smelters advanced refined copper prices 1/2 cent a pound, to 26 cents, yesterday in their first price change since June 23, when they announced a 1-cent reduction.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The House minority leader, Representative Joseph W. Martin Jr., predicted today that the bill to provide Federal aid to science education would be passed by the House of Representatives this session.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 2 -- Dr. Clark Kerr, president of the University of California, announced today the establishment of a laboratory of radio astronomy in connection with the Berkeley campus. He said plans for construction of an eighty-five-foot radio telescope at a site still to be selected, were proceeding with all speed.
BONN, Germany, July 2 -- The Bundestag voted a resolution today instructing the Government to request the Big Four to establish a standing group to deal with the problem of Germany's reunification.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census today estimated sales of merchant wholesalers in May at $9,400,000,000. This was 2 per cent above the total in April.
A formal protest was filed yesterday with State Rent Administrator Robert C. Weaver against the reclassification of the Fabian Hotel as a rooming house, making it subject to rent controls.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) -- The House passed and sent to the senate today a bill to limit the effect of the Supreme Court so-called "Mallory" decision. That ruling freed an accused rapist on the ground that the police had improperly question him.
REPRESENTATIVE SAM RAYBURN should earnestly reconsider his ban against television coverage of hearings conducted by committees of the House.

A 21-year-old prisoner at the city penitentiary on Rikers Island was stabbed yesterday and in a second incident a woman correction officer was assaulted by an inmate in the Women's House of Detention at 10 Greenwich Avenue.

Morris L. Ernst said yesterday that "a full-scale Congressional investigation is now necessary in order to get the facts and truth" of the disappearance of Dr. Jesus de Galindez before the American people.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee approved today a money bill of more than $1,159,000,000 for public works programs in the fiscal year that started July 1.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- With the fiscal year less than forty-eight hours old, President Eisenhower looked all the way to next year today and saw prospects of more -- but diminished -- deficit spending.

WHETHER it's a surplus or at scarcity of furniture, women have trouble buying it. During the war they couldn't do much buying, because there wasn't much to buy. Today they often don't buy, because, with so much for sale, they are at war with themselves on which style to pick, according to a recent survey.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- A bill providing for a Congressional inquiry into importation of foreign-made music film track was introduced today by Representative Frank Thompson Jr.

Bernard Gordon, who recently bought two five-story apartment houses at 119-21 West 104th Street from the Afrontos Realty Corporation, has resold them to Max Teichner for investment. The buildings contain twenty-nine apartments and occupy a plot 50 by 100 feet.

MUCH of the fare traditionally associated with Independence Day outings -- food for the grill and the picnic hamper -- is available at persuasive prices this weekend. By far the best city-wide bargain in the meat-and-poultry category is chicken.
DETROIT, July 2 (AP) -- Jim Bunning pitched a four-hitter today to help the Detroit Tigers down the Kansas City Athletics, 5 -- 0.
ALGIERS, July 2 -- Algiers gave General de Gaulle a markedly cool welcome tonight by comparison with the massive, noisy reception accorded to him when he came here a month ago.
GUANTANAMO BAY, Cuba, July 2 -- The Cuban rebels released five kidnapped North Americans today. Those freed included four United States citizens and a Canadian national.
WILTON, Conn., July 2 -- Dr. Theodore B. Reed, retired New York physician, died at his home here today after an illness of several months. He was 69 years old.
Four new films, including a double-bill program, will open today at first-run theatres.

Directors of the Glen Alden Corporation yesterday elected Harry W. Bradbury president to succeed Francis O. Case, who resigned. Mr. Bradbury, executive vice president in charge of coal operations since April 1, was previously president of the Lehigh-Valley Coal Company.
EAST LANSING, Mich., July 2 (AP) -- Charles E. Wilson accepted today chairmanship of the Michigan Advisory Committee to the President's Commission on Civil Rights.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 2 -- Led by Helen Marie Weiland of the Aronimink Country Club, Philadelphia won the girls' junior intercity golf team match over the Knollwood Country Club course today.

Literature and the sun struggled for more than half an hour for the attention of children during a story-telling session in Central Park yesterday. Eventually, narrative power triumphed. But first the story-teller and her audience made a retreat in force. And there were defections, of a sort, among the young listeners.

Just about every member of the maintenance squad at Belmont Park felt like a successful horse owner when the feature face was over yesterday. The winner of the mile race was Wirey-Marks, owned by Mrs. Jules Schwartz, and Mrs. Schwartz is the wife of the man who is in charge of the maintenance squad at the park.
LONDON, July 2 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan accused Premier Khrushchev today of not being really interested in the success of a heads - of - government conference.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Following is the text of Bernard Goldfine's statement tonight issued through Tex McCrary, New York public relations adviser:
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- "You will be great!" were the words penciled in big red letters across the top of Bernard Goldfine's prepared statement as he began testifying at the Capitol this morning.
LONDON, July 2 -- United Nations intervention in Cyprus was urged today by Zenon Rossides, spokesman for Archbishop Makarios, the spiritual and political leader of the Greek Cypriotes.

HENLEY ON THAMES, England, July 2 (UPI) -- Harvard University's lightweight crew and Kent (Conn.) School, the only American entries to see action today as the Royal Henley regatta opened in a drizzling rain, easily won their first heats in the Thames Challenge Cup competition.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 2 -- Nine major administrative changes, designed too accelerate Rutgers University's planning for greatly increased enrollment in the future, were announced today. Dr. Lewis Webster Jones, president of Rutgers, said that the moves, which include the creation of two vice presidents, the office of dean of the university and vice provost, would increase efficiency.

ST. ANNE'S-ON-THE-SEA, England, July 2 (UPI) -- Gene Sarazen, the 56-year-old golfing squire from Germantown, N. Y., sloshed through a torrential rain to shoot a 73 that left him seven strokes behind Peter Thompson's in the first round of the British open championship today.

The swing of New York County Republicans to the support of Nelson A. Rockefeller for Governor attracted wide attention in the state yesterday but failed to touch off any stampede for the newly announced candidate.

THIS ornery varmint stepped into focus on the television screen, lips curled in a sneer and a mean look in his eyes. His holsters were slung low, the obvious mark of a gun-fighter. Here was a villain who could be hated at first sight, an oversize bully who would come to a bad end.

This is the time of year when New Yorkers become acutely aware of air contamination spewed out from apartment house incinerators. There are more than 10,000 of these nuisances in the city and, with windows open much of the time, air pollution becomes a major problem.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads estimated today the net income of Class I railroads in May at $24,000,000, the best showing for any month this year.

MIDLAND, Tex., July 2 (AP) -- Len G. McCormick, former lineman for Washington and Baltimore professional football teams, announced today the purchase of one of the world's largest ranches, the fabulous Fowlkes brothers' tract in Texas Big Bend country.

ELMSFORD, N. Y., July 2 -- Fourteen hundred residents of Greenburgh, the largest town in Westchester, have demanded hearings before the Board of Assessors to object to increases in the assessed valuations of their properties.

Culture was "box office" last night in Central Park -- but it was also free. New Yorkers waited in a quarter-mile-long line as the New York Summer Shakespeare Festival opened its season with a production of "Othello."
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 2 -- The Brazilian Government, deep in a coffee surplus, modified today the new policy for supporting its major crop that was announced last weekend.
The merged labor movement suffered a setback yesterday in its drive to take over some of the territory of the ousted Bakery and Confectionery Workers International Union.
A musical for Broadway with Ann Sheridan supplying the "oomph" is being planned in Hollywood.

The nation's gasoline stocks declined 1,487,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, according to weekly figures issued by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end supplies were 186,486,000 barrels, compared with 187,973,000 a week earlier and 188,523,000 a year ago.
An embarrassing situation in which the Board of Education was forced to deny summer education to thousands of high school students was resolved yesterday.

DRESDEN, Germany, July 2 -- Nine United States soldiers imprisoned by East Germany for twenty-five days complained today that they were being held as political hostages. In a tense news conference put on for them by East Germany, they hooted at contentions that the German Communist regime was a sovereign government.
BAYREUTH, Germany, July 2 -- "Once a prisoner was ordered to be flogged with twenty-five strokes for some offense. Sommer put him on the whipping block and made him count off the strokes.

RANGOON, Burma, July 2 -- Reports today from the majority of jungle insurgent groups fighting against the Government indicated their willingness to accept amnesty terms and surrender as soon as arrangements could be made.
Correction Commissioner Anna M. Kross postponed yesterday until Aug. 1 the effective date of her order losing Rikers Island to self-committed narcotics addicts.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- Senate members of the Congressional Atomic Committee unanimously approved today President Eisenhower's nomination of John A. McCone to be a member of the Atomic Energy Commission.

It is discouraging to read that Correction Commissioner Anna M. Kross has announced that Rikers Island would no longer accept self-committed narcotic addicts for treatment. For those who are concerned with helping the victims of addiction this removes practically the only way of removing the addict from the environment which lies behind his disease.

Six hundred years from now, if the present rate of population increase continues, "the number of human beings on earth will be such that there will be only one square meter for each to live on * * * the one square meter would include Arctic wastes, deserts and mountain tops."
WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower said today that the Federal Government would enforce the law on civil rights issues "as laid down by the Supreme Court procedures."

PARIS, July 2 -- Andre Malraux, Information Minister, said today that the Government would base itself on four principles: true choice and decision; execution of decisions taken; governmental action in continuity, and "neutralization of the Communist party in the domain of national decision."
Former President Herbert Hoover took off yesterday afternoon for the Brussels World Fair where he will be President Eisenhower's personal representative.
Before the release of some of the North Americans yesterday, Fidel Castro was reported to have been preparing to order the freeing of all of them.
A bill to ease restrictions on alien seamen in United States ports has quickly gained the support of American shipyards.

Mr. Arnold has had an imaginative fling with feathers, fabric, and fur. Fur hats have been dyed unconventional colors -- purple, pumpkin and pickle green. Black and white squares of mink sewn together look like a set of dominos in a puffy beret.

BOSTON, July 2 (AP) -- Faye Throneberry, a Boston cast-off, leaned into the Red Sox bullpen to spear Lou Berberet's long drive for the final out today that saved a 5-3 victory for the Washington Senators.

High praise was heaped yesterday upon an East River pilot who kept a burning freighter and a blazing tanker in midstream last Wednesday. The praise came from the pilot of the city fireboat William J. Gaynor.
SAIGON, Vietnam, July 2 -- President Ngo Dinh Diem outlined plans here today for a big expansion in South iVetnam's export earnings.

The election of Streuby L. Drumm as president of the West Penn Power Company, largest subsidiary of the West Penn Electric Company, was announced yesterday by Earle S. Thompson, chairman of both concerns.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Following is the text of statement today by Bernard Goldfine before the Housee Subcommittee on Legislative Oversight:
LOS ANGELES, July 2 -- The June 3 City referendum that approved giving the Los, Angeles Dodgers land for a baseball park, still hasn't become legal.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Bernard Goldfine prepared for his baptism of Congressional fire today with the help of a staff of high-priced lawyers and public relations men who have themselves figured in more than a few Washington controversies.

The first chartered airplane to bring refugees to this country under provisions of the Emergency Refugee Act of last September arrived here yesterday. It carried ninety-nine passengers from Munich, Germany.

Announcement that the Santa Rosa, $25,000,000 newest addition to our merchant marine, would mark July 4 by stopping at Kingston, Jamaica, on its maiden Caribbean cruise reminds us of the many links that exist between the United States and the lovely islands to our south and east.
Richard Berry fenced until the early hours this morning to retain his national epee title at the Hotel Commodore.

Some recession-hit factories in this state are closing a week or two in advance of their regular vacation shutdowns. This became evident yesterday when the State Labor Department announced that applications for basic unemployment insurance benefits had risen by 7,500 last week.

Health insurance companies have won what they consider an important victory. This was the unanimous ruling by the Supreme Court on Monday that the Federal Trade Commission was barred from regulating insurance advertising in states having their own statutes covering the matter.
A Brooklyn woman gave birth to a boy in Jamaica Police Headquarters yesterday after neighbors who were driving her to St. Albans Naval Hospital lost their way in Queens.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- The Joint Committee on Atomic Energy approved a $386,679,000 atomic building program today. This was more than double the $193,000,000 Administration program.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 2 -- More than a million persons welcomed home Brazil's world soccer champions today in the greatest public demonstration in this country's history.

NEW ORLEANS, July 2 (AP) -- United States District Judge J. Skelly Wright struck down today a Louisiana law that gave a special legislative committee authority to reclassify any public school as exclusively white or Negro.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) Following is the transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference:
CHICAGO, July 2 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

HACKENSACK, N. J., July 2 -- Bergen County was $127,000 richer today as a result of ruling late yesterday by the United States District Court of Appeals in Philadelphia. The court held that the money, seized in a gambling raid Oct. 23, 1950, at the home of Leo Link in Teaneck, rightfully belonged to the county.

The board of directors of the Motormen's Benevolent Association voted unanimously last night to suspend relations with the United Transit Employes Council, a coalition of ten small subway unions that are not affiliated with Michael Quill's Transport Workers Union.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly yesterday. The spot month declined 15 points but other months were 7 points higher to 3 points lower than on Tuesday.
CAIRO, July 2 -- A responsible source in Cairo denied today that the United Arab Republic was discriminating against Jews in granting visas or re-entry permits for Egypt and Syria.

Directors of the Nachman Corporation yesterday voted to split the common stock on a two-for-one basis and proposed to increase the authorized shares to 1,000,000 of $5 par, from the present 300,000 shares of $10 par.

Group Health Insurance has announced a possible extension of the wide coverage its subscribers already enjoy. G. H. I. has been a bellwether among nonprofit health insurance plans, feeling its way successfully by trial -- and sometimes error -- into new fields of protection where other agencies have followed. Last time it was care of the teeth, through Group Health Dental Insurance, Inc. This time it is the treatment of nervous and "mental" disorders.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Vito Genovese, reputed "king of the rackets," invoked a Fifth Amendment plea more than 150 times today as a Senate committee accused him of crimes from black marketing to murder.
James R. Hoffa gave the signal yesterday for the biggest organizing campaign undertaken by any union since World War II.
PARIS, June 17 -- The French river fishing season opened last Sunday and today two fish were caught from the banks of the Seine in Paris.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 2 -- Communal trouble between Greek and Turkish Cypriotes flared today in Limassol.

CHICAGO, July 2 -- To meet an expected increase in demand for tin cans, the Inland Steel Company embarked today on an expansion of its tinplate capacity by more than 60 per cent, it announced here today.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, July 2 -- Under the aura of potential statehood, Alaska was being pictured in some quarters today as a modified future. Nevada, with legalized gambling helping to balance the budget of the forty-ninth state.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The United States, in working for the release of Americans held captive abroad, is trying to bring them back alive, President Eisenhower said today.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- President Eisenhower signed legislation today paying the way for a greater exchange of atomic weapons information and materials with friendly nations.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 2 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser arrived today to visit President Tito at a time when the Yugoslav chief of state seems determined to show the Kremlin he has influential friends.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., July 2 -- Long Island's closely knit team of strawberry growers, pickers, auctioneers and shippers will make its final "deal" for the Eastern seaboard's fresh fruit markets Friday, July 4.

THE few galleries remaining open during July are showing paintings and sculpture of greater interest than has been their policy in past summers. Quite sensibly, they realize that New York is visited during this season by many museum officials, on their way to or from Europe, who at other times are unable to be here.

LONDON, Thursday, July 3 (AP) -- The Soviet Union charged today that the United States plane forced down near Soviet Armenia Friday was engaged in reconnoitering and photographing Soviet territory for the United States Strategic Air Command.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -President Eisenhower reiterated today a hands-off attitude toward the struggle among New York Republicans for their party's gubernatorial nomination.

GENEVA, July 2 -- The scientists did the talking at the opening sessions of the technical talks on ways of detecting nuclear explosions, but it was the diplomats who tried to figure out what they had said.
