HAVANA, July 3 -- Pessimism was felt here today regarding the possibility of the early return of the rest of the Americans and Canadians still being held by the rebels in Oriente Province.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- The Commerce and Labor Departments have made public preliminary estimates indicating that the dollar value of new construction put in place rose seasonally last month to nearly $4,400,000,000.

ALBANY, July 3 (AP) -- The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court ordered today the reinstatement of Lee J. Behringer, a Dewey appointee who had been dismissed by Governor Harriman's Democratic Administration.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- House investigators made public today a list of thirty-three past and present Government employes described as the recipients of cash Christmas gifts from Bernard Goldfine, Boston industrialist.

English Electric Company, Ltd., expects to "turn a profit this year or next" on nuclear power reactors, Dr. H. Shull Arms, chief engineer of the company's atomic power division, told a press conference yesterday in the Barclay Hotel.
WASHINGTON, July 3--The United States is prepared to sell atomic submarine engines to France and Britain.

RABAT, Morocco, July 3 -- This country's first oil legislation, designed to attract foreign companies, has been drafted and will be made public in a few days. It will offer liberal long-term concessions, authorized sources said.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 3 -- Official circles seemed more convinced than ever today that barring massive infiltration from Syria the military situation was under control.

Colonial Stores, Inc., which operates 459 supermarkets in eleven states east of the Mississippi, yesterday reported slightly lower earnings in the twenty-four weeks ended June 14 from those in the period last year. Sales, however, were up 2.5 per cent.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 3 -- Southern School News reported today that Southern and border states ended the 1957-58 school year with 770 school districts desegregated and 2,129 still segregated.
LONDON, July 3 (Canadian Press) -- Massey-Ferguson, Ltd., of Toronto announced today that it was making another offer for a block of shares in Standard Motor Company of Coventry, England.

LIBERTY, N. Y., July 3 (AP) -- Rabbi Samuel Turk of New York was re-elected president of the Rabbinical Alliance of America today at the closing session of the organization's sixteenth annual convention.
ALBANY, July 3 -- The state is making plans to put a check on ragweed this summer.

Spear Co., which operates home furnishing stores in this city, has asked its stockholders for written authorization for the board of directors to sell at its discretion any of all of the company's property and assets.
MASSENA, N. Y., July 3 -- The Eisenhower Locks on the St. Lawrence Seaway were placed in use today for the first time.

" The Reluctant Debutante," co-starring Rex Harrison and Kay Kendall, has been scheduled as the next attraction at the Radio City Music Hall, after the current engagement of "Indiscreet." Pandro S. Berman produced the romantic comedy and Vincente Minnelli directed, from an adaptation of a play by William Douglas Howe.

Supreme Court Justice Francis X. Conlon set aside yesterday an order by the city's License Commissioner imposing ten-day suspensions on the licenses of two of the city's biggest theatre ticket agencies.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- The Senate Finance Committee ended its public hearings today on the reciprocal trade extension bill. Its members were still sharply divided over whether to grant President Eisenhower's request for a five-year extension, which the House has approved.
WARSAW, July 3 -- Polish Government buyers in the United States are running into a problem rare in these days of recession: seller resistance.
A PLEASANT thirty-minute variety presentation called "Showroom" arrived last night on Channel 7.

ON Independence Day in the Age of the Atom, New York's pavement is comparatively deserted. Inhabitants stream out of town in endless traffic tides -- in glittering motor cars, in glittering planes, on air-conditioned railroad trains.

Bold Ruler will seek victory in the $75,000 added Suburban Handicap at Belmont Park today with 134 pounds on his back. The task is commonly accepted as a prodigious one for the distance of a mile and a quarter but the expectation seems to be that the Wheatley Stable's colt will carry out the assignment.
More than $1,000,000 was left for medical research in a will filed for probate yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 3 -- Seven writers new to television will contribute stories to "The Naked City" series of half-hour filmed shows about New York. They are due to be introduced Sept. 30 on the American Broadcasting Company network.
A special program featuring three American educators who are surveying Soviet education will be televised on the National Broadcasting Company network from 7:30 to 8 P. M., Friday, July 18.

In estimating the burgeoning of Soviet activity on all the cultural fronts two questions need to be asked: What does this concentration on the arts mean to the Soviet Union and its people? What lessons, if any, do the Soviet approach and accomplishments hold for the United States?
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The Senate rackets committee appeared today to be building a case for a permanent crime commission at the Federal level.

BONN, Germany, July 3 -- The Government-owned Howaldts-Werke concern of Kiel has begun construction of a 65,000-ton tanker for the Greek ship owner, Aristotle S. Onassis, it was reported from Kiel today.

BONN, Germany, July 3 -- Gerhard Martin Sommer was sentenced today to life imprisonment upon conviction of murdering at least twenty-five inmates at the Buchenwald concentration camp fifteen years ago.
BERLIN, July 3 -- The East German press produced a story seemingly designed for domestic propaganda purposes out of an interview with the nine detained Americans.
Invitations have been sent to 100 debutantes who will be presented at the twenty-third annual Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball at the Waldorf-Astoria on Dec. 22.
WIMBLEDON, England, July 3 -- It will be Althea Gibson of America against Angela Mortimer of Britain for the all-England women's tennis championship.

The Thrift Furniture Corporation, tenant in the five-story building at 47-49 West Fourteenth Street for about thirty years, has purchased the property. The parcel is 50 by 103 feet and is assessed at $115,000. It was part of forty-four parcels that once were owned by the Spingler-van Buren Estates, Inc.
MIAMI, Fla., July 3 (AP)--A Federal grand jury indictment of four Miami Beach bankers on charges of misapplying $7,000,000 in bank funds was thrown out today by Federal Judge Seybourn H. Lynn.
After five days of hearings the Coast Guard yesterday recessed indefinitely its investigation into the collision of the Swedish freighter Nebraska and the tanker Empress Bay.

MOSCOW, July 3 -- For a rare fifteen minutes on this Independence Day eve the United States Government had a free microphone to address Soviet citizens any way it liked. It used the opportunity to plead for the free flow of information between East and West.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- Secretary of the Interior Fred A. Seaton insisted today that the Administration's proposed subsidy payments for lead and zinc -- lower than recommended by the Senate Interior Committee -- are high enough to give domestic producers a fair share of the market.

CARACAS, Venezuela, July 3 -- Rear Admiral Wolfgang Larrazabal, provisional President, denied emphatically today that any planes bearing arms for Fidel Castro, the Cuban insurgent leader, had been sent from Venezuela. The President said the report was "completely false."

With the inclusion of a new state in the Union the country is faced with a task which has aroused the curiosity of an increasing number of people for several years: How do we revamp the American flag to reflect an America with more than forty-eight states?

DETROIT, July 3 (AP) -- The auto industry closed nearly 60 per cent of its assembly plants this week, Ward's Automotive Reports said today, reducing indicated car output to 33,840 units. This compares with 92,277 cars last week and 73,682 in the like 1957 week.

Throngs of heat-smitten New Yorkers jammed the city's exits last evening in pursuit of a relaxing Fourth of July week-end. And the Weather Bureau reported a chance of relief today from the heat of the previous three days.
A $6,046,969 contract for paving and utilities on the new instrument runway at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, was let yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.

WHITE PLAINS, July 3 -- Residents and merchants in this city won their fight today against the $35,000,000 "nightmare" shopping and office center that was to have risen on 162 residential acres at outlying Rosedale.
NEW HAVEN, July 3 -- Evidence has been uncovered that a major lake existed 170,000,000 years ago in the vicinity of Branford, Conn., eight miles from the Yale University campus.
AKRON, Ohio, July 3 (AP) -- The $22,000 Rubber City golf tournament turned into a birdie-shooting contest today as forty-five of the 130 starters broke par.

THE H is back in herbs. According to herbalists, the correct pronunciation of the word is herbs, not 'erbs. In addition to public acceptance of this pronunciation, there is currently increased interest in the use of herb seasonings in cooking.
CHICAGO, July 3 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, July 3 (UPI) -- The Army blamed a punctured detonation cap today for the explosion that killed ten persons and injured two others May 22 at a Nike site at Middletown, N. J.

A vice regent of a Manhattan chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution, resigned from the organization yesterday to disassociate herself from its "destructive" causes. "I believe that the members of the D. A. R. are sadly misrepresented by an aggressive minority who have been using it to advance their own political purposes," Mrs. Russell C. Langdon wrote in her letter of resignation.
Operations of the Grancolombiana Line were resumed here yesterday afternoon after it had agreed to deal with Local 153 of the Office Employes International Union.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 3 -- Herbert Hoover arrived today to represent President Eisenhower at the Brussels World's Fair during the United States' national days. He flew here in the President's plane with an official party that included Deputy Under Secretary of State Robert Murphy.
Cotton futures moved 6 points up to 6 off yesterday in slow trading on the New York Cotton Exchange.

AIN AB, Lebanon, July 3 -- Gendarmes and free-firing partisans chased rebel Druses out of Ain Ab again late today after a series of hit-and-run skirmishes along this ridge commanding an approach to Beirut. Ain Ab is five miles from the Beirut airport.
IF the technical disarmament talks in Geneva lead eventually to the beating of atomic weapons into plow-shares, it will be partly the work of a lean-faced scientist whose favorite pastime is plowing.
Following is the text of a letter to Gov. Robert B. Meyner from the presidents of nine railroads operating in New Jersey:
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- An investigation is under way to determine whether the telephones of House members inquiring into relations between Bernard Goldfine and Sherman Adams have been tapped.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (UPI) -- The Senate Republican leader, William F. Knowland, predicted today that the Senate would restore some of the $872,000,000 slashed by the House from President Eisenhower's foreign aid program.

LONDON, July 3 -- The Archbishop of Canterbury, Dr. Geoffrey F. Fisher, opened the ninth Lambeth Conference of Bishops of the worldwide Anglican Communion today with an exhortation for the reunion of "the whole Catholic Church."
GENEVA, July 3 -- The Western scientific delegation prepared today for serious technical discussions on the detection of nuclear explosions with Soviet bloc scientists.
HARTFORD, July 3 -- The World Assembly of the International Congregational Council was told today that the missionary program in South Africa needed "drastic revision."
BOMBS -- or, rather, firecrackers -- bursting in air, and also some rather remarkable fireworks on the stage, were part of the concert last night in Lewisohn Stadium.
TJENTISTE, Yugoslavia, July 3 -- President Tito showed Gamal Abdel Nasser around the battlefield of Sutjeska today.

MOSCOW, July 3--Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev has accepted with some reservations President Eisenhower's plan for a meeting of United States and Soviet technical experts to work out guarantees against surprise attack.
Carnegie Hall will not make way for a red-colored skyscraper. There is even a good possibility that the famous concert hall, built by Andrew Carnegie in 1891, will not be torn down at all.

A Transit Authority deficit? One of the possible reasons causing a constant decline in passenger revenue and the threat to the 15-cent fare may be the hazardous disservice the Transit Authority continues rendering to the public. For instance, the public is subjected to outmoded head-fans in cars, resulting in grave danger to health.
WHITE PLAINS, July 3 -- Because of nine deaths in five weeks on one curve of the Cross County Parkway in Mount Vernon, additional patroling there was ordered today by the Westchester parkway police.
LONDON, July 3 (AP) -- Ingrid Bergman, after two marriages ending in sadness, plans to be married to Lars Schmidt, Swedish theatrical producer, "when it's legally possible."

ALGIERS, July 3 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle proclaimed today a "vast plan" intended to give Algeria its "rightful share" in the progress of France. This plan pro vides for economic expansion, social improvement and political reform.
Thirteen detective commanders from the five boroughs were transferred yesterday in what Deputy Commissioner Walter Arm described as a move to "tighten efficiency in the detective division."
ALBANY, July 3 -- A plan to grant degrees for less than four years of study is under consideration by the State University.
Tony Vincent evened a score with Frank Froehling yesterday. The favorite in the New York State clay-court tennis championship defeated the junior from Coral Gables, Fla., 6 -- 0, 6 -- 0.
LONDON, July 3 -- Trooper John Tedbury of the Life Guards, who broke the rules while on mounted sentry duty, appeared on a charge of disobeying standing orders today before his commanding officer.
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- James R. Hoffa set out today to weld United States transport unions -- land, sea and air -- into a solid front.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission today sent reproving letters to the National Broadcasting Company, the Columbia Broadcasting System and the American Broadcasting Company television networks and to stations WMAL-TV here and KBTV, Denver.
Mrs. Maxine Mitchell of Los Angeles regained the women's national fencing championship last night.
Delays or detours on a number of major routes will affect motorists in the metropolitan area over the Fourth of July week-end.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 3 -- The Hampton Auxiliary of the Association for the Help of Retarded Children will benefit from a fashion show at Herb McCarthy's Bowden Square Restaurant here next Thursday.
GUANTANAMO BAY, Cuba, July 3 -- Raul Castro, a Cuban rebel leader, was reported today to have drafted an apology for the kidnapping of fifty United States and Canadian service men and civilians.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 3 -- Povi Bang-Jensen, a political officer of the United Nations, was dismissed today after his refusal to turn over to the Secretariat testimony he had taken from witnesses on the Hungarian uprising in 1956.
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Bernard Goldfine testified today that he had given checks as Christmas presents to thirty-three past and present White House and Congressional employes.

The international community, which has its headquarters on the East River, lost the services of a universally respected veteran when Dr. Benjamin Cohen of Chile retired this week. Dr. Cohen has served the United Nations in many capacities ever since its origin. He organized the Department of Public Information, moved, as he might put it, by the question, "Why can't peace make headlines?"

WASHINGTON, July 3 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower signed a $1,620,000,000 rivers and harbors authorization bill late today. He praised Congress for eliminating projects that had led him to veto two previous measures.
The Grand Exalted Ruler of the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks placed a marker on the street sign at Elk and Chambers Streets yesterday.

Despite the upcoming holiday week-end, there was little lethargy in Wall Street yesterday. Traders stayed close to their posts and bid prices irregularly higher in active dealings. When the final tally was struck, prices showed a gain for the sixth straight session.

The vast majority of juvenile delinquents stem front less than 1 per cent of the city's families. Equally significant is the fact that the same families contribute overwhelmingly to other social welfare and health problems. Yet for a long time they have stood fast against help of any kind. Suspicious and distrustful, they evince a type of negative resistance.

State and municipal long-term financing totaled $4,401,251,066 during the first half of 1958, a record high for the period. The total was more than 27 1/2 per cent higher than market borrowings for the first half of last year, which totaled $3,447,093,404.
LONDON, July 3 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of the latest letter of Nikita Khrushchev, Soviet Premier, to President Eisenhower, as distributed in English by Tass, official Soviet news agency:
FIRE ISLAND, L. I., July 3 -- Fishing always has been considered a man's sport, with perhaps fifty million devotees, including a handful who take the little women along for the ride.
LONDON, July 3 -- The British Government lifted some restrictions on borrowing today.
Paratroopers of the Eighty-second Airborne Division, past and present, landed in New York yesterday and captured Mayor Wagner.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Seven statistical indicators painted a picture today of a steady economy or a slightly improving one. The unusual bunching of indicators occurred partly because of the holiday tomorrow. The indicators covered unemployment, inventories, retail sales, department store sales, carloadings, factory employment and corporate working capital.
TAMPA, Fla., July 3 (AP) -- A 572-foot oil tanker caught fire tonight. The blaze was extinguished at her Port Tampa City pier.
ELMSFORD, N. Y., July 3 -- Svelte ladies in bright dresses and many gentleman golfers tonight mada an enormous fuss over a spry little pro of 74 called "J. R."

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- President Eisenhower approved today a reallocation of West Coast oil imports for various companies, but left the over-all ceiling unchanged.
This is a gateway cruise. It provides a waterway avenue to subsequent voyages later in the year.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 3 (UPI) -- The Trud Club of Leningrad, stroking rythmically amid lightning and rain, led from the start today and eliminated the University of Washington's eight - oared crew from the Henley Royal Regatta.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The national debt was $276,444,438,345.81 at the end of the fiscal year 1958 -- last Monday night -- the Treasury reported today. That was roughly $6,000,000,000 higher than a year ago.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 3 -- Norman Krasna, playwright and scenarist, is writing a new movie for production by Jerry Wald next year at Twentieth Century-Fox.

Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran said yesterday that "no one can carry a torch more than myself." The 38-year-old monarch divorced Princess Soraya last March because she could not give him a male heir to the throne.
LONDON, July 3 -- The orchestra of the Juilliard School of Music of New York won high praise tonight from newspaper critics and long applause from the audience at the Royal Festival Hall.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 3 (AP) -- Ernie Banks crashed a 380-foot home run over the left-field fence in the eighth inning today for a 4-3 Chicago Cubs victory over the San Francisco Giants.

There are usually good reasons for the designation of a national holiday. Sometimes the occasion celebrates the birth of a leader. More often it commemorates a critical change in the development of a society or a nation. The latter is the case in our observation of July Fourth as "Independence Day." It marks our emergence as a national state and commemorates the Declaration that embodied our ideals.
THIS Fourth of July, with the coming statehood of Alaska one cause for celebration, the subject of sourdough comes to mind.
PHILADELPHIA, July 3 (AP) -- If you wave players through while hunting a lost ball on a golf course, you do so at your own risk.
A BIG wave of zany beach hats has hit our shores this summer. A few are so seriously chic that they can go to lunch at the Pavillon. but most are so laugh-provoking that they serve as party gags.

NEW DELHI, India, July 3 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru declared today that the Hungarian executions had increased tension in the world and had "taken us hack" from that movement that was going on toward liberalization.

This country's tariff quota for 1958 on imported wool fabrics, fixed at 14,200,000 pounds, was declared officially filled yesterday, according to Customs authorities.
Several days before the Fourth of July week-end, Americans had already dipped into their savings for $385,000,000 of spending money, raising money in circulation to $31,358,000,000.

LONDON, July 3 -- The stock market continued to firm up today, helped by the strength shown on Wall Street. The news of the relaxations of borrowing controls came too late to have any real effect on prices, but a firmer tendency was reported in after-hour's dealings, particularly for shares of installment credit companies.

TRENTON, July 3 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner said today that New Jersey's railroads had appealed for a one-year postponement of their 1958 tax bill to ease an "insurmountable burden." The bill totals $18,500,000.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, July 3 -- There was no consternation today among patrons of the Panhandle, the Carousel, the Frisco or eleven other bars and two liquor stores in a two-block stretch of Fourth Avenue here.

ST. ANNE'S-ON-THE-SEA, England, July 3 (AP) -- Gene Sarazen of Germantown, N. Y., earned the right to play in the final thirty-six holes of the British open golf championship today with a second round of 73.

The boarding across a new Times Square stairway to the subway was removed yesterday and a favorite entrance and exit of 5,500 riders was restored to use. It leads directly to the shuttle platform.

The Laclede Gas Company has postponed indefinitely the sale of $10,000,000 of first mortgage bonds scheduled for competitive bidding on July 8.
TEL AVIV, Israel, July 3 -- An Israeli audience tonight acclaimed "The Firstborn," the first Broadway show brought to this country.
A thief on probation was charged yesterday with having hired three men to steal $174,000 in jewels, stealing half the loot from them and then turning his accomplices over to the police.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Tex McCrary checked out of Washington tonight after a day in which Congressional investigators had expressed deep interest in his role as volunteer public-relations adviser to Bernard Goldfine.

Seven teen-aged members of a gang called the "Red Wings," were indicted yesterday on charges of the first-degree murder May 30 of a young Cuban. He was attacked allegedly because of his Spanish origin.
Nine members of a national narcotics ring were convicted of conspiracy yesterday in the sale and distribution of heroin and smoking opium valued at $7,000,000 on the illegal market.

Now that the experts have been confounded who were predicting only a few months ago that Alaskan statehood was dead for the session there has been a new burst of interest in the possibilities of Hawaiian statehood as well.

LOS ANGELES, July 3 (AP)--The second largest crowd in National League history, 66,485, watched a couple of poker-faced pitchers crank out polished victories tonight as Los Angeles and St. Louis split at the Coliseum.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 3 (AP) -- Elmer W. (Doc) Sherwood and William E. Sayer, who once were top advisers in the state administration, were convicted today of conspiring to bribe and bribing state officials in the Indiana highway scandals.
The Emerson Radio and Phonograph Corporation has entered into an agreement to purchase the consumer products division of Allen B. Du Mont Laboratories, Inc. The price exceeds $5,000,000 cash.

The Georgia Pacific Corporation said yesterday that it would ask the United States Supreme Court to review a decision by the Court of Appeals here that the company had infringed on a patent for striated plywood panel held by the United States Plywood Corporation.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 3 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said today that there was no evidence now of "mass infiltration" of men and arms into Lebanon.

The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday suspended the licenses of Bertram T. Grant, a boxing judge, and Herman (Hymie the Mink) Wallman, a manager and second for conduct "detrimental to the interests" of the sport.
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The State Department said tonight that the letter produced by Mr. Malik was an "obvious forgery," "patently absurd," and would be treated with the "scorn it deserves."

WASHINGTON, July 3 (UPI) -- Representative Emanuel Celler. Democrat of Brooklyn, urged the Justice Department today to intervene in the appeal of the Little Rock (Ark.) school integration suspension ruling to show "the interest and concern of the United States in this problem."
TOPEKA, Kan., July 3 (AP) -- Kansas' bumper wheat crop helped send cash prices to their lowest level in fourteen years this week.

WITH the production of "Othello," which opened officially on Wednesday evening, the Shakespeare Festival in Central Park brings us another clearly organized and interesting production.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (UPI) -- Gen. Randolph McC. Pate, commandant of the Marine Corps, warned today that the corps could be divided among a series of unified commands under President Eisenhower's defense reorganization plan.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday, totaled 626,573 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
AACHEN, Germany, July 3 (AP) -- West Germany won the relay jumping event at the European championship horse show today. Individual honors went to Italy's Capt. Raimondo D'Inzeo.
It was hot in Toronto yesterday, and there was confusion among the gas experts. The weather won.

In the opinion of the late Douglas Southall Freeman, biographer of George Washington, the most neglected American of importance during the Revolutionary War period was Henry Knox. North Callahan spent five years in research and writing about Knox and has produced a biography that his publisher, Rinehart, believes will fill the gap.

The Trunkline Gas Company of Houston, Tex., filed yesterday with the Federal Power Commission plans for an $81,500,000 expansion program that would involve an initial increase of 135,000,000 cubic feet capacity a day.

HARTFORD, July 3 -- Unanimous support for the nomination of Chester Bowles as United States Representative in the Second Congressional District was expressed today by top Democratic party leaders from the area. The district comprises the four counties of eastern Connecticut.

The president of the New York Central Railroad named five of his top aides yesterday to discuss with the city the possible integration of the railroad's Park Avenue tunnel with the city's rapid transit system.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (UPI) -- Oklahoma's Gov. Raymond Gary asked Congress today to place strict limits on foreign oil imports to save the economy of his state and the free enterprise system in the United States.

CHICAGO, July 3 (AP) -- Wheat futures prices experienced their usual harvest time slide again today on the Board of Trade. Other grains also were weak as dealers backed away from making any large commitments over the three-day holiday week-end.

The American Civil Liberties Union said yesterday that it would not be proper for Congress to investigate the disappearance of Dr. Jesus de Galindez "unless actual or potential legislation or the failure of the executive and judicial branches to uphold the law is involved."

May I offer through The Times the humanitarian public's sympathy to Mrs. Hinrichsen for the ridicule which now greets her acts of kindness in rescuing forty-six abandoned dogs? BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 3 -- Since the arts program at the Brussels World's Fair is long on highbrow stuff, a boisterous knockabout musical comedy like "Wonderful Town" seemed like a reasonable change of pace.

Fireworks, buffeted about by regulations and restrictions, have lost some of their noise but none of their sparkle. The industry has been experiencing a recession for many years. It is struggling to survive by promoting "safe and sane" fireworks -- those which illuminate without exploding.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 3 -- Duane Hanover, who rapidly is becoming known as "the people's choice" at Roosevelt Raceway, turned in another smashing effort tonight to capture the thirteenth edition of the $25,000 National Pacing Derby.

EL PASO, Tex., July 2 -- Four hundred Government officials, high-ranking officers, industry executives and newspaper representatives left El Paso today, convinced that the missile is here to stay.

BOSTON, July 3 (AP) -- Joe Ginsberg stroked a long pinch single to left field for the deciding run today as Baltimore defeated the Boston Red Sox, 7 -- 5, in fifteen innings.

Cocoa futures were steady early in the session yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange but late selling tumbled prices. Final prices were at or near the lows of the day. Several positions fell almost as much as the 1-cent-a-pound daily limit.

This newspaper concludes today a survey of the condition of the Soviet arts prepared by Howard Taubman after a visit to that country. Mr. Taubman, a veteran student of the arts and particularly of music, was favorably impressed by the great popular interest in the arts, the generous Soviet Government support of the arts and artists, and the like, and reported as much.

JOHN ADAMS of Massachusetts, delegate to the Continental Congress, wrote his wife in July, 1776, that the anniversary of the day American independence was declared "ought to be solemnized with pomp and parade, with shows, games, bells, bonfires and illuminations, from one end of this continent to the other."
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The United States demanded again today that the Soviet Union arrange for the release of nine United States Army men whose helicopter drifted into East Germany June 7.

NEWPORT, R. I., July 3 -- The imposing figure of Duke Ellington dominated the opening program of the fifth annual Newport Jazz Festival tonight.

THERE was a rather distressing squib in the papers the other day that Big John Cannady had been shot through the neck by a disorderly patron at the night club Big John owns in Charleston, S. C. The item said that the one-time center of the New York Football Giants was in "critical" condition.

MILWAUKEE, July 3 (AP) -- With Ed Bouchee contributing a home run in his first National League appearance of the season, the Philadelphia Phils defeated the Milwaukee Braves, 3 -- 1, today at County Stadium. The victory was the 195th of Robin Roberts' pitching career.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- In the highly critical picture of the United States that some Americans have drawn, our many national deficiencies as charged, and as contrasted with Soviet Russian assets, have usually included inability to show our better side to the world.

They make him easy to recognize all over Europe, where, as in the New World, his quaint stories about Don Camillo have given him celebrity. In his new book, however, this humorous whiskerando, Giovanni Guareschi, writes mainly about more melancholy days.

TORONTO, Ont., July 4 -- The Provincial Government of Ontario announced today that charges would be laid against the Northern Ontario Natural Gas Company and its top officers alleging violations of the Provincial Securities and Corporations Acts.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 4 (AP) -- San Francisco rallied for five runs in the ninth inning to post a 6-5 victory over Chicago today, but Dave Hillman of the Cubs beat the Giants, 6 -- 1, in the second game of the double-header.

BERLIN, July 4 (Reuters) -- Three schoolboys were the real culprits last Christmas when the East German police accused Western agents of digging a "spy tunnel" across the border, the West Berlin police said today.

Several musicians will make their debuts at Lewisohn Stadium during the third week of summer concerts, which opens with a Rachmaninoff program Monday evening and will end Saturday with the twenty-seventh annual Gershwin Night.

WASHINGTON July 4 -- The Defense Department has reaffirmed a policy of giving less than honorable discharges to members of the armed forces reserves because of associations or activities that occur after their period of active duty.
John K. Norton has just retired after forty years as a teacher and educational administrator. But he will go right on doing what he has been doing all his life.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., July 4 -- "That-a-way" is east on Long Island for real leather-pounding, Western style horseback riding these days. In Suffolk County it has burgeoned into a major sport and hobby in the last five years.
HONG KONG, June 19 -- Forty men, women and children who might otherwise be starving are making a living on Chan Kung Island, an island regarded as a nonproductive rock five years ago.
PARIS, July 4 (Reuters) -- Stockholders of the Universal Suez Canal Company approved today the final compensation agreement between the company and the United Arab Republic.

CINCINNATI, July 4 (AP) -- Don Dell, a Yale junior from Bethesda, Md., upset Alex Olmedo of Los Angeles in the Tri-State tennis tournament today.

DES MOINES, July 4 (AP) -- The crest of the flood on the Raccoon River -- one of two major Iowa streams now on a rampage -- rolled past the south edge of the Des Moines downtown loop today, but left behind only fairly minor damage.

HONOLULU, July 4 -- Four members of a special bipartisan delegation left for Washington today to press for admission of Hawaii as a state at this session of Congress. The second half of the eight-man group leaves tomorrow.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 4--Mrs. Bixby Andrews of Windymere, Southampton, gave a supper dance tonight at her home on First Neck Lane in honor of her debutante daughter, Miss Susan Bixby Andrews, and Miss Lynn Willing Wanamaker, daughter of Mrs. Patterson Wanamaker of Philadelphia and Southampton, and of Rodman Wanamaker.
Street gangs working for contractors under the jurisdiction of Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack are busy on jobs costing a total of $3,384,356.
TJENTISTE, Yugoslavia, July 4 -- President Tito flung back today all Soviet bloc accusations of heresy and stood firm on Yugoslavia's right to "build socialism" in her own way.

BABYLON, L. I., July 4 -- Ralph Cameron's Runnin' Wild and Charley Dominy's Spod finished one, two today in the Star Class race of the annual three-day week-end regatta of the Babylon Yacht Club.

LIME ROCK, Conn., July 4 -- While driving his Triumph today in a practice run for tomorrow's national sports car races, Harold Hurtley lost control of his car, was tossed on to the track and was immediately killed.
TORONTO, July 4 (Canadian Press) -- Amid the fastest trading in more than two years, speculative mining stocks dominated the stock market today.
New Yorkers who went to the beaches yesterday--and got more than six feet from shore-refreshed themselves in water cooler by several degrees than usual.
GLEN RIDGE, N. J., July 4 -- A drug company executive, his wife, their two children and the man's mother were found dead today of poisoning in an apparent multiple murder-suicide.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -A 56-year-old minister was found hanged today in a high tower of his church in downtown Washington. He had been missing since last Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- Try as it may, the Administration has been unable to accelerate radically the nation's military build-up. This has been the case despite the national outcry for action in the wake of the first Soviet satellite last October.
BONN, Germany, July 4 -- The Bundestag approved the Government's record post-war budget for the fiscal year of 1958-59 today and adjourned for the summer.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 4 -- Under sunny skies and a steady breeze a record fleet of 143 boats took part in the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound regatta off the Larchmont Yacht Club today.
MEXICO CITY, July 4 -- A movement that appears to be a struggle for power in organized labor here has become apparent two days before Mexico's national elections.

TOKYO, June 26 -- Tokyo's most distinguishing landmark is no longer Mount Fuji -- or Fujiyama, as it is called in Japanese, "yama" meaning mountain. The graceful volcano is hidden from city viewers by mist a great deal of the time.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, July 4 -- An occasional contraband firecracker popped in Fairbanks today. But that, except for locked stores and a closed restaurant or two, was about the only clue to the fact that this was a national holiday.

WASHINGTON, July 4--Bernard Goldfine said today that he had had nothing to do with reported attempts to intimidate Congressional investigators or tap their telephones.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 4 (AP) -- Earl Buchholz of St. Louis gained the final round today in the junior boys' division of the Wimbledon tennis championships.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- A new venture in rehabilitating child amputees is being considered by the Children's Bureau in cooperation with the Prosthetics Research Board of the National Academy of Sciences.

ATHENS, July 4 -- Consultations between Greek Cabinet Ministers and senior Ambassadors that have been going on here on the issue of Cyprus is ended tonight. A spokesman said one thing had emerged for certain: There was no immediate prospect of a meeting between Premier Karamanlis and Prime Minister Macmillan.

ST. ANNE'S-ON-THE-SEA, England, July 4 (UPI) -- Peter Thomson of Australia and Dave Thomas of England tied for the British open golf championship today with record 278's for the regulation four rounds. They will meet in a thirty-six-hole play-off tomorrow for the title.

CHICAGO, July 4 (UPI) -The Kansas City Athletics swept a double-header with the Chicago White Sox today. They took the first game, 6 -- 5, on Bob Cerv's two-run pinch homer in the eighth inning and won the second game, 4 -- 3, behind circuit clouts by Harry Simpson and Bill Tuttle.

After adjustment for seasonal variations, department store sales in the Third Federal Reserve District were down 5 per cent from April to May. WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The bonfire has gone out in Anchorage. The bars are doing normal business again in Juneau. In Fairbanks and Seward and Ketchikan the big day is over. Alaska is gradually settling back to normal and now begins the calmer assessment of just what she has achieved by becoming, ninety-one years after the United States purchased her from Russia, the forty-ninth state of the American Union.

IN January, 1956, Ralph Varady escaped for a year to the island of Moorea, near Tahiti, and in "Many Lagoons" he has told the story of the experience. A friend, Capt. Omer Darr, whose schooner, Te Vega, made regular runs between Honolulu and Tahiti, engineered the escape.

CLEVELAND, July 5 (AP) -- Mickey Vernon's two-run homer sparked a five-run first inning surge by the Cleveland Indians that helped beat the Kansas City Athletics, 8 -- 2, tonight in the opener of a two-game series.

CAIRO, July 5 -- With all the bright new Soviet arms, the free spending and the armies of missionaries in various guises, still the most powerful weapon in the hands of President Nasser, the much touted "liberator of Africa and the Middle East," is the radio.
PEIPING, July 5 (Reuters) -The police arrested two more Chinese servants at the British Embassy here today, making a total of five detained in the last week and seven so far this year.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The United States Public Health Service, in a study of almost 200,000 veterans, has found that the death rate among persons who smoke or have smoked is 32 per cent greater than for persons who have never smoked at all.

WHEN Van Cliburn played the Tchaikovsky Piano Concerto in B flat minor with the New York Philharmonic in 1954, there was no doubt of the young man's ability to burn up the keyboard. He tore up and down the piano, dominating the orchestra with a huge and rather raw tone. It was not mature playing, but it was the exciting playing of youth, and it left no doubt about a formidable talent.

IT would seem to be open season for Summer Places. Leslie Waller, in his latest novel, "Phoenix Island," has leveled his sights on a vacation resort and let go with both barrels. His target is an inhabited sandbar within easy train and ferry reach of Madison Avenue, U. S. A., of which it may be said, "any resemblance to any other island, real or imaginary, is indeed a coincidence."

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 5 -- President Juscelino Kubitschek of Brazil has warned that if a conference of Western Hemisphere Governments is held without adequate preparations it "would only dramatize our failure."
A former Government intelligence agent looked to Congress yesterday for a free hand to seek the release of Americans held captive in five countries.
MARY KELLY, a gregarious young woman with dancing green eyes and a cheerful outlook on life, often meets people who tell her what an interesting job she has.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) June 30 -- The United States has completed an ambitious and successful effort here to help another nation develop something besides its economy.
DALLAS, July 5 (AP) -- A long dispute between Braniff International Airways and 2,300 of its clerical and passenger service employes was settled today.
HARTFORD, July 5 -- Protestantism was described today as one of the "principal divisive and disruptive forces" among churchgoers in many communities.

BONN, Germany, July 5 -- The first test of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's popularity since atomic armaments became a national issue in West Germany will come tomorrow in North Rhine-Westphalia, a key state in the Federal Republic.

LONDON, July 5 -- The Soviet Embassy dismissed as "imaginary" today an assertion by a former British airman that he had written the letter in which a supposed United States airman threatened to drop an atomic bomb in the North Sea.

A roomful of electronic equipment on the third floor of a downtown Birmingham, Ala., building is gradually taking over direction of the electric power supply for some 7,000,000 people in Mississippi, Alabama, Georgia and Florida.
The growing New York Public Library system, with branches in Manhattan, the Bronx and Staten Island, will be a branch the richer on Tuesday. A new unit will open in the Bronx.
A spurt in the sale of beverages in which liquor is an ingredient is just around the corner.

IF ever a successful political campaign was patched together with scotch tape, rubber checks and sheer bravado, it was that incredible effort of 1948 when Harry S. Truman upset not only his Republican rival, Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, but virtually the entire massed forces of the nation's press, public opinion pollsters and political experts, including most of those in his own entourage.

" ART does not reproduce the visible; rather, it makes visible." This opening and virtually synoptic comment in the Credo of Paul Klee is not only the most succinct description of twentieth-century art I have come across; it also points directly at what bothers people about modern art who hold by the tenet that art always reproduces the already visible and who fail to discern its philosophic import when it does not.

Foreign aid is a program of Democratic origin that traditionally has been supported by most Democrats in Congress and opposed by most Republicans. Under the Eisenhower Administration, the pattern has shifted somewhat. More Republicans now vote for aid, partly because the President strongly supports it.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 5 -- The chairman of the United Nations Observation Group told newsmen today that the observers considered the situation in Lebanon a "civil war" even if there was foreign influence.

WASHINGTON, July 5--Three prominent Government advisers have prepared charges that the nation's defenses have been badly managed and that Government leaders permit only a few officials to know of the danger to national security. The charges will be made public tomorrow.

A TRIP down the vicious rapids of the Green and Colorado Rivers is no longer considered suicidal, as it once was, but for the uninitiated it still is a severe test of courage and stamina. Properly guided vacationists run some of the rapids of the Green every year, but an extended river trip can be crucial if undertaken without proper equipment and able rivermen.
The national fencing three-weapon team championship yesterday went to a team representing New England.

In the drive to build up sales next fall, retailers will go all out stressing price. The large mail order houses have already let it be known that average prices in their new catalogues are somewhat below those of recent books. And price pressure is building up in the wholesale markets.

Opportunities for textile college graduates are promising and will be increasingly so in the future, according to a survey conducted by Arthur D. Little, Inc., Cambridge, Mass. The industrial research consulting company made the study in behalf of ten leading textile colleges and the National Council for Textile Education.

FAIRS were old when the colonies along the Eastern seaboard of our country were new. Nevertheless, when the idea was transplanted from Europe it took root in fertile soil here and prospered. This year approximately 300 country fairs will take place from Maine to Maryland.

IN the light of the investiture of Gen. Charles de Gaulle as Premier of France and the weighty issues awaiting resolution by the new regime, the cinema's problems do not seem too important. Nevertheless, its practitioners are wondering what De Gaulle will mean to the French film set-up.
HARTFORD, July 5 -- Chester Bowles, former Governor of Connecticut and former Ambassador to India, agreed today to seek the Democratic nomination in the Second Congressional District.

The annual convention of the National Education Association distinguished itself on Friday by unanimously approving a resolution urging everybody to approach the "matter of integration in the public schools with the spirit of fair play, goodwill and respect for law which has always been an outstanding characteristic of the American people."

UNLIKE almost all those who are classified as jazz singers, Billie Holiday is basically neither a blues singer nor that type of singer of popular ballads who is identified as a "pop" singer. She draws from both sources but depends on neither. She is, purely and simply, a jazz singer. Three recently released disks trace the musical path she has followed over the last twenty years.

Last week was one of a striking paradox. The stock market moved steadily higher in the face of lower corporate earnings and some reduced dividends. Even the pre-holiday lethargy, traditional at this time, failed to develop. Trading was surprisingly active.
MOSCOW, July 5 -- The Soviet Government announced tonight that it has taken into consideration the regrets expressed by the United States over the flight of an Air Force plane into Soviet territory.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., July 5 -- What manner of people make a community?

Tony Vincent of Elmhurst, Queens, and Sidney Schwartz of Long Beach, L. I., reached the title round of the New York State tennis championship yesterday. They will meet today at 12:30 P. M. at the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club in Bayside, Queens, on the final program arranged by the co-chairmen, William Bennett and Dr. Arthur Fishl.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 5 (Reuters) -- Politicians wound up their election campaigns today as some sources charged interference by Finland's neighbor, the Soviet Union.
MILAN, Italy, July 5 (AP)--American track stars won six events tonight in a four-nation track and field meet.

GENEVA, July 5 -- In a wood-paneled conference room where League of Nations lawyers once used to argue, scientists from the East and West started meeting this week to lay the technical basis for a possible suspension of atomic testing.
The popularity of wash-and-wear garments is proving a boon to the boys' wear industry. The easy laundering of the garments has encouraged mothers to enlarge boys' wardrobes and purchase style items.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, July 5 (Reuters) -- Government figures on the death toll in the recent Tamil-Sinhalese communal clashes were published here for the first time today. Justice Minister M. W. de Silva told the Senate that the rioting in May and June took "only 158" lives.

Trade observers estimated that the week in retail trade would run up to 15 per cent ahead of the 1957 period, although they conceded that it was difficult to estimate the figure because of the long holiday.

SPORTS writers get as many opportunities to vote as do legislators. Someone is forever sending out ballots, sampling opinion or compiling "all" teams of various descriptions. Not long ago The Sporting News of St. Louis, the baseball weekly, initiated an ambitious project when it polled the Baseball Writers Association on the No. 1 men at each position, a so-called All-Time All-Star team.

LONDON, July 5--Britain's National Health Service was ten years old today. It has become an accepted part of British society. Few of the physicians who originally opposed socialized medicine would abolish it now.

ED SULLIVAN has every reason to derive satisfaction from his presentation last week of the Moiseyev Dance Company of Moscow. Not only was the hour of Russian folk dancing one of the artistic successes of the season but it also proved a smashing popular hit as well.
LOS ANGELES, July 5 -- Three weeks of testimony aimed at blocking the extradition of Andrija Artukovich, a high-ranking Yugoslav official during World War II, ended this week.
Wall Street is a crazy, mixed-up place.
CHICAGO, July 5 -- The Public Administration Service is acting as the midwife at the birth of a new state.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Two Supreme Court decisions this week brought to an end a critical year of litigation over the unyielding problems of racial segregation.

" DEMOCRACY is the worst form of government -save all the other forms." With this judgment, attributed to Sir Winston Churchill, the author of "The Representative Republic" strongly disagrees. He believes that democracy can be really good and writes to protest "against the fallacy that constitutional government is necessarily weak and that it must be on the defensive in the struggle against subversion by either the extreme Right or the extreme Left."
A New York Central fireman was killed last night when a freight train locomotive plowed into a halted caboose at 162d Street along the Hudson River.
WASHINGTON, July 5--Subsurface indications grew today that Sherman Adams might not long retain his post as President Eisenhower's principal aide.

FRANKFURT, Germany, June 20 -- In a remodeled town house on a tree-lined residential street here, thirteen United States diplomats are working at what they sardonically call "the Frankfurt rest cure."

ONE definition of the critic -- it must be one of the most popular ever arrived at; it is certainly one of which a collector of his own work becomes acutely conscious -- is that he is a man who conducts his education in public.

THE story of the local boy who made good in the big city and of the other local boy who stayed home has been told before, but seldom, I think, with quite the verve and depth of James McCague's rural-Indiana version.

The Junior Red Cross of New York City is seeking 1,500 teenagers as summer volunteers for the city's playgrounds, hospitals and other community services. Dr. Frederick C. McLaughlin, director, has made a special appeal to high school students who are finding it difficult to get summer jobs.

TORONTO, July 5 (AP) -Canada qualified today to meet the United States in the final round of the American zone Davis Cup tennis competition next Thursday, Friday and Saturday at the Toronto Cricket, Skating and Curling Club.

SEA CLIFF, L. I., July 5 -Furious II, skippered by Ray Kaufman of the Manhasset Bay Snipe fleet captured both the morning and afternoon races as the Commodore Becker Trophy invitation races opened in Hempstead Harbor today.

QUEBEC, July 5 -- Quebec's biggest political controversy since the Union Nationale government of Premier Maurice Duplessis came to power for the first time twenty-two years ago begins a new phase next week.
More than half of the 1,840 delegates from every state and territory registered here yesterday for the ninety-fourth annual convention of the Grand Lodge, Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks.

There was little surprise last week in Western diplomatic circles when it became known that Wladyslaw Gomulka, the Polish Communist leader had bowed to a Soviet ultimatum and moved to the Moscow-Peiping side of the Communist bloc's dispute with Yugoslavia.

A man who loves to teach and a man who is eager to learn have combined their talents in an $118,000,000 venture -- the Lazard Fund, Inc., Wall Street's newest investment company. The thousands of purchasers of the fund's 8,500,000 shares expect to benefit from the skill this combination is designed to generate.
PISTOIA, Italy, July 5 (AP) -- An American tourist was killed and another gravely injured today when their automobile blew a tire and crashed into a tree.

The onset of vacations has caused a lull in the apparel markets. Orders, however, are still coming in for better dresses. Fall lines have been very well accepted and many stores are planning color promotions.
Hyman B. Cantor, president of the Carter Hotels Operating Corporation, gave the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee an "earful" last week.

ST. ANNE'S-ON-THE-SEA, England, July 5 -- Peter Thomson, a 28-year-old Australian, turned on the pressure on the last nine holes of a thirty-six-hole play-off against Dave Thomas of England today to win his fourth British open title in the last five years.

WARSAW, July 5 -- For the last three unhappy and critical weeks a Communist Poland has been trying desperately to grope through to an understanding of the plans and motivations of the Communist neighbor that dominates life here.

The lower half of Michigan's industrial corridor is getting tired of being near the greatest fresh-water drainage system in the world -- the Great Lakes -- and not having a drop of the water to drink.

MONTREAL -- Her Royal Highness, Princess Margaret, arrives in Canada next Saturday, and the itinerary of her four-week coast-to-coast visit, as announced by the Canadian Government, has been devised to show off the most interesting parts of the country from the point of view of the summer tourist.
ALGIERS, July 5 -- A majority of Algerian Moslems refused today to obey a strike order issued in leaflets and over the Cairo radio by the leadership of the rebel nationalist movement.
MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 5 -- Racing conditions didn't follow the usual pattern during today's Yacht Racing Association competition on Long Island Sound.

The United States Navy Department has announced plans to collect and publish documents relating to the naval and maritime history of the American Revolution. Anyone possessing or knowing of unpublished letters, diaries, reports, ships' logs, and other naval documents for the years 1775-85, is requested to make such material or information available to the Director of Naval History.
ESPERANTO as an international language would have run a very poor second to the much older international tongue of music here in Austria during the annual three-week Vienna Festival.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., July, 5 (AP) -- A 34-year-old Methodist minister finished the national left-handers golf tournament today with 299 for seventy-two holes and immediately disqualified himself for the title if his score should stand up.
A homeless and penniless young stranger in New York gave himself up in remorse yesterday after an unsuccessful attempt at a hold-up. He identified himself as Leroy Ferdie Trumps, 25 years old.
Theatre parties at the Nov. 21 performance of "Marriage-Go-Round" and at "The Flower Drum Song" on Jan. 9 will aid the Henry Street Settlement.
AACHEN, Germany, July 5 (AP) -- Spain won the Grand Prix des Nations team jumping today at the international horse show. The United States team was an unexpected second with Germany third.

" CULTURE" in America is a fighting word. At the mention of the state of American culture people choose up sides, for it is unlikely that there has ever been a nation as concerned about its cultural facade as ours.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 5 (Reuters) -- A British armored car opened fire today on a crowd of villagers, killing two Greek Cypriotes and injuring at least thirteen. Twenty-two British soldiers were injured.

AKRON, Ohio, July 5 (AP) -Art Wall Jr. of Pocono Manor, Pa., scored his third straight sub-par round today, a 68, for a 54-hole card of 200 and a 3-stroke lead in the $22,000 Rubber City open golf tournament.
A program for basic medical research, rather than for research into specific diseases, was announced yesterday by S. Sloan Colt, president of the National Fund for Medical Education.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., July 5 -- Summer residents of the Hamptons are making plans, under the chairmanship of Mrs. Lee Bird of Amagansett, for the second annual Pet Show to benefit the Hampton Animal Shelter.
LOS ANGELES, July 5 (AP) -- Pancho Segura won first-place singles money of $3,000 by beating Ken Rosewall, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 3, in the $15,000 round-robin pro tennis tournament today.

Last week marked the tenth anniversary of the announcement of the transistor, the invention of scientists of the Bell Telephone Laboratories, which heralded what has become known as the "new electronic age."

A conference of experts from the East and West, "to study the possibility of detecting violations of a possible agreement on suspension of nuclear tests," opened last week in Geneva, Switzerland. The conference is being held behind closed doors, but the main problems involved and the difficulties that must be overcome before a reasonably foolproof agreement can be arrived at are generally well known.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 5 -- Harvard University's undefeated lightweight crew, the only American entry to reach a final at the Royal Henley regatta, won the Thames Challenge Cup today by defeating Britain's Thames Rowing Club by three-quarters of a length.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark. -- Sportsmen and vacationists weary of fighting for a few square feet of privacy in so many resort areas might try the inviting solitude and beauty of Lake Ouachita, ten miles northwest of Hot Springs. The lake is the newest in a chain of three artificial reservoirs created on the Oauchita River which are aimed at making southwest Arkansas a popular resort area in years hence.
The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis will make an announcement July 22 on its plans.
ALDEBURGH (locally pronounced Awlburra) is a fishing village and a minor tourist resort on England's east coast, with a population of less than 3,000. Its only hall seats fewer than 300 people.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 5 -- The Wheatley Stable's luck extended to Monmouth Park today when its bay filly Lady Be Good took the thirteenth running of the $24,650 Colleen Stakes. The 13-5 shot scored by three-quarters of a length over the odds-on Lawdy Claudy.

MUCH has been said about the concert opportunities that Europe offers to young American musicians. What is not generally known is that most of the young Americans who go abroad pay for their recitals.

IN 1950, the University of Illinois purchased a collection of papers largely consisting of Elizabeth Barrett Browning's unpublished correspondence. Besides such correspondence, dating from 1838, when Mrs Browning was still Miss Barrett, to 1861, the year of her death, the treasure trove also contained a number of letters by Robert Browning, as well as assorted memorabilia of the Barretts during their years at Hope End, their minaret-crested estate.
THE HAGUE, Netherlands, July 5 (Reuters) -- A new Dutch Guiana Cabinet, headed by S. D. Emanuels as Premier, was announced today in Paramaribo, the capital.

CITY gardeners who missed an early spring start outdoors need not envy their more ambitious neighbors. There still is time to plant the terrace to make it more enjoyable for summer dining and lounging.

PARIS, July 5 (Reuters) -The seven-nation Western European Union Assembly concluded a three-day session today with a resolution calling for regional cooperation in the production of armaments within the wider framework of the Atlantic alliance.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 6 -- For a time this afternoon, it appeared that the 124 skippers in the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound regatta would be sailors with no place to go.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (UPI) -- Calvin Griffith, the President of the Washington Baseball Club, said today he would place before an American League meeting in Baltimore tomorrow a decision by his Board of Directors to look into the possibility of moving the team's franchise.

BABYLON, L. I., July 6 -- A sudden wind shift caught two of the contending craft covering each other on the wrong side today, enabling Wassum, sailed by Bill King and John Snedeker, to capture the Star Class race and take series honors as the three-day invitation regatta of the Babylon Yacht Club ended.

M. Moch, speaking at a Socialist party conference in a Paris suburb, said the danger of such a development had been avoided by the May 27 declaration of General de Gaulle that he was forming "a republican government."

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Government experts now foresee that Federal purchases of goods and services in the fourth quarter of this year will reach an annual rate at least $3,000,000,000 higher than in the second quarter.

Fifty tons of white marble sculpture and blue mosaic will arrive here from Italy in a week to brighten up an old church dingy with city grime. The church is the eighty-two- year - old Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle at Columbus Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.

PITTSBURGH, July 7 -- Steel mills this week can scan order books in an attempt to estimate a hoped-for rebound from last week's holiday lull. Some observers expect July to be the lowest month of the year for output, but a group that looks for a surprise uptrend by the middle of this month is growing.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Pentagon leaders believe that the best tactic for dealing with small wars is to strengthen the allies of the United States so that their own forces are strong enough to deter aggression against them.
