HAVANA, July 6 -- Insistence by the Cuban rebels that Ambassador Smith deal directly with them for the freeing of the remaining American captives is the cause of the delay in the release of the prisoners.
Ed Wynn will be a regular Thursday feature on National Broadcasting Company television next season.

If, at about 2:30 yesterday afternoon at the Stadium someone had dreamed up a curfew -- or something -- that would have halted activities, the Yankees might have been saved from losing to the Red Sox.

BRUSSELS, July 6 (UPI) -- A dozen persons were arrested when policemen charged Flemish demonstrators in front of the French pavilion at the World's Fair tonight. Several thousand demonstrators had massed in front of the pavilion.
The Eighth Armored Division Association yesterday named Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, this year's recipient of its annual award for contributions to world peace.
A visiting clergyman from France said yesterday that "the most dangerous state of soul is fear, for it controls armaments, taxes, war and peace."

LONDON, July 6 (AP) -- The Soviet Union has protested to the United Nations that demonstrations against the Soviet delegation in New York could result in the Soviet Union's being "deprived of taking part in the work of the United Nations.''
CHICAGO, July 6 (AP) -- Wheat futures prices were on their usual harvest-time slide this week, but with the brakes on. Most other grains had their strong moments before finally closing lower.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 6 -- Eddy Jenner with Mist was the Quincy Adams-17 race winner when a combined Eastern Y. R. A. fleet of thirty-nine sailed in five classes off the Indian Harbor Y. C. today.

NEW HOPE, Pa. July 6 -- Daniel Garber, a landscape painter whose works are exhibited in permanent collections of many of the nation's leading galleries, died yesterday after a fall of his home in Lumberville, Pa. His age was 78.

When they last met, eleven years ago, John Foster Dulles was a State Department adviser and General de Gaulle was a statesman more or less in retirement. Mr. Dulles was about 59 years old and General de Gaulle was approaching 57. Now they have met again, Mr. Dulles speaking authoritatively for American foreign policy, General de Gaulle laying down a program for the Fifth French Republic that is still struggling to be born.

New figures released by the Securities and Exchange and Federal Trade Commissions show that profits of manufacturing corporations in the first quarter of 1958 were the lowest, in relation to sales, of the entire post-war period.

LONDON, July 6 -- A farm laborer retracted today his confession that he had sent the Soviet Embassy the letter purporting to be from a United States airman who was going to drop an atomic bomb off the coast of England.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 6 -- Robert N. (Bob) Bavier's thirty-foot sloop, Memory, won the new Commodore Blattmann trophy by placing best in the entire fleet on corrected time in the twenty-seventh Riverside- Stratford Shoal overnight race which ended today.

The New York thoroughbred racing program will transfer to Jamaica today. A session lasting twenty racing days will be presented at the popular course following the Belmont meeting which concluded Saturday.
RHEIMS, France, July 6 (Reuters) -- Musso was rushed to the hospital by helicopter. His skull was fractured and both legs broken.
WASHINGTON, Monday, July 7 (AP) -- Representatives of Mr. Goldfine said early today that one of their suites in a Washington hotel had been planted with secret listening devices.
Plans for an eight-story building to house the Graduate School of Business of Columbia University were announced yesterday. The structure, designed by Moore Hutchins, will cost $5,000,000.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 6 -- In Latin America, coffee is king. But the king is ailing.

THE ECONOMICS OF INTERNATIONAL MIGRATION. 502 pp. Edited by Brinley Thomas. St. Martin's Press, New York. $9. The move from cities to suburbs, the trek of Negroes from South to North, the movement of Puerto Ricans to the mainland probably are the migration trends best known to most Americans.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -Now, on top of everything else, Senator Wayne Morse wants Congress to investigate television music.

SFAX, Tunisia, July 6 -- The French evacuation of Tunisia began in effect here today as about 1,000 French soldiers boarded the chartered freighter L'Aulnes. The ship will sail tomorrow or Tuesday for Algeria.

The Rev. Dr. John M. Krumm, chaiplain of Columbia University, warned yesterday that "many" aspects of the current religious revival were "a threat to the qualities of independence of mind and spirit and of freedom and personal responsibility."

The Chase Manhattan Bank had net operating earnings of $28,176,733 or $2.15 a share, in the first six months of 1958, it reported over the week-end. In the comparable period of 1957, the Chase Manhattan earned $26,764,958, or $2.04 a share, based on the 13,090,000 shares now outstanding.

This past year increasing concern has been expressed both by government officials and by business men about the rising level of Communist economic influence in the free world. To the public discussion of the issues thus raised, the survey printed in this newspaper today adds both perspective and information. Both are needed if we are to meet the Communist economic drive intelligently.
A $2,000,000 elementary school in East Harlem will be named for Ida and Isidor Straus, New York philanthropists who lost their lives when the Titanic sank in 1912.
CLEVELAND, July 6 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians tallied six runs in the fourth inning and defeated the Kansas City Athletics today, 8-5.
MOSCOW, July 6 (UPI) -- The Soviet Union took the lead today in the first round of the world gymnastics championships, beating Japan and Czechoslovakia in the men's compulsory event.

GENEVA, July 6 -- The two most difficult technical problems facing the East-West conference of scientific experts are the detection of atomic explosions deep in the earth and high in the stratosphere.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, July 6 -- This cosmopolis of contrasts -- drive and relaxation, modern buildings and unpainted shacks, numerous bars and many churches -- is determined to keep its place, under statehood, as Alaska's "first city."

WILDWOOD N.J., July 6 -- With the largest holiday crowd in thirty years on hand, the police department at this resort recorded 110 arrests over the week-end. The offenses included assaults on policemen, drunken driving, discarding firecrackers and holding noisy parties in rooming houses.

THE whole thing seemed a trifle implausible. The Chicago Cubs were playing an exhibition game with the Los Angeles Dodgers in Mesa, Ariz., last April. Into this geographical mishmash stepped Del Webb of the New York Yankees as a press box visitor, as much out of place as this reporter. Hence the greeting was one of mutual astonishment, of the what-are-you-doing-here type.
With plans all made for his active participation in the new Broadway season, Roger L. Stevens has started mapping out his production schedule for the season of 1959-60.

WHEN Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman reviewed the Twelfth Regiment in its new armory on dedication night, April 21, 1887, the souvenir program noted that Army engineers had made the fortress -- they called it that -- "impregnable from outside attack."
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 6 -Pro-Government circles rejected today all idea of compromise with the Opposition to end the eight-week civil strife here.

"WONDERFUL WAYS WITH SOUPS" is the name of a new cook-booklet that is available to the public. In its sixty-four pages, handsomely illustrated with color photographs and drawings, are more than 200 suggestions for serving and cooking with canned, condensed and frozen soups.

A panorama of Alaska, presented in picture and text, will be published in a paper-bound edition later this month by Sterling Publishing Company. Entitled "Alaska, the 49th State," the volume describes the region, its history, resources, industries, topography and people.

ESPECIALLY appreciated during the season of high heat and stifling humidity are shops that offer fine prepared foods requiring no effort by the home cook. Such establishments will supply -- at a price, of course -- main dishes or whole dinners to be eaten at home with little or no reheating necessary.
Today is the first day of summer play school for more than 5,000 city children, most of them between the ages of 5 and 10.

A survey by correspondents of The New York Times indicates that the Communist bloc's influence on the economy of the rest of the world rose during the first half of 1958 and promises to increase in the future.

Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that J. Clarence Davies Jr. would become director of the city's Bureau of Real Estate on Aug. 1. He will succeed James Felt, now acting director, who will resume full-time duty as chairman of the City Planning Commission.

Presiding Justice Bernard Botein of the Appellate Division, First Department, has given us good news in reporting that the waiting time for the trial of cases in the Supreme Court in New York County is less than it has been for forty years. There is now practically no delay in any of its calendars except one -- the perennially clogged one of jury trials in personal injury cases.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Criticism of the United States defense program by three Government advisers was broadcast today.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Bernard Goldfine promised through a spokesman today to account "to everyone's satisfaction" for the $776,879 worth of uncashed bank checks that have formed one of the major mysteries in a House investigation of his relations with Government agencies.
The rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Mark's in-the-Bouwerie stepped down from his pulpit yesterday to introduce a new form of religious instruction to his congregation.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -President Eisenhower and three of his grandchildren returned to Washington by motor cavalcade today after a three-day Fourth of July holiday at the Eisenhowers' farm home near Gettysburg.
The Marschalk Pratt division of McCann-Erickson, Inc., is taking over the parent company's office in Dallas, in a continuation of its expansion in the South and Southwest.
JERSEY CITY, July 6 -- A 9-year-old boy told the police here tonight that he had seen his mother shoot and kill his father in their home after a violent argument.
RHEIMS, France, July 6 (AP) -- Luigi Musso, the Italian auto racing ace, died of head injuries suffered when his Ferrari crashed in the Grand Prix de France today. Musso won the race last year.

As a Belgian citizen who has seen the fair at Brussels and has visited several times the American and Russian pavilions I would like to reply to the derogatory criticism of the American tourists on their own pavilion; criticism which finally resulted in the sending of a special Presidential envoy to Brussels.

Former President Herbert Hoover, returning from Belgium yesterday, gave high praise to the United States exhibition at the Brussels World's Fair. He was President Eisenhower's special envoy to the fair.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 6 -- Film rights to a new novel by Romain Gary, "Lady L," have been sold to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer in a deal negotiated by the author's agent, Irving Lazar. Mr. Lazar would not verify a report that the purchase price was about $100,000, but did say the terms involved a percentage of the picture profits.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Congress returns tomorrow from the long Fourth of July weekend to mark time with minor measures as it awaits key action by committees.

Basic differences in driving and traffic conditions between Europe and the United States have cost Renault almost $500,000. The expenditure has been to replace the generator and voltage regulator on the 20,000 French-built Dauphine models exported to the United States in the last several months.
Heavy gains have been recorded thus far this year in eastbound trans-Atlantic steamship travel to Europe.

DWELLERS in a "have" country like the United States, who still believe in the steady advance of their civilization, will find that Germaine Tillion's "Algeria: The Realities"* makes chilling reading. Algeria happens to be numbered among the "have-not" nations, which, as Mlle. Tillion reminds us with cogent statistics, contain three-quarters of the human race.

"OUTLOOK," Chet Huntley's Sunday evening news program over Channel 4, is rapidly becoming established as one of the more provocative half hours on the home screen. Last night it covered the Brussels World's Fair on film, and just possibly the British Broadcasting Corporation may be asking for equal time.

HARTFORD, July 6 -- Leo Flaherty, a Rockville lawyer, announced today that he would carry his fight for the Congressional nomination in Connecticut's Second District to the Democratic convention at Norwich Tuesday night.
LONDON, July 6 -- Despite United Nations doubts, Britain still contends that the United Arab Republic has seriously intervened in Lebanon in support of the uprising against President Camille Chamoun.

CENTRE ISLAND, L. I., July 6 -- Walter S. Gubelmann's Windigo, a seventy-one-and-one-half- foot yawl, today scored its second victory in the three-race competition for the Philip J. Roosevelt Trophy. Windigo had a corrected-time margin of ten minutes and forty-five seconds over H. Irving Pratt's sloop Caper.
MOSCOW, July 6 -- Informed sources here said they expected the Russians to release within twenty-four hours nine United States airmen detained in Transcaucasia since June 27.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -There has been no change in economic relations between the United States and the Soviet Union in the last three years.

Your issue for June 25 contained a story by Edwin L. Dale Jr. on the current Senate Finance Committee investigations. The story included a quotation and some paraphrases from a telephone conversation Mr. Dale had had with me the day before.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 6 -- The man in the press box behind the center court rose with the rest yesterday as Althea Gibson received the ladies' singles trophy from the Duchess of Kent. "If it wasn't for Gibson," he said, "you could count America out of women's tennis entirely."
Three new films are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
BUENOS AIRES, July 4 -The Argentine State Railways has ordered 210 Diesel motor coaches from the Fiat, S. A., in Italy. One hundred and twenty are to be constructed in this country.
Union workers returned to their barley and hop vats last night as four local breweries resumed operations after a twelve-day shutdown.
Our man Randolph (John W., the guardian of the Wood, Field and Stream corner on the sports pages) probably has heard more tall tales about fishing than any person on the staff of this newspaper.
BOSTON, July 6 (AP) -- A general alarm fire on the Boston waterfront destroyed two piers and two warehouses tonight.
The steamship market declined again last week. Activity held at just about the level of the previous week. A slight dip in the rate index was also reported.
The award of two contracts for $1,001,104 to repave part of the Franklin D. Roosevelt (East River) Drive was announced yesterday by Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack.

WASHINGTON July 6 (AP) -- A Senate study said today a wide gap existed between the rights alleged to have been granted to minority groups in the Soviet Union "and the practical application of Soviet nationality policy."

AMSTERDAM, July 6 -- As a result of general curbs on spending last year the Netherlands balance payments again show a considerable surplus. Imports have decreased sharply against much smaller decrease in exports, consumption and investments have declined, tension in the labor market has disappeared and interest rates both in the money and capital markets have dropped.

ZURICH, Switzerland, July 6 -- By far the most significant development last week affecting business on the Zurich Stock Exchange was the abolition of the Libkamark in West Germany as from July 1. This followed the cut in the German bank rate from 3 1/2 to 3 per cent as of June 27.
Plans to study the problem of low-flying planes over Queens have been agreed upon by a newly organized committee representing county civic groups and Government and semi-official air agencies.
A campaign to reduce malicious false alarms of fire was announced yesterday by the Fire Department.
A modernization job that took two and one-half years has transformed the former Wanamaker department store at Broadway and Ninth Street into an office center. The conversion cost about $5,000,000.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 6 -- About 30 per cent of the 2,500,000 persons on the electoral roll voted in the first day of the Finnish elections today. In the 1954 elections about 50 per cent voted in the first day.
In a step-up of city public works construction to help combat the recession, new contracts exceeding $40,000,000 have been awarded in the first half of 1958.
A group of Swiss military leaders arrived here by plane yesterday to look over anti-aircraft guided missiles that may be purchased by the Swiss Government.
Tony Vincent, formerly a sojourner on the Riviera, won the New York State clay court tennis championship yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 6 (AP) -- Larry Jackson hit Jimmy Davenport with a pitch with two out in the ninth inning today, forcing in the winning run as the San Francisco Giants beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 5 -- 4.

PULA, Yugoslavia, July 6 -- The announcement was made here today that Greek Foreign Minister Evangelos Averoff-Tositsas would arrive at Brioni Island Tuesday to confer with President Tito and President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic.

Governor Harriman urged New Yorkers yesterday to have their children vaccinated against polio. He also advised all adults in the state under 40 years of age to get all three shots of the Salk vaccine.

JUDGING by the recent flood of inquiries to this department, many country home owners want to give their city apartment or suburban home some kind of pest-prevention treatment before closing it for summer.
Sabotage yesterday disrupted service of the Brooklyn Borough Gas Company, against which a strike has been under way since last Monday.
Free enterprise is America's best hope in the battle against communism, but complacency can cost us the economic war, Charles Percy, a business executive, said last night on television.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, July 6 -- Ending a thirtyyear self-imposed exile, Dr. Hastings Banda arrived here by plane from London today to take over the leadership of the Nyasaland African National Congress. His avowed aim is to get Nyasaland out of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland.

ROME, July 6 -- Amintore Fanfani has taken over as head of the new Italian Government with an order to all members of his six-day-old Cabinet and their staffs to begin work at 8:30 A. M. He also ordered them to cut their siestas to two hours.
WARSAW, July 6 -- They ran the Polish Derby at Sluzewiec today and except for a small amount of hand kissing, it could have been Jamaica.
LONDON, July 6 -- The Government's relaxation of credit controls gave a fillip to the stock markets at the end of last week.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 6 -- Anti-United States elements here are charging that a forthcoming visit of Secretary of State Dulles is an attempt to "buy" Brazil's goodwill.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 4 -- The United Nations, like the average home owner, has been having housekeeping troubles: Windows stick, the roof leaks in spots and the carpeting needs patching. As for the grass on the First Avenue front lawn, the gardeners are ready to give up and try paving and a row of hedges.

JUNEAU, Alaska, July 7 -Gov. Mike Stepovich is expected to summon Alaskans to a special election on Aug. 26 for acceptance or rejection of Congress' invitation to make this Far North Territory the fortyninth state.
A newly promoted battalion chief of the Fire Department was suspended yesterday for having failed to report a fight between two firemen a week ago Sunday in an Elmhurst, Queens, firehouse.
Walter Florell showed two opposing silhouettes in his new hat collection.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- President Eisenhower approved today the entry of the territory of Alaska as a full-fledged state.
TRENTON, July 7 -- The Appellate Division of the Superior Court ordered the Erie Railroad today to put off Temporarily its plan to discontinue its Jersey City-Manhattan passenger ferry service.
Sales of ACF Industries, Inc., in the fiscal year ended April 30 equaled those of the previous year, but earnings of the diversified industrial manufacturer were lower.
New types of supersonic aircraft, missiles, vertical and short - take - off systems and launching sites and bases with concrete and steel shelters are giving a new look to the Tactical Air Command.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Today's disclosure that a House investigating official had attempted to record a conversation was not the first in the investigation of Federal agencies.

PHILADELPHIA, July 7 -- Striking members of The Philadelphia Inquirer unit of the Newspaper Guild of Greater Philadelphia rejected today a negotiated settlement proposal that would have ended a thirty-seven-day walkout.
HARTFORD, July 7 (UPI) -- The Rev. Dr. Hugh Vernon White told 400 delegates to the International Congregational Council today that "American Christianity is painfully becoming of age."
PARIS, July 7 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle named Jacques Soustelle as Minister of Information tonight. M. Soustelle was one of the prime movers of the May 13 uprising by European settlers in Algiers.
Thirty young women will be introduced to society at the ninth annual Gotham Ball, which will be held Thanksgiving night, Nov. 27, at the Plaza.
Stocks rose yesterday for the eighth successive day in a session marked by wide swings for a handful of issues.

HARTSDALE, N. Y., July 7 -- Sally Wilson of Scarsdale, the defending champion, lead the way through the first round of the New York State girls' tennis tournament at the County Tennis Club today. She defeated Ione Kourides of Forest Hills Queens, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 1.

MONTAUK POINT, L. I., July 7 -- Jerry Ruschmeyer of the Lake View Hotel leaped from a chair and dashed for the kitchen. Nothing was boilling over. Another swordfish had arrived and Ruschmeyer wanted to make sure his chef prepared it properly.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 7 -- A mid-afternoon rainstorm halted first-day play in the women's Eastern clay courts championship at the New Rochelle Tennis Club today. The sun later reappeared but the courts were too wet to continue play.

The State Education Department reported yesterday that eight out of 547 school budgets for 1958-59 had been rejected in school district elections so far reported in the state. All eight are in the New York metropolitan area.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., July 7 -- Mrs. Joseph Nesbitt of the Westchester Country Club captured the medal in the fourteenth Women's Tri-County golf championship by scoring 39, 38--77 at Innis Arden today.

LONDON, July 7 -- Two promising new chemicals now being used experimentally in the detection and treatment of cancer were discussed at the opening sessions of the Seventh International Cancer Congress here today.

William H. Whyte Jr., Commissioners Mark McCloskey and Charles Abrams and others, according to The Times of June 26, recently denounced urban redevelopment projects in New York as "bleak towers" and "box-like buildings, no better than the slums they replaced."

There is something sad in the saga of Bertha, the white whale who was captured in Alaskan waters and who died in an airplane en route to her new home at the Coney Island Aquarium -- something sad and a little frightening too.
The West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company will enter the building products field today with the start of production at its new $1,000,000 flakeboard plant in Tyrone, Pa.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI) -- The House subcommittee investigating Bernard Goldfine's relationship with Federal agencies took on a press representative today.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- The Bell Telephone System asked the Federal Communications Commission today to rescind its June 25 order that private line telephone rates be reduced 15 per cent.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -Baron Ignatius Shacklette, who has made a career of investigating people, likes dogs.

YONKERS, July 7 -- The Tishman Realty and Construction Company of New York reported today the beginning of a multimillion-dollar department store here for S. Klein of New York. The construction is on a twenty-seven-acre site beside Central Park Avenue, near the Greenburgh boundary.
Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter called yesterday for drastic modification of the state's adoption laws.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 7 (Reuters) -- Government troops launched an assault today on Benau, the last remaining town held by Indonesian rebel forces in central Celebes.

THE "country look," with its comfortable, cheerful simplicity, creates an easy-to-care-fee background for today's relased living. This informal style has grown so in popularity that it now influences the decor of only the summer cottage, out also the year-round home, be it in New York City or suburbia.

As one who feels increasingly the value and necessity of the public school system in a free society I was pleased with your emphasis on June 29 upon the need of the "qualitative as well as quantitative" approach to our basic educational problems as reflected in the Rockefeller Brothers Fund report.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 7 -- The four Moslem countries of the Baghdad Pact are reported to have pledged their support to President Camille Chamoun of Lebanon in his fight against rebel efforts to force him to resign.
Exploitation of video tape or new quick kinescope recording processes was still further increased yesterday by the Columbia Broadcasting System and the National Broadcasting Company networks.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 7 (AP) -- The final contracts for the San Francisco Giants' $15,000,000 stadium project won the approval of the Board of Supervisors today by a 7-2 vote.

WHITE PLAINS, July 7 -- Westchester officials indicated today that the County Parkway Authority might not be able financially to proceed with its assigned task of rebuilding the Bronx-to-Connecticut parkways.

There is an obvious lesson to be drawn from the different receptions given by Venezuelans in Caracas to Vice President Nixon in May and to Representative Charles O. Porter of Oregon, who is there now. Mr. Nixon, it will be recalled, was stoned and spat upon. Mr. Porter has had cheering crowds and warm friendliness.
Elfrida von Nardroff's string of record-breaking television quiz show winnings ran out last night.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The annual legislative battle over housing began to build up steam today.
The dismissal of an indictment charging Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. with income tax evasion was urged yesterday because of "irregularities" described as "criminal in nature."

A month before Joyce Cary's death last year the complete manuscript of his new book "Art and Reality" arrived at Harper's, his publisher. It is based in part on lectures prepared for delivery at Clare College, Cambridge.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- For the odorous atmosphere enveloping the House subcommittee investigation into the affairs of Bernard Goldfine where they impinge on the conduct of government, and sordid incidents in the course of this inquiry, a historian could produce parallels. The fact that these are few may be consoling.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- President Eisenhower conferred at length with Secretary of State Dulles today on means of correcting the "erosion" of United States-Canadian relations. This was in preparation for their three-day visit to Ottawa, beginning early tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The chief investigator of a Congressional subcommittee resigned tonight after he had been caught using a microphone in a hotel room to get evidence on Bernard Goldfine.

SALLY VICTOR'S fall hat collection makes the most of a good profile. Her fall hats, draped and shaped magnificently, sit high on the head or are in the form of a bonnet, throwing the profile in sharp relief. Others sit well off the brow with a definite backward slant. Some of these are molded into fullness at the neck like a chignon hairdo.

LONDON, July 7 -- Air Vice Marshal D. C. T. Bennett of the Royal Air Force, commander of the Pathfinder planes in World War II, asserts that the late Prof. Ernst Heinkel, German aircraft designer, told him of a German plan to cooperate with the Soviet Union to conquer the world.
OTTAWA, July 7 -- Important talks -- and some high-level golf -- are expected to take place here during President Eisenhower's three-day visit to Canada's capital, starting tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The United States efforts to bring about release of nine United States Army men held in East Germany appear to have reached a dead end.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI) -- The Government plans to step up its campaign to warn the public of the dangers of excessive cigarette smoking, Surgeon General Leroy E. Burney said today.

Ancients and the Fourth The Fourth is well over now, but the ancients still are muttering. It has passed into history, the page has been turned, but those tiresome, elderly voices drone on. There is, of course, a slight change in the substance of their remarks.

SUDSBURY, Ont., July 7 (Canadian Press) -- Another curtailment in nickel production, effective next week was announced today by the International Nickel Company. It will reduce Inco's production to a rate of about 200,000,000 pounds a year.

WASHINGTON, July 7(AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission said today it had reached final agreement on a contract with the Rural Electric Cooperative Power Association of Elk River, Minn., for operation of a demonstration nuclear power plant.
New York City's newest bowling establishment, Victory Lanes in Bayside, Queens, opened last night.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI) -- The Navy revealed the embryo of an electronic computer today that it expects will be able to walk, talk, see, write, reproduce itself and be conscious of its existence.

Chancellor Adenauer's policy of making Germany a bulwark of North Atlantic defense by arming it with nuclear weapons has won another resounding victory. In a local election that was in effect a plebiscite involving 30 per cent of the West German population the Chancellor's Christian Democratic Union carried the state of North Rhine-Westphalia by an absolute popular and parliamentary majority even larger than their average score in the national election last year.
GUANTANAMO BAY, Cuba, July 7 -- A United States Navy helicopter brought out three more American civilians released by the Cuban rebels today.

The Institute of World Affairs, Inc., will benefit from the Oct. 21 performance of "A Touch of the Poet," starring Helen Hayes and Erie Port_man. .The Eugene O'Neill play is scheduled to open at the Helen Hayes Theatre on Oct. 2.

Stock traders had a much better than even chance of making a profit in the period April through June. The New York Stock Exchange reports that in that time, 882 common stocks advanced in price, 179 declined and twenty-nine showed no net change.

CHICAGO, July 7 (AP) -- Wheat futures worked slowly and steadily higher today on the Board of Trade while other grains and soybeans held within fractions of a cent of the previous closes, some higher, some lower.
The Democratic state chairman declared yesterday that Republican leaders had settled on Nelson A. Rockefeller as their candidate for Governor.

Several producers are studying a new script by Arch Oboler with the idea of optioning it for Broadway presentation next spring. Particularly interested in obtaining the rights are Elaine Perry and Saint Subber.

BALTIMORE, July 7 -- The unhappy head of the Washington Senators, Calvin Griffith, who had indicated yesterday he was interested in shifting his franchise, made no request to do so at the American League meeting today.
Vandals broke into the garage and service department of the Clark Equipment Company over the holiday week-end and did about $25,000 worth of damage.

Since sports heroes have traditionally attributed their success to such things as clean-living and breakfast cereal, it is refreshing, for a change, to talk to Judy Frank, a golf champion, who says she keeps late hours, smokes excessively and takes a drink from time to time.

AN era in television ended unexpectedly last night: "See It Now," one of the medium's most distinguished programs, gave its final performance. A seven-year run, not just another season of TV came to a close.

Any thoughts about running advertising ideas up a totem pole, instead of the proverbial flag pole, are premature. However, now that Alaska is on the threshod of statehood, ad and marketing executives are showing increasing interest in the area.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas predicted today that Congress would pass foreign aid, reciprocal trade and defense reorganization bills generally satisfactory to the Administration before adjourning "some time in August."

BALTIMORE, July 7 -- Once upon a time there was a baseball team known as the Brooklyn Dodgers. Even those fans who have short memories probably will recall them. They operated in a cute little ball park known as Ebbets Field. When the Brooks were at their youthful best, they were the scourge of the National League, so loaded with right-handed hitting power that no manager dared use a left-handed pitcher against them.

The second annual International Festival of Children's Films will get under way tomorrow at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue between 103d and 104th Streets. The screenings will include the showing of twenty-five films from nine nations on successive Wednesdays and Thursdays.
UNITED NATIONS, July 7 -Nationalists who demonstrate against the presence of foreign troops in their countries may regret it when the troopships sail.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today to give the Government "clear statutory authority" to refuse passports to known Communists and those subject to Communist party discipline, domination or control.

Vito Genovese, reputed head of the Mafia, was arrested last night on a charge of conspiring to import and sell narcotics. At the same time, Vincent L. Gigante was arrested on a similar charge growing out of a sealed indictment handed up yesterday by a Federal grand jury.
Steel production is scheduled to improve this week from last week's low level, which reflected a holiday curtailment, the beginning of plant-wide vacations and a decline in orders.

CHICAGO, July 7 (AP) -- The defending champion, Don Essig, shot a 71 to tie a sales representative and a park district employe for the first-round qualifying lead today in the national public links golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- Sky observers were alerted today to an increase in solar activity.
PULA, Yugoslavia, July 7 -- Greece's Foreign Minister, Evangelos Averoff-Tositsas, arrived in Yugoslavia today en route to talks on Brioni Island with his Yugoslav and Egyptian counterparts.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 7 -- Dr. Charles Malik, Foreign Minister of Lebanon, said today that his Government took "strong exception" to the first report by the United Nations Observation Group in Lebanon.

When Steever and Rosemary Oldden decided to go to Europe three years ago, they didn't leave their home, they took it with them. Or, rather, they went in it, because the Olddens' home is a trim thirty-eight-foot ketch
CHICAGO, July 7 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock market here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

BALTIMORE, July 7 -- Fred Haney, the manager of the National League team, sprang a surprise today by naming a lefthander, Warren Spahn of the Milwaukee Braves, to start against the American League tomorrow in major league baseball's twenty-fifth All-Star game.

BENNO MOISEIWITSCH, Russo - British pianist, played at the Lewisohn Stadium for the first time last night. The program in which he made his debut there was devoted to Rachmaninoff. Thomas Scherman led the Stadium Symphony Orchestra, and the event attracted 5,500 persons.

The four New York players representing the United States in the fifth annual international students' chess matches at Varna, Bulgaria, made a promising start yesterday. They won two of their four games from Albania, according to a report received through Bulgarian news sources.
The stuff of which privateering is made does not respect normal sleeping hours, Lyle H. Munson discovered yesterday.
CLEVELAND, July 7 -- President Eisenhower was urged today to make himself "unmistakably clear" in favor of the Supreme Court's decree banning racial segregation in public schools.

Thirteen years after the Japanese surrender Peiping's Communist regime has announced that it has again suspended the repatriation of Japanese nationals from mainland China. The reason given is that Peiping does not like the "hostile" attitude of Japanese Premier Kishi. The same reason was given, a few weeks ago, when Peiping broke off negotiations with private Japanese associations in the field of trade.

Railroad labor indicated little enthusiasm yesterday for James R. Hoffa's proposal to weld all transportation unions into a solid front Guy L. Brown, grand chief engineer of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers, prepared a personal message to the 70,000 members of his union disapproving the project.

TRENTON, July 7 -- An anti-discrimination group today urged Gov. Robert B. Meyner to take fast action to prevent William J. Levitt from excluding Negroes from his proposed 15,000-home development in Burlington County.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- The Internal Revenue Service said today that it would drop a legal battle against municipal ordinances that take advantage of a loophole in Federal laws covering police subsistence allowances.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today altered the import quota for long-staple cotton to meet a recommendation of the Tariff Commission.
MEXICO CITY, July 7 -- Adolfo Lopez Mateos, candidate of the Administration's Institutional Revolutionary party, has been elected Mexico's next President.

ALBANY, July 7 -- The state's colleges and universities graduated a record number of qualified teachers last month, but not enough to fill all the public school teaching jobs that will be vacant in the state next fall.

Some 280 scientific reports will be presented at the Fifth World Petroleum Congress in New York City next year. Eger V. Murphree, president of Esso Research and Engineering Company and chairman of the policy-making body of the Congress, recently held a two-day meeting in Vienna, Austria, made the announcement there yesterday.

Marine Midland Corporation, New York State bank holding company, reported yesterday consolidated net operating earnings of $7,298,003 or 85 cents a share for the first six months of 1958. This was based on the 8,549,772 common shares outstanding and after payment of $229,175 in preferred dividends.
Power failure stalled two BMT local trains and stranded 310 sweltering passengers yesterday afternoon in the Montague Street tube under the East River.
MOSCOW, July 7 -- The Soviet Union announced today it had released nine United States airmen detained for ten days after their unarmed transport had been forced down on Soviet territory.
BALTIMORE, July 7 -- Mayor Wagner may not regain a National League club for New York soon, but today at least he finally made the maximum effort to do so. To some degree, he obtained results.
A Federal judge yesterday ordered the International Brotherhood of Teamsters to pay $210,000 in legal fees to three attorneys for rank-and-file critics of James R. Hoffa, the union's president.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 7 -- The Staff Committee of the United Nations considered today a plea for assistance from Povl Bang-Jensen, a senior political officer who was dismissed last Thursday for "grave misconduct."
COLOMBO, Ceylon, July 7 (Reuters) -- The government restored today powers of arrest without warrant to troops and the police -- two days after the emergency measures had been lifted.
An intensive Democratic campaign to stimulate registration in New York City for this fall's state election came to light yesterday.
Political unrest is plaguing the regime of President Francois Duvalier in Haiti, according to information reaching The New York Times yesterday.
The Urban League of Greater New York is encouraging Negroes to apply for housing in areas of this city where they have been unable up to now to rent apartments or buy homes.

Post Office officials in the metropolitan area reported yesterday that they had the stamp problem licked. They view with equanimity the difficulties involved in the postal rate changes effective Aug. 1.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 7 -- John Patrick will prepare the screen adaptation of the William. Inge play, "The Dark at the Top of the Stairs," for Warner Brothers.

The Securities and Exchange Commission filed an action in Federal District Court here yesterday against Russel McPhail, president of the McPhail Candy Corporation, and his uncles J. Marion Martin, vice president, and Dan McL. Martin, secretary.

NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., July 7 -- Six painters, their brushes dipped in turquoise and white, set to work this morning on the Long Island Rail Road Station here. The painters are employed by the L. I. R. R., but the colors they are using -- like those to be used in twenty-five other stations -- are the community's choice.

The first Soviet student group to visit the United States since World War II arrived yesterday for a month's tour. The group included nineteen students in Soviet higher edu cational institutions and Yevgeny Bugrov, a 35-year-old professional youth official.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- The Senate passed and sent to the House today a bill to restore a program of Government assistance for strategic metals and minerals.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 7 (AP) -- The nine United States airmen freed by the Soviet Union today were brought to Teheran by car and plane for a brief rest, bath and dinner before taking off for Wiesbaden, Germany. There they will report directly to United States Air Force European headquarters.

In the six months since it convened, the second session of the Eighty-fifth Congress has passed or made major progress on a number of important bills -- more than seemed likely only a few weeks ago. It still has a formidable schedule before it if it is to adjourn with honor a few weeks hence.
YONKERS, July 7 -- The police are looking for a would-be burglar who, until 3 o'clock this morning, owned a pair of green suede shoes, size 9.

UNTIL recently, most Northerners' only acquaintance with mangoes was in India's famous chutneys for which the fruit is an important ingredient. But now, thanks to shipments of the fresh variety from Cuba, Puerto Rico and Florida, mangoes are readily available to New Yorkers in summer.
BALTIMORE, July 7 (AP) -Baltimore's two taxes on advertising and advertisers were declared unconstitutional today in their first legal test.

Horace R. Wisely, a business man of Salinas, Calif., was eledt' led yesterday as Grand Exalted Ruler of the Benevolent and Proctive Order of Elks. He succeeds H. L. Blackledge, a lawyer, of Kearney, Neb.
The 981-mile-long Ohio River handled what the customarily staid Army Corps of Engineers described as a "whopping" 81,567,152 tons of commerce last year.
LONDON, July 7 -- The stock market opened the week on a fairly confident note and there were more rises than falls on balance.

BONN, Germany, July 7 -- Political observers agreed today that the Socialist "campaign against atomic death" had backfired into a massive victory for Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Christian Democratic Union in yesterday's key state election.
Eddie Arcaro won four races on Jamaica's opening-day program yesterday, including the featured Liberty Belle. It was the first time this season a rider in New York had won four in one day.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- A burgled closet, shoes that moved, a woman's scream, a seized "bug" -- these were a few of the elements that made up a bizarre forty-eight hours at the Sheraton-Carlton Hotel.

LIMA, Peru June 26 -- A joint mission of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the Food and Agricultural Organization of the United Nations is studying the agricultural resources of Peru. The study seeks to find ways through which future development can meet the requirements of an expanding, well-balanced economy.
LONDON, July 7 -- George Ward, Secretary for Air, told the House of Commons today that normal precautions against the unauthorized dropping of atomic bombs were entirely adequate.
Local governments announced plans yesterday for more than $54,000,000 in school, water and improvement financing within the next month.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) President Eisenhower signed today a bill requiring manufacturers' price tags on new automobiles.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Organized business set out today to bottle up the Senate-approved Kennedy-Ives bill for labor reform.
Safeway Stores, Inc., the nation's second largest food Chain, realized a 7 per cent increase in earnings in the half-year on a sales gain of 4 per cent above the similar period last year.
BOSTON, July 7 -- All of Bernard Goldfine's Massachusetts tax affairs are being checked, Joseph P. Healey, State Tax Commissioner, said today.

The Board of Health is considering an experimental authorization for the sale of undated milk on Staten Island. The move, sought by the milk industry, would represent the first break in the city's long resistance to any relaxation of present rules requiring that milk containers be dated.
A new recreation center for British merchant seamen in the Port of New York will be opened Thursday.

"IF this were an entirely accurate account of my life in Cork," the author of "Mrs. O' "* tells us, "I should probably be writing it behind bars. So I should say that it is impressionistically true when not always factually so."

You repeatedly refer to persons in the South who oppose integration as the minority mob. We are not the minority nor are we a mob. Our majority is so large that it would be political suicide for any candidate for public office to favor integration. Our ranks include men in all walks of life and, to your surprise, the majority of the Negroes.
LONDON, July 7 (Reuters) -- Arthur Milton, England's opening batsman, today hit a century in his first test innings.
The Alan Wood Steel Company dropped its plan to increase prices yesterday.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 7 (Reuters) -- Many European Governments have protested American shipping policy measures that reserve the shipment of certain goods to vessels flying the American flag, it was announced today.
DETROIT, July 7 (AP) -- Many auto assembly plants, idle for varying periods last week, resumed operations today.

A syndicate jointly managed by Lehman Brothers, Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith and Reinholdt Gardner is today offering 320,000 shares of $25 par 5 per cent preferred stock of Laclede Gas Company today at par and accrued dividends.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday moved 1 point off to 14 points above the level of last Thursday.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's message to Congress on passport legislation:

Consolidation of The First-Mechanics National Bank of Trenton and The Trenton Banking Company, first and third largest banks in the New Jersey capital, has been approved by directors of both institutions. The bank is to be known as the First Trenton National Bank.

Commercial production of polypropylene yarn has been started by Reeves Brothers, Inc., textile manufacturer, at its Fairmont Mill, Clevedale, S. C., it has been announced by John H. Karrh, managing director of the company's plastics division. The plant was established some years ago for polyethelene products.

IT'S not too late to shop for playclothes. Women who feel that their summer wardrobes need reinforcements right away can still be accommodated. There is a choice of shorts, play-suits and shirts, and here are a few of the sources:
Willie Dockery, a Brooklyn Sanitation Department employe, gained a surprise ten-round split decision over George Benton of Philadelphia last night.

Work on components for the nuclear power station of Consolidated Edison Company of New York is progressing satisfactorily in manufacturing plants around the country and at the Buchanan, N. Y., site, spokesmen indicated yesterday.
The New Haven Railroad contended yesterday that its passengers had adequate ways of reaching its Mount Vernon station.

MOSCOW, July 7 (AP) -- The Soviet Union took a commanding lead in the Women's compulsory exercises in the world gymnastic championships today with Rumania second and Japan third on the basis of incomplete results.

TOKYO, July 6 -- The police opened a drive yesterday against increasing gangsterism and teen-age delinquency in Tokyo, the world's second largest city. Two hundred eighty policemen searched one of Tokyo's principal amusement neighborhoods from 8 o'clock in the morning till last midnight.

Coffee futures fell sharply yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The market was influenced by reports that offerings of Brazilian coffee increased. Prices were 1/2 to 3 cents a pound lower than on Thursday.
Henri Salaun of Boston heads the rankings of the United States Squash Racquets Association for the season of 1957-58. He won the national amateur championship for the third time this year.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 7 -- The strangest exhibit at the Brussels World's Fair is intended to be a poem of the electronic age. It is the pavilion of Philips, one of the great European electronic companies.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission said today the Houston Corporation of St. Petersburg, Fla., was seeking registration of $36,188,000 of ten-year subordinated debentures and 1,809,400 shares of $1 par common stock.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Average wholesale prices in primary markets rose 0.1 per cent to 119.2 per cent of their 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
Poor weather over most of the East on Sunday held the traffic toll over the long Independence Day week-end below the pre-holiday estimate.

CONSUMERS may think they are alone in their concern for the wearing qualities of clothing, but they have company. Scientists, too, worry about the durability of fabrics and, in their research laboratories, are in a position to do something about it.

MONTREAL, July 7 (AP) -- Joseph Ungar, a Hungarian immigrant who remaried here five years ago believing his first wife had died in a Nazi gas chamber, apparently has decided to remain with his second wife, his lawyer said today.
GENEVA, July 7 -- Western and Soviet bloc scientific delegations approached common conclusions today on the feasibility of detecting atomic explosions by acoustical methods.
Prince Mohammad Daud, Premier of Afghanistan, was a guest yesterday afternoon at Columbia University.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 7 -- The Little River Farm's Easter Dawn, driven by Johnny Edmunds, rushed forward in the final sixteenth to gain a head decision over Lew Burton in the featured pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
CLEVELAND, July 7 -- Architects and manufacturers of building materials were urged today to strive for closer coordination in product design.
An agreement for a large gold dredging operation in the Bolivian Andes, requiring a corporate investment of about $3,000,000, was announced yesterday by the South American Gold Platinum Company.

Purchase of Kilgo Motor Freight, Inc., by Paul L. Andrews from Mr. and Mrs. John Kilgo of Charlotte, N, C., was announced yesterday. It was a stock transaction, but details were not disclosed. Kilgo Motor Freight operates 135 truck-trailer units and his terminals, in Charlotte, N. C., Charleston, Florence, Greenville and Darlington, S. C., Jersey City, Philadelphia, Baltimore, Md. and New York.
MONTAUK POINT, L. I., July 8 -- Charter-boat fishing is like poker, golf or shopping with the wife: It sometimes causes men to do and say strange things.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., July 8 -- A day's inspection, on the ground and in the air, of the new Daytona Beach International Speedway leaves the impression that this can be the finest automobile racing plant in America.

BALTIMORE, July 8 -- As soon as Casey Stengel got his firing machinery to stop sputtering, the American League rocket left the launching pad in Memorial Stadium today and went whooshing off into outer space. One minor adjustment did it, a mere jerk of the thumb. It was in the second inning that the great scientific brain of the Yankee manager made an important calculation.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 8 -- Del Miller, now serving a fifteen-day suspension for driving "in a manner inconsistent with an attempt to win," was cleared of all suspicion of dishonesty today by George P. Monaghan, New York State Commissioner of Harness Racing.
ALBANY, July 8 -- The State Education Commissioner reserved decision today on a move to prevent the Yonkers Board of Education from putting one of its high schools on double session in September.
LONDON, July 8 (Reuters) -- Britain sweated out a nervous hour today.
ORLANDO, Fla., July 8 (AP) -Federal attorneys sought today to develop a case against two lawmen accused of violating the civil rights of two escaped Negro convicts at the time of their recapture.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Congress reacted angrily today to news that the unarmed United States plane had been shot down by Soviet jet fighter planes.

WHITE PLAINS, July 8 -There will be four major contests for Westchester County political party nominations in the Aug. 12 primaries. This was disclosed today with the final filing of petitions. Three contests will be among Republicans; one concerns Democrats.

Today's new film is "A Time to Love and a Time to Die," Universal - International's version of Eric Maria Remarque's novel. The war drama will have a dual opening at the Mayfair, Broadway and Forty-seventh Street, and the Little Carnegie, 146 West Fifty-seventh Street.

Directors of the New York Central Railroad voted yesterday to omit the quarterly dividend the third time this year. The closing price of 16 1/2 on the New York Stock Exchange was unchanged from the day before.
CHICAGO, July 8 (AP) -- The defending champion, Don Essig, matching par 73 with the help of two eagles, today won the medal in the national public links golf tournament with a 36-hole total of 144.
PARIS, July 8 -- Former Premier Georges Bidault said today that the heart of his new political movement, Christian Democracy of France, was the belief that Algeria must remain French.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI) -- Robert Garner, president of the International Finance Corporation, predicted today a substantial increase in the movement of foreign investment capital to Latin America in the next two years.

A group managed jointly by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Kidder, Peabody Co. and White, Weld Co. is offering today $30,000,000 of Northern States Power Company 4 per cent first mortgage bonds, due in 1988, at par.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Active Communists and persons who might "seriously impair the conduct of foreign relations" of the United States could be denied passports under a bill sent to Congress today by the Administration.
CLEVELAND, Ohio, July 8 -An appeal was made today to support the Negro's fight to end racial discrimination and segregation.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 8 (Reuters) -- The International Commission of Jurists said here today that the arrest of Imre Nagy and other leaders of the 1956 Hungarian uprising was a breach of international law, as well as of Hungarian internal law.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- A revised bill providing procedures for the sale of the $120,000,000 Klamath Indian timber stand was approved today by the House Indian Affairs subcommittee.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The Senate Finance Committee approved today the nomination of Arthur S. Flemming as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare. The Senate is expected to act favorably on the nomination within a few days.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- Thomas O'Donnell, who was the superintendent of the Illinois state police during the administration of former Governor Stevenson, denied today that Mr. Stevenson had ordered authorities to "lay off" union racketeers in 1952.
The country's big stores said yesterday that Saturday was no longer the busiest day in the week for many department and specialty stores. This is a shift from previous habits.
The Los Angeles, Calif., Department of Light and Power called yesterday for competitive bids next Wednesday for $21,000,000 of electric plant revenue bonds. The issue will mature from 1959 to 1988.

The Committee on Slum Clearance acted yesterday to make $10,000,000 in Federal aid available over the next five years for the twenty-block West Side rehabilitation project. To receive Federal grants in that amount the city would have to put up $5,000,000 of its own funds.

CLEVELAND, July 8 -- The chaotic slate of local building codes in many parts of the country was blamed today for unnecessarily high construction costs. The nation's architects, meeting in convention here, were urged to wage a campaign to achieve standardized, uniform regulations for all municipalities.
BUFFALO, July 8 -- A dispute between physicians and social workers over their relative qualifications to supervise baby adoption broke out today at a legislative committee hearing.
The Elks, national fraternal organization, spent $7,000,000 last year on its welfare program.
NORFOLK, July 8 -- The former Hudson River ferryboat George Clinton left here today on the second leg of her sea voyage from New York to Alvarado, Mexico, where she will resume ferry operations.
Charges of unfair labor practices have been filed against Transportadora Grancolombiana, Ltda. (Grancolombiana Line) by Local 1809, Steamship Office Workers Union, independent.
A plea for fast action by the City Council on a bill to bar sight-seeing buses from parking in the Times Square area was made yesterday by Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -President Eisenhower suggested today a cut in the number of Federal scholarships in the aidto-education bill approved by the House Education Committee.
BOSTON, July 8 -- Passenger service on the beleaguered Old Colony division of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad ended tonight.

The appointment of Joseph Ross as president of the Davison-Paxon Company, Atlanta, Ga., a unit of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., was announced yesterday by Wheelock H. Bingham, president of Macy. Davison-Paxon has a store in Atlanta and branches in six other Georgia cities.

LONDON, July 8--Queen Elizabeth II fell ill today with acute catarrhal sinusitis near the end of a twelve-day tour of Scotland and northern England. Her temperature was 100 degrees. The illness is not serious, however.
GUANTANAMO BAY, Cuba, July 8 -- A United States negotiator said today that he hoped the first servicemen kidnapped by Cuban rebels would be released tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -Farmers cut their cotton acreage 12 per cent this year under a crop control and land retirement program that should help reduce the cotton surplus.

GENEVA, July 8 -- Dr. Yevgeny K. Fedorov, chairman of the Communist scientific delegation at the EastWest talks on detection of atomic tests, indicated today that the United States was likely to shoot a rocket to the moon before the Soviet Union.

The Playwrights Company, facing one of its most crowded production programs in years, is planning to add two more projects to its 1958-59 schedule. One is a comedy by Romeo Muller, called "Like Wonderful," and the other is an adaptation by John Reich of Pirandello's "Enrico IV."
The long-standing feud between Bronx Democrats and the Liberal party came to a peaceful and mutually satisfactory end last night.

Robert W. Sarnoff, president of the National Broadcasting Company, is scheduled to be named chairman of the board at Friday's meeting of the board of directors of N. B. C. Robert E. Kintner is to become president.

ALBANY, July 8 (UPI) -Spokesmen for a group of Western New York industries called today for a "thorough investigation" of the Niagara Mohawk Power Company and its recent request for a $10,500,000 rate increase.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The National Association of Manufacturers is attacking the Kennedy-Ives labor reform bill as "a fraud and a delusion."
The Advertising Council acted yesterday to continue its anti-recession ad program a month past the Aug. 1 cut-off date.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 8 -A Soviet ballet group of eleven dancers, which includes. Vakhtang Chabukiani, one of his country's outstanding male dancers, arrived here last night on the first leg of on eighty-day tour of seven Latin-American republics.
Boy Scouts, in doing a host of good deeds yesterday for trees and the city, learned that with each green thumb comes at least one blister.
TRENTON, July 8 -- Governor Robert B. Meyner said today William J. Levitt might agree to racial integration in his proposed Burlington housing development if the public insisted on it.

BALTIMORE, July 8 -- Those Baltimore rooters who booed Casey Stengel -- the primary target -- and other Yankees after Gus Triandos, the local favorite, had been removed for a pinch hitter in the sixth inning of today's All-Star game, did not disturb Stengel. They did, though, embarrass Triandos.

On May 12 of this year The Associated Press filed a story from Washington beginning with this sentence: "President Eisenhower sent Congress today a report recommending liberalization of travel restrictions as one of the best means of improving international relations." The President presumably agreed with the report, which had been prepared for him by Clarence B. Randall, his special assistant on foreign econimic affairs.

PHILADELPHIA, July 8 -- The thirty-eight-day strike of The Philadelphia Inquirer unit of the Newspaper Guild of Greater Philadelphia ended today. The union accepted the terms of a new two-year contract.
Stock market prices made a general but controlled retreat yesterday, a little tired from their eight-day scramble upward.
The Fire Department opened an intensive campaign yesterday to reduce malicious false alarms.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., July 8 (AP) -- Two golfers from the Buffalo area scored decisive victories today in the state junior golf championship matches.
James R. Hoffa's proposal for an alliance of all transportation unions ran into an aerial attack yesterday.

When Hitler began his career of conquest his first victim after his electoral victory in the Saar was Austria, which he captured by conspiracy and subversion from the inside and then occupied as part of his Third Reich. This easy conquest gave such momentum to his empire-building program that there was no way of stopping him except by a world war.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 8 -- Lebanon charged today that the United Arab Republic had continued its "massive intervention" since the arrival of the United Nations Observation Group in Lebanon.

WASHINGTON, July 8--Bernard Goldfine and his attorneys faced a new "get-tough" policy from a House subcommittee today. And the New England industrialist's lawyers indicated an equally tough attitude.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The United States today granted the Scandinavian Airline permanent rights to fly to Los Angeles and to fly a new route to Anchorage, Alaska. But it turned down a Swedish-Norwegian-Danish plea to add San Francisco to the polar route the airline has been flying since 1954.

A big and somewhat nostalgic sigh of relief must have gone up from thousands of New Yorkers -- and others too -- when the news came out that Carnegie Hall was not to be torn down after all, at least for the present. Mr. Glickman is to be congratulated on his decision not to dispossess the Philharmonic Orchestra before its new home in Lincoln Square is ready.

LONDON, July 8 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan said today that Cypriote representatives could take part in the negotiations on the future of Cyprus that he proposed June 10 to the Premiers of Greece and Turkey.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 8 (UPI) -- A rebel bomb blasted and set fire to a five-story department store thronged with shoppers in downtown Beirut today in the biggest bombing incident of the nine-week Lebanese revolt.
The State Racing Commission was asked yesterday by the City Council to reverse its new policy of permitting children to attend races.
A novel labor-management plan will safeguard the health and welfare benefits of unemployed wholesale and warehouse workers in this city for six months after they lose their jobs.
A small boom in television picture and receiving tubes is under way at Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., it is reported.

Two postwar trans-Atlantic passenger shipping records are likely to be set this week. They will be the largest weekly movement of inbound and outbound ship travelers and the biggest individual sailing day.
OLD GREENWICH, Conn., July 8 -- Mrs. T. Arthur Menzel, a former champion, was eliminated in the first round of the fourteenth women's Tri-County Golf Championship at Innis Arden today.
BALTIMORE, July 8 -- "They got nine hits and we got four. I guess on that you could say they had a right to win."

WASHINGTON July 8 (UPI) -- The president of the American Cotton Manufacturers Institute urged Congress today to free the ailing textile industry from the "shackles" of Government farm, trade, aid and tax policies.

The big blast north of Massena last week, which opened a new era for Great Lakes overseas shipping, also opened a new era of increased competition with the Port of New York, already suffering from the inroads of other Atlantic ports in its foreign cargo trade. Four years ago this port handled 19.1 per cent of the nation's total; last year only 13.3 per cent.

Congratulations to The New York Times for its second big contribution to the understanding of juvenile delinquency in New York City. Harrison Salisbury's series on "The Shook-Up Generation" dramatized the many factors and the problems of the gang.
The Premier of Afghanistan, Prince Mohammed Daud, invited American business men last night to invest in his country's resources.

During the years when Congressional investigations of communism held the spotlight it was frequently pointed out that innocent victims suffered unfairly as the result of testimony by irresponsible witnesses in open hearings. Demands for the reform of committee procedures developed.

DARIEN, Conn., July 8 -- Residents of an exclusive shore area of this town have begun a campaign to create a separate tax district. The area, known as Tokeneke, has been operated privately for many years by the Tokeneke Association, composed of a majority of the 165 property owners.
OTTAWA, July 8 -- President Eisenhower arrived today on a four-day visit to seek ways of improving Canadian - United States relations.
PHILADELPHIA, July 8 (AP) -- Young Julius Pulvers Jr. emphasized today his desire to stay in the United States.

Twenty-seven Democratic and six Republican contests for party nominations in the primary on Aug. 12 were indicated last night as the deadline for filing designating petitions with the Board of Elections expired.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 8 -- All the forecasts for the Finnish general election have been proved wrong by the preliminary results, which became known this morning.
LEBANON, N. H., July 8 (AP)--Bernard Goldfine, industrialist, means substantial business to this community. His two local mills represent a $1,000,000 annual payroll.
Oswald D. Heck was reported yesterday to be thinking of abandoning his efforts to win the Republican nomination for Governor and throwing his support to Nelson A. Rockefeller.
Wagner College on Grymes Hill, Staten Island, yesterday hired an assistant basketball coach who, at times, won't play second fiddle.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 8 -- A vicious line squall out of the west this afternoon swamped the New York Yacht Club's junior regatta off the shores of the Riverside Yacht Club.

The group of visiting Soviet students spent their second day in New York yesterday circling Manhattan in a boat, attending a reception, holding a press conference and meeting American students at Union

LONDON, July 8--Worldwide increases in the incidence of cancer are not necessarily the result of cigarette smoking or radiation from atomic bombs, the seventh International Cancer Congress was told today. Some of the increase noted undoubtedly is due to more regular and more efficient routine medical check-ups, particularly among the aged, speakers said.

EMME'S fall hat collection by Adolfo was dominated by simple, dramatic shapes. The hats resembled Brancusi's abstract sculpture because all were designed in strong shapes devoid of drape or detail. None could be popped on casually.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -Senator Edward J. Thye, Republican of Minnesota, said today a decision was expected in November by the Federal Power Commission in the multi-million dollar Midwest Natural Gas case.

The Lukens Steel Company suffered a decline in earnings of 48.9 per cent in the first half of this year on a sales drop of 16.8 per cent compared with the corresponding period last year, according to the results issued yesterday.

GLEN HEAD, L. I., July 8 -A sturdy youngster with the style of a professional moved through two rounds of the metropolitan junior golf championship today. He was 17year-old Gerry Barnett of Brielle, N. J., who weighs 225 pounds, stands 6 feet 5 inches and hits the ball a mile.

IT is only during July that New Yorkers can savor two of summer's tartest and most delightful berries--gooseberries and currants. The berries, which come from farms upstate in the Hudson Valley, will be found in fancy grocery stores and fruit markets now.

BALTIMORE, July 8 -- The Yankees may dominate the American League from here to the outer fringes of space, but that doesn't mean the remaining seven clubs of the junior loop's so-called "second division" are utterly void of skill and ingenuity.

HARTFORD, July 8 -- Chester Bowles, former Ambassador to India and former Governor of Connecticut, was nominated for United States Representative on the Democratic ticket at a Second - Congressional District convention at Norwich tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- C. Douglas Dillon, Under Secretary of State, warned today that unless the Senate restored money cut from overseas economic development funds the United States "will face the prospect of important losses to communism in the next few years."
CHICAGO, July 8 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Some issues of long-term Government bonds yesterday suffered the sharpest drop since they started to decline early last month. Hardest hit were the 3 1/2s of 1990, which sank more than a point to 102 bid.
PULA, Yugoslavia, July 8 -Greece's Foreign Minister Evangelos Averoff-Tositsas, sought today to reassure the West that Greece had no intention of withdrawing from her Western alliances.
The bill to legalize bingo in this city was passed by the City Council yesterday. The vote was 22 in favor and one not voting.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The Army announced plans today to keep the twenty-seven existing National Guard units, though sixteen of them will be at reduced strength.
BERLIN, July 8 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev told an East German audience tonight that Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of West Germany was acting on a policy of strength that "exists only in his imagination."

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., July 8 -- Tommy Goodwin of the Westchester Country Club, who has won the New York State amateur golf championship four times between 1932 and 1953, and Joe Kryla Jr. of Leewood, tied for the medal in district qualifying for the thirty-sixth state tournament at Westchester Hills today.
WASHINGTON, July 8--Continuing improvement in the job situation in June was reported by the Government today.

Every so often the International Boxing Club throws a "fistic smorgasbord," a pastrami -and-beer feast attended almost exclusively by prize fighters and boxing writers, two factions that have produced some of the most stalwart intellects this side of the Gaiety Delicatessen.

Eddie Arcaro "beat the chalk" and was beaten on the chalk in the racing at Jamaica yesterday. The 42 - year - old jockey, who is having one of the best years of his career, drove to a nose triumph with Isendu over the heavily favored Hip Hip Hurray in the feature race.

MIAMI BEACH, July 8 -- The head of the Rabbinical Council of America emphasized here tonight that Orthodox Judaism had made "stupendous gains" in the last twenty-five years in every cultural, communal and religious aspect of American Jewish life.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Key Senate Democrats were criticized today for not having brought Hawaii's bid for statehood promptly to a test.
HARTFORD, July 8 (UPI) -Christianity must make its appeal more universal if it is to win acceptance by the peoples of the East, a British church leader said today.
CHICAGO, July 8 (AP)---Grain futures prices moved in a fairly broad range on the Board of Trade today but closed weak in a late sell-off.

The New York Regional Chapter of the Red Cross has received 182 pints of blood donated on Monday. Ninety-six pints were collected at Our Lady of Mercy Roman Catholic Church, 2512 Marion Avenue, the Bronx.
While commercial television these days seems to be bogging down in a morass of "Westerns," mysteries and quiz shows, educational television is marching ahead steadily on firm ground.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The Senate rackets inquiry exposed the "sweetheart" agreement in variable forms today.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The White House announced tonight that Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower would begin his postponed trip to Central America this Saturday.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., July 8 -- Mrs. Reinert M. Torgerson of Cherry Valley fashsioned a steady 38, 37--75 today to take a two-stroke lead in the eighth annual Women's Cross County Golf Association 54-hole medal-play championship at Rockville.

A bon voyage reception was given at the Sheraton-East yesterday afternoon by Mr. and Mrs. Harold P. Bock for the American debutantes who, with a corresponding group of French debutantes, will be honored at a ball to be held in the Orangerie of the Palace of Versailles on Friday evening.
BUENOS AIRES, July 8 -President Arturo Frondizi said tonight that Peronism would never return to Argentina.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI) -- A Federal judge today upheld the Government's right to enforce curbs on oil imports to this country.

FOR city homemakers who went out of town for the Fourth of July, the week-end was a foretaste of longer vacations to come. While the apartment or house can be trusted to take care of itself for a long week-end, wise homemakers will take special precautions before leaving for an extended period if they expect their homes to be pleasant to come back to.
Dr. Robert F. Metzdorf, a member of the Yale University Library staff since 1952, has been appointed to the newly created position of Yale University archivist.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI) -- Senator Karl E. Mundt said today he would try to push through a law to keep baseball club owners from "thumbing their noses at the public" in shifting franchises from one city to another.
IF William J has his way, women will be breaking out on Fifth Avenue in a rash of morning hats, tea hats and parading hats.
It was with considerable interest that I read Frances R. Grant's letter in the June 26 issue of The New York Times concerning the Latin-American tour of the New York Philharmonic Orchestra.

Foreign policy, as practiced in the Balkans, is by tradition brilliantly unsteady. Often its patterns resemble those of a kaleidoscope held in the hands of a palsied child. Almost a century ago the Comte de Gobineau, a frustrated French diplomatist, warned his Government: "Political prophecy is always difficult; but in Greece it is hopeless."

An investing client of Jacob Pantell bought the five-story apartment house for fifty-four families at 1524 Longfellow Avenue, corner of 172d Street, the Bronx. The deal was for cash over mortgages of $96,081. The property is 100 by 100 feet and is assessed at $125,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 8 -- A joining of American and British television interests has resulted in the formation of an international distributing organization known as the Independent Television Corporation. It has an initial capitalization of $2,500,000 and a first-year production budget of $10,000,000.
An intensive police search was under way last night for four thugs who assaulted and robbed an elderly man and his wife early yesterday in Brooklyn, causing the death of the man.
Vito Genovese and Vincent L. Gigante were arraigned in Federal Court here yesterday on an indictment charging them with participation in an international narcotics conspiracy.

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 8 -- Reorganization of Thailand's Cabinet and of the nation's leading political party will take place within a week or ten days, well-informed political observers predicted here today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 8 -- The world rice crop will show a substantial decrease this year, interrupting a rapid expansion that began in 1954.

OTTAWA, July 8 -- President Eisenhower and Prime Minister John Diefenbaker began backtracking today over a thirty-year trail of United States-Canadian economic relations in an effort to soothe irritants that have become burning political issues here.
GENEVA, July 8 -- Western and Soviet bloc scientists continued their discussions today on the reliability of acoustical devices for detecting atomic explosions.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 8 -- Finland's political scene was tossed into turmoil today as a result of the Communist party's surprising gains in the nation's parliamentary elections Sunday and yesterday.

Shipments of lumber products from the Western pine region in the second quarter were the lowest for the period since 1952, according to the Western Pine Association. The volume of 1,928,000,000 board feet was 8.3 per cent below the same period last year, the report said.

LONDON, July 8 -- A set-back in the pound sterling and the possibility of further industrial unrest restrained the stock market today. However, gains outnumbered losses in most groups, although the turnover was smaller and prices less firm.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 8 -- Hollywood film-studio musicians will vote tomorrow and Thursday in a National Labor Relations Board election to choose between the American Federation of Musicians and its new rival, the Musicians Guild of America, as exclusive bargaining agent.

The appointment of Dr. Sidney Forman as Librarian of the United States Military Academy was announced yesterday by Lieut. Gen. Garrison H. Davidson, Academy Superintendent. It was approved by Wilber M. Brucker, Secretary of the Army. Dr. Forman succeeds Col. William J. Morton Jr., who recently retired from active duty.
