WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The United States has agreed to allow Australia, New Zealand, Austria, Finland and the Netherlands to revise tariffs on a few American products. The Department of State in announcing this today, said the five nations in return had granted new concessions on other items, as provided for under international trade agreements.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) --The Atomic Energy Commission announced plans today to explore the possibility of using a radioactive coolant material from an atomic power plant in Nebraska as the key material for another industrial process.
BREMEN, Ind., July 8 (AP) -Robert Earl Hughes, one of the fattest men in the world, lay seriously ill today in a trailer parked outside Bremen Community Hospital.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 8 (Reuters) -- Four persons died today as violence and murder continued in Cyprus.
Sears, Roebuck Co. yesterday reported a 4.1 per cent decline in sales for June from the 1957 level, which resulted in a 2.5 per cent drop for the first five months of this fiscal year.
ALGIERS, July 8 -- The appointment of Jacques Soustelle as Minister of Information in the Government of Premier Charles de Gaulle received an enthusiastic welcome here today.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -House investigators questioned an official of the Aristotle S. Onassis shipping interests today about income of $1,000,000 a month on which no Federal income taxes are required.
The Transit Authority asked the city for $170,921,700 yesterday to be spent next year on new equipment and an extensive subway modernization program.
" Omnibus" has been signed for late Sunday afternoons next season on the National Broadcasting Company television network.
The trustees of the Kips Bay Boys Club have taken over the Nov. 20 performance of the new musical, "La Plume de Ma Tante" at the Royale Theatre.

WIESBADEN, Germany, July 8 -- The United States transport aircraft that wandered across the Soviet frontier eleven days ago was shot down by Soviet MIG jet fighter planes, the United States Air Force announced here today.

ATHENS, July 8 -- During World War II, Evangelos Averoff - Tositsas, Greece's present Foreign Minister, was a member of the Greek underground. After having eluded the Fascists for a long time, he was captured and imprisoned.

Cocoa futures tumbled the daily limit of 1 cent a pound in all positions yesterday, except July which has no limit. The latter fell 137 to 142 points (hundredths of a cent a pound). Volume on the New York Cocoa Exchange was heavy, 660 lots. At the close, there were seventysix unsatisfied offerings at prices ranging down from the limit.
MOSCOW, July 8 (AP) -- Boris Chakhlin of Russia won the world individual gymnastic championship tonight, recording 116.05 points out of a possible 120.
MOSCOW, July 8 -- Dream, damn it, dream!
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 5 points off to 7 points up yesterday in modest business.

CHICAGO, July 8 -- Anthony J. (Tony) Accardo, reputed chief of the Chicago crime "syndicate," failed today to obtain a television blackout in his forthcoming appearance before a Senate rackets hearing.
PASADENA, Calif., July 8 (AP) -- A 30-million-dollar expansion of America's satellite factory was disclosed today by Maj. Gen. Walter K. Wilson Jr.

THIS year's crop of wai chee, hok yip, kwei mei, no mei tze and other strains of the litchi fruit -- the moon pearls -- has been delivered in town by plane, and Peter Lee's Tiffin Tea Shop in Baxter Street distributes them to Chinese homes, to the better Chinese restaurants, to some of the city's chain stores, to ocean-liner dining rooms.

Increases in salaries voted recently by the Congress to the host of Federal employes focus attention on the vast growth of our American public services in the last two decades. The public, accustomed, however, to think largely in terms of the Federal Government in evaluating or appraising civil service, appears to be unaware that expansion of the public service has been far greater in the state and local governments.
Events tonight: Goldman Band, Richard Franko Goldman conducting, Central Park, 8:30; Dessoff Choirs Summer Sing, 130 West Fifty-sixth Street, 8; "The Bartered Bride," Jan Hus Auditorium, 8:30.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 8 -- For her "national days" at the Brussels World's Fair France has marshaled some of her most renowned forces. The ballet companies of the Paris Opera and Opera-Comique, as well as the orchestra and chorus of the Opera were on hand tonight at the Grand Auditorium for a gala attended by President Rene Coty and King Baudouin of Belgium.

A drenching twenty-minute squall that buffeted the metropolitan area yesterday briefly trapped 6,000 subway riders in underground trains in Brooklyn and disrupted rush-hour service for about 250,000 other passengers.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -The Department of Justice asked a Federal Court today to order Lever Brothers Company of New York to divest itself of the washday detergent product "All."
CHICAGO, July 9 (AP) -- Don Essig, the defender, today won a pair of matches with ease and led sixteen survivors into the third round of the national public links golf tournament.

STOCKHOLM, July 9 (UPI) -- Tomas Barris of Spain upset some of the world's top half-milers, including Arnie Sowell of Pittsburgh and Don Bowden of the University of California, while winning the 800-meter race in 1:49.6 tonight at the Stockholm Games.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- The Air Force announced today that it was issuing orders that would call 94,000 Ready Reservists to active duty automatically in a major national emergency.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 9 -- The Air Force fired a forerunner of its moon rocket into space tonight with a mouse inside a new type of nose cone. Scientists hoped to retrieve the cone from the ocean 5,500 miles from here.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 2 to 14 points yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
Paul W. Williams resigned as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York yesterday and immediately announced his candidacy for the Republican nomination for Governor.
The Luna Park Houses development was pictured yesterday as a milestone in the rebuilding of Coney Island into a substantial residential community and a center of orderly public recreation.

LONDON, July 9 (Reuters) -- Following, in an unofficial translation broadcast by the Moscow radio, is the text of a Soviet Aide-Memoire handed in Moscow today to Llewellyn E. Thompson Jr., United States Ambassador, by Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Foreign Minister:
BERLIN, July 9 -- Premier Khrushchev looked around East Germany today to see how the process of communizing it was coming along.

ST. LOUIS, July 9--The United States Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals acted today to assure an early ruling on whether the Little Rock, Ark., school board must resume racial integration at Central High School in September.
The Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company, marking its fiftieth anniversary, instituted service yesterday on what it proclaimed to be "the country's first air-conditioned rapid transit line."
HAVANA, July 9 -- Faculty members of the Havana University will draw no further salaries while the institution is closed, according to a decision of President Fulgencio Batista and his Cabinet today.
John Graham, who as a draftee opposed a rise in standards for Selective Service sought by Pentagon leaders, returned to the offensive yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The Senate confirmed without opposition today two major Presidential appointments.
PARIS, July 9 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle has told President Eisenhower that he is too busy right now to visit the United States but is looking forward to a meeting later.
The Navy has been asked to consider the New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn for the work of refitting forty-five Naval craft that are to be loaned to friendly nations.
A marionette show without crime, cowboys or Indians proved yesterday in the broad daylight of Central Park that it could hold the attention of hundreds of children for nearly an hour.
State Supreme Court Justice Samuel H. Hofstadter denounced professional boxing yesterday as an "enterprise of squalor" that ought to be outlawed.

The Mead Corporation, manufacturer of paper, paperboard and wood pulp, raised sales for the twelve and twenty-four weeks ended June 15 above 1957 levels. Earnings, however, were less than in the corresponding periods last year.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Bernard Goldfine told Congressional investigators today that his use of $776,000 in bank checks was none of their business.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 9 -- Habitues of the United Nations delegates' lounge, ordinarily blase toward colorful national dress, twisted their necks today to peer at three burly Samoans.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) -- William Pollock, president of the Textile Workers Union, called today for a thirty-hour week at forty hours pay to prevent textile workers from ending up on the "economic scrap-heap."

The Comptometer Corporation, Chicago, has acquired the assets of the Kord-Mar Company, with patent rights to Kord-Mar's cutter and crimper, J. J. Clerkin, vice president of Comptometer announced yesterday. The cutter processes cuts corrugated cartons into multi-size sheets; the crimper converts these sheets into protective storage and shipping packaging materials. The machines will be offered through a new ComptoPak division of the Comptometer Corporation, Chicago.

Philip Morris, Inc., producers of Marlboro, Philip Morris, Parliament and other brands of cigarettes, has purchased substantially all the capital stock of Benson Hedges (Canada), Ltd. The price was said to be about $1,000,000 in cash.
CHICAGO, July 9 (AP)--Traders said they could see little or no reason to do more than the minimum business in futures contracts today, and prices of the major grains were mostly lower.

One of the larger trial rooms in the United States Court House in Foley Square attracted more Federal judges, attorneys and marshals, spectators and press coverage yesterday afternoon than it has in years.
MOSCOW, July 9--For the third time in two weeks the Soviet Government called on the United States today to promise to halt tests of nuclear weapons in advance of an...

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Chicago restaurant operators told a Senate inquiry today that they had solved labor difficulties by enrolling employes for union membership without their knowledge and paying their dues. They said that the employes did not benefit.

Two more objections to the proposed widening of Fulton Street have been received by the City Planning Commission. The Commission is studying Borough President Hulan E. Jack's plan to widen the street to 90 feet from South Street to West Street.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- The F-108 interceptor plane is being designed to carry at least two guided missiles with atomic warheads so as to shoot down enemy bombers before they get within a thousand miles of United States soil.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 9 -- The Belgian Consul General for Damascus claimed diplomatic immunity today when arraigned on charges that he had tried to smuggle weapons into Lebanon from Syria.
PAWTUCKET, R. I., July 9 (AP) -- Backbone posted his fifth victory in his last six starts in taking the $57,750 Providence Stakes at Narragansett Park today.

MIAMI BEACH, July 9 -- The Rabbinical Council of America appealed to the nation's military establishment today to give "full legal and social recognition to the Sabbath as a holy day of religious significance for Jews."
The F. W. Woolworth Company scored another new sales record in June with a volume of $64,188,470. This was $2,482,398, or 4.02 per cent, more than the $61,706,072 sales rolled up in the 1957 month.
The Erie Railroad asked permission yesterday to cut off-hour, week-end and holiday commuter service in this state.

DETROIT, July 9 (AP) -- The Ford Motor Company cut its dividend rate today. Instead of the 60 cents a share it has paid quarterly since its stock was put on public sale two years ago, the company announced a 40-cent dividend. The dividend is payable Sept. 11 to stockholders of record Aug. 12.

ROME, July 9 -- The new Italian Premier, Amintore Fanfani, pledged himself and his Cabinet in both houses of Parliament this afternoon to strict observance of the Atlantic alliance and everything it implied.
OTTAWA, July 9 -- Just before the guests sat down to dinner at Government House last night Canada's Governor General Vincent Massey, the host, and President Eisenhower, his guest, exchanged gifts.

OF all the liquids known to man, none so quickly and effectively slakes a summer's thirst as iced tea. Unsweetened, the drink has no caloric content. Swallowed in judicious proportions, it is what Madison Avenue phrase-makers refer to as nonfilling. Next to water, iced tea is perhaps the least expensive cold drink in the civilized world.

LOS ANGELES, July 9 (AP) -- The last-place Los Angeles Dodgers continued their mastery over the first-place Milwaukee Braves tonight, belting the world champions, 10 -- 3. Steve Bilko drove in four runs for the home team.
OTTAWA, July 9 -- President Eisenhower told the Canadian people today that their grievances against the United States trade and economic policies were more imaginary than real.
Many patrons and patronesses for the fourth Imperial Ball have been announced by Mrs. Walter S. Gubelmann and Mrs. Stanley C. Hope, co-chairmen of the fete.
The Immigration and Naturalization Service is awaiting developments in legal proceedings pending against Vito Genovese before deciding whether it will institute deportation action.
The New York Telephone Company yesterday borrowed $65,000,000 on thirty-five-year refunding mortgage bonds at an interest cost of 4.03 per cent.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed that in the week ended Wednesday, July 2, there were:

MONTREAL, July 9 (Canadian Press) -- The powerful Teamsters' and Longshoremen's Unions agreed today to start "almost immediately" an all-out drive to organize Canadian dock and transport workers from the East Coast to the Great Lakes in readiness for an expected shipping boom through the St. Lawrence Seaway.

To move the capital of one of the largest countries in the world, and to do it in a matter of four years, is a feat of the first order. Brazil is doing it. The dedication of the striking new Presidential Palace of Aurora, or Palace of the Dawn, just about makes it certain that Brasilia will really be the capital of Latin America's giant in 1960, as President Kubitschek planned.
PULA, Yugoslavia, July 9 -- The foreign ministers of Greece, Yugoslavia and the United Arab Republic today ended two days of talks on international issues.
ALBANY, July 9 (AP) -- New York will spend a record total of $1,825,000,000 in the current fiscal year, more than a third of it for education.
GENEVA, July 9 -- The East-West conference of scientific experts ended today the first major phase of its discussions on the feasibility of detecting tests of nuclear weapons.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation is going to give away money.

The chief representative abroad for Cuba's insurgent leader Fidel Castro said last night that Senor Castro has approved a meeting of opposition groups to form a unified organization in the fight against the regime of President Fulgencio Batista.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The Senate Finance Committee rebuffed President Eisenhower today by voting to extend his reciprocal trade program for only three years instead of the five he requested.

Cuban Government forces penetrated within a half day's march of Fidel Castro's rebel base in the Sierra Maestra last week but were halted with heavy casualties, according to Morton Silverstein, a New York television producer. Mr. Silverstein returned Tuesday from the Castro camp in eastern Cuba.

The role of the specialist on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange is to make an orderly market. Nonetheless stocks sometimes gyrate wildly on sudden news. Yesterday, however, provided an example of what can be called a "very orderly sell-off," attributable to the operations of a specialist.
Mayor Wagner put New York on record yesterday in support of the national housing bill that has been reported by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- Pearl stickpins, presumably imitation, were sent to the Third Precinct Police Station yesterday for plainclothesmen to wear for identification when visiting Bernard Goldfine's seventh-floor headquarters in the Statler Hotel.
LUXURY was the keynote yesterday at a showing of Irene's fall hats. However, rich fabrics and furs were played down to the point of seeming casual.
WASHINGTON, July 9--Following is the text of the State Department note of July 3 to the Soviet Government on the detention of United States servicemen in East Germany:...
Business men in the Rockaways are peeved at the weather man because he forecasts rain on summer week-ends and holidays.
Former President Harry S. Truman said yesterday that he thought the Government "would be in a bad fix" without Sherman Adams because "he's running it, you know."
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- Charges of partisan politics on Hawaii statehood were voiced today in an explosive session of the House Interior and Insular Affairs Committee.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 9 (UPI) -- Researchers are cooking 100 pounds of chocolate for some sick baboons in Africa.

In 1919 the Tremont Stakes was won by a pretty good horse, Man o' War, who went off at 1 to 10. For the sixty-sixth running of the famous stakes for 2-year-olds at Jamaica yesterday, the crowd of 21,824 didn't have quite that much confidence in the Llangollen Farm's Restless Wind, sending him off at 1 to 5.

GLEN HEAD, L. I., July 9 -- Ralph W. Johnston of the Garden City Country Club reached the final round of the forty-first junior championship of the Metropolitan Golf Association today with a 3-and-2 victory over Gerry Barnett 3d of Manasquan River at the Brookville Country Club.

CHICAGO, July 9 -- William H. Kerr, a former union official who invoked the Fifth Amendment at a Senate rackets inquiry, was suspended from a supervisory position today in the Illinois State Department of Welfare.

SPOKANE, Wash., July 9 (UPI) -- Nino Valdes, a 216-pound Cuban, scored a technical knockout over Harold Carter at 1:45 of the ninth round tonight in their scheduled ten-round heavyweight bout at the Coliseum.

Fresh lay-offs more than off-set job recalls in factories and offices throughout the state last week. The result was a rise of 5,500 in the number of workers drawing regular state unemployment insurance benefits.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 9 -- The two-day election contest between the American Federation of Musicians and the new Musicians Guild of America for control of major film studio musicians got off to a brisk start this morning.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., July 9--Christ Protestant Episcopal Church will hold its annual summer fair in the parish hall and on the church grounds here on July 19 from 11 A. M. to 5 P. M. Proceeds from the fete will go toward the refurbishment of the parish hall.

In your editorial of June 30 titled "Traffic Offenders" you seem to accept the allegations of an official of the State Citizens Council of Traffic Safety that the courts have tended to become "soft" in adjudicating all offenses, including traffic violations.

ISMAILIA, Egypt, July 9 (Reuters) -- Three United States companies signed contracts here today to carry out a two-year program to deepen and widen the Suez Canal. The companies are the Atlantic Gulf Pacific Company, the Standard Dredging Corporation and the Hawaiian Dredging and Construction Company.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 9 -- Brazilian student organizations plan to meet Secretary of State Dulles with "hostile" posters but will stage no violent demonstrations.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) -- The Federal Communications Commission ordered the Western Union Telegraph Company today to produce by Dec. 31 a plan for divesting itself of its international operations.

CAMDEN, N. J., July 9 -- Four thousand roses were distributed to women employes crossing picket lines of the Association of Professional Engineering Personnel on strike at three Radio Corporation of America plants.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 9 -- George Morton Levy, the major domo of harness racing at Roosevelt Raceway, who has made all types of contributions to the sport, made still another tonight. He arranged for a teen-age sitting service.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- A State Department official testified today that the United States could not now deny passports even to persons known to be spies.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- The Senate Armed Services Committee abruptly ended public hearings on defense reorganization today. It prepared for closed sessions to consider the House version of a bill to overhaul the Pentagon.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) -- Federal Judge Alexander Holtzoff upheld today the dismissal of Burton C. Bovard as General Counsel of the Federal Housing Administration during the 1954 housing windfall scandals.
SPRINGFIELD, N. J., July 9 -- Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches took a one-stroke lead in the Women's New Jersey Golf Association's 54-hole medal-play championship today.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., July 9 (AP)--Leon Kantor of New York Mills and Curt Siegel of Buffalo gained the final of the state junior golf championship today.
A saving of $885,513 was indicated yesterday in the low bids received by the Department of Public Works for the underground garage to be built in Brooklyn's Civic Center.

WASHINGTON, JULY 9 (UPI) -- Neil H. McElroy said today that the Western military alliance would suffer "serious consequences" unless the Senate restored House cuts in President Eisenhower's foreign - aid program.

The American press reported. A few days ago, the death of two Cuban young ladies. The version offered by Batista's repressive police was to the effect that they died during a shooting affray between policemen and some revolutionaries who were hiding in the victims home.
Following are excerpts from Paul W. Williams' statement yesterday announcing his candidacy for the Republican nomination for Governor:
PHILADELPHIA, July 9 (AP) -- An agreement was reached today to end a nine-day-old strike by about 6,000 ironworkers in eastern Pennsylvania, southern New Jersey and Delaware.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) -- Senate-House conferees agreed today on a compromise bill to cut the interest rate on Government loans to small businesses from 6 to 5 1/2 per cent.
Whenever the day arrives for the start of the Anderson Memorial team tournament, the Winged Foot Golf Club at Mamaroneck resembles the site of a college reunion.

The Pennsylvania General State Authority sold $30,000,000 in building revenue serial bonds yesterday to an investment banking group headed by Drexel Co., Harriman Ripley Co., The First Boston Corporation and Kidder, Peabody Co.
A process by which the nation's vast oil shale deposits may be made to yield liquid fuels at competitive costs has been announced by the Denver Research Institute of the University of Denver.
BUENOS AIRES, July 9 -- The Argentine armed forces displayed their strength today before crowds that turned out in the soft winter sunshine to watch the annual Independence Day parade.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., July 9 -- Mrs. William Greenberg of Ryewood upset Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt of Westchester C. C., the medalist, 1 up, in the quarter-finals of the fourteenth Women's Tri-County golf championship at Innis Arden today.

MONTAUK POINT, L. I., July 9 -- Virtually every charter-boat skipper here has a little black book filled with telephone numbers of men who want to be notified when the striped bass and bluefish start showing up.

BERLIN, July 9 -- Wladyslaw Gomulka of Poland was conspicuously absent from the gathering of East European Communist leaders on the eve of the Fifth Congress of the Socialist Unity (Communist) party here.
CONCORD, N. H., July 9 (AP) -- E. C. Ferguson, State Senate president, said today that the people of New Hampshire expected "either outright condemnation or complete exoneration of Sherman Adams."
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- The board of directors of the Washington baseball club voted today against shifting the team.

Jack Brause, realty investor, who bought the eight-story office building at 525-27 Broadway, southwest corner of Spring Street, about a month ago, has resold it to investing clients of Herman Agins, attorney. The property is 50 by 100 feet and is assessed at $310,000.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 9 -- An upset was recorded today in the women's Eastern clay courts championships at the New Rochelle Tennis Club when Claudia Henschke of New York eliminated Betty Coumbe of Mamaroneck, N. Y.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Following are excerpts from today's hearing of the House Subcommittee on Legislative Oversight:
A Queens diamond merchant has been charged with grand larceny in the disappearance of jewelry that may total $1,000,000 in value.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- It was those delightfully cool days of spring and early summer -- not a shifting Gulf Stream or some other mystery of the sea -- that made Atlantic Coast beaches so cold for bathing in June and the first days of July.

LONDON, July 9 -- The outstanding feature of the stock market today was the continued strength of British Government securities. Fresh gains of 5 shillings (70 cents) were linked with the confident expectations that the bank rate will be further reduced soon to stimulate falling industrial activity.

MILWAUKEE, July 9 (UPI) -- Wisconsin Democrats ignored White House explanations today and accused Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower of "mooching on the taxpayers" by using three military planes to fly from a vacation resort to Washington.

LONDON, July 9 (AP) -- All but one of Lord Redesdale's daughters will share in his $361,000 estate under a will published today. Cut off without a cent was Jessica, who married a Left-Winger and named her child for Lenin.
BUFFALO, July 9 -- Details of a lucrative career channeling babies of unwed mothers for adoption by childless couples were laid before a legislative hearing by a Buffalo lawyer today.

The Lebanese crisis marks the second occasion in the past two years that has required the speedy dispatch of military personnel under the United Nations flag to the scene of a real or potential international disturbance which, however localized, could present a threat to the peace of the world.
PARIS, July 9 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle's plans for economic stability struck a snag today as French farmers refused to accept his proposals for limiting food price increases.
ANTONITO, Colo., July 9 (AP) -- A squad of Army mountain-climbing experts rescued an Albuquerque (N. M.) business man today from a canyon ledge where he had been trapped for five days.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., July 9 -- This 310-year-old village will have its first movie premiere on Wednesday evening, July 23, when through the cooperation of Robert Dowling, East Hampton summer resident, and United Artists, "Separate Tables" will be shown at the Edwards Theatre.

In the nose cone research the Air Force is trying out an advanced technique for protecting the nuclear warhead from reentry heat. This heat is generated by air friction when the missile re-enters the atmosphere from the almost airless upper regions.
Lehman Corporation reported yesterday net assets of $227,121,998, equal to $23.69 a share, as of June 30. This compared with $247,449,178, or $26.74 a share, a year earlier.
WILMINGTON, Del., July 9 (AP) -- The Atlas Powder Company announced today that Ralph K. Gottshall, president, had been elected chairman. He will continue as president.

TOKYO, July 9 -- The Japanese police are studying what kind of charges if any to file against sixty - six professed members of the Communist party discovered among 597 Japanese repatriates now on their way to Japan from Red China.
CHICAGO, July 9 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Coffee futures soared yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The B positions climbed 86 to 115 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 50,250 bags, and the M months advanced 100 to 121 points on 32,250 bags.
The City Housing Authority will take a new step today in extending into the Civil Service field bargaining rights that are standard in private industry.

SERENDIPITY III, which opened this week in new quarters at 225 East Sixtieth Street, is designed in the manner of a general store. However, the customer, after choosing wares, may sip espresso at a table in the corner, rather than resting her feet on a potbellied stove.
LONDON, July 9 (UPI) -- A large part of the British Navy was put up for disposal today.

While the rest of Europe remains safely in the political Center or tending to the Right, there are two countries bordering on the Soviet bloc in which the Communists have been able to make substantial gains. One is Greece, where the Communists have become the largest opposition party, though Premier Karamanlis' conservatives continue to hold an absolute majority in Parliament.

Today's new film is "The Light in the Forest," Walt Disney's version of the Conrad Richter novel, in color, at the Normandie Theatre, 110 West Fifty-seventh Street. Fess Parker, Wendell Corey, Joanne Dru and James MacArthur have the principal roles in the Buena Vista release.

Electric power production last week fell to an estimated 11,150,000,000 kilowatt hours from 11,757,000,000 kilowatt hours the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. The figure for the latest week is an estimate because of late returns resulting from the Fourth of July holiday.

HOMESTEAD, Fla., July 9 -- Raymond Weinstein, a 17-year-old sophomore at Brooklyn College, today scored his second victory without a defeat in the national junior chess championship. Weinstein won from James Bennett of Fort Worth in an English opening lasting eighteen moves.

So far as employment and unemployment are concerned, June is almost invariably a month of apparent paradoxes. It is the month when the labor force is swollen by the graduation of college students and when many more thousand students begin to look for vacation jobs. As a statistical result of this we are more than likely to be confronted with the apparent anomaly of employment and unemployment rising at the very same time.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board ordered an investigation into the Miami-Puerto Rico and New York-Puerto Rico fares of Eastern, Pan American and Trans Carribean airlines today.

OTTAWA, July 9 -- Following are the texts of Prime Minister John Diefenbaker's speech today welcoming President Eisenhower to the Canadian Parliament and President Eisenhower's address to the Canadian Parliament, as recorded by The New York Times:
Ford stock made a new high for the year yesterday, then plummeted 2 7/8 points for the day on news of a dividend cut. Most of the market followed downward at a gentler pace.

The coalition between Democrats and Liberals in the Bronx came under attack yesterday from L. Judson Morhouse and Representative Paul A. Fino. Mr. Morhouse is the Republican state chairman and Mr. Fino a Republican Representative from the Bronx.
Barry Wood, executive producer of "Wide Wide World," has resigned from the National Broadcasting Company and will join the Columbia Broadcasting System this month.

FOUR generations of Americans have preferred to wear identical blue denim pants, and for 108 years no one has come up with a more rugged, irresistible pair. No other piece of clothing has evoked such allegiance in this country nor has the cut of these ubiquitous pants been changed from the original pair, despite all cyclones of fashion.

Bank clearings for the twenty-six major cities of the nation in the week ended yesterday totaled $18,815,345,000, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc. This was 27.9 per cent below the $26,110,103,000 recorded in the previous week, but 8.8 per cent above the level of last year when the volume was $17,299,346,000.

PORTHCAWL, Wales, July 9 (UPI) -- Dick Richardson of Wales ended his string of losses to United States boxers tonight. He opened a cut around Bob Baker's right eye in the fifth round and outpointed the Pittsburgher in their ten-round bout.

GUANTANAMO BAY, Cuba, July 9 -- Two more American civilians detained by the Cuban rebels were brought out by a Navy helicopter at 4:31 P. M. today. They were James D. Best, 32 years old, of St. Mathews, Ky., and Albert M. Ross, 51, of Houston, Tex.

A Soviet student delegation told a group of American youngster yesterday something of the effects of de-Stalinization on Soviet education. The American told the Russians a little about segregation's effects on the United States education.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) -- Complaints that the Federal Government discriminated against workers because of race or religion increased during the last two years, President Eisenhower's Committee on Government Employment Policy disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- William P. Rogers, the Attorney General, made it plain today that the Administration would not ask Congress for any civil rights legislation this year.

THREE creative Americans have just proved to the citizens of Milan that good taste knows neither international nor social distinctions. They have given their adoptive country this lesson in merchandising: Given quality fashions, chic Italians will buy in department stores.

LAST night's program at Lewisohn Stadium was a telescoped affair that incorporated elements of Tuesday's rained-out program and yesterday's originally announced one. Heidi Krall, soprano, and Albert da Costa, tenor, both scheduled for Tuesday, replaced a Franck piece and sang the final scene from the first act of Wagner's "Die Walkuere."
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and former Senator Herbert H. Lehman announced today the formation of a national committee to oppose "right-to-work" legislation.

False alarms of fire are a waste and a menace the dimensions of which are not as well known as they should be. Commissioner Cavanagh did well, therefore, to put on demonstrations in four of the worst trouble spots in town calling public attention to this abuse and to order warnings posted on the street-corner alarm boxes.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 9--Dag Hammarskjold said today that he dismissed Povl Bang-Jensen last week partly because the senior political officer had imputed "sabotage" and "dishonest motives" to his colleagues.
HARTFORD, July 9 (UPI) -- A New York Congregational leader urged the church tonight to come out "from behind closed doors" and display a "sensitive social conscience."

NEW HAVEN, July 9 -- The twenty-seven-member council of the Connecticut Medical Society recommended today that the society terminate sponsorship of the Connecticut Medical Service and organize a new insurance plan for the payment of bills of physicians and surgeons.
TORONTO, July 9 -- Whitney Reed was named with Barry MacKay today to play the singles for the United States in the Davis Cup tennis match with Canada.

WINNIPEG, July 9 (Canadian Press) -- Increased Canadian wheat sales abroad will dig a welcome hole in the piles of surplus wheat on Canadian farms by the end of the July, 31 crop year, a grain official indicated today.

These menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are designed to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The United States denounced today the "inhumane attacks" in which two Soviet jet fighters shot down in flames an unarmed United States military transport plane twelve days ago.
LONDON, July 9 -- An exceptionally painful form of cancer of the bladder can now be treated with a pill of a new substance called lactone.

WALGROVE SNOOD and Kim Carruthers were sitting on the club terrace overlooking Debenture Bay. They were waiting for their wives, who were preening for the midsummer dance. In the early evening light a passing cabin cruiser looked like a model for an ocean liner.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) -- Senator William Proxmire of Wisconsin announced today that he was stopping his monthly newsletter until after the November Congressional elections to comply with the "spirit" of the corrupt practices law.

WHITE PLAINS, July 9 -- The opening of Westchester's new $1,200,000 Saxon Woods Park swimming pool was set for July 22 at a meeting of the County Park Commission today. The pool, under construction for the last two years, measures 324 by 130 feet.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) -- The Labor Department reported today that fewer workers were made idle by strikers in May than in any other May since 1955.

BACK in the old days when the American Leaguers manhandled their opposite numbers with ruthless regularity in the All-star game, the National Leaguers groped for a plausible means of hiding their embarrassment.
Widespread magnetic storms caused by a flare-up on the sun's surface have disrupted overseas radio communications for the last two days.
The Old Colony division of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, dead for a day, has been revived, at least for the time being.

ALGIERS, July 9 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle apparently will have to do additional missionary work on a very large scale to gain the cooperation of Algerian Moslems and "win the battle of the referendum."

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 9 (AP) -- A nose cone launched into space last May 18 by the Army's Jupiter rocket survived a 9,000-mile-an-hour plunge back to earth and was recovered intact from the ocean. The flight, however, was over an intermediate range of 1,600 miles.
ROME, July 9 (UPI) -- L'Osservatore Romano, Vatican newspaper, appealed today for an end to death on automobile race courses.
Joe Gordon made his first appearance at the Stadium last night as the new manager of the Cleveland Indians and the one-time Flash of the Bombers made it an auspicious occasion.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 9 (AP) -- Sixth-Seeded Maxwell Brown of Louisville and Third-Seeded Marta Hernandez of Mexico City were ousted from singles play in the Western amateur tennis tournament today -- the first casualties among the domestic seeded players in the tourney.
CHICAGO, July 9 -- The American Security Council is collecting here at the rate of 20,000 a month the names of individuals and organizations labeled as subversives.

Brooklyn taxicab driver contended in Manhattan Supreme Court yesterday that the police property clerk had violated the law in refusing to turn over to him about $30,000 in jewels that he had found in his cab more than a year ago.
OTTAWA, July 9 -- Canadian resentment flared today over the presence of armed Secret Service agents covering the movements of President Eisenhower here.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Casey Stengel demonstrated today the same easy mastery over the legislative Washington Senators that he has over the local baseball club of the same name.
CLEVELAND, July 9 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits of New York said tonight that the civil rights struggle in the United States was entering a period of crisis.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- One of the biggest mysteries nagging Washington about the Bernard Goldfine investigation is whether his public relations corps is working to defend Mr. Goldfine or Sherman Adams and the White House.

Recently the world was shocked by the news from Budapest announcing the execution of former Premier Imre Nagy, Minister of National Defense Pal Maleter and two other leading members of Hungary's short-lived freedom fight of 1956.

NEWPORT, R. I., July 9 -- Columbia, one of the three newly built America's Cup defense candidates, faced an official starting gun for the first time today. The results, while inconclusive, were eminently satisfactory.

Satellites and missiles are having an impact on toys, which is reflected in a host of pseudo-scientific items introduced by toy producers this year. This was reported by Mel Freud, president of the Toy Guidance Council, Inc., at a preview yesterday of playthings for the 1958 season at the council's offices.
The Elks lodges have granted their trustees stand-by authority to raise $1,225,000 for Government defense purposes in an emergency.

A drop of 3,079,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, they amounted to 183,407,000 barrels, compared with 186,486,000 a week earlier and 185,920,000 a year ago.

NEWARK, July 9 -- New Jersey's State Division against Discrimination announced today that the Veterans Administration had agreed to withhold loan approvals from builders practicing discrimination because of race, creed or color.
The four-man United States team yesterday defeated Iceland, 3-1, in the students' chess championship tournament at Varna, according to a report from Bulgaria.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) -- The House of Representatives tentatively approved today a bill to authorize a $1,762,000,000 construction program for United States military bases at home and abroad.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, and Representative Kenneth B. Keating, Republican of upstate New York, proposed today that the Senate and House Rules Committees be given authority to enforce ethical standards among members of Congress.
MOSCOW, July 9 -- Soviet Communists protested today that President Tito of Yugoslavia had slandered and distorted the "peace-loving" foreign policy of the Soviet Union and Communist China.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- If Congress, as it may at this session, approves the bill to establish more specific criteria on which the Secretary of State can withhold passports from American citizens, the Supreme Court in time may be obliged to interpret not only the powers of Congress in this area but also the President's powers in the conduct of foreign policy, wherein the Secretary is his deputy.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower prepared today to leave Saturday on a "study mission" to Central America. He made his preparations in the midst of a controversy over the use of military planes to bring him back from a fishing trip.

TOKYO, July 9 -- Foreign Minister Aiichiro Fujiyama asked the United States Embassy today to arrange talks with Secretary of State Dulles when the Japanese business man-diplomat visits the United States early in September to attend the opening of the United Nations General Assembly.

The Chrysler Corporation said yesterday that it had received pledges of $80,000,000 in excess of the $150,000,000 revolving credit it had sought to establish recently with a nation-wide group of banks. The agreement is in effect.
LONDON, July 9 -- Anonymous letters to the Soviet Embassy here promising to drop atomic bombs in the North Sea seem to have become a fad.
NAPLES, Italy, July 9 (UPI) -- Ezra Pound returned to Italy today and hailed his adopted nation with a Fascist salute. The poet called the United States "an insane asylum."
CLEVELAND, July 9 -- The charge was made here today that architects had abdicated their role in the planning of many home communities.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The Treasury disclosed tonight it had purchased $589,500,000 of its own new 2 5/8 per cent bonds of 1965 between June 19 and the close of trading today.
Ira Wallach and David Baker, last represented here as a team by the musical hit "Phoenix '55," have co-authored a new revue satirizing topical matters from subliminal advertising to "togetherness."

RIVERHEAD, July 9 -- Voters in eleven Suffolk County school districts approved budgets in balloting that continued into the early hours today. But in a twelfth, district -- Shelter Island -- the voters rejected the proposed budget.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- The Senate passed by voice vote today an appropriations bill to finance public works, chiefly water projects, in the current fiscal year.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- A shortage of Federal judges throughout the country is putting the American system of justice in peril, Congress was told today.
Three West Side piers were tied up yesterday by pickets of Local 153 of the Office Employes International Union, who said they represented the white collar workers of the Belgian Line.
A new acid-resistant insulating and refractory material was demonstrated with smoke and fire at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.
DUBLIN, July 9 (AP) -- Albert Thomas of Australia set a world three-mile record with a time of 13 minutes 10.8 seconds tonight.
BEIRUT, July 9 -- The Lebanese Government began a stronger campaign against terrorism today following yesterday's bombing of the ABC Department Store here.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- It is frequently said that Arthur Sherwood Flemming is coming back to Washington. Actually, he is usually just moving to another desk. He has been here, full-time or part-time, since 1927.

MIAMI BEACH, July 10 -- The new president of the Rabbinical Council of America said here today that a comprehensive program to promote Orthodox Judaism among college youth would be introduced on campuses throughout the country.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 10 -- The bid for qualifying honors in the annual Anderson memorial tournament at the Winged Foot Gulf Club ended in a tie today. Two teams turned in a best-ball score of 68 on the West Course to set the pace for ninety-two pairs of amateur golfers.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 10 (AP) -- Using instruments sterilized in a pot of boiling water on the kitchen stove, a Yugoslav physician performed an emergency operation on Aloysius Cardinal Stepinac's right leg yesterday to halt a blood clot from threatening his life.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI)--Two aides of Bernard Goldfine said today that they would take lie detector tests tomorrow. However, a newsman and a House investigator who resigned declined to take the tests.

During the battle for Stalingrad, Heinz Schroter was present as a war correspondent with the German Sixth Army. In 1943 he was commissioned by Joseph Goebbels to write the official history of that action, but on reading the manuscript the Propaganda Minister banned its publication.

Businesses trimmed the level of their borrowings from the leading New York City banks $197,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The reduction compared with one of $103,000,000 in the similar week a year ago.
Senators and Representatives were urged by the Public Service Commission yesterday to leave authority over local passenger service of the railroads in state hands.
Jimmy White, a matchmaker in professional boxing bouts and reportedly a "front man" for Frankie Carbo, known as the underworld's commissioner of boxing, was indicted here yesterday.
Two candidates for the Republican nomination for Congress in Manhattan's Seventeenth "Silk Stocking" District clashed last night in shirtsleeves.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 10 (AP) -- Bob Purkey, a Cincinnati right-hander, maintained his mastery over the San Francisco Giants tonight in pitching a 4 -- 0 victory and recording the forty-second straight scoreless inning he has hurled against the Giants.
LONDON, July 10 -- The Chancellor of the Exchequer, Derick Heathcoat Amory, said today that the time was ripe "for a further bold move forward along the road of international economic cooperation."
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Following are excerpts from today's testimony before the Special House Subcommittee on Legislative Oversight:
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- More than 1,200 persons turned out tonight for a testimonial dinner for Senator William E. Jenner, Indiana Republican, who is not seeking re-election.
NEWARK, July 10 -- Property taxes levied by local governments in New Jersey's twenty-one counties this year reached a record of $710,944,000, the state Chamber of Commerce reported today.
State Housing Commissioner Joseph P. McMurray tossed $300 of prize-money into the well of architectural learning yesterday and wished for a thousandfold return in eventual savings on building costs.
A three-month decline in customs revenues was arrested here last month.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Air Force announced tonight that the mouse-carrying test vehicle it launched last night at Cape Canaveral, Fla., had landed some 6,000 miles away in the South Atlantic.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 10 ((AP)) -- The Caltex Pacific Petroleum Company will open a thirty-four-mile pipeline Tuesday through the Central Sumatra rain jungles, linking Indonesia's newest oil field to the sea.

Today's new film is "Guitars of Love," a German-made musical comedy in color, co-starring Vicco Torriano and Elma Karlowa, at the Seventy-second Street Pilayhouse, 346 East Seventy-second Street. The Emelka-Willy Zeyn production was directed by Werner Jacobs and also features Mantovani and his orchestra. Sam Baker Associates is presenting the import.
Belgian Line piers on Manhattan's West Side remained tied up yesterday as teamsters and longshoremen continued to observe picket lines set up by a white collar workers' union.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- The House today passed the compromise bill making the five - year - old Small Business Administration a permanent Federal agency.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. July 10 -- Povl Bang-Jensen, senior political officer dismissed last week for "grave misconduct,'' demanded today that the United Nations publish his side of the case.
Commodity futures closed generally lower yesterday in dull and featureless trading on the New York exchanges.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI) -- The Senate Armed Services Committee approved a bill today that would give the Federal Government joint responsibility with the states for civil defense activities.

Boy Scouts are at work to save Third Avenue's trees. Because property owners have neglected to loosen hard-packed soil around the base of the trees rain cannot penetrate to the roots and the trees are dying. This is a condition not uncommon throughout the city.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Federal Reserve Board, by a vote of five to two, today rejected a proposal that New York City's second largest bank and Westchester's County's largest bank merge under a holding company.
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 10 -- The New Jersey Racing Commission today adopted a regulation barring children under 16 years of age from attending horse races.

A huge fourteen-legged marine monster made its way serenely through the waters of New York harbor yesterday. It was not, uninformed opinions notwithstanding, an atomic-age mutation of the common water bug.
TORONTO, July 10 -- The United States won the opening Davis Cup tennis match with Canada today just before rain intervened to force a postponement of the second singles.

MONTAUK POINT, L. I., July 10 -- This is about a tuna that fought heroically approximately eighteen miles due south of Montauk Point Lighthouse yesterday. Despite a 9/0 hook in its lip, the fish survived a forty-five-minute struggle against a fisherman -- and sharks. For this valiant effort it won a reprieve.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI) -- Congress was urged today to battle the Soviet Union on the economic front with the same determination it had shown in meeting the missile-satellite threat.

PORT - AU - PRINCE, Haiti, July 10 -- For the first three months of its existence the Government of President Francois Duvalier did everything possible to gain the cooperation of Louis Dejoie and Clement Jumelle, Haiti's Interior Minister said in an interview today.

Willis Hanks, who walks five miles a day taking special delivery mail to the garment district, announced yesterday that he would try to swim the English Channel next month. The distance from Cape Gris Nez, France, to Dover, England, is twenty-one miles.
Your July 3 editorial "Psychiatric Insurance" is disappointingly incomplete, although it may be intended simply as an effort to congratulate and boost a "local product."
WASHINGTON July 10 -- (UPI) -- The House of Representatives broke with precedent today. It refused temporarily to give the Senate authority to spend $625,000 for land to be used as a parking lot.
The Soviets have intervened in the Geneva scientific conference on nuclear explosions in a manner which must raise new doubts about the sincerity of their reluctant participation.
THE first showing to consumers of the new furniture styles revealed at the June wholesale market in Chicago opens today at Gimbels.
FORT MEADE, Md., July 10 AP) -- A quirk of military law today freed Pvt. Norman W. Swain, 41 years old, who once was sentenced to twenty-five years at hard labor for wartime desertion.

CHICAGO, July 10 -- On Dec. 5, 1951, Mr. Teitelbaum told the House committee headed by Representative Cecil R. King, Californian Democrat, that a clique of Government officials tried to shake him down for $500,000 to fix his income-tax troubles.
The Elks Grand Lodge installed its national officers yesterday at the final session of its five-day annual convention here.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI) -- The House of Representatives overwhelmingly passed and sent to the Senate today a bill authorizing a $1,718,768,000 construction program to bolster United States military bases at home and abroad.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 10 -- The United States Government has abandoned its attempt to deport Mrs. Iva Toguri d'Aquino, the "Tokyo Rose" of World War II, Bruce Barber, immigration director, said here today.
BUENOS AIRES, July 10 -- President Arturo Frondizi began seeking today a negotiated settlement of the revolt by Argentine judges against his court reforms.
The giant panda that has been barred from the United States because it comes from Communist China is on a sort of royal tour of Europe that may make it more famous than Lassie, if not richer.

Excess-reserves of Federal Reserve member banks increased, on average, $107,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This brought them to $790,000,000, the highest figure since Jan. 19, 1955.
TRIPOLI, Lebanon, July 10 -- This old seat of the Crusaders entered the third month of a strange siege today with a fanfare of dynamite blasts and a rattle of small arms fire.

A. O. Smith Corporation The A. O. Smith Corporation, Milwaukee makers of commercial water heaters, central heating and air-conditioning equipment, gas-fired boilers and other products, has purchased the domestic water softener business of the Refinite Corporation of Omaha.

The excellent report in your June 27 issue about community colleges and about the latest one planned for Queens is greatly appreciated by those of us who serve as board members on these quickly increasing two-year terminal colleges.
A record number of departing steamship passengers created heavy traffic afloat and ashore here yesterday.
Representative Henry J. Latham has declined a Republican renomination and Seymour Halpern, a former State Senator, has been chosen to run in his place in the Fourth District in Queens.

The United States team defeated Bulgaria, 3 -- 1, to qualify for the finals of the international students' chess tournament at Varna, according to a report received yesterday through Bulgarian news sources.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The House of Representatives approved tonight, 295 to 46, a bill to let heads of Government departments suspend or dismiss any Government officer or employe on security risk grounds.
CLEVELAND, July 10 -- The nation's architects, by overwhelming vote, renewed today their opposition to the proposed extension of the East Front of the United States Capitol in Washington.
Kings County District Attorney Edward S. Silver said yesterday that his Rackets Bureau had broken up a loan shark ring that charged 200 to 1,000 per cent interest.

Willys - Overland do Brasil, affiliate of Willys Motors, Inc., Toledo, Ohio, announced plans yesterday to complete a $22,000,000 expansion program at its plant near Sao Paulo, Brazil. The expansion is aimed toward the production of passenger automobiles.

Bronx Republicans pledged their sixty-one votes to Nelson A. Rockefeller yesterday. This action and other developments during the day gave Mr. Rockefeller a commanding lead for the Republican nomination for Governor.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Abraham Teitelbaum, once counsel of the late Chicago mob chief Al Capone, refused to tell a Senate committee today about his associations and activities.

MORMONISM, from its beginning, was a phenomenon that only the American seedtime could have nurtured. Dogmatic (and, at times, even fanatic) in its genesis, it had American staying power. Believing in its prophet Joseph Smith, it bided its time, pushed steadily westward -- and, when history and its star were joined, created the American Zion.
SPRINGFIELD, N. J., July 10 -- The second round of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association's thirty-fifth annual fifty-four-hole medal-play championship ended in a tie today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 10 -- Ten years ago the average Asian family enjoyed a poultry dish on its table about once a year -- during the main annual festival. Today the same family dines on chicken or duck about once a week in some regions, and eggs are plentiful and cheap enough to be served almost every day.
The effectiveness of a new antibiotic against a germ that is an almost universally serious problem for hospitals was reported at a conference here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Dull-eyed Republicans, wounded by the slings and arrows of adversity and apprehensive of more to come, brightened a bit today with the news that Paul W. Williams has given up his $20,000-a-year job as United States Attorney for New York State's Southern District to seek the Republican nomination for Governor.
Cotton futures moved irregularly on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. Prices closed 5 points off to 14 points up.

OTTAWA, July 10 -- President Eisenhower shot a 17-over-par 90 on the eighteen-hole Ottawa Hunt and Golf Club today, oblivious of a search by Canadian policemen and United States Secret Service agents for two suspected assassins.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 10 -- Four Moslem heads of state meeting here Monday will concentrate on what they can do as representatives of the Baghdad Pact nations to support the Government of Lebanon in its present crisis.
"Sing Along" was suddenly stricken with laryngitis yesterday as the Columbia Broadcasting System decided to take it off the air.
MILAN, Italy, July 10 -- The Sultan of Lahej said here today that he did "not recognize the British Government's right in taking the action they have taken in my respect."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 10 -- An expanded program of five pictures for production during the next two years is planned by Pennebaker, Inc., the independent company organized by Marlon Brando. Two previously projected films, "Guns Up," starring Mr. Brando, and "Shake Hands With the Devil," starring James Cagney, are due to get under way next month in Mexico and Ireland, respectively.

The National Sculpture Society wishes to commend The New York Times for publishing on June 25 the admirable suggestions of the distinguished architect Francis Keally regarding the Karl Bitter sculptures.
OTTAWA, July 10 -- Following is the text a joint statement by President Eisenhower and Prime Minister Diefenbaker announcing the establishment of a joint defense committee:
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 10 (UPI) -- The De Beers Consolidated Diamond Mines announced tonight it had bought controlling interest in the fabulously rich Mwadui diamond mine in East Africa.

ONE hardy group of visitors to New York this week is ignoring both heat and sightseeing and concentrating on shopping. These are the buyers in town for the semi-annual Gift Show to replenish store stocks for the autumn.
A Federal mediator endeavored yesterday to avert a strike of 20,000 telephone maintenance and repair men in the metropolitan district.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 10 (AP) -- Angry strikers at the General Motors Ternstedt division plant here brushed aside union officials' pleas to end their wildcat strike tonight.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 10 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of a communique issued today in English by the Yugoslav news agency Tanyug on the meeting between President Tito of Yugoslavia and President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic:
Greet School, a home for 200 youngsters at Hope Farm in Dutchess County, will be the beneficiary of a theatre party the evening of Nov. 6.
TEN years ago an Englishman named James Laver wrote a letter to his daughter, who had just passed her tenth birthday.

DUBLIN, July 10 -- The National University of Ireland conferred the honorary degree of Doctor of Laws today upon Basil O'Connor, New York lawyer and philanthropist, and Maj. Eugene Kinkead, who was for many years chairman of the Colonial Bank and Trust Company of New York.
A group of six Chicago and New York commercial banks yesterday submitted the best bid for $15,000,000 of bonds of Cook County, Ill. Metropolitan Sanitary District of Greater Chicago bonds.

Bits and pieces of business news stitched themselves together into a patchwork quilt of a market yesterday. There was a great deal of irregularity, but the averages were a good bit higher at the close.
LONDON, July 10 -- The relationship between lung cancer and smoking causes no alarm in the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON CROSSING, Pa., July 10 -- The Corps of Army Engineers has completed the first half of a comprehensive $2,000,000 survey of the water resources of the Delaware River Basin. It is also preparing to select sites for dams and reservoirs.
"BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 10--For her national days, Britain is leaning heavily on the oratorio.

The three-story building containing fifty-nine apartments and fifteen stores at 5 to 39 East Fourteenth Street has been purchased by Alexander Hirsch in a deal negotiated by L. V. Hoffman Co. and Helmsley-Spear, Inc., brokers. The property is 308 by 103 feet and is assessed at $765,000.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today that conditions prevailing July 1 indicated crop production this year may equal that of any previous year.

CLEVELAND, July 10 -- The intent of President Eisenhower's Executive Order banning racial discrimination and segregation among Federal employes is being systematically violated throughout the South, it was charged today.
ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I., July 10 -- A raid by fifty Treasury agents on a rooming house here today resulted in the arrest of four persons accused of operating a county-wide policy ring.
LONDON, July 10 (AP) -- The Hawthornden Prize, a major British literary award, was presented today to Dom Moraes, 19 years old, an Indian poet.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and subsidiaries continued to feel the effects of the recession in the first half of 1958, particularly in new telephone installations and long distance message volume.
GENEVA, July 10 -- Western and Soviet bloc scientists agreed today that acoustic detection devices should be included in any inspection network for policing a suspension of tests of nuclear weapons.

The appointment of Leonard J. Novogrod as executive vice president of W. J. Sloane, Inc., was announced yesterday. The company, a subsidiary of the Barker Bros. Corporation, operates a group of home furnishing stores.
The Yankees are no club to aggravate, and Joe Gordon, the new skipper of the Indians and a former Yank himself, should have kept that in mind.

The big New York City banks cut sharply the average interest rate charged on business loans between March and June. This reflected the reduction in April from 4 to 3 1/2 per cent in the prime loan rate.
WASHINGTON, July 10--The State Department reported today a wave of Hungarian Government reprisals against persons involved in the uprising against Soviet control in late 1956.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Congressional investigators decided today to build up a case for contempt-of-Congress action against Bernard Goldfine.

WRECKERS have torn the heart out of blackened old Broome Street Tabernacle near Police Headquarters in Center Market Place. The inner walls, the pews, galleries and partitions have been pounded to splintered board and lath.
NEWPORT, R. I., July 10 -- With the arrival of Weatherly, all four candidates for the defense of yachting's America's Cup were present or accounted for here today.
Paul W. Williams told the Rotary Club of New York yesterday that the "strict code" of the Mafia had helped it to dominate crime over the United States.

Even at the height of the pleasure boating season there comes a need for a short cruise. Perhaps the reason is sheer summer laziness. Perhaps the skipper and his family have been navigating out on the seas as a steady diet for several weeks and now seek a one-day voyage, close to home.
HARTFORD, July 10 (UPI) -- The International Congregational Council concluded a nine-day meeting today with calls for an end to denominationalism.

SINCE weather along the Eastern Seaboard has been reasonably kind for the last few days, fresh fish and seafood from that area are arriving at the New York market in greater quantities than in many weeks.
McGUIRE AIR FORCE BASE, N. J., July 10 (AP) -- An Air Force transport made a detour while flying the Atlantic Ocean today to pick up a 7-year-old girl in need of an emergency operation.
The problems of continental defense were an important topic during the Canadian-United States discussions in Ottawa that ended yesterday.
CHICAGO, July 10 (AP) -- A moderate but broad demand spread through the grain pits on the Board of Trade today. Nearly all futures prices were bid substantially higher than the previous closes.

TAKING a cue from the eighteenth-century painter Gainsborough, Mr. John has created a fall hat collection both romantic and dazzling. Strong, dramatic shapes in opulent fabbrics and furs were to be found throughout the line.
WASHINGTON, July 10--The Secretary of Commerce said today that he was "more optimistic" than ever about the outlook for the economy later this year.
CHICAGO, July 10 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
A man whose sense of direction is almost flawless during hunts for bats in strange caves confessed yesterday that the city's subways confused him.

AN audience of 10,000 persons gathered last night at Lewisohn Stadium for the second all-Tchaikovsky program of the summer. Mischa Elman was the soloist, and his performance of the Violin Concerto was the high point of the evening.
The aroma of hot coffee, French perfume wafted on air-conditioned zephyrs, gifts of candy. This is commuting?

HOMESTEAD, Fla., July 10 -- With victories in the third and fourth rounds, Raymond Weinstein of Brooklyn College made it four straight today to be clear of the field in the annual national junior chess championship. He defeated Thomas Heldt of Albuquerque, N. M., and Larry Remlinger of Long Beach, Calif.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 10 (AP) -- A grocery concern filed aintitrust charges yesterday against the Burgermeister and Falstaff Brewing Corporations and the California Beer Wholesalers Association. Burgermeister has its headquarters here, and Falstaff in St. Louis, Mo.

The debate over public assistance to foreign countries, which has taken a good deal of the time of Congress -- and deservedly so -- has tended to obscure in part the increasingly important role that is being played by the flow of private funds from this country into long-term capital investments abroad.

Power Reactor Development Company has awarded Sylvania-Corning Nuclear Corporation a contract for more than $1,000,000 of atomic fuel loadings for the 100,000-kilowatt Enrico Fermi nuclear power plant at Lagoona Beach, Mich.

LONDON, July 10--Britain has withdrawn recognition of the Sultan of Lahej, ruler of the largest and wealthiest of the western Aden principalities, and has banned the Sultan from the protectorate and colony.
LONDON, July 10 -- Britain's hope of getting a European freetrade area under way by Jan. 1 is fading fast.

ALGIERS, July 10 -- The French Army is conducting a summer offensive in widely scattered areas of Algeria, French military sources said today. The objective of the drive, about which no details have been made public, is to destroy as many nationalist rebel units as possible before the referendum on constitutional reform to be held in France and Algeria Oct. 5.
If the author of the reigning best-selling novel "Anatomy of a Murder" had been a practicing lawyer in New York instead of in Michigan, perhaps this absorbing story would not have been written.

OTTAWA, July 10 -- A joint Cabinet committee to decide and direct Canadian and United States policies for the defense of North America under "civilian control" was announced today in a statement by President Eisenhower and Prime Minister John Diefenbaker.
LONDON, July 10 -- Apart from a further advance in Government securities, the chief feature in the stock market here today was the broadening of interest in South African gold mining shares.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Senate Finance Committee handed President Eisenhower a setback today by voting, 12 -- 2, for a drastically modified bill to extend the Reciprocal Trade Agreement Act.

The British Minister of Transport and Civil Aviation indicated here yesterday that he considered the Boeing 707 jet transport, despite its noise suppressors, too noisy for unrestricted operations into London Airport.
Two Brooklyn men who confessed to the mugging of an elderly couple were held without bail yesterday when they were arraigned in Brooklyn Felony Court on charges of assault and robbery.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI) -- The Special House Subcommittee on Legislative Oversight listed today twenty-one occasions on which Bernard Goldfine had paid hotel bills for his close friend, Sherman Adams, or members of the Adams family.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 10 -- President Camille Chamoun's first firm statement that he would not attempt to seek re-election has provoked intense political activity and generated many rumors.

Net income of the Rockwell Manufacturing Company in the six months ended June 30 totaled $2,434,000 or $1.06 a common share, the midyear report disclosed yesterday. In the first half of 1957 the net was $4,743,000 or $2.07 a share.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday, totaled 457,661 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

The farcical atmosphere that has recently begun to envelop the Goldfine-Adams case in Washington should not be permitted to distract attention any further from the real and serious issues. It is up to the House subcommittee on Legislative Oversight to get its investigation back on the track, from which it has clearly been allowed to stray.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI) -- The divided House Labor Committee was urged today by a subcommittee to approve a simplified substitute for the Senate-passed union welfare fund bill.
HONG KONG, July 9 -- The Peiping Government is expanding the network of railways in the east coast Chinese provinces of Kiangsu, Chekiang, Fukien and Kwangtung.
Sam Levene, who played a wily dress manufacturer in last season's "Fair Game," will return to Broadway in November to star as a harried television producer in a comedy called "Make a Million."
A 2 per cent drop in advertising this year from last year's record high is forecast by Printers' Ink.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., July 10 -- The disarmament of the free world would leave it open to Communist domination, Mme. Chiang Kai-shek declared here tonight.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 10 -- Boys and girls from every part of Westchester will converge here Saturday for the county's first annual junior fishing contest.
MOSCOW, July 10 (AP) -- Boris Chakhlin and Larissa Latinina of Russia, the world all-around gymnastic champions, dominated the individual world title competition today as the five-day meet ended.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Bernard Goldfine listed today gifts of woolen cloth he made to twenty-three state and territorial Governors in 1955.He promised to go right on giving things to both? "important people and the average man in the street."
JUNEAU, Alaska, July 10 -- An earthquake great magnitude, followed by severe aftershocks, rocked southeastern Alaska during the night.
CUT 'N SHOOT, Tex., July 10 -- About forty-five miles north of Houston, deep in the thicket, and thick with moonshiners, is a snuff-dipping little Texas town called Cut 'n Shoot.

LONDON, July 10 (UPI) -- The voice of Robert Donat spoke at his own memorial service today a month after he had died of a heart attack at the age of 53. A tape recording of the actor's final prayer was played back at the London Church of St. Martin's in the Fields, where his friends gathered to pay him tribute.

Radio Free Europe announced yesterday that Erik Hazelhoff, former director of television network sales for the National Broadcasting Company, had been named its European director. He has been deputy European director of Radio Free Europe for the last year.

We read with great interest the incisive letter of Hon. Charles H. Silver, president of the Board of Education of the City of New York, in your issue of June 27 with reference to the recent Rockefeller Fund Study Committee on educational needs in the United States.
PULA, Yugoslavia, July 10 -- President Tito and President Gamal Abdel Nasser called today for a summit conference and an end to production and testing of nuclear weapons.

CHICAGO, July 10 (AP)--Junie Buxbaum, taking a week's vacation from his job as a Memphis auto salesman to play golf, ousted Bob Faulkenberry, 4 and 2, today to gain the national public links semi-finals.

The New York Central Railroad and the Order of Railway Conductors and Brakemen agreed yesterday in Federal Court to negotiate a settlement of their dispute over the duties of conductors on sleeping cars.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Following are the conclusions of the Federal Reserve Board in its ruling against a proposed holding company combination of the First National City Bank of New York and the County Trust Company of White Plains:
GUANTANAMO BAY, Cuba, July 10 -- A Navy helicopter brought out today the first kidnapped sailor to be released by the Cuban rebels. He is Airman Thomas R. Mosness of Ames, Iowa.
MINEOLA, L. I., July 10 -- The telephone has become a gardening tool for thousands of enthusiasts in Nassau County.
BERLIN, July 10 -- Walter Ulbricht, Communist leader, set forth today a program for tightening the party's grip on all phases of life in East Germany.

One of the greatest room hunts in the history of New York is in full swing. Ten thousand Jehovah's Witnesses are making a house-to-house canvass of Manhattan, Brooklyn, the Bronx and Queens. They seek living quarters for 125,000 Witnesses who will converge on New York for a week-long world assembly of the movement beginning July 27.

Mrs. Harold F. McGuire, chairman, has chosen her committee for the Oct. 23 performance of "Goldilocks," which will benefit the Bargain Box. The musical is scheduled to open at the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre on Oct. 9.

President Eisenhower has had the expected reply to his invitation to General de Gaulle to pay us a visit. The French Premier is "very much attracted by the idea" but finds that it would be very difficult "during the next few months."
Eddie Arcaro is doing his best to dispel the sports bromide "you gotta be hungry to win." The 42-year-old jockey is far from hungry, but he certainly wins.

Steel production in June totaled 7,132,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings. This was the highest figure for any month so far this year, according to a preliminary report issued yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.
MANAHAWKIN, N. J., July 10 -- For most schools throughout the country, the 1957-58 school year ended last month. But at the Southern Regional High School here it is still in full swing.
BERLIN, July 10 -- The Soviet Union has agreed to provide technical assistance and increase its deliveries of industrial raw materials under a new agreement with East Germany.
NEW HAVEN, July 10 (AP) -- The Tuscorara Indian nation won some time today in its fight to prevent the State of New York from taking part of its land for a power reservoir.

Memorial services were held at the Riverside Church last night for Imre Nagy, former Hungarian Premier, and his four comrades who were executed last month by the Hungarian Communist leaders for their part in the Hungarian uprising of 1956.
A group managed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., is offering today $30,000,000 of 4 1/2 per cent sinking fund debentures of Southern Natural Gas Company, due in 1978, at par to yield 4.50 per cent.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 10 -- Jakob Isbrandtsen, head of Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., said today that Government boondoggling was partly responsible for what he called the present unhappy condition of the shipping industry.

PARIS, July 10 -- Other members of the European Atomic Energy Community have been informed that the French Government is ready to take a leading part in the joint program agreed upon by the community and the United States.
IT would be misleading to draw one picture of Mme. Chiang Kai-shek. She is a woman of many moods and many talents. She can be witty, gay, charming and schoolgirlish. She can be courageous.

PARIS, JULY 10 -- The French Government is apprehensive that the Soviet Union is trying to bypass Britain and France and negotiate directly with the United States on the possibility of a heads-of-government conference.
WIESBADEN, Germany, July 10 -- Four United States airmen were beaten by Soviet farmers and one was nearly lynched after having parachuted from their burning aircraft, crew members disclosed today.

ROME, July 10 -- A civil tribunal here annulled today the eight-year-old marriage of Ingrid Bergman, film actress, to Roberto Rossellini, Italian motion-picture director. Miss Bergman had announced in Britain earlier this month that she intended to marry Lars Schmidt, Swedish theatrical producer.
New England Electric System has registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission a plan to issue its common shares in exchange for publicly held common stocks of several subsidiaries.
NEWPORT, R. I., July 10 (AP) -- Robert R. Young of Newport and Palm Beach, Fla., left an estate of $8,367,237, according to his inventory filed in Newport Probate Court today.
The new antibiotic kanamycin appears to be useful against germs that can cause severe diarrhea in children, according to pediatricians at the Tulane University School of Medicine in New Orleans.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI) -- Mansfield D. Sprague, Assistant Secretary of Defense, warned today that House cuts in President Eisenhower's military aid program would increase the risk that United States allies would be "inadequately prepared" to meet an enemy attack.

CLEVELAND, July 11 -- Architects and city planners were cautioned here today that community appearance "cannot be achieved by a veneer smeared on from the outside." Civic beauty, they were told, must be attained by protecting cities from disfigurement and liberating them from a straitjacket which compels them to grow within the limits of arbitrary rules.
