" ESP," last night's new show on Channel 7, turned out to be a quiz show except that no knowledge was needed; contestants just flew by the seat of their pants.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) lent the equivalent of $33,000,000 at 5 3/8 per cent for fifteen years to the Japan Development Bank to aid expansion of the iron and steel industry. American, German and Swiss banks participated in the loan to the extent of $960,000 without the World Bank's guarantee.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Ships and planes searching the south Atlantic failed again today to recover a rocket nose cone and its mouse passenger.
ROME, July 10 -- A disagreement over an interpretation of part of the Bible is straining relations between the Vatican and some quarters of the Roman Catholic Church in France.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Eight silent figures identified with Chicago rackets balked a Senate committee for five hours today.

HONOLULU, July 11 (AP) -- Neil H. McElroy, Defense Secretary, arrived here tonight after a nonstop flight from Washington in an Air Force jet tanker. He is en route to the United States H-bomb tests at Eniwetok.

A strike date for a walkout by 20,000 telephone maintenance and repair men in the metropolitan area will be set today at a meeting of the board of directors of the United Telephone Organizations at the Edison Hotel.
GENEVA, July 11 -- Western and Communist scientific delegations continued today their consideration of the feasibility of detecting atomic tests by collecting radioactive debris.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- An agreement providing House consideration next Tuesday of a bill to curb Supreme Court powers was reported today by Representative William M. Colmer, Democrat of Mississippi.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The index of average wholesale prices at the primary market level declined 0.1 per cent to 119.1 per cent of its 1947-49 average during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 11 (UPI) -- Orlando Cepeda belted a three-run homer in the twelfth inning today, enabling the San Francisco Giants to post a 7-4 victory over the Cincinnati Redlegs.

H-R Representatives, Inc., and H-R Television, Inc., a subsidiary, leased most of the twenty-first floor in the Seagram Building, 375 Park Avenue at Fifty-second Street. The lessees, who are advertising representatives of radio and television stations, acquired an option to lease the rest of the floor within a few years.

Time and the devices developed to measure it are the subjects of "Time and Its Measurement," by Harrison J. Cowan. It will be published Aug. 26 by World. The story of the measurement of time is traced from the Biblical sundial of Ahaz to the atomic clock with a pendulum that is the vibration of a single atom.
One man lost his life and two others were missing after an early morning collision yesterday between a British freighter and a fishing boat off Martha's Vineyard, Mass.

The Seventh-Day Adventists announced yesterday that "the Fuzzy-Wuzzy grandson of a head-hunting New Guinea chief" would speak at 7 o'clock tonight in their New York Center, 227 West Forty-sixth Street.

SPRINGFIELD, N. J., July 11 -- Maureen Orcutt of White Beeches, with rounds of 77, 80, 79 -- 236 over the upper course of the Baltusrol Golf Club, gained her ninth victory in the Women's New Jersey Golf Association's 54-hole medal-play championship today.
NEW WINDSOR, N. Y., July 11 -- This little unincorporated village of 2,754 persons is preparing for the battle of its life. It is taking on the United States Air Force in a fight over taxes.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Joblessness among workers covered by the unemployment compensation system declined for the eleventh consecutive week in the final week of June, the Labor Department reported today.
The fortieth annual Professional Golfers Association championship tournament will be televised on the Columbia Broadcasting System network.
Twenty-three foreign visitors to New York will be shown the "seven wonders" of the city on a tour today and Sunday.

The International Business Machines Corporation in the first half of this year recorded the highest sales and earnings for any six-month period in the company's history.

MINEOLA, L. I., July 11 -- Three persons seized by Treasury agents after a raid on a Rockville Centre rooming house yesterday were held in bail on gambling charges when arraigned in First District court here this morning.
ALTMAN'S, a store with one of the largest selections of imported shoes in the country, is about to add another star to its galaxy.

Examiner Harold Weber of the Public Service Commission, reserved decision yesterday at a hearing on a proceeding by the City of Mount Vernon to assure adequate entrances at the New Haven Railroad station there.

E. J. Lavino, president of E. J. Lavino and Company, metals concern, Philadelphia, has been elected chairman of its board. Russell N. Ward, executive vice president, has been named president, succeeding Mr. Lavino.
The taxable assessed valuation of real estate in the city's central business district increased $138,400,000 in the two fiscal years from 1954-55 to 1956-57.

The proposed sale at auction of the Washington Retail Market on the lower West Side, which was scheduled for July 30, has been postponed to an indefinite date in September, the City Bureau of Real Estate announced yesterday.

The head of the house lately has been going to the dentist's. While this is the usual expression, there is no doubt that in his own particular case it is an oversimplification. The head of the house has been living at the dentist's, being released from there only a few moments each day that he may sleep.
LONDON, July 11 -- Parleys between representatives of Britain and Yemen to halt the Aden border fighting have been arranged at the summer palace of Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia.
Futures prices closed generally irregular yesterday on the New York Exchanges. Trading in most markets was dull. Evening of positions prior to the week-end accounted for most of the volume.
There is at least one couple in town that is yet to be convinced that the dog is man's best friend.

PATERSON, N. J., July 11 (AP) -- The police charged Victor Corbo with murder tonight in the death of 3-year-old Ellen Graham, who earlier died of a brain hemorrhage in the Corbo home. Corbo, 40 years old, and his wife, Rita, 29, were the child's foster parents.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- The Senate approved today the nomination of Leo A. Hoegh, former Governor of Iowa, as director of the combined Office of Defense and Civilian Mobilization.
CHICAGO, July 11 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- The United States is prepared to permit the sale of trucks to Communist China by the Ford Motor Company's Canadian subsidiary, officials said today.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The United States Tax Court today canceled income tax claims of more than $4,000,000 arising from the transfer of the Howes leather-making empire to New York University in 1947.
Representatives of five Hungarian organizations will hold a mass meeting tonight and resume picketing the Soviet United Nations headquarters tomorrow to protest oppression in Hungary.
DOVER, N. J., July 11 -- Goldfish dart about on a flooded roof at the Dover General Hospital, amusing the patients and keeping the cooling water on the roof free...

GUANTANAMO BAY, Cuba, July 11. The Cuban rebels released today the last of the twenty civilians they had kidnapped. But they still held twenty-nine of thirty United States sailors and marines kidnapped two weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI) -- The Senate approved legislation today to authorize a long list of retired Government personnel, including former President Harry S. Truman and Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, to accept and wear foreign decorations.
Prices of cotton futures moved in a narrow range yesterday in light trading. The close was 1 point off to 6 up.
OTTAWA, July 11 -- Less than an hour after having said good-by to President Eisenhower at the airport, Prime Minister John Diefenbaker reported to Parliament today on the talks of the last four days.

Five of seven teen-aged boys charged with the first-degree murder of a Cuban youth in Thomas Jefferson Park on May 30 pleaded not guilty in General Sessions court yesterday. They appeared before Judge Mitchell D. Schweitzer.

JERSEY CITY, July 11 -- A contract to equip Hudson County's new $6,500,000 administration building with desks, chairs and other furnishings at a cost of $1,068,524 was ruled invalid today by Superior Court Judge Charles W. Broadhurst.

At this time a year ago, the Yankees, who yesterday at the Stadium overwhelmed the Cleveland Indians, 11 -- 3, owned a 52-26 won-lost record. They were in first place, three and a half games ahead of the runner-up Chicago White Sox. Following yesterday's triumph, the Bombers' record for this campaign was 51 -- 26. There, though, the similarity ends.

ST. LOUIS, July 11 (AP) -- Gov. Orval E. Faubus of Arkansas is preparing to ask the Supreme Court to review decisions granting an injunction against interference with integration at Central High School in Little Rock.
Paul W. Williams waived his claim yesterday to the support of New York County's eighty-one delegates at the Republican state convention.

TORONTO, July 11 -- Whitney Reed rose to the test of his first Davis Cup match with a thoroughly worthy performance today and the United States now leads Canada, 2 -- 0, in their semi-final round series in the American zone.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The United States formally demanded tonight that the Soviet Union punish its fighter pilots who shot down an unarmed American transport plane over Soviet territory June 27.

ASK any proud new parent and -- if he's not too modest -- he'll tell you: His baby is the most beautiful, best-natured, most intelligent infant in the world. The loving mother or father needs no test record to prove what his eyes can so plainly see. The unique superiority of his offspring is unquestioned.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- The television industry was accused today of making unfair attacks on a staff that prepared a report for the Federal Communications Commission.

LENOX, Mass., July 11 -- A solid week-end of Mozart was started tonight in the Shed as the second week of the Berkshire Music Festival got under way. The concert had been scheduled for the Theatre-Concert Hall, but a downpour during the afternoon and early evening necessitated the shift.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 11 -- A $3,000,000 project nearing completion here will provide the final link in one of Nassau County's major traffic arteries extending eleven miles to the South Shore.

MOSCOW, July 11 (UPI) -- The Premier of the Soviet Republic of Azerbaijan has been dismissed from his post, it was announced today. A decree published in the official newspaper in the capital of Baku announced simply that Premier Sadykh G. Ragimov had been dismissed and his place taken by Veli Yusif Ogli Akhundov, a secretary of the Azerbaijan party.

Irving Klein has purchased for investment the one-story taxpayer containing five stores and occupying a plot 105 by 83 feet at 2981-91 Third Avenue at 154th Street in the Bronx. The parcel was sold by Jack Resnick, realty operator, subject to a purchase money first mortgage of $120,000.

The report by United Nations Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold on possible external intervention in the Lebanese conflict seems to have been received with disbelief and irritation by both the Lebanese Government and Western observers. The reaction by the Chamoun Government in Lebanon is perfectly understandable; that by many in the United States, however, has been, at best, curiously naive, and at worst demonstrative of a substantially inadequate comprehension of the situation in Lebanon.

Steel production is showing a mixed pattern. Next week in the Youngstown, Ohio, district operations are scheduled to rise to about 49 per cent of capacity from an average rate of 43 per cent this week.
MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 11 -- Ralph Bogart and Robert Brownell of Chevy Chase, Md., who have won the Anderson Memorial tourney on three occasions, advanced through two rounds with sub-par golf today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 11 -- The American Federation of Musicians thirty-year monopoly in the film industry ended at 12:45 A. M. today.

LOS ANGELES, July 11 (AP) -- Fred Haney, the Milwaukee baseball manager, prompted by a party attended by four of his stars, assembled his world champion Braves today for a warning about the perils of Hollywood.

Josef Krips, noted Beethoven conductor, will make his debut with the Stadium Symphony Orchestra Monday in the first of four Beethoven programs, which he will conduct on successive days in the Lewisohn Stadium.
ATCHISON, Kan., July 11 (AP) -- Winds of 90 to 100 miles an hour swept northeast Kansas last night accompanied by rains that reached seven and one-half inches in less than an hour.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI) -- The House Ways and Means Committee breached the Administration's no-tax cut line today. It started a drive to give special relief to self-employed persons trying to provide for their old age.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., dedicated at Brevard, N. C., yesterday what was described as the first full-scale plant for manufacturing extremely pure silicon. The new facility will be a prime supplier of the vital material to the electronics industry, with a capacity of 70,000 pounds a year.
CHICAGO, July 11 (AP) -- This was a most unusual day on the Board of Trade. The bread grains unhinged and ran sharply in opposite directions -- wheat higher, rye lower.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- A race track bettor can write his own ticket with apparatus that was patented this week. He buys a blank ticket, pokes it through a slot in the machine, and selects his horse by push-button.

Activity in the new capital market next week is likely to be greater than in any week so far this year. Barring any last minute postponements, almost half a billion dollars of corporate debt and senior equity issues will be offered.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- The Senate, after some strong debate, voted today to prohibit futures trading in onions through any board of trade in this country.

Dr. Milton Eisenhower starts out today on a full-scale, fact-finding mission to Central America and Panama. It is a carefully prepared trip on the highest level, at least from the economic and financial side. The heads of the Export-Import Bank and the new Latin-American Development Loan Fund, high officials of the Treasury and State Departments and some specialists make up the impressive group.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The Senate passed and sent to the House today a $155,000,000 bill to give subsidies and bonuses to the ailing mining industry. The vote was 70 to 12.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Congressional investigators told Bernard Goldfine today that it was obvious he had received preferred treatment from Federal agencies.

TRENTON, July 11 -- Officials representing nine Hudson County municipalities and the City of Newark said today they opposed a tax moratorium this year that has been asked by nine railroads operating in New Jersey.

Argentina defeated the United States, 2 1/2 -- 1 1/2, in the first round of the finals of the world student chess tournament at Varna yesterday, according to a report received through Bulgarian news sources.

LONDON, July 11 -- Against a background of a falling Treasury bill rate and expectations of a reduction in the bank rate, British Government securities led a general advance in the stock market today.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 11 -- The Clearview Stables' Egyptian Princess from Winthrop, Me., handled by Earle Avery, scored a five-length victory in 2:05 1/5 in the $24,150 United States Harness Writers' Trot at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 11 (AP) -- A spectacular spill marred the fifth race at Monmouth Park today. George Gross was thrown heavily when his mount, Lady Glade, clipped the heels of Prince Chasmar and fell at the eighth pole.

LONDON, July 11 -- Delegates at the closing sessions of the Seventh International Cancer Congress were told today that chemicals that control cellular heredity and function hold out the highest hopes for a cancer cure.
WILTON, Me., July 11 (AP) -- Bernard Goldfine's Wilton Woolen Company was auctioned last month and brought $375,000, it was learned yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, July 11 (AP) -- Mme. Chiang Kai-shek visited the bedside of an old war comrade today and, like hospital visitors the world over, she tried to cheer up Maj. Gen. Claire Lee Chennault, who is fighting cancer.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 11 -- Oddly enough, the United Nations has in some respects thrived on the crises of the past few years. Not that the U. N. can in any sense yet be considered even an approximately effective approach to world government.

HAVANA, July 11 -- Jose Fernando Cossio, acting head of the Federacion Estudiantil Universitaria, the student organization of the University of Havana, was arrested by Cuban police yesterday at the home of his father-in-law in the Vedado residential district.
The Greek Government denied yesterday that Premier Konstantin Karamanlis had said in Switzerland Thursday there was a good chance that a three-nation conference on the Cyprus question would be held.

The Crane Company has named William B. Gilmour general manager of merchandising, it was announced yesterday. In a reorganization of the sales division, Darrell R. Nordwall was named general manager of sales and William O. Brown, vice president for sales.

DAYTON, Ohio, July 11 (AP) -- The Air Materiel Command, the Air Force's contracting organization with headquarters here, announced today the awarding of more than $60,000,000 in contracts. In the last three days the command has awarded about $435,000,000 in contracts.
The J. I. Case Company is expanding in the European market with the acquisition of a majority interest in Societe Francaise, at Vierzon, 100 miles from Paris.

DETROIT, July 11 (AP) -- A court hearing was promised today over a Detroit Arts Commission ban on the appearance of a ballad singer who once refused to answer questions before the House Un-American Activities Committee.

SUMMER furniture, regardless of how weather-resistant it is said to be, requires some pampering to keep it in good condition. The following simple care methods are suggested by the makers of Spic and Span for outdoor furniture of various types of material:
WITH ALGERIAN REBEL FORCES, July 10 -- The Army of National Liberation, which has held the French Army at bay for three years, hopes for a major battle against the French soon.
TRENTON, July 11 -- Many of the nation's largest industrial concerns, apparently undaunted by the recession, are building or expanding research facilities in New Jersey.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- A spokesman for Americans for Democratic Action said today that President Eisenhower spoke with a timid, confused voice on civil rights enforcement.

CHICAGO, July 11 (UPI) -- Dan Sikes, a Florida law student cutting his summer-school classes to play golf, advanced to the final of the national public links tournament today. He shot par golf for thirty-four holes to beat Bob Patterson, a Portland, Ore., stevedore, 3 and 2.

Net asset value of Institutional Investors Mutual Fund reached a record high of $174.77 a share on June 30, William H. Harder, president, reported yesterday. This compared with values of $163.31 a year before and $163.82 on March 31.

Robert Moses, in his capacity as chairman of the Mayor's Slum Clearance Committee, took advantage of the opportunity offered the other day by the ground-breaking ceremony at Luna Park Houses, Coney Island, to make a few salient comments on the rebirth of Coney in particular and community planning in general. He hailed the newly emerging Coney Island as a substantial, dignified, permanent year-round residential community and as a center of orderly, seasonal large-scale public recreation.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, July 11 -- One of the highlights of an ambitious Holland Festival this year is a posthumous opera by Sem Dresden, a Netherlands composer. It is called "Francois Villon" and is an attempt to capture the essence of the fifteenth century Frenchman who was rake, thief, assassin and poet.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 11 -- United States Ambassador Robert M. McClintock reaffirmed today the United States pledge to support the Lebanese Government.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 11 (AP) -- Representatives of General Motors and the United Auto Workers met this afternoon to discuss grievances that had touched off a twenty-four-hour unauthorized strike at General Motors giant Ternstedt plant here.
GENEVA, July 11 -- Neutral Switzerland announced her intention today to equip the Swiss Army with tactical nuclear weapons.

The United Nations Trusteeship Council has been taking time this week for a "general debate on political, economic, social and educational conditions in the trust territory of New Guinea administered by Australia." This is part of the Council's regular job under the U. N. Trusteeship system. It is a job that is being better done today than ever before.

NEW DELHI, India, July 11 -- A sharp difference f opinion has cropped up within the Indian Communist party over an important business deal entered into by the Communist-administered state government in Kerala with an Indian industrialist.

A Bronx policeman was held in $7,500 bail yesterday on charges of stealing six pistols from the Bronx office of the Police Department property clerk. He was also charged with possessing two other weapons stolen from a policeman's locker in 1955.
A split between Democratic and Liberal party leaders in Brooklyn came to light yesterday. It could cost the Democrats their chance of unseating Representative Francis J. Dorn, a Republican.
CHICAGO, July 11 -- Anthony Joseph Accardo, also known as Joe Batters, is, in a very special sense of the term, "an organization man."

WESTBURY, L. I., July 11 -- George P. Monaghan, State Harness Racing Commissioner, reserved decision today on the motion of Del Miller, the leading stake-winning driver at Roosevelt Raceway, for reversal of his suspension.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 11 (UPI) -- A gunman killed a Turkish policeman today -- the eighth such killing in the last twenty-four hours.

The Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine will conduct a series of four weekly forums beginning tomorrow on "Science, Religion and Education." Each session will convene at 5 P. M. in the Cathedral Choir School.
NEWARK, July 11 -- Plans for Newark's first low-rent apartments for elderly persons have been approved by the Public Housing Administration.
CLEVELAND, July 11 -- The Spingarn Medal for the highest achievement of an American Negro in 1957 was presented tonight to the nine Little Rock children and their adviser, Mrs. L. C. (Daisy) Bates.
An attempt to keep the American Communist party from endorsing the execution of Imre Nagy failed at a meeting of the party's national committee late in June.
CAMP KILMER, N. J., July 11 -- On the double and with white hats trimly squared, 109 salty youngsters jogged onto this Army post this morning to spend a land-locked week-end.

CLEVELAND, July 11 (UPI) -- Cyrus Eaton made a new attack on the House Un-American Activities Committee today. He wrote that some of its members were "not noted for their intellectual depth or high ethical standards."

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The Senate, obviously prompted by the Adams-Goldfine controversy, dusted off an eleven-month-old House-approved code of ethics for Government officials today and adopted it without debate.

HALIFAX, N. S., July 11 (Canadian Press) -- A Halifax company is about ready to attempt to refloat the 29,500-ton Liberian ore carrier Cosmic, which is grounded on a shoal in the Gulf of St. Lawrence.

The annual meeting of the Penn-Texas Corporation, delayed by litigation since May 5 from reconvening to elect a board, will be held on Monday. A decision by New York State Supreme Court Justice Henry Epstein yesterday cleared the way.

MIAMI BEACH, July 11 -- The Rabbinical Council of America announced here today the establishment of a central rabbinic court to deal with problems of domestic relations involving the religious marriage and divorce of members of the Jewish Orthodox faith.
As chairman of Young Citizens for Paul Williams, I must comment on your article of July 2 in connection with Nelson Rockefeller's announced candidacy for the Republican nomination for Governor.

ADEN, July 11 -- A potentially dangerous situation has been left on the border between Yemen and Lahej state in the Aden protectorate by Britain's "dismissal" of the Sultan, Sir Ali Bin Abdul Karim, and by the defection of a large part of the Lahej armed forces.
Stocks advanced on a broad front yesterday, sending The New York Times rail and combined averages to new highs for the year.
The United States Court of Appeals upheld without dissent yesterday the conviction of Rudolph Ivanovich Abel as a Soviet spy.

Paolino Gerli and Francis Gerli of Gerli Co., Inc., raw silk importers which own and operate Cheney Bros., Inc., have purchased 72,300 shares, or a 13 per cent stock interest, in the Collins Aikman Corporation from Robin International, Inc., import-export concern.
BERLIN, July 11 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev said today he would press his campaign against Yugoslav "opportunism and revisionism" to a victorious end.
VERSAILLES, France, July 11 -- The first debutante ball for American and French debutantes unfolded tonight in the seventeenth-century setting of the Orangerie at the Palace of Versailles.
STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., July 11 (UPI) -- A body found in the Housatonic River was identified today as Mrs. Roger W. Cutler Jr., 41 years old, wife of a Boston banker.
Switzerland's decision to provide nuclear weapons for her armed services continues a trend that has become more and more pronounced since the United States atomic monopoly was broken.

Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney has resolved a year-long dispute with his third wife, the former Eleanor Searle, with a $2,000,000 cash payment to her. She also will get property that will bring the total settlement to nearly $3,000,000.

The hard-hitting fighter, Gaspar (Indian) Ortega, met the boxer, Mickey Crawford, at Madison Square Garden last night. The slugger came out on top. Ortega gained a split decision in a fast-moving welter-weight bout.

In The Times of July 7 C. L. Sulzberger notes in his column that "revisionism" is a new crime in the Marxist lexicon. May I take issue with him to the extent of observing that the word has a somewhat longer history.

NEWPORT, R. I., July 11 -- Vim will sail against Columbia and Weatherly will race Easterner tomorrow in the opening match races of a summer-long contest to determine which twelve-meter yacht will defend the America's Cup against the British challenger, Sceptre, off here in September.

TOKYO, July 8 -- A United States-leased shipyard in Japan's Inland Sea has set out to break its own world record for large-size ships. The Kure, Japan, shipyard division of National Bulk Carriers, Inc., has started work on a 103,000-deadweight-ton oil tanker that will eclipse in size six 85,000-ton vessels of similar type constructed at the Kure works for American and Greek owners.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 11 -- The Tennessee Senate convicted Raulston Schoolfield of Chattanooga today on three articles of impeachment and removed him from office as judge of the Hamilton County Criminal Court.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 11 (AP) -- Two United States soldiers who got too gay and tried to shinny up the flagpoles at the Soviet Pavilion of the World's Fair have been sent back to their units in West Germany for disciplinary action.
A dead heat involving Bill's Sky Boy and Bureaucracy marked the feature race at Jamaica yesterday. At the conclusion of the mile-and-a-fur-long event this pair could not be separated by the camera.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- President Eisenhower returned to the White House today from Ottawa and a series of informal talks intended to reverse the recent deterioration of United States-Canadian relations.
ST. LOUIS, July 12 (UPI) -- Sam Jones increased his league-leading strikeout total to 108 tonight in pitching the St. Louis Cardinals to a 6 -- 2 triumph over the Philadelphia Phillies.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 11 -- The full Cabinet has approved the proposed $4,000,000 loan from the World Bank for electric power development it was announced today. The loan, which would have a four-year term, has been approved "in principal" by the bank, the announcement said.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., July 11 (AP) -- Federal Judge Albert V. Bryan has given twenty-nine oil companies charged with price fixing until Sept. 10 to prepare arguments for transfer of their trial to Oklahoma.
The Board of Health was told yesterday that a "sneak attack" was being made, while consumers were away on vacation, to end the dating of milk containers.

HARTFORD, July 11 (AP) -- The Government was upheld in Federal District Court here today in a case involving a West Hartford school teacher's will that named as ultimate beneficiaries her two brothers in Germany.
The Children's Health Service, founded eighty-five years ago by the New York Diet Kitchen Association, will be the beneficiary of an anniversary cocktail dance in the Pierre ballroom on Nov. 13.
MOSCOW, July 11 -- The leaders of the Soviet Union selected Mikhail A. Suslov, one of their number, to act as their spokesman at a diplomatic reception tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- Senator Olin D. Johnston of South Carolina asked for a full count today of the earth satellite and rockets of Operation Vanguard.

Anything that adds convenience to our New York City transit system helps the system and the public. Hence we welcome the "new" subway entrance in the Times Square island just south of Forty-third Street.

Ranking line officers of the Fire Department will be "out" if they tolerate infractions of the departmental rules. Moreover, firemen found guilty of violating such major regulations as fighting on duty will be summarily dismissed.

Canada's efforts to become less dependent on the United States in trade made progress in May. Her exports to Continental Europe totaled $91,037,000, more than double the $44,484,000 in the same month last year.
LONDON, July 11 -- Paul Robeson twice refused today to say whether he was a member of the Communist party.

MONTAUK POINT, L. I., July 11 -- Few persons in this fishing community derive greater satisfaction from a day's work than Frank Tuma, a broad-shouldered, 59-year-old man who is known as the social director of Montauk Point.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The Senate sped to passage today a $2,475,000,000 omnibus housing bill going far beyond President Eisenhower's recommendations.

An Associated Press dispatch printed in The Times of July 6 reported that I had said that I would now go to the Soviet Union if my expenses were paid. While true as to fact, it most ungraciously misrepresented the spirit of my statement to the A. P.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 11 -- One hundred and five more trials of participants in the anti-Communist revolution of 1956 will be held, or are being held in Budapest now, the United Nations Special Committee on Hungary reported today.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 11 -- The largest summer trade show in the history of the nation's housewares industry ended today on a note of optimism among leaders in the field.

PARIS, July 11 -- The principal military participants in the military civilian dissident movement in Algeria were among the men named for promotion or decoration today by the Government of Gen. Charles de Gaulle.
The immediate withdrawal of pickets from three Belgian Line piers on Manhattan's West Side was urged yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association.
One man was killed and two other persons were injured yesterday afternoon after being trapped between a bus and a car at Thirty-third Street and Fifth Avenue.
May I please make a few comments on your leading editorial of July 6 entitled "Is Foreign Aid Unpopular?"

IN the past seventy-nine years, Vice Admiral Emory Scott Land has covered a lot of ground. Born in Colorado, he attended the University of Wyoming, acquired a lifelong passion for football and enlisted in the Rough Riders in 1898 before entering the Naval Academy.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, July 12 (AP) -- The Ceylonese Cabinet has approved a four-point plan intended to end three months of communal rioting in this island nation by allowing some use of the Tamil language, a reliable source said today.

I am a member of Vassar '58. After reading Miss Nielsen's article I had a reaction similar to that of Juliet Furman, Barnard '32, who declared that Vassar girls fail to realize the needs of our society (Letters, June 29). My first impulse was to write in defense of my class.

The Senate recently approved a bill to create a National Cultural Center in Washington. Discussion surrounding this measure concerned only the site and the financing. The concept itself was unchallenged. We welcome this action and wish similar success to the companion bill which awaits House action. The creation of such a center would indicate an overdue awareness by Congress of the magnitude of public interest in the arts.

Electronic automation for Coast Guard search and rescue operations will begin tomorrow with the installation of a huge computer at the service's eastern area command in the Custom House. The machine will become fully operational in another week.

THE last collection of Geoffrey Household's short stories was called "Tales of Adventurers." The same title would be equally suitable to the president volume -- or indeed to the entire canon of Mr. Household's work.

GENEVA, July 12 -- One day in the coming months a mushroom cloud can be expected to rise over the sands of the southwestern section of the Sahara Desert. The cloud will symbolize the entry of a new member into the exclusive membership of the Atomic Club -- France.

NOW that warm summer weather has arrived the paved terrace or screened porch will be a popular gathering place for family and friends. But if the area is in full view of the neighbors, much of the pleasure of outdoor living may evaporate.

Summer clearance sales were on last week as merchants sought to reduce their stocks. Cool and rainy weather did not help sales, which generally dipped around 5 per cent under the like 1957 week. Inventories of major household appliances are considerably higher than a year ago.

The new Navy frigate Farragut, first of three of this class to be constructed at the Quincy, Mass., shipyard of the Bethlehem Steel Company, will be launched Friday afternoon. Actually a large destroyer, a vessel of this class is designed to serve as the leader of a destroyer group.

AS recently as three years ago most people, on hearing the names Hartack, Shoemaker and Valenzuela, probably would have associated them with, respectively, a World War I biscuit, leather and a South American country. Today many would easily place them as three of the top jockeys on American race tracks.
A study of teacher salaries in suburban communities over the last twenty years shows that teachers have not fared so well as other groups.
Jobs are opening up at the top level. Executives are being sought by many concerns in many types of industry. There is special emphasis on research and development, marketing and planning.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., July 11 -- A milestone in the nation's defense program was reached this week-end with the formal opening of a $40,000,000 plant here for production of the Atlas Intercontinental Ballistic Missile.

Alan M. Scaife, president of the board of trustees of the University of Pittsburgh, arrived at the New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens, yesterday, after a twoweek observation of the Soviet educational system.

MONTAUK POINT, L. I., July 12 -- Whiting Evans is a 52-year-old insurance agency supervisor who reads palms, likes to design and wear "crazy" hats and understands the habits of swordfish better than most broadbill addicts here.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 12 -- Jimmy Cruise drove six straight winners at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Cruise, a 40-year-old driver from Westbury, was the first to achieve such a record in harness racing in New York.
CHICAGO, July 12 (AP) -Dudley L. Simms of Charleston, W. Va., became the fortysecond president of the Lions International today at the close of the service club's convention here.
GIBSON ISLAND, Md., July 12 (AP) -- A New York and a New Jersey skipper tied for first place today after two races in a three-race regatta for the Star Class championship of Chesapeake Bay.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 12 (Reuters) -- Seven persons were killed today as mounting violence between Greek and Turkish Cypriotes threatened to topple this British colony into fullscale civil war.
William Wyer is a leading railroad man who cheerfully accepts the fact that a bus is the best way for a visitor to reach his Upper Montclair, N. J., office from New York.

TO many the most meaningful aspect of murder (factual or fictional) is the problem of motive: what can drive people (in other respects often disquietingly like ourselves) to this ultimate violation of human existence? Two new books offer absorbing efforts to analyze and classify the motives for killing.

A Nationalist Chinese Government employe was robbed outside the Port Authority Bus Terminal shortly before 6 A. M. yesterday. Three men were arrested and held in $15,000 bail each.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Treasurer's checks, cashier's checks, certified checks -- Congressional investigators have been talking about them a lot this week, and Bernard Goldfine a little.

GENERAL DE GAULLE wrote of his war years under the title of Memoires de Guerre" There were two parts, both popular in France. "L'Appel" dealing with l940-42. "L'unite" for 1942 44. Local rights to the pair naturally were snapped up, and in 1955 Viking brought out part one as "The Call to Honor."

FOR THIS WEEK: Divide and replant overcrowded lily of the valley patches. . . . Pick raspberries and blueberries before the Birds do. . . . Remember to syringe plant foliage when watering terrace boxes. . . . Keep faded flowers picked off pansy, geranium, snapdragon plants. . . . Check local conservation lists before transplanting any wildlings. . . .

A class of thirteen men was graduated yesterday from the Webb Institute of Naval Architecture at Glen Cove, L. I. It was the school's sixty-second annual commencement. The thirteen men received Bachelor of Science degrees. Four Navy lieutenants received master's degrees.

MOSCOW, July 10 -- A young man asked the Soviet party and youth leaders this week why they did not stop "playing revolution" and call off their "foolish'' fight against the jet set and rock 'n' rollers in big cities.

A SEVEN-MEMBER quadricentennial Commission has been established in Florida to make plans for what will be a seven-year-long celebration of the state's founding 400 years ago. The commission's seven members will rotate the office of chairman, and a director will be hired to make plans for three celebrations which will follow a somewhat similar pattern to last year's Jamestown celebrations.

STOCKHOLM -- Nightclubs and an easing of restrictions on the public consumption of alcoholic drinks are new features among Sweden's tourist attractions this summer. Faced with increasing competition in the tourist trade, Swedish authorities have reluctantly abolished some of the strict rules which earlier limited night life to almost nothing.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 12 -- The first test flight of the Atlas intercontinental ballistic missile with all three of its engines operating was canceled shortly after 2 o'clock this afternoon here after the dramatic moment of ignition.

AMITYVILLE, L. I., July 12 -- Rough seas, churned up by a twenty-five to thirty-mile-anhour so'wester, caused some anxious moments this afternoon as the annual two-day invitation regatta of the Narrasketuck Yacht Club got under way.

PARIS -- An unusual type of sight-seeing tour has been organized in France by the French National Railroads for this summer's visitors. These are one-to-five-day trips, limited to either Roman architecture or relics of ancient Rome, Renaissance castles or the prehistoric caveman paintings, or even, in a more limited and original field, to ancient fortified feudal churches in the Oise River Valley near Paris.

The Navy last week demonstrated the embryo of an electronic computer named the Perceptron which, when completed in about a year, is expected to be the first non-living mechanism able to "perceive, recognize and identify its surroundings without human training or control."

The New York Public Library's Spencer Collection of illustrated books and manuscripts in the Fifth Avenue and Fortysecond Street building will close on Friday for staff vacations. It will reopen in mid-September.

GENEVA, July 12 -- Signature of a final agreement on compensation to be paid by the United Arab Republic to shareholders of the Suez Canal Company was postponed indefinitely today when differences arose at the last minute between the two sides.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -(UPI) -- Five United States farm experts left here today to conduct a thirty-four-day study of Soviet agriculture.

CLEMMONS, N. C. -- Motorists touring North Carolina this summer -- and especially those with children -- will find ample room to stretch their legs in the 1,100 rolling acres of the relatively new Tanglewood Park.

HOMESTEAD, Fla., July 12 -- Although undefeated in eight rounds of the national junior chess championship tournament, Raymond Weinstein of Brooklyn College was tied for the lead at 7 -- 1 today by Larry Remlinger of Long Beach, Calif.

TORONTO, July 12 -- The United States Davis Cup tennis team qualified for the final round of the American zone today with its third successive victory over Canada. Barry MacKay of Dayton, Ohio, and Sam Giammalva of Houston settled matters in the semifinal series by defeating Robert Bedard and Don Fontana in the doubles at the Toronto Cricket, Skating and Curling Club.

THE gardener who moves into a new home during midsummer need not put up with bare ground -there is still time for planting. He can get immediate pleasure from his garden as well as prepare for the work ahead.

C. is causing consternation among its rivals, the Columbia Broadcasting System and the National Broadcasting Company, who have had the afternoons to themselves on a cross-country basis.

THE 1958 yearbook of the Brooklyn Friends School, published by the senior class, departs sharply from the usual pattern. It is an original production, and photography makes the difference.

A lack of Summer merchandise has caused stores to plan early back-to-school promotions in order to stimulate sales. Resident buying sources say that windows featuring school apparel will be seen by the end of July or the first week of August.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 12 -- Howard G. Seymour's Mutiny won the Resolute Class honors today in the interclub championship series sponsored the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.

EVERY country represented at the Brussels World's Fair is making a concentrated effort to put its best foot forward on its national days. Though the spirit is friendly the competition is keen.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 12 (Reuters) -- Prince Norodom Sihanouk, whose Socialist party won a landslide victory in the March elections, will head the new Cambodian Government as Premier.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I. July 12 -- Changing weather dealt a fleet of 109 racing boats three solid blows in rapid succession on Long Island Sound today. The weather caused extensive, but not serious damage to the sloops in the Yacht Racing Association regatta.

Johnson states that there was no special significance in the Senate's swift adoption on Friday of a code of ethics for Government officials that was approved by the House eleven months ago and has been lying around ever since. Senator Johnson is an ethical man and when he says anything we usually believe it.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 12 (AP) -- Aloysius Cardinal Stepinac's physician reported today he was continuing his rapid recovery from a leg operation, but an American specialist was being called for a consultation.

CHICAGO, July 12 (AP) -Bernburgoo, a 19-1 shot, put on a blazing finish to upset Round Table and win the $85,000 Warren Wright Memorial Handicap at Arlington Park.

The fighting in Lebanon, now in its third month, seemed to grow hotter last week. But on the political front there was talk of a compromise that might end the strife. The feeling was that if a compromise came about it would amount to a setback for the proWestern forces in the Middle East.

MILLIONS of television viewers unable to visit such exotic locales as the Jivaro headhunting preserves in Brazil are happy to settle for "Bold Journey," an American Broadcasting Company network series; "I Search for Adventure" and "Golden Voyage," regionally distributed throughout the nation, and "Seven League Boots," a local Los Angeles show.

ABERCROMBIE, Benjamin and Christopher are off on another adventure -- their sixth in print. In this episode the look-alike triplets hear helicopters humming overhead and are so fascinated that they decide to build one of their own. This involves, first, gaining a lot of serious knowledge about helicopters from library books, and then, scrap materials from generous store-keeper Mr. Finney.

An ardent practicing yachtsman currently wearing the two stars on his white cap signifying a vice commodore is largely responsible for a volume entitled "Medical Emergencies in Pleasure Boating," Vice Commodore Nicholas C. Leone of the Corinthian Y. C., Washington, when not afloat is a physician.

NEWARK, July 12 -- The Parking Authority announced today the completion of plans for its first facility in the city's downtown area.

ENGLEWOOD, N. J., July 12 -- The First Presbyterian Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Betty Lea Lamons to Malcolm Branson Lowe Jr. The Rev. Bertram Atwood and the Rev. Dr. Vernon Broyles Jr. officiated at the ceremony.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -The T-shirt industry has decided to change its sizing system to commercial standard dress sizes for women.

ALBANY, July 12 (AP) -Only 212 of 900 so-called nursing homes in New York State provide necessary nursing services, a state commission said today.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 12 -- If Ramsay Burton has anything to do about it this town soon will have a clubhouse for its retired folk.
PARIS, July l2 (AP) -- Premier Charles de Gaulle ordered today faster action to revise France's. Constitution and moved to strengthen his control over the armed forces.

Department store sales in the nation in the week ended July 5 were 1 per cent above those in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board has reported. The figure compares with a drop of 4 per cent, revised, in the preceding week.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Events this week arising from the House subcommittee inquiry into the relations between Bernard Goldfine's business enterprises and the Government regulatory agencies, and also into his gifts of value, more firmly established Sherman Adams' intimacy with Goldfine as a heavy liability for the President, his Administration and the Republican party in general. In earlier subcommittee sessions, Republican politicians had feared this consequence but hoped it might not follow.

Cotton futures were irregular last week, but closed with all deliveries on higher ground. At the close of trading on Friday, active contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 3 to 14 points for the week. The best gains were made by the more distant positions.
