Norman Cardinal Gilroy, Archbishop of Sydney, Australia, presided with Cardinal Spellman yesterday at the 10 A. M. solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
HOMESTEAD, Fla., July 13 -- Undefeated in nine rounds, Raymond Weinstein, 17-year-old sophomore from Brooklyn College, emerged today as the new junior champion of the United States Chess Federation.
GOTEBORG, Sweden, July 13 (AP) -- Ingemar Johansson, Sweden's undefeated heavyweight champion, tonight knocked out Germany's Heinz Neuhaus in 2:56 of the fourth round of a non-title ten-round bout.
BUENOS AIRES, July 13 -- Government leaders have told Washington economic fact-finders here they are eager to open Argentine petroleum development to foreign capital.

PANAMA, July 13 -- President Ernesto de la Guardia Jr. told Dr. Milton Eisenhower today that Panama urgently needed financing for increasing production to meet the problem of her rapidly mounting population.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 13 -- The Screen Actors Guild will make another attempt to settle privately a controversy with the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists involving jurisdiction over a small area of taped television commercials. The federation has asked for a National Labor Relations Board election.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (UPI) -- The Census Bureau reported today that it would begin a series of six censuses next January to gather statistics on American life.

LONDON, July 13 -- The impact of United States and other Western aid programs on Ceylon's faltering economy may prove a decisive factor in the coming struggle to hold the island nation within the West's sphere of influence.

BAASTAD, Sweden, July 13 (AP) -- Ashley Cooper of Australia, the Wimbledon champion, and Mrs. Heather Brewer Segal of South Africa each rallied today to win the singles finals of the Baastad tennis tournament.
THREE model apartments opening today do the amateur decorator two favors: they suggest ways of handling space in problem-size rooms and indulge her fondness for pastels.
LONDON, Monday, July 14 (UPI) -- The British Broadcasting Corporation reported today the pro-Western government of Iraq had been overthrown by a coup d'etat.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- A Federal Trade Commission examiner recommended dismissal of charges today that the Scott Paper Company, Chester, Pa., violated antitrust laws by acquiring three other companies between 1951 and 1954.

It looked like more trouble for the Yankees when Jim Landis lofted a two-run homer, bringing the Chicago White Sox even in the fifth inning of the second game at the Stadium yesterday. Al Lopez' Pale Hose had captured the opener, 7 -- 4.
LONDON, July 13 (Reuters) -- Two leading British Sunday newspapers criticized today President Eisenhower's move for legislation to deny passports to United States citizens on political grounds.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Administration and Congressional leaders are expressing new optimism about the chances for the approval this year of Federal aid to science education.

Capital expenditures by the petroleum industry in the United States and abroad last year aggregated $11,000,000,000, an increase of 12 per cent over 1956, according to the "Financial Analysis of the Petroleum Industry," published today by the Chase Manhattan Bank. The survey was prepared by Frederick G. Coqueron, an analyst in the bank's petroleum department.
Three persons drowned yesterday, and two died in an automobile accident in the metropolitan area.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 13 -- About 3,500 librarians and library trustees began registering here today for the seventy-seventh annual American Library Association convention, which opens tomorrow and will last a week.
WEST ORANGE, N. J., July 13 -- Marco Cutrone enjoyed his 100th birthday celebration today with champagne, a full-course dinner and some lively music at Crystal Lake Casino.

LENINGRAD, U. S. S. R., July 13 -- Adlai E. Stevenson attracted considerable attention today during a sight-seeing tour of this Baltic seaport. His entourage, looking much like an election campaign party back in the United States, streamed through historic churches and palaces amid a bevy of photographers and attentive officials sent from Moscow.
A stricter enforcement policy against marine violators of the city's anti-smoke laws was announced yesterday by Dr. Leonard Greenburg, City Commissioner of Air Pollution Control.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- The United States was warned today that it must step up its medical research.
NEXT to the backstage mechanics of the theatre there are few things more fascinating than the behind-the-scenes derring-do of a celebrated restaurant.

Through the Food and Agriculture Organization the United Nations has received an impressive and heartening report on the growth of poultry production in Southeast Asia. Thailand, Malaya, Singapore and Borneo are the most immediately affected. In Singapore, for example, the flock had risen in ten years from half a million to twenty-four million.
THE Most Reverend and Right Honorable Geoffrey Francis Fisher, Archbishop of Canterbury and Primate of All England, completely belies his austere and somewhat frightening titles.

GUANTANAMO BAY, Cuba, July 13 -- Rear Admiral Robert B. Ellis, commander of the United States naval base here, announced tonight that evacuation of the twenty-nine kidnapped United States servicemen still held by the Cuban rebels would begin tomorrow afternoon.
Eastern railroads warned yesterday of possible bankruptcies if Congress passed a pending bill to liberalize unemployment insurance and pensions for railroad workers.
New York State's adoption laws must be tightened to reduce the "gray market" in babies, three experts contended here yesterday.

LENOX, Mass., July 13 -- The Mozart week-end of the Berkshire Festival concluded this afternoon with the most interesting of the three concerts. The program was divided between Charles Munch and Hugh Ross, and the latter, with the Festival Chorus and a fine group of soloists, conducted several seldom-heard choral works.

EYDIE GORME and Steve Lawrence were off to a happy start last night as the summer replacements for Steve Allen's program on Channel 4. Theirs was an hour of light and youthful variety, nothing very ambitious but a show enjoying tasteful and imaginative touches.

AMAGANSETT, L. I., July 13 -- Members of the Amagansett Village Improvement Society will conduct their annual fund-raising project on Tuesday to support the Amagansett Libary, the Scholarship Fund, the care of the railroad station and the village's stately elms.
New York City enchanted twenty-three planners and architects from abroad yesterday as easily as it overwhelms most tourists.
The skies were a soft, light blue, the streets were silent, the sun beamed as the temperature reached a balmy 81.8 degrees at the day's high and the city's waters slapped lazily against its shores.

NOT since the golden days of Earle (Greasy) Neale have the Philadelphia Eagles had a coach to compare with Lawrence (Buck) Shaw, the new birdwatcher of the eyrie. Like the ineffable Neale, Buck is an imaginative operative who is held in profound respect in the football business. The handsome strategist from California formally checked into Philadelphia last week.
AMAGANSETT, L. I., July 13 -- This small resort community was the scene of an ocelot picnic over the week-end.

NEWPORT, R. I., July 13 -- Because of a lack of wind, the second set of match races in the preliminary trials to select a defender for the America's Cup had to be called off today before the twelve-meter sloops could complete a shortened windward-leeward course of ten miles.

The development of a new synthetic rubber which is said to make tires longer wearing was announced over the week-end by the Texas-United States Chemical Company. The company, jointly owned by the Texas Company and the United States Rubber Company, said the manufacturing process involved the mechanical mixing of carbon black, principal reinforcing agent for rubber, with synthetic rubber latex during production.

Recent talks by three Protestant leaders highlight a dilemma of religion in society: the moral imperatives set forth in policy statements versus what one termed "the righteous complacency" of many churchgoers.
The Transit Authority will change the time schedule of its reserved-seat express to the Playland Station in Rockaway, beginning today.
CHICAGO, July 13 (AP) -- Eruptions like volcanoes may be creating a relatively hot time on the cold planet Jupiter.

Mid-Manhattan merchants warned yesterday that "the continued indecision" among city agencies on plans for off-street parking was leading to a large-scale loss of business to suburban shopping centers.

The appointments of Edward J. Pierce as a trustee of the Savings Banks Life Insurance Fund for a four-year term beginning July 1, and of Thomas H. Hawks to a second term of four years as trustee were announced over the week-end by George A. Mooney, Superintendent of Banks.
ST. LOUIS, July 13 (AP) -- The hitting of Bill Mazeroski and Bob Skinner paced the Pittsburgh Pirates today in a 10-8 and 8-6 double-header sweep over the St. Louis Cardinals.

MOTHERS who are unable to control their preschool children usually had a "stormy relationship" with their own parents. Their feelings of hostility often were translated into a drive to dominate both their husbands and their children.
The Fund for the Republic has published a three-part analysis of United States policy concerning the Soviet Union.

The Republic of Panama plans to offer $26,000,000 of external bonds through an underwriting group managed by Lehman Brothers, it was announced over the week-end. The issue will be registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission soon.
A police headquarters for three public housing projects in Brooklyn has been set up by the New York City Housing Authority.
PITTSBURGH, July 13 -- The Soviet Union and its people have dedicated themselves to higher education with "deadly seriousness."

LOS ANGELES, July 13 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers whipped the Cincinnati Redlegs twice today. Five home runs and their two youngest pitchers, Stan Williams and Bob Giallombardo, enabled the Dodgers to triumph, 3 -- 0 and 3 -- 2.
Advertising and marketing men, most of whom are keeping a tight rein on expenses, are showing increased interest in closed-circuit television as an anti-recession tool.
Leonard W. Hall moved yesterday to check the speed of the bandwagon drive of his chief rival for the Republican nomination for Governor.
Plans for a new apartment building in the Sutton Place section of Manhattan have been announced in connection with the sale of 1052-56 First Avenue and 407-13 East Fifty-seventh Street.
The award of scholarships to thirty-two colleges and universities for 127 young men was announced yesterday by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation of New York City.
DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, Monday, July 14 -- The Baghdad radio announced today that the Iraqi Army leadership had overthrown King Faisal and proclaimed a republic in Iraq.

HAMBURG, Germany, July 13 (AP) -- Harvard's lightweight eight, winner of the Thames Cup at the recent Royal Henley Regatta, went down to defeat for the second straight day today, finishing second to the Hamburg Rowing Club.
GENEVA, July 13 -- While refusing to commit itself diplomatically, the United States is proceeding on the assumption that the current atomic tests in the Pacific may be the last it will conduct.

WETHERSFIELD, Conn., July 13 (AP) -- Jack Burke Jr., apparently recovered from a wrist operation, today captured the $3,500 top prize in the Insurance City open golf tournament. It was his first major victory since he won the Professional Golfers Association and Masters titles in 1956.
More realistic accident-reduction programs were advocated yesterday by the President's Committee for Traffic Safety.
Lumber cargoes on the west-east intercoastal run supplied the only bright spot last week in an otherwise extremely dull ship charter market.
ALBANY, July 13 (AP) -- Provisions of a railroad bill before Congress could lead to total abandonment of commuter train service in the United States, Governor Harriman asserted today.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 13 -- Hopes for an early political compromise in the Lebanese crisis were dimmed a little today.

PARIS, July 13 -- Ten weeks before the New Delhi meeting of the International Monetary Fund, European observers have been struck by the impact of the United States recession on European credit policies.

ZURICH, Switzerland, July 13 -- All last week the run on bonds in Germany, started by the cut in the bank rate there from 3 1/2 to 3 per cent and the abolition of the Libkamark agitated the bond market in Zurich.

GENEVA, July 13 -- A final agreement was signed today on the compensation to be paid by the United Arab Republic to shareholders of the Universal Suez Canal Company. The canal was nationalized by an Egyptian Government decree on July 26, 1956.

LIME ROCK, Conn., July 13 -- One hundred and ten cars came here today for an afternoon of top-flight club racing under direction of the Long Island Sports Car Association. There were five events, all keenly contested.

Writing in the June issue of The Monthly Labor Review of the United States Department of Labor, Ewan Clague, Commissioner of Labor Statistics, has performed a public service. He has addressed himself to clearing up what is widely, if erroneously, referred to as a major "paradox" in the present recession. In the six months between October, 1957, and April, 1958, the seasonally adjusted rate of unemployment just about doubled.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 13 -- Patricia Stewart of Kew Gardens, Queens, seeded No. 2, captured the women's Eastern clay court tennis championship today. She defeated Carmen Lampe of Forest Hills, Queens seeded No. 3, by 6 -- 3, 8 -- 6, at the New Rochelle Tennis Club.

CLEVELAND, July 13 -- Roy Wilkins, executive secretary of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, advised Northern Negroes today to vote for liberal civil-rights supporters, regardless of party.
TWO hundred newspaper women are in New York to scout the couture collections this week and report on the state of the nation's fall fashions.

Scotland of the glens, bagpipes and wonderful "wee drapie" readily stirs familiar, if slightly misty, associations. Not so well known is the Scotland that currently is taking the high road to a new era of intensively varied industry.
TOKYO, July 9 -- A project to link Japan's two largest cities, Tokyo and Osaka, with the world's fastest rail service has started to take shape.

A YOUNG mother who had wheeled her baby daughter on lower Park Avenue and in streets roundabout -- they lived in a Park Avenue hotel -- came to realize that babies in strollers were rare in the neighborhood.

THESEUS, as most schoolboys should know, was the king who united Greece when Bronze Age legends had not yet merged with the dawn of history. One of the legends suggests that Poseidon, the earth-shaking god of the sea, was his father -- the aftermath of an amour that turns up often in classic mythology.

CHICAGO, July 12 (AP) -- Time appeared to be runing out on wheat futures traders this week while producers continued playing a waiting game with the biggest supply of winter wheat the nation has ever had.
Rising unemployment among the 38,248 Hungarians who were given asylum in the United States after the 1956 revolt is arousing concern among government and welfare agencies.
The elimination of racial prejudice and the achievement of world peace are goals "to which the future of the world is committed," the Rev. Dr. Robert D. Hershey said yesterday.

The Rev. Dr. A. J. Andeweg, pastor and head of the Mission Center for the Deaf in Beirut, Lebanon, said yesterday that his mission was "not touched at all" by the present Lebanese crisis. He asserted that newspaper reports had "somewhat exaggerated" the fighting in Lebanon.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 13 -- Richard S. Nye added the Greenwich Cup to his trophy case today when he won the new Indian Harbor Yacht Club race around Long Island with his 53-foot ocean-going yawl Carina.
MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 13 -- Dean Beman, 20, and his partner, Bill Buppert, 26, of Bethesda, Md., furnished a surprise by winning the Anderson Memorial best-ball golf tournament today.
Citations of 262 policemen for meritorious service were announced yesterday by Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Meade Alcorn, chairman of the Republican National Committee, will meet with members of the Administration and Republican Congressional campaign strategists on Wednesday. Problems of the coming elections will be discussed.
Verdi's stormy masterpiece, "Rigoletto," was performed against a background of real lightning and showers Saturday night in the Central Park Mall.

Mike Wallace's career as a television interviewer appears to be at the crossroads. Although he is under contract to the American Broadcasting Company until next May, his current series of interviews will conclude on Sunday evening.

ALPENA, Mich., July 13 (AP) -- The defending champion, Dyna, of Sturgeon Bay, Wis., capitalized on a fresh breeze to take the lead tonight in the 235-mile Port Huron-to-Mackinac Island yacht race across Lake Huron.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Monday, July 14 (UPI) -- The North Korean Communists demanded today that all United States troops and atomic weapons be withdrawn from South Korea immediately or the United Nations must face the "ensuing consequences."

SAN FRANCISCO, July 13 (AP) -- Felipe Alou singled home the winning run in the last of the ninth today as the San Francisco Giants gained a 6-5 victory over the Milwaukee Braves. The victory lifted the Giants over the Braves into the National League lead.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Representative Oren Harris disclosed today that he had signed subpoenas for four additional witnesses to appear before the subcommittee investigating the affairs of Bernard Goldfine.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 13 -- For close to five centuries this city has signalized great events in the life, the coronation or marriage of a king with an Ommegang. This afternoon one of those rare and richly traditional events was held to celebrate the World's Fair.
Much was made, and rightfully so, of the opposite-field homer Mickey Mantle slugged off Early Wynn as the Yankees blanked the Chicago White Sox, 5-0, last night at the Stadium.
LONDON, July 14 -- British exports fell sharply last month, but the wildcat strike of London dockworkers was largely responsible, the Board of Trade said today.
Jamaica fans who like to follow Jack Leonard had a pleasant day yesterday despite the rainy weather and sloppy track.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) -- The Senate Judiciary Committee today scheduled a hearing for Friday on the long-stalled nomination of Assistant Attorney General W. Wilson White to head the Justice Department's new Civil Rights Division.

BATON ROUGE, La., July 14 (UPI) -- Gov. Earl Long vetoed today a "seatmate" bill that would have permitted the first person in a double seat of a bus to decide if a person of another race could use the other seat.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., July 14 -- The Suffolk County Board of Supervisors criticized Governor Harriman today for the recently announced ten-year delay in completing the Long Island Expressway.

JUNEAU, Alaska, July 14 -- Delegate E. L. Bartlett returned to Alaska today to confer with party leaders before announcing whether he will be a Democratic candidate for Governor or for the United States Senate from the prospective forty-ninth state.

Wallpaper and harmonizing textiles make up the new exhibit at the Scalamandre Museum of Textiles, 57 East Fifty-seventh Street. The papers range from traditional flocked designs on silk in subdued colors to bright, stylized modern patterns.

Five hundred pints of blood were donated last Friday to the Red Cross regional blood bank here. The New York Naval Shipyard in Brooklyn gave 155 pints toward the total and 144 pints were from Pan American World Airways, 28-19 Bridge Plaza North, Long Island City, Queens.
OTTAWA, July 14 -- The largest financing in Canada's history was announced today by Donald Fleming, Minister of Finance. It involves the offer of new bonds for old ones amounting to $6,400,000,000.
Pacific Far East Line has moved to replace its entire subsidized fleet of nine ships.

LONDON, July 14 (Reuters) -- President Camille Chamoun of Lebanon has appealed to the United States, France and Britain to send troops to seal its frontier with Syria, a usually well-informed source said tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Western Union filed with the Federal Communications Commission today a new schedule raising press telegraph rates 7.1 per cent.

The Columbia Broadcasting System has assigned Barry Wood to produce the new country music show starring Jimmy Dean. The series, which will replace "Beat the Clock," will be televised from 2 to 2:30 P. M., Mondays through Fridays, beginning Sept. 15.

CLARK, N. J., July 14 -- A group of mothers has banded together to set up a library here with the help of Rahway. As a result, a few young former television addicts are finding that literacy can be fun.

Gamal Abdel Nasser made his views clear in his book, "The Philosophy of the Revolution." He said the nationalist aspirations of the Arab peoples of the Middle East could best be advanced through two great natural assets: strategic location and oil.

RYE, N. Y., July 14 -- Margo (Murr) Crow, defending the Founders Cup for the host American Yacht Club, held a quarter-point lead over Carolyn McCurdy of the Noroton (Conn.) Y. C. after two preliminary races in the Long Island Sound girls' sailing championship today.

Motorists who like to use the Brooklyn Bridge in getting to and from Manhattan will welcome the prediction of city officials that the current $4,748,389 reconstruction of the bridge's Manhattan plaza should be completed this fall. Originally mid-December had been the target date, but work has moved along so expeditiously that an October completion is now probable.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 14 (Reuters) -- The Baghdad radio broadcast early today the following Announcement No. 1.
A group of fire buffs presented a preview yesterday of a thirty-minute documentary color motion picture depicting the hazards of fire-fighting in New York.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Britain announced today that North American growers would be able to sell 75,000 long tons of apple to the United Kingdom during the 1958-59 season.
The revolt in Iraq caused most futures prices on the New York exchanges yesterday to advance.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday he would be glad to arrange a hearing on off-street parking for mid-Manhattan merchants.
OLD GREENWICH, Conn., July 14 -- With their husbands at work and their children deposited with baby-sitters, some seafaring suburban housewives took a holiday today at the Rocky Point Yacht Club.
International oils led the stock market down yesterday on news of the Iraqi revolt. Market values on the New York Stock Exchange contracted by an estimated total of $2,800,000,000.
The president of the New York Central Railroad assailed demands for continued state regulation of railroad passenger and commuter service yesterday. He called the demands unfounded and superficial.
A $2,000,000 shopping center, said to be the first such for Puerto Rico, is to go up near San Juan.

Every year Americans contribute to funds for cancer, heart disease and other drives. But no one really cares. The same families all over America seek every form of medical salvation once health is lost or threatened, no matter what the expense -- and the expense is often enormous.
MOFFETT FIELD, Calif., July 14 (AP) -- Government researchers displayed today for the first time a poor man's rocket for space research.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 14 -- The Iraqi revolt has changed the Baghdad Pact meeting in Turkey from a simple consultation before a more general meeting in London July 28 to a talk on self-preservation.
Nuri as-Said, who has escaped from the Iraqi rebel forces, had headed the Baghdad Government more often than any other man.

Iraq is a land gradually recovering from centuries of backwardness. Her prospects are excellent, but her people are not immune from the heady winds of extreme nationalism blowing in from other Arab countries.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 14 -- Willie Turnesa of Knollwood shot a three-under-par 68 in the rain at Whippoorwill today to take a three-stroke lead in the first round of the Ike golf tournament. The 43-year-old Turnesa, a former United States and British Amateur champion, won the same 72-hole test last year by eight strokes.
BERNARDSTON, Mass., July 14 -- There are days a trout fisherman ought to devote to getting large quantities of money for buying flies. This was one of them, but it is too late to think of that now.
" MIRROR, mirror on the wall -- what in tarnation will I wear next fall?"
WASHINGTON, July 14 -President Eisenhower told Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev today that Soviet-United States trade could be expanded without any formal actions by the United States Government.

PARIS, July 14 -- The French Army and the Moslems of Algeria marched together down the Champs Elysees today as the nation celebrated the 169th anniversary of the fall of the Bastille and the Revolution of 1789.
Better police protection at public housing projects was promised yesterday by William Reid, chairman of the City Housing Authority.
Gardeners in the metropolitan area who have been awaiting the season's first offensive by Japanese beetles can relax.

WARSAW, July 14 -- The delicately balanced relations between Poland's Communist Government and the Roman Catholic Church of this deeply religious nation are being subjected to rising strains and tensions.
CHICAGO, July 14 -- Construction of a welded aluminum girder type of bridge will be completed next month.
The annual theatre party and supper dance for the benefit of Boys Harbor, a center for needy youths in East Hampton, L. I., is being planned for Oct. 30.
The Jones and Laughlin Steel Corporation, the nation's fourth largest steel producer, increased earnings 143 per cent in the second quarter over the first.
PARIS, July 14 -- As Paris adds the finishing touches to the fall fashions that will be displayed at the end of July and the beginning of August, there is excited talk of a new designer.
The lack of enthusiasm evidenced by Congress concerning the renewal of the reciprocal trade agreements, in the midst of a world economic slump, seems an ominous portent for the future.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -At a White House ceremony today President Eisenhower presented the Medal of Freedom to Lewis L. Strauss, recently retired chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, "for exceptionally meritorious service in the interests of the security of the United States."

WHITE PLAINS, July 14 -- George Alpert, president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, accepted an invitation today to meet with Westchester County officials on July 22 in the county office building here to discuss ways of continuing rail service for commuters.
BOSTON, July 14 (AP) -- Ted Lepcio, a pinch hitter, drew a tenth-inning walk to force in Jackie Jensen for a 4-3 Boston Red Sox victory over Cleveland today.
The election of Daniel A. Packard and Ray J. Mauer to the board of Geyer Advertising, Inc., was announced yesterday.
" House Happy," Muriel Resnik's next novel, to be published Sept. 19 by the Thomas Y. Crowell Company, is to be converted into a musical.
SUMMIT, N. J., July 14 -- Mrs. Gordon Park of Glen Ridge won the qualifying medal in the fifth annual championship of the Garden State Women's Golf Association today.

Radio and television executives worked through the night in an effort to clear local and network channels for today's emergency session of the United Nations Security Council on the Middle East situation. The meeting is scheduled to open at 10 A. M.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- A bill to authorize $387,000,000 for new atomic energy projects passed the House virtually without opposition today, despite a letter from President Eisenhower strongly objecting to much of it.
STREATOR, Ill., July 14 (UPI) -- Sewer gas, forced into the basement of a big downtown hardware store by flooding rains, exploded with a shattering roar today.

The recent drop in coffee prices has emphasized need for a world - wide marketing agreement, according to the twenty-first edition of Annual Coffee Statistics. The publication, covering 1957, was issued yesterday by the Pan-American Coffee Bureau.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 14 (AP) -- The American Library Association tonight cited Cecil U. Edmonds of West Memphis, Ark., and Mrs. J. Henry Mohr of San Francisco for outstanding work as library trustees.
A search is on for Ilya Wolston, a nephew of the confessed Soviet spy Jack Soble, for failing to appear before a grand jury investigating espionage.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee approved today a $123,320,419 money bill to run Congress and its associated agencies in the year ahead.

PATERSON, N. J., July 14 (AP) -- Victor Corbo, 40 years old, and his wife, Rita, 30, were brought into court today on a murder charge. They are accused of beating their 3-year-old foster daughter to death.

IN America, the price of wine -- both domestic and imported -- is often cited as the greatest deterrent to its widespread enjoyment as a mealtime accompaniment. The average Frenchman, the argument continues, enjoys his glass of pinard with every meal because it is well within his buying power.

The five - story apartment structure at 1429 Thirty-fifth Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by Jerome Giordano to the 1069 Second Avenue Corporation. Title to the property was insured by the Home Title Guaranty Company. The seller was represented by Joseph Goldberg Harry T. Sherman represented the purchaser.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission estimated today that individuals saved $4,100,000,000 in the first quarter of this year, or $700,000, 000 more than in the last quarter of 1957.
DR. SELMAN ABRAHAM WAKSMAN is the man who gave the word antibiotics its modern meaning.
Hagerstown, Md., announced yesterday that it would seek submission of bids on July 29 for $5,500,000 of various purpose bonds, due from 1959 to 1983.

Cooper Union has retained the architectural firm of Voorhees, Walker, Smith Smith to design the building for its new School of Engineering. This was announced yesterday by Irving S. Olds, chairman of the board of trustees.

There wasn't a dull moment in the feature bout at St. Nicholas Arena last night as Carmelo Costa, a 5-foot 4-inch featherweight from Brooklyn, administered a boxing lesson to Al Tisi of the East Side.
BUENOS AIRES, July 14 -- The Port of Buenos Aires, Federal and local courts and public hospitals continued crippled today by labor or political conflicts.
The bankrupt Hudson and Manhattan Railroad received authorization in Federal Court yesterday to pay $1,920,000 to the holders of the carrier's first mortgage and refunding mortgage bonds.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 14 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves walloped San Francisco, 12 -- 3, today behind the five-hit pitching of Lew Burdette and regained first place in the National League over the Giants by a half game.
The advertising account of the Standard Triumph Motor Company of New York is moving again.

Sales of the nation's major chain and mail order companies last month just managed to top those for June, 1957 according to a compilation yesterday by The New York Times. Volume was 0.9 per cent above that for the 1957 month, compared with a rise of 5.1 per cent in the year-to-year comparison a month earlier.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, postponed indefinitely today a trip to the Soviet Union and some European countries planned for next month.
The first passenger ship designed and built specially for service between Europe and ports on the Great Lakes was launched in a shipyard in the Netherlands Saturday.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Treasury bill rate moved up again this week to above 1 per cent, the Treasury reported tonight. The average interest rate for $1,700,000,000 of the 91-day discount bills was 1.137 per cent, compared with 0.934 per cent last week.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) -- The Senate Public Works Committee endorsed today President Eisenhower's controversial choice of Arnold P. Jones, a former Deputy Budget Director, to be a director of the Tennessee Valley Authority.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- About 4,500 Federal workers across the country today coped on paper with the problems of survival and recovery from a hypothetical, continent-wide nuclear assault.

The recovery trend in the Government bond market ended suddenly yesterday with news of the pro-Nasser revolt in Iraq. Fears that this country might become involved depressed the long-term end of the Government list by as much as 1 3/4 points.
FARMINGDALE, L. I., July 14 -- Work at the old Liberty Aircraft Corporation plant here will be suspended by the end of the week, plant officials said today.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -The shadow of Nasserism fell full across the Arab Middle East today. Washington awoke to it with surprise and did not like it.

GUANTANAMO BAY, Cuba, July 14 -- The Cuban rebels failed today to release any of the twenty-nine United States servicemen they kidnapped June 27. United States authorities said officially that "torrential rain" had prevented the insurgents from fulfilling a pledge made yesterday to begin freeing the sailors and marines.
The Russian team, with a 9 -- 3 score, leads after three rounds of the finals of the international student chess champions at Varna, Bulgaria, according to a report received yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The State Department urged the Senate today to restore House cuts in foreign aid funds lest European Allies fall short of the missiles and aircraft needed to withstand a Soviet onslaught.

Local women bowlers who enjoy the game enough to bowl about once a week but aren't proficient enough to register high scores will have a chance to win the Betty Brady Memorial Award during the coming season.

Cumulative strains and stresses have a way of catching up with us about this time of year. One may be luxuriating in a comfortable, air-conditioned office during intermittent heat spells, but the sum total of conferences, the chain effects of problems met and partially solved, petty irritations and enervating humidity tend to emphasize a state of lowered vitality.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., July 14 (AP) -- A ban on Communist-made products at Port Everglades was issued today by Nelson DeBan, chairman of the Port Authority.
INDIANAPOLIS, July 14 (UPI) -- Two men were sentenced to jail today for bribery in the Indiana highway scandals. Elmer Sherwood and William E. Sayer received sentences of 2 to 14 years.

IN the past this observer did not always see eye to eye with Branch Rickey. Not that we ever questioned his wisdom. He was at all times intensely interesting and enlightening. Certainly, he was never dull. But when he would settle back to discourse behind his pontifical front, bushy eyebrows and pure Havana, you were never certain whose leg he was pulling.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 14 -- Local 47, American Federation of Musicians, advised its members today they were free to seek jobs in the major movie studios, which were struck by the union in February, but cautioned against dual unionism.

HONG KONG, July 14 -- A Peiping radio broadcast said today the United States must reply "immediately" to China's June 30 demand for the resumption of Chinese-American talks in Geneva within fifteen days.
CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 1 to 18 points yesterday. The far October and December showed the most strength. The rise equaled 5 cents to 90 cents a bale.
NEW ORLEANS, July 14 (AP) -- Stockholders of The New Orleans Item approved today the sale of the afternoon paper's principal operating assets to the rival Times-Picayune Publishing Company.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 14 -Those few members of the new Iraqi revolutionary Cabinet who are well known here have a reputation for strong Arab nationalism.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) -- The House Ways and Means Committee hammered out bipartisan agreement today on a $250,000,000 program of tax relief for small business.
We would like to take exception to the statement by Frederic Duvigneaud, Minister of the Interior of Haiti, published in The New York Times of July 11.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -Bernard Goldfine returns to the witness chair tomorrow morning under threat of contemptof-Congress proceedings unless he reverses himself and answers questions about his financial affairs.
Two Bronx patrolmen who were arrested Sunday and accused of stealing Police Department firearms were arraigned yesterday on charges of grand larceny.

RICHMOND, Va., July 14 (AP) -- Prince Edward County school officials came up with a surprise move today in Federal Court in an effort to delay further the setting of a definite date to start desegregating the public schools.

Despite new outbreaks of violence on Cyprus there are signs of a possible break in the dark clouds hovering over that island. This break could take the shape of a conference between Britain, Greece and Turkey in which Cypriote representatives would participate. At very least such a conference would help to cool inflamed national passions which threaten the solidity of the North Atlantic alliance.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Michigan's fight for speeded construction of the Great Lakes connecting channels will reach the crucial and probably toughest stage this week.

The Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company reported yesterday record first-half sales of ordinary life insurance totaling $468,063,415. This was a gain of $98,735,531, or 26.7 per cent from the 1957 period level.

An offering of debentures and common stock of Salem-Brosius, Inc., is being made by a group headed by Blair Co. The $2,500,000 of 5 1/2 per cent convertible subordinate debentures, due in 1973, are priced at 100 plus accrued interest. The 85,000 shares of common stock are priced at $15 a share.

PANAMA, July 14 -- The doors of the United States Embassy were bolted and Marine guards stood by this morning as about 100 high school and university students demonstrated against Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower.
Nineteen boys between 12 and 19 years old, were rounded up last night by the police, who said the boys had been massing for a fight between two street gangs in Crotona Park, the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The Interior Department pressed today Senate-passed legislation to authorize construction of five plants for the conversion of salt and brackish water into fresh water.

The third Soviet satellite and its rocket carrier will pass over this area tonight about 9:20 o'clock. However, partly cloudy skies and possible thunder showers probably will keep the space travelers out of sight.
CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) -- Whitney Reed of Alameda, Calif., moved into the third round of the National clay-court tennis tournament today as rain and late-arriving players curtailed first-day activity.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., July 14 -- Dr. Selman A. Waksman, winner of a Nobel Prize in 1952 as co-discoverer of streptomycin, will retire Aug. 31 as director of the Rutgers University Institute of Microbiology.
LONDON, July 14 -- Prices of oil shares tumbled on the stock exchange today on the news of a coup in Iraq and other issues declined in their wake.

PITTSBURGH, July 14 (UPI) -- Earl Belle, 26-year-old Pittsburgh "financial wizard" who went to South America when his paper financial empire began crumbling, admitted in a contrite letter today that his investors had been duped. However he indicated he was not coming home to face the music.
Paul W. Williams declared yesterday that he planned to carry on his campaign for the Republican nomination for Governor.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 14 (UPI) -- A cargo of Japanese tea that checked out "slightly radioactive" left today for New York aboard the Norwegian freighter Trancred.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Lawrence N. Steinberg bowed out today as a member of a three-man panel to examine charges of corruption against Ray Cohen, Philadelphia teamsters boss.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 14 (AP) -- Bitter strife between Greek and Turkish Cypriotes went on today despite the most severe British measures imposed in three years of emergency on this Mediterranean island.

Wool growers and manufacturers of wool products have organized a group to promote American-made wool products. It will be known as Woolens and Worsteds of America and will maintain an information center at 608 Fifth Avenue.
The aircraft carrier Leyte, flagship of Carrier Division 18 of the Atlantic Fleet, tied up yesterday at Hudson River Pier 84 at Forty-fourth Street for a week's visit.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -President Eisenhower moved today to confine the explosive Middle East political crisis arising out of the overthrow of the pro-Western Government of King Faisal II of Iraq.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 14 -- Reports of the Iraqi revolution were received here today with deep misgivings.
Lilly Dache does not pull all her fashion tricks out of a hat. She also does magic with make-up and coiffures.

Chemical Fund, Inc., reported yesterday net assets of $153,886,575 on June 30. This was the highest total reported at the end of any quarter in the mutual fund's twenty-year history. It compared with $151,006,754 a year earlier and $136,101,875 at the end of 1957.

OTTAWA, July 14 (Canadian Press) -- Prime Minister Diefenbaker tonight urged Victory bond holders to participate in the huge conversion with the same spirit and determination that brought distinction to Canada in the Second World War.
NEWARK, July 14 (AP) -- The New Jersey Public Utility Commission granted today a request by the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad to curtail its service.
AMMAN, Jordan, July 14 -- King Hussein of Jordan said today he had assumed power as head of the Arab Union of Iraq and Jordan "in view of the absence" of King Faisal of Iraq.

' Cinerama-South Seas Adventure," which arrives tonight at the Warner Theatre, Broadway and Forty-seventh Street, is today's lone film newcomer. The offering, the fifth feature filmed in the Cinerama wide-screen process, was photographed in color on islands throughout the Pacific from Hawaii to Australia.

Crown Prince Abdul Illah of Iraq, who has been reported slain, ruled the country for fourteen turbulent years until his nephew, King Faisal II, came of age May 2, 1953. On that day -- Faisal's eighteenth birthday -- Abdul Illah handed over his power to the young King.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 14 (AP) -- Nationalist China today announced a new Cabinet and hailed it as the strongest since Generalissimo Chiang Kaishek's Government left mainland China in 1949.

PHILADELPHIA, July 14 -- Richard Graves, the unsuccessful Democratic candidate for Governor of California in 1954, was appointed today to the $35,000-a-year post of executive vice president of the new Philadelphia Industrial Development Corporation.

In March of this year, Lieut. Gen. James M. Gavin resigned as chief of the Army's Department of Research and Development. He said he could serve his country better by speaking more frankly as a civilian than was possible by one in uniform.

GENEVA, July 14 --The Western and Soviet bloc scientists began considering today the most controversial method for detecting atomic explosions -- the recording of the earth shock waves created by the blast.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., July 14 -- The defending Westhampton Yacht Squadron crew, skippered by Jim Simes, won all three races sailed today as the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's junior sailing championships got under way.

Two commercial structures at Washington and Newark Streets in Hoboken, N. J., have been sold by the Evening Journal Association to the Martin-Hoboken Realty Company, Inc. The properties __ consist of a four-story brick structure at 78-80 Washington Street and an adjoining five-story brick building at 109-11 Newark Street. The total building area comprises 31,000 square feet.
A Brooklyn cab driver won a year-long battle with the city yesterday for $30,000 in jewels he said he had found in his taxi.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 14 -- "Tom Sawyer," a new musical comedy based on Mark Twain's novel, opened here tonight on the outdoor stage of the Starlight Theatre in Swope Park. A near-sell-out crowd of 7,352 persons attended the premiere.
Thousands of Americans who have "adopted" overseas children through the Foster Parents' Plan are doing their Christmas shopping now.
The United Automobile Workers hinted yesterday that it might set a strike deadline to spur its lagging contract negotiations with the Big Three auto manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) -- The Senate Education subcommittee rebuffed President Eisenhower today by approving a bill to continue Federal aid for schools crowded by the children of service men and Government workers.
The ninth attempt to reconvene the 1958 annual stockholders meeting of Penn-Texas Corporation was successful yesterday morning as a nine-man board of directors was elected.

Directors of Reichhold Chemicals, Inc. yesterday increased the quarterly dividend to 25 cents and also voted a stock dividend of 2 per cent on the common, payable on Aug. 15. The company paid 20 cents in cash and 2 per cent in stock in May and February, this year.
CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) -- Wheat futures traders tried hard again today to come into possession of more of the actual grain.
UNITED NATIONS, July 14 -- The Security Council will meet tomorrow at 10 A. M. to take up the explosive situation in the Middle East.
VICTORIA, B. C., July 14 (AP) -- Princess Margaret got an island today despite the protests of an Indian chief.

HONG KONG, July 14 -- Three more Chinese Roman Catholic priests, one in Canton and two in Hengyang, have been arrested by Communist authorities as "Rightists" opposed to the Peiping regime, according to reports received here.
Charges were dismissed yesterday for two unemployed moving men who were left holding the bag in an attempted bank robbery July 3.

CHURCHILL, Man., July 14 (Canadian Press) -- A four-man team of United States scientists left by air yesterday for the northern coast of Ellesmere Island, 450 miles from the North Pole, to begin a six-week study of geological formation.
AMMAN, July 14 (Reuters) -- King Hussein said today in his radio address that "our Hashemite family stands as strong as a mountain and remains firm in the face of the forces of evil and atheism."
INDIANAPOLIS, July 14 (AP) -- Alex Olmedo of Lima, Peru, upset Bernard Bartzen of Dallas in the men's singles final of the Western amateur tennis tournament today. The scorces were 1-6, 8-6, 6-0.
ACCRA, Ghana, July 14 -- The Ghana Bank started to put into circulation today 42,000,000 ($117,600,000) of Ghana's own currency in notes and coins.
Canada has just completed a census of its machinery, telling, in effect, how the Commonwealth stacks up in the basic metalworking industry.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon told a twelve-member Hawaii delegation today to "keep the heat on" in their plea for Congressional action this year on the Hawaii statehood bill.
LOS ANGELES, July 14 -The city's proposed grant of land to the Los Angeles Dodgers for a baseball park was held invalid by the Superior Court today.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 14 -- Five months before the start of the Soviet bloc's current campaign against Titoism, Nikita S. Khrushchev warned Yugoslav Communists that they were in for a fight.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The sudden explosion in Iraq, triggered by what some Mideast authorities here have tentatively accepted as an authentic outburst of Arab nationalism, has accentuated a line of thought which has been forming in the minds of many critical observers of United States foreign policy.
AMHERST, Mass., July 14 -- The task of striking a balance between science and the humanities was under discussion here today by spokesmen of industry and education.
In the Kasr al Zahour (Palace of Flowers) in the ancient city of Baghdad, five nations tried to forge a new link in the Western defense chain in November, 1955.
ASCOT, England, July 14 (AP) -- A 17-year-old Turkish Princess waited calmly and quietly today at an English finishing school here for news of her fiance, King Faisal of Iraq.
Borough President Albert V. Maniscalco of Richmond has informed the Board of Health that he is opposed to making his borough a "testing laboratory" for the distribution of undated milk.

ALGIERS, July 14 -- Mohammed Bellounis, an Algerian insurgent leader who allied himself with the French Army last August and later "denounced" the alliance, was killed today by French Forces. the French Army announced tonight.

SINCE today is St. Swithin's Day, more than one person will look to the heavens for a forecast. According to the old legend, if there should be rain today, "for forty days it will remain." Although no one takes this very seriously, it is a day to think about raincoats.
LONDON, Tuesday, July 15 -- The British Cabinet discussed the possibility of armed intervention in Iraq in a meeting late last night, informed sources reported.

Airline officials are showing increasing concern over the problem of jet noise. Concern mounted last week after Harold Watkinson, British Minister of Transport and Civil Aviation, said here that the Boeing 707 jet might be too noisy, for London Airport.
A six-day strike by office workers of the Belgian Line here was ended yesterday.
NEWPORT, R. I., July 14 -- Again today a dying breeze left the four contenders for the assignment of defending the America's Cup short of the finish line at the expiration of the time limit.
BERLIN, July 14 -- East German Communists employed the ritual of criticism and self-criticism today to strengthen the leadership of Walter Ulbricht.

GARDINERS ISLAND, L. I., July 14 -- A leg-banding party in search of the osprey, or fish hawk, discovered over the week-end that most of the huge nests on the extensive meadowlands at the northern end of this island had been abandoned.
A further rise in steel production is scheduled for this week. Output a week earlier had rebounded from a sevenweek low, that had reflected a holiday curtailment, vacations and a deecline in orders.

JUNEAU, Alaska, July 12 -- The time schedule for conducting Alaska's statehood plebiscite, primary and general elections this fall is tight. So tight, in fact, that territorial officials envision a squadron of bush pilots dropping bundles of ballots at scores of out-of-the-way villages.

LONDON, July 14 -- The old days are over in Ceylon. Eleven years ago the British left their spacious cool, echoing Government buildings. Now a generation of Ceylonese that succeeded and copied them is fighting to stay at the top.

WASHINGTON, Tuesday, July 15 -- The Defense Department announced early this morning the movement of a number of military transport planes to an undisclosed Euro pean Air Force base. This reinforced indications that the United States may send troops to the Middle East possibly Lebanon.

LONDON, Tuesday, July 15 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan late last night ordered 6,000 British troops to get ready for speedy movement to the Middle East, plunged into new turbulence by the coup in Iraq.
DETROIT, July 14 (AP) -- The auto makers continue to reduce their new car inventories. On July 1 they had 672,842 unsold units in dealer stocks, compared with 741,251 a month earlier.

A BRITISH variety of James Thurber's immortal Walter Mitty dreams of conducting a great symphony. The chances of his doing that are extravagantly against him. He is by occupation a rising official in a government bureaucracy, enjoying his obsession on the side. His wife, naturally, worries.

Hungarian refugees and Americans of Hungarian extraction picketed the Park Avenue headquarters of the Soviet delegation to the United Nations for the second straight day yesterday and routed a dissenter who infiltrated their ranks.

ABOARD THE U. S. S. RANGER, Off Rio de Janeiro, July 14 -- The United States Navy took Brazil's president, Juscelino Kubitschek, sailing on the South Atlantic this morning to show him jet aircraft operations from its most modern carrier.
CAIRO, July 14 -- Pro-Nasser officers seized control of the Iraqi capital of Baghdad in a lightning coup at dawn today.
HONOLULU, July 14 (UPI) -- Japanese swimmers won four of five events last night to complete their domination of the four-day Keo Nakama swimming meet.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (UPI) The State Department told Congress today that a proposed export subsidy on United States dairy products might "gravely" hurt American relations with other free nations.
Yonkers Raceway disclosed yesterday the richest stake program in the history of harness racing.
MAYWOOD, Ill., July 14 -- The American Can Company announced today that it had filled 3,000 aluminum squeeze tubes with liquid and semi-solid foods to be used in space flights.

TORONTO, July 14 (UPI) -- The United States completed a sweep of its North American Davis Cup semi-final round with Canada today. John Douglas of Stanford University defeated Toronto's Don Fontana, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1, and Barry MacKay overcame Paul Willey, 6 -- 8, 6 -- 2, 12 -- 10, 7 -- 5.
It has been just five months to the day since young King Faisal II became the head of the new Arab Union of Iraq and Jordan.
Oil industry executives were eagerly awaiting direct information concerning the political situation in Iraq as a result of yesterday's coup.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 14 -- Jimmy Cruise, who won six races in six starts Saturday night, scored a half-length victory with Greentree Express tonight in the Miramar Pace at Roosevelt Raceway. The winner, the 3-5 favorite, was timed in 2:06.

Sales and earnings of the General Electric Company showed a decided improvement in the second quarter over the first three months of this year. Sales for the half year were the second highest in the company's history, but earnings were 19 per cent less than in the 1957 period, a report issued yesterday disclosed.
James D. Norris, chairman of the board of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, was served with a subpoena yesterday to appear Sept. 16 before a grand jury investigating corruption in boxing.

The nomination of Rolland E. Irish to be president, of the American Life Convention, an association of legal reserve life insurance companies, has been announced. Mr. Irish is president of the Union Mutual Life Insurance Company, Portland, Me.
A union that is threatening a telephone strike in the metropolitan area used recorded telephone messages yesterday to keep 20,000 members informed whether they should quit work.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15 (AP) -- Top-seeded Mrs. William du Pont Jr., former title-holder from Wilmington, Del., advanced to the third round of the Middle States women's grass court tennis championship today.
President Eisenhower signed yesterday with reservations and "misgivings" a measure authorizing the construction of two superliners with heavy Government financial assistance.
The American Cargo War Risk Reinsurance Exchange acted yesterday to withdraw its war risk insurance rates applicable to cargoes bound to or from Iraq and Jordan. The action is effective today.

United Airlines has ordered from Teleregister Corporation of Stamford, Conn., a $16,000,000 passenger reservations system. It is believed to be the largest interconnecting electronic data processing system ever built for one industry.

The Socony Mobil Oil Company, Inc., is developing a world-wide network of electronic computers, linked by transceivers and other rapid means of communication. A transceiver is a radio transmitter-receiver that uses the same tubes for both operations.
United States immigration authorities have issued permanent "shore leave" permits to more than 22,000 crew members of 110 foreign ships that have called at the Port of New York since May 1
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Significant improvement in June in three major indicators of the economy was reported by the Government today.
Ordinarily it is with complete agreement that we read the editorials in The Times. However, with "Requiem for a House" (issue of July 5) we regret to announce that this rapport must come to an end.
George Meany prohibited yesterday alliances between affiliates of federated labor and the expelled International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's message to Congress on the Middle Eastern situation:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 15 -- The United States gave the Security Council a pledge today that United States Marines would remain in Lebanon only until the United Nations was able to insure her "continued independence."
WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) -- House Democratic leaders have decided to press for an 8 per cent to 10 per cent increase in Social Security benefits before Congress adjourns.
The tenth annual dinner dance to further the work of Recreation Service for Children of Bellevue has been scheduled to take place in the grand ballroom of the Plaza on Oct. 9.
LONDON, July 15 -- British land, sea and air forces were moving tonight from Malta, Kenya and the Persian Gulf to the support of their American allies in Lebanon.
THE "little season" has opened in Bloomingdale's decorating department with model rooms that have so many ideas in color and furnishings that they may give alert visitors a jump on the "big season."

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- When the President informed I the Congressional leaders he summoned to the White House yesterday of the Lebanon Government's request for military assistance and of the several measures he might take to respond to it, he asked each visitor in turn for alternative suggestions.
ST. PAUL, Minn., July 15 (AP) -- The officer who led United States Marines ashore in Lebanon today apparently had an inkling his unit was headed for action.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 15 -- United States Marines landed in Beirut at 3 P. M. today to back up the Lebanese Government of President Camille Chamoun against rebels or outsiders. The Beirut public received them like a circus coming to town.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15 (AP) -- A union organizer formally accused the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations of having discharged him to block organization of an organizers' union.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 15 -- Mrs. Alfred Corning Clark is general chairman for the second annual Midsummer Night Ball, which is held at the Southampton Beach Club during the August full moon to benefit Southampton Hospital.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- United States naval, air and army units were ordered today into "improved readiness positions" in support of the United States Marines' landing in Lebanon.

ALTHOUGH menu planning is a pleasurable pastime, it is not -- even for the socially adept business executive -- always cakes and ale. This is the opinion of one business woman who is equally at home discussing high finance, lobster thermidor, bank loans and vintage years.
The letter of Irving M. Engel, printed in your newspaper July 2 on the subject of Sunday closing, contains a serious error of fact which goes to the root of his argument.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., July 15 (AP) -- An insurance executive today blamed "a shifting standard of morality" for part of the high cost of auto liability insurance. He said that other policy holders and not the insurance companies are the real victims.

A $300,000,000 public offering of 4 per cent United States Steel Corporation sinking fund debentures, due 1983, is being made today at 100.50, to yield 3.97 per cent, by Morgan Stanley Co. and associates.
Stanley Chase, who announced recently that he and his partner, Carmen Capalbo, would produce independently from now on, has acquired a new play by Gore Vidal entitled "Fire to the Sea."
LONDON, July 15 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan announced today changes in Britain's defense establishment designed to streamline and centralize control of defense operations.
CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- Barry MacKay, the 22-year-old Davis Cup player from Dayton, Ohio, brushed aside two opponents today in his opening bid for the national clay court tennis crown.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., July 15 -- Mitchel Field will celebrate its fortieth anniversary tomorrow. The air base, staffed by 4,085 officers and men is the headquarters for the Continental Air Command.
ADEN, July 15 -- The reception by Arab employes of the United States Consulate here of news of the Iraqi coup reveals the depth and force of Arab nationalist sentiment.

ELKS from thirty-nine Kansas lodges arrived at the ninety-fourth Grand Lodge Convention here last week with $5,301 in half-dollars. The money had been collected all over the state for the Elks' National Foundation, which devotes its income to charities.

Despite record sales attained in the first half of this year, earnings of the Continental Can Company declined about 13 per cent, according to the midyear report issued yesterday by Gen. Lucius D. Clay, chairman.

A flood of grain is pouring into St. Louis, and from there flowing down the Mississippi headed for export markets. It represents the largest wheat crop in eleven years and the second largest ever. Harvesting in Illinois and Missouri is at its peak; millions of bushels are moving off the farms every day.
The General Electric Credit Corporation announced yesterday that it was undertaking its own advertising program and had selected Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc., as its agency.

Savings in New York State's 233 savings and loan associations increased $56,225,770 in June, which was $5,507,835 or about 11 per cent above the gain in June, 1957, according to the Savings Association League of New York State.

The Mideast troubles, which led to the landing of Marines in Lebanon, sent most commodities soaring in heavy trading yesterday on the New York exchanges. Wool, cot tonseed oil and the world sugar futures registered the sharpest daily gains of 1958 in the most active sessions of the year.
Hope for eventual prevention of cancer is supported by recent research on the body's natural defenses, according to a report issued yesterday by the Sloan-Kettering Institute for Cancer Research.
URBANA, Ill., July 15 -- Stenographers and secretaries have been found to take only short breaks, no matter what their bosses may say.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee unanimously approved today a plan to reorganize the Defense Department after modifying some features that had drawn an attack from President Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The Senate passed and sent to conference with the House today a bill authorizing $386,679,000 for new atomic energy projects. This is almost twice as much as President Eisenhower requested.
The committee on finance and currency of the New York Chamber of Commerce urged Congress yesterday to remove the proposed Financial Institutions Act from committee and to enact the measure.
Billy Joe Patton, the colorful amateur golfer from Morganton, N. C., was named yesterday as captain of the United States team that will compete in the Americas Cup matches.

Oil operations continued normal in Iraq yesterday.
Stores are spending a larger percentage of their income for operating expenses, but the number of dollars is fewer.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The White House announced today the resignation of Gabriel Hauge as President Eisenhower's Special Assistant for Economic Affairs.
PARIS, July 15 (Reuters) -- The United States informed its Atlantic alliance allies about the Lebanon landings at a hurriedly called meeting here today of the Permanent Council of the alliance.

COCOA BEACH, Fla., July 15 -- A two-hour work stoppage by ground personnel at Pan American World Airways stations across the country has been called for 10 A. M. tomorrow in connection with a strike of workers at the Air Force missile test center at Cape Canaveral.

AUSTIN, Tex., July 15 (AP) -- The National Bankers Life Insurance Company of Dallas said today it was in good financial condition as State Insurance Commissioner William A. Harrison started a hearing to determine if its operating license should be revoked.
MALE call today -- for all summer bachelors who must swelter in the city while wives hie to a country oasis dressed in shorts and bare-backed halters.

An extra dividend of 25 cents in addition to the regular quarterly dividend of 50 cents a share was voted yesterday on the common stock of Allied Mills, Inc. Both are payable Aug. 9. No extra was distributed a year ago.
ALBANY, July 15 -- A state campaign to protect the public from mentally ill doctors and dentists was criticized today for not including members of other licensed professions.

E. E. Norris has joined Calvert Distillers Company as vice president and director of advertising and sales promotion. Robert Bragarnick, vice president in charge of marketing at Joseph E. Seagram and Sons, Inc., made the announcement yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission said today Snap-On Tools Corporation of Kenosha, Wis., had denied agreements with its dealers which illegally restrained trade.

The Colgate-Palmolive Company set sales records for any half year or for any three months period in the quarter and six months ended on June 30. Mid-year figures issued yesterday showed also that earnings were above the 1957 levels. Colgate is a leading manufacturer of soaps, detergents and toiletries.
The landing of United States Marines in Lebanon yesterday may ultimately help to produce what it is intended to prevent.

Peter Lyon, author of magazine articles, is at work on two books. One is a biography of Samuel S. McClure and of his times. McClure (1857-1949) founded the McClure Syndicate in 1884, the first newspaper syndicate in the United States.

Memphis, Tenn., borrowed $10,000,000 yesterday on water revenue bonds due serially from 1960 to 1988. The securities were sold at an interest cost of 3.0945 per cent to a syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., Equitable Securities Corporation and Smith, Barney Co.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Congressional investigators reported tonight that they had unearthed what they characterized as "political influence" by high Administration officials in an Army textile material contract.
LONDON, July 15 -- Events in the Middle East again depressed the stock market today. But there was a short-lived mild rally in the afternoon and a few prices closed slightly above the day's lowest.

HONG KONG, July 15 -- Communist China is closing a fifteen-months-old "rectification" campaign that has uprooted more than 1,000,000 persons from their homes and set them to work -- some to "corrective labor" -- in undeveloped mountain and forest regions.
TOKYO, July 15 -- Japan's major concern today over events in Iraq was the possible effect of the anti-government uprising on Japan's trade with Iraq.
" KEEP TALKING" made its debut as television's newest game show on Channel 2 last night.

Harrison Reader, head of Peak Films, English movie company, has announced plans to move its base to operations for independent production to the United States with offices at 49 West Fifty-seventh Street.

THE BEETHOVEN FESTIVAL at Lewisohn Stadium, shortened from four performances to three as a result of Monday night's rain, had its belated start last night. Josef Krips made his debut as a Stadium conductor and Claudio Arrau was soloist in the "Emperor" Concerto.

NIAGARA FALLS, Ont., July 15 (Canadian Press) -- Provincial Engineering, Ltd., an engineering and manufacturing company, has been purchased by Houdaille Industries, Inc., of Buffalo, N. Y., Ralph F. Peo, president of the American company announced today.
JERUSALEM, Israeli Sector, July 15 -- Israel was relieved and cheered today by the landing of United States Marines in Lebanon.

AMMAN, Jordan July 15 -- A large force of Iraqi soldiers loyal to King Faisal is marching toward Baghdad to counter-attack insurgents who captured the Iraqi capital yesterday, the Amman radio reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The landing of troops in Lebanon focused attention today on the Eisenhower Doctrine, a joint resolution of the Senate and House of Representatives signed by President Eisenhower on March 9, 1957.
PANAMA, July 15 -- An internecine student fight that probably will have repercussions in the countries to be visited by Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower was shaping up here today.
COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., July 15 (AP) -- Mrs. Bruce McGhie of Armonk fired a 1-under-par 79 today and led sixteen qualifiers for the twenty-ninth state women's amateur golf tournament.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange climbed 8 to 49 points yesterday, with the far months showing the most strength.

AMHERST, Mass., July 15 -- The "false position" of United States foreign aid policy has contributed to such situations as the coup in Iraq, Dr. Percy W. Bridgman, 1946 winner of the Nobel Prize for Physics, said today.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (UPI) -- The United Press International news service agency told the Federal Communications Commission today that interim increased rates for private line teleprinted communications services, as proposed by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, were "patently discriminatory against press customers."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 15 -- Movie rights to the Broadway hit, "Two for the Seesaw," have been acquired by Eliot Hyman and Ray Stark of Seven Arts Productions at one of the highest prices paid for a non-musical play.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 15 -- Members of the Security Council were told today that Dr. Fadhil al-Jamali of Iraq, who had sat with them a few weeks ago, had been murdered and dragged through the streets of Baghdad.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15 (AP) -- The national Open champion, Tommy Bolt, kept officials of the Professional Golfers Association waiting for three hours today and finally failed to show up for a meeting called to decide whether he should be barred from the circuit for misconduct.
The Public Service Electric and Gas Company of Newark, N. J. reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for six and twelve months ended June 30.
Two churches that had been marked for demolition will be spared by changes in the city's plan for slum clearance and redevelopment in the Chelsea district.
WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Senate, with five members present, voted today to appropriate $123,320,419 to operate Congress for the rest of the fiscal year ending June 30, 1959.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., July 15 -- The first of a projected series of art festivals to be held in this summer art colony opened today in seven big fireproof tents on high ground not far from the center of the community.

Mandrel Industries, Inc. of Houston, Texas, is expanding its electronics operations. " Law and Disorder," a British-made comedy starring Michael Redgrave and Robert Morley, will have its American premiere at the Baronet Theatre (Third Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street) following the engagement of "Blue Murder at St. Trinian's," the theatre's current tenant. NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 16 (Reuters) -- An island-wide curfew aimed at Greek-Turkish violence was lifted after forty-eight hours today -- and two more Turkish Cypriotes promptly were slain.

Sales of the B. F. Goodrich Company for the first half of this year dipped 8.8 per cent, while earnings fell 27.5 per cent from the year-ago level, according to the report yesterday of John L. Collyer, chairman, and J. W. Keener, president.

Y., July 16 -- The New York Times, in presenting excerpts from the debate before the Security Council yesterday, incorrectly attributed to Omar Loutfi, representative of the United Arab Republic, criticism of the conduct of members of the United Nations Observation Group in Lebanon.

Statistics made available this week on the state of the economy during June include figures on industrial production, personal income and new housing starts. The Department of Commerce reported an increase in June of $1,900,000,000 in personal income, the fourth such increase in as many months.

LONDON, Thursday, July 17 -- The British Cabinet discussed military intervention in Jordan at an emergency meeting that ended early this morning.

The unpredictability of fillies was demonstrated once more in the fifty-second running of the Astoria at Jamaica yesterday. That five and a half furlong race is for 2-year-old fillies and the crowd of 18,700 established Lady Be Good of the Wheatley Stable the 1-to-2 favorite.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 16 (AP) -- Norma Talmadge, silent film star, left an estate valued at $3,060,321.41, exclusive of real estate in California and Florida. A final inventory of the estate was filed in district coutr today.

THE nation having about recovered from the impact of Casey Stengel's recent appearance before a Senate antimonopoly subcommittee, more details are drifting in to add to the luster of that astounding performance. To hand comes the complete, unabridged and official report of that hearing. In book form, it couldn't miss as a best seller.
The Kennecott Copper Corporation late yesterday announced an increase in its price for refined copper of 1 1/2 cents a pound, effective today. The new price is 26 1/2 cents a pound.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 16 -- The possibilities of television tape recorders as a new tool for advertisers were detailed for executives of Los Angeles ad agencies last night by Station KTT-TV, an independent outlet here.

The eleventh annual Monmouth Fair for the benefit of the Monmouth County Historical Association at Freehold, N. J., will take place at the Monmouth Park Race Track, Oceanport, N. J., on Aug. 9 and 10.

Commodity futures prices moved erratically in nervous trading yesterday on New York exchanges. Profit taking following Tuesday's sharp rise, depressed many markets. Most traders were consolidating positions and awaiting further developments in the Middle East before placing major commitments.

" Masquerade Party," one of television's sturdy standbys, will become a summer replacement for "Arthur Godfrey's Talent Scouts" on Aug. 4. It will be televised over the Columbia Broadcasting System network on Mondays from 8:30 to 9 P. M. through Sept. 15.
An order by the Commissioner of Hospitals yesterday morning prevented the fitting of a contraceptive device for a woman who is in a city hospital with a severe case of diabetes.

The City Housing Authority has chosen a special consultant on race relations. He is Madison S. Jones, who will assume the new, $15,000-a-year post on Sept. 1.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board refused today to allow the airlines to confer jointly on certain fare problems.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., July 16 -- Despite a Federal injunction, employes of the Transport Workers Union Local 525 continued today to picket the road to the missile test center at Cape Canaveral.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The recession was a shade deeper in the first quarter of this year than earlier figures indicated, revised estimates of the gross national product showed today.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 16 (UPI) -- King Faisal of Iraq was shot dead the first day of the uprising by an officer who broke into the royal palace with a band of rebel soldiers, the Iranian Ambassador in Baghdad reported today.

Bank clearings for the twenty-six major cities of the nation in the week ended yesterday totaled $23,656,617,000, according to Dun Bradstreet. The New York Central Railroad will begin to carry the mail by its Flexi-Van service on Monday. Flexi-Van, inaugurated last April by the Central between Chicago and New York, is a method by which loaded highway trailers glide off their wheels onto special railroad flat cars.

Harry Golden, whose book of roving essays, "Only in America,"* appears today, is that rara avis.
