The United States Court of Appeals here rejected without dissent yesterday an appeal of two Cincinnati men from the payment of $2,300,800 on a bid made last year for property of the defunct New York, Ontario and Western Railroad.

Federal and state statistics on strikes showed yesterday that the recession was making unions slow to quit work. The figures indicated that strikes were fewer and shorter than in almost any other period since World War II.

Hilde Gueden, Metropolitan Opera soprano, will make her Stadium Symphony Concert debut Saturday night, July 26, under the baton of Josef Krips. She will sing excerpts from Mozart's "Idomeneo" and "Il Re Pastore" and airs from the operettas of Johann Strauss.

ST. LOUIS, July 17 (AP) -- Stan Musial belted two home runs today to move into second place behind Babe Ruth for career extra-base hits in the major leagues, but first-place Milwaukee nudged St. Louis, 8 -- 7, on Mel Roach's seventh-inning single.

UNLESS bluefish make a sudden attack in strength -- and there are indications that this may happen -- game fish news this week-end probably will be made by swordfish, white marlin, school tuna and sharks.

GUANTANAMO BAY, Cuba, July 17 -- A United States sailor on sentry duty here asserts that he was seized by Cuban rebels and held for an hour and a half. He reports that his .45-caliber automatic pistol was taken away.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 17 -- Moving outside its ten-picture financing and production deal with United Artists, the independent company known as Seven Arts Production completed arrangements today with Paramount Pictures for the production of two films.
LONDON, July 17 -- Lieut. Gen. Sir John Glubb said tonight most Arabs would not welcome Western intervention.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -The House Postoffice and Civil Service Committee approved today legislation to give a $25,000-a-year pension to former Presidents of the United States.
LONDON, July 17 -- Britons are divided about the wisdom of the intervention by the United States and Britain in the Middle East.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -The House of Representatives passed a bill today designed to curb Supreme Court findings that Federal statutes nullified conflicting state laws.

The intervention of United States troops in Lebanon to safeguard so-called Western interests in the area at the request of a very unpopular Government and against the majority of the Lebanese people simulates the action of the British and the French in the Suez crisis and the Russian intervention in Hungary.
PARIS, July 17 -- A new group, the National Committee of Unity for Christian Democracy, emerged today on the French political scene.
Frank Costello yesterday won at least six days of reprieve before surrendering to serve the remaining four years of a prison term for income tax evasion.

The price of copper produced by custom smelters moved up yesterday, following an announcement of an increase for the metal the day before by Kennecott Copper Corporation, the world's largest producer.
A charge of grand larceny against a suspended patrolman, David E. Graham of the Bathgate Avenue station, was dismissed yesterday after a hearing in Bronx Magistrate's Court.

Governors of the American Stock Exchange approved yesterday a new schedule of commissions, identical with that adopted last spring by the New York Stock Exchange. The membership will vote on the proposal within two weeks.
Educators should form the central unit in a program for the relief of community problems, a New York City policeman said yesterday.
LONDON, July 17 (AP) -- Following is the text of Prime Minister Harold Macmillan's statement in the House of Commons today announcing that British troops had landed in Jordan:
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Loadings of revenue freight last week totaled 491,142 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- Industry witnesses today supported a Senate mineral subsidy bill, but an Administration spokesman labeled it as too liberal.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) -- Former Senator Edwin C. Johnson urged the Senate today to limit to forty the number of players any major league baseball club can own or control.
Steels, metals, chemicals, aircrafts and rails, caught in the updraft of international crisis, carried the stock market to new highs yesterday.

AN abundance of fresh fruit and greens, the hallmark of summer, continues to dominate the city's marketing scene. The quality of this produce ranges from indifferent to excellent and the price is right.

The entry of British troops into Jordan yesterday was a natural and inevitable consequence of the chain of events set in motion by the Iraqi revolt. It was obvious from the beginning that Jordan had to be bolstered or it would face a similar revolt followed by the adherence of Jordan to the system of Nasser's United Arab Republic.

ALBANY, July 17 -- State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz ruled today that a village may not use its zoning ordinances to exclude a private school for delinquent children. He said zoning restrictions could not be invoked by a village when the location and building plans of the institution had been approved by the State Department of Social Welfare.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- Two Chicago women testified today that they had been threatened with broken bones unless they joined a restaurant workers' union.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 17 -- A hitherto somewhat obscure section of the United Nations Charter -- Article 51 -has become perhaps the most discussed topic of the day here.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 17 -- The Israeli Government granted permission today for flights over Israel by planes carrying British troops to Jordan. It had protested the flights to Britain earlier in the day.
Mayor Wagner declared yesterday that his forthcoming appointment of a $25,000-a-year Deputy Mayor would be made without consultation with Democratic county leaders.
Mrs. Preston Davie said last night that the meeting of New York County Republican leaders next Tuesday would be thrown wide open for an endorsement of a Republican candidate for Governor.
The White Plains, N. Y., City School District is planning to sell $9,780,000 of bonds on July 30. The issue will come due serially from 1959 to 1988.
Northeast Airlines announced yesterday the purchase of nine turbine-propeller Viscount airliners.
Declines in production and consumption of newsprint from 1957 levels continued in June, according to trade association reports issued yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 17 -- The United Nations Observation Group in Lebanon asked today for additional men and planes so that it could keep a direct and constant patrol along the 179-mile border with the Syrian region of the United Arab Republic.
Young men with ambitions of becoming city policemen were told yesterday of the advantages of enlisting with the military police while serving their two-year tour of Selective Service duty.

WITH THE ALGERIAN REBELS, July 11 -- Seventeen young Algerian recruits arrived in this mountain fastness last night after a walk of six days and six nights from the Bone region, about sixty mile away.
WARSAW, July 17 -- A New York investment banker successfully wound up today the difficult job of giving away $1,000,000 worth of pharmaceuticals.
The P. Lorillard Company, makers of Kent, Old Gold and Newport cigarettes, continued to show striking gains in sales and earnings in the quarter and six months ended June 30.

MOSCOW, July 17 -- A crowd of Russians gathered before the United States Embassy in Moscow today to protest against the landing of United States Marines in Lebanon. Some in the crowd were in an angry mood and some were just curious.

PLANDOME, L.I., July 17 -- Billy Edwards of Cherry Valley clipped six strokes from par with a competitive course record of 34, 32 -- 66 to take the medal in the Long Island Golf Association amateur championship at the Plandome Country Club today.

FOR the last ten years or so the old Ruth Dana Draper four-story town house at 122 East Fifty-fifth Street, between Park and Lexington Avenues, has been run by bookish Britons. Brian T. Batsford, Ltd., publishers, had it first.
OTTAWA, July 17 (Canadian Press) -- The Government has forecast that capital expenditures on home construction this year will exceed those of 1957 by 25 per cent.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- Representative Clair Engle, Democrat of California and chairman of the House Interior Committee, said today it appeared to him that every dollar appropriated by Congress for a road, school or hospital for the Navajo-Hopi Indians became "a four-bit piece" by the time it reached the Indians.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 17 -- Cotton Queen, the youthful daughter of Rodney that had been having trouble remaining on gait, trotted without a fault tonight to capture the $25,100 Miss America Stake at Roosevelt Raceway.

THE California court decision invalidating the Dodgers' luscious Los Angeles land grab, certainly not wholly unexpected, seems to have tossed everything right back to where it was two months ago, two months before that, and all the way back to where matters stood the day Walter F. O'Malley painted so glowing a picture of the gold that awaited the National League on the Sun-kissed Slope.

There's often quite a difference between what business men say they expect to do and what they do. The National Industrial Conference Board reported yesterday that, during the first quarter, industry spent on new plant and equipment only 90 per cent of the amount it had estimated it would spend. The estimates were made last year.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 17 -Some formerly pro-Government political leaders were reported today to be switching to the Opposition because of President Camille Chamoun's appeal to the United States for military aid.

ROME, July 17 -- Hundreds of Communists, mostly youngsters, staged anti - American demonstrations in front of the Chamber of Deputies and the United States Embassy here tonight. They shouted "Peace, peace!" and "Down with aggressors!"
LONDON, July 17 -- Two battalions of Britain's Sixteenth Parachute Brigade landed at Amman, the capital of Jordan, today.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- The director of a predominantly Protestant organization protested today that a new Federal tax ruling "encourages churches with religious orders to go into any and every kind of commercial business."

SAN FRANCISCO, July 17 (UPI) -- Dick Farrell threw a wild pitch with the bases loaded in the ninth today to let in the winning run as the San Francisco Giants rallied to hand the Phillies their sixth straight loss, 8 -- 7.
CHICAGO, July 17 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
WASHINGTON, July 17 -The United States made a show of air power over Jordan today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif. July 17 -- "Report from Space," a projected science-fiction series from the pen of Ray Bradbury, a well-known member of that school of writing, has been acquired for production by Bryna Productions.

STOCKHOLM, July 17 -Sweden is watching American and British actions in the Middle East with mixed feelings. This attitude is reflected in newspaper comments, as well as the official position taken in the United Nations Security Council by Sweden's Ambassador, Gunnar Jarring.
The Fifth Avenue Synagogue announced yesterday that the Rev. Dr. Immanuel Jakobovits, Chief Rabbi of Ireland, would become its spiritual leader in September.

Samuel Hopkins Adams, the 7-year-old journalist and author, is working on a new novel for Random House entitled "Tenderloin." Because count has been lost the publisher "thinks" the forthcoming novel is Mr. Adams' fifty-sixth book.
NEWARK, July 17 -- An 83year-old man from Columbia, S. C., who wandered about Newark for two days with $10,900 in cash in his pockets was reunited with his family in New York today.

Business loans by the seventeen major New York City banks declined $98,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The reduction compared with a drop of $85,000,000 in the 1957 week.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 17 -- Today's Security Council session drew the largest crowds since the debates on Hungary and Suez in 1956.
Cigarette manufacturers, who have been presenting one innovation after another in recent months, delivered still another yesterday -- a dual filter.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The United States and Britain have decided to limit their intervention in the Middle East for the time being to Lebanon and Jordan. Intervention...

Five amateur archaeologists, who have been digging in the Bronx as avidly as though they were after pirate treasure, have turned up sections of a Revolutionary fort. With shovels, pickaxes, trowels, filters -- and one day's hire of a bulldozer -- they have followed an old British map in an area roughly bounded by Giles Place, Cannon Place and 238th Street.
ROME, July 17 -- If today's tots are not wearing decontamination suits tomorrow, they will be borrowing Mommy's trapeze -- and on them it looks better.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -The Air Force reported tonight the crash in the Atlantic Ocean of a medium tactical reconnaissance plane, with a crew of three, which was part of an air strike force assigned to the Middle East operations.
DETROIT, July 17 (AP) -The American Motors Corporation, apparently heading for its most profitable fiscal year since 1953, has paid off the last of its bank loans.
THE three television networks canceled regular evening programs last night to provide continuous live coverage of the meeting of the United Nations Security Council.
A COAT inspired by a French design, made of Italian fabric, sewn in the Netherlands and flown to New York would normally carry an expensive price tag.

Jack Paar plans to present his television show live from Havana on Monday, July 28, at 11:15 P. M. over the National Broadcasting Company network. The major portion of the program will originate in the Tropicana night club.

NORFOLK, Va., July 17 -The 40,000-ton attack carrier Antietam, bristling with combat-equipped marines, assault helicopters and jet fighter aircraft, left her pier at the Norfolk Naval Base today. She was ready for deployment to the Mediterranean.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- The Navy announced today that a blimp would fly to the Arctic Ocean this month on a combined scientific and military exploratory mission.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady 1 to 24 points higher yesterday with the far months again showing the most strength. A point is 5 cents a bale.

E. L. Bruce Company yesterday filed an antitrust action in the Federal District Court here against the Empire Millwork Corporation, Rhodes Hardwood Flooring Corporation, Edward M. Gilbert, Harry Gilbert and Yolan Gilbert.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The comments on the Middle East situation made in the Senate this week by Democratic members merit a listing in the new chapter of history now being written in that area. That is because these comments are a preliminary outline of foreign policy issues on which the Democrats now expect to go before the voters of the United States.
GENEVA, July 17 -- Western and Eastern scientists resumed today their discussion of the radiological method of detecting atomic explosions. But they still failed to reach agreement.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 17 -- Following are excerpts of remarks today before the Security Council:

" The Matchmaker," Paramount's version of the Broadway comedy by Thornton Wilder, co-starring Shirley Booth, Anthony Perkins, Shirley MacLaine and Paul Ford, has been booked for an engagement at the Little Carnegie later in the summer, according to the company.
NEW YORKERS can gain colorful and informative impressions of France, Italy, the Orient and many other countries in a new, popularly priced tour.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 17 -- Following is the text of a report to the Security Council today by the United Nations Observation Group in Lebanon:

On July 2, on the basis of a statement by the European Office of the American Jewish Committee, The New York Times reported from Paris that the United Arab Republic had issued a decree openly discriminating against Jews by forbidding the access to U. A. R. territory of Jews who had quit that country between the ages of 10 and 65.

CARDIFF, Wales, July 17 (UPI) -- Tom Robinson of the Bahama Islands set a British Commonwealth Games record of 9.5 seconds in the first heat of the men's 100-yard dash today at the opening of the thirtyfour-country meet in Cardiff Arms Park.

LONDON, July 17 -- The establishment of an international research station on the volcanic Galapagos Islands, 600 miles west of the coast of Ecuador, was discussed here today at the International Zoological Congress.
The following dispatch was written by Frank H. Bartholomew, president of United Press International, following a visit to Switzerland.
State Superintendent of Insurance Julius S. Wikler called on all Blue Cross plans in the state yesterday to include hospitalization for mental illness in their basic contracts.

The big horse at Jamaica yesterday was Christopher T. Chenery's First Landing. Many of the 18,135 fans on hand had a speculative interest in the 2-year-old colt and their "move" in his direction wasn't generated by any front-page headlines, either.
The grand jury investigating boxing yesterday indicted Harry (Champ) Segal, a professional fight manager. He was accused of acting as an undercover fight manager in a middleweight bout last March.

JUNEAU, Alaska, July 12 -- This territorial capital, nestling between Mounts Juneau and Roberts on one side and the Gastineau Channel of the Alaskan "inside passage" on the other, is concerned over its future.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- A new advance in the United States quest to harness the hydrogen bomb reaction for industrial power was reported today.

WASHINGTON, July 17, (AP) -- Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, announced the organization today of a business panel to study the Soviet Union's trade offensive and other world economic developments.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The Treasury announced today that it would offer a one-year certificate bearing 1 5/8 per cent interest in exchange for $16,264,000,000 of certificates and bonds maturing Aug. 1 and Sept. 15.
CHICAGO, July 17 (AP) -- A strong flurry in the final few minutes of trading sent most grain futures prices into new highs for the season on the Board of Trade here today.
Record sales and earnings were achieved by Parke, Davis Co. in the first half of this year.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee was forced today to suspend hearings on an Administration bill authorizing the State Department to refuse passports to Communists, Red sympathizers and others.
BUFFALO, July 17 -- The National Catholic Family Life convention voiced here today its "categoric and unequivocal" opposition to segregated housing.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) -- The House Agriculture Committee dimmed prospects today that Congress would close a loophole this year through which some companies had escaped meat regulation by the Federal Trade Commission.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 17 -- Organized religion in the suburbs is in danger of "betraying its heritage by becoming the handmaiden of secular pressures," a group of Long Islanders was warned today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 17 -- Following are the texts of a Swedish resolution presented today to the Security Council, and revised versions of the United States and Soviet resolutions submitted Tuesday on the Lebanese situation:
Official silence fell yesterday in the controversial question of birth control therapy in city hospitals.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The Senate today killed an attempt to make the reciprocal trade program permanent and held a night session on the bill as prospects for speedy passage faded.

Gaining a 1 1/2-1/2 margin against East Germany in the fifth round, Russia's champion team maintained its lead in the students' chess tournament at Varna, according to a report from Bulgaria yesterday. Two games were adjourned.

COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., July 17 (AP) -- Mrs. Barbara Bruning McGhie of Chappaqua was the lone survivor today among five former champions who had entered the 1958 state women's golf tournament. She defeated Mrs. Francis Maloney of Rochester, 4 and 2, in quarter-final play on the 6,372-yard Cooperstown Country Club course.

NEWARK, July 17 -- In defiance of a restraining order from the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners, the New York Central Railroad today curtailed its non-rush-hour passenger ferry service between Weehawken and New York.

KING HUSSEIN I -- short of stature but long on courage -- has squared his slight shoulders again. Close observers of the Jordanian scene find his latest stand against Nasserism and communism thoroughly in keeping with his past plucky performances.
PORT CHESTER, N. Y., July 17 -- Motorists soon will be able to drive nonstop from the Bronx to Rhode Island over 144 miles of one of the most thickly populated and...

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 17 (UPI) -- Undefeated Tomy Lee raced to his fifth victory today. He won the $90,000 Starlet Stakes at Hollywood Park by two and one-quarter lengths for the 2-year-old championship of the Hollywood Park meeting.

For two hours yesterday Governor Harriman watched and encouraged fifty father-and-son teams soliciting funds for the United Jewish Appeal of Greater New York. The Governor is the appeal's chairman of the telephone campaign for this month.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 17 -- Brazil's President Juscelino Kubitschek warned today that Middle Eastern events and the possibility that "from one hour to the next cold war may become transformed into effective war" were rendering more urgent than ever the strengthening of this hemisphere.

TRENTON, July 17 -- Despite the previously negative response from North Jersey municipalities, Gov. Robert B. Meyner said today he had arranged a conference to reconsider the proposal of nine railroads to pay their 1958 taxes in installments.
CLEVELAND, July 17 -- A protest against the proposed imposition of tolls for ships using the Welland Canal was issued here today by the Lake Carriers Association.
The U. S. S. Taconic, a humble toiler of the sea, has suddenly taken a front-page role in history in the harbor of Beirut, Lebanon.
ST. HELIER, Jersey, July 17 (Reuters) -- An object washed up on a beach at Jersey in the Channel Islands last month has been identified as part of a United States Snark guided missile.

The General Foods Corporation maintained its high level of earnings in the quarter ended June 30, the first of its fiscal year, by showing a profit of $12,754,000. In the similar three months last year, the net earnings were $12,778,000.

The Teamsters Union joined one of its court-appointed monitors yesterday in calling for a Federal investigation of the monitor's charge that he had been offered $100,000 to become a rubber-stamp for the union.
MOSCOW, July 18 (AP) -- The United States Embassy here is an insignificant looking cream-colored building on the large thoroughfare called B Circle which rings the center of Moscow.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- A Labor Department official has predicted that insured unemployment next winter will be about as bad as it was earlier this year.
The Department of Welfare had fifty-six Indians on city reservations yesterday. The reservations were in four downtown hotels.
MEXICO CITY, July 18 (AP) -- The Government announced last night it would finance the withholding of Mexican cotton from the world market in order to obtain fair prices.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement issued today by Lincoln White, State Department press officer, on a warning given by the United States to the United Arab Republic:

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The United States Government is preparing to call in the committee of oil companies that formulated plans for the Suez oil lift in 1956 to consider plans for a possible new emergency.
NEWARK, July 18 -- The State Board of Public Utility Commissioners ordered the New York Central System today to restore full passenger service on its ferry boats between Weehawken and New York.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- A former Army official said today that he had protested vigorously last year against "pressure" in an Army contract case that involved Sherman Adams.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Major United States military movements in the Middle East were still in progress today. A Pentagon spokesman described the situation as "still touchy."
Statistics on a 106,400-deadweight-ton supertanker under construction in Japan for an American company were disclosed yesterday.
NEW DELHI, India, July 18 -- India called today for the withdrawal of United States forces from Lebanon.
DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, July 18 -- A leading Iraqi republican predicted today that his country would merge with the United Arab Republic in the near future.
Air bubbles rose for twenty minutes yesterday from the murky depths of the East River as the second stage of salvage work was started on the sunken tanker Empress Bay.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI) -- The House Appropriations Committee approved today its last regular money bill of the session, a $3,131,094,797 measure for the Atomic Energy Commission and some other Federal activities.

The already great political, economic and military dependence of East Germany upon, and subjection to, the Soviet Union is to be carried even farther. Under the terms of the new Soviet-East German economic agreement the latter area will in effect become a manufacturing subsidiary of the former. Greatly increased quantities of Soviet raw materials will flow westward, and greatly increased quantities of East German manufactures will be shipped toward Moscow in return.

BONN, Germany, July 18 -- Felix von Eckardt, head of the Federal Press Office, told reporters today that it was his Government's urgent wish that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization undertake a comprehensive discussion of the United States and British policies and aims in the Middle East crisis.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved yesterday 2 points higher to 18 lower, in a moderate volume of business.

The weather forecaster is criticized for many things that happen, meteorologically speaking, during the year. Now he has incurred the displeasure of business men in the Rockaways, Queens, because he forecasts rain on summer week-ends and holidays. The resort men complain that the prediction of bad weather keeps crowds away from the beach, even if the rain never materializes.
The wheel has gone the full turn in the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan since the British were ousted from that tiny state a little more than two years ago.
Summer provides those in the theatre world with time to plan and develop new ideas, and this is true also for those engaged in the religious drama movement in New York.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 18 -- Robert Murphy, United States Under Secretary of State, talked today with Gen. Fuad Shehab, commander of the Lebanese Army, Premier Sami es-Solh and the Speaker of Parliament, Adel Osseiran. The substance of their talks was not disclosed.

UNTIL Gloria Shain was 27 years old, she had never sunk her pretty white bicuspids into an onion or a silver of garlic. Then she met and married Noel Regney, a Frenchman who, like all true Gauls, would sooner swill coffee during dinner than forsake these pungent vegetables. Monsieur prevailed and Madame is now cooking a la Francaise.

THOMPSONVILLE, Conn., July 18 (AP) -- Marvin Kratter, New York realty investor, has purchased the land and buildings of the Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company. The transaction involved $1,000,000 in cash and a mortgage of $4,000,000.

LENOX, Mass, July 18 -- A week-end of music devoted chiefly to works of Brahms opened tonight at Tanglewood with the Serenade No. 1 in D, Op. 11, played by the Boston Symphony Orchestra. Charles Munch conducted.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 18 -- Nearly all of the United States Sixth Fleet was in port here or off Beirut today. The latest units arrived in the morning and landed further contingents of marines to reinforce those already ashore.

TORONTO, July 18 (Canadian Press) -- William Mills was ousted today as secretary-treasurer and business agent of the Toronto General Truckers Union. He was also barred for life from holding office in the union.
City officials were still silent yesterday on the matter of birth control therapy in the municipal hospitals.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- A Senate report sharply censured the Justice Department today for agreeing to compromise consent judgments in most of its antitrust and monopoly cases.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Supporters and opponents of the reciprocal trade bill agreed today to wait until next week for a Senate vote on extending the program.

LONDON, July 18 -- Danger signals flying in Moscow have led British officials to expect some early and tangible Soviet assistance for President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic and for Arab nationalism.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The Senate overwhelmingly passed a Pentagon reorganization bill tonight giving President Eisenhower many but not all of the changes in set-up he had requested. The vote was 80 to 0.

THERE are two ways of judging Edward Nichols' biography of Gen. John F. Reynolds, "Toward Gettysburg."* One is by its title -- as another book about the Civil War. Yet it is far more than that. It is -- by its contents -- a remarkably clear picture of what it meant to be an American soldier in the dynamic middle reaches of the nineteenth century.

Eighteen Hungarian refugees picketing the offices of the Soviet delegation to the United Nations yesterday held as placards afternoon newspapers saying "Moscow Mobs Riot, 100,000 Storm U. S. Embassy."

CARACAS, Venezuela, July 18 -- Venezuelan oil production for the first half of 1958 was about 2,510,000 barrels a day, according to official statistics released today. This is about 380,000 barrels a day less than in the same period last year.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 18 -- Following are the texts of resolutions introduced by the United States and the Soviet Union in the Security Council today calling for an emergency General Assembly session:
LONDON, July 18 -- A tough 44-year old parachutist, who has been one of the unknowns of Britain's armed forces, has jumped into the news as commander of the first contingents sent to protect Jordan.
SUMMIT, N. J., July 18 -- Terry Logan of Essex Fells retained her Garden State Women's Golf Association championship today.
State Senator Walter J. Mahoney took the spotlight yesterday in the battle for the Republican nomination for Governor.
The rise in wholesale gasoline prices became general yesterday. Domestic factors, according to spokesmen for the producers, were responsible for the increase.

After a heavy week of corporate financing, activity in this area of the new capital market is slated to be at a fairly low ebb in the week ahead. Conversely, new offerings of tax exempt securities will be larger than they have been for some time.

The debate in the Security Council on the dispatch of troops to Lebanon and Jordan was destined from the beginning to end in frustration. The disposition of the votes and the veto powers involved made it certain that no result could be achieved.

Three youths staged a daylight mugging in Harlem yesterday with a uniformed policeman standing across the street in plain view.

Leonard J. Winston, realty operator, has purchased the six-story building at 1350 Shakespeare Avenue, the Bronx. It has thirty-three apartments and nine stores. The property 116 by 80 feet, fronts on Edward L. Grant Highway and Boscobel Place.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- President Eisenhower remembered the birthday of one of his administrative assistants today with an appointment to a Federal judgeship, a lifetime job, at $25,500 a year.

That fellow down the street with the malicious grin has been making the rounds with the first tomato of the season. With unabashed conceit he displays the smooth round fruit that he babied into a deep pink weeks before its time.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The Senate rackets committee closed the Chicago phase of its hearings today with a condemnation of management and unions in the restaurant industry. When hearings resume next Wednesday, they will deal with the Detroit area.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 18 (AP) -- Union representatives of 100,000 workers at seventy-two General Electric Company plants across the country announced demands today for a guaranteed annual wage.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 18 -- The traveler landing in this beautiful capital is immediately impressed by the contrast between the air of apparent peace and tranquillity and the very obvious tensions between sections of the population.
SALT LAKE CITY, July 18 -- It pays to have faith. That is the moral, it would appear, of a business saga that recently has taken place here.
LONDON, July 18 (Reuters) -- Following are excerpts from an address in Damascus by Gamal Abdel Nasser, President of the United Arab Republic, as broadcast by the Cairo radio:

WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce said today it was "conceivable" that a family with a total income of $9,800 a year could receive Federally subsidized public housing under the omnibus housing bill approved by the Senate.
CHICAGO, July 18 (AP) -- Corn futures prices extended their recent gains with a good rally on the Board of Trade today. Other grains and soybeans finished mostly lower.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI) -- Representative Brent Spence, Democrat of Kentucky, reminding his colleagues that "charity begins at home," urged the House Rules Committee today to approve a $2,000,000,000 loan program for local public works.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Vigilant Detroit traffic police are costing the Federal Government $365,510 annually in man-hours lost, the Army has told Congress.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Average wholesale prices in primary markets declined 0.1 per cent to 119.2 per cent of their 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

CARDIFF, Wales, July 18 (UPI) -- The Duke of Edinburgh reading a message from Queen Elizabeth II to a record field of 1,300 athletes, officially opened the sixth British Commonwealth Games tonight at Cardiff Arms Park.
MOSCOW, July 18 -- Mr. Khrushchev has conferred here with President Nasser on the explosive Middle Eastern situation, the Soviet Government announced tonight.

The Security National Bank of Long Island in Huntington confirmed yesterday that the Federal Bureau of Investigation was investigating an unsecured loan of $200,000 the bank had made to Earle Belle, a Pittsburgh financier.

GENEVA, July 18 -- The conference of scientists from the East and the West began a new phase of their discussions today, still divided on the radiological method of detecting tests of nuclear explosions.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Bob Feller today assailed the payment of large bonuses to promising youngsters.
AUSABLE FORKS, N. Y., July 18 (AP) -- Rockwell Kent said today he would leave Monday for Soviet Russia, a trip long delayed by the State Department's refusal to issue the artist a passport.

GLYNDEBOURNE, England, July 18 -- The case of "The Rake's Progress" should be reopened. Stravinsky's only full-length opera has received a markedly different verdict here from the one it had in New York six years ago. The change of venue has done it a world of good.
A committee headed by Mrs. Robert S. Salant is making plans for a theatre benefit on Dec. 8 for the Child Adoption Service of the State Charities Aid Association.
ALBANY, July 18 -- The State University will increase from two to seven the number of teachers' colleges offering training for science and for high school science and mathematics teaching.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 18 -- Premier Chen Cheng told Nationalist Chinese legislators at a tea party yesterday that his Government was prepared to meet any eventuality in the Taiwan area that might stem from the Middle East crisis.

PLANDOME, L. I., July 18 -- Gordon Stott of the Nassau Country Club, the winner in 1950, was the only former champion to survive as the thirty-fifth Long Island Golf Association amateur championship moved through the first two rounds of match play at the Plandome Country Club today.

ROME, July 18 -- Amintore Fanfani, Premier and Foreign Minister, sent personal messages today to President Eisenhower and Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of West Germany. Government headquarters here and the United States and West German embassies refused to disclose the contents.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 18 -- Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower told the Costa Rican National Assembly this afternoon that the conscience of the United States "is free this day for the action of my Government" in the Middle East. He was applauded by the chamber.
WARSAW, July 18 -- Poland and Yugoslavia took new steps today in the delicate political moves they have been carrying out for the past couple of weeks.

The Jewish Child Care Association of New York has sold the five buildings occupying a plot 125 by 100 feet at 206 to 216 East Fifty-ninth Street to Jack Brause, realty investor. The property, 105 feet east of Third Avenue, was assembled by the seller two years ago for improvement with a building for its own occupancy.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Representative Olin E. Teague, Democrat of Texas, said today that he doubted the day would come when needy veterans would not be given medical care by the Veterans Administration for non-service-connected ailments.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI) -- Harris Ellsworth, chairman of the Civil Service Commission, recommended today that Congress refrain from taking action on legislation regarding Government security dismissals until the Administration completed its study of the problem.

BUENOS AIRES, July 18 -- The Argentine judiciary won its fight today to keep political patronage out of the Federal courts.

GUANTANAMO BAY, Cuba, July 18 -- Cuban rebels freed today the last fourteen kidnapped United States servicemen that they were holding. They told the men they had done so because of "the Lebanese situation."

AT the end of Long Island a visitor will find more to buy than just the celebrated ducks and potatoes. For instance, several of the big New York stores maintain charmingly decorated small shops along the main street of Southampton, which are still stacked to the top shelves with summer sports clothes, now growing scarcer by the minute in the big city.

Cherry-Burrell Corporation The Cherry-Burrell Corporation reduced the quarterly dividen on the common sock with the declaration yesterday of 10 cents a share, payable July 31. In previous quarters 20 cents was paid.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Two Democratic members of a statehood delegation from Hawaii said after a conference with House Speaker Sam Rayburn, Democrat of Texas, today that they were greatly encouraged about prospects for statehood in the next Congress.
NEWPORT, R. I., July 18 -- For the fourth time in seven days, the "race off" signal interrupted the preliminary trial series to select a defender of the America's Cup.
The unofficial motto of the Marine Corps -- "Once a Marine, Always a Marine" -- was voiced again yesterday by veterans of the corps at a reunion here.
Three more war books are scheduled for publication next month on successive days. They will be issued by Norton.
CHICAGO, July 18 (AP) -- Sammy Giammalva, 23-year-old Houston tennis strategist, upset top-seeded Barry MacKay today in the quarter-finals of the national clay court tournament.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 18 -- Two ocean-race winners and the four division champions from last year's event were among the forty-three entries in Indian Harbor Yacht Club's cruise, which started shortly before noon today.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., July 18 -- Workmen completed laying the steel plate underdecking around the steel-reinforced concrete vault of the Suffolk County National Bank's new single-story building this week. The new edifice is rising at Roanoke Avenue and Second Street.
The short interest position on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 6,087,260 shares at the close of business on Tuesday.
Federal agents and the police were hunting last night for a 33-year-old wheel-chair patient who had disappeared twice from Welfare Island, where he was being held in deportation proceedings.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 18 -- The Musicians Guild of America today urged Hollywood musicians to start a back-to-work movement Monday at the major studios. As a first step the musicians were advised to inform contractors of their willingness to resume work immediately.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 18 -- United States marines, spread out along nine miles of the Lebanese coast, have the situation so well in hand that some of them began philosophizing today on why they were there.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- An aerial "tug" was patented on behalf of the Hiller Aircraft Corporation of Palo Alto, Calif., this week. The tug is a helicopter designed to lift and lower a jet airplane where space is limited.

LONDON, July 18 -- Bryan F. Linney, 45-year-old British engineer, was sentenced today to fourteen years' imprisonment for selling secret information to a former military attache at the Czechoslovak Embassy here.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18 -- The Third United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled today that Philadelphia has the right to collect wage taxes from nonresidents employed at the Naval Base here.

AMMAN, Jordan, July 18 -- Additional small units of British paratroopers flew into Jordan today as King Hussein's Government awaited the start of an American oil lift to this gasoline-starved country.

RABAT, Morocco, July 18 -- The Moroccan National Consultative Assembly "forcibly denounced" tonight "the intervention of foreign armed forces in the internal affairs of countries" of the Middle East.

Bankers' acceptances -- bank-guaranteed notes, which arise mainly in world trade -- were in steady demand by investors, mostly institutional, last month, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

ROME, July 18 -- Hips are being camouflaged by Rome designers Clarette Gallotti, Fontana and Garnett. Miss Gallotti, known as the "Weaver of the Islands," is bubbling the hipline of her capri trousers. Fontana flanks the flanks with squared saddle-bag pockets or rudder-fins. Eleanora Garnett festoons the hips with peplums and tunics, some inflated like giant potato chips. In return Fontana and Garnett give us back the waistline, for the most part nature's own.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- A bill requiring the numbering of small motorboats as part of a marine safety program was passed today by the House and sent to the Senate. The measure was passed by a standing vote of 181-29.

Y., July 18 -- Any haitus that might develop in the flow of oil from Middle Eastern countries would loom as an opportunity for coal producers in Belgium, Britain, France and Western Germany. Lovisa Lund, fresh from Sweden and unable to speak English, comes with her family to a small farming community made up of settlers from many countries. At first she is deeply disappointed to find life in her new home unbelievably crude and her neighbors unfriendly.
The Third Marine Division Association yesterday selected Sidney McMath, former Governor of Arkansas, as president. The association is holding its third annual meeting in the Roosevelt Hotel.

PARIS, July 19 -- France will offer three choices of future status to her overseas territories under the new constitution -- continuance as territories, integration with France or membership in a federation.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., July 19 -- Al Mengert, the 29-year-old Echo Lake pro, matched par for the final twenty-seven holes today to win the New Jersey open golf championship for the second straight year. He finished with a 281 for seventy-two holes.
" ACTIVATE the 'Queen of Sheba' file," producer Alexander H. Cohen ordered last week in tones sufficiently imperious for a man embracing royalty, no matter how long deceased.

GENEVA, July 19 -- Even if an international agreement should be reached to suspend atomic tests, it probably would be almost two years before a detection system could be completed to police the agreement.

While most of the ideas for developing the non-military uses of nuclear power are aimed at a controlled rather than an explosive liberation of the tremendous power of the atom, a little known project is devising methods to use just this fast explosive power for peaceful purposes.

MAINE'S millionth visitor, who is not really the millionth visitor at all, will be chosen at a drawing on Aug. 3 at Portland, and the winner -- most probably a couple -- will be taken on an expense-free, two-week tour of the state after a three-day celebration.

United States-flag cargo vessels will not be able to operate profitably in the St. Lawrence River and Great Lakes services at present cargo rates and under proposed seaway tolls, according to shipping experts.
BERLIN, July 19 -- Nine United States Army men held for six weeks by the East German authorities were released today under a Red Cross arrangement.

" SOME day this hill will mean so much to you that you wouldn't leave it even if you had the chance," so young Mr. Scott, a prospector for land, assured 10-year-old Ann Hamilton. But Ann was skeptical -- she knew too well the lonesomeness of an only girl among the isolated frontier families of the Western Pennsylvania region.

The rapid disappearance of America's wild and untamed places before the onslaught of the bulldozer is being matched only by the rapid growth of demand for unspoiled outdoor recreational areas. The resultant pressure on such natural havens of peace and beauty as are left in this shrinking continent of ours has made it imperative that they be granted some firm legal protection under an explicit declaration of Congressional policy.
The clouds of war darkened the skies of the Middle East last week as troops, ships and planes of many nations once again converged on that cockpit of history.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Fred A. Seaton, Secretary of the Interior, summoned officials of sixteen oil companies today to an emergency meeting here next Wednesday on the Middle East.
NOW is the time to enjoy the flowers of field and roadside in casual bouquets. Wild flowers should be picked carefully and discriminately. Then blooms must be properly conditioned before handling.

Polv Bang-Jensen should be commended rather than condemned for his moral courage in risking and losing his livelihood in order to protect the trust placed in him as an individual and as a representative of the United Nations.

COLORADO is the rampart state of the nation. In its western half the Rockies raise a barricade whose villainous saw-tooth terrain includes fifty-four peaks over fourteen thousand feet high. Throughout the state's history, transportation has been a major problem. Beginning in 1871, William J. Palmer attempted to solve the difficulty by building the first of the many narrow gauge lines which later laced the mountains.

LOS ANGELES, July 19 -- A leading figure in the field of atomic science suggested this week that continuation of low-power nuclear tests was important quite aside from weapons development.

THOSE men and women we call saints were not born better than other people, they just tried a little harder to be better. This we see in reading the stories of their lives in THE SAINTS: A Concise Biographical Dictionary (Hawthorn, $12.95), edited by John Coulson. An amazing number of heroes of the faith, 2,223 to be exact, from all times and places, are included in this handsomely printed volume.
Those of us who have been grown up long enough to remember one or more World Wars may have wondered last week, with a sudden chill running through our veins, if history were about to repeat itself.

THERE has been, since the war, no dearth of books in English about Yugoslavia. They have been for the most part repetitious and have dealt with the obvious. It has remained for an American social anthropologist to give us a fully detailed report of life as it is lived today in a Yugoslav village.
SANTA MONICA, Calif. -- A noteworthy addition to southern California's now growing roster of major tourist attractions will materialize this Tuesday with the opening of Pacific Ocean Park here.

IN seven big fire-proof tents on high ground not far from the center of town more than 400 contemporary American paintings, selected by eight regional juries from more than 10,000 examples submitted in a nation - wide competition, have gone on display in the first of a projected series of Provincetown art festivals.
SARASOTA, Fla., July 19 (UPI) -- H. Maxwell Goldfine slashed himself between 80 and 100 times with a razor in an apparent suicide attempt today after a near all-night party.
BONN, Germany, July 19 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer decided today to cancel his weekend visit to West Berlin because of the Middle East crisis and its possible repercussions on the European scene.

DETROIT, July 19 (AP) -- The United Automobile Workers said today that 40,144 Chrysler workers had voted for strike action if necessary to win union demands in negotiations for a new contract. The vote against strike action was announced as 2,144.

PHILADELPHIA, July 18 -- The first Negro clergyman of the Evangelical United Brethren Church is serving as pastor of Trinity Church. The church has had only white members in its sixty-two years of existence in the Germantown section here.
The market for United States Government securities is being freshened for a succession of big financing transactions that are sure to keep bond pricers busy from now until February.

ONE of the rather rare and beautiful wild flowers of late July and August is the false foxglove (gerardia). Its stalks of showy yellow flowers appear at a time of year when few other wild flowers are blooming, and certainly none that has the delicate, springlike charm of false foxglove.

Rear Admiral Henry C. Perkins, Commander of the Eastern Coast Guard Area, has announced the appointment of Capt. Donald B. MacDiarmid as air and operations officer for the area with headquarters here.

Banks started their annual campaign last week to rouse the memories of depositors with dormant accounts. The first advertisements of savings banks, listing the names and last known addresses of missing depositors, appeared in local newspapers.

KING OF PRUSSIA, Pa. -- The nation s newest luxury motel, a $2,580,000 layout on a fifteen-acre tract, was dedicated and officially opened for business last week after ceremonies in which the Washington Grays, a historic military unit, and several hundred civic and business officials of the Greater Philadelphia area participated.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 19 (UPI) -- Only a few tanks and soldiers at strategic street corners remained today to show that Iraq had undergone a violent change in Government.

BOSLEY CROWTHER'S article last Sunday, "More Movie War," pinpointed a depressing fact. There can be little question that instead of using the record of recent hostilities meaningfully, underlying causes are "being sloughed off as standard background for generally inconsequential dramas of love."

IF "Backstage Portrait" is in any way an authentic portrait of life in contemporary England, it would seem that the adults are pretty casual in their treatment of 17-year-old daughters. Olivia Hartwell's parents inform her that it is necessary for her to get a job, and as there doesn't seem to be anything she particularly wants to do, they suggest that she work as assistant stage manager in her Uncle Wilkie's repertory company in Wales.

Although unseasonably cool weather hampered trade at the big retail stores here last week, the employment picture was brightened somewhat. Electric power output to large industrial customers turned upward to show a gain of 2.15 per cent for the month of June over that of 1957, as contrasted with a year-to-year decline of 9.41 per cent in May, and a dip of 7.68 per cent in April.

Assured that their trip to Moscow will not be called off, members of the United States men's and women's track and field team went through a last tune-up yesterday in a Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union handicap meet at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.
TRENTON, July 19 -- Harrison A. Williams, Democratic candidate for United States Senator, and his fourteen associates on the Congressional ticket announced a campaign today for aid to the state.
PRINCETON, N. J., July 19 -- Failures for academic reasons reached a new low at Princeton University in 1957-58, Dean Jeremiah S. Finch said today.
The 1959 International Seamen's Lifeboat Races -- the twentieth running for the lifeboat racing championship of the world -- will be held next year in connection with World Trade Week.
Objects of American Indian art will be included in an auction sale Thursday at 11 A. M. at the Plaza Art Galleries, 406 East Seventy-ninth Street.

The landing of the marines in Lebanon bears no resemblance to the attack upon the Suez Canal in 1956. It was done at the request of the country's recognized Government, not against its will and not in order to overthrow it. Yet President Eisenhower rightly spoke of possible serious consequences.

THE Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, near Lee, Mass., will break somewhat with its own precedent this week not only by giving over the entire program to one company, but also by adding an eighth performance to the customary schedule.
Trucks set several records last year, including the payment of $2,410,000,000 in special truck taxes, the Automobile Manufacturers Association reported yesterday.
CHICAGO, July 19 -- Bernard (Tut) Bartzen of Dallas and Sammy Giammalva of Houston gained the singles final today in the national clay courts tennis tournament.
The recent pick-up in business will continue, according to the National Association of Purchasing Agents.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 19 (UPI) -- Bolivians will vote tomorrow to elect one-third of the eighteen-man Senate and half of the sixty-eight-member Chamber of Deputies.

MOST children are fascinated with a talking bird -- small wonder then that Andy's baby crow, Jo-Jo, is the pet of the neighborhood. While Andy carefully nursed this bird of insatiable appetite, Jo-Jo's roguish personality and impudent tongue bloom on the worm diet. He loves glitter, and steals decor from ladies' hats.

DELIGHTFUL and astute, are the comments by youthful readers, expressing their ideas of idea literary fare for their summer vacation reading enjoyment. ("Fantasy, Horror, a Boy and His Dog.") Interestingly enough, although, twenty diverse shades of opinions are offered, only one youngster avowed preference for comic books.

THE grim and shadowy world intrigue is illumined in these two tales of British agents on solo missions deep behind the Iron Curtain. In Lawrence Durrell's "White Eagles Over Serbia," it is Colonel Methune operating out of Special Operations -- the "awkward shop" -- who wanders about the mountains of Serbia prior to the Tito-Stalin rupture to learn the reason for all the royalist activity in that area.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 19 -- Robert Murphy, President Eisenhower's special representative, has rejected a complaint by the Speaker of the Lebanese Parliament that the United States should not have sent troops into Lebanon without the Parliament's consent.
CHICAGO, July 19 -- Hay fever victims would do well to stay out of Coldwater, Mich., the "hay fever capital" of the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI) -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, told balking House Democrats today that 1958 income for cotton growers would be cut "substantially" unless Congress revived a farm surplus disposal law by early August.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 19 -- Larchmont Yacht Club's sixtieth annual race week got off to such a windy start today that the majority of the races scheduled had to be canceled for safety reasons.

Department store sales in the Twelfth Federal Reserve District for the week ended July 12 showed a gain of 2 per cent over the similar period a year ago. This marks the first time in more than five weeks that the district total has been on the plus side.

GUATEMALA, July 12 -- The Government of President Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes, barely four and a half months old, is being subjected to the political batterings of both Right and Left Wing elements. The Right Wing opposition has scored a political coup by adding the head of the powerful Roman Catholic Church to its forces.
PALOMAR, Calif., July 19 (AP) -- For ten years astronomers atop mile-high Palomar Mountain have been looking into space farther than man had seen before.
CLEVELAND, July 19 -- More than one-third of the available Great Lakes ore carriers are idle land probably will not move a cargo this season.
HAVANA, July 19 -- The Cuban armed forces are poised for a new offensive against the insurgents who have been fighting government troops in Oriente Province for the last sixteen months.

WITH good reason the daylily is becoming more widely used in landscaping. This hardy perennial is easy to grow, demands only routine maintenance, is little troubled by insects or disease and, once established, increases in decorative value over the years.
Louis Dejoie, exiled Haitian political leader, arrived at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, late yesterday afternoon from Mexico City, where he had been living since May.

THE Argus 500 Electromatic, just announced by Argus Cameras, brings the price of the fully automatic, self-operating type of slide projector, down to $99.95. Slides are automatically changed at any selected interval of from three to thirty seconds.
LONDON, July 19 (Reuters) -- A cancer specialist said today that he had discovered in cigarette smoke a substance identical to a known cancer causing agent of "considerable potency."
DANBURY, Conn., July 19 -- A $6,470,000 urban redevelopment project that will transform this city's main business district is awaiting Federal approval.

MANY ingenious twists enliven this crisply told tale of an antique toy ship that flies through time as well as space. Now pocket-size, now large enough to accommodate the four Lucky Grant children, it takes them wherever they wish and back home before they are missed.
PARIS, July 19 -- It was reported today that the French Government had taken a stiff position on the negotiations for a European free trade area that will be resumed here next week.
Five states are scheduled to hold "right-to-work" referendums Nov. 4.

JERRY LEWIS likes baseball and he likes crowds. Most of all he likes to entertain people, to see happy faces and to hear waves of laughter. He had both to his heart's content last week while filming sequences for "The Geisha Boy" on the campus of the University of California at Los Angeles on Monday and the next day at Wrigley Field.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 19 -- The Middle East today is one vast question mark, as much economic as political. Where does it go from here?

BEIRUT, July 19 -- The Marines have landed in Lebanon, but politically it is still unclear how far the situation is in hand. Many pro-Western Lebanese are unhappy about the American landing. They fear it may mean this will be the first battlefield of a new world war.
The 4 per cent yield on high grade, long term corporate bonds has returned after almost four months.
ROME, July 19 -- Pope Pius XII made his first broadcast to cloistered nuns throughout the world today. Many of them had never listened to a radio.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19 (AP) -- Mrs. William du Pont Jr. of Wilmington, Del., defeated Gwenyth Thomas, 17, Shaker Heights, Ohio, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4, for the Middle States women's grass courts championship today at the Philadelphia Cricket Club. Mrs. du Pont was seeded No. 1.
PORTLAND, Ore., July 19 -- Twenty-five nations have reserved space for an International Trade Fair to be held next year as part of Oregon's centennial exposition.

ON its fifth time around, Cinerama is offering yet another travelogue, which makes it appear the proprietors of the wide-screen process are pretty well settled into a straight sight-seeing groove.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- The Bureau of Mines has forecast that 6,785,000 barrels of domestic crude oil a day will be consumed or exported in August.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 19 -- The School of Theology of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island will open on Sept, 20 the first permanent home it has had since its founding in 1955.

Southwestern business in most aspects looked moderately good last week. Although department store sales still were below 1957 levels, other parts of the picture were better. Adequate rains over most of the area considerably improved the farm-ranch outlook.
John A. Tillinghast took off for Moscow July 2, got as far as Copenhagen, and is due back in New York today.
CHICAGO, July 19 -- Closed-circuit television, which has had a variety of industrial and educational uses, will go commercial here for four days starting Monday.

HAVERTOWN, Pa., July 19 -- Sam Snead, who has won a hundred tournaments, took the lead after fifty-four holes in the Professional Golfers Association championship today. Snead posted his second consecutive 67 at the Llanerch Country Club to make his aggregate 207.

PARIS, July 19 -- Lingering French annoyance over the failure of the United States and Britain to consult Paris prior to the landings of their forces in the Middle East has been the subject of mild protests to London and Washington.

The murder of Cristoforo Rubino on a Brooklyn street Friday night was attributed yesterday to his underworld colleagues in a major narcotics syndicate.

TOKYO, July 15 -- Conditions in Indonesia today are somewhat more stable than they were several months ago. Armed resistance to the Government, however, continues in many parts of the country and the economic, political and military problems facing the regime are formidable indeed.

WHEN Col. Gregory ("Pappy") Boyington, United States Marine Corps, one of the really great fighter pilots of World War II, came home after surviving three years of combat flying and nearly two years of life in a Japanese prison camp, he was a national hero.

Your editorial "Government and Art" in your July 13 issue will be welcomed by all who are interested in better governmental relations to the arts. THE sturdy tree of Jewish folk music has its roots deep in antiquity and its freshest buds in the modern world. Like the people who produced it, Jewish folk song has been frequently transplanted to alien soil and grafted to other culture, but still it flourishes.

DAYLILIES will hold the spotlight at the annual Hemerocallis Show sponsored by the Massachusetts Horticultural Society in cooperation with Region Four of the American Hemerocallis Society. HONOLULU -- With Alaska gaining statehood this year, Hawaii has moved one up on the roster toward becoming the Fiftieth, and the latest speculation on the part of tourist people here in the Territory is what effect statehood would have on visitor influx.

ONE hundred years ago this summer Lord Macaulay finished and sent off a short life of William Pitt the younger -- seventy octavo pages, and his last important work. He died the next year. This biographical essay, one of five that he had undertaken for the Encyclopedia Britannica, had caused him much trouble, as he noted in his diary, and yet it was one of the best things he ever did.

A MOST unusual woodland plant, and one which at first might not appear to have a flower, is the Indian pipe (Monotropa uniflora). The entire plant, including stems and leaves, is completely white, and resembles a miniature pipe standing on its stem.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 19 -- Two home runs and Ramon Monzant's effective relief pitching today carried San Francisco to a 5-4 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates as the Giants retained a half-game hold on first place in the National League race.

The world's most powerful continuously operating electromagnet, designed for the exploration of new frontiers of matter in the region near absolute zero (459.6 degrees below zero Fahrenheit), went into operation at the University of California in Berkeley last week.
ANTWERP, Belgium, July 19 (UPI) -- gorilla escaped from a zoo today and vented his fury from a rooftop until the police shot him dead.

STANTON, Del., July 19 -- The bargain-basement rush by the ladies of the thoroughbred world continued at Delaware Park today as William Haggin Perry's Alanesian captured the $38,362 New Castle, the second bauble in the distaff Big Three crown.

CONTRACT bridge with four-deal scoring has suddenly become popular throughout the country, and in New York City, where it has enjoyed some popularity for years, it is being played more often than ever before.

Continued claims for state unemployment compensation remained relatively unchanged last week at 41,900, but new claims advanced to 3,598 as summer vacation shutdowns started. Employees who are not eligible for paid vacations become, for statistical purposes, temporarily unemployed.

Hardly anyone would think of calling a politician a Girl Scout, or vice versa. But, Mrs. Dorothy Bell Lawrence has a word for women who want to go into politics. Her advice is: join the Girl Scouts and see the ward.

RALEIGH, N. C., July 19 -- Senator B. Everett Jordan resigned this week as Democratic National Committeeman after four years in the post. He had been under mild criticism for continuing to hold the post after his appointment to the Senate by Gov. Luther H. Hodges in April to succeed the late Senator W. Kerr Scott.

HARPSWELL, Me. -- This town on the southeast coast of Maine has two special claims to distinction this year: the first, a lasting one, is that for a century Harpswell has been a source of inspiration for writers and poets as no other Maine community has; secondly, it is celebrating its bicentennial, next Saturday through Aug. 1.

DETROIT, July 19 (UPI) -- Nearctis, with Benny Sorenowned by Windfield Farms Ltd., broke from the third post position, paced the fourteen-horse pack to the first turn and led all the way for a two-and-a-quarter-length victory in the $50,000 added Michigan Mile today.

Employment in Pennsylvania reached 4,196,200 in mid-May after climbing 17,500 from mid-April, according to a survey by the Bureau of Employment Security of the Pennsylvania Department of Labor and Industry. During that period, the bureau reported, employment in non-manufacturing industries rose 14,300, farm employment 4,900 and self-employed, unpaid family and domestic workers 7,600.

H L. HUMES' "The Underground City" does not, as your reviewer Frederic Morton says in his slurring comments, "pose" as a moral inquiry -- it is a moral inquiry, and a searching one. It examines the politics of war and peace, and of international relations.

LOS ANGELES, July 19 -- Ordinarily the only thing mysterious about the Los Angeles Dodgers is why they play such erratic baseball. But a larger enigma as of this week-end was their home-hunting outlook.

AS surely as fashion is previewed in the great couture salons of Paris, so the furniture headlines are spelled out in the annual wholesale markets at home. Each is the official forecast. And the forecast in furniture, at the recent Chicago and Grand Rapids markets, was this: a wider range of styles than ever before, with traditional decidedly in the lead.

LONDON, July 19 -- The exhibition of a tiny deep-sea worm-snail that was thought to have died out 500,000,000 years ago was hailed by zoologists at the International Zoological Congress here today as as important as the discovery of the coelacanth, the "fish with legs."

CINCINNATI, July 19 -- The president of the Hotel and Restaurant Employes and Bartenders International Union announced plans today to name a clean-up committee next week for the union's eleven units in the Chicago area.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 19 -- Indonesian veterans volunteered today an armed brigade to fight against United States and British troops in Lebanon and Jordan.

SUMMER chores in the wild-flower garden are relatively light. This is especially true of a well-established plot, where the plants are adjusted to their locale. Newly planted wild flowers and ferns, of course, will require more attention.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 19 -- The first three-engine Atlas intercontinental ballistic missile broke apart and crashed flaming into the sea at 1:36 P. M. today, two minutes after launching.

Weather shouldered the responsibility for the disappointing sales reported by retailers in the Kansas City trade area last week. Rains were general. In some areas floods resulted in widespread damage. Construction work in most areas came to a halt as the rains fell every day last week.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., July 19 (AP) -- The snorkel submarine Piper caught on a sand bar in calm seas off this Cape Cod town early today.

ALGIERS, July 11 -- The French Army's drive to make all but the most mountainous regions of Algeria safe for the October referendum is only partly a matter of pure military force. The army's second weapon is psychological warfare or, as it is called here, the "revolutionary war."

ASCOT, England, July 19 (AP) -- Ballymoss, owned by John McShain of Philadelphia, today won England's richest horse race -- the King George VI and Queen Elizabeth Stakes. First place was worth $66,197.
