GENEVA, July 20 (AP) -- The Swiss Government said today that it was prepared to organize a summit meeting proposed by Soviet Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev. However, Geneva hotel men say such a meeting would be physically impossible in Geneva before the end of the month.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 20 (UPI) -- The Giants chased Bob Friend with five runs in the first inning today and went on to beat Pittsburgh, 7 -- 3. The victory kept San Francisco, which has now won six straight, a half-game ahead of Milwaukee in the National League race.

CAIRO, July 20 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev was reported today to have told President Gamal Abdel Nasser that "volunteers" were waiting at Soviet airports to fly to the Middle East if the Arab leader should ask for them.
HULATA, Israel, July 20 -The normally explosive fortysix-mile Israeli-Syrian border has been unusually calm since the eruption of the Middle East crisis. There are no signs of trouble brewing.

The award of the final-round Davis Cup tie in the American Zone to the Westchester Country Club in Rye is one more bit of evidence of the comeback the club is making in the tennis picture. The matches between the United States and the winner of of the Argentine-Israel semifinal will be held Aug. 15 to 17 on the Westchester turf.
Foreign Secretary Selwyn Lloyd of Britain expressed the view yesterday on his departure for London that the Middle East crisis could be solved within the framework of the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The United States and Britain coordinated their Middle Eastern policies today for what looked like an August summit meeting with the Soviet Union.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 20 -Four battalions of United States Marines are guarding three vital areas around Beirut. They are the international airport, the port area and a district north of the city.

The National Bureau of Economic Research has for many years led the way in our effort to answer a question that the late Wesley C. Mitchell employed as the title for his last (posthumous) work on the subject. That volume, which was edited by Arthur F. Burns, Professor Mitchell's successor at the bureau, and published in 1951, was entitled: "What Happens During Business Cycles."
NEW DELHI, India, July 20 (AP) -- Following is the text of Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's response to Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's summit proposal:

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 20 -- The Larchmont Yacht Club got a few hours of excellent racing weather today. This was an improvement over yesterday, when the first day of Larchmont Race Week had more cancellations than competition.
HAVERTOWN, Pa., July 20 -- Dow Finsterwald, the new professional golf champion of the nation, once had to promise not to play the game.

AMSTERDAM, July 20 -- The Stock Exchange last week was shaken by Middle East developments and sharp losses occurred in all sections. However, prices ralied on Friday. There was considerable activity in Royal Dutch, although Royal Dutch Shell's Iraq output is only 5 per cent of its total production.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 20 -- Borba, Communist party organ, indicated tonight that the Government would prefer an effort to find a settlement of the middle Eastern crisis through an urgent meeting of the United Nations General Assembly rather than through a five-power summit meeting, as Moscow proposed.
The H. J. Heinz Company had the highest consolidated sales in its history in the fiscal year ended April 30, H. J. Heinz 2d, president, reported in an annual statement released today.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- The Middle East crisis has sharply stepped up the number of long-range nuclear United States bombers kept on alert for instant action.
BONN, Germany, July 20 -The West German Government refused to commit itself today on Nikita S. Khrushchev's demand for an immediate summit conference to deal with the Middle East crisis.

BONN, Germany, July 17--Officials here hope Premier Charles de Gaulle's attitude toward the European free trade area project will become clear next Wednesday. The Foreign Ministers of the six Common Market nations will then meet in Paris to decide whether to keep the negotiations for a free trade area going.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 20 -After a day without a curfew a Turkish Cypriote was shot dead tonight in the walled city of Nicosia. An immediate curfew was imposed.
Hashim Jawad, newly arrived delegate of the revolutionary Government of Iraq to the United Nations, said yesterday that the threat of Communist penetration of the Middle East no longer existed.

The American Federation of Television and Radio Artists ended its annual convention here yesterday after a twentyseven-hour discussion of pending contract negotiations with the major networks. Current contracts expire Nov. 15
Borough President John Cashmore of Brooklyn announced yesterday that he had asked the Board of Estimate for $636,000 to complete a major step in the widening of Boerum Place in downtown Brooklyn.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 20 -- Walter S. Gubelmann's seventyone-foot yawl Windigo and A. E. (Bill) Luders Jr.'s thirtyfive-foot sloop Storm repeated 1957 trophy victories today in the finish of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club's annual three-day cruise.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican .of New York, said today that the Administration's passport control bill ran counter in some respects "to our traditional 'concepts of Justice and fair. play.'"
MOSCOW, July 20 -- The Soviet Union celebrated Aviation Day today with restrained and carefully worded tributes to military and civilian fliers.

LENOX, Mass., July 20 -- An audience of 9,154, including 250 members of an excursion organized by the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences, gathered at Tanglewood for this afternoon's concert by Pierre Monteux and the Boston Symphony Orchestra.
The Rev. Dr. Lee A. Belford, chairman of the Department of Religious Education at New York University, yesterday branded anti-Semitism a "social snobbery," extremely unfortunate" and "evil."
The union whose members The make two-thirds of the country's dresses is getting a new look as distinctive as the chemise.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- One of the many extraneous results of the Goldfine-Adams affair is that Congressional approval of legislation authorizing United States help for Euratom, the European atomic power program, is now in doubt.
AMMAN, Jordan, July 20 -Jordan announced today she had severed her last diplomatic tie with President Gamal Abdel Nasser's United Arab Republic.

A 5-year-old boy died yesterday in a Harlem fire that a 6-year-old boy living in the same house admitted he had set. Five tenants in the four-story building, including four children, were critically burned.

A telephone switchboard that almost thinks has been developed for custom installations by L. M. Ericsson Telephone Company of Stockholm, Sweden. The new system is said to "Memorize" numbers to complete delayed calls in various ways.

CHICAGO, July 20 (UPI) -Bernard (Tut) Bartzen of Dallas won his second national clay court tennis title today with baseline skill that overcame Sam Giammalva of Houston, 3 -- 6, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 2, 6 -- 2.
CINCINNATI, July 20 (AP) -The E. W. Scripps Company purchased The Cincinnati TimesStar today and immediately merged it with the city's other afternoon newspaper, The Cincinnati Post.

PITTSBURGH, July 20 -- Steel production and orders so far this month have been somewhat above the estimates made a month ago. Latest reports show that new business for some companies is not below the June level.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -India has informed the United States and international institutions that she is in urgent need of about $300,000,000 before the end of this year.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, July 20 -- Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower leaves Costa Rica tomorrow to begin what is probably the more difficult half of his Central American tour.

SCHEVENINGEN, the Netherlands, Monday, July 21 (Reuters) -- Fishing vessel owners from seven countries announced today that they would continue to fish within Iceland's new twelve-mile territorial waters limit -- but outside the old fourmile limit -- after Sept. 1.
L. Judson Morhouse, Republican state chairman, threw his support to Mrs. May Preston Davie last night in the battle for control of the New York County Republican committee.
BELLPORT, L. I., July 20 -Skin divers, guided in the turbulent Atlantic surf here by an airborne detection device, tried unsuccessfully to swim 137 years into the past yesterday.

BUCHANAN, N. Y., July 20 -- A pit seventy feet deep and 250 feet in diameter has been blasted in solid rock beside the Hudson River here for the reactor of the Consolidated Edison Company's first nuclearfueled electric generating plant.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 20 -The Government announced today that the Ambassador of the United Arab Republic, Abdel Hamid Ghaleb, was unwelcome and must leave Lebanon.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 20 (AP) -- A huge gas-filled bag, which set an altitude record for filmrecording plastic balloons, jettisoned its load from 130,000 feet in open ranch country near Forsyth, Mont., late today.

The Cuban adventure, in which Americans and Canadians were at one time hostages of the rebels, has ended as happily as anything so rash and ill-advised could be expected to end. All the kidnapped men are now back safe and sound, having been treated with a courtesy and friendliness that in other circumstances might have been considered amusing.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- A week after the Iraqi revolution, official and private information is bringing a picture of the new Government into focus.

The election of Grant Thomas as president and a director of the American Synthetic Rubber Corporation of Louisville, Ky., was announced over the week-end by Gordon Walker, board chairman. Mr. Thomas succeeds Bancroft W. Henderson, who has retired, but will continue as a board member.

Southbound cargo on Trade Route No. 2 was about 20 per cent higher in 1956 and 1957 than the 500,000-ton level of 1951-55. This was indicated in a review of the route, which has been tentatively approved by Clarence G. Morse Maritime Administrator.
A number of real estate operators here are violating the new, Fair Housing Practices Law, the city finds, but a "significant" number are complying or are taking steps to do so.

BERLIN, July 20 (AP) -West Germans marked today the fourteenth anniversary of the abortive army bomb plot against Hitler. Speakers said the leaders of the plot had sought "to wipe disgrace from the German name."

NEW DELHI, July 20 -- The Government declared today that if there was any attempt by "foreign forces" to overthrow the revolutionary regime in Iraq, New Delhi would immediately recognize the new Government without waiting for routine diplomatic formalities.

The fourteen-story loft building at 214-18 West Twentyeighth Street, west of Seventh Avenue, in the fur district, has been sold by Kenfurs Associates, Inc. It occupies a plot 50 by 100 feet adjoining the Fashion Institute of Technology. The property is assessed at $325,000 and was bought by an investing client of Williams Co., broker.

A floor int he thirty-four-story office building nearing completion at 575 Lexington Avenue at Fifty-first Street has been leased by the American Building Maintenance Company, one of the country's largest building service organizations.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 20 -- Israel was tensely waiting today for some indication of the next Western moves in the Middle East.

NEW DELHI, India, July 20 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru told Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev in a letter today that India would gladly attend a summit conference on the Middle East "if there is an agreement about holding such a conference."

Having established a safe lead in the first session of the seventh and final round at Varna, and thereby retained the championship, Russia's student chess players went on to defeat the United States, 2 1/2 -- 1 1/2 according to a report from Bulgaria yesterday.
CAIRO, July 20 -- The ruler of Kuwait, the Persian Gulf state that provides half of Britain's oil, conferred twice in Damascus today with President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 20--Richard S. Dirkes' Stowaway won the Manhasset Bay one-design class honors today in the interclub championship series regatta of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- The next Vanguard satellite to go into orbit may be able to recognize and call attention to large storm masses as they build up around the earth. It would thus be able to help warn of the development of at least some major hurricanes and typhoons.
HAVERTOWN, Pa., July 20 -Dow Finsterwald, a modest young fellow who regards himself as a conservative player, became the Professional Golfers Association national champion today.

A blind news dealer accused of slashing another blind man's throat in ambush Saturday night was held without bail yesterday in Queens. The victim was in critical condition last night at St. John's Hospital in Long Island City.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- Roy Sievers' ninth-inning home run off Early Wynn gave the Washington Senators a 5-4 victory over the Chicago White Sox in the second game of a double-header today after the White Sox had won the first game, 4 -- 2, behind the five-hit pitching of Dick Donovan.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 20 (AP) -- Guards went on strike at three Nevada installations of the Atomic Energy Commission today because of a wage dispute.
BELGRADE, July 20 (UPI) -- An explosion in a hydroelectric power plant being built in a top secret military area 125 miles from Belgrade killed twenty-three persons, officials reported today.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., July 20 -- The break-up in flight of the nation's first three-engined intercontinental ballistic missile yesterday was caused by a defective rate gyroscope.
LONDON, July 20 -- Hugh Gaitskell, leader of Britain's Labor party, demanded today acceptance of the Soviet Union's proposal for a summit conference on the Middle East crisis.
Several sermons in the city yesterday dealt with the Lebanese crisis.

LONDON, July 20 (UPI) -Rebel sympathizers took over the Iraq Embassy here today in a diplomatic "revolution." Their spokesman asserted that they had the full support of all except two embassy staff members.
The Rev. Dr. Anderson Nicol described "the undivided heart" yesterday as "totalitarian religion, giving all, forsaking all, sacrificing all, and loving all."
MANAMA, Bahrein, July 20 (Reuters) -- British land, sea and air forces in the Persian Gulf stood by today for any trouble arising from the Iraqi coup last week.

STRATFORD, Conn., July 20 -- Given an unfamiliar Shakespeare play, the American Festival Theatre and Academy has created out of it something that is plausible, dainty and enchanting. The play is "The Winter's Tale," which opened in the Festival Theatre this afternoon and became the third production in this season's repertory.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 20 -- Stanley Kramer has completed long-standing negotiations with Gregory Peck to co-star in "On the Beach." The producer had no comment about the status of the offer he made some months ago to Ava Gardner, but disclosed that he had decided to direct the picture himself.

In trying to protect alleged states' rights from Supreme Court decisions based on the doctrine of Federal pre-emption, the House of Representatives has passed as weird a piece of legislation as could be imagined -- and one that calls for unceremonious burial.

Our Government deludes itself if it thinks the Anglo-American expedition will not be regarded as "aggression" into the Middle East by Nasser and that he will not request Russian help to thwart it. The probability is that this help, at least in the beginning, will not be open.
VANDERBILT HOTEL officials, poking around in a hotel sub-basement the other day, came across curious, long-unused gold cutlery, outdated china and silver and vintage bathroom crockery.
PHILADELPHIA, July 20 -The formation of Arms of Friendship, Inc., was announced today by Dr. Robert L. Johnson, president of Temple University.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 20 -- International conferences at an early date on possible use of agricultural surpluses to build up food reserves in underdeveloped countries appear probable. The United States holds by far the major share of such surpluses.

WASHINGTON, July 20--Premier Charles de Gaulle's Government is reliably reported here to be stalling on a planned agreement to establish United States-equipped intermediate-range ballistic missile bases in France.
The Ralph M. Parsons Company, Los Angeles, Calif., has been engaged to help establish a $23,000,000 sugar can plantation and sugar refinery in Iran, it was announced over the week-end.
New York City is spending more than $45,000,000 a year that is in effect a subsidy of slums.

LONDON, July 20 (AP) -British concern for the fate of a small state with great oil wealth, situated on the southern border of Iraq, was reflected today in a build-up of army, air and naval forces in the area.
BOSTON, July 20 (AP) -- "The big thing I had on my mind going out for the last inning was I didn't want to walk anybody," the 25-year-old Bunning said after beating Boston.
The New York Arthritis and Rheumatism Foundation announced yesterday an expanded medical program for the coming year. It will involve $144,000 in grants.

IN Colorado every automobile license plate proclaims that the state is "colorful." After three weeks of vacationing in Colorado I am convinced. "Colorful" is a modest understatement. Where else in this country is there such spectacular scenery and so much of it? Why, just looking out of the hotel room where I am writing, I can see a majestic range of mountains and a wonderful assortment of clouds.
PARIS, July 20 -- The French Government gave indications today that it would not be stampeded into a meeting with the Soviet Union at a summit conference on the iMddle Eastern situation.
Six new films are scheduled to arrive in local theatres this week. The program follows:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 20 -- A Soviet spokesman said today that the Soviet Union would press for an emergency session of the General Assembly unless the Western powers agreed to a summit meeting on the Middle East crisis.
BOSTON, July 20 (UP) -- Jim Bunning pitched a no-hitter today for a 3-0 Tigers' victory over the Red Sox to end Boston's six-game winning streak.
TOKYO, July 15 -- Six and a half years after their post-war revival, the domestic air services in Japan have been built into a high-frequency operation for business men and tourists.

Your editorial of July 16 entitled "Housing Hodgepodge" leaves me with apprehensive shivers that you have unwittingly joined the forces of retrenchment and retreat in the long, uphill fight for better housing for the American people.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 20 -- Music of the English language at its noblest has been added to the music of many lands heard this summer in connection with the Brussels World's Fair. The Old Vic Company of London tonight ended a brief engagement that offered two of Shakespeare's plays, "Henry VIII" and "Hamlet."
Nothing like it had ever happened to 10-year-old Peter Mayor of Hounslow, Middlesex, England, and his father, a British postman.

WARSAW, July 21 -- Government statisticians, in Poland's first family budget study, reported today that Pani Kowalska -- the Polish equivalent of Msr. John Doe -- spend 52 to 58 per cent of the family earnings on food, 22 per cent on clothes and about 6 per cent on alcohol and tobacco.

The five-story apartment house at 334 East Forty-ninth Street has been sold after an ownership of fifty years by Wildley C. Rickerson and Mollie Gallaher. The buyer was the 334 East Forty-ninth Street Corporation, of which Hyman Tucker is president. The Snyder-Amy Management Company, Inc., was the broker in the deal.

The National Broadcasting Company has directed its news department to develop a one-hour program that might be used to alternate with "Omnibus" on Sunday afternoons. As announced earlier, "Omnibus" will be televised next fall on alternate Sundays from 5 to 6 P.M.

The fact that India again feels obliged to seek, in the United States and elsewhere, substantial financial support should not be misinterpreted. India is not bankrupt, nor is India going bankrupt. The Indian statement that "India will simply have to stop paying her bills" could be misleading.
District leaders supporting Daniel J. Riesner for temporary leadership of the New York County Republican organization decided last night to force a showdown with leaders loyal to Thomas J. Curran.

ROME, July 21 -- The first planeload of Americans to be evacuated from Iraq arrived here today on their way home. The group was composed of thirty-six women, several of them expectant mothers, and fifty-four children.

Charles C. Platt in a letter to The New York Times has suggested that the City of New York Commission on Intergroup Relations "could help considerably" by inducing middle-income Negroes to set up their own cooperative housing and invite white families to join them in a "kind of integration in reverse."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 21 -- Following are the texts of statements made in the Security Council today by Koto Matsudaira of Japan and Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold, and excerpts from other addresses.

The women's dress industry is an industrial jungle of ruthless competition among more than 2,000 relatively small employers which has given notorious racketeers a high yield area in which to operate. This situation has put an economic premium on nonunion shops in which substandard wages give their owners "an edge" in getting outlets for their products.
If the Curtiss-Wright Corporation withdraws from management of the Studebaker-Packard Corporation, will the agency brought in by Curtiss-Wright lose the $7,000,000-a-year automobile account?
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- The House of Representatives passed a bill today authorizing seven and one-half million dollars for a memorial at Corregidor in the Phillippine Islands.
Sharpened competition from other countries appears as a significant factor tending to reduce United States exports this year substantially from the 1957 record level.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The House of Representatives gave Ringwood, N. J., its day in court today. The borough is seeking $146,133 in back taxes it says the Government owes it on its iron mines.
The Soldiers and Sailors Monument in Jamaica, Queens, will be moved seven blocks to a new site as the result of an agreement to smooth jammed traffic and ruffled patriotic feeling.
WASHINGTON, July 21--The House shouted today its approval of $260,000,000 tax relief for small business despite scattered charges that the bill was inadequate and a "mirage."

CHICAGO, July 21 -- Mr. Miller ordered the seizure of the offices of Local 450 in Cicero, Ill., a Chicago suburb, this morning. He announced that Louis G. Madia, the local's secretary-treasurer, and Danny Leonardi, business agent, had been discharged.
The Protestant Council of the City of New York yesterday demanded an immediate meeting with Dr. Morris A. Jacobs, Commissioner of Hospitals, to discuss the city's policy on birth control therapy.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Oregon's Democratic Senators split today on an amendment to the Reciprocal Trade Bill that would give special tariff protection to cherry growers.

The Ford Motor Company recorded a net loss of $17,300,000 in the second quarter this year. Earnings for the first half declined by $165,600,000, according to the semi-annual report issued yesterday by Henry Ford 2d, president.

AMMAN, Jordan, July 21 -- The relative calm here in the last few days has led observers to believe that Egypt and Syria have been stymied, at least temporarily, in their efforts to overthrow King Hussein.
Stocks made their best gain of the year yesterday and carried The New York Times averages to new 1958 highs.

Delegations from more than a dozen Greenwich Village organizations lined up last night in solid opposition to the City Planning Commission's proposal for a thirty-six-foot roadway through Washington Square.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 21 -- Last night United States Marines and other troops sleeping in foxholes outside Beirut enjoyed comparative quiet. The men are spread under combat conditions round the perimeter of an area running north and south of Beirut for about nine miles along the seashore and extending one to two miles inland.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The United States suggested to Britain and France today that the United Nations retain priority over any heads-of-government meeting in discussing the Middle East crisis.
A 33-year-old Cuban wheelchair patient who disappeared twice last week from Welfare Island, where he was being detained in deportation proceedings, surrendered early yesterday morning.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- The House voted today to keep pace with newsprint trends by allowing narrower newsprint paper to come into the country duty-free.
The R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company achieved record sales and earnings for the quarter and six months ended June 30, it was reported yesterday by Bowman Gray, president.
The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development lent $39,000,000 yesterday to the Sudan to develop its transportation system.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The White House denied today that the Adams-Goldfine affair had had the indirect effect of delaying submission to Congress of the legislation authorizing United States help for Euratom, the six-nation European atomic power program.

LOS ANGELES, July 21 (UPI) -- Soft-spoken Floyd Patterson, the world heavyweight champion, today said he was not a great champion, such as Joe Louis or Rocky Marciano, because he had not had a chance to prove himself
THE waistline will make the highest marks in college next fall. Altman's is showing a large collection of college fashions that concentrate on the Empire line.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Twenty-six Senators, all but two Republican, were reported today to have signed a statement urging Congressional action at this session on statehood for Hawaii.
OTTAWA, July 21 -- The Canadian Government favors top-level talks between the Western and Soviet leaders "as soon as possible," Prime Minister John Diefenbaker told Parliament today.

THE Columbia Broadcasting System's news division last night presented "The Ruble War," a special study of Russia's economic offensive against the free world. It was a stimulating hour that pointed up the need for greater awareness in this country of the importance of foreign aid.
PARIS, July 21 -- Easing of the trade embargo or restrictions on strategic products to Communist countries is expected to be announced next month.

HAVANA, July 21 -- A protest has been presented to the Supreme Court of Cuba by four attorneys alleging that the Urgency Court of Havana provides "no guarantees" for the trials of prisoners accused of terroristic and anti-government activities.

The appointment of James S. Locke as a vice president of Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company and general manager of the Micro Switch division was announced yesterday. Honeywell makes automatic control instruments. Mr. Locke, formerly manager of Honeywell's Minneapolis factory operations, succeeds the late W. W. Gilmore.

The passenger sales manager for Japan Airlines at 590 Fifth Avenue was killed shortly before 12:30 P. M. yesterday when he fell or jumped in front of a southbound IND subway train in the Forty-second Street station on Eighth Avenue.

The Federal Reserve System's readiness to support the market for Government bonds gave a lift yesterday to trading in Treasury securities. But this was not enough to offset indifference to the $16,300,000,000 Government debt refunding that opened yesterday and is to be closed tomorrow.
MILWAUKEE, July 21 (AP) -- Curt Flood slammed his sixth homer of the season in the fourteenth inning tonight, giving the St. Louis Cardinals a 5-4 victory over the Milwaukee Braves.

The two four-story apartment houses at 1953-73 Seventieth Street. Brooklyn, have been sold by the Estes Realty Company to an investment client of Lawrence Kadish. The buildings, on a plot 250 by 100 feet, are at the corner of Twentieth Avenue in the Bensonhurst area.
CHICAGO, July 21 (AP) -- Anne Quast of Everett, Wash., today shot a 72 for medalist honors in the women's Western amateur golf tournament.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 21 -- The strangest feature of the Lebanese military situation is that the landing of United States forces so far has not increased the operational tempo either of the Opposition or of the Government's efforts to suppress it.

CARBONDALE, Ill., July 21 (AP) -- A university professor said tonight that the Army had granted a special discharge to a private whose mathematical "genius" the professor insisted the Army had been misusing.

The committee arranging the theatre benefit for the Park Association of New York City, Inc., has selected the Nov. 6 performance of the comedy "The Marriage-Go-Round," which is scheduled to open at the Plymouth Theatre on Oct. 29.
A "Ferris wheel" that distributes merchandise to various floors of a warehouse was put on display here yesterday.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, July 21 -- The Middle East crisis has depressed prices of tea and rubber, Ceylon's major export crops.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today nominated Bertha S. Adkins, now assistant chairman of the Republican National Committee, to be Under Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.
PRACTICAL aspects should not be overlooked in the excitement of planning a sparkling new kitchen.

A modest improvement in steel buying by automobile makers and better-than-expected orders from the construction and oil industries were reflected in a continued increase in steel production last week. A further climb was scheduled for this week.

BERLIN, July 21 -- The Soviet Army Command in East Germany is being asked to repair the building of the United States military liaison mission in Potsdam which was attacked by a mob Friday, and to pay for property damaged or stolen.
LONDON, July 21 (AP) -- Bill Steinkraus of Westport, Conn., scored a brilliant victory today in the Manifesto Stakes of the Royal International Horse Show at London's White City Stadium.
The search for what may be left of the famous steamship Savannah will eb continued off Bellport, L. I., "until there is no more hope."
OTTAWA, July 21 -- Dr. Kwame Nkrumah, Prime Minister of Ghana, offered what he called a "workable solution" for the Mideast crisis here today.
A 125-mile highway in Colombia is being plotted, engineered and all but built in Syosset, L. I.
TEHERAN, Iran, July 21 (Reuters) -- The Iranian railroad network has been linked with the Soviet-European rail system at the Julfa rail junction on the Soviet-Iranian border.
State mediators last night offered their services in an effort to prevent a national strike of 8,000 capmakers. The walkout is scheduled to start this morning.

CINCINNATI, July 21 (AP) -- Bob Thurman's three-run homer paced the Cincinnati Redlegs to a 9-4 victory over the Chicago Cubs tonight. Harvey Haddix had to squelch a ninth-inning rally before nailing down the victory that jumped Cincinnati from the cellar to fifth place in the National League cellar to fifth place.

MOSCOW, July 21 (AP) -- America's track and field teams -- seventy-three strong and six short -- arrived in Moscow tonight to a greeting of kisses, flowers and cheers. The team competes against the Soviet Union national team here Sunday and Monday.

WISE old heads around City Hall think that Councilman David Ross' two bills to control the possession of rifles and ammunition have a fair chance of enactment this fall. If they are enacted hunters will have to endure an exasperating nuisance.
CHICAGO, July 21 (AP) -- The broadest setback since the marines landed in Lebanon last Tuesday hit grain futures today on the Board of Trade.

CARDIFF, Wales, July, 21 (UPI) -- Dawn Fraser of Australia lowered her world record for the women's 110-yard freestyle to 1 minute 1.4 seconds tonight in winning the event at the British Empire and Commonwealth Games.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Mr. Hoffa announced today he had invited Harry Bridges to a meeting here with leaders of the International Longshoremen's Association on Aug 14.

RABAT, Morocco, July 21 -- The question of evacuating all foreign military bases in Morocco, including those of the United States, has become extremely pressing because of recent events, Premier Ahmed Balafrej said today.

In January, 1956, Marvin L. Kalb, then 26 years old, went to Moscow as press attache of the American Embassy. It was the year of the "thaw" that followed Khrushchev's "downgrading" of Stalin. Speaking Russian and not being restricted to Moscow, Mr. Kalb found many chances to talk to students, taxi drivers, workers, scholars, Communist party members and people in the streets.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 21 -- Hoarhound drops at 3 cents a quarter-pound, two-penny apples and an old-fashioned cracker barrel are crowding the customers in at a Salt Lake City savings and loan association.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Treasury bill rate declined slightly this week after moving up for about a month, the Treasury reported tonight. The average annual interest rate on $1,700,000,000 of the ninety-one-day discount bills was 0.988 per cent, compared with 1.137 per cent last week.
PARIS, July 21 -- "Is integration of France and Algeria possible?"

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 21 -- As the host country Belgium bid farewell tonight to the young people who had been attending the International Congress of Jeunesses Musicales with one of the masterpieces of music -- Beethoven's Ninth Symphony.
CARSON CITY, Nev., July 21 (AP) -- The State Supreme Court threw out of court today the blackmail charges brought against Herman Greenspun, Las Vegas newspaper publisher.
CHICAGO, July 21 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

THE After Dinner Opera Company presented a double bill of operettas, Jacques Offenbach's "Sixty-six" and Gerald Cockshott's "Apollo and Persephone," at the open-air Wollman Memorial last night in Central Park.
ALBANY, July 21 (AP) -- Governor Harriman said today the state should be consistent and turn over barge canal terminal facilities at Oswego as well as Buffalo to port authorities without cost.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. yesterday ordered the transfer of eight officers of two Bronx fire companies after $2,447 was stolen from their firehouse.
MEXICO CITY, July 21 (AP) -- Mexico is now producing half the newsprint it needs for its newspapers. In time it hopes to be self-sufficient and perhaps produce enough for export.

Pillsbury Mills increased earnings about 41 per cent in the fiscal year ended May 31 on a sales gain of about 6 per cent, the annual report disclosed yesterday. Paul S. Gerot, president, said sales and earnings were the highest in the company's eighty-nine-year history.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 13 to 22 points (65 cents to $1.10 a bale) yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Congress was asked today to wait at least six months before acting on President Eisenhower's request for State Department authority to deny passports to Communists and fellow travelers.
CINCINNATI, July 21 (AP) -- The Hotel and Restaurant Workers Union placed a trusteeship today on all eleven locals of its Chicago Joint Board.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 21 -- The Soviet Union bitterly attacked today a Japanese compromise resolution that would strengthen the United Nations Observation Group in Lebanon and thus make possible the withdrawal of United States troops.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 21 (AP) -- Just a month after one of the most luxurious hotels in the Middle East opened, soldiers took away eleven of its guests. Four were beaten to death by a mob. Three barely-escaped with their lives. The fate of the four others, all Jordanians, is still not known.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) -- The Senate Public Works Committee approved today a House-passed bill putting all Federal highway legislation into a single package.

Reporting on the preliminary findings of a group of American educators following a survey of higher education in the Soviet Union, Dr. Edward H. Litchfield was impressed by the "deep commitment" with large scholarships "given to from 80 per cent to 90 per cent of the students so that virtually all of the superior men and women are able to attend."

ABOARD U. S. S. SARATOGA, in the Eastern Mediterranean, July 20 -- All hands -- about 4,000 officers and men -- listened intently today when Capt. Alfred R. Matter read President Eisenhower's message to the armed forces over this aircraft carrier's public address system.

FRANKFURT, Germany, July 15 -- West German banking authorities say they are making headway toward a revived capital market permitting investment abroad in normal commercial forms on a long term basis. Meanwhile the influx of capital into Germany is being offset by official lending abroad and by credits for export of capital goods that benefit underdeveloped regions.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 21 -- Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower was greeted here this afternoon by a demonstration of the Christian Democratic Conservative Youth Movement protesting military aid to Nicaragua.

Jean H. Jackson, the suspended honor patrolman accused of stealing more than $25,000 from offices of the police property clerk, pleaded guilty yesterday to grand larceny in the first degree and conspiracy.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 21 -- The United States was believed today by many Lebanese to be seeking means of a political settlement between the warring factions in Lebanon.

CAIRO, July 21 (Reuters) -- The Persian Gulf sheikdom of Kuwait, supplier of more than hail of Britain's oil supplies, "objects to foreign troop concentrations" on its soil, a representative said today.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- The House of Representatives, disregarding Administration opposition, tentatively approved today a bill extending and enlarging the four-year-old farm surplus disposal law.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 21 -- The American Federation of Musicians, which is struggling to retain control over Hollywood musicians, today won two legal decisions in the Superior Court.
The Jehovah's Witnesses took over Yankee Stadium and the Polo Grounds yesterday to prepare the ball parks for their Divine Will International Assembly, which starts Sunday.

YONKERS, N. Y., July 21--Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell assailed as "a myth" yesterday the belief that older people do not make good workers. He urged American industry to select its employes without regard to their age, color or sex.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 21 -- The Stoneybrook Stable's Victory Flush from Scarsdale, N. Y., driven by George Phalen, scored his fifth victory of the season in the Summer Jubilee pacing feature at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. The winner paced the mile in 2:04 4/5 and returned $13.40 for $2.
TEHERAN, Iran, July 21 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev of the Soviet Union has invited the Shah of Iran to visit Moscow again.
TIME was when piano lessons, like spinach, say, or orthodontia, were forced upon unenthusiastic children by parents who assured them: "You'll thank me for this some day."

To be a 200-average bowler for ten straight years requires lotes of time for practice and improvement. Stan Niemiec, the 43-year-old secretary of New Jersey's Bergen County Bowling Association, has the 200 average, but not all of the time he spends at the sport can be considered practice.
About 850 of the city's citizens between 60 and 90 years old took an all-day sail yesterday on the Hudson and East Rivers and Lower New York Bay. The cruise was complete with entertainment.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 21 (UPI) -- A New York Roman Catholic priest imprisoned for five years by the Chinese Communists said today the Reds kept on display a priest's skull that was marked with a bullet hole to remind clergymen what could happen to them if they caused trouble.

CUXHAVEN, Germany, July 21 (AP) -- The Hanseatic, West Germany's largest ocean liner and newest bid for a bigger share of the trans-Atlantic trade, sailed festively on her maiden voyage to New York today.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Study of a modern foreign language should be part of every child's education at least from the third through the sixth grades, the United States Office of Education said today.
LONDON, July 21 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan expressed qualified support today for the Soviet proposal of a five-power summit meeting to discuss the Middle East crisis.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 21 (Reuters) -- Governor Sir Hugh Foot ordered a rigid curfew tonight over the whole island for forty-eight hours from dawn tomorrow. The governor was seeking to halt a climbing tally of inter-communal killings.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 21 -- The representative of the pre-revolutionary Government of Iraq in the United Nations Security Council told the police today that his life had been threatened. The chair of Iraq, a non-permanent member of the Council, remained vacant throughout today's critical debate on the situation in the Middle East that has developed since the Iraqi revolution.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. announced yesterday that he had received and "immediately accepted" an invitation from Governor Harriman to a reception Monday in honor of Prime Minister Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Secretary of State Dulles is expected to fly to London late this week for a meeting of the Council of the Baghdad Pact nations, beginning next Monday. His purpose is understood to be twofold:
PIN curls and shampoo do not usually signify salvation. But in one of the city's most meager beauty salons, they do.

This should be a tender story, a story of gentle, next-door neighbors. It should be a blissful tale of bird-feeding at dawn by a little, kind lady, and a tale touching on the wisdom of a Solomon. But instead it is a doleful story.

If residents of Washington Heights feel that they waited over-long for something to be done about permanently repairing the retaining wall adjacent to some of the apartment houses in their neighborhood, they are entirely justified in their attitude. Only now has preliminary work begun on the repairs, and this did not occur until after the Department of Buildings, largely through court procedure, nudged property owners responsible for the wall into action.
Workmen were busy yesterday giving a face-lifting to the Astor Hotel's Grand Ballroom, one of the oldest and largest in the country.
LONDON, July 21 -- Sentiment improved slightly in the stock market today after a hesitant start. Rises of a few pence predominated. The volume of trading remained small.

A retired police lieutenant and his son became classmates yesterday at Yeshiva University. They are seeking credits to become provisional teachers in the fall in the Carle Place School District of Long Island.
KAISERSLAUTERN, Germany, July 21 (Reuters) -- Airman 2/C Joel Smith was reported today to be real sick. He is allergic to money.
BABYLON, L. I., July 21 -- The Morgan Bowl, emblematic of the women's sailing championship of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association, is expected to remain in Babylon.

TORONTO, July 21 (UPI) -- Gordon Ball, a member of Ontario's champion Willingdon Cup team, shot a 4-under-par 67 today to win the opening qualifying round of the fifty-fourth Canadian amateur golf championship.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- The House of Representatives voted today to quadruple the severance pay of reserve officers involuntarily released from active duty after having completed at least five continuous years of active service.
The adventures of Yogi Berra in right field are just beginning. Already there are tales to tell.
MOSCOW, July 21 -- The Soviet Government condemned today the flights of United States military planes over neutral Austria and demanded they be stopped immediately.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Legislation to grant a $25,000-a-year pension and other benefits to former Presidents was expected by Congressional leaders today to be enacted before the session adjourned. This view was expressed despite the certainty that the proposals faced strong opposition, particularly in the House of Representatives.

The United States and Britain have responded to the coup d'etat in Iraq by stationing troops in Lebanon and Jordan. In the absence of effective United Nations action two terrible alternatives threaten in the Middle East.

PARIS, July 21 -- The Western Big Three indicated to their allies in the Atlantic alliance today their willingness to meet with the Soviet Union on the Middle East problem in a United Nations setting.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 21 -- Victor Seixas and Althea Gibson, the ranking players of the country, returned to action today as the Pennsylvania championships, the first of the big grass court tennis tournaments, started at the Merion Cricket Club.

A horn-blowing, cowbell-ringing, foot-stomping crowd of 1,254 boxing fans, most of them supporters of Eddie Lynch, went to St. Nicholas Arena last night to watch the ten-round bout between the West Side welterweight and Billy Flamio of the Bronx. Flamio spoiled the evening for the Lynch adherents.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- There is no dispute between the Department of Justice and Congress over the principle of the Smith bill, which the House last week approved by the large vote of 241 to 155. Nor is there any disagreement between them that Congress, in enacting a statute, may finally determine its meaning and construction -- though not its constitutionality.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- An emergency board recommended today that the third man in the cockpit of the new jet airliners have minimum commercial pilot qualifications.

A contract was let yesterday for the demolition of the first buildings that are to be removed from the site of the $250,000,000 Lincoln Square redevelopment. The Drachman Demolition Company, Inc., of Long Island City, Queens, was the lowest of six bidders for razing apartment and tenement buildings.
As two of his rivals campaigned upstate, Nelson A. Rockefeller won six more delegates yesterday in the race for the Republican nomination for Governor.

IN New York, there is no lack of restaurants that specialize in foreign cuisine. The food featured in these establishments ranges from mouth-burning mole sauces of Mexican origin to subtle inspirations of French chefs.
The General Electric Company served notice yesterday that it would take a long strike rather than submit to union demands for a "guaranteed annual wage."

NEWARK, July 21 -- Perry M. Shoemaker, president of the Lackawanna Railroad, called for tax relief today from "long-standing discriminatory practices against railroads" by Jersey City and other Hudson County municipalities.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 21 -- The position of Hashim Jawad in the United Nations these days resembles that of an actor waiting in the wings.
James R. Hoffa has been subpoenaed for a new confrontation by his critics in the Senate rackets investigation Aug. 4.
The appointment of Maj. Gen. J. F. R. Seitz as First Army Chief of Staff was announced yesterday at Governors Island.
LONDON, July 21 -- The Labor party's Shadow Cabinet refused today to accept the resignation of George Brown, its spokesman on defense matters.

Many New Yorkers who spend the summer in the area around Old Chatham, N. Y., are aiding with plans for the third annual Shaker Museum Festival, which will be held on the museum grounds there on Aug. 2.

Penalty for the Spring The garden has become far too big, and so has the lawn. The garden has become of such size that all but a few of the week-end hours must be devoted to its care. The lawn takes all the rest.
LONDON, July 21 -- A spokesman at the Iraqi Embassy here affirmed today Iraqi oil would continue to flow to its usual markets.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 21 (AP) -- Two packages of cosmic ray film plates carried to 130,000 feet by a huge plastic balloon were found in southeastern Montana today.
E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. improved its sales and earnings in the second quarter this year over the first three months. The results, however, were well below the second quarter of 1957.
Optimism concerning the Middle East crisis induced large-scale selling on most New York commodity exchanges yesterday.
Task Force Charlie, consisting of 1,200 men to provide logistic and other support for an army airborne battle group, continued to land in Lebanon yesterday.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 21 -- Today, for the first time since the Larchmont Yacht Club's annual race week got under way on Saturday, all hands were able to get into action.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Sinclair Weeks, the Secretary of Commerce, asserted today that Sherman Adams "has been whiplashed more brutally than any individual in public life in our generation."

PARIS, July 21 -- France's second atomic reactor began operating today at the nuclear center at Marcoule in the southeast. The nation's other reactor is also a Marcoule.
CAIRO, July 21 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser returned to Cairo today flushed with the victory of the Iraqi revolution.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 21 -- Following is the text of a letter sent by Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold today to Arkady A. Sobolev, Soviet representative to the United Nations.

GOLF enthusiasts who take their game seriously--and what golfer doesn't--must have breathed a great sigh of relief when Dow Finsterwald sank his final putt that crowned him the new P. G. A. champion at Llanerch.

Nikita S. Khrushchev's recent efforts to appear before the world as protector of the Middle Eastern peoples' independence and freedom would be funny if they were not made in so tragic and grave a political context. We have referred earlier in these columns to the incongruity between Khrushchev's recently discovered passion for noninterference in the affairs of foreign nations and the reality of Soviet conduct in the Hungarian Revolution less than two years ago.
NEW HAVEN, July 21 -- The appointment of John B. Gates of Greenwich to a two-year term as chairman of the Yale University Alumni Fund was announced today at the university.

The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation yesterday reported gain in operating revenues and net income for the six and twelve months ended June 30, despite declines in sales of electricity. Gas sales in both periods were higher than in comparable 1957 periods.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) -- William F. Knowland, Senate Republican leader, once one of former President Harry S. Truman's sharpest critics, praised the former President today for supporting President Eisenhower's dispatch of troops to Lebanon.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 21 (UPI) -- Premier David Ben-Gurion said today that events in the Arab states had increased the threat of Israel's "encirclement by Nasser."
WASHINGTON, July 21--The Government went $2,813,388,661 into the red in the fiscal year that ended June 30, the Treasury and the Budget Bureau reported today.

ST. LOUIS, July 21 (AP) -- All seven judges in the Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals will decide whether racial integration will continue this fall at Central High School in Little Rock, Ark. A hearing has been set for Aug. 4 here.

DURING the summer months husbands and fathers are apt to hear women in their families moan about having nothing to wear -- and really mean it. For those women whose wardrobes will not last until September, here is a round-up of some dark, cool cottons currently in the stores.
AMMAN, Jordan, July 21--Britain's paratroopers are "occupying" this Arab capital for a few hours each evening--to the apparent delight of the Arab, Greek and other merchants.
Robert Moses complained yesterday about "misleading and alarming articles in the press concerning the plane trees along Third Avenue."

" AT Lady Molly's,"* by Anthony Powell, is a genial rattling of skeletons in the stately homes of England. The characters sound as if they had graduated from Thomas Love Peacock and Oscar Wilde's works and were on their way to parts in the moralities of Noel Coward and Evelyn Waugh.
DETROIT, July 21 (AP) -- Passenger car production in the United States moved up slightly last week. But it still was far behind last year's volume.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) -- The Department of Defense took a relaxed view today on the activities of two American life-insurance salesmen working among United States troops in Lebanon.
GENEVA, July 21 -- The East-West conference of scientific experts moved closer today toward general conclusions on the four principal methods of detecting atomic tests.
HONG KONG, July 21--Western observers here consider it extremely unlikely that Communist China is ready, willing or able to send military "volunteers" to the inflamed Middle East.

Dr. Kwame Nkrumah, Prime Minister of Ghana, who arrives in the United States today, will spend three days in New York. He will fly from Washington to New York Saturday night.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- The House refused today to accept a Senate amendment knocking out of a miscellaneous appropriation bill a House voted payment of $589,000,000 to the Civil Service retirement fund.
ANKARA, Turkey, July 22 (Reuters) -- Premier Adnan Menderes told the Soviet Union today that Turkey would not be a cause of increased tension in the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Bill Howton, an all-pro end, told Senate sports investigators today a House-passed bill would strip players of protection from what he termed dictatorial policies of football club owners.

I would like to take exception to some statements made by Daniel M. Koral in The Times of July 15. Mr. Koral, in expressing a desire that the Democratic party nominate James A. Farley for Senator, says that "with his experience and intelligence he [Mr. Farley] would make a very good Senator."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 22 -- The machinery for getting the heads of government together for a Security Council meeting on the Middle East, as proposed today by President Eisenhower and British Prime Minister Harold Macmillan, already exists.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- President Eisenhower told Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev today to go to the Security Council if he wanted a summit meeting on the Middle East.
OKLAHOMA CITY, July 22 (AP) -- J. Howard Edmondson was the victor today in Oklahoma's Democratic gubernatorial runoff primary. He defeated W. P. (Bill) Atkinston of Midwest City.
A progress report on integration in the public schools of Louisville, Ky., was given yesterday by Dr. Omer Carmichael, the superintendent of schools there.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 22 -- The Government said today that "the revolution is here to stay." It also implied that it would not turn toward communism.

The Republic Steel Corporation increased earnings in the second quarter over those in the first three months, but half-year net was substantially lower than last year, according to the report yesterday of C. M. White, chairman.

From 1760 to 1915 America's most important and influential authors, painters, sculptors and scholars went to Italy. In "The Dream of Arcadia," Van Wyck Brooks tells the story of those Americans who lived and worked in Italy and saw in that "beautiful and classic" land the earthly fulfillment of their dream.

Federal Judge William B. Herlands ruled yesterday that an indictment charging Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. with income tax evasion was valid. The Harlem clergyman must, therefore, stand trial for offenses alleged to have been committed in 1951-52.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 22 -- Israel has requested the British to find another route for their airlift from Cyprus to Jordan. There has been no outright demand, however, that they do so.

PHILADELPHIA, July 22 (UPI) -- The Philadelphia Phillies discharged Manager Mayo Smith today and rehired Eddie Sawyer, the skipper who in 1950 guided the "Whiz Kids" to the club's first National League pennant in thirty-five years.
The market for Government securities had its busiest day yesterday since the Treasury's last refunding operation in June.
" The Plot to Kill Stalin," a play based on events in the last five months of the life of the Soviet Premier, will be televised by the Columbia Broadcasting System on Sept. 25 from 9:30 to 11 P. M.

Directors of the Addressograph-Multigraph Corporation yesterday voted to split the common stock three for one, subject to shareholder approval. The plan calls for issuing two additional shares for each share outstanding on Sept. 15.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- The White House has refused to consider protests against a switch in authority over the St. Lawrence Seaway.

Dr. Morris A. Jacobs, Commissioner of Hospitals, refused yesterday to meet at this time with a committee of the Protestant Council of the City of New York to discuss the question of birth-control therapy in city hospitals.
LONDON, July 22 (Reuters) -- The point on a phonograph needle may mean 5,000,000 ($14,000,000) for Mrs. Marsia Killick, a 40-year-old mother of four children.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 22 -- Some of the reasons for the strained relations between the United States and Latin America were explained today to Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower and his study-goodwill mission.

Acting with all the rashness and impetuosity of his years, Trainer Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons yesterday decided to accept the impost of 136 pounds assigned to Bold Ruler for Saturday's $50,000 Brooklyn Handicap at Jamaica.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- High school students learn mathematics just as well in large classes as in small ones, according to evidence offered in a bulletin published today by the United States Office of Education.

Jones Beach, which has just been acclaimed as one of the seven architectural wonders of the New York area, has entered its thirtieth season, and in hopes of keeping pace with the growth in recreational seekers to the one-day vacationist's summer outpost further expansion of the six-mile-long strip is under way.

The Massachusetts Investors Trust, the world's largest mutual fund, reported yesterday net assets of $1,149,844,598, equal to $10.98 a share on 104,677,195 shares held by 194,301 shareowners on June 30. This compared with $1,156,024,565, or $11.84 a share, on fewer shares a year earlier.

PHILADELPHIA, July 22 -- Twenty-four Eastern railroads today were ordered to pay the Pennsylvania Motor Truck Association $652,074 in treble damages and $200,000 for counsel fees. In addition, District Court Judge Thomas J. Clary issued a final injunction that prohibits the railroads from repeating practices that the truckers had charged constituted an illegal conspiracy to drive them out of business.

LONDON, Wednesday, July 23 -- The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia expressed opposition today to the Western proposal that a summit conference on the Middle East be held within the United Nations Security Council."
BRIGADIER ABDUL KARIM EL-KASSEM, Premier and Minister of Defense in the revolutionary government of Iraq, is a professional military man.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- The House Appropriations Committee cut more than $500,000,000 today from Defense Department construction fund requests. The committee criticized the new Air Force Academy as an outstanding example of "loose fiscal procedures."

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 22 (UPI) -- Gallant Man scored Hollywood Park's golden double by winning the $107,600 Sunset Handicap on the final program of the meeting today. He had captured the $162,100 Gold Cup ten days earlier.
The grand jury investigating corruption in boxing indicted Gabriel Genovese yesterday on charges of undercover management of fighters.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- President Eisenhower has declined to put a "must" label on any pending legislation. Republican leaders say Congress can adjourn by Aug. 9 if it acts speedily.

LONDON, July 22 -- A memorial to Msgr Ronald Knox, the Roman Catholic scholar and writer, is to be established at Trinity College, Oxford, by the endowing of a prize or scholarship connected with Biblical or classical studies.

The city wisely is moving into a relatively new area of municipal housekeeping -- the control of industrial wastes discharged into its sewerage system for treatment in the pollution-control plants. Up to now the problem has not been too pressing, because industrial wastes have been discharged directly into the waters surrounding New York.

While consumer goods of the Bulova Watch Company have been affected by the recession, sales for the quarter ended June 30 "held up perceptibly well when considering general economic conditions," Gen. Omar N. Bradley, chairman, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday.
LONDON, July 22 -- The stock market was generally firm today with the uncertainty about the Mideast situation apparent only in the movement of Mideast oil issues.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Republicans tried today to get a special House investigation of the investigators of Sherman Adams and Bernard Goldfine. The move appeared to have failed.

WHITE PLAINS, July 22 -Undeterred by rain, Westchester County opened its big new public swimming pool in Saxon Woods Park today with abbreviated speeches and a water show. Designed for 6,000 bathers a day and 2,000 at a time, the pool had only a dozen youngsters waiting eagerly in the drizzle to take the first plunges.
A bolt introduced a few years ago is providing quiet relief from the rat-a-tat of riveting on steel framework.

NEW HAVEN, July 22 -- The House of Delegates of the Connecticut Medical Society moved today to resolve its six-month dispute with the Connecticut Medical Service, which operates a prepaid medical-surgical insurance plan.

NEARLY 500 home economists from forty nations arrived in New York within the last few days en route to the University of Maryland, where they will attend the ninth International Congress on Home Economics. During the course of a tour of Manhattan, they paused long enough to comment on American supermarkets, culinary colloquialisms and the differences between the cooking techniques of various countries.

PARIS, July 22 -- In the three-day negotiations that will start here tomorrow on a European free trade area the French will try to put an end to their isolation. They will seek some compromise with both the West Germans and the British, both of whom are more favorable to a free trade area than the French are.
CHICAGO, July 22 (AP) -- Another steep setback hit nearly all grain futures today on the Board of Trade.
The state exonerated William Richter yesterday from charges concerning his notarizing an affidavit in the Jesus de Galindez case.

IN the great longhouse of Temonggong Koh, paramount chief of the warlike Iban and mighty, head-hunter, a religious ceremony was taking place. Libations of strong rice wine had been offered to placate evil spirits. Quantities of the nasty-tasting stuff had been consumed by the participants. Elaborate dishes of many kinds of food had been offered to the gods.
The 1959 model cars will offer "something for everybody," in the opinion of James O. Wright, vice president of the Ford Motor Company.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 22 -- Dr. Abdul Majid Abbas, representative of the pre-revolutionary Government of Iraq, returned to the Security Council today, guarded by a New York detective.
Thirteen buildings occupying a blockfront on Third Avenue near Stuyvesant Square have been purchased by an investor from the Third Estate.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 22 -- United States Naval spokesman reported today that sixteen carrier-based aircraft had been hit by .30-caliber bullets since operations over Lebanon began, but that no personnel had been injured. The Navy planes have not returned the fire.
The Gulf Oil Corporation reported yesterday for the six months ended June 30 an estimated consolidated net income of $115,737,000. This equaled $3.72 a share on the 31,193,310 shares outstanding.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 22 -- Neither rain nor an overcast sky kept the hardy sailors of the Long Island Sound fleet away from Larchmont Race Week's fourth day of competition.

CARACAS, Venezuela, July 22 -- A rupture in the armed forces of Venezuela occurred today, resulting in an acute political crisis.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 22 -- Arkady A. Sobolev, the Soviet delegate, accused the United States and Britain today of having vetoed the Soviet amendments to a Japanese resolution on the Lebanon question.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 22 -- Several hundred Greek Cypriote men and women were arrested today in a day-long operation by security forces, responsible Greek Cypriote sources said tonight.
Postal officials here said yesterday there would be no period of grace after Aug. 1 for delivery of mail bearing postage insufficient under the increased rates.

The New York Life Insurance Company has contracted to buy the land at 730 Third Avenue and the twenty-seven-story office building rising there from the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association and the Central Third Corporation, the joint owners.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that in the last year the city had doubled the size and more than doubled the striking power of police forces directly combating juvenile delinquency.
Bryan Houston, Inc., announced yesterday that it had resigned a $2,000,000-a-year Colgate-Palmolive account.
A gunman fatally shot the owner of a clothing store in a $40 hold-up yesterday on upper Broadway, but was captured by the police after a six-block chase in which a number of passers-by participated.
CONWAY, Ark., July 22 (UPI) -- The 25-year-old son of Senator John L. McClellan was killed today when a twin-engine plane crashed ten miles south of Conway, Ark.
TUNIS, July 22 -- The Tunisian Government was bitterly assailed by the Algerian rebel National Liberation Front today. The Algerians said it was playing into the hands of French colonialists.

A garage attendant last night crashed through a brick wall and plunged three stories in a small foreign sports car he was trying to park. The aceident occurred at the rear of the Club Garage, 108 West Fifty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Senate approved a revised reciprocal trade bill tonight that goes far toward meeting President Eisenhower's specifications for legislation to maintain a liberal foreign economic policy. The vote was 72 to 16.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 22 -A pottery fragment bearing an inscription in the ancient Lydian language has been unearthed by American archaeologists in Sardis, Turkey.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Government toned down today the emergency nature of tomorrow's meeting of oil industry executives on the Middle East situation. The aim of the de-emphasis is to avoid causing more stir than already exists.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 22 -- President Eisenhower's special envoy, Robert Murphy, has widened his talks here to include declared members of the Opposition.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 22 -- With a strong final sixteenth, favored Gay Dancer, from the Annroc Stables of Brooklyn, scored a half-length victory over Jerry Perkins in the Civil Defense pacing feature at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

The ever-increasing United States debt has worried many business men and economists. The Chase Manhattan Bank figures that debt in the nation is at the "almost unbelievably large" figure of three-quarters of a trillion dollars -- $750 billion. That's the amount owed by individuals, businesses, the Federal and local governments.
Opposition by real estate and taxpayer groups mounted yesterday to tax concessions for the world's largest cooperative housing development, which is planned for the Coney Island area of Brooklyn.
AMMAN, Jordan, July 22 (Reuters) -- The Jordanian Government announced tonight the "murder" of two of its senior ministers who were in Baghdad at the time of the Iraqi coup.
PITTSBURGH, July 22 (AP) -- Earl Belle, 26-year-old financier, and his associate. Mitchell D. Ostwind, also 26, were charged by the Federal Bureau of Investigation today with a $62,500 swindle.
Five new features, including two double-bill programs, will open today at local theatres.
PARIS, July 22 -- Sixteen Deputies were named today to a consultative committee that will examine and give an opinion on the Constitutional reforms that the Government is drawing up.
NORWALK, Conn., July 22 -- Officials have figured out a way to attack drunken driving on Norwalk's waterways despite the absence of any law prohibiting such conduct.
An impressive and spectacular port welcome yesterday for the city's newest fireboat, the Harry M. Archer, M.D., was partly muted by the new craft's inability to answer the harbor's greetings.
A plan to control traffic lights by radio at the city's 8,000 intersections that have signals was announced yesterday by Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley.
LONDON, July 22 -- Selwyn Lloyd rejected today suggestions that Britain intended military action in the Persian Gulf area, including the Sheikdom of Kuwait.
A Brooklyn Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday that the Board of Elections would not have to substitute voting machines for paper ballots in the Aug. 12 primary election.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 1 point (5 cents a bale) up to 16 points (80 cents a bale) down yesterday.

International disarmament agreements can be effectively inspected and controlled, according to an investigation undertaken by a group of scientists, engineers and other specialists for the Institute of War and Peace Studies at Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- Representative Francis E. Walter has accused Miss Frances G. Knight, director of the Passport Office, of "going out of her way" to carry out promptly the recent Supreme Court ruling on passports.
Employes of downtown banking institutions will donate blood to the Red Cross today at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, 33 Liberty Street.
LODZ, Poland, July 22 -- Wladyslaw Gomulka emphasized today Poland's allegiance to the Communist bloc and hailed the Soviet Union as his country's strongest friend and ally.
Schedules were reduced on thirty-five city-owned bus lines in Brooklyn last midnight.
TRENTON, July 22 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner appointed John A. kervick of Short Hills today as State Treasurer. He succeeds Aaron Neeld in the $18,000-a-year post.
Specific reference and extreme exception is made to the letter of two former Haitian Government Ministers published July 15.
MOSCOW, July 22 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev indicated tonight his concern lest recent developments in the Middle East get out of hand.

Prices fell off yesterday morning on the New York Stock Exchange but a long crawl upward in the afternoon brought gains for the sixth successive session and new 1958 highs for The New York Times averages.
Shelters 600 feet deep are needed to protect New Yorkers from an atomic bomb, the director of the State Civil Defense Commission warned yesterday.
MOSCOW, July 22 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev has advised East Germany to stop preaching politics to its intellectuals if it wishes to halt their exodus to the West.
WHITE PLAINS, July 22--The railroads moved a step nearer financial help from Westchester County today.
A textile fiber described by its maker as extremely versatile will makes its appearance in apparel fabrics in the fall.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) -- The House Ways and Means Committee gave final approval today to a bill to grant special tax relief to self-employed persons trying to build retirement funds for their old age.
The Republic of Lebanon is sometimes called "The Lebanon," but "Lebanon" without an article is considered better usage.
The city is slated to pay condemnation awards for a school site in Canarsie, Brooklyn, totaling about five and one-half times the 1957-58 assessed valuation of $14,600.

ADEN, July 22 -- Yehia alHirsi, commandant of the Lahej state forces, who absconded last month with men, equipment and money, is reported to have written to the Sheiks in the western Aden protectorate, asking them to join him in Taiz, capital of Yemen, "to plan action."
WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) -- The committee recessed indefinitely late today without acting on Mr. White's nomination.
The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis announced yesterday that henceforth its dimes would also march against arthritis and congenital defects.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 21 -The forgotten men of Lebanon's crisis are the United Nations observers sent here to see whether arms and men were coming into Lebanon from the Syrian part of the United Arab Republic.

Officers and directors of the Girls Club of New York have taken over the entire seating capacity of the Royale Theatre for the Nov. 10 performance of "La Plume de Ma "Tante." The original London cast will appear in Robert Dhery's musical revue.
A 63-year-old man who got into an argument with a young stockbroker last night over a minor traffic accident in the Bronx died during the dispute.

Ohio borrowed $31,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance the construction of major highways. The money was raised by the sale of serial bonds due from 1959 to 1972 at an interest cost of 2.8811 per cent.

Net income of the Union Carbide Corporation in the second quarter rose by 18 per cent from the first three months of this year, but half-year earnings were 28 per cent below the record in the initial six months of 1957.

LONDON, July 22 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan offered Nikita S. Khrushchev tonight the prospect that "fruitful agreements" would emerge from an extraordinary session of the United Nations Security Council.
CAIRO, July 22 -- Gamal Abdel Nasser jubilantly predicted today a victory of Arab nationalism under his flag in Jordan, Lebanon and Algeria.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., July 23 (UPI) -- The liberty ship Ocean Ulla, ended her rock 'n' roll session here today.
STONY ISLAND, Lake Ontario, July 22 -- This place has the most luxurious advantage ever invented for a visitor: a built-in excuse for not catching black bass.
