WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- A House Interior subcommittee approved subsidies for minerals producers today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 22 -- The Security Council broke off its debate on the Middle East crisis today to await the outcome of East-West negotiations on a summit conference.
The bulk of the country's cap production was halted yesterday by the first industry-wide cap strike in the 110-year history of the United Hatters, Cap and illinery Workers International Union.

MOSCOW, July 21 -- The Soviet Union announced today that its jet fighters were duty bound to use any means to bring down the unarmed United States transport that strayed over the southern Soviet frontier last month.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 22 (AP)--Attorneys for Gov. Orval E. Faubus mailed an appeal today to the United States Supreme Court against an injunction. The injunction ordered Governor Faubus to ease interfering with integration at Central High School.
BABYLON, L. I., July 22 -- Babylon Yacht Club's No. 1 crew today successfully defended the Morgan bowl, emblematic of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's women's sailing championship.

JACKSON, Miss., July 22 (AP) -- The attorney for a Negro challenging Mississippi's voter registration laws questioned sixteen Negro witnesses today in an apparent effort to prove racial discrimination.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 22 -- The Lebanese Presidential election due Thursday was postponed indefinitely tonight. This was decided despite efforts by Robert Murphy, special United States envoy, to promote a compromise between the feuding Government and Opposition chiefs.
JAAP PENRAAT is an industrial designer freshly come to town from his native Amsterdam. He has looked upon this city and found some things that bewilder him.

WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Committee for Economic Development said today that the private economic power of business and labor unions, particularly labor unions, might be able to cause inflation in the United States even if the Government followed proper anti-inflation policies.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 22 -- Brigadier Abdul Karim el-Kassem, new Premier of Iraq, said tonight it would be the Government's aim to increase cooperation with the West especially in oil production.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 22 -- Following are the texts of addresses to the Security Council by Dr. Karim Azkoul of Lebanon and Arkady A. Sobolev of the Soviet Union, and excerpts from other statements made in today's debate:

DETROIT, July 22 -- The woman telegrapher groaned when Hank Bauer of the Yanks opened tonight's game against the Tigers at Briggs Stadium with a single. A minute later Gil McDougald hit a homer off Paul Foytack.
CHICAGO, July 22 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- A Senate Appropriations subcommittee voted today, because of the Middle East crisis, to reject an Administration request to cut the size of the Army, Marines, National Guard and the Reserves.
CARDIFF, Wales, July 22 (AP) -- Gerhardus Potgieter of South Africa smashed his world record in the 440-yard hurdles today at the sixth British Empire and Commonwealth Games.

Thirty-eight American employes of the Miami shipping company that operates the Liberian steamship Florida have asked President Eisenhower to review a ruling by the National Labor Relations Board. The ruling permitted an American labor union to become bargaining agent for the non-citizen crew of the ship.

The City Planning Commission has found in a survey that the city's central business district, defined as Manhattan below Sixtieth Street, owes much to a genuine building boom that took place in the two-year period from fiscal 1954-55 to 1956-57. In that interval the taxable assessed valuation of real estate in the central business area went up by $138,000,000, or some 15 per cent of the gain for the city as a whole.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- Senate and House conferees approved tonight a compromise bill aimed at easing the economic plight of the railroads and other parts of the transportation industry.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The National Labor Relations Board will broaden its area of operations beginning Sept. 1.

Four floors and a store in the twenty-eight-story office building rising at 717 Fifth Avenue, southeast corner of Fifty-sixth Street, have been leased by the Owens-Coming Fiberglas Corporation. The lease involves 60,000 square feet of space at an aggregate rental of more than $9,000,000. The deal took a year to negotiate, according to Harry N. Masson, vice president of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., the broker.
WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- A House Judiciary subcommittee approved today a bill to create forty-five new Federal judgeships in widely scattered parts of the nation.

STRATFORD, Ont., July 22 -- After opening at Stratford, Conn., on Sunday, "The Winter's Tale" took the liberty of opening again at Stratford, Ont., the next evening. Although the material is the same in both places, the styles of production could hardly be more unalike.

Aviation has made a new advance in its struggle to break free of dependence on runways. A series of test flight of an Army-financed experimental craft has proved the feasibility of the tilt-wing principle.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The President's Council of Economic Advisers estimates that over-all business activity in the second quarter of the year was slightly better than in the first.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 22-- A young United States Marine was shot and fatally wounded by another early today near Beirut's International Airport. He was the first United States ground force man killed in the Lebanon operation.

The United Stated military intervention in Lebanon, followed by similar British action in Jordan, has rapidly developed into an international situation which if not immediately checked may explode into an atomic war.

The board of directors of University Settlement Associates, an affiliate of University Settlement, has selected the Oct. 28 performance of "Goldilocks" for its annual theatre party. The new musical will open Oct. 9 at the Lunt-Fontanne Theatre.
The Suffolk County Board of Supervisors was accused yesterday of "ignoring the record" in criticizing Governor Harriman for delay in constructing the Long Island Expressway.

STRATFORD, Ont., July 22 -- Fanfares are nothing new to the Stratford Festival. Indeed, a resounding brass and a drum call everyone to their seats for each act at the Festival Theatre. It is always a welcome sound, and the same can be said for the Fanfare and Anthem especially composed by Louis Applebaum, the festival's director of music, for this year's Music Festival.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) -- The Senate Judiciary Committee was told today of reports that an Army general had "cased" Central High School in Little Rock five days before troops were ordered there to enforce a court order for the admission of Negro students.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 22 -- Jean Simmons has agreed to co-star with Rock Hudson in "This Earth Is Mine," a joint production effort by Universal International and Vintage Productions.
CASEY STENGEL was more than a mite irked as he prepared to take his Yankees on another jaunt around the Western half of the American League.

LOS ANGELES, July 22 (UPI) -- Superior Judge Arnold Praeger issued a permanent injunction today against certification of the results of the June 3 referendum on the Dodgers' contract with the city to obtain land for a new stadium.
KANSAS CITY, July 23 (UPI) -- Ralph Terry spaced seven hits tonight as he hurled the Kansas City Athletics to a 3-1 victory over the Boston Red Sox.
The Roman Catholic Church yesterday reaffirmed the position that no Catholic could accept contraceptive birth control as a medical treatment or cooperate in the administration of such treatment.

TORONTO, July 23 (AP) -- Eric Hanson of Toronto gained today in the Canadian amateur golf championship by upsetting the defender, Nick Weslock of Windsor, Ont., and then defeating Jake Kleist of Syracuse, 2 up.

CARDIFF, Wales, July 23 (UPI) -- Judy Grinham of England produced the fifth world record performance of the British Empire and Commonwealth Games tonight. She won the women's 110-yard back-stroke swimming title in 1 minute 11.9 seconds.
Four officers of the Fire Department will stand trial on charges of neglect of duty in a case involving the theft of $2,447.50 from a Bronx firehouse last Sunday.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 23 -- The leader of Nicaragua's Free Labor Union Federation declined an invitation today to call on Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower at the United States Embassy.

The Senate's emphatic rejection of the highly protectionist Kerr amendment to the reciprocal trade bill and its overwhelming approval of the bill itself are all to the good. Yet much of the mischief done by the Senate Finance Committee still remains in the bill and should be excised in conference.

A drop of 2,462,000 barrels in gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend, total supplies were 179,707,000 barrels, compared with 182,169,000 a week earlier and 178,267,000 a year ago.
PHILADELPHIA, July 23 -- This staid old metropolis, which usually slumbers peacefully during the humid stretch of a long summer, is fairly buzzing with baseball.
DETROIT, July 23 -- It cannot be said that the Yankees finally caught up with and over-powered Frank Lary tonight at Briggs Stadium, where they battered the Bengals, 16 -- 4.

A SUPERB half-hour of television reporting -- informative, detailed and hard-hitting -- was seen last night over Channel 2 in Winston Burdett's study of the oil-rich state of Kuwait. Indeed, it was one of the most distinct and clear expositions of some of the basic causes of the Middle East crisis yet to be seen on the home screen.

The Defense Department reorganization bill, passed in differing versions by the House and Senate, was approved by a conference committee yesterday just after the United States had assumed the risk of major war in the Middle East.

On July 16 the Commissioner of Hospitals of New York City forbade the giving of birth control advice to a diabetic mother at the Kings County Hospital. On the following day The New York Times published an editorial deprecating this action. I should like to compliment you on the opinions there expressed.

Two theatre parties are being planned for the benefit of the Hudson Guild Neighborhood House at 436 West Twenty-seventh Street. They will take place at the Nov. 11 and Dec. 1 performances of "The Pleasure of His Company," scheduled to open at the Longacre Theatre on Oct. 22.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 23 -- An American airliner carried one American into Baghdad today and 146 Americans out. Most of those who departed were children.
Labor's high command is scheduled to get a briefing on the explosive world situation from John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State.

Directors of the General Foods Corporation backed up the optimism voiced by Charles G. Mortimer, president, at the annual meeting here yesterday, by voting a 10-cent increase in the quarterly dividend on the common stock.
MADISON, Wis., July 23 (AP) -- The executive committee of the American Municipal Association voted today to direct its staff to study proposals for taxing newspaper advertising.
The Damodar Valley Corporation, situated in India's most highly industrialized region, received its third loan yesterday from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

THE history of our time is full of questions -- and overflowing with questioners and their questionnaires. Posterity may well look back with astonishment at this state of apparently ungovernable curiosity. It is exemplified at its best in today's book, "The Cultured Man,"* by Ashley Montagu.

Three youths, members of a gang called the "Assassins," were convicted yesterday of the brutal assault of a member of a rival gang last April 22. They were sentenced to Elmira Reformatory for a period of up to three years.
CAIRO, July 23 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser is reported to be hopeful that he will be invited as an observer to the proposed summit meeting at the United Nations Security Council.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- The $160,000,000 Frying Pan - Arkansas reclamation project, approved today by the House committee, 19 -- 4, has been approved three times by the Senate, but the House in previous years has refused twice to consider it.

PARIS, July 23 -- In an all-day meeting today the foreign and finance ministers of the six European Economic Community countries failed to reach full accord on the proposed free-trade area embracing seventeen European nations including Britain.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Some of the world's most hardheaded realists about international events -- the New York and European currency dealers and speculators -- appear to have concluded that the Middle East crisis will not lead to a major military or economic upset.

WASHINGTON July 23 (UPI) -- A former professional football coach urged Congress today to give players greater protection from owners if legislation is enacted exempting organized sports from Federal antitrust laws.

To many of the 20,289 fans at Jamaica yesterday, it looked as if First Landing had to erase a slight deficit in order to catch and pass Atoll in the $33,725 Great American Stakes. But according to Eddie Arcaro, who rode him, First Landing was ahead every step of the five and a half furlongs in winning by a neck.

Dillon, Read Co., Inc. and Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc. and associates are offering today $35,000,000 of Natural Gas Pipeline Company of America 4 3/4 per cent debentures, due 1978, at 99 to yield 4.83 per cent.
Work will start late this month on the port's first transatlantic liner pier equipped to handle mid-winter travelers in comfort.

LONDON, July 23 (Reuters) -- Worth turned time back one hundred years this morning when, opening its fall fashion collection, it showed a replica of a grand ball gown made by the founder of the house for the Empress Eugenie.
LONDON, July 23 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial translation of the text of Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's message to President Eisenhower, as broadcast tonight by Moscow radio.
OSSINING, N. Y., July 23 -- The State Supreme Court will be asked tomorrow to throw its mantle of protection over a golfing handicap.
SOMERS, N. Y., July 23 -Historians reported today that the American circus was originated in this northern Westchester town in 1805, ten years earlier than hitherto believed.

AMMAN, July 23 -- The 12,000-ton tanker Clyde Explorer arrived at Jordan's Red Sea port of Aqaba today with a load of gasoline and oil for this fuel-short country.

Bernard P. Malone, a former supervising inspector in the Department of Buildings who was convicted June 24 on charges of perjury and criminal contempt, was sentenced yesterday to four years in prison.

LONDON, July 23 -- Stock market prices advanced in virtually every important section today. Trading did not expand significantly and buying remained selective. However, rises among industrials went up to 2 shillings - (28 cents), with store, electrical, steel and chemical shares in good demand.

BALTIMORE, July 23 (AP) -- A Federal Grand Jury heard more witnesses today on the operations of the Commercial Savings and Loan Association, Inc., with headquarters in Baltimore.
The New York Central Railroad reported yesterday a June deficit of $975,370. This brought the road's deficit in the first six months of this year to $25,565,920.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- A proposal to step up President Eisenhower's defense spending plans by $2,500,000,000 caused a deadlock today in the Senate Appropriations Committee.
Governor Harriman promised last night that the newly formed state anti-crime units would not usurp the powers of local law agencies.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (UP)-Senator Arthur V. Watkins urged Eastern "city slickers" today to preserve park lands in their own backyards instead of trying to fence in more of the wide open spaces of the West.

BAYREUTH, Germany, July 23 -- Tradition took another bruising as the Wagner Festival began here tonight. The old way of doing things has not been sacrosanct here at the Wagner holy of holies since 1951, when the composer's grandsons, Wieland and Wolfgang, took over.
Tex McCrary and his wife, Jinx Falkenburg, have closed a deal to continue their interview program over radio station WOR.
LONDON, July 23 (UPI) -- Hugh Wiley of Towson, Md., won the King George V Gold Cup, the premier event of London's International Horse Show, tonight at White City Stadium. Wiley rode Master William.

The Chase Manhattan Bank has contracted to sell the eleven-story and penthouse office and bank building at 188 Montague Street running through to Remsen Street in downtown Brooklyn. The building formerly was owned and occupied as a branch office by the Chemical Corn Exchange Bank.
CAIRO, July 23 (AP) -- Western travelers arriving today from Khartoum said a pro-Nasser coup had been attempted in Sudan in the last few days. It apparently was blocked by Sudanese authorities.

Mayor Wagner said yesterday that the Board of Estimate would "review carefully" the condemnation award of $81,715 for a school site in the Canarsie area of Brooklyn. The 1957-58 assessed valuation of the site was only $14,600.

Warren and Arthur Smadbeck, Inc., realty investors, purchased the three apartment buildings at 234-36-38 East Sixty-third Street from corporations controlled by Harry Glass. The Smadbecks own the adjoining three apartment houses at the southwest corner of Second Avenue and Sixty-third Street and now control a plot 155 by 100 feet.

The President's Council of Economic Advisers has just released its tentative estimate of the Gross National Product for the second quarter of 1958. This figure, which is a rough measure of the annual rate of production of all goods and services by the national economy, strongly suggests that we witnessed the bottom of the business downturn in the first quarter.

HOUSTON, July 23 (UPI) -- Joe Brown's rally in the second half of the fight tonight enabled him to keep his world lightweight championship on a close but unanimous fifteen-round decision over Kenny Lane before a sell-out crowd of more than 11,000 fans in the Coliseum.
Two teen-age youths were picked up and a $200 pocket watch retrieved yesterday in Central Park when a newly installed police radio system began operation.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Premier Amintore Fanfani of Italy will visit Washington July 29-30 for talks with President Eisenhower and Secretary of State Dulles, the White House announced today.

A musical version of Walter Hackett's farce-comedy "Captain Applejack" has been scheduled for Broadway presentation next January.
BUENOS AIRES, July 23 -- The Argentine Federal police today banned a Peronist rally planned for Saturday in memory of Eva Peron.
The hotel industry has not been immune to the recession.
LONDON, July 23 -- Queen Elizabeth II today named four women and ten men who are to receive life peerages under an act designed to revitalize the House of Lords.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 23 -The Lebanese Parliament was summoned today to meet July 31 to elect a successor to President Camille Chamoun.
STOCKHOLM, July 23 -- Foreign Minister Oesten Unden took to the radio tonight in an attempt to answer rising criticism here of Swedish policy at the United Nations.
GENEVA, July 23 -- A Jewish leader warned today that a current decline of overt anti-Semitism might constitute a new danger to Jewish survival.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Implicit in the latest Eisenhower-Khrushchev correspondence is that this Government has been pushed and pulled into taking a reluctant step toward a "summit" conference. The pulling was centrifugal, having been applied externally by the pressure of the British Labor party on Prime Minister Macmillan and by world-wide public opinion.

The trouble has been recently that Mr. Khrushchev has named dates too near for comfortable preparation, has attached conditions not always easy to meet and has accompanied his offers of peace with language not ordinarily associated with polite diplomacy.

JACKSON, Miss., July 23 (UPI) -- Gov. J. P. Coleman rejected a Federal subpoena today to testify in a trial challenging Mississippi's voter registration laws. A lawyer for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People threatened to seek a contempt citation against the Governor.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Government unveiled a tentative plan today for dealing with any cut-off of Middle East oil. It was roughly similar to the plan used for the 1956-57 Suez crisis, but differed in several significant particulars.

Investors who trade in odd lots (usually less than 100 shares) sold more shares in June than they bought for the first time since December, 1954, according to yesterday's quarterly report of the New York Stock Exchange. That indicated that the small investor was acting cautiously.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 23 -- Inflation-ridden Brazil has decided to tighten the fiscal belt, cutting Government expenses in an effort to diminish what promised to be a staggering budget deficit this year.
BONN, Germany, July 23 -- The Cabinet expressed support today for the United States and British military moves in Lebanon and Jordan.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 23 -- The third Air Force missile to carry a mouse into space thundered from its pad here tonight at 6:13 o'clock, Eastern Daylight Time.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (UPI) -- The United States Controller General sharply criticized the Army today for having bought $20,000,000 worth of faulty grenades that are now being destroyed.

HOLLYWOOD; Calif., July 23 -- Having lost the first fight, the American Federation of Musicians has no intention of engaging voluntarily in a second contest of strength with the Musicians Guild of America for motion-picture studio jobs.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Representative Felix Edward Hebert (pronounced "ay-bear") is no tyro at investigations.

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 23 (Canadian Press) -- St. Catharine's Rowing Club and the New York Athletic Club today jumped into an early lead in the standing of the four-day Royal Canadian Henley Regatta.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Renewed pressure, led by Britain, is being brought to bear upon the United States to join the Baghdad Pact.

SYOSSET, L. I., July 23 -About 4,000 home-bound commuters on the Port Jefferson line of the Long Island Rail Road were shuttled by bus to their destinations after a collision between a tractor-trailer and a train near the Huntington station today. Seven persons were injured.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Senate adopted a resolution today urging that study be given to establishing an international development association to make long-term, low-interest loans to under-developed areas.
TRENTON, N. J., July 23 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner appointed Harold J. Ashby of Newark today as chairman of the State Parole Board.

Bellevue Hospital has given practical experience to all kinds of young physicians in a history that goes back to 1736. This month for the first time, according to a hospital official, it has welcomed a nun among its new internes.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 23 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold has drawn up tentative plans under which the proposed summit meeting would be held under the auspices of the Security Council but behind closed doors.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -The assumption in official quarters here tonight was that a heads-of-government meeting on the Middle East in the United Nations Security Council would take place in New York within a fortnight.

CARACAS, Venezuela, July 23 -- The Provisional Government of Rear Admiral Wolfgang Larrazabal today announced complete victory over a coup attempted yesterday by a group of military figures headed by the Defense Minister.

MOSCOW, July 23 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev accepted today Western proposals for a summit meeting on the Middle East within the framework of the United Nations Security Council. He attached minor conditions to his acceptance.
Rain and heavy fog early yesterday delayed planes at metropolitan airports, slowed ferry service to Staten Island and held up the docking of the French liner Liberte for seven hours.

The present period of easy money and low interest rates tends to disprove a long-held theory. The idea has been that when interest rates are high, investors usually put idle funds to work and then withdraw them when interest rates turn down.
HAVANA, July 28 -- Fierce fighting was reported today to have broken out in Oriente Province with the opening of another offensive by the Government to suppress the rebellion led by Fidel Castro.

Commodity prices closed irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading in most markets was dull. Activity was featureless, because most traders again were awaiting developments on the international situation.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Hawaii cleared a hurdle on the way to statehood today only to be advised to give up the effort until next year.

IT is no wonder that Saks Fifth Avenue dotes on male shoppers. Last week a prize customer bought fifteen sports coats and twice as many pairs of slacks in about thirty minutes. The same decisive man polished off a previous buying spree by inquiring the way to the mink coats. He selected two.
The threatened strike of 20,000 telephone maintenance employes in the metropolitan area was put off by their union yesterday until some time after Aug. 5.
LONDON, July 23 -- British officials tonight greeted Nikita S. Khrushchev's conditional acceptance of summit talks in the United Nations Security Council as a "valuable advance."
CHICAGO, July 23 (AP) -- The adjustment of grain futures to more normal market conditions appeared today to have been completed on the Board of Trade.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Consumer prices edged up to another record in June.
PARIS, July 23 -- Soviet acceptance of a proposal for a meeting of heads of government in the United Nations Security Council tonight provoked reexamination of French hostility to the idea.
CHICAGO, July 23 -- The Inland Steel Company reported today that second-quarter sales and earnings showed improvement over the first quarter, although they were below the second quarter of 1958.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon formally opened a Republican Operation Coffee Cup campaign today by telling G. O. P. workers to "get up early and stay up late" if they wanted to win this year's Congressional election.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Representative F. Edward Hebert confirmed today that four more individuals had been subpoenaed in the investigation of an Army contract and possible White House influence.
A lower court judgment in favor of the Beech Aircraft Corporation in a damage suit stemming from a plane crash has been upheld by the United States Court of Appeals.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- Senator Pat McNamara, Democrat of Michigan, called today for a Congressional study of a Canadian proposal to establish tolls for use of the Welland Canal, which connects Lakes Erie and Ontario.
Manufacturers in New York, Chicago, Philadelphia and New Jersey agreed to quick settlements yesterday in the first national strike of cap makers:

With the coming of the Russian-American Track and Field Games in Moscow next week the attention of sports-minded Americans will be focused on the scene unfolding on the Soviet athletic field. However, right here in New York each day is held another sort of athletic contest on the ramp that runs from the Lexington Avenue local and express subway tracks to the Times Square Shuttle.
The United Corporation, closed-end investment fund, reported yesterday an 18 per cent gain in assets during the first half.

The Venezuelan people are to be congratulated on their defense of the civic freedom so recently won. An old-fashioned military coup, headed by General Castro Leon, who was, ironically, Minister of Defense, has been defeated. The interim Government of Admiral Larrazabal carries on pending an election for President and Congress.

Lieut. Gen. James M. Gavin's ''War and Peace in the Space Age," which Harper had announced for late August publication, will now be issued Aug. 11. General Gavin, who retired last March as chief of the Army Office of Research and Development, reviews his Army career that began in 1922 and gives his views on the state of this country's national defense, which he considers to be weak.

PHILADELPHIA, July 23 (UPI) -- The Philadelphia Phillies welcomed Eddie Sawyer back as manager tonight by beating the San Francisco Giants twice. They knocked the Giants out of first place in the National League with a 2-0 victory after taking a 3-2 decision in the completion of a game suspended June 22.
Samuel Austin Chapin, Amherst College's oldest alumnus, was reading messages of congratulation from many parts of the country yesterday. And for good reason. Today is his 100th birthday.

Mayor Wagner will leave today for a ten-day vacation in California. He said last night that he had "given no thought" to change his plans because of a possible summit meeting that would bring Soviet Premier Khrushchev to the city within the next two weeks.

Dr. William Heard Kilpatrick, a pioneer in progressive education, declared yesterday that despite an "educational hysteria" aroused by the Soviet earth satellites, progressive education would move forward in this country.
Corporation Counsel Peter Campbell Brown, whose most recent months in office have been stormy, will leave his $25,000-a-year city post early in September.

RABAT, Morocco, July 23 -Alfred T. Wellborn, United States Charge D'Affaires in Morocco, called on King Mohamed V today on instructions from Washington to deliver a message concerning the Middle Eastern situation.
THERE was a time in America when the "soup of the evening, beautiful soup," was almost uniformly a steaming concoction served preferably in mid-winter.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (UPI) -- The Senate passed a bill today to give the Federal Government joint responsibility with the states for the civil defense program.

Security officials said yesterday that the proposed trip of Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev to New York would pose extraordinary security problems. It also would fulfill a long and repeatedly expressed desire of the Soviet Premier to visit the United States.
DENVER, July 23 (AP) -- Congressional criticism of construction practices at the United States Air Force Academy was termed unfair today by Maj. Gen. James E. Briggs, Academy superintendent.
NORWALK, Conn., July 23 -- Geologists of Yale University are undertaking to determine whether dredging operations have any effect on shore erosion in this area.
Most leading groups moved down yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. But strength appeared in some neglected portions of the list and it ended an up-and-down day all but unchanged.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -House and Senate conferees reached agreement today on a final version of the Pentagon reorganization bill. It denies President Eisenhower two important goals for which he had fought hard in Congress.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 23 -- Malcolm Anderson of Australia was shockingly beaten on wet turf in the Pennsylvania lawn tennis championship at the Merion Cricket Club today and walked off the court in anger.

An East Side boy who prefers to fly led eighteen buddies to a national marching championship yesterday at Rockefeller Plaza. He is Henry Olynyk, a 19-year-old City College junior of 705 East Ninth Street.
James A. Farley criticized Federal immigration laws last night for excluding "millions of worthy people."
The first two science and mathematics teaching scholarships sponsored by the city were awarded yesterday at City Hall by Mayor Wagner and City Council President Abe Stark.
CHICAGO, July 23 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 12 to 32 points (60 cents to $1.60 a bale) yesterday, with the new October and December weakest.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 23 -- Baghdad was breathing easily tonight after its hour of turmoil a week ago.

"Cat on a Hot Tin Roof," the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer version of Tennessee Williams' Pulitzer Prize-winning drama, has been scheduled to follow the forthcoming "The Reluctant Debutante" at the Radio City Music Hall, according to a company announcement.
BRUSSELS, July 23 (AP) -- An American-born Swedish housewife, Mrs. Sigrid Johansson, won the world archery championship for women today by defeating two United States rivals.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 23 -- This was Junior Day in the Larchmont Yacht Club's sixtieth annual race week. It was the second junior day of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound, and it was in direct contrast to the first junior regatta of this season.
GENEVA, July 23 -- Western and Eastern scientists agreed today that a radiological detection method should be included in an inspection system to monitor any cessation of tests of nuclear weapons.

UTICA, N. Y., July 23 (AP) -- A former champion Tommy Goodwin was eliminated today in the first round of the State amateur golf tournament. Emil Pasnik of Hamburg, defeated Goodwin on the twentieth hole.
The Middle East crisis has spurred activity in the ship sales market both here and in London, the world's leading centers for second-hand tonnage.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- President Eisenhower named Marian Anderson today as one of seven new members of the United States delegation to the thirteenth session of the United Nations General Assembly opening Sept. 16.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 23 (AP) -- Plion, undefeated in five Monmouth Park starts, including two this season, today scored his second stakes triumph of the year, winning the thirteenth running of the $20,000 added Lamplighter Handicap.
The Treasury's $16,262,000,000 refunding came to a successful end yesterday, largely because of market support purchases by the Federal Reserve System.

A corner arcade store in the new Tishman Building at 666 Fifth Avenue at Fifty-second Street has been leased by Transcontinental, S. A., Argentine Airline for sales and general offices. George L. Studley, vice president of Julien J. Studley, Inc., was the broker.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed that, in the week ended Wednesday, July 16 there were:
Sales and earnings of the Radio Corporation of America dropped substantially in the first six months of this year, as compared with the like 1957 period.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) Senator John O. Pastore, Democrat of Rhode Island, asked the Government today to review charges and countercharges aired in stormy hearings on a bill to restrict television and radio in the music field.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 23 -- They came by the hundreds today, the humble, the curious and the vengeful, to see the despoiled house of a fallen Premier.
The editorial "In the City's Hospitals" ignores the crux of the problem concerning the use of birth control appliances.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- A uniformed Boy Scout delivered a handbook for emergencies to President Eisenhower today. It was a twenty-four-page manual on how to get ready for peacetime and wartime disasters.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- A group of Republicans gave notice today of a fight on the House floor to exempt employer unilateral plans from the pension and welfare reporting bill.

California borrowed $100,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to help war veterans buy farms and dwellings. Serial obligations due from 1960 to 1984 were sold to a syndicate headed by the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association and the Bankers Trust Company.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- A 7 per cent increase in Social Security insurance benefits was tentatively approved today by the House Ways and Means Committee.

The Central and South West Corporation reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for three, six and twelve months ended June 30. The big utility holding company has subsidiaries in Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and Louisiana.

COCOA BEACH, Fla., July 23 -- For the first time in three Thor-Able launches, the Patrick Air Force Base gave the mouse a full-scale news conference last night before it started on its 6,000-mile journey through space.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- A four-year renewal of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act appears certain to win approval of a Senate-House conference committee created today.

The Torgersons, Ruth and Ray, of the Cherry Valley Club, Garden City, L. I., are a well-known metropolitan golfing couple. They have won the husband-and-wife championship of the Women's Metropolitan as well as the Cross County Golf Association on eleven occasions.

STONY ISLAND, Lake Ontario, July 23 -- It turned out today that the waters of Lake Ontario are not still too cold for black bass to strike and that the bass are not necessarily in twenty feet of water.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 23 -- Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlevi appeared in a confident mood today as he told members of Parliament that his policy of "positive nationalism" had achieved cordial relations with the Soviet Union and the Western powers.

Retailers of men's clothing, looking ahead to next spring, plan to buy larger quantities of summer-weight suits. Fewer of them are expected to be in the darker shades, and medium and light colors should be in demand. These are two highlights of an annual survey conducted by the Clothing Manufacturers Association.

Today's new film is "The Captain From Koepenick," a German-made comedy-drama in color starring Heinz Ruhmann, at the Seventy-second Street Playhouse, 346 East Seventy-second Street. The Gyula Trebitsch production was directed by Helmut Kautner, who co-adapted Carl Zuckmayer's stage play with the author. Distributors Corporation of America is releasing the import.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., July 24 -- The Carborundum Company board of directors today authorized start of a $10,000,000 plant expansion program here. The decision came after company agreement with the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers on major revisions in a new labor contract.

Albert J. Guerard, author of eight books of fiction and criticism, has two more books ready for publication. One is a novel, "The Bystander," which Atlantic-Little, Brown will issue Monday. It is a story of love and sexuality on the French Riviera.
NAPLES, Italy, July 23 (AP) -- Charles (Lucky) Luciano was questioned for two hours today on whether he had had a hand in the crime convention last November at Apalachin, N. Y. Luciano denied it.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 24--Agriculture in Australia, often blessed but frequently buffeted by natural forces, including drought, has profited handsomely through an alliance with science. Benefits to date promise to pyramid in the future.
Paul M. Butler, Democratic national chairman, predicted yesterday that his party would gain twelve to fourteen Senate seats in the Congressional elections this fall.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Shoved forward to a United Nations "summit" meeting with Premier Khrushchev by forces at home and abroad that it found politically irresistible, the United States Government is also inching toward that destination under the false brand, fabricated by Soviet Russian propaganda, of a Mideast aggressor.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 24 -- Hollywood press agents are the latest to feel the economic pinch that has touched virtually every department of moviemaking. Employment of the group by major studios has dropped from 150 to 95 during the last year, according to the publicists Local 818, International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 24 -- The mystery about the identity of the author of "The Brave One" is to be aired again this time in Los Angeles Superior Court.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 24 -- President Camille Chamoun expressed today the hope that United States troops might start to leave Lebanon about a month from now.
JACKSON, Miss., July 24 (UPI) -- A panel of three Federal judges refused today to cite Gov. J. P. Coleman for contempt of court because he rejected a Federal court subpoena.
HAVERFORD, Pa., July 24 -- Victor Seixas followed Australia's Malcolm Anderson out of the Pennsylvania lawn tennis championships today at the Merion Cricket Club.
PHILADELPHIA, July 24 -- The railroad defendants have filed an appeal against a final judgment of the District Court in the antitrust suit won by the Pennsylvania Motor Truck Association.
The Brooklyn Union Gas Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net incomes for the three, six and twelve months ended June 30.
ALBANY, July 24 -- A "cleanup or close" campaign against unsanitary resort hotels, children's camps and motels has been opened by the State Health Department.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 24 -- Light and flukey air, which varied from a mere whisper to puffs that, on occasion went as high as five knots, again proved irksome to crews competing in the sixtieth annual race week of the Larchmont Yacht Club today.

COCOA BEACH, Fla., July 24 -- Twenty-four hours after the launching from Cape Canaveral of a Thor-Able rocket with a mouse in the nose cone, there was no indication and little hope that the tiny passenger would be rescued. The rocket was fired at 6:13 P. M. yesterday.
STAMFORD, Conn., July 24 -- A demand that this city act immediately to increase its park and recreational facilities was made today by the Joint Committee on Parks and Recreation.

Man's flight to the stars in our age is more a matter of time and waiting than a fantastic dream born in the mind of the science-fiction writer. Or so it appears to several Soviet leaders, who recently charged their own pseudo-scientific writers of showing lack of imagination.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- France notified the United States today of her intent to denounce the civil air transport agreement signed by the two nations in 1946.

The recent brutal attack by the Russians on our Air Force over Armenia is but a continuation of the pattern begun in 1946, and the frequency of such incidents since then gives rise to a number of disturbing questions.

The Shell Oil Company reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $19,182,070, or 63 cents a share, in the three months ended June 30. This compares with $33,871,344, or $1.12 a share, in the similar period last year. Gross income was $394,120,159, against $437,791,415.
CHICAGO, July 24 (UPI) -- Will Harridge, president of the American League, today fined Ted Williams $250 for spitting at Kansas City fans who booed the Boston Red Sox slugger last night.
MOSCOW, July 24 -- The Soviet Union agreed today to cut by 50 per cent Austria's remaining obligations to deliver oil to the Soviet bloc.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- The House passed a sharply shaved $1,218,815,000 military construction appropriation bill today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 24 -- The United Nations received an offer today to help take care of the extra callers who might turn up for the proposed heads-of-state conference.
MOSCOW, July 24 -- Soviet industry surpassed its production goal in the first half of 1958 by 4 per cent, the Government announced today.

BAYREUTH, Germany, July 24 -- A modern version of "Die Meistersinger," as Wieland Wagner has conceived it for the Wagner Festival, is spectacular at its best in the final scene. It is also at its worst in the first act, dehumanized.

Even in these times, when "historic" events are almost commonplace, the summit meeting on the Middle East shapes up as something exceptional. The air is full of superlatives. This is, in fact, bound to be one of the key conferences of modern times.
CHICAGO, July 24 (AP) -- Selling was general and moderately heavy in grain futures today, and prices on the Board of Trade sagged sharply in most contracts.
DETROIT, July 24 -- The American Motors Corporation reported today net earnings of $7,253,785, or $1.30 a share, for the quarter ended June 30.

LOS ANGELES, July 24 -- Damages of $5,000,000 were sought in a suit filed in Federal Court against Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., Warner Brothers Records, Inc., and nine Warner music publishing subsidiaries by Precision Radiation Instruments, Inc., which now produces records under the Tops label.

In quest of knowledge, thirteen high school students from Bay Shore, L. I., spent two hours yesterday in the Soviet Union's United Nations Mission at 680 Park Avenue. After walking blithely past an amazed squad of policemen, they entered Communism's plush bastion at Sixty-eighth Street to exchange ideas on world affairs with two members of the Soviet United Nations delegation.

Plans for the construction of a 600-car garage above a street-level store on Livingston Street in downtown Brooklyn were announced yesterday by Abraham Straus. The Board of Estimate gave its approval to this and two other off-street parking facilities.
Thomas K. Finletter's announcement of his candidacy for the New York State Democratic Senatorial nomination is no surprise, but is welcome all the same.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- Senate investigators said today that Communists had resorted to numerous frauds to obtain United States passports and had used them for purposes hostile to American interests.

I am writing to thank the United States through you. This is not merely a personal feeling, but the sincere opinion of the people of Lebanon both here and abroad. We were praying for a miracle and it has been granted by the generous answer to our desperate appeal.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission authorized today the construction and operation of a new international radio broadcasting station near Belmont, Calif. It is the first permit of its kind to be issued since World War II.
CANTON, Ohio, July 24 (AP) -- Plants of the Timken Roller Bearing Company here and in Columbus and Zanesville were shut down today by a strike.
City Councilman Earl Brown said yesterday that he had detected a rising tide of sentiment in Harlem against Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr.
How dear to the hearts of the majority of American families today are the annual vacation plans! It seems such a usual thing to anticipate the welcome change of holiday sights and sounds.
HARTFORD, July 24 (AP) -- The police said tonight that three boys had admitted setting a junkyard fire here earlier today.

CARDIFF, Wales, July 24 (AP) -- Keith Gardner, a 29-year-old Jamaican student at the University of Nebraska, and two Australians -- Dave Power and Mrs. Marlene Mathews-Willard -- completed doubles in the British Empire Games today.

Two elevator apartment buildings at 576 and 600 Timpson Place in the Bronx have been sold by the H. I. J. Holding Corporation to an investing client of Noel Leiblich, attorney. Each house is on a plot 125 by 117 feet and contains fifty-five apartments.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) -- The House Ways and Means Committee voted today, 14 to 11, to give the nation's 1,000, oo railroad workers special tax savings of up to $27.30 a year now and possibly more later.
TOMORROW night before the sun is down, Japanese in New York and Japanese from Toronto will have met in the green park on the Hudson shore at 103d Street.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) -- Senate Republican Leader William F. Knowland declared today that a summit conference on Soviet Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's terms would result in "another Munich" for the West.
BUENOS AIRES, July 24 -- President Arturo Frondizi announced tonight that Argentina had received foreign investment offers totaling $1,000,000,000 for oil development.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican of Indiana, questioned today the ethics of Representative James Roosevelt, Democrat of California. His action set off an uproar in the Senate Banking Committee.

A summit meeting in this city -- or in that enclave we call the United Nations headquarters -- might require a security force of as many as 5,000 men to protect the participants. This was an unofficial estimate made after Premier Khrushchev's acceptance had been received. If an army of that size is indeed necessary, we hope that it will be made available.
DARIEN, Conn., July 24 -- The Dan Deering Company of Norfolk, with $2,012,000, was apparently the low bidder for this community's new high school when bids were opened last night.

The Board of Estimate was called upon yesterday to disapprove either of two proposals for a roadway through Washington Square Park. The demand was made by Anthony B. Akers, unopposed candidate for the Democratic and Liberal nominations as Representative from Manhattan's Seventeenth District.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Admiral Quiggle was born in Grand Island, Neb., May 22, 1906. He attended Kearney, Neb., High School and enlisted in the Navy in 1924. He received an honorable discharge in 1926 and entered the Naval Academy, receiving his commission in 1930.

LONDON, July 24 -- The British Government intends to tell Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev that peace and stability cannot be restored to the Middle East while Soviet arms and money support President Gamal Abdel Nasser's "Arab imperialism."
Some of the dolls to be offered in the near future to small girls will be made of different "flesh."

A round of applause that was intended as something more than a salute to the winning favorite went up as the opening race was being completed at Jamaica yesterday. The victory went to Isidor Bieber's Hello Kitsy, but the compliments were for Teddy Atkinson, the jockey.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 24 (Reuters) -- British troops continued arresting Greek and Turkish Cypriotes today, and the Greeks staged a general strike in protest.
Commodity prices generally declined yesterday on New York Exchanges. Trading was dull.
THE shows are on, the critics have been in and large audiences are gathering to pass judgment on the current crop of model-room productions.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 24 (AP) -- Four Negroes were permitted to apply for city Civil Service jobs yesterday as city officials removed the traditional "white only" restriction on such positions. Ray Mullins, director of the Personnel Board, announced the removal of the racial ban, which in the past has barred Negroes from jobs as policemen, firemen and clerks and from other administrative posts.

Bingo for New York City was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate. The bill now goes to Mayor Wagner, whose signature is considered assured, and then to the city's voters for ratification at the Nov. 4 election.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 24 -- Sheik Beshara el-Khoury, who was forced to resign the Presidency of Lebanon in 1952, may make a come-back in the Presidential elections scheduled for a week from today.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 24 (AP) -- "I am the son of the army and the nation," the man who commanded the July 14 Iraqi revolution said today.
WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Motorola, Inc., fired another shot today in the running battle over the place of the Bell System telephone companies in the fast-growing mobile radio communications field.

PARIS, July 24 -- France clung tonight to her opposition to a meeting of heads of government in the United Nations Security Council at New York but delayed formulation of her position and possible counter-proposals until Saturday.

MILWAUKEE, July 24 (UPI) -- The St. Louis Cardinals routed Warren Spahn in the first inning and went on to score a 4-0 victory over the Braves today on Sam Jones' four-hit pitching. Jones allowed only one Brave to reach third base and only two got to second.
More red, amber and green traffic lights will replace the old red-green units as a result of the Board of Estimate's approval yesterday of a $761,000 outlay by the Department of Traffic.
A patronage dispute involving three park employes who stand to lose $1,350 in pay is blocking a proposed $2,000,000 redevelopment project in Mohansic Park in northern Westchester.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The United States Embassy in Beirut has reported that Lebanon's current crisis "has resulted in a general paralysis of economic life."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 24 -- The United Nations Observation Group in Lebanon is confident that it can, without help from the United States Marines, seal the Syrian border and drastically reduce the smuggling of arms and the infiltration of men into Lebanon.
WHITE PLAINS, July 24 -- Justice Samuel W. Eager said in State Supreme Court here today that he was reluctant to supersede the officers of a country club in fixing a member's golfing handicap.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 4 to 16 points yesterday. (A point equals 5 cents a bale.)
You are to be congratulated for pointing out to readers of The Times on July 13 that "toll roads are safer."
Paul John (Frankie) Carbo, reputed to be the underworld king of boxing, was indicted yesterday on ten charges of illegal operations in the sport. A nation-wide alarm was issued for his arrest.
An outboard motorboat yesterday completed the first trans-Atlantic crossing by such a craft. It was escorted by a freighter most of the way from near Copenhagen.
Bad news and higher prices walked hand in hand yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange, and the averages rose again to new 1958 highs.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Administration has decided to ask Congress for an immediate increase of $8,000,000,000 in the national debt limit of $280,000,000,000.
LONDON, July 24 -- The stock market extended its advance today, with Government securities in the lead.

AMMAN, Jordan, July 24 -- Maj. Gen. Sadik Sharaa, deputy commanding general of the still-born Arab Union Army of Jordan and Iraq, arrived here today by car from Baghdad with seven other Jordanian officers. He was granted an immediate audience by King Hussein.

Draft indebtedness of Latin-American importers to United States exporters declined $8,100,000 in June to $158,100,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The bank's monthly survey of fourteen large commercial banks showed declines for eighteen countries, with Peru accounting for the largest decrease.
GENEVA, July 24 -- The World Jewish Congress offered today to send an international Jewish delegation to Moscow to discuss the problems of Jews in the Soviet Union.

The operator of a service station in Queens who had sold gasoline to a 15-year-old boy driving a stolen car that later struck a cyclist was convicted yesterday of contributing to the delinquency of a minor.

CAIRO, July 24 -- Joint committees have been set up to draw up a program of closer cooperation between Iraq and President Gamal Abdel Nasser's United Arab Republic in the military, political, economic and educational fields, it was announced today.
The power companies' advertising campaign for automatic dishwashers is moving into high gear.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) -- Five members of the House subcommittee investigating Federal agencies called today for a prompt vote on whether to cite Bernard Goldfine for contempt of Congress.

Los Angeles plans to borrow $21,500,000 on improvement bonds secured by general taxation. The issue will be dated Sept. 1, 1958, and will come due serially on Sept. 1 from 1959 to 1988. The sale will be held on Aug. 19.
ELMSFORD, N. Y., July 24 -- Fred Annon, the 44-year-old Ryewood professional, shattered par with a 67 to lead the Westchester Open golf field today.
NEW DELHI, India, July 24 -- Soviet acceptance of a heads-of-government meeting within the framework of the United Nations Security Council has been favorably received in official circles here.

ALBANY, July 24 -- The State Education Department announced today the names of 300 veterans who have won Regents War Service Scholarships. The awards, based on a competitive examination held June 7, were effective July 1.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Senate and House passed and sent to the White House today the Pentagon reorganization bill approved by President Eisenhower.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- With money and harsh words, the Senate put new pressure on the Administration today in an effort to compel a faster build-up of United States military strength.
Nikita S. Kkrushchev's trip to New York, in the opinion of diplomats who know him, could afford a unique chance to demonstrate to him what democracy and the American system really are.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 24 -- The New York Times was cited tonight by a Soviet editor as an example of a newspaper without its own freedom.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 24 -- Del Miller, a harness racing owner, driver, trainer and breeder, ended his feud with Roosevelt Raceway today. Miller, after a month's absence, will drive here again tomorrow night.

ROME, July 24 -- Italy and Morocco are scheduled to sign an oil accord tomorrow. Enrico Mattei, politically powerful chief of the government's oil and gas agency, left here today for Rabat to complete the deal.
While the latest earnings of American Motors Company were making bad reading for its competitors, investors flocked to buy AMO on the New York Stock Exchange.

The number of workers drawing unemployment insurance in this state decreased more sharply last week than in any week since the recession began nearly a year ago. The drop of 37,500 in registrations for regular benefit payments was nearly three times the largest previous decline.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 24 -- Rear Admiral Lynne C. Quiggle was reported missing when the liner President Cleveland arrived here today.

The present session of Congress will be guilty of grave dereliction if it allows the case of Hawaii's statehood again to go by default. There is simply no honorable excuse for the manipulation that is preventing the issue from coming to a vote.
A guest book in solid rock near Beirut marks the passage of foreign soldiery through Lebanon for 3,000 years.
Business men and Government officials representing Staten Island are making a concerted effort to save the Staten Island shipyard of the Bethlehem Steel Company.
CARACAS, Venezuela, July 24 -- Venezuela returned to normal today after a widespread "symbolic" general strike yesterday in support of the Government of Admiral Wolfgang Larrazabal.
As a former Massachusetts citizen, now a citizen of New York State, I should like to discuss the candidacy of James A. Farley for the United States Senate.
Steve Federoff defeated Joseph A. Dunn for the post of secretary-treasurer of the National Maritime Union, it was announced yesterday by the Honest Ballot Association.
ATHENS, July 24 -- An audience here gave a warm reception tonight to the Smith College Singers.

BERLIN, July 24 -- An agreement has been established between the East German Government and the Evangelical churches to eliminate "disturbing factors" in church-state relations, A. D. N., official East German press service, announced today.
The New York State Association of Chiefs of Police adopted resolutions yesterday urging legislation to raise the salaries of policemen and to improve their lot in other ways.
Machine tools continue to gain steadily in net new orders.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The United States has called home its Ambassador to Cambodia for a report on Cambodia's recognition of Communist China.

Net income of the Owens-Illinois Glass Company for the first half of this year was $16,436,963, equal to $2.07 a common share, against $17,097,196, or $2.16 a share, a year earlier. Sales dipped to $243,474,455 from $247,456,069, Carl E. Megowen, president, reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The volume of construction contracts awarded for the interstate highway system last month was almost double that of the month before, the Bureau of Public Roads reported today.

Other areas have ambitions for the honor but Cape Cod can prove beyond much doubt it is the pleasure boatman's perfect North Atlantic waterway vacation spot. It would be hard to swing a dock line without hitting one of what must be hundreds, if not thousands, of harbors, anchorages, bights, bays.
MOSCOW, July 24 -- Diplomats in Moscow were certain today that a summit meeting on the Middle East situation could not begin in New York next Monday as Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev had proposed.
RABAT, Morocco, July 24 -- The Moroccan Government will sign an oil-prospecting and concession agreement tomorrow with Enrico Mattei, oil chief of the Italian Government.

What is Khrushchev's game? What did he seek to gain by his melodramatic offer to come here for a summit conference within the framework of the United Nations? The whole world is asking these questions now. Obviously the full answer will only come later. But already part of what he is after is obvious.
The Brooklyn division of the Protestant Council issued a statement yesterday saying that birth control was a matter to be judged by competent doctors and their patients.

The United States Court of Appeals decided yesterday that the New York State Power Authority had followed an incorrect procedure in condemning land of the Tuscarora Indian tribe for the Niagara River power project.

DESPITE a moist and threatening sky, there were 9,500 people in Lewisohn Stadium last night to hear the second jazz program in this season's Stadium Concerts series. The attractions were Duke Ellington and his orchestra and the Gerry Mulligan Quartet.

There is something special about the appointment of Marian Anderson to be a member of our delegation at the next meeting of the United Nations General Assembly. The choice may be construed as a recognition of her own unique worth. We like to think, however, that it is rather a way in which the United States does honor to the world organization.
MOSCOW, July 24 (UPI) -- The United States and Russian teams disagree over how to decide the winner of their dual track and field meet Sunday and Monday in Moscow's new Lenin Stadium.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 24 -- The Soviet Union used the opening here today of the annual conference of the Interparliamentary Union to charge the United States and Britain with aggression in the Middle East and renew an insistence that a Middle East question be added to the agenda.

The five-story brownstone dwelling at 16 West Twelfth Street has been sold by Dr. Paul Matlin to a client of William Alfred White, Inc., broker. Before the seller bought the property five years ago the house was known as the Frederick Vanderbilt Field home.

The Federal Reserve System disclosed yesterday that it had bought $1,090,000,000 of the forthcoming 1 5/8 per cent one-year Government certificates in support of the Treasury's $16,262,000,000 refunding completed Wednesday.
PARIS, July 24 -- The Government outlined today a plan designed to overcome France's serious urban and rural housing problem.

The warm and humid weather that has beset the metropolitan area since Wednesday will continue tomorrow, the Weather Bureau said yesterday. But cool air from Canada that is now moving over the Great Lakes is expected to provide a fair and pleasant Sunday.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- Maj. Gen. Paul D. Adams of the Army has been appointed commander of Army and Marine land forces in Lebanon.
TRENTON, July 24 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner filled twenty-five state positions today.
PHILADELPHIA, July 24 -- "You ask me whether I think the Giants can go all the way and win this pennant," said Bill Rigney as he stretched his long legs and made himself as comfortable as possible.
TRENTON, July 24 -- State education officials here are seriously concerned over the growing inadequacy of school facilities, which is expected to increase over the next two years.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 24 -- Government and Opposition leaders moved tonight toward re-establishing unity on foreign policy.
UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., July 24 -- Edward M. Smith of Upper Montclair won the Metropolitan Golf Association senior championship today with a 38, 37 -- 75 over his home course.
RABAT, Morocco, July 24 -- United States authorities here ordered the Dutch ship Lijnbaan to leave the port of Safi tonight without discharging her cargo of munitions for an American air base.

WHEN Napoleon crossed the Niemen River into Russia in June of 1812 he seemed as confident as ever. His Grand Army was huge, probably about 500,000 men -- Frenchmen, Germans, Austrians, Croats, Italians, Poles, Dutch, Spaniards and even Portuguese. He had assembled thousands of wagons, droves of cattle and 1,372 cannon.

DALLAS, Tex., July 24 -- In 1952 and again in 1956 overwhelmingly Democratic Texas went Republican in the Presidential election. Its inclination in 1960 may be significantly hinted in the outcome of two political battles Saturday.
LONDON, July 24 -- The United States was criticized here today for abstaining from the international convention for prevention of pollution of the sea by oil.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 24 -- Dr. Charles Malik, the Lebanese Foreign Minister, said today that infiltration of men and arms into Lebanon from the United Arab Republic was continuing.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The United States Government began building its defenses today for the proposed summit meeting at the United Nations.

Unionized cap makers prepared yesterday to concentrate on the organization of cap jobbers to "close off distribution sources for sweatshop products." The decision was announced by Alex Rose, president of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers International Union, in the wake of the union's first national strike against cap manufacturers.

LONDON, July 24 -- The British Government said today that a grave deterioration in the internal situation in Cyprus since June had caused the most serious threat to peace since Britain began administering the island eighty years ago.
The National Distillers and Chemical Corporation announced yesterday the election of John E. Bierwirth as chairman and Roy F. Coppedge Jr. as president.

Seeking a worthy successor to Tennessee Williams' "Garden District," the York Playhouse, Sixty-fourth Street and First Avenue, has chosen "The Golden Six." The author is Maxwell Anderson, a member of the Playwrights Company and the winner of a Pulitzer Prize as well as two awards from the Drama Critics Circle.

Mayor Wagner said yesterday that he was ready to cooperate with the United Nations and the Federal Government in any arrangements they might make to receive the heads of governments attending a summit conference here.

Member banks operated in the week ended Wednesday under the easiest reserve conditions in more than three and one-half years, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. On average, net free reserves increased $256,000,000 to $703,000,000, the highest level since Nov. 17, 1954.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) -- Federa Judge Richmond B. Keech refused today to order an immediate halt to United States nuclear tests in the Pacific.
DETROIT, July 24 -- Ryne Duren, hit on the left cheek by a pitch by Paul Foytack, was removed on a stretcher from Briggs Stadium and taken by ambulance to Detroit Memorial Hospital today.
GENEVA, July 24 -- The East-West conference of scientific experts reached agreement today on the method of detecting atomic explosions through recording of earth shock waves.
CHICAGO, July 24 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 24 (Canadian Press) -- The Detroit Boat Club took a big lead today in the Royal Henley regatta.
A salvage flotilla trying to raise the sunken tanker Empress Bay in the East River ran into difficulties late yesterday. And the tanker sank again.

The New York Stock Exchange has suspended trading in the stock of the Chile Copper Company and in the Class A stock of the Devoe Raynolds Company, Inc., effective Aug. 4. Application will be made to the Securities and Exchange Commission to delist the issues.

GENEVA, July 24 -- Henry J. Taylor, United States Ambassador to Switzerland, denied "categorically" today statements attributed to him in a United Press International article a week ago on espionage activities here.

The Chrysler Corporation reduced its loss in the second quarter to $10,100,000, from $15,100,000 in the first quarter. In the second quarter last year, the company earned $43,200,000 or $4.94 a share.

Louis Dejoie, Haitian industrialist and exiled opposition candidate for President, charged here yesterday that Haiti was going through one of the worst periods of "terrorism and oppression" in her history.

Roosevelt Hospital will benefit from the annual Ball of Roses, a dinner dance to be held on Jan. 8 in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza. The dance is given by the hospital's volunteer committee and board of trustees for the hospitals free card program.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) -- The House Labor Committee approved today a bill calling for a White House Conference on the Aging.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) -- The Federal Communications Commission refused today to allow the American Telephone Telegraph Company to increase rates for leased teleprinter services, used by the press, by an average 37 per cent.

B. Shackman Co., jobbers of toys and novelties, leased the store, mezzanine and basement at 2 West Thirty-fifth Street in the building known as 366 Fifth Avenue, southwest corner of Thirty-fifth Street. The company was established in 1898 and has been at 71 Madison Avenue near Twenty-seventh Street for many years.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) -- A House Banking sub-committee agreed today on a controversial bill calling for a vast expansion in the Federal Government's role in promoting construction of housing and classroom facilities.
LONDON, July 24 (AP) -- United States horsemen today captured the team event for the Prince of Wales Cup in the international horse show.

Sales and earnings of Standard Brands, Inc., for the quarter and six months ended June 30 exceeded those of last year, according to the report issued yesterday by Joel S. Mitchell, president. The company processes and distributes a diversified group of food products.

AN adventure, according to Webster's dictionary, is a bold enterprise involving risk. One of the more hazardous adventures -- from the standpoint of both purse and palate -- is that which the motoring vacationist faces when he must choose a place to stop for dinner.
A split has developed among leaders of the International Longshoremen's Association on the question of seniority for dock workers.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) -- The Justice Department has acceded to the Senate Judiciary Committee's request for documents that the department prepared during the school controversy in Little Rock, Ark., last fall.
A Brussels World's Fair motif will be carried out at the twelfth annual Turf Charity Ball and Carnival tomorrow in the clubhouse of the Monmouth Park Race Track, Oceanport, N. J.

UTICA, N. Y., July 24 (AP) -- Ray Billows played steady golf, but needed a sprinkling of luck as he advanced to the third round of the men's state amateur tournament at the Yahnundasis Country Club today.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 24 (AP) -- Returning travelers say Communists have come into open conflict with President Gamal Abdel Nasser's forces in Aleppo, Syria.
BONN, Germany, July 24 -- Paul-Henri Spaak, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, paid a hurried visit today to Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and returned to Paris after lunch.

Seven New York State savings and loan associations had assets in excess of $100,000,000, on June 30, the Savings Association League of New York State reported yesterday. Last year four associations were in this category.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Senate debated again today a farm bill that would take a long step toward scrapping the basic principle of farm programs over the last quarter of a century.

ON Thanksgiving Eve, 1939, a man later identified as Paul John Carbo was seen running down a Hollywood street, a little out of breath and puffing on a big cigar. Slumped over the wheel of a car parked near-by was Harry (Big Greenie) Green- berg, a local g@ngster.

WHITE PLAINS, July 24 -- The number of alcoholics in Westchester County was estimated today at 20,255. Of this number, said the County Council of Social Agencies, 5,050 have major physical and psychological handicaps from excessive drinking.

PARIS, July 24 -- Explaining their government's wish to terminate the present civil war agreement with the United States, French officials say this agreement favors American lines, penalizes Air France and is generally antiquated.

HAVANA, July 24 -- The truce declared by the Cuban Army to permit the rebels in the Sierra Maestra of Oriente Province to deliver wounded Cuban soldiers in their hands was extended through today, according to Col. Oscar Figarola, head of the Cuban Red Cross. This was to permit the rebels to deliver wounded civilians. The truce seems to cover only one area.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 24 -- Miss Charlotte De Cozen, Montclair, N. J., and Mrs. William Tracy, Essex Fells, the medalists, led the way into the semi-final round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association four-ball match play tournament with a 7-and-6 victory over Mrs. Allen Laden and Mrs. Philip Baris, Aldecress, at the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club today.
The National Association of Broadcasters has set Jan. 1, 1959, as the effective date for its new rule that bans the portrayal by actors of physicians, dentists and nurses in television commercials.
Times Square auctioneers gaveled away at the same old stands yesterday despite a warning from the city's Commissioner of Licenses that they faced the revocation of their permits.
STONY ISLAND, Lake Ontario, July 24 -- The following short passage in the life and loves of Mike Hudoba ought to be a lie, because good fishing lies are rarer than good fishing. But it is the truth.
IN MAKING blueprints for a wedding, no problem looms larger than choosing the most becoming wedding dress.

MOSCOW, July 24 (AP) -- Vladimir Kuts, Olympic 5,000 and 10,000 meter champion, was omitted from the thirty-eightman Soviet track and field team named today to face a picked American squad this week-end.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- Senator Beall announced that he intended now to revise his two bills into a single measure calling principally for truthful advertising by savings and loan associations.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- The Senate Finance Committee voted today for aid to the entertainment business through removal of the admission tax from the first $1 of the price of tickets.
Several groups in Reform Judaism declared yesterday that "an emerging public-school religion" had posed a serious threat to the principle of separation of church and state.

LENOX, Mass., July 25 -- This fourth week-end of the Berkshire Music Festival is to be the Russian-French one. That is, its programs are to be about equally divided between the composers of those two nations. The first of three bi-national programs tonight was led by Pierre Monteux. It attracted an audience of 6,437.
Corporate philosophies are being explored by more and more American companies.
Scale manufacturers have felt the weight of the recession but this has not hindered the industry in improving its products and extending their use.

In August of last year, Lord Altrincham, editor of The National and English Review, wrote an article in that publication suggesting that the British Monarchy could be improved to insure its permanence and that Queen Elizabeth, as its crown-bearer, left something to be desired.
CHICAGO, July 25 -- Sales and Earnings of the Brunswick-Balke - Collender Company, sports equipment manufacturer, set new records in the second quarter and first six months of this year.

FORTY million worried Americans tuned their television sets this week to a show that suddenly had become more popular and more important than "Gunsmoke" or "TwentyOne." The show was the emergency session of the United Nations Security Council on the Middle East crisis.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 25 -- The revolutionary government of Iraq is promising the people freedom, economic progress and social reform.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's letter to Premier Khrushchev on the summit meeting.
The eight-day international convention of the Jehovah's Witnesses will open tomorrow simultaneously at the Yankee Stadium and the Polo Grounds.
Activity in the new capital market will be almost at a standstill next week as underwriters prepare for a fairly heavy August schedule.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 25 -- Secretary General Dar Hammarskjold asked Lebanon's consent today to expand the functions of the United Nations Observation Group that has been trying to check border infiltration into Lebanon.
The contract bridge pair of Mrs. Lee Perly of Roslyn, L. I., and Leonard B. Harmon of New York City won the annual Brooklyn Open Pairs Championship last night.
DUBLIN, July 22 -- Irish Air Lines, which started trans-Atlantic operations nearly three months ago, is disappointed in the development of air cargo traffic.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 25 -- Pleasure craft moored off the Pequonnock Yacht Club here have been coated by fuel oil that was accidentally released from storage tanks of a near-by steel company.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- The development of nonskid eyeglass frames by one of its sergeants was reported today by the Walter Reed Army Medical Center.

The oil industry is seriously disturbed by the recent pair of contracts signed by two American companies with Yacimientos Petroliferos Fiscales, the Argentine Government-owned company. The new pacts could make it more difficult for companies operating concessions elsewhere abroad to continue the generally accepted fifty-fifty split in profits with the producing nations, since they substantially reduce the oil companies' return.
WESTBURY, L. I., July 25 -- Del Miller, one of the nation's leading harness racing drivers, returned to the line-up at Roosevelt Raceway last night. He drove in two races. He batted .500.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 25 -- The wind played a mean trick on Dick Sheehan, owner of the good ship Surf today. Just when it appeared that the Larchmont skipper might be on the way to an easy triumph among the Internationals, the breeze began to appear where he wasn't.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday filed "under protest" tariffs that would cout rates for private telephone networks by 15 per cent. The action was taken in compliance with a recent order of the Federal Communications Commission.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The Senate passed a farm bill tonight that carries the first major change in basic farm price support mechanism in a quarter of a century. The vote was 62 to 11.

CHICAGO, July 25 -- Mrs. A., a retired school teacher, 56 years of age, returned home from her husband's funeral one day at dusk. As she entered her house she met a strange woman in black. Mrs. A. turned on the light. The woman was wearing exactly the same clothes as Mrs. A, the same coat, the same hat, the same veil. Their hands appeared to meet.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 25 -- The United States, in an air and sea buildup, has increased its troops ashore in Lebanon to more than 10,000 as of tonight.

PORT DALHOUSIE, Ont., July 25 (Canadian Press) -- The Detroit Boat Club, with seven victories in the nine events it had entered in the four-day Royal Canadian Henley, built up a solid lead in the third-day program of the regatta today.
GENEVA, July 25 -- Western and Communist scientific delegations concluded the first major phase of their work today by agreeing on a fourth basic method for detecting atomic explosions.
