WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The Government's housing chief threatened today to recommend Presidential veto of the Democratic-sponsored housing bill now speeding through Congress.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- A plan for coordinated rail services between Binghamton and Gibson, N. Y., by which the Erie and Lackawanna Railroads expect to save more than $1,000,000 a year was approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission today.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI) -- Senator Homer E. Capehart, Republican of Indiana, demanded today an investigation of testimony by James Roosevelt, Democrat of California, before a Senate Banking subcommittee.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- President Eisenhower withdrew today his nomination of Bernard L. Flanagan, one-time Capital policeman, to be a member of the United States Civil Service Commission. The action had been requested by the nominee.

LIVINGSTON, N. J., July 25 -- Mrs. Rector Davol of Round Hill and her 17-year-old daughter, Gayle, successfully retained their Women's Metropolitan Golf Association mother-and-daughter championship today.
CHICAGO, July 25 (AP) -- Trading in grain futures was at a slow pace today, and in the absence of any commercial influences prices drifted steadily lower.
BEIRUT, July 25 -- The United States diplomatic position here has come under increasing fire since the marines landed and Robert Murphy arrived as President Eisenhower's special envoy.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad reported yesterday a deficit of $523,716 in June, in contrast with one of $45,650 in June last year.

I should like to clarify a confusion that occurred in President Eisenhower's July 2 press conference between the points of view of the United World Federalists and the Atlantic Union Committee. In a discussion of Grenville Clark's recently published book, "World Peace Through World Law," the President said, "* * * as a matter of fact, Justice Roberts was of the same group. * * *"

WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI) -- Lyndon B. Johnson, Senate Democratic Leader, bluntly told Neil H. McElroy, Secretary of Defense, today that "excellent" plans were no substitute in these critical times for bombs, missiles and satellites.
A wife's complaint to the Waterfront Commission that her longshoreman husband had not been bringing home his full pay led to the arrest yesterday of an alleged loan shark on the docks.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- President Eisenhower notified Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev today that the United States would not be limited in any United Nations summit conference to a discussion of United States-British intervention in Lebanon and Jordan.
BABY may need a new pair of shoes, but it is more fun to buy him a toy.

LOS ANGELES, July 25 (UPI)--Zora Folley blasted Pete Rademacher's dream of getting another title fight tonight by flooring him four times for a knockout at 1:15 of the fourth round. That was two rounds faster than the heavy-weight champion, Floyd Patterson, turned the trick last August.

LONDON, July 25 -- Britain's reply to the Soviet proposal for a summit meeting in the Security Council of the United Nations will be sent to Moscow over the week-end, possibly tomorrow, officials said today.
The bridges that span the East River were treated yesterday to the closest view they are likely to have of their baby sister.
A Polish seaman seeking political asylum in the United States has been seized here by Immigration officials and returned to his ship.
James F. Macandrew has been named director of the State Education Department's new television project in New York City.
Chance Vought Aircraft, in the first six months this year showed a sharp increase in sales and earnings over those of the similar period a year ago, according to the report issued yesterday.
A private industry has agreed to supply a place to pour rain water that periodically makes a "flood bowl" of Union Turnpike and Langdale Street on the city line in Bellerose, Queens.

MILWAUKEE, July 25 (UPI) -- Milwaukee added a half-game to its National League lead tonight by splitting a double-header with the Chicago Cubs. The Braves won the second game, 4-1, after losing the first, 5-4.

The National Association of Broadcasters is to be congratulated on its clear-cut and decisive action to take the phony doctors and nurses out of the TV commercials. After January next it will no longer be possible for any actor or announcer to put on a white coat and pose as "science." The new rulings in the code are unequivocal. The broadcasters are honestly trying to clean up a bad situation.
An apparent breakdown of negotiations with the Todd Shipyards Corporation was reported yesterday by the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The wholesale price index of average primary market prices was unchanged at 119.3 per cent of its 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 25 -- Eight nations have given conditional promises to contribute more than $29,000,000 to the special United Nations fund for economic aid to under-developed countries, it was announced today.
Sharply reduced sales and earnings in the first half prompted directors of the Budd Company yesterday to reduce the quarterly dividend from 35 to 25 cents. The dividend is payable Sept. 6.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 25 (AP) -- The rocket carrier of Sputnik III will be visible tomorrow, Sunday and Monday in the United States, the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory said tonight.
WESTPORT, Conn., July 25 -- The State Police began a campaign on the Merritt Parkway today against motorists who throw paper and other refuse from their cars.
JUNEAU, Alaska, July 25 (AP) -- Gov. Mike Stepovich announced today he would seek the Republican nomination for "Term B" of the United States Senate from the fledgling state of Alaska.
The attempt to salvage the sunken tanker Empress Bay developed into a race against time yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- William Lewis Uanna had charge of security of Oak Ridge, Tenn., where the atomic bomb was produced, during 1943-44. Within a few weeks he may have charge of the security of Soviet Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev.

LONDON, July 25 (UPI) -- George Hobbs of Britain, riding Royal Lord, won the White City Stadium Cup at the Royal International Horse Show today. George Morris of New Canaan, Conn., riding Sinjon, took fourth place.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The State Department had to take time out in the Middle Eastern crisis today while it cleaned up a smaller one in middle Europe.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- Senator Olin D. Johnston, Democrat of South Carolina, said today that the Government was preparing to sell apartments at Gaffney, S. C., with a mortgage value of $426,000, for $43,000.

RALEIGH, N. C., July 25 -- The state Democratic Executive Committee nominated Senator B. Everett Jordan, today as the party's candidate for the remaining two years of the term he now is serving in the United States Senate.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI) -- The Senate Armed Services Committee trimmed about $14,000,000 today from a House-approved bill to authorize $1,644,652,000 for new military construction.

A significant stride in combating traffic tie-ups has been taken by Commissioner Wiley with his plan to control signal lights from Traffic Department headquarters. The initial installation will be in eastern Queens, along the six-mile stretch of Hillside Avenue from Van Wyck Expressway to the Nassau County line, with all arterial routes in the city to be brought into the system as funds permit.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 6 to 70 points yesterday, with the far months weakest. A point is 5 cents a bale.

A specter that has been putting in an appearance more or less regularly every year now since 1953 is again back to haunt the Administration. That is the problem of keeping the public debt within the debt ceiling -- a problem that will be additionally complicated in the present fiscal year at least by the prospect of a very substantial budget deficit.
A windfall for lovers of printing type has been announced by the New York Public Library -- in a broadside done in about 100 different type faces.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy said yesterday that a summit meeting here would provide an opportunity to demonstrate the impartiality and efficiency of a democratic police department.
TEHERAN, Iran, July 24 -- A high Iranian official today invited the Kurdish minorities of Iraq and Syria to regard Iran as their "motherland."
COCOA BEACH, Fla., July 25 -- The search for Wickie, the mouse in the nose cone of a two-stage intercontinental rocket, was called off this afternoon.
ROME, July 25 -- Informed Western sources in Jordan give King Hussein only about a fifty-fifty chance of keeping his throne more than six months without all-out Western support.
CHICAGO, July 25 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas signed an order in Washington yesterday continuing bail for Frank Costello. This apparently means an end to the Government's effort at this time to return the gambler to prison for the remaining four years of an unexpired term for tax evasion.

A surface finish of the highest accuracy has been achieved on a hypersonic wind tunnel being put through its final stages at the plant of the R. H. Freitag Manufacturing Company in Akron, Ohio. Hypersonic is approximately five times the speed of sound.

Enough things happened at Jamaica yesterday to cause many of the 19,487 fans to exclaim in wonderment "What next?" There was a double disqualification. There was a runaway. There were refunds and there was the New York season's highest win payoff.

The shopping center containing thirteen stores at 114-12 to 114-34 Merrick Boulevard, near Linden Boulevard, in St. Albans, Queens, has been sold by the Berelar Realty Company. It fronts 259 feet on Merrick Boulevard and is 200 feet deep, extending back to 170th Street.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI) -- The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to increase Federal subsidies for needy persons on state-operated relief rolls at an annual cost of about $280,000,000.

WASHINGTON July 25 (UPI) -- Senator Warren G. Magnuson, Democrat of Washington, said today that he was investigating a Soviet proposal for Soviet-United States construction of a rail and automobile tunnel beneath the Bering Strait to ling Alaska and Russian Siberia.
BAYREUTH, Germany, July 25 -- A revolution in the staging of Wagner at Bayreuth was proclaimed in 1951 with "Parsifal," the first production of the first post-war festival.

Earlier this week it seemed as though Premier Khrushchev were winning on points in the battle of words which is preceding an expected summit conference. Yesterday President Eisenhower, obviously in cooperation with Secretary Dulles, won back some of the lost ground.

WASHINGTON, July 25--The Securities and Exchange Commission announced tonight it had adopted a code of ethics that instructs members to reject any efforts by the White House or Congress to influence their actions.

The Hamilton Watch Company of Lancaster, Pa., plans to buy or build an assembly plant in Switzerland, it was revealed yesterday by Arthur B. Sinkler, chairman and president. It would be the first American subsidiary to be set up to make watches in Switzerland in more than twenty-five years.
A half-acre plaza in front of the new thirty-eight-story Seagram Building at 375 Park Avenue has become an oasis for office workers and passers-by.
Speculative fever brought new records to the stock market yesterday.
JERSEY CITY, July 25--Continuing its announced drive to reduce operating expenses of the school system by $1,000,000, the Board of Education last night dropped forty more non-teaching employes.
The final week of Stadium Symphony Orchestra concerts, July 20 to Aug. 2, will present a young American conductor, Samuel Matlovsky, in his Lewisohn Stadium debut.
An arbitrator ruled yesterday that the New York Telephone Company could not require employes in a lower job classification to do the work of those in higher groups.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- Spokesmen for minerals producers are expected to urge the Senate Appropriations Committee next week to restore part of the $5,786,000 cut made by the House in the Atomic Energy Commission's raw materials program.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. announced yesterday the suspension of Lieut. Edwin F. Kass on a charge of stealing about $400 from firehouses.

OF ALL the furniture styles revived for today's home, Shaker seems, at first glance, to be the least likely to succeed. This style is illustrated in the authentic period settings that will go on view next Saturday at the Shaker Museum, Old Chatham, N. Y.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 25 -- In an onslaught of thundering services. Barry MacKay yielded two 12-10 sets to Ronald Holmberg and still survived to gain the final round of the Pennsylvania lawn tennis championship today.
Fourteen persons, including twelve firemen, were treated for injuries yesterday in a fire that virtually destroyed a four-story tenement building in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.

PARIS, July 25 -- The French appeared today to be moderating their objections to a summit meeting in New York on the strength of assurances of great flexibility of procedure to provide the tranquil atmosphere they desire.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI) -- The number of unemployed workers on the jobless benefit rolls rose by 36,500 last week to a total of 2,625,400, the Labor Department reported today.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 25 -- Another Turkish Cypriote was slain today and a second was seriously wounded as violence flared again on this unhappy island.
A Pan American World Airways Clipper, crippled at sea, made a safe landing at Argentia, Nfld., shortly after last midnight.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- Representative Peter F. Mack Jr., Democrat of Illinois, today accused the Lincoln Sesquicentennial Commission of extravagance in spending $15,713 to furnish and equip its offices here.

NEW JERSEY will hold a public hearing on proposed regulations for the 1958 upland hunting season and there almost certainly will be representatives of hunters present to oppose most of them, particularly the dates.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- The Department of Interior asked today for bids by Sept. 3 for leasing of about 16,000 acres of public lands in the Gubik gas field in North Central Alaska.

OTTAWA, July 25--The Canadian Government proposed the neutralization of Lebanon and possibly the whole of the Middle East under the United Nations today as a means to a political solution of tensions in the area.

CLEVELAND, July 25 -- To the red-hot Yankees, all pitchers look alike these days and nights. It was, therefore, no great surprise that the league leaders racked up the Indians' Ray Narleski in seven innings and blanked the Tribe, 6 -- 0, at Municipal Stadium tonight.
ANKARA, Turkey, July 25 -- A Turkish Foreign Ministry spokesman said yesterday it was "unbelievable" that Turkey would take any unilateral military action in the present Middle East turmoil.

DURING the summer months, many requests arrive for information about refreezing of foods that have thawed. In general, this practice is not a good idea. Once thawed, frozen food deteriorates rapidly and it may be harmful.
LONDON, July 25--Prices continued to rise on the Stock Exchange today with many quotations returning to the levels held before the Iraqi coup.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Secretary of State Dulles left by air for Bonn and London late this afternoon for three days of intensive talks prior to the prospective summit meet ing at the United Nations on the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- In certain respects the most important statesman Dulles will meet during his current leap to Europe is Adnan Menderes, the suave Premier of Turkey. Menderes is going to London for a conference of the disintegrating Baghdad Pact.

LONDON, July 25 (Reuters) -- England's opening batsmen excelled today and at the close of play on the second day of the five-day cricket test match at Manchester the hosts had scored 192 runs for the loss of two wickets.

PARIS, July 25 -- Negotiations for a free-trade area embracing seventeen European nations have been saved from a breakdown by three days of discussion that ended here tonight. The talks had been virtually deadlocked for six months.
OCEANPORT, N. J., July 25 -- "It was a greater thrill than winning the Kentucky Derby."
LONDON, July 25 -- A live type of American anti-polio virus has been given a mass test among the natives of central Africa. Nearly 250,000 doses have been given by mouth.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The chief of the State Department's Division of Physical Security will go to New York Monday to confer with police officials on arrangements to guard delegates to the proposed summit meeting at the United Nations.
State Senator Walter J. Mahoney of Buffalo spurted into second place yesterday in the race for the Republican nomination for Governor.
IT is generally assumed that sun glasses are a fairly recent innovation. Actually, they have been worn for many centuries.
The Government has picked the steamship line that will operate the world's first nuclear-powered liner.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The Patent Office, which has recorded instruments for measuring almost everything else, recorded one for measuring extrasensory perception this week.

HAVANA, July 25 -- President Fulgencia Batista said today that the Cuban Government was fully prepared for any outbreaks by revolutionary elements tomorrow, anniversary of the 1953 revolt from which the 26th of July Movement of Fidel Castro, rebel leader, takes its name.
Plans to move a paper mill from Ausable Forks, N. Y., where it has been operating for sixty-five years, to Valencia, Venezuela, are being held in abeyance.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission barred United States brokers today from handling shares of Canadian Javelin, Ltd., a stock actively traded in the over-the-counter market. Canadian Javelin was placed on what the S. E. C. calls its Canadian restricted list.

Two five-story apartment buildings at 14 and 24 Thayer Street in the Dyckman area of upper Manhattan have been sold by the Iceland Realty Corporation, E. Charles Iceland, president. They contain eighty apartments and occupy a plot 200 by 90 feet.
DAYTON, Ohio, July 25 (AP) -- Donald Knee, an active 13-year-old boy, complained of a bump on the back of his head last Sunday. His parents applied an ice pack and the swelling seemed to go away.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 25 -- A Western source predicted tonight that the Security Council would meet within a week or ten days to carry out President Eisenhower's plan for arranging a summit meeting.

Referring to the recent item in your news columns concerning proposed legislation providing that the United States Government return enemy assets seized in World War II and held in lieu of reparations, this proposal should be defeated for both moral and legal reasons.

IF the translators of P. G. Wodehouse are on their toes, as usual, they may have something to contribute to the next summit conference. They may have ready, in a dozen languages, the text of his funniest novel in years, "Cocktail Time,"* to help relax international tensions.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI) -- The Defense Department confirmed today that the United States had arranged to use the University of Manchester's huge Jodrell bank radio telescope, largest in the free world, for tracking purposes in "various satellite programs."

CARDIFF, Wales, July 25 (AP) -- Australia's swimmers shattered one world record and three games records tonight in the sixth British Empire and Commonwealth Games. A team of British girls beat them once, but it took a world-record performance to do it.
DALLAS, July 25 -- Several times an hour today telephones rang at The Dallas Morning News with queries from citizens whether they could vote tomormor in both Democratic and Republican primaries.

PARKSVILLE, N. Y., July 25 -- Another link in the state's expanding network of expressways was opened today with ceremonies in this Catskill village. Governor Harriman formally dedicated the eight-mile section of Route 17 that carries the four-lane limited-access highway around the village of Liberty.
The Clamor in the Dell is over. The Armistice of Lewisohn Stadium will be celebrated tonight.
Guest preachers from this country and abroad will be heard at 11 A. M. in New York pulpits tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The Treasury revealed today that it had suffered a 29 per cent "attrition" on the privately held portion of its recent $16,000,000,000 financing, despite massive help from the Federal Reserve System. That is, investors holding nearly a third of the maturing securities chose cash in preference to new securities.

Summer is the time for wearing old clothes, and lucky is the man who has some. Summer is the time for frayed shirts and for pants that are out at the knees and considerably patched behind. It is the time for old jackets, for tattered dungarees and for hats looking as though they had been run over by heavy road-building equipment.

The Texas Company estimated yesterday consolidated net income at $138,535,542, or $2.37 a share, in the six months ended June 30. In the similar period last year, the company reported a net income of $165,145,982, or $3.01 a share.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 25 -- A former British Foreign Secretary today led the West's counter-offensive against the Soviet Union as the forty-seventh annual conference of the Interparliamentary Union here became a bitter "cold war" debating forum.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 25 -- Rebel leader Saeb Salaam said today the rebels would not permit Presidential elections to be held as long as President Camille Chamoun was in power and foreign troops were in Lebanon.
Commodity prices closed irregularly after generally dull trading on New York exchanges yesterday.

School superintendents from twenty-six states who have been in conference for three weeks at Teachers College, Columbia University, ended their meeting yesterday with a plea for more emphasis on actual education and less on buildings.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 25 -- Samuel Fuller, writer-director-producer, has contracted to make four pictures for Columbia through his independent company, Globe Enterprises, Inc.
The International Rescue Committee will benefit from a fashion show and luncheon to be held Oct. 7 at the Astor.
BUENOS AIRES, July 25 -- The Government moved toward general exchange reform this week by offering new export rates to foreign meat packers.
UTICA, N. Y., July 25 (AP) -- Johnny Snyder of Troy defeated the seven-time champion, Ray Billows, by 2 up today in the biggest upset so far in the 1958 State amateur golf tournament.

President Chamoun of Lebanon may be somewhat optimistic in the hope that the American troops he invited to his country will be leaving in another month; but the deputy American representative to the United Nations yesterday was able to back up this view to the extent of saying -- without giving a precise date -- that he thought they might be departing quite soon.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., July 25 (AP) -- Mayor Samuel S. Stratton asked the Federal Communications Commission today to force a local television station to sell him time for a political broadcast.
MOSCOW, July 25 (UPI) -- The Soviet Union has accused Turkey of planning to attack Iraq "in a few days' time" and has sharply warned the Turks against taking such action, it was disclosed today.
MASERU, Basutoland, July 25 -- Proposals for granting a measure of representative government to the Basutos were made in a report submitted to the Basutoland National Council today.
LIMA, Peru, July 25 -- The Peruvian Navy, through its Naval Industrial Service, will launch tomorrow what is said to be the largest vessel ever built on the West Coast of South America.
NEW DELHI, India, July 25 -- An American-designed device put to work today may revolutionize the life of rural India.

PITTSBURGH, July 25 (UPI) -- The Pirates racked up their fourth straight on Curt Raydon's four-hit, 10-0 victory over the San Francisco Giants tonight. The largest crowd at a night game here this season -- 30,545 -- was present.
ELMSFORD, N. Y., July 25 -- Forty-four-year-old Fred Annon of Ryewood, who says he is driving the ball farther than ever, recaptured the Westchester open golf championship today.
Four Times Square auctioneers were summoned yesterday by the city's Commissioner of Licenses to appear for a hearing on whether their licenses should be revoked.
A 5-year-old Bronx boy may lose the sight of his right eye as a result of having been struck in the face with a belt buckle during a street fight among three men.
PARIS, Saturday, July 26 -- A strengthening of executive power and consequent weakening of legislative power will be characteristics of France's Fifth Republic, on paper at least.
MOSCOW, July 25 (AP) -- Edouard Streltsov, until last month the idol of Soviet soccer fans, has been sentenced to twelve years in jail for rape.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- The United States told the Soviet Union again today that the current scientific talks in Geneva could speed the actual suspension of nuclear tests only if the major powers later agreed to take such action.

BONN, Germany, July 26--Secretary of State Dulles visited Bonn this afternoon en route to London in an effort to dispel misunderstandings that have arisen over United States and British policies and troop landings in the Middle East.

" CATCH Up With Britain," which contains the boast "We can catch up with Britain if we try -- before 1962" and which has a chorus "Hey! Hey! Hey!!!" at the end of each line, is the most popular song in China this summer. Millions of people from all walks of life have learned it from Peiping Radio's Sunday morning "New Song Hour," the program believed to have the biggest audience in the country.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., July 26 -- Larchmont Yacht Club's sixtieth annual Race Week ended today. Because of "just protests" today's races in eight division were thrown out and titles went to skippers who led the standings yesterday.

WHEN English names were bestowed upon vegetables, few fared more poorly than that unusual product of August gardens, the eggplant. Although its name derives from certain tropical varieties which are small and white, the product as we know it bears no more resemblance to an egg than a grapefruit does to a grape.
WHEN asbestos-cement shingles were first introduced some years ago, much of their appeal to homeowners appeared to be their excellent weather resistance that would not require painting.
MILWAUKEE, July 26 -- The Chicago Cubs, backed by the relief pitching of Marcelino Solis, beat the Milwaukee Braves, 7 -- 4, today. Solis hurled four-hit, shutout ball for six and two-third innings.
DRIVING a car to the West Coast and back is not exactly my idea of a vacation these days. But it seemed like a good idea last month.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 26 -- A twenty-eight-acre island within sight of New York City's skyline is serving as a camping ground these summer days for the Greenwich Young Men's Christian Association.
WALTER BRENNAN appears to possess many of the qualities of that irascible but genial old billy goat, Grandpa McCoy, the fictional West Virginian he portrays in "The Real McCoys."
WESTBURY, L. I., July 26 -- O'Brien Hanover completed a clean sweep of Roosevelt Raceway's pacing stakes for 3-year-olds by winning the $25,000 Governor's Cup tonight.

ABOUT the year of the foundation of Jamestown, it seems that some English voyager entered into a broad bay and sailed northward a few miles to where it narrowed and was like a river mouth. He learned some names from the Indians, and on the map which he drew up, he wrote Mannahata to the west of the river mouth and Manahatin to the east.

LAKE PLEASANT, N. Y. -- The irrepressibly optimistic vacationist who still seeks that mythical "perfect playground" may find this beautiful section of the Adirondack Mountains comes close to satisfying his dream. Certainly it is as peaceful and private a spot as can be found within one day's drive of New York City.

CARDIFF, Wales, July 26 -- Herb Elliott of Australia bettered the four-minute mile today for a record seventh time. He overcame a strong wind and a spike wound to win the British Empire Games mile in 3 minutes 59 seconds.

THIS is wonderful country for growing roses, a rosarian's dream come true. Days are warm and sunny, nights are comfortably cool. The rainfall is plentiful and the soil deep and fertile. Rosebushes respond with tremendous vigor. The flower colors are clear and bright.

LOS ANGELES, July 26 -- Those who knew Harry M. Warner, pioneer motion-picture executive who died last night, will gather tomorrow to pay their final respects.

STANTON, Del., July 26 -- Endine, an 11-1 shot, held gamely in the stretch today to take the $160,562 Delaware Handicap for the Christiana Stables. She won by a nose from King Ranch's Dotted Line.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Nearly 200 field parties of the United States Geological Survey are collecting and interpreting data from a wide variety of geologic and geographic environments, the Department of Interior announced today.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 26 -- Although voting in the Arkansas Democratic primary does not take place until Tuesday, all indications are that the outcome of the gubernatorial election was decided last September on the grounds of Central High School.

ROME, July 26 -- Italy is impressed by the military power the United States is displaying in the Middle East, but not by the performance of its diplomacy there. Soviet maneuvering is regarded here as being extremely astute.

SALZBURG, Austria -- Visitors arriving here for the annual music festival which began a five-week run yesterday may find few changes in the scenery of the classic operas presented, but they will come upon many in the city's surrounding landscape.

THE three television networks, which encountered a tough selling season last summer, are finding the job of peddling air time even more difficult this summer. As of the middle of last week, the networks had a total of fourteen hours weekly of unsold prime evening time for the 1958-59 season.

CHICAGO -- New devices and materials designed to further mechanize the processing of color prints, together with the photographer's increasing awareness of color, dominated the sixty-seventh annual National Convention and Photographic Trade Show held here last week by the Professional Photographers of America, Inc.

The British crown colony of Cyprus last week was in the grip of the most serious wave of terror in the four-year history of struggle on the island. The program will be diversified, extensive and while mostly of a technical nature from the amateur's view-point, will offer several talks on photographic esthetics.

The sphinx moths are busy over the flower gardens these late July evenings. Some call them hawk moths and others know them as hummingbird moths. They may be mistaken for hummingbirds in the dusk, for at a glance they seem about the same size and they haunt the deep-throated flowers, the petunias, the bergamots, all the trumpet flowers much as does the daytime hummer.

Malcolm MacDonald, son of the late Prime Minister, has spent most of his time since World War II in Southeast Asia; he speaks with higher authority than any other Westerner of the people who live there, their conditions and problems.
A record wheat surplus seems inevitable. This stems from the second-largest crop on record now being harvested and a small drop in the surplus in the last three years when crops were much smaller.

THIS is the time of year which fair fanciers like best of all -- the state fair season. Leading the procession once again is North Dakota with a six-day exposition at Minot beginning tomorrow. Also, as has become customary, Arizona will close the 1958 season with its fair at Phoenix, Oct. 31-Nov. 11.

At this time of year throughout Europe hotels and pensions are entertaining tourists who had long ago made preparation for this summer visit. Many of the travelers are exceedingly industrious sight-seers.

GAEVLE, Sweden, July 26 (UPI) -- Ulf Bertil Lundh of Norway won the mile run in 4:05 tonight on a heavy track in an international track and field meet. Don Bowden of California finished third in 4:12.
Leonard W. Hall said yesterday that he had found that the "exaggerated" claims of delegate strength being made by some supporters of Nelson A. Rockefeller had given rise to resentment and disbelief.

DETROIT, July 26 (AP) -- Swoon's Son staged a brilliant stretch drive today and won the $50,000-added Michigan Sweepstakes, wiping out the memory of last Saturday's surprise defeat by a longshot, Nearctic.
Dr. Kwame Nkrumah, Prime Minister of Ghana, came to New York last night for a three-day visit after talks with President Eisenhower and Secretary of State John Foster Dulles in Washington.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- During the debate on the recession this year there were occasional Republican charges that only the Korean War saved the Truman Administration from the recession of 1948-49.
The scheduled maiden arrival here on Tuesday of the Hamburg-Atlantic Line's Hanseatic is almost certain to touch off again the age-old ship question: How big is big?
RIO de JANEIRO, July 26 -- Krupp, the German steel company, has come back to Brazil with a project bigger, better and more welcome than the one rejected last year.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said today that boron was the strategic commodity most often diverted to Communist countries in violation of the Export Control Law.
Department store executives] in the New York metropolitan area estimated that sales last] week were 3 to 6 per cent above volume for the similar week of last year.

GENEVA, July 25 -- Four weeks ago scientists from East and West set about to find a "common language" for their views on policing any ban on nuclear weapons tests. Progress in the talks has been due partly to skilled interpreters struggling with the mysteries of modern science.
MOSCOW, July 26 (Reuters) -- The Moscow City Soviet opened a drive against drunks and noisemakers.

PITTSBURGH, July 26 -- Johnny Antonelli and Marv Grissom of the San Francisco Giants shut out the Pittsburgh Pirates, 1 -- 0, today. The winners, blanked themselves in their last two games, ended their famine in the third inning when they scored.

TO turn from O'Connell Street in Dublin down the banks of the River Liffey is to step backward in time. Cobbled roads, horses, barges, bewigged lawyers, treacherous steps to poky shops -- all much as they were when Jonathan Swift wrote "Gulliver's Travels."

PARIS -- Midsummer visitors to Paris can expect to find this city long on some tourist facilities but startlingly short on others. This is the time of year when the neighborhood butcher, baker and blousemaker pack up, hang a Fermeture Annuelle sign on the door of their establishments and disappear for a month or more with nary a thought for prospective customers.

MOSCOW, July 26 (UPI) -- Soviet explorers today reported a temperature of minus 83 degrees Centigrade (minus 117 degrees Fahrenheit) at a post in the Antarctic. This would be the lowest temperature ever recorded anywhere in the world.
AMMAN, Jordan, July 24 -- The 2,000 British paratroopers guarding the National Airport here are the core of the fastest-moving combat outfit in the British Army.

IPSWICH, Mass. -- Sun bonnets and silver-buckle hat will hide broken-bottle coiffures and crew cuts in this Essex County coastal town on Saturday, Aug. 9, during the seven-hour, biennial observance of Seventeenth Century Day.

THIS is the fourth link in the chain of novels to which Anthony Powell has given the title "The Music of Time." I believe admirers of Mr. Powell, whose sense of comedy and satire has been compared with that of Max Beerbohm and Evelyn Waugh, should be prepared for a disappointment: they may find this latest volume considerably less funny, more wordy and confusing, than "A Buyer's Market" and "The Acceptance World."

CAIRO, July 26 -- The tension in President Nasser's United Arab Republic began to subside this week from the peak of nuclear war jitters that had arisen over Western to the Iraqi revolution. There were clear signs that the Cairo Government was becoming more and more convinced that the United States and Britain were not planning an attack on the new pro-Nasser regime that had overthrown the monarchy in Baghdad.

LISBON, Portugal, July 26 (AP) -- The passengers and crew of an airliner that developed engine trouble over the North Atlantic last night reached here in a replacement plane tonight, hours behind schedule.

There were clear signs that the Cairo Government was becoming more and more convinced that the United States and Britain were not planning an attack on the new pro-Nasser regime that had overthrown the monarchy in Baghdad.

CHICAGO, July 26 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox, paced by the slugging of Sherm Lollar, J im Rivera and Jim Landis, defeated previously unbeaten Boston right-hander, Ike Delock, today and rolled to an 11-6 victory behind a fifteen-hit attack.
The Association for the Help of Retarded Children, Inc., will benefit from a gala fete on the night of Oct. 9 at Yonkers Raceway.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 26 (AP) -- The Army's newest satellite probably will never be visible to the unaided eye.
MANAMAH, Bahrein, July 26 (Reuters) -- Britain has promised more military aid to the Sultan of Muscat and Oman to help him crush his arch rival, the Imam of Oman, informed sources said here today.

TO many white Americans, adult as well as juvenile, the Indian is a storybook figure, known chiefly through the movies and school projects. Today, however, tribesmen are voting, working in industries and calling from their reservations for settlement of claims and a Point Four program.

Municipal officials and private parties now industriously grinding an axe for more movie production in Our Town are about to be joined by a dedicated team with what they feel is a new approach. The men involved are Martin Poll, president of the flourishing Gold Medal Studios in the Bronx. and Saint Subber, co-producer of such Broadway hits as "The Dark at the Top of the Stairs" and "Kiss Me, Kate."
Two weeks ago the world appeared to have come to a grave crisis over the Middle East. There was acute fear that World War III might be at hand.

HOUN OHARA, a famous headmaster of Japanese flower arranging, will demonstrate his art at 2 P. M. on Wednesday and Thursday at B. Altman Co., Fifth Avenue. Mr. Ohara's appearance -- his first in this country -- is sponsored by Ikebana International.

Cotton prices moved almost continuously downward last week, reversing the trend of previous weeks.

RABAUL, New Britain, July 27 (UPI) -- An American Army physician said today that there was no evidence of radiation sickness among the crew of the Japanese Coast Guard vessel Takuyo Maru, which ran into a fall-out from United States nuclear tests in the Pacific two weeks ago.

Jose errer's next Broadway venture will be "Edwin Booth." Last represented here as co-author and director of "Oh Captain!," Mr. Ferrer will be involved in the new offering as star, director and co-producer. His partner in the presentation of the biographical drama by Milton Geiger, a scenarist, will be the Playwrights Company, with which he had a profitable association as director of "The Fourposter."
Smith-Corona Marchant, Inc. plans to purchase British Typewriters, Ltd., of West Bromwich, England, subject to approval of the latter's shareholders.
TEL AVIV, Israel, July 27 -- Israeli diplomats have been instructed to seek Western support for a front of non-Arab states in the Middle East.
The dismay that steals over a man occasionally to realize he will not be tapped for one of the year's Ten Best Dressed may console itself with a fiercely guarded pile of old clothes.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 27 -- Few dollars have trickled into Lebanon from the pockets of the 10,000 United States troops ashore here.

RYE, N. Y., July 27 -- A fleet of twenty-six cruising yachts headed from Scotch Caps shortly after noon today in the face of a ten-knot easterly on an overnight race that is the first leg of the American Yacht Club's twenty-seventh annual cruise

I have just read the letter published July 19 from Whitney North Seymour Jr., in which he expresses surprise and dismay at what he terms "the absence of a single patriotic event scheduled in Manhattan last July Fourth."

The tides of political change appear to be running strong in Manhattan's Seventeenth Congressional District. To stem the flow, the Republicans in the district have entrusted their future to vigorous young hands.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 27 -- Barry MacKay plodded off the muddy spike-torn turf of the Merion Cricket Club this evening, the winner of the Pennsylvania tennis championship after saving seven match points in a three-hour battle with Alejandro Olmedo. The score was 6 -- 8, 6 -- 4, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 14 -- 12.

NEW DELHI, India, July 27 -- The ruling Congress party and the Central Government in New Delhi fear that the Communist regime in Kerala State is trying systematically to destroy the democratic process through which it came to power.
STAMFORD, Conn., July 27 -- A warning to municipal planners to keep hands off public and recreation areas was sounded today by the Connecticut Society of Public Park Administrators.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) -- The Immigration Commissioner, Joseph M. Swing, said today that a drive on foreign sailors who jumped ship in United States ports had caused a 34 per cent increase in the number of deportations last year.
A 62-year-old woman, employed as a part-time kitchen helper, was smothered to death last night in a psychiatric ward at Bellevue Hospital.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- The Surgeon General of the Public Health Service urged anew today that all Americans under 40 years old receive Salk vaccine inoculations against poliomyelitis.

Net assets of the 169 members of the National Association of Investment Companies reached $11,983,705,000 on June 30, the association reported over the week-end. The investment companies had a record 3,671,285 shareholder accounts.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 27 -- James B. Moore Jr.'s Lure led the Resolute Class fleet home today in the Manhasset Bay interclub championship sailing series, defeating G. Seymour's Mutiny by more than a minute.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 26 -- Nicaragua is facing her first labor crisis since the Somoza family began its dynastic control of the country in 1934.

THE hodgepodge of wares stacked in the aisles, piled on counters and even hanging from the ceiling makes the Trinacria Importing Company seem, at first glance, like an old-fashioned country store. But closer inspection of the shop -- it is at 415 Third Avenue, corner of Twenty-eighth Street -- reveals that most every item is imported and that most would not have been found in a rural emporium here.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- The Defense Department has assured a House committee it is not tightening secrecy screws on news because of the Mideast crisis.

AMMAN, Jordan, July 27 (AP) -- A Jordanian army patrol clashed with a band of eight infiltrators near the Syrian border today and captured them, an army spokesman said. One of the captured men was wounded; no mention was made of any Jordanian casualties.
Mike Wallace's interview series, which appeared to have gone into limbo last week, has been renewed for six weeks under the continuing auspices of the Fund for the Republic.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., July 27 -- The rap of a carpenter's hammer resounding through the Sycamore Groves at the former Margery Post Estate here is signaling the start of the largest expansion program in the four-year history of C. W. Post College.
NEW DELHI, India, July 27 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said in Calcutta today that "all elements of explosion" still remained in the Middle East although the situation had eased somewhat.
Paving and grading work will get under way this week on a 3,500-foot section of the long delayed Brooklyn-Queens Expressway in central Queens.
MOSCOW, July 27 (AP) -- George Eastment, coach of the United States track team, exhorted his athletes before the start of competition against the Russians today to do their utmost for their country.
A Bronx woman was arrested in Queens yesterday and accused of passing a forged winning bingo card supplied to her by a ring of fast-working counterfeiters.
THE Society to Withhold Summer Theatre Programs From Young Wives Until After the Conclusion of the Performance is an organization with a certain singleness of purpose.

COCOA BEACH, Fla., July 25 -- The first woman engineer to work on the Thor Intermediate Range Ballistic Missile program -- and one of the first women to work on any missile project at near-by Cape Canaveral -- has just finished a three-week tour of duty there.
Long - range detection and tracking of aircraft and missiles have been made possible by new developments in radar and in supporting equipment.
American Airlines indicated yesterday it would not require flight engineers on its jet airplanes to be qualified pilots.

GETTYSBURG, Pa, July 27 (AP) -- President Eisenhower heard a prayer tody for God's guidance for himself, his Secretary of State and the United Nations Security Council in their effort to bring peace of world crisis.

PHILADELPHIA, July 27 (AP) -- Willie Jones hit two homers, Carl Sawatski hit one and Solly Hemus added two triples today as the Philadelphia Phillies laced the Los Angeles Dodgers, 7 -- 4, to open a double-header.

The Protestant Big Sisters will benefit from the Dec. 19 performance of the play "Tall Story," which is expected to open here in November. Tickets may be obtained from Miss Fanshawe at 136 East Sixty-fourth Street.

PARIS, July 27 -- France's monetary reserves now are $775,000,000. This total consists of $575,000,000 represented by gold holdings in the Bank of France and $200,000,000 in reserves in the exchange stabilization fund.
CLEVELAND, July 27 -- Not even Casey Stengel expects to win 'em all, but a double setback of his Yankees by the Indians today at Municipal Stadium annoyed him considerably.

BALTIMORE, July 27 (AP) -- Art Wall Jr. of Pocono Manor, Pa., birdied the first extra hole today for a sudden death play-off victory against Jack Burke and Bob Rosburg in the Eastern open golf tournament.
GENEVA, July 27 -- Despite Soviet insistence on an end of all nuclear tests, some Communist scientists at the East-West technical talks here are privately conceding that more tests may be necessary.

PITTSBURGH, July 27 (AP) -- Dick Groat hit a bases-loaded sacrifice fly in the fourteenth inning today to provide the Pittsburgh Pirates with a 2-1 victory over the San Francisco Giants in the opener of a double-header.

The first of six meetings to plan a state platform for the Democratic party will be held at the Garden City Hotel, Garden City, L. I., at 10:30 A. M. tomorrow. Representatives of civic groups in Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Counties have been invited to attend.
Puerto Ricans here celebrated the sixth anniversary of their commonwealth yesterday in Central Park in an atmosphere that was both wet and political.
PARIS, July 27 -- Minority members of the Socialist party expressed their opposition today to Premier Charles de Gaulle and to the manner in which a new French Constitution was being drafted.
The pastor of President and Mrs. Eisenhower said yesterday that "nothing is more important in the world today than that personal relations be kept personal and all human relations remain human."
THE best dressed freshmen of 1958 will be wearing Bermuda shorts, Shetland sweaters and sneakers on campus this fall.

The owner of a service station in the Bronx was held up at knife-point and robbed of $125 last night by a 14-year-old boy using his 8-year-old brother as an unwitting accomplice. The boys were seized two blocks away by four youths who were attracted by the owner's shouts.

Private financial institutions axe playing an increasingly important role in overseas investments by the Export-Import Bank of Washington, the bank indicated yesterday. The bank is the overseas lending arm of the United States Treasury.
UTICA, N. Y., July 27 (AP) -- John Konsek today won the New York State amateur golf championship, defeating John Ward of Syracuse, 4 and 2.
The Liberal party proposed yesterday that a city committee be appointed to screen the rental payments made by relief clients living in substandard housing.

PITTSBURGH, July 27 -- The long-awaited upturn in the steel industry has come. The near collapse that some steel observers looked for in July did not materialize. Taking into account the seasonal factor of summer shutdowns the strength of the steel market is substantially improved from the bottom reached in April and May.

Are we in danger of having our sense of wonder dulled by the rapidity of the march of science these days? Consider merely the news reported in these pages yesterday: The United States sent into orbit its fourth artificial satellite, a vehicle designed to measure intense radiation in space, radiation whose very existence was unknown a few short months ago.
NEW ORLEANS, July 27 -- Lieut. Gen. Claire L. Chennault, who led the Flying Tigers to fame in the skies over China, died here today in Ochsner Foundation Hospital. His age was 67.
The picture of the United States as a "pious and religious" nation was described yesterday by the Rev. Dr. John M. Krumm, chaplain of Columbia University, as a "most dangerous and frightening thing."

SADDLE BROOK, N. J., July 27 -- At the age of 40, George Magans held two jobs to support his family. For twenty-three years he had been a postman in near-by Rochelle Park. He clerked in a supermarket in the evenings.

An American edition of a schoolboy's account of what it was like to be fighting in the Hungarian revolution of 1956 will be published by Atlantic-Little, Brown on Sept. 8. It will be called "Boy on the Rooftop." It was written by Tamas Szabo (a pseudonym) in Paris where he had made his way after his escape into Austria.

MOSCOW, July 27 -- The United States swept first and second places in each of five events to gain an 83-75 lead over the Soviet Union today in the first dual track and field meet between the two countries.

To bring New Yorkers up to date on the vast expansions and changes that have taken place in their park system over the past twenty-five years the Parks Department has issued a new brochure that will enable both residents and visitors to become better acquainted with our readily available recreational facilities.

LONDON, July 27 -- The United States will offer "friendly consideration" to any proposal at a summit conference for an arms embargo embracing the Arab states of the Middle East, American officials disclosed tonight.
The West Coast produced the major advertising news over the week-end.

The Eastman Kodak Company had a net income of $37,330,269, or $1.93 a common share, in the first half of this year, the company reported over the week-end. This compared with $40,221,346, or $2.08 a share, in the similar period of last year.
HAVERFORD, Pa., July 27 (AP) -- The Pennsylvania lawn tennis championship was $1,000 richer today because it rained.
Committees have been formed to plan for the fifty-third annual Piping Rock Horse Show to be held Sept. 11 through Sept. 14 at the Piping Rock Show Grounds in Locust valley, L. I.

The Government showed failure "to understand an important economic fact" when it charged that oil companies conspired to raise prices last year, H. S. M. Burns, president of the Shell Oil Company, said in a letter to stockholders mailed over the week-end.

SARNIA, Ont., July 27 -- An Upper Sandusky, Ohio, husband-and-wife team, driving a Mercedes, was declared the winner today of the tenth annual Press On Regardless rally of the National Sports Car Club of America.
EAST ROCKAWAY, L. I., July 27 -- The Westbury Volunteer Fire Department won first prize here today in the fourth annual Old Fashioned Intercommunity Drill.
Animals weird and varied enough to satisfy the fancies of a carnival barker have arrived in the Bronx Zoo from Australia and New Guinea.
MOSCOW, July 27 -- The Soviet press charged today that the United States was delaying a summit conference on the Middle East while it tried to restore its military position in that area.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Following are the votes of the members from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended July 26:

LENOX, Mass., July 27 -- At each of his two concerts this week-end at Tanglewood, Charles Munch gave festival-goers an astringent modern appetizer, a big Russian concerto and a heaped-up serving of French impressionism.
AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, July 27 -- The stock market was quiet last week, despite increasing optimism that danger of widespread major military conflict in the Middle East was receding.

The Criterion Advertising Company, specialists in shopping center outdoor advertising, leased space in the new building at 630 Third Avenue, at Forty-first Street, for its main office, now at 122 East Forty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The latest notes from the United States and British Governments remind us they were drafted primarily by Messrs. Dulles and Lloyd, two veterans of the legal craft. Francois de Callieres, who more than two centuries ago composed the best manual on negotiating, observed: "In general the training of a lawyer breeds habits and dispositions of mind which are not favorable to the practice of diplomacy."

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) -- Dr. Burney said today that a "breakthrough is imminent" in the battle to prevent and cure cancer. Whether "imminent means one year or five years I don't know," he added, but he voiced optimism "on the basis of reports from the National Institutes of Health and from throughout the country."

Leonard W. Hall predicted yesterday that Nelson A. Rockefeller would be out of the running for the Republican nomination for Governor if he did not tell the party where he stood on issues and what kind of a campaign he would wage.

Figures on ocean-borne foreign commerce in January, 1958, show the lowest percentage of United States participation since the enactment of the Merchant Act of 1936, according to the American Tramp Shipowners Association.

MADRID, July 27 (AP) -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco, in an interview with the Roman Catholic newspaper Ya, said today that a general revision of Western policy toward the Middle East was necessary.
The United States newest satellite made its celestial rounds on schedule yesterday.
JAMESTOWN, N. D., July 27 (AP) -- Two smiling balloonists made a harrowing landing on a North Dakota pasture today, ending man's longest journey into the stratosphere.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The Government has some unpublished figures indicating that it has recently become a little cheaper to buy a house.
LONDON, Monday, July 28 (UPI) -- Britain's production in the first quarter of this year rose by about 1 per cent, the Treasury announced today.
ALGIERS, July 27 -- The number of public safety committees in Algeria was increased by one today with the formation of a committee of public safety for the Algiers Region.
GENEVA, July 29 -- Many Jewish leaders fear that assimilation may achieve what persecution could not achieve: the eventual disappearance of the Jewish people.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Administration officials this weekend were working on a program to reduce the dangers and enhance the possible accomplishments of a summit meeting in the United Nations Security Council next month.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) -- Sinclair Weeks, secretary of commerce, announced today the allocation to the states of $3,400,000,000 in Federal aid for road building -- the largest apportionment ever made.
NATHAN HOMER KNORR is head of what is probably the fastest-growing religious movement in modern times.

Citing various features of the new Air Force academy at Colorado Springs as an "outstanding example" of extravagance and inadequate planning, the House Appropriations Committee has sharply criticized the Defense Department for "loose fiscal procedures" in connection with construction policies and practices.

MILWAUKEE, July 27 (UPI) -- Carl Willey allowed only five hits and Henry Aaron drove in three runs with a homer and a single today as the Milwaukee Braves defeated the Chicago Cubs, 4 -- 1. The Braves took undisputed possession of first place in the National League.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 27 -- The new chief of Iraq's development program described the revolutionary aims today in terms of new houses for villagers instead of a new palace for the king.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., June 27 -- Warner Wilcox scored two victories and placed second once with Stardust to take the International Class series today in a special program conducted by the Larchmont Yacht Club. A serious collision marred the series.

Saturday night's electrical storm deprived 15,000 homes of electricity for brief periods on Long Island and the Rockaways. The Long Island Lighting Company reported yesterday that the interruptions had ranged from ten minutes to an hour.

The Scarsdale Plaza Theatre Building, containing a 1,000-seat theatre and six stores on Garth Road, Scarsdale, N. Y., has been purchased by Garth Plaza Enterprises, Inc., of Brooklyn. Raymond R. Beatty was the broker.
NOTTINGHAM, England, July 27 (Reuters) -- The ghosts of Robin Hood and his merry men skulked in shame tonight through the green glades of Sherwood Forest.

LAKE COCHITUATE, Mass., July 27 -- The Yonkers Canoe Club won the team title at the national canoe-racing championships today. The Westchester paddlers scored 31 points, captured three events and tied for first in another.
DALLAS, Tex., July 27 -- The Republicans will have a hard time corallling Texas's Presidential vote again in 1960.
Thomas K. Finletter proposed yesterday that the United Nations General Assembly be convened to ratify any decisions on the Middle East that are reached at summit talks within the Security Council.

SEOUL, Korea, July 27 (UPI) -- President Syngman Rhee said today that President Eisenhower was a "brave man" for his firm position on the Middle East. But he advised the West not to be "too concerned" about the possibility of a Middle East war.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- The presence of 10,000 United States troops in Lebanon and the expected summit conference have cast a shadow on the question of when the second session of the Eighty-fifth Congress will adjourn.

On July 11 you printed a letter from E. S. Willis, consultant to the General Electric Company, rebuking you for your editorial congratulating Group Health Insurance on its experiment with psychiatric care, without also praising G. E. for its employe insurance program, which includes psychiatry.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 27 (AP) -- There were new faint hopes of peace in Cyprus today. But bloodshed continued.

The International Rescue Committee protested yesterday the action of United States immigration officials in forcibly returning a Polish seaman to his ship even though he reportedly sought political asylum here.

DAY-DREAMING little boys with main thought for derring-do want to be policemen or firemen. It has always been so. Now, according to a 252-page survey just placed in the hands of the city's Board of Estimate, fire-fighting and police work are nowhere nearly so strenuous as garbage-can tossing. That calling stands second in the nation only to logging in hazards.
The Department of Air Pollution Control announced yesterday that its "get-topgh" policy had resulted in a record number of summonses and violation notices in the six months ended June 30.
Two films are scheduled to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

DESERT ENTERPRISE. By David H. Finnie. 224 pp. Harvard University Press. $5. Probably few books have been published at just the right moment to tie in with world news. Here's one whose publication date was moved ahead just for that reason. It tells the story, briefly, colorfully and fairly, of the international oil companies in the Middle East.
Reliance on one's own ability to overcome temptation and sin is "doomed to failure and disaster," the Rev. John Depkiewicz declared yesterday at the 10 A. M. solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

TARQUINIA, Italy, July 27 -- A painting of a three-masted-sailing ship that plied the Mediterranean about 2,500 years ago has come to light in a newly discovered Etruscan tomb here. The place will be known as the Tomb of the Ship.
ZURICH, Switzerland, July 27 -- A strange situation developed last week when two diameterically opposed trends dominated the stock market.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 27 -- Beirut was calm today after a night of heavy shooting.

OSAKA, Japan (Reuters) -- The Japanese cotton textile industry, which has expanded sales abroad at the expense of Western competitors, is complaining that its exports markets are being invaded by cheap Communist Chinese piece goods.

FORT SMITH, Ark., July 27 (UPI) -- Army authorities continued their investigation today into the hand burns suffered by thirty-one basic trainees when their platoon sergeant ordered them to do push-ups on a sun-baked asphalt basketball court.

A recent letter signed "Jaywalker" cited an unfortunate example of a fatal accident which occurred at a corner as proof of the contention that it is safer to cross in the middle of the block than at the corner.

Julian B. Baird, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, appeared last week before the House Committee on Banking and Currency to urge the enactment of a bill identified as H. R. 12586. This measure would extend until June 30, 1960, the present authority of the Federal Reserve Banks to purchase public debt obligations of the Treasury up to the amount of $5 billion.

WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Neil H. McElroy, Secretary of Defense, has informed Congress that some nuclear weapons in the nation's stockpile have been altered in a way that increases radioactive fall-out over a local area.
A touch of old Japan entranced 5,000 spectators in a Riverside Drive mall at 103d Street as followers of the Gautama Buddha observed the annual Feast of Obon Saturday night in homage to the dead.
BONN, Germany, July 27 -- The West German Government gave public support today to Israel's participation in a summit conference if Arab states are invited.

SALZBURG, Austria, July 27 -- Time was when Mozart was the mainstay of the Salzburg Festival. But this year's opening production, last night, was Verdi's "Don Carlo" sung in Italian, and a stirring effort it was.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 27 -- John Huston has entered into a five-picture deal with Eliot Hyman and Ray Stark of Seven Arts Productions. The director-writer-producer's first undertaking will be a film, not yet titled, dealing with a ten-year period in the life of Dr. Sigmund Freud.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 27 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold and United Nations diplomats prepared today for a week of intensive consultations on the proposed summit conference.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- When the applause in this town is being distributed, Senator Lyndon B. Johnson discovered last week, it helps to be named Eisenhower.
CZESTOCHOWA, Poland, July 27 -- Poland's Roman Catholic Church accused the Communist Government today of having violated the sanctuary of the country's most sacred shrine.

ST. LOUIS, July 27 (UPI) -- Alex Kellner pitched a seven-hitter today for a 10-1 Cincinnati Redleg victory and a split with the St. Louis Cardinals. The Cards had the pitching in the first game, a six-hit job by Larry Jackson, and won, 4 -- 3.

TUNIS, July 27 (AP) -- President Habib Bourguiba declared today that Europe was "playing like a spoiled child" toward the United States. He warned that if the United States should give up hope and abandon the Western world, Soviet forces would invade within twenty-four hours.
The sixteen-month-old African republic of Ghana is willing to provide troops for a United Nations police force in Lebanon if the Security Council or General Assembly so recommend.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) -- Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican of South Dakota, accused House Democrats today of following the wishes of "labor bosses" in delaying action on the Senate-passed labor reform bill.

In an astonishing letter to Secretary Dulles, Chairman Francis E. Walter of the House Un-American Activities Committee has suggested that a State Department employe was guilty of "capricious and unauthorized action" because she was loyally carrying out the recent passport decision of the United States Supreme Court.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 27 -- Plans to tap the immense energy that lies imprisoned in the molten center of the earth were announced here last week by the Pacific Gas and Electric Company.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 27 -- Samuel Goldwyn has relieved Rouben Mamoulian as director of "Porgy and Bess" and has engaged Otto Preminger to replace him. In his announcement this morning the producer ascribed his action to "basic differences of opinion."
The steamship charter market fell last week after an earlier flurry because of the tense Middle East situation.
WASHINGTON, July 27 -- Following are the texts of messages exchanged by President Camille Chamoun of Lebanon and President Eisenhower.
NEWTON, N. J., July 27 -- Champion Shirkhan of Grandeur, the Afghan hound that won top honors at Madison Square Garden last year, was named best in show at the Newton Kennel Club's fixture today.
Rebel leaders in Lebanon say they will fight if American troops come too close to their headquarters.
LONDON, July 27 -- With the easing of international tension last week, prices on the stock markets improved.
I should like to call attention to your July 24 editorial "Nasser's Opportunity," which contains several unfounded charges.
TOLEDO, Ohio, July 27 (AP) -- A Long Island, N. Y., man and two of his sons were killed today in a rear-end collision on the Ohio turnpike west of here near Swanton.
The 1958 Brooklyn team-of-four championship was won early today by a contract bridge team captained by Ned Drucker of New York City.

More than 180,000 well-disciplined Jehovah's Witnesses packed themselves in and around the Yankee Stadium and the Polo Grounds yesterday for the opening of their eight-day Divine Will International Assembly.

SUMMER presents many special problems effecting both indoor and outdoor living. Manufacturers, conscious of these difficulties, are concerned with everything from combating mosquitos to filling the ice box.
CHICAGO, July 27 (AP) -- The grain futures market slid back into its normal trading groove last week after wiping out the sharp gains following the Middle East flare-up.

KIRKUK, Iraq, July 26 -- The Military Governor of north Iraq was emphatic that there had been no serious disturbances in his area since the coup of July 14 that overthrew the monarchy. There had been no defections from the Second Army Division he commanded.

The Rev. Dr. Hampton Adams, pastor of the Park Avenue Christian Church, 1010 Park Avenue, said yesterday that "the Christian reverence for life requires of some of us what we practice and give encouragement to birth control."
The Fire Department fought 8,561 more fires in 1957 than it did the year before, but damages in 1957 were $5,281,196 lower.

The Detroit Edison Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday a 10 per cent drop in electricity production for the first half. Production in the twelve months ended June 30 dropped 2.3 per cent to 13,105,366,800 kilowatt hours.
A CAN of paint, a roll of wallpaper or new draperies are sufficient to spark up a room setting. Abraham Straus has proved it in a way that all women will understand.

W(SHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- House investigators found evidence today that the Government had sold thousands of auto brake linings as surplus overseas and was now buying them back from dealers in this country.

Committees have been chosen to work for the success of the eighth annual luncheon of the Friends of the Philharmonic. The fete is scheduled to take place in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria on Nov. 25.
CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) -- Soybeans had scattered support but the grains were under the pressure of hedging and liquidation today on the Board of Trade and prices eased.
Scientists from threescore countries are assembling in Moscow for deliberations that they hope will not be darkened by the shadow of political controversy.
SAN SALVADOR, July 28 -- Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower denied emphatically today that the United States was supporting dictators in the Western Hemisphere.
The Federal Maritime Board entered into two contracts yesterday that will provide 1,600,000 man-hours of shipyard work on both coasts.

PROGRESSIVE jazz and poetry, a combination that purportedly has entranced Greenwich Village's avantgarde, was presented last night on "Stars of Jazz" over the American Broadcasting Company's television network.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today to put new financial and geographic restrictions on the Tennessee Valley Authority.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 28 -- Security Council delegates were surprised today by the Soviet Union's rejection of President Eisenhower's proposal that the Council take over the responsibility for arranging a meeting of heads of government.

AT 3:30 P. M. yesterday in Kingsburg, Calif., Mrs. Lewis Johnson, a short, hefty woman known to all as Dimples, was briskly ironing a basketful of clothes and listening to music on the radio, when the announcer cut in and said:
SAN FRANCISCO, July 28 (AP) -- Five persons were killed and two were gravely injured by lightning today as scattered storms swept central California from the cast to the Sierra Nevada foothills.
NORFOLK, Va., July 28 -- The pupil assignment plan of the Norfolk School Board was challenged in Federal District Court here today.
SOME of the luscious statistics that always precede, attend and follow each tuna-tournament season have begun to flow in, and this year they are particularly piquant.

HAVANA, July 28 -- American marines landed today in Cuba to protect the water supply of the United States Guantanamo Naval Base in Oriente Province, according to Rear Admiral Robert B. Ellis, commander of the base.

LONDON, July 28 -- Secretary of State Dulles' first impression of the Soviet Premier's letter to President Eisenhower was understood to be that although Mr. Khrushchev had objected to the President's program he had concluded by asking for a date on which to commence its implementation.

Richard W. Gano, a native of Orange, N. J., who followed Horace Greeley's advice and found success in business and in his chosen hobby of bowling, will become the forty-fifth president of the American Bowling Congress Friday.
Money kept carelessly in firehouses is an incentive to "robbery, embezzlement, possible assault, even murder," Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. said yesterday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 28 -- Two United States Representatives rose at the conference of the Interparliamentary Union here today to question the good faith of the Soviet Union in suspending its tests of nuclear weapons.
Seventeen - year - old Jackie Leonard took the rainy-day riding honors at Jamaica yesterday with four winners, including a victory in the $7,500 Rockville Centre Handicap before 23,404 fans.
Ilya Wolston, a nephew of the confessed Soviet spy Jack Soble, was in Federal court yesterday charged with contempt for failure to appear before a grand jury investigating espionage.
LONDON, July 28 -- Britain insisted tonight that discussion of the Middle East crisis must be confined to the Security Council of the United Nations.

CHICKEN livers, which are usually rather expensive, can be bought at prices that are relatively economical in those shops that sell barbecued chickens. Right now, for example, some stores charge $1.30 to $1.40 a pound for chicken livers.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today to authorize a $13,000,000,000 increase in the statutory debt limit. This would raise the limit from $275,000,000,000 to $288,000,000,000.
Net income of the Socony Mobil Oil Company in the first half this year fell to $67,500,000 from $126,800,000 in the corresponding period last year, the semi-annual report showed yesterday.
Andrew and Virginia Stone, the husband and wife film-making team, have left for England to begin their search for an ocean liner to be featured in their next movie drama.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) -- The House Interior Committee approved today a bill to stockpile copper and pay subsidies to producers of seven other minerals.
AMERICAN men saw red when they were first introduced to the chemise. Recently, the Reds saw the chemise when a Manhattan fashion consultant took it to Moscow.
CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The Armco Steel Corporation cleared $20,956,744 in the first half of this year, against $38,583,106 in the period a year ago, Charles R. Hook, chairman, reported yesterday. The results for both years include those of the National Supply Company, which was merged into Armco last April 30.
PARIS, July 28 -- The movement for independence in French West and Equatorial Africa received a strong impetus last night from one of the two major political parties in that area.
Depressed prices and increased operating costs cut earnings of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) in the first half of this year.
Bids for the job of converting two Grace Line cargo ships into "lift-on, lift-off" container vessels were opened by the United States Maritime Administration yesterday.
The case of Joseph Papp, a television stage manager who was dismissed last month by the Columbia Broadcasting System, has been submitted to arbitration by the Radio and Television Directors Guild.
BEIRUT, July 28 (AP) -- Rebel and Government partisans engaged in hard fighting today in the north Lebanon town of Zegharta, four miles northeast of the coastal city of Tripoli.
The Rev. Dr. Wendell Q. Halverson, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church of La Grange, Ill., was elected general presbyter of the Presbytery of New York yesterday.
ALBANY, July 28 (AP) -New York State collected a record $551,393,498 in taxes in the first quarter of the current fiscal year, the Harriman Administration reported today.

The two five-story apartment buildings at 153-5-7 Lenox Avenue, at the southwest corner of ll8th Street, have been purchased by Lipton Associates, Inc., a client of Edward L. Dubroff, attorney. Schimmer, Kerner P-Feder were co-brokers in the deal with Porter Co.
The Department of Parks said yesterday it needed more than a million dollars to save trees along the streets.

BRUSSELS, Belgium July 28 -- The Prague Opera completed a week's stand here tonight with Smetana's "The Bartered Bride." In its World's Fair visit the company has been alternating this comic work with Janacek's tragic "Jenufa."

A delegation of five Puerto Rican Senators and Representatives announced yesterday that it would urge independence for Puerto Rico in visits to Congress, Latin American embassies and the United Nations.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 28 (AP) -- General Mills, Inc. reported today record sales and earnings for the year ended May 31. Sales were $529,820,000. Net earnings were $14,694,000 or $2,458,000 more than in the previous fiscal year, and $637,000 higher than the previous record year of 1955-56, the company said. PHILADELPHIA, July 28 (AP) -- The San Francisco Giants beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 3 -- 2 and 2 -- 1, tonight to move within one point of the National League lead.

TOKYO, July 28 -- Tadataka Sata, Socialist leader, left by plane for Peiping today.
Dense fog and rain seriously hampered operations yesterday at New York's airports and the heavy weather was expected to continue today, the Weather Bureau said last night.

CANTON, N. Y., July 28 -- Young offenders are confirmed in a delinquent pattern by the failure of the community to permit them to make a normal re-entry into society, a State return to society, a State Crime Conference was told tonight.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., July 28 -- Suffolk County will experiment with snow fencing, brush and other low-cost sand-catchers to check erosion and build up exposed beaches along its Atlantic Ocean shoreline.
CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) -The Laundry Workers, Dry Cleaning and Dye House Workers International Union got court approval today to recover $137,000 in welfare funds.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) -- The House Ways and Means Committee overwhelmingly approved a bill today to give the 11,800,000 Social Security beneficiaries a 7 per cent increase in benefits starting in December.
WHITE PLAINS, JULY 28--Multimillion-dollar highway jobs in Westchester County will continue to snarl traffic for the remainder of the summer, but one major bottleneck here was eliminated today.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals today reinstated a suit challenging the validity of the voluntary program to curtail oil imports.

FISHERS ISLAND, N. Y., July 28 -- Carl Hovgard, the commodore of the host American Y. C., captured the Shethar Bowl today when his 56-foot yawl Circe placed first on corrected time in the distance race from Rye to Fishers Island.

The fact that the Board of Estimate is confronted with a condemnation award of $77,500 -- about five and one-half times the 1957-58 assessed valuation of $14,600 -- for a school site in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn suggests that the time has come for streamlining and improving the machinery under which land is taken by condemnation for public use.

MOSCOW, July 28--Soviet Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev has accused the United States of stalling on a summit meeting on Middle East problems within the United Nations and has revived his plan for a five-power gathering in Europe instead.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI)--The Defense Department announced today that the Army would draft 11,000 in September. This will be 1,000 more than in each of the previous three months.

A group of leading architects and planners in this area has proposed a new type of municipal ordinance that would help the New York region's 550 towns and cities to improve their appearance. The new ordinance would be tailored to meet the special conditions in each community, but in general it would enact a community design plan to regulate the appearance of all buildings and properties seen from public streets or pedestrian ways.
PARIS, July 28 -- After the showing of the first Paris collections today, it appears that skirts will remain at a knee-revealing level, waists are mounting and shoulders are gaining steady width.
