WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- Chicago's plea for Congressional sanction to divert additional water from Lake Michigan met with wide opposition today.

Sally Carrighar, author of books on nature subjects, lived in Alaska for nine years. During that time her attention turned from little known Arctic wild animals to the native Eskimos and white settlers. In her new book, "Moonlight at Midday," she tells about the people, recounts native legends and discusses Alaska's past and present. The book will be published by Knopf on Oct. 20.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) -- The New York City Bar Association declared today that passports should be denied only to criminals and to persons who would "endanger vital national security interests of the United States."

LITTLE, ROCK, July 28 -Voters of Arkansas cast their ballots tomorrow in a Democratic primary that is widely regarded as a test of public opinion of Gov. Orval E. Faubus' stand on integration of public schools in Little Rock.

Rosalind Russell is reading a musical version of Emily Kimbrough's "It Gives Me Great Pleasure." The book, it will be recalled, is a candid and witty recounting of the author's adventures as a traveling lecturer.
The Prime Minister of Ghana cited two major links yesterday between this city and his West African republic. They are the cocoa trade and the feeling of kinship for New Yorkers of African descent.

Luggage manufacturers are concerned over the fact that many persons are using old-style travel cases for new-style trips. So, through their trade association, the Luggage and Leather Goods Manufacturers of America, they are making plans for an industry-wide promotion campaign to increase volume.
DETROIT, July 28 (AP) -The Ford Motor Company denied the conspiracy charges today.

A Brooklyn attorney indicted on charges of making false claims on an insurance company for four clients was denied the minutes of a special grand jury yesterday. The jury was empaneled last March to investigate ambulance chasing.
Tony Di Biase, an Astoria (Queens) welterweight, had to stave off a late rally by Jimmy Archer to gain a unanimous decision in the main bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 28 -Lebanon's political crisis may be near solution tonight with agreement on a Presidential candidate acceptable to both the Government and the Opposition.
TOKYO, July 28 -- Alichiro Fujiyama re-stated today the Japanese Government's opposition to the presence of United States troops in Lebanon.
WARSAW, July 28 -- Official Roman Catholic sources accused the Polish Government today of having broken the law, violated the rights of citizens and shocked the religious feelings of the nation.
Back on its own, the market for United States Government securities sold off sharply again yesterday, as speculative accounts continued to be liquidated.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 28 -- Dr. Eric A. Walker, president of Pennsylvania State University, said tonight that education was suffering from a lack of a technological revolution.
Following is the text of a statement issued yesterday by Edward T. Dickinson, State Commerce Commissioner, announcing his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator:
WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower dropped in tonight on high-ranking Republicans holding a testimonial dinner for six Republican Senators who are retiring.
A court action started yesterday by a minority stockholder of Unexcelled Chemical Corporation delayed for at least a week the results of the proxy contest for control of the company.
LAKEHURST, N. J., July 28 (AP)--A Navy blimp waited today for a break in the weather to start again on a trip to the North Pole.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -House investigators will consider tomorrow whether to cite Bernard Goldfine for contempt of Congress.
LONDON, July 28 -- The stock market turned slightly dull today, with small losses outnumbering gains in most sections.
FORT HANCOCK, N, J., July 28 -- The conversion of the Minute Man to the missile man is taking place here.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Spokesmen for the Senate's anti-filibuster bloc called today for an all-out drive to tighten debate rules.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- Three outstanding college coaches today called the pro football draft unfair to the players and said the pros did not need it to survive.
HABBANIYA, Iraq, July 28 (AP) -- A group of 1,020 British airmen, 43 Americans and 270 British women and children have been confined to a small area in this Iraqi base for the last two weeks.

It was a fortunate chance that Premier Fanfani of Italy should have been invited by the White House to come to the United States at this moment. This is a time, thanks to the Middle Eastern crisis, when the United States especially needs the support, advice and friendly criticisms of her allies.

In a transaction invoIving seven apartment houses, Geisinger Germain, realty operators, have acquired the parcels at 1522-34 Clarlotte Street in the Bronx. They purchased the properties from the Bernblum Realty Corporation through the Taylor Company, broker.
PHOENICIA, N. Y., July 28 (AP) -- The president of a Brooklyn lumber company and his wife were killed today when their car was struck head-on by a trailer-truck on Route 28 near here.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 28 -- The old so-called tribal courts, under which administrative officials could take jurisdiction in either civil or criminal cases, have been abolished in Iraq.

Officials of the American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations will resume discussions today in Washington on damage suits brought by workers kept from their jobs by union picket lines.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 16 to 103 points (80 cents to $5.15 a bale) yesterday, with far months showing the greatest weakness.

ANKARA, Turkey, July 28 -- Opposition party leaders called on the Turkish Government today to recognize the new revolutionary regime in Iraq. The Opposition demanded a policy of strict nonintervention in the internal affairs of other countries in the Middle East.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 28 -- The summer business boom, so slow in starting this year that Hollywood had begun to despair, finally materialized during the seven days ended July 19.

JERSEY CITY, July 28 -- Commission government, a type of municipal government introduced in New Jersey by Woodrow Wilson, was denounced as archaic here today by the Independent Voters Council of New Jersey. The group hopes to change the commission government in Jersey City to the Mayor-and-Council type.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 28 -- Members of the Argentine and United States Davis Cup teams were in the field that began play today in the seventieth annual Southampton invitation tennis tournament at the Meadow Club.

Edwin Dale's article of July 21 and your editorial of July 22 are urgent reminders -- even at a time of the crisis in the Middle East -- that India's economic position remains the pivotal test in our foreign assistance program.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 28 (AP) -- A marble inscription honoring the Roman Emperor Lucius Verus (who reigned 161-169 A. D.) has been found by American archaeologists excavating the ancient Lydian capital of Sardis in Turkey, Harvard University reported today.
Nathan H. Knorr, head of 700,000 Jehovah's Witnesses, unequivocally divorced his movement yesterday from the main stream of organized religion.

Every year thousands of tourists -- many of them Americans -- flock to a quiet Italian town forty-four miles west of Florence. In the twelfth and thirteenth centuries it was a flourishing commercial center but now it is noted chiefly for its art treasures.

ONE of the most rewarding orchestral evenings and the most promising young conductor it has been this listener's pleasure to hear in many months brought the third season of the Morningside Music Festival to a distinguished finish last night. The concert took place in the auditorium of Public School 125 at 425 West 123d Street.

United Air Lines, Inc., which operated in the red in the first quarter this year, made a sharp recovery in the second quarter with earnings of $4,601,107. Second-quarter earnings last year were $2,288,167.

LONDON, July 28 -- Secretary of State Dulles today committed the United States to partnership in the Baghdad Pact with Britain, Turkey, Iran and Pakistan. The United States' acceptance of obligations expressed in Article 1 of the pact was accompanied by an oral promise to increase military assistance to the three Asian members. These two steps were considered "just as good" as signing a treaty by American sources.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 28 -- Long Island's small fry and medium-sized fry had their day on the links today. Some lugged golf bags bigger than themselves as they took part in the thirty-seventh annual Long Island junior and boys' championship tournament.
Wreckers went to work yesterday on the first of more than 400 buildings that are to be torn down to clear a thirteen-block area for the $205,000,000 Lincoln Square redevelopment.
PROVERB for a country guest: A gift in the hand is worth two week-ends in the bush.
WARSAW, July 28 -- Poland's peasants were told by the Government today that they would have to continue compulsory deliveries of grain and potatoes to the state.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's letter to President Eisenhower today on a Middle East heads-of-government conference was the fifth to pass between Washington and Moscow in the last ten days.
A 45-year-old clerk at the Underwriters Trust Company at 50 Broadway was arrested yesterday on a charge of stealing $20,000 from the bank.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Premier Khrushchev's latest contribution to "open diplomacy" for negotiating a summit conference on the Middle East furnishes further support for a forecast made here by students of Kremlin tactics when Khrushchev initiated the correspondence.
Steel production rose more than expected last week, and a continued increase is scheduled this week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 28 -- The United States Marines today spiked rumors that the marine found shot dead yesterday had been the first American victim of rebel sniper fire in Lebanon.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- A Senate committee criticized the Air Force today for financing private rocket test facilities and said the service had shown "a growing lack of energy" in space activities.

The Atomic Development Mutual Fund reported yesterday net assets of $51,387,042 as of June 30. This compared with $51,818,295 a year earlier and $48,995,846 on March 31 this year. The per share values were $4.61 on June 30, $4.40 on March 31 and $5.34 on June 30, 1957, the last two on fewer shares.
Meat packers are moving into the electronic age. Rapid communications are essential in an industry that deals mainly with perishable products.

Two major studies of the economics of pensions have been approved by the National Bureau of Economic Research, Dr. Arthur F. Burns, president, announced yesterday. Work on the studies has been started, he added.

Walter Alston's days as manager of the last-place Los Angeles Dodgers are numbered unless the club does a complete change and starts winning during the next ten days, United Press International learned yesterday on excellent authority.
The nation's high schools were urged yesterday to stop trying to convince their students that "mathematics is fun" and instead provide challenging and rewarding programs.

MOSCOW, July 28 -- Track and field stars of the Soviet Union pulled out a narrow victory over men's and women's teams from the United States here tonight. The American guests showed surprising strength in the long-distance runs and startling lapses in the high jump and pole vault.

KANSAS CITY, July 28 -- Municipal Stadium, where the distance from home plate to left-center is 375 feet and to right-center 387 feet, is ideal for a switch-hitter with good power. Mickey Mantle fits that description and Mickey put on a tremendous show in leading the Yankees to a 14-7 victory over the Athletics tonight.
Low-priced issues attracted much of the attention in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange, and the market gave an impression of being stronger than it was.
THE college freshman's most irreparable mistakes are abandoning her real personality and hanging onto an old boy friend.
CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) -- Chicago's chief prosecutor accused a Senate investigating committee today of failure to cooperate in his efforts to indict restaurant industry racketeers.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. predicted yesterday that he would defeat City Councilman Earl Brown by a 2-to-1 margin for the Democratic nomination for Representative from Harlem's Sixteenth Congressional District.
The New York Foundation reported yesterday that grants exceeding $2,000,000 had been made in 1956 and 1957. The chief beneficiaries were mental and other health institutions.
Speculator liquidation and stop-loss selling caused cocoa prices to fall sharply yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -Forty-two Ford, Chevrolet and Oldsmobile dealers in the Washington area were indicted today on charges of conspiring to fix artificially high prices on new cars and parts.
PARIS, July 28 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle tonight studied the latest Soviet note on prospects for a summit conference. Meanwhile he banned official comment on it.
DETROIT, July 28 (UPI) -- Leo Kiely walked Charlie Maxwell with the bases loaded and two out in the ninth inning today to give the Detroit Tigers a 5-4 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

PARIS, July 28 -- A $200,000,000 loan to Turkey was discussed today by the Council of the Organization for European Economic Cooperation. It was expected that an agreement would be reached later this week.
FLORENCE, July 28 -- As half the floating population of the Grand Hotel and Harry's Bar dwindled toward Paris, bookkeeping made happy talk yesterday in and around Florence's Strozzi Palace.
LOS ANGELES, July 28 -- Five Spanish sailors who feared for their lives if they returned to Spain were given political asylum in Mexico today and returned to that country.
BALTIMORE, July 28 (AP) -- The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad today reported a net income for June of $2,049,647, down $83,180 from the net income of June, 1957.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 28 -- Cyprus was hit by a new wave of murders, bombings and arson today as the struggle between Greek and Turkish Cypriotes was resumed.
DETROIT, July 28 (AP) -- Automobile production is expected to taper off further this week as more makers close for model changeovers.
BURLINGTON, Vt., July 28 (AP) -- The president of the Motion Picture Association of America said tonight that critics of the industry cannot agree on what films they like or dislike.
LOS ANGELES, July 28 (UPI) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers today reported a major player shakeup.

Reflecting increased sales, earnings of the Celanese Corporation of America and its domestic subsidiaries rose 18 per cent to $3,191,635 in the quarter ended June 30. This is equal to 34 cents a common shares and compares with $2,701,070, or 26 cents a common share, earned in the second quarter of last year.
Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., in the first half this year had the highest sales and earnings for any similar period in its history.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 28 (UPI) -- Dr. J. E. Walker, 78 years old, who had been called one of the ten most influential Negroes in the United States, was shot to death in his office here today.

Columbia University announced yesterday the receipt of a gift of $250,000 from Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin J. Buttenwieser of New York and their children. It will establish the Joseph L. Buttenwieser Professorship in Human Relations.

The Studebaker-Packard Corporation is expected to park its advertising account at the D'Arcy Advertising Company. However, the auto maker's present agency, Burke Dowling Adams, Inc., may retain some of the business.
Haiti intends to ask for the recall of the United States Ambassador, and has already obtained transfer of the second ranking officer at the embassy, a Haitian official said here yesterday.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L. I., July 28 -- There was a thick fog over the water and confusion among some of the skippers as the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's annual Cruise Week championship Regatta got under way today.
The Kennecott Copper Corporation showed a sharp drop in earnings in the first six months of this year, reflecting lower prices for copper and reduced domestic sales.
GENEVA, July 28 -- Western and Eastern scientists proposed today the use of earth satellites as international sentries in space to monitor an agreement to suspend tests of nuclear weapons.

BOXING is having its annual Hall of Fame election and it seems to be having a problem. That is only natural because any sport that retrogresses as rapidly as has boxing in recent years is bound to have its difficulties when it comes to naming immortals for posterity. For the painful truth is that boxing is running out of candidates.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -A scholarship aid program cleared a Senate subcommittee today with good prospects of Senate approval at this session.
Following a recent spate of postponements in the new-capital market, four corporations announced plans yesterday for new financing totaling more than $325,000,000.

Joe Culmone came up from New Jersey for one ride at Jamaica yesterday, and he made the ride an excellent one. The aggressive jockey had the mount on Montpelier's Nahodah in the $22,600 Wilson Handicap. The horse didn't figure to do much against any of the seven others.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 29 -- Seventeen-year-old Jeffrey Graham did some island-hopping today -- from Staten to Long -- and quickly made his presence felt in the Long Island junior golf championship.

MOSCOW, July 29 -- Many foreign observers in Moscow agree with Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev that the Western powers, and particularly the United States, are delaying a summit conference on the Middle East.
PEQUANNOCK, N. J., July 29 (AP) -- A contract for public use of parochial school classrooms has raised a controversy in this Morris County township.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The State Department sharply denied today charges by a Haitian official that the United States Ambassador had interfered in Haiti's internal affairs.
One hundred persons were evacuated from two West Side tenements yesterday because of a bulge in a wall of one.

A gallery of High Renaissance paintings at the Metropolitan Museum of Art has just received an enormous addition -- a table that was made about 1570 for the Farnese Palace, one of the most splendid of Roman palaces.
Gabriel Genovese surrendered yesterday to the District Attorney's office. He pleaded not guilty to an indictment charging him with being an undercover (unlicensed) boxing manager.

I note in your editorial of July 21 your quotation of Gabriel Hauge's definition of "dynamic conservatism." In my judgment our economic system works best under wise government control and regulation. Without them it is like an engine that needs, but doesn't have, a governor.
Ground was broken yesterday for the third large apartment project on former slum sites within a haft-mile radius on the upper West Side.

The building containing sixty-nine apartments and occupying a plot 175 by 100 feet at 1167-69 Stratford Avenue in the Bronx was sold by Louis Chinsky to an investing client of Sol Greenstein, attorney. The sale was negotiated by Joseph Panman Associates, broker, for cash over mortgages amounting to $230,000.

PITTSBURGH, July 29 (AP) -- Three teen-age boys are in the custody of juvenile authorities here, charged with stealing and tampering with telephone company equipment to build their own phone exchange.
Dr. Kwame Nkrumah, Prime Minister of Ghana, said last night the world must realize that African and Asian peoples no longer would put up with imperialism, colonialism or ideas of racial superiority.

You recently stated that Dr. Harvey H. Segal, director of the New York Metropolitan Regional Study being made by the Harvard Graduate School of Public Administration for the Regional Plan Association, had reported that "export" of wages earned within New York City -- spending outside of money earned within the city -- would force a city income tax.
David Susskind, television producer, returned from London yesterday and reported that Laurence Olivier "was considering" an offer to star in "The Moon and Sixpence."

We called attention here recently to what was described as a public service performed by Ewan Clague, Commissioner of Labor Statistics, in an article in the June Monthly Labor Review. This public service consisted of pointing out that what was widely referred to as a distinguishing "paradox" in the present recession -- a rising consumer price index coinciding with a decline in business activity -- was not a paradox at all.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI) -- The Justice Department asked Congress today to give it the power to prosecute American citizens for spying against the United States on foreign soil.

MOSCOW, July 29 (AP) -- The Soviet Union declared tonight that Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev was still ready and willing to participate in a summit meeting in the United Nations Security Council in New York.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Democratic leaders are rapidly hammering into final shape an agenda of "must" legislation for the session's closing days.
Members of Congress from the New York area appeared yesterday to be rallying in an effort to keep the Staten Island shipyard of the Bethlehem Steel Company from closing.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The Senate gave unanimous approval today to a bill to speed and expand research to find ne windustrial uses for farm products.
Tallulah Bankhead has been signed by Walter Starcke to star in his first independent entry, "Crazy October."

PARIS, July 29 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle has delayed formulation of the French position on the latest exchange with the Soviet Union about a summit conference pending the outcome of consultations with France's European and Atlantic allies.
The largest liner in the West German merchant marine made her debut in New York Harbor yesterday.

IF ever a man is qualified to write the book, "How to Lose Friends and Make Fresh Enemies," he is Walter Francis O'Malley, the head man of the seemingly headless Dodgers, who meets the requirements with room to spare.
The United service Organizations is discontinuing its financial support to other agencies in New York that conduct clubs and have activities for servicemen.

WHITE PLAINS, N, Y., July 29 -- James A. Martin of Winged Foot won the medal in the Westchester qualifying round for the Metropolitan Golf Association amateur championship at the Century Country Club today.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI) -- The Administration asked Congress today to renew its authority to renegotiate defense contracts to recapture "excessive profits."

Today's new film is "La Parisienne," an imported comedy starring Brigitte Bardot and Charles Boyer, at the Plaza, Fifty-eighth Street, east of Madison Avenue, and the Victoria, Broadway and Forty-sixth Street.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower signed today a bill creating a powerful Federal space agency to supervise this country's efforts to unlock the secrets of the universe.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- President Eisenhower will reject Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's proposal for a five-nation conference on the Middle East. The President views the Soviet offer as an attempt to supplant the United Nations with the Soviet concept of big-power control of the world.

KANSAS CITY, July 29 -- Seven runs were scored in a stormy eighth-inning uprising at Municipal Stadium tonight. The Yankees fashioned the first two, but before they were able to enjoy them and the 2-2 tie, the Athletics rebounded with five and upset the league leaders, 7 -- 3.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., July 29 -- A fashion show and tea, an annual event for the benefit of Boys Harbor here, an interracial camp for needy boys, is scheduled to take place Friday afternoon. The fete will be held on the grounds of the Anthony Drexel Duke estate in Three Mile Harbor adjoining the camp site.
CHICAGO, July 29 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
GREENWICH, Conn., July 29 -- Just for a change, there was no fog or rain as 134 young skippers turned out to enjoy an excellent sailing day on Long Island Sound today.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- One of the remarkable aspects of the Middle East crisis has been the comparative silence of the American people and the almost total lack of debate on the whole thing in Congress.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Hesitantly and reluctantly the world is approaching a critical negotiation. Its ultimate objective would seem to be isolating the Middle East from war by neutralizing that area.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Lieut. Gen. James M. Gavin traded rhetorical punches today with Charles E. Wilson today and assailed the Administration's big-bomb defense policy.
STAMFORD, Conn., July 29 -- A new state statute permitting public transportation for pupils of nonprofit private schools will soon be invoked in Fairfield County.
SCHOOL is out now, but when it is in session, Albert Uswelk collects groups of high school boys and girls to tutor them in French in his taxicab.
The United Taxpayers party nominated candidates for the five top state offices at a convention here last night.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Federal Reserve System sees its recent intervention into the longer-term Government securities market as the exercise of an "escape clause" in standing policy, not an abandonment of that policy.
YONKERS, July 29 -- A grassroots survey here by political leaders indicated today that in a city of this size and character doorbell ringing is the most effective way to reach voters.
Webb Knapp, Inc., last year had a net income of $3,199,435, or slightly less than the 1956 net of $3,450,968, William Zeckendorf, president of the real estate concern, reported yesterday.
CHICAGO, July 29 (AP) -- Grain futures had good buying support today on the Board of Trade. All contracts moved up as demand because more general in the final few minutes of trading.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 29 -- The Greek and Turkish communities on Cyprus continued their sporadic intercommunal warfare today but at a much slower pace.
PARIS, July 29 -- Today's fashion collections confirmed the feeling for the high waist and significant shoulders and sleeves. Skirts dropped a little, and not a loose chemise was in sight.
LONDON, July 29 -- Despite Soviet objections, Britain plans to press for a United Nations Security Council meeting for a discussion of the Middle East crisis.

LONDON, July 29 -- Britain and the three Moslem members of the Baghdad Pact were said today to be considering recognition of the new regime in Iraq. An informed source said that they were moving toward recognition, but that no decision had been reached.

A self-help experiment in improving Negro high schools in the South may point the way to narrowing the gap between Negro and white students there, it was indicated yesterday in a report by the Phelps-Stokes Fund.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, July 29--President Francois Duvalier personally led his palace garrison today to crush a revolt after rebels had seized the army barracks here.

MANCHESTER, England, July 29 (Reuters) -- England beat New Zealand by an innings and thirteen runs in their fourth cricket test today. The final scores were New Zealand 267 and 85; England 365 for nine wickets declared.
The United Lutheran Church in America announced yesterday its opposition to the policy of the city's Department of Hospitals on contraception.

MOSCOW, July 29 (UPI) -- Russia today started preparing for next year's track meet against the United States in Philadelphia by sending a squad of women scientists to question American stars on their training methods.

MIDDLETON, Ohio, July 29 (AP) -- The Armco Steel Corporation announced a rise in prices on a dozen steel products today. The increases, which average 2.75 per cent, will go into effect Thursday. The announcement by Armco, the nation's seventh largest steel producer, brought this comment in Cleveland from Thomas F. Patton, president of the Republic Steel Corporation, the nation's third largest steel maker:
ALBANY, N. Y., July 29 -- (UPI) -- Economic conditions in New York State failed to improve in May after a slight rise in April, the State Department of Commerce reported yesterday.
The validity of a primary election slate of insurgent Democrats in Greenwich Village will be challenged in Supreme Court today by the established Democratic leadership of Tammany Hall.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 29 -- James J. Wadsworth, deputy United States representative, today paid his first call on Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold since President Eisenhower proposed a summit meeting under Security Council rule.

NORWALK, Conn., July 29 -- The increasing number of vehicles, especially trucks, whose drivers are avoiding the payment of tolls at the Norwalk toll station of the Connecticut Turnpike is alarming both city officials and the Chamber of Commerce.
BASRA, Iraq, July 28 -- Thieves have taken a holiday in Basra.

Two unusual and highly interesting events are on the auto racing program for Saturday. At Lime Rock, Conn., the second annual Little Le Mans ten-hour endurance race for small foreign production cars will be run. At Bridgehampton, L. I., for the first time, a 100-mile late-model stock car race will be run on the three-mile course built primarily for sports car contests.

HENRI TROYAT'S "The Red and the White," published in this country last July, was one of the best novels yet written about the Russian Revolution and civil war. A huge, sprawling and violent chronicle of battle, terror, misery and social upheaval, it was an impressively able work. But its sardonic detachment lessened its emotional impact.

It would be hard for North Americans to realize the shock that must have gone through the whole of Latin America yesterday when it was learned that American marines have gone into one of their countries. This is what happened in Cuba when marines were sent outside of Guantanamo Naval Base to guard its water supply on the Yateras River.
UPTON, L. I., July 29 -- The 1958 crops at the Brookhaven National Laboratory's "atomic farm" show the marked effect of growing in an atmosphere charged with powerful gamma rays.

TORONTO, July 29 -- A representative of Rothman's Ltd., British tobacco manufacturing company, said yesterday that it now felt that a link between smoking and lung cancer had been proven "beyond all reasonable doubt."
PITTSBURGH, July 29 (AP) -- Dr. Jonas Salk, developer of the poliomyelitis vaccine, confirmed today that he had been conducting experiments on cancer patients.
The Transit Authority thinks it has found the answer to its declining-revenue problem: Religion.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Administration released $150,000,000 more today to bring the total for the special anti-recession housing program to $750,000,000.
CAIRO, July 29--The Government began intensive diplomatic activity today to try to block the use of Western bases in Africa and Europe against the United Arab Republic.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 29 -- The man said "Maintenant nous commencons avec 'I Found a New Baby.'" And the program of jazz at the Brussels Fair sent here by the Newport Festival took off and began to soar.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 2 points (10 cents a bale) off to 44 points ($2.20 a bale) up yesterday, with the far months showing the most strength.

MIAMI BEACH, July 29 (AP) -- Bobby Boyd of Chicago scored a fourth-round technical knockout, and Jessie Bowdry of St. Louis scored an eighth-round technical knockout tonight in the double-feature fight card at the Miami Beach Auditorium.

PARIS, July 29 -- The finance and foreign ministers of seventeen European nations agreed today that their governments should act in concert to check the expected effects in Europe of the United States recession.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (UP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's statement on the space agency bill:
CANTON, N. Y., July 29--The state is drafting an experimental program that will move as many as 3,000 prisoners out of jails and into work camps and open institutions.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today the basic features of the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad's plan for eliminating its preferred stock and $110,722,830 in accumulated, unpaid dividends.
LONDON, July 29 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of the communique issued tonight after the Baghdad Pact ministerial council meeting here:

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 29 (AP) -- United States District Judge William E. Miller denied today former Representative Pat Sutton's motion for a new trial in a $25,000 libel decision. The decision granted the amount to Edward Lamb, a Toledo industrialist.

MUKHTARA, Lebanon, July 29 -- A Lebanese insurrection leader warned today that agreement by Parliament on a new President Thursday would not bring peace unless it were coupled with speedy withdrawal of United States forces.
Thomas J. Curran, long-time leader of the Manhattan Republican organization and a former New York Secretary of State, died at 12:30 P. M. yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 59 years old.

Louis J. Lefkowitz, Attorney General of New York State, reported yesterday that he had issued a list of sixty Canadian securities companies and brokers who have been enjoined from doing business in this state. The list was sent to the New York Stock Exchange, the American Stock Exchange, and the National Association of Securities Dealers.

MIAMI, July 29 (UPI) -- Customs agents seized sixteen men and a plane load of ammunition and supplies today for a 150-man expeditionary force. Officials thought the force may have been headed for the Dominican Republic in a move to overthrow the dictatorship of Generalissimo Rafael L. Trujillo.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The House Rules Committee approved for floor consideration today a bill to give former presidents of the United States $25,000 a year and other benefits. The measure passed the Senate last year.

Some 750 of the 1,200 marine engineers who had been striking against a group of Atlantic and Gulf Coast tanker operators since last Friday were back at work yesterday morning, a spokesman for the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association announced. The return freed about 125 strikebound tankers, he said.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The House of Representatives sent to the White House today a bill continuing Federal aid to school districts "impacted" with children of Federal employes, civilian or military.

Three patrolmen appeared before a Bronx grand jury yesterday. One was cleared and two others were indicted. The grand jury is investigating the theft of weapons and cash from the Bronx office of the Police Department Property Clerk.

IT is just about time for hunters to start going over their gear again, since the hunting season is only a couple of months away and many hunters have nothing else to do, except work. And it is one of the best ways in the world to exasperate wives.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- President Eisenhower made a new appeal today for more foreign aid money, pegging it to the Middle East crisis.
Prominent public figures and leaders of both major political parties joined in tributes yesterday on the death of Thomas J. Curran, Republican leader of New York County.

AN all-Verdi night yesterday at Lewisohn Stadium drew an audience of 12,000 to hear a group of tried-and-true numbers. Alfredo Antonini conducted the Stadium Symphony, and the vocal soloists were Roberta Peters, soprano; Claramae Turner, contralto; Jan Peerce, tenor, and Carl Palangi, bass-baritone.
A steady but modest pickup in both the steel business and the economy a sa whole during the rest of the year was forecast yesterday by the chairman of the United States Steel Corporation.

ALBANY, July 29 (AP) -- The State Land Board voted 2 to 1 today to turn over the $1,000,000 barge-canal terminal facilities at Oswego to the Oswego Port Authority for $1. The action followed a request by Governor Harriman yeserday.

Nelson A. Rockefeller picked up twenty more convention votes yesterday in his quest for the Republican nomination for Governor. The votes, from the northeast corner of the state, brought his total pledged support to 339 votes of the 586 needed for the nomination.

To the growing list of trade associations now comes the Mince Meat Institute, with the avowed purpose of nurturing the tradition of enjoying mince pie. This seemingly minor bit of news is of interest to more than the food industry.
The First National Bank of Boston, which has one of the largest bank bookkeeping operations under one roof in the United States, has put to work a $1,750,000 electronic "moron."

WARSAW, July 29 -- The Polish Government and the Communist party publicly recognized today the rapidly deepening rift between the state and the Roman Catholic Church. Two major political attacks were directed against church authorities.
MADISON, N. J., July 29 -- Chester Sanok of Upper Montclair won the medal in the New Jersey qualifying round for the Metropolitan amateur title golf tournament at the Braidburn Country Club today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 29 (AP) -- Wally Post hit a pinch double to left field to score Chico Fernandez in the eleventh inning as the Philadelphia Phillies edged the St. Louis Cardinals, 3 -- 2, tonight in a regularly scheduled game. Earlier in the evening, the Cards won, 3 -- 2, in a month-old suspended contest.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 29 -- Mayor and Mrs. Wagner of New York and their 13-year-old son, Robert Jr., started a California vacation today with a tour of the Twentieth Century-Fox studio as guests of Buddy Adler, executive producer.
Censorship is continuing on dispatches from Jordan, Iraq, Egypt and Lebanon, The Associated Press reported yesterday.
Shipbuilding throughout the world continues to set peacetime production records, but new orders are not keeping up the previous pace.
BABY sitters, tired business men and the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad owe more than they know to a woman named Lenore Tobin.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 29 -- The first in a series of six public hearings on proposals for the state Democratic platform of 1958 was held here today.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- A Congressional investigating committee recommended action today against Bernard Goldfine for contempt of Congress.
GRAYLING, Mich., July 29 (AP) -- Records fell in all but one division in the first field round of the national field archery tournament today.
ATLANTA, July 29 (AP) -- Efforts of a Congressional committee to uncover Communist party connections in the South were balked repeatedly today by witnesses who refused to answer questions.
BELLPORT, L. I., July 29 -- The second day of the Cruise Week regatta of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association had ideal sailing weather.

GENEVA, July 29 -- Dr. Ernest O. Lawrence, one of the three United States delegates to the East-West technical talks on detection of atomic tests, left by plane for the United States tonight because of illness.

THE busiest auction center in Manhattan has nothing to do with Aubusson rugs, Chippendale chairs, grandfather clocks or tobacco. It concerns itself with the most perishable of produce--fresh fruit, which arrives at Pier 29 on the lower West Side while most of the city sleeps.

PARIS, July 29 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle began today the second phase of France's transformation from the Fourth to the Fifth Republic by turning over the draft of the new Constitution to a consultative committee.
LITTLE ROCK, July 29 -- Gov. Orval E. Faubus won a third two-year term today and overwhelming endorsement of his defiant stand against the Federal courts in the school integration controversy.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Administration outlined its fallout shelter program to the Senate Appropriations Committee today and sought $13,150,000 for construction of prototype shelters, architectural and engineering research and public education on the fall-out hazard.
The Philadelphia Electric Company reported yesterday increases in operating revenues and net income for the six and twelve months ended June 30.

Despite strength for aircrafts and drugs, the stock market was unable to continue its advance yesterday for an eleventh day. Nonferrous metals, motors, chemicals, oils, building and business equipment stocks were notably weak.
Borough President James J. Crisona of Queens was reported yesterday to be a probable bipartisan choice for one of seven new places on the Supreme Court in the Tenth Judicial District.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- The airlines today dropped into the lap of the Civil Aeronautics Board their quarrel over the "no-show" problem -- the failure of passengers to cancel or use their reserved seat space.
High preferred dividends suffered another casualty yesterday. Stockholders of Deere Co. voted at a special meeting to change the farm equipment maker's capital structure.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP)--United States Senators clamoring to keep major league baseball in Washington were challenged today to agree to subsidize a team if it lost money.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) -- Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, announced today the apportionment of $33,000,000 in Federal aid for improving roads in and near national forests.
JERUSALEM (Israel sector), July 29 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion warned the major powers today that any attempt to truncate Israel's territory would be resisted by armed force.
TRENTON, July 29 -- Nine major railroads lost an appeal for a moratorium on their 1958 taxes in this state tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Senate overrode its Agriculture Committee tonight and adopted a bill providing for a Federal code of humane slaughtering of livestock.
New York City has borrowed $50,000,000 on tax anticipation notes bearing 1 1/2 per cent interest, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Now that United States Marines are well-established in Lebanon, the United States Government is searching for a way to get them out again.
CAIRO, July 29 (Reuters) -- The Education Minister of Kuwait, oil-rich British-protected sheikdom, said here today that Kuwait had decided to increase its intake of Egyptian schoolteachers.

The Atlantic Refining Company reported yesterday a net income of $7,667,000, or 78 cents a common share, for the first half. This compared with $25,322,000, or $2.74 a share, in the first half of 1957.

Sales and earnings of the Borden Company in the first half of this year were exceeded only by those of the corresponding period last year. Harold W. Comfort, president of the nation's second largest dairy products company, predicted a "good" year.

There have been few countries in the world so tormented in the last few years as Haiti. Another uprising -- the third attempt in nine months against the regime of President Francois Duvalier -- was put down yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 29 (AP) -- Milwaukee real estate man sued the Blatz Brewing Company today for $4,250,000 and an accounting, charging breach of a contract under which the beer company used a secret process he had developed.

PREMIER AMINTORE FANFANI of Italy, who addressed Congress yesterday, is called admiringly "il motorino" -- the little motor. Cartoonist like to picture him as the Napoleon of the Christian Democratic party.

EAST HAMPTON, L. I., July 29 -- The annual "Village Vanities," staged by theatrically inclined members of the summer colony in cooperation with local residents as a benefit for Guild Hall, will be held here in the John Drew Theatre, Guild Hall, the last four evenings in August.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 29 -- American technicians who had been working with Iraqi Government departments under the United States foreign aid program have been authorized to return to their jobs when requested to do so by the new authorities.

Exports of American books are not economically a large item in our foreign trade. In 1956, for example, the exports to the Middle East, Central Africa and Asia amounted to about five and a half million dollars, of which a little less than half were textbooks. Yet what these books do for the good name of the United States cannot be measured in terms of dollars.
The American Can Company showed a 19.4 per cent decline in earnings in the second quarter on a drop of 3.6 per cent in sales from a year ago.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Senate general labor bill appeared headed for certain death in the House Labor Committee today and one of its authors charged that the National Association of Manufacturers was spearheading a drive to kill it.
The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation had record first-half volume this year with sales of $465,735,000. Earnings rose 29 per cent above those of the 1957 first half, it was disclosed yesterday.

SAN PEDRO, July 29 (UPI) -- An irate service station proprietor, who feels "its a shame the Los Angeles Dodgers are in last place," today admitted to police that he was responsible for hanging the team manager, Walt Alston, in effigy in front of his station.

The college professor is the subject of a study entitled "The Academic Mind," by Paul F. Lazarsfeld and Wagner Thielens. It will be published in October by the Free Press of Glencoe, Ill. The volume is based on thousands of interviews conducted on campuses throughout this country.

Earnings and sales of General Motors Corporation in the second quarter declined from the first quarter and from the year-ago levels. The drop, however, was less than for the automobile industry as a whole and considerably less than those of the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation, the other two members of the "Big Three."
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 29 -- Premier Sami es-Solh narrowly escaped death in a bomb explosion here this morning. At least six persons were killed, but the Premier was only shaken up.
Lower earnings and a reduced dividend were announced yesterday by Burlington Industries, Inc., a leading manufacturer of textiles.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- Prof. Amintore Fanfani, Premier and Foreign Minister of Italy, told Congress today that his country would join in endeavors to increase freedom and prosperity in the troubled Middle East.

Heavy liquidation in September futures depressed cocoa prices on the New York Cocoa Exchange yesterday. An expectation of large cocoa production induced the selling. Final prices were down 17 to 58 points (hundredths of a cent a pound).
NEWARK, July 29 (AP) -- A Maplewood lodge pleaded guilty tonight to attempting to compel a raffle winner to kick back $500.

Organized labor has told state Democratic leaders that it wants Mayor Wagner as the party's candidate for the United States Senate. This statement was made at a recent unpublicized meeting with Carmine G. De Sapio, New York County Democratic leader, and Michael H. Prendergast, Democratic state chairman.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI) -- Legislation to grant special tax relief to self-employed persons building retirement funds was passed by the House today. The Administration had protested that it would cost $360,000,000 a year.
The fortieth annual state convention of the American Legion will open here this afternoon.
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- The Committee for Economic Development said today the nation could afford a defense budget of at least $60,000,000,000 without economic damage.
BOSTON, July 29 -- Following is the text of a statement today by Samuel P. Sears and Lawrence R. Cohen, attorneys for Bernard Goldfine:
ALAMOGORDO, N. M., July 29 (AP) -- One of the world's most eminent psychologists reports that unidentified flying objects are not quirks of imagination.
Six thousand Jehovah's Witnesses will be baptized by complete immersion today at Orchard Beach in the northeast corner of the Bronx.

LONDON, July 29 -- The recent dullness persisted in the stock market today, although many issues closed above the day's lowest levels. Most of the changes were only a few pence, but the weakness encompassed most of the principal sections.

An office floor in the new Canada House rising at 680 Fifth Avenue at Fifty-fourth Street has been leased by United Printers and Publishers, Inc. The company will move its executive offices to the quarters from Joliet, Ill., and Chicago.

As an Arabic student in the United States I would like to point out that the Arab people and the people of the West have always had friendly relations. In two world wars they fought together. The Western powers used our country, and our people supplied them with men and materials, in the hope that they would help our cause of unity.

In your issue of July 28 Richard D. Robinson (an authority on modern Turkey) has drawn a remarkable picture of the Egyptian military dictator: closely identified with genuine social and economic reform, desirous of Western economic and military aid, sternly repressive of domestic communism.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 29 -- Hamilton Richardson lost a set today as every member of the favored array advanced to the round of sixteen in the Southampton invitation tennis tournament at the Meadow Club.

SHELTER ISLAND, L. I., July 29--Commodore Carl Hovgard's fleet flagship, Circe, and Fred Lorenzen's fiberglass yawl, Seal, were division winners in the twenty-seventh American Y. C. cruise for the second straight race today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 29 -- The bullet that killed Lieut. Col. George A. Flint on Mount Scopus near Jerusalem last May 26 was fired from Jordanian - controlled territory, it was reported here today.
The annual shareholders meeting of Sperry Rand Corporation was marked by general dissatisfaction yesterday over the price of the company's stock and the present state of its business.
The Republic Aviation Corporation announced yesterday a $35,000,000 program of research and development in the new field of astronautics.

To be a prominent political figure in the Middle East is to live dangerously. The statement has been proved many times over in many countries of the area, most recently in Iraq and again, yesterday, in Lebanon. The attempted assassination of Lebanon's Premier, Sami es-Solh, which left in its bloody wake the tragic bodies of a number of innocent victims, is a case in point.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) -- The House passed without explanation or debate today a Senate bill to let steamship companies continue for two more years a dual rate system that was held illegal by the Supreme Court on May 19.

Spider Webb had his hands full with Franz Szuzina of Germany until the seventh round last night. Then, with one long right and a flurry of follow-up close-range punches, he stopped Szuzina in the main event at Madison Square Garden.

THE Columbia Broadcasting System presented last night another superior program of background material on the Middle East crisis. It was an analysis of the rising tide of Arab nationalism and bluntly stressed the need for the United States to develop some consistent policy with respect to the realities of life in the Mediterranean area.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 30 -- Tom Munnell of the Pequot Yacht Club scored another easy triumph in Division I of the Lightning class today. He sailed home first aboard MC-2 as the Riverside Yacht Club took over the chores of staging the Eastern Junior Race Week open regatta.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) -- The Senate Antitrust Subcommittee was requested today to add harness racing to a bill to exempt professional team sports from Federal antitrust laws.
American Airlines is committed to spend $365,000,000 over the next four years to acquire the world's largest fleet of jets and turbo-prop planes.
Six thousand off-street parking spaces in midtown Manhattan for short-term parkers were urged yesterday at a meeting of city officials and business men.
Plans for a $2,000,000 building to house both student nurses and X-ray and operating suites were announced yesterday by Beth Israel Hospital.

Judah Wattenberg sold the six-story apartment house for ninety-four families at 43-31 Forty-fifth Street, Sunnyside, Queens. The buyer was an investing client of Leepson Rubman, attorneys. The property of 200 by 100 feet was sold for cash over mortgages of $370,000.
As a Kurd from the northern part of Iraq I would like to make a few comments on the statements by the Iranian Deputy Premier, Brig. Gen. Timur Bakhtian, in The Times of July 26.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 30 (AP) -- Final papers for the San Francisco Giants' pear-shaped baseball stadium were signed today after a minor hassle threatened a delay in starting the 45,000-seat layout.

Jackie Gleason will star in William Saroyan's "The Time of Your Life" on Oct. 9 from 9:30 to 11 P. M. over the Columbia Broadcasting System television network. The comedy will be featured on "Playhouse 90."

KALAMAZOO, Mich., July 30 (AP) -- Martin Riessen of Hinsdale, Ill., scored a third-round upset in the national junior and boys' tennis championships today when he defeated Jim Shaffer, the fourth-ranked junior from St. Petersburg, Fla., 2 -- 6, 6 -- 0, 11 -- 9.

DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, July 30 (AP) -- A military spokesman for the United Arab Republic said Turkish soldiers fought Syrian border guards today for fifteen minutes just inside Syria and then took up hill positions in Turkey. The Turks were in a small military vehicle, he said.

CINCINNATI, July 30 (AP) -- Bob Purkey yielded only five hits and knocked in two runs with a single tonight as the Redlegs whipped the San Francisco Giants, 5 -- 1, and knocked them out of first place in the National League. Walt Dropo and Pete Whisenant hit home runs for the Redlegs.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 30 --Tile Evening Guild of the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich will sponsor its tenth annual fashion show on Sept. 29 at Ekman Center.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 30 -- The National Orchestra of Spain, which played here tonight as part of its country's World's Fair observances, is one of the better ensembles of Europe. It is well disciplined; its choirs are agreeably balanced; it plays with glowing warmth of tone.
Federal officials will swarm over the Norwegian freighter Tancred when she arrives today from the Far East via the West Coast.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 30 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold suspended the leaves of key United Nations personnel today pending a decision on the organization's role in the proposed summit talks.
Down in Cut 'n' Shoot in Texas, "they drown cowards."
CANTON, N. Y., July 30 -- A tough policy by the State Parole Board is keeping nearly one convict in ten behind bars after he is eligible for parole.
KANSAS CITY, July 30 -- Whether Casey Stengel's sixty-eighth birthday was his happiest could not be ascertained immediately tonight. But it must have been one of the wettest of his career.
About 1,000 friends of the late Thomas J. Curran paid their respects yesterday to the former New York County Republican chairman at Reddin's Funeral Home, 325 West Fourteenth Street.

Commodity prices were generally firm in dull trading on the New York exchanges yesterday. Cocoa, copper, lead, rubber, tin and zinc rose; cottonseed, soybean oil and hides declined, and coffee, sugar, wool and potatoes were mixed.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 30 -- A United States legislator urged today that the countries of the Soviet bloc be given an opportunity to determine their form of government under the United Nations. The proposal was made by Representative Michael A. Feighan, Democrat of Ohio, at the Inter-Parliamentary Union's conference here.

PELHAM, N. Y., July 30 -- Thomas J. Goodwin of the Westchester Country Club won the qualifying medal in the thirty-eighth annual Westchester amateur golf championship at the Pelham Country Club today.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- The Senate Finance Committee approved and sent to the Senate today a group of House-passed bills dealing with veterans' benefits. Included were measures to:
GUILDERLAND, N. Y., July 30 -- A twelve-foot-long bridge over Normanskill Creek has caused a "cold war" between the town of Guilderland and Albany County and involved the United States Army.
STANDING room only was the order of the day at Altman's yesterday. The attraction was a demonstration by Houn Ohara of the art of Japanese flower arrangements.

Chief of Detectives James B. Leggett said yesterday that there has been no communication between the police of New York and Rome concerning the activities of Charles (Lucky) Luciano and two hoodlums recently murdered here.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 30 -- With New York metropolitan racing suspended until the Saratoga season ends late in August, the seven-day "Jamaica-at-Monmouth" meeting got under way today with an overnight jump of 5,878 in attendance and a mutuel handle increase of $670,593.
ALBUQUERQUE, July 30 (AP) -- The Albuquerque Tribune reported today the locations of seven atomic weapons storage sites in the United States.

MOSCOW, July 30 -- The scientists in charge of the International Geophysical Year were trying to figure out here today what to do with their complex and costly machinery for worldwide scientific cooperation when the eighteen months' "year" ends next Dec. 31.

Broadway has made another incursion into the television field for directorial talent. The latest involves Ralph Nelson, who has been signed by the Producers Theatre to stage "The Man in the Dog Suit," the comedy by Albert Beich and William H. Wright.
A report that state and city labor officials had told Democratic leaders they wanted Mayor Wagner as the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate created a broad stir yesterday.
Today is the last day to mail a letter for 3 cents.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The State Department said today that the small detachment of marines guarding the water supply of the United States base at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, would be withdrawn as soon as possible.
Two men were indicted by a Federal grand jury yesterday on charges of using the mails to defraud the public of $2,300,000 in stock transactions.
GENEVA, July 30 -- The East-West conference of scientific experts began consideration today of an over-all detection system to police a cessation of the testing of nuclear weapons.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaya, July 30 -- The Federal Legislative Council gave the Government authority today to continue for another year the emergency regulations under which the anti-Communist war is being fought.

FREEHOLD, N. J., July 30 -- Freehold Raceway, 106 years old, presented for inspection today an extension of its modernized concrete and steel grandstand. It increases the over-all seating capacity of New Jersey's only pari-mutuel harness racing plant to 3,500.

WARSAW, July 30 -- The Polish Government has called high authorities of the Roman Catholic Church to a special conference here tomorrow on the critically sharp relations between the church and the Communist regime.
The Estate Securities Company, realty operator, contracted to buy the six-story apartment building at 3750 Broadway, southeast corner of West 156th Street, from the 3750 Realty Corporation.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Senate and House approved today a compromise version of a bill to aid railroads and revise the Federal law on transportation regulation. The bill now goes to the White House.

PHILADELPHIA, July 30 (UPI) -- Gwyneth Thomas of Shaker Heights, Ohio, and Belmar Gunderson of Chambersburg, Pa., reached the semifinals of the Philadelphia grass courts tennis championships today at the Germantown Cricket Club.
GRAMMAR school pupils will use the same fashion vocabulary this fall that their mothers began to use last year, if Gimbels calls the tune. It offers them the chemise, trapeze and Empire fashions.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 8 to 58 points yesterday, with the far months weakest. A point the far months weakest (A point equals 5 cents a bale).

The Pabst Brewing Company has acquired the Blatz Brewing Company for upwards of $14,500,000. Pabst and Blatz two of the oldest names in brewing, together sell 4,000,000 barrels a year. Announcement of the merger, which had been rumored for several weeks, was made jointly yesterday by Harris Perstein, chairman and president of Pabst, and James C. Windham, president of Blatz.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities showed that, in the week ended Wednesday, July 23, there were:

WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) -- The House Veterans Committee approved a bill today to limit free hospital care for veterans whose ailments were not the result of military service and who could afford private treatment.
THE following is one way to prepare for a salmon trip to the Gander River in Newfoundland. If it is the right way everything is going to be all right.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 30 -- Lebanese political circles did not know tonight whether Parliament would meet tomorrow as scheduled to elect a new President of the republic. There was a strong possibility that the election might be put off indefinitely by lack of a quorum, leaving the long crisis unresolved.
The Waterfront Commission yesterday ended a hearing into an alleged "phantom" racket on the piers in the Red Hook and Greenpoint sections of Brooklyn.

ATLANTA, July 30 (AP) -- A Montgomery, Ala., Negro insurance man, called a "dedicated zealot of the Communist movement," tried unsuccessfully today to turn a Congressional committee hearing on un American activities into a discussion of mistreatment of Negroes in the South.

Ebasco Services, Inc., engineering and financial consultant, has been hired by the United States International Cooperation Administration to help two Iranian Govern ment banks to stimulate private enterprise. The I. C. A. will lend $23,000,000 to the banks, it is understood.

A decline of 648,000 barrels in the nation's stocks of gasoline for the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. Supplies were 178,808,000 barrels, compared with 179,556,000 a week earlier and 175,698,000 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, jabbed at Democratic Congressional leaders today for what he called their surrender in the fight for a labor reform bill. He also criticized the National Association of Manufacturers and the Chamber of Commerce for their opposition to the Kennedy-Ives bill.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., July 30 (AP) -- Hepburn T. Armstrong, candidate for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator, today urged Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt to stop sending campaign contributions to Gale McGee, his opponent, in the Aug. 19 primary.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- United States officials worked today on plans to make sure that the prospective heads-of-government meeting would not lead to a Soviet political and propaganda break-through in the Middle East.
Twenty-five leaders of the two main branches of the Baptist faith in the metropolitan area decided yesterday to consider closer cooperation here.

KANSAS CITY, July 30 (AP) -- The New York Yankees' manager, Casey Stengel, today labeled the San Francisco Giants a "freak" team. He said it was impossible to build a club from the bottom to a pennant in one year.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- The House Interior Committee refused today to kill the Hawaii statehood bill.

NAHA, Okinawa, July 30 (AP) -- The United States offered today to abandon its controversial system of land-holding in the Ryukyu Islands for the strongest United States military base in the Far East if a better system could be found.
A 21-year-old paraplegic was arrested early yesterday for assertedly assisting in a Queens burglary. He was accused of having used his specially equipped vehicle as a getaway car.
TEANECK, N. J., July 30 -- Merrill Poliakoff, 11 years old, was killed here this afternoon while experimenting with rocket propulsion on a toy automobile.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, July 30 -- A dozen former Army officers were reported today to have been taken into custody following yesterday's unsuccessful effort at revolt.
CHICAGO, July 30 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) -- The House Public Works Committee ignored President Eisenhower's wishes today by stamping approval on a bill to permit the Tennessee Valley Authority to finance new power plants through bond sales.

In the rush of world events little or no attention was paid to a belated act of justice on the part of the Attorney General in removing the name of the Independent Socialist League and certain related organizations from his list of subversive organizations. Satisfaction in this act is tempered by the reflection that it cost ten years of expensive struggle. And the list itself lives on.
MOBILE, Ala., July 30 (AP) -- An immigration official Interviewed a Polish seaman seeking political asylum and then flew back to Washington today before newsmen could reach him.
The post of director of science for the city school system, which has never been filled since it was created in 1953, may be filled next month.
Negotiations for the exchange of American and Soviet films, which were broken off in Washington last April, will be resumed in Moscow early in September.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- A House inquiry was told today that millions of dollars could be saved if the armed services made better use of equipment.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The House Ways and Means Committee approved legislation today to increase the temporary ceiling on the national debt to $288,000,000,000 and the permanent ceiling to $285,000,000,000.
Mayor Wagner has promised State Democratic leaders that he will attempt to refute reports that this city is contemplating either a payroll or city income tax.

Two books about the Middle East are planned for publication soon. Bookman Associates has scheduled for early fall release "Islam and the Modern Age," by Ilse Lichtenstadter, and "Temperament and Character of the Arabs," by Sania Hamady.
PARIS, July 30 -- The French Government was still opposed today to a summit meeting within the framework of the United Nations Security Council.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 30 -- Neutral Sweden appeared today to be moving toward deciding to acquire tactual nuclear weapons.

France's Fourth Republic is fading away. With the publication in Paris Tuesday of the draft of a new Constitution the Fifth Republic looms large on the horizon. A consultative committee is studying the document and the nation will vote on it in the early autumn.

A great deal of justifiable and growing concern has been evidenced recently by our city planners, merchants' associations and ordinary citizens in the traffic and accompanying parking problems that confront our midtown business sections and our outlying districts. No such concern seems to be evident, however, with respect to other parts of our city.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The Senate passed tonight a $40,000,000,000 defense appropriation bill reflecting rising Congressional doubt about the nation's capacity to fight limited war.

HAVANA, July 30 -- Fidel Castro, rebel leader, has demanded over his radio station the withdrawal of United States Marines sent into Cuban territory to guard the water supply of the United States Guantanamo Naval Base.
The good ship Hudson Belle. which daily carries New York racing fans to the vicinity of the Monmouth track in New Jersey, was left at the post yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 30. -- Italian Premier Amintore Fanfani supported today President Eisenhower's demand that any summit conference on the Middle East be kept within the framework of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- The Labor Department said today that it had worked out an agreement under which Mexican farm laborers in this country would get "fair wages" without depressing the earnings of American workers.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 30 -- Premier David Ben-Gurion is asking the Western allies and the Soviet Union to arrange a meeting between himself and President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic.

MOSCOW, July 30 -- The Soviet Government said tonight that the Western powers were planning to attack Iraq and said that if that happened "other peace-loving people will go to the aid of the victim of aggression."
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Following is the text of a statement today by James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, on the status of labor legislation:
WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today for $125,000,000 to help start a new civilian-directed agency on a program to conquer outer space.

GRAYLING, Mich., Jully 30 (AP) -- The defending champion, Ann Marston of Wyandotte, Mich., moved up to first place today in the second round of the women's free-style division of the national field archery tournament. Sights are used in free-style archery.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 30 -- The capitalist of harness racing, William Robert Haughton, will be seeking to end the season at Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night in grand style. Haughton, the country's leading driver for the past six years, will compete in eight of the nine races on the final night of racing here.

The Long Island Lighting Company reported yesterday a gain of 12.1 per cent in gross revenues for the twelve months ended June 30. Net income for the period increased 12.7 per cent from the corresponding 1957 period.
DETROIT, July 30 (AP) -- An unauthorized strike closed two General Motors plants here today.
The Baghdad Pact's new streamlined look -- minus Baghdad -- adds a legal and written commitment for the United States to a tacit and moral one.

Thirteen summer students at City College took a trip to Roosevelt Raceway Tuesday night to study the mathematics of the $2 bet. Comparing notes in their classrooms last night, they decided it was easier to calculate the odds on a horse race than to pick a winner.

Walter Gropius and Pietro Belluschi, leaders of the modern school of architecture, will collaborate with a local firm in the design of a fifty-story sky-scraper to be built at the rear of Grand Central Terminal.

Studebaker-Packard Corporation common climbed to the top of the most active list on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday amid a spate of rumors concerning new management, mergers, a new car and refinancing.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- The Government said today that the admission of Alaska as a state would shift the geographic center of the United States from Kansas to South Dakota.

AT midnight one week from today, the crayfish season opens in Sweden. On the following night, one of the most colorful of gastronomic festivals will begin in that nation's homes, gardens and restaurants. The occasion is known as Krafttidden, or crayfish time, and is celebrated until the end of September.

SAYVILLE, L. I., July 30 -- The lack of serious protests and an eighteen-to-twenty-mile-an-hour so'wester made things right today with the fleet competing in the annual Cruise Week of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association.
STAMFORD, Conn, July 30 -- Merchants here and in Greenwich are losing money because residents are shopping in neighboring New York State to avoid the 3 per cent sales tax imposed in Connecticut.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Senator Joseph C. O'Mahoney, Democrat of Wyoming, today resumed his attack on the Government's plans for letting the oil industry handle emergency needs that might result from a Middle Eastern oil cut-off.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 30 -- The explosion of an oil tank caused great confusion here today.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., July 30 (AP) -- The Providence chapter of Sweet Adelines, Inc., announced today its withdrawal from the international singing organization, contending that changes in the by-laws excluded Negroes from membership.
CHICAGO, July 30 -- Chicago welcomed today Prime Minister Kwame Nkrumah of Ghana.

SCRANTON, Pa., July 30 (AP) -- Lackawanna County Judge Otto P. Robinson sentenced four Scranton labor union leaders to prison terms today for having conspired to damage a house being erected by non-union workers. Each will serve one to two years.

A $4,000,000 advertising program for Eversharp-Schick safety razors has been scheduled in all media. This is the first program to emerge from Compton Advertising, Inc., recently appointed by Eversharp, Inc.

AMMAN, Jordan, July 30 -- Robert Murphy, President Eisenhower's special representative in the Middle East, arrived here by air from Beirut, Lebanon, today for an overnight conference at the invitation of the Jordanian Government.

John C. Doyle, president of Canadian Javelin, Ltd., of Montreal, disclosed yesterday that he had met here with an official of the Securities and Exchange Commission to try to "clarify" the agency's reasons for banning the company's stock.
A shouting crowd of 300 gathered on the street in front of the West 123d Street police station in Harlem early today in a protest of what they thought was police brutality.

Against the explosive background of a continuing crisis in the Middle East President Eisenhower has made a new appeal to Congress for adequate mutual security funds to bolster allied and friendly nations in that vital area. He has asked in particular for a restoration of more than half a billion dollars of the $872,000,000 slashed from his original "foreign aid" request.
Strains of popular music attracted hundreds of visitors to Madison Square Park, on Fifth Avenue between Twenty-third and Twenty-sixth Streets, at noon yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 30 -- The Berkshire Music Festival, which has become a leading summer music event since its establishment in 1936, will be the basis for a motion picture. The film will be produced by Twentieth Century-Fox with the cooperation of the Boston Symphony Orchestra and its conductor, Charles Munch.
The Wagner administration ruled out yesterday any possibility that it might turn over the city's piers to the Port Authority for modernization and operation.
LONDON, July 30 -- Pakistan and Iran recognized the new revolutionary regime in Iraq today. Turkey was expected to follow suit at once and Britain in a day or two.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The protest, implicit in the large majority vote cast for the renomination of Governor Faubus in the Arkansas Democratic primary, against Federally-decreed-and-enforced racial integration in the public schools of states with segregation laws was anticipated by the Executive department. But the consequences of something which is likely to happen have an unrealistic quality, and it requires the event before the consequences are weighed on the scales of reality.
In a few years many cities may compel motorists to control the exhaust fumes of their cars, Dr. Leonard Greenburg, city Commissioner of Air Pollution Control, said yesterday.

With a precision that would do justice to the military, 7,136 Jehovah's Witnesses were baptized by total immersion yesterday in a two-and-a-half-hour ceremony. The mass baptism was conducted at Orchard Beach in the Bronx under almost cloudless skies.
NEWARK, July 30 -- Thirty-five persons were injured when a trolley car struck a second car in an open cut of the city subway system at 5:20 P. M. today during the peak of the evening rush hour.

ROME, July 30 (AP) -- Miss Frances V. Opavsky, 38 years] old, of San Francisco, a secre-] tary at the United States ,,mibassy in Rome, died yesterday of injuries suffered in an auto-] mobile accident. I

ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 30 (UPI) -- St. Louis Democratic leaders were disappointed with Senator Stuart Symington, Democrat of Missouri, today. His eye-catching campaign posters do not mention that he is a Democrat.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The continuing rush of people to California is expected to give the state seven more seats in Congress after the 1960 census. That is the same number California picked up after 1950.
CROSBY, Minn., July 30 (AP) -- An attempt to set an altitude record with a huge balloon failed today when the polyethelene bag blew out.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) -- The April-May-June retail cost of a "market basket" of farm-produced foods was 8 per cent higher than in the same period last year, the Agriculture Department reported today.

These menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are designed to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
Ohio is planning to sell another issue of highway construction bonds on Sept. 17. The borrowing will total $30,000,000.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Manufacturers' new orders picked up sharply in June over May, which was revised upward, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Food Fair Stores, Inc., celebrated its silver anniversary with record sales and earnings for the fiscal year ended April 26. The nation's sixth largest food chain operates 300 supermarkets in eight states from Connecticut to Florida.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican of Vermont, said today that Middle Eastern assassinations would go on "so long as the Western nations appear as the champions of Zionism."
MOSCOW, July 30 -- The Soviet Union charged today that a United States plane from Iran had deliberately violated Soviet air space over the Caspian Sea and been forced to flee.

LONDON, July 30 -- Reginald Maudling, British Paymaster General, said today that he was very hopeful of the attainment of substantial agreement by the year's end on the framework of a treaty establishing a European free-trade area.
Many cities and villages that are making efforts to eliminate slums are failing to prevent other parts of their communities from becoming new slums, the State Housing Commissioner said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) -- Contempt action against Bernard Goldfine bogged down briefly today in paperwork.
LONDON, July 30 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan has asked the Greek and Turkish Premiers to join with him in appealing to Greek and Turkish Cypriotes to stem the wave of violence sweeping Cyprus.

Three more major steel producers announced price increases averaging about $4.50 a ton on important products yesterday. This added support to the widespread view in the industry that an across-the-board price advance was assured.

Spreading price increases by steel producers practically stampeded the stock market in its closing hours yesterday. Shorts rushed to cover, prices of steel stocks soared and the final thirty minutes of trading on the New York Stock Exchange saw a volume of 750,000 shares.

Cuban rebels have returned a pistol taken from a United: States /q'avy sentry July 16 at the Guantanamo Bay base in Cuba, with an apology and report of punishment for the rebel involved. Tom Costigan, Columbia Broadcasting System correspondent, reported yesterday receiving copies of the rebel and Navy letters closing the incident.
PARIS, July 30 -- Widespread criticism and little enthusiasm greeted today the text cf the draft Constitution that the Government of General Charles de Gaulle placed in the public domain yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- The Senate confirmed unanimously today President Eisenhower's appointment of five delegates and five alternates to the United Nations thirteenth General Assembly.
