One critic of the farm bill now pending in the Senate -- a measure espoused by the American Farm Bureau Federation and endorsed at least lukewarmly by the Administration -- has declared that if passed it will "repeal the heart and soul of the New Deal farm program."
CHICAGO, July 30 (AP) -- Grain dealings dragged along at an unusually slow pace today and most prices on the Board of Trade finished within very small fractions of where they started.
ROME, July 30 -- Concern over renewed church-state tension in Poland was voiced in the Vatican today.
BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I., July 30 -- State Housing Commissioner Joseph P. McMurray today recommended a coordinated public housing, slum clearance and redevelopment program for part of this village.

Prices of Treasury securities rose decisively yesterday for the first time in more than a week. Although limited to 3/8 point, the gains were in all parts of the list, reflecting a substantial improvement in market sentiment. For the fourth successive session, the Federal Reserve was aloof of the market.

The Skelly Oil Company reported a net income yesterday of $10,548,955, or $1.83 a share, for the six months to June 30. This compared with $19,933,551, or $3.46 a share, in the similar 1957 period. Gross income dropped to $123,285,697 from $133,530,801.

BROOKFIELD CENTER, Conn., July 30 -- The annual Friendship Fair of St. Paul's Protestant Episcopal Church here will be held on Saturday, starting at 11 A. M. Walter Hatcher is general chairman of the fair and Robert E. French is vice chairman.

"CLARENCE KING,"* by Thurman Wilkins, is a remarkable biography about a remarkable American. He flourished in the turbulent era of late nineteenth-century America when the pioneer was giving way to the promoter, according to popular legend, and Henry Adams was conducting his enthusiastically pessimistic education among gold bricks of all sizes and varieties.

Arnold Weinstein bought the six-story apartment house at 3225 Olinville Avenue in the Pelham Parkway district of the Bronx for cash over mortgages amounting to $240,000. The building contains fifty - four apartments.

WHITE PLAINS, July 30 -- The Sonotone Corporation reported today that it would move from Westchester County to an area with lower wages and taxes. The company has been in the county twenty years and is one of its biggest employers.

HARNESS racing is about to click off another milestone in its amazing progress as one of America's most fascinating sports. Tomorrow night the spotlight will be on the remodeled Yonkers Raceway, a fabulous $18,000,000 plant said to provide the last word in convenience and comfort.
FITCHBURG, Mass., July 30 (UPI) -- The three co-medalists were eliminated and the defending champion barely survived in the New England amateur golf tournament today.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- The House of Representatives voted 165 to 45 today to give $25,000-a-year pensions to former Presidents of the United States, and $10,000 annually to their widows. The annuities would be taxable.
LONDON, July 30 -- Britain's reply to Premier Khrushchev's latest note on the projected high-level meeting to discuss Middle Eastern problems will be delivered tomorrow.
FLINT, Mich., July 30 -- Buick unveiled its "comeback" car today to open the 1959 model year.
SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 30 -- Ronald Holmberg was beaten in the Southampton invitation tennis tournament at the Meadow Club today to become the first big casualty of the week.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 30 (Reuters) -- The chief of the General Staff, Col. Gen-Vaclav Kratochvil, has been removed from office, it was reported today.

Today's new film is "A Certain Smile," Twentieth Century-Fox' version of the novel by Francoise Sagan, with Rossano Brazzi, Joan Fontaine, Bradford Dillman and Christine Carere, at the Paramount, Broadway at Forty-third Street. Henry Ephron produced, in color and CinemaScope, and Jean Negulesco directed, from a screen play by Frances and Albert Hackett.

WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Graham Arthur Barden, a Representative from North Carolina since 1936, is a man without a hurry in the world. This characteristic of the chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee was in the news today as he made his explanations for the demise of major labor reform legislation in this session.

CHICAGO, July 30 (AP) -- International Harvester Company and the United Auto Workers agreed tonight to an indefinite extension of their main labor contract, pension and health security and supplemental unemployment benefit plans.

Second-quarter net income of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation was $4,167,000 higher than in the first quarter of this year, and $653,000 more than the second quarter of 1957. Half-year earnings were 2.1 per cent lower than a year ago, Gwilym A. Price, chairman, reported yesterday.

For the past twelve years Community Councils of the City of New York, Inc., have taken the initiative to help "forgotten children" -- those who have passed all the essential examinations for assignment to camp and are ready to go. But they must stay behind because the quota for campers is filled.
The first half's earnings of the Chrysler Corporation, Ford Motor Company and General Motors Corporation were bad news for the companies' stockholders. Also for all taxpayers.

LITTLE ROCK, July 30 -- The renomination of Gov. Orval E. Faubus to a third two-year term under-scored the massive resistance of Arkansans to Federal efforts to enforce racial integration in the public schools.

Dr. Morris A. Jacobs, Commissioner of Hospitals, rejected a request by the Protestant Council yesterday for a special hospital board meeting on his recent order prohibiting birth-control therapy for a Protestant patient in a municipal hospital.
GUATEMALA, Judy 30 -- Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower arrived here today on the last stop of his goodwill and fact-finding tour of Central America.

Prince Rainier III of Monaco and Princess Grace will be guests of honor at the fourth annual Imperial Ball at the Astor on Dec. 4. The event will again be a benefit for the Hospitalized Veterans Service of the Musicians Emergency Fund.

Philip Morris, Inc., realized a 14 per cent increase in earnings on a sales gain of 7 per cent in the second quarter this year, Joseph F. Cullman 3d, president of the cigarette company, reported yesterday. Half-year sales were up 6 per cent above those for last year, while earnings rose 5 per cent.

LITTLE FALLS, N. J., July 30 -- The Passaic Valley Water Commission today stopped drawing water from the Passaic River here when heat, humidity and industrial waste combined to pollute the water. The police reported that thousands of dead fish were floating on the river yesterday.

MILWAUKEE, July 30 (AP) -- Warren Spahn, a southpaw who hadn't beaten the Dodgers in nearly seven years, gained his thirteenth victory tonight by taming Los Angeles on six hits as the Milwaukee Braves triumphed, 4 -- 3.
DETROIT, July 30 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers edged the Boston Red Sox, 2 -- 1, today on Al Kaline's eighth-inning triple.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 30 -- Bob Gilmartin of North Hempstead scored a 2-and-1 victory over Dick Capasso of Bethpage today to win the Long Island Golf Association junior championship at the Garden City Country Club.
LONDON, July 30 -- A government spokesman said today that there would be a substantial relaxation of embargo restrictions on the sale of Western goods to Communist countries.
The State Department was urged by a group of Protestant officials yesterday to accept the idea that what is best for the Middle East may not necessarily be best for the West.
LONDON, July 30 -- Stock prices tended to drift lower today as volume declined.

WARSAW, July 30 (UPI) -- Polish athletic officials, declining to follow their Russian "cousins," promised today to score the men's and women's events separately in this weekend's United States-Poland track and field meet.

MILWAUKEE, July 31 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves rallied for three runs in the eighth inning today to beat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 4 -- 1, and increased their National League lead over the second-place San Francisco Giants.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- George Meany denounced today alliances that give comfort to the leadership of a corruptly dominated union.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) -- The Senate Antimonopoly Subcommittee today wound up its lengthy hearings on a House-approved bill to exempt professional team sports from the antitrust laws.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- When Marion B. Folsom became Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare three years ago today, he saw improving education in the United States as his big problem. Today, his last in the Eisenhower Cabinet, it still is, but he feels the first big step toward solving that problem may be taken soon with passage of the aid to education bill.

Columbia University announced yesterday that Dr. Clifford L. Lord, director of the Wisconsin State Historical Society, had been appointed Dean of the School of General Studies. He will assume the post Sept. 1.

FORT JACKSON, S. C., July 31 (AP) -- Pvt. Hobart L. Brinsmade Jr., 21 years old, of Bronxville, N. Y., died at the Army Hospital late today. He was one of two trainees who had suffered heat prostration.

The Cuban consulate here was invaded yesterday by supporters of the rebel leader Fidel Castro. The raiders brandished a toy pistol to line two women employes against a wall, then scattered papers and broke a pane of glass.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 31 -- The New York Racing Association yielded to political pressure today and altered its new policy of admitting children to the state's thoroughbred tracks. The association announced that henceforth youngsters less than 16 years of age would not be permitted at the tracks.
New York has been host for the last six days to its biggest and in all likelihood its best-behaved convention.
Five auctioneers appeared before the Commissioner of Licenses yesterday at a hearing on operations in three Times Square auction shops.

Die-hard opponents of the Lincoln Square redevelopment flooded the thirteen-block slum clearance area yesterday with leaflets that advised residential and business tenants: "Do Not Be Intimidated -- Don't Move."

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 31 -- Mrs. Ogden Phipps' Neji, king of the obstacle racers, finished third behind the Irish-bred Cloonroughan and My Last Try in the $22,000 Midsummer Hurdle Handicap at Monmouth Park today.

Commissioner Morris A. Jacobs' prohibition of birth-control therapy in municipal hospitals was protested yesterday by the Rev. Arthur Wells, moderator of the New York Congregational Church Association.

Prices changed direction three times during a violent session of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. The last change was downward and The New York Times combined average of fifty stocks closed with a small loss.
The 3-cent stamp for mailing a letter went the way of the nickel subway ride and the nickel beer yesterday.
The Federal Reserve System in the week ended Wednesday sopped up a portion of the member bank resrves created by its recent massive intervention in the Government securities market.
The Standard Oil Company of California had a net income of $116,735,443, or $1.85 a share, in the first six months of this year, R. G. Follis, chairman, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, said today he believed Republican chances in the November Congressional elections had improved along with farm prices.

The United States has committed itself to "full partnership" in the new Baghdad Pact. It has demonstrated, by the landing of armed forces in Lebanon, its interest in the Middle East and its determination to resist aggression.

The Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago reported yesterday a decline of 1.8 per cent in sales of electricity for the first half of this year. The drop was attributed to a decline of 9.7 per cent from the 1957 level in industrial sales. Residential volume was up 6.2 per cent and commercial sales were up 4.9 per cent, the report said.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) -- The House Banking Committee approved, 18 -- 3, today a vast expansion in Federal housing construction and slum clearance.

The International Social Service and the Child Welfare League of America called yesterday for amendment of the McCarren-Walter Immigration Act to end what they said was an often tragic "mail-order baby business."

OYSTER BAY, L. I., July 31 -- The Appellate Division in Albany today upheld an order by the State Education Commissioner, Dr. James E. Allen, setting up a new central school district in the Town of Oyster Bay. This district would replace three districts in the villages of Brookville, Locust Valley and Bayville.

Prof. Hans Kohn in his letter published July 20 lives up to the old tradition of Arab-Jewish harmony that typified for many generations the relationship between these Semitic people. In recent years many people, particularly some Jews, have been led to view everything regarding the Arabs through the spectacles of Zionism.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The Senate passed and sent to the White House today a bill designed to prevent executive agencies from using a law enacted in 1789 to withhold information and records to which Congress and the public are entitled.
Stock prices rose sharply on the New York Stock Exchange in July, in the heaviest trading for any month in three and a half years, and the heaviest for a July in twenty-six years.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 31 -- Following is the text of the conclusions of the second report of the United Nations Observation Group in Lebanon:
Governor Harriman appealed to President Eisenhower yesterday to "seize the opportunity" at any summit conference "to obtain acceptance by the Arab states of the integrity of Israel."

Indians called it Nanticut, which meant to them "The Far Away Land." Modern yachtsmen will not want to disagree. Nantucket still is the far-away land, nearly the easternmost jumping-off place with the next stop Europe.

Photographs of an imposing, newly discovered Antarctic mountain range have been received from members of a party that reached it last Dec. 10 on a tractor journey from Ellsworth Station on the Weddell Sea.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Following is the transcript of Secretary of State Dulles' news conference today, as made public by the State Department:

Federal Judge Gregory F. Noonan yesterday sentenced one of the reputed key figures in a nation-wide narcotics ring to forty years in prison. This was said to be one of the most severe sentences ever imposed in this area for trading in narcotics.

The Martin Beck Theatre, Eighth Avenue and Forty-fifth Street, has been leased for ten years, beginning next Monday to City Playhouses, Inc., of which Louis Lotito is president. Mr. Lotito's group is a subsidiary of the City Investing Company, headed by Robert W. Dowling, who is associated with Robert Whitehead and Roger L. Stevens in the producing field.
The city's 18,099 uniformed policemen were counseled yesterday to use "courtesy and common sense" in enforcing the new pedestrian traffic regulations.
MOSCOW, July 31 -- Soviet scientists today gave their leagues from other lands the first detailed and substantive report on some of their exploration in space with earth satellites.
Your editorial of July 28 "Mr. Walter on Passports" is to be commended.

Several more steel companies, including the two largest, announced price increases on flat-rolled steel yesterday. And the leading aluminum producer raised the price of aluminum--a move expected to be matched soon by the rest of the industry.
THIS yachting can be a tricky piece of business, especially for a landlubber who wouldn't know a bowsprit from a rear bumper. It's almost enough to take the wind right out of one's sails.
IT is pretty difficult to determine which came first in Sweden, the smorgasbord or the massage.
As noted in your newspaper of July 23, there was a fire at Camp Sebago, one of the six camps operated in Palisades Interstate Park by the Boys' Athletic League.

TORONTO, July 31 -- A $100,000,000 road and bridge-building program to strengthen Ontario's arterial highway links with the throughway systems of neighboring states in the United States was announced yesterday by Premier Leslie Frost.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 31 -- The Yugoslav Supreme Court has confirmed the prison sentences meted out last February to three men convicted of having plotted to overthrow Marshal Tito's Communist regime.

ONE good place to shop for food when it is too hot to cook or even to heat purchased prepared dishes is the H. S. Pork Store, 1356 First Avenue, between Seventy-second and Seventy-third Streets. Formerly B. Hdrana's, the establishment offers, in addition to some familiar meats for serving cold, a number of unusual -- and delicious -- products that are made with old Bohemian recipes.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- President Eisenhower voiced the hope today that atomic energy throughout the world might be turned from warlike to peaceful purposes.
PARIS, July 31 (Reuters) -- Following, in unofficial translation, is the text of Gen. Charles de Gaulle's message to Soviet Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev, published here tonight.

The Fairbrook Realty Company has sold to an investor the six-story apartment house on a plot 50 by 180 feet at 451 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn. The building contains thirty-one apartments and garage space for five cars. It was sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $150,000 in a deal negotiated by Hussey Hoeh, brokers.

STONINGTON, Conn., July 31 -- George B. Gibbons Jr. with his Mackinac sloop Mariann, G. Stuart Enscoe with the Casey cutter Windrush and Franklin Dickman, sailing his 31-foot sloop Puritan, were the division winners as the twenty-seventh American Yacht Club cruise moved here today from Shelter Island.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The Treasury announced today a 59 per cent allotment on its recent cash offering of $3,500,000,000 of tax anticipation certificates bearing 1 1/2 per cent interest.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee voted unanimously today to cite Bernard Goldfine, New England industrialist, for contempt of Congress.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 31 -- Gen. Fuad Chehab was elected President of Lebanon today by a vote of 48 to 7 on the second ballot in Parliament. There was one abstention.

A summit meeting within the framework of the United Nations Security Council to deal with the explosive Middle East has become an imminent possibility as a result of Prime Minister Macmillan's call for such a meeting beginning Aug. 12.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) -- The Senate approved legislation today to clarify Federal bookkeeping and tighten Congressional control over Government spending.

ENGLISH homes may be noted for their lack of central heating, but they will not be found lacking in other contemporary, automatic conveniences. So reports Miss Mary George, director, of Britain's Electrical Association for Women.

The Irzsharp Realty Corporation contracted to buy the five-story apartment house for twenty-two families at 621 East 161st Street in the Bronx and immediately resold its contract to the T. I. Realty Corporation. The property is assessed at $42,000. Roche Panoff, Inc., were the brokers in both deals.

The United States has taken a step that is both wise and right in announcing a revision of its method of land-holding in the Ryukyu Islands. Our new High Commissioner, General Booth, has said that there will be an immediate stop to the requisitioning of land for indefinite use and that the status of land already occupied will be renegotiated.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, July 31 -- The Orchestre de la Suisse Romande is a staple of the record catalogues and Americans have had abundant occasion to hear it on disks. Its conductor is Ernest Ansermet, who is well known to Americans in person for he has been a frequent guest with our orchestras.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 31 -- Long Island Sound sailors have seen all types of weather since the blue-water campaign began: fog, heavy rain, too strong winds and flat calm.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- A familiar political hunt is on for the doer of the deed which apparently has laid the Kennedy-Ives labor reform bill on its deathbed. As in a good many other murder mysteries (few believe the wounded legislation can survive), the suspects are accusing one another, and there are also insinuations that a policeman on the case may have been hired by the criminal.
The American Tobacco Company and its subsidiaries had record earnings in the quarter and six months ended June 30, despite a decline in sales, the semi-annual report disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The United States Court of Appeals sent another television case back to the Federal Communications Commission today for a determination whether improper influence had been used.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 31 -- The United Nations observation group in Lebanon reported today that whatever arms smuggling from Syria had taken place "cannot be on any-

CINCINNATI, July 31 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Redlegs rallied for six runs in the last two innings tonight and defeated the San Francisco Giants, 10 -- 9. A pinch-hitter, Pete Whisenant, singled home the winning run with one out and the bases loaded in the ninth.
Reflecting the more confident outlook for business, corporations and local governments stepped up their new financing in July.
A minimum age of 19 years for firemen was advocated yesterday by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. The present minimum is 20.

PARIS, July 31 -- Fortune's favorite, Yves St. Laurent of Dior, charmed us today with another successful collection of fashions. However, he shocked us with his mid-calf skirts, which were about five inches longer than those shown by other Paris designers.
LONDON, July 31 -- The tone of the stock market was cheerful today, although the volume remained small and buying selective.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 3 to 19 points yesterday, with old crop months strongest. (A point equals 5 cents a bale).
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- The House Interior Committee today set its final vote on the Hawaii statehood bill for next Wednesday.

Two Brooklyn detectives who had been assigned to learn why a man who had sneaked under a subway turnstile carried an unusually large amount of money were charged yesterday with extorting $600 from him and with illegally accepting a fee.
Mayor Wagner called for the repeal yesterday of the state law under which the city, since July 1, 1953, has had the power to impose a tax on payrolls.
MONEY matters, but it rarely makes or breaks four years at college. According to six girls on Lord Taylor's college board, allowances are a matter of tastes, not necessity.

Commodity prices closed generally mixed on the New York exchanges in dull and featureless trading yesterday. Sugar, coffee, cocoa, wool, hides, rubber and zinc were mixed; copper, cottonseed, soybean oil and lead rose and potatoes and tin were lower.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission said today that if a broadcasting station elected not to handle any political speeches, nothing in the law forced it to do so.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 31 -- A rising crescendo of small arms fire began today at the instant the Lebanese radio said that Gen. Fuad Chehab had achieved the required majority for election as President.
ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, July 31 -- The advance billing on the salmon in the Gander River is that there is a muckle of them but that most of them are kind of mickle.
PEEKSKILL, N. Y., July 31 -- The formation of an interstate commission to perpetuate commuter rail service in the New York City region was advocated today to Democratic state leaders.
Two suspected gunmen were captured after a hold-up in Brooklyn early today in a seventy-mile-an-hour chase during which seven shots were fired.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- Two Detroit laundry operators charged today that Herman Kierdorf had used his power as a Teamsters Union official to take away business from them and give it to the Star Coverall Company.
GENEVA, July 31 -- The Soviet Union appeared today to be attempting to minimize the need for an elaborate control system to police an international ban on the tests of nuclear weapons.
CHICAGO, July 31 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

NEW DELHI, India, July 31 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru expressed the hope today that the United States would pull its troops out of Lebanon since the controversial issue of the election of a President had been settled.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Following is the text of a note delivered today by the United States Embassy at Moscow to the Soviet Foreign Ministry on the prevention of surprise attack:
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The Kennedy-Ives labor reform bill has gone to its limbo with the approval, and in some cases to the satisfaction, of the dominant forces in the labor movement.

OTTAWA, July 31 (UPI) -- Slight increases in exports and falling imports left Canada a trade deficit of $193,700,000 for the first six months of this year, two-thirds smaller than last year and the lowest since 1955.

NEWARK, July 31 -- An investigation today of the collision between two trolleys in the subway yesterday disclosed that all four brakes on the second trolley had been operating perfectly. Thirty-five persons were injured in the crash.
Directors of the Motor Products Corporation declared a dividend of 60 cents yesterday, payable to common stockholders on Sept. 30.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 31 -- Britain's request for a Security Council meeting at the heads-of-government level will be submitted tomorrow to Guillaume Georges-Picot, French delegate.

Aid for the city's war against smoke has come, of all places, from the penthouses. The folks who live up there have found the air contaminants that have been so annoying to all of us to be most damaging to penthouse plants and flowers. So all thirty-five members of the Rooftop Gardeners Association have done something about it by systematically reporting smoke violators to the Department of Air Pollution Control.

A United States Navy transport plane was reported forced down yesterday by fighters of the Dominican Republic's Air Force, according to The Associated Press. The plane was released auter being searched. The Dominicans were reported to have been looking for smuggled arms. '
INDIANAPOLIS, July 31 (AP) -- Forrest Teel, 54-year-old drug company executive, was shot to death in his car here early today.
GEN. Fuad Chehab, who was elected President of Lebanon yesterday, likes to call himself in French, Le Grand Muet -- "the Big Speechless One."
New York State unemployment -- as measured by jobless insurance benefits -- continued its sharp decline last week.
Small traces of strontium 90 were found yesterday in tea brought here from Japan by the Norwegian freighter Tancred.

MILWAUKEE, July 31 (AP) -- Eleven cars of the Milwaukee Road's Olympian Hiawatha, carrying many of its 497 passengers to vacations, derailed today while traveling at ninety miles an hour. Fifty persons were injured, none fatally.

WHITE PLAINS, July 31 -- After seventeen years' imprisonment on a first-degree murder conviction that has since been declared illegal, William Wade walked out of the Westchester County Courthouse here today a free man.

LONDON, July 31 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan proposed today that a special meeting of the United Nations Security Council, to be attended by heads of government, be called into session on Aug. 12.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., July 31 -- Thoroughbred racing at Saratoga, instituted in 1864, had its 1958 opening today and the attendant circumstances indicated that "racing is here to stay."

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- A new code of conduct for the Federal Power Commission says each commissioner and staff member should "avoid any action in their work or in their personal affairs which could serve as a possible basis for suspicion of unethical practice."

Officials of the Navy's Bureau of Ships were reported yesterday to be ready to request a meeting with representatives of the Bethlehem Steel Company on the possibility of keeping open the company's Staten Island shipyard.

WESTBURY, L. I., July 31 -- Despite forty-five nights of inclement weather, the recession and the fact that parents without baby-sitters had to limit their patronage to the flats, Roosevelt Raceway ended its 105-night season tonight with records in total wagering and total attendance.
SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., July 31 -- A Rhodes scholar and a Phi Beta Kappa student met in the Southampton invitation tennis tournament at the Meadow Club today.

POINT O' WOODS, L. I., July 31 -- Skippers competing in the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's annual Cruise Week regatta today had a promising so'wester at the start, but the wind faded, leaving sails limp. As a result, two classes, the Lightnings and Narrasketucks, failed to finish in the three-and-one-quarter-hour time limit.

MOSCOW, July 31 -- Adlai E. Stevenson has returned to Moscow from a 6,000-mile tour through the Soviet Union impressed by two things: the friendliness of the people and their "depressing lack of knowledge and understanding of the United States."

The controversy over the right to prescribe contraceptive devices in the city hospitals cannot be swept under the rug; and the Mayor will sooner or later have to come to a clear decision which he has thus far avoided. It seems to us there is only one decision he can properly make.
A "subtle shift" in supply and demand is going on in the capital market, according to the mid-summer survey of R. W. Pressprich Co.

The Grace Line has submitted plans for the construction of three new passenger-cargo ships for its run between Eastern Seaboard ports and the West Coast of South America Clarence G. Morse, Maritime Administrator, disclosed yesterday.
A group of educators was urged yesterday not to shun progressive education because many thought of the term as "a dirty word."

LONDON, July 31 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of Prime Minister Harold Macmillan's letter to Soviet Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev on a proposed summit conference, as read by Mr. Macmillan in the House of Commons:
PARIS, July 31, -- The Government presented the nation tonight with a tax bill of 55,000,000,000 francs ($130,950,000) to help maintain financial stability.
The weather hung like a wet blanket over the city yesterday as temperatures reached into the 90's. A late afternoon cloudburst added to the discomfort of thousands returning home from work.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) -- Immigration Commissioner Joseph M. Swing refused today to grant asylum to a Polish seaman who sought refuge in this country after jumping ship in New York.
A promotion program termed the "largest undertaken in the textile industry," was announced yesterday by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., in Wilmington, Del.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) -- The House of Representatives cited seven men for contempt of Congress today. All had refused to answer questions about alleged Communist attempts to infiltrate United States industry.
The State Automobile Mutual Insurance Company of Columbus, Ohio, has acquired control of the Dixie Fire and Casualty Company and Southern Home Insurance Company, both of Greer, S. C.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The United States proposed in a note to the Soviet Union today that East-West technical talks on measures to prevent surprise attack should begin in Geneva the first week in October.

A harness racing show in an elaborate setting will begin tonight at Yonkers Raceway, which has just been remodeled at an estimated cost of $18,000,000. The first race in this 104-night season will be at 8:25, and the daily double will close at 8:15.

CANTON, N. Y., July 31 -- Policemen are not social workers and should not be expected to solve the problem of juvenile delinquency, Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy of New York declared tonight.
Nelson A. Rockefeller accused Leonard W. Hall last night of misrepresenting his position on state taxation. The two are rivals for the Republican nomination for Governor.

HAVANA, July 31 -- Cuban rebels in Oriente Province plan to approach Rear Admiral Robert B. Ellis, commander of the United States Navy's Guantanamo base, with an offer to guard the base's water supply, according to information received here.

This is Friday. In a few hours now, those who are about to start their vacations will be on the way. It is a very fine day, indeed, for those people. During the course of the first hour, all mail for incoming will be distributed among others, and all mail will be expedited from outgoing as rapidly as possible.

WITH the recent announcement by a hotel executive of his determination to build two trans-Atlantic "superliners" that would charge a fare of $50, it is not inconceivable that families here soon will be planning vacations in Europe with the abandon with which they now contemplate two weeks in the mountains.

Army engineers here said yesterday it was unlikely the sunken tanker Empress Bay would be moved from the bed of the East River before tomorrow. The contract of the salvaging concern calls for the concern to pay a penalty of $1,000 a day for every day the Empress Bay remains in the river after midnight tomorrow.
PARIS, July 31 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle repeated today his insistence on a European setting for a meeting of heads of government on the Middle East crisis. He proposed Aug. 18 as the date.
WARSAW, July 31 -- High officials of the Polish Government and the Roman Catholic Church met today to try to negotiate an end to the split between them.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The United States would like to keep troops in Lebanon until that nation's security is assured by the United Nations, Secretary of State Dulles indicated today.

Councilman Earl Brown, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for the House of Representatives in Harlem's Sixteenth District, asked President Eisenhower yesterday to call a conference of Negro and white leaders on "the school integration crisis."
PARIS, July 31 (Reuters) -- The Chrysler Corporation, one of the United States Big Three auto producers, is preparing to crash the European market, it was reported here tonight.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 31 -- Italian Premier Amintore Fanfani left for home this afternoon. Before his departure he lunched with Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold and, it is reported, outlined a three-point formula for peace in the Middle East.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Secretary of State Dulles said today that the United States would seek at a summit meeting to lay the foundation for an agreement outlawing indirect aggression.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that prices farmers received for crops and livestock registered their second consecutive decline in the month ended July 15.

Net income of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation rose moderately in the second quarter. But earnings for the first half were off sharply from a year ago and failed to cover the dividends declared on the common stock.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, July 31 -- The Haitian Congress today authorized President Francois Duvalier to rule by decree for the next six months, making him a virtual dictator for that period.

Art Carney and the "Du Pont Show of the Month" have reached an agreement whereby he will star in the Mary Chase comedy "Harvey." It will be televised on Monday, Sept. 22, from 9:30 to 11 P. M. over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.
CHICAGO, July 31 (AP) -- A moderate buying flurry in the final few minutes sent nearly all grain futures well ahead today on the Board of Trade.
TEL AVIV, Israel, July 31 -- Robert Murphy, President Eisenhower's special envoy in the Middle East, came to Israel today for a brief conference with Premier David Ben-Gurion.

The election of General Fuad Chehab as the next President of Lebanon comes as one of the few bright developments in the otherwise murky, atmosphere of the Middle East. The fact that he got an overwhelming majority, that important rebel leaders of the National Front supported him, and that he is an illustrious, non-political, middle-of-the-road professional soldier with a loyal army behind him, all add to the hopefulness.

Brief nostalgic ceremonies at Fort Monroe, Va., yesterday marked the retirement of a young "Old Soldier" -- Gen. Willard G. Wyman, for the past two years commanding general of the United States Continental Army Command.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The long debate on the art and wisdom of summitry reached a critical point today -- namely, whether there should be a smoke-filled room at the summit when and if the great men get there.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., July 31 -- Tommy Goodwin, who first won the title in 1935, moved through the first two rounds of the Westchester amateur championship today. Although he did not equal the 2 under par 69 that brought him medal honors at the Pelham Country Club yesterday, the four-time champion turned back his rivals in impressive style.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) -- A Federal judge dismissed today two lawsuits aimed at halting United States nuclear tests in the Pacific.
The controversy over the use of contraceptive devices for birth-control purposes in city hospitals is bound to be acrimonious since both sides believe fundamental moral principles to be involved.
CUT 'N' SHOOT, Tex., July 31 (AP) -- Thanks to the heavyweight challenger, Roy Harris, his home town of Cut 'n' Shoot is getting a post office.
Bon voyages yielded a gross of $148,727.25 during the first half of this year.
LONDON, July 31 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan appealed to the people of Cyprus today to stop killing, wounding and despoiling each other.

KANSAS CITY, July 31 -- None of the thirteen hits the Yankees collected tonight off five Athletics' pitchers was a homer, but there were enough singles and doubles to construct an 8 -- 3 triumph at Municipal Stadium.
The American Legion's national legislative director, Miles D. Kennedy, cautioned Legionnaires yesterday that they were "fast wearing out" their welcome in Congress.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 31 -- Edgar J. Mannix, long a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer executive, is relinquishing his duties as general manager of the studio, but will continue to serve the company in an advisory capacity.
John Hay Whitney, United States Ambassador to Great Britain, has purchased Parade Magazine, a Sunday newspaper supplement.
CHICAGO, July 31 -- The Journal of the American Medical Association today described tests of a new agent for treatment of blood clots that have moved from one part of the body to another.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) -- Final Congressional approval was given today to a ban on the interstate manufacture and shipment of switchblade knives.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) -- The Democratic party asserted today that Republicans had become vulnerable on what Vice President Richard M. Nixon once called the "only three sure-fire issues" that could hurt an Administration in power.

CHAUTAUQUA, N. Y., July 31 (UPI) -- Congressional backing has enabled labor leaders to flaunt their power to reshape the economic and cultural life of the nation as a springboard to political domination, an official of the National Association of Manufacturers declared today.
All-night queues at a box office, as well as ticket scalping, were phenomena a century ago. And they were brought about merely by readings.

GUATEMALA, July 29 -- President Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes told Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower today that Guatemala needed $95,700,000 in long-term credit assistance for major economic development projects. The Guatemalan quetzal is on a par with the dollar.

HACKENSACK, N. J., July 31 -- Holding that taste cannot be legislated, County Judge C. Conrad Schneider ordered the Borough of Rockleigh today to issue a building permit for a house of modern architecture.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The House of Representatives voted today to increase Social Security insurance benefits and taxes.

A newly appointed magistrate, Edward D. Caiazzo, is using an unusual approach in Traffic Court to impress upon speeding motorists the dangers of their ways. He called his method yesterday "shock treatment with a little education."
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Britain will recognize the new Iraqi regime tomorrow, and the United States will follow suit a day or two later, officials said today.

NEW HAVEN, July 31 -- Tuition increases ranging from $100 to $200 a year will go into effect at Yale University in July, 1959. Dr. A. Whitney Griswold, president of Yale, said the move was necessary to bring the charges "up to a closer and more realistic relationship" to costs.
GRAYLING, Mich., July 31 (AP) -- Joe Fries of Los Angeles today won the 1958 National Field Archery Association's free-style (with sights) men's championship by 6 points.

THE vacation before last (and how long ago that seems!) I spent four days in Portugal. So short a visit was frustrating. There was so much more that I wanted to see. But it was long enough to make me hope that some day I could return to a charming and beautiful country. Naturally, then, with my interest already aroused, I was attracted to "The Portuguese Escape,"* by Ann Bridge.

IF a city dweller plants a tree on the sidewalk in front of his house, the municipality, through the Park Department, eventually owns the tree and cares for it. If a property-owner plants a street lamp the city latches onto that, too. It has probably never happened before.
A plant has been opened in Ravena, a village on the Hudson's slopes just south of Albany, to process and pack creamy white mushrooms.

TRENTON, July 31 -- Joseph E. McLean resigned today as Commissioner of Conservation and Economic Development. Gov. Robert E. Meyner immediately appointed Mr. McLean's deputy, Salvatore A. Bontempo, to succeed him in the $18,000-a-year cabinet post.

The Young Women's Christian Association has contracted to sell the three-story building at 204-06 East Seventy-seventh Street adjoining its nine-story Studio Club. The building is being acquired by Fred H. Hill, realty investor, who is negotiating a lease to a health club.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Friday, Aug. 1 -- A Government spokesman announced early today that "a few people" of undisclosed nationality had been arrested on suspicion of arson in connection with a Baghdad oil depot fire.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) -- The House-Senate Committee on Atomic Energy approved today a pending United States agreement with Britain on exchange of military atomic secrets.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- Agreement in principle on a $20,000,000 bridge program, including a new international bridge across the Niagara River, was reached here today by United States and Canadian representatives.
CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Will Harridge, the president of the American League, said today he had asked clubowners to consider amending playing rules to permit the use of any player-twice in one game.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -Mrs. Eisenhower opened today a national women's drive to give to the President a Republican majority in Congress at the November elections.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 1 -- The exodus of Yugoslav officials to the mountains and the seashore to escape sweltering Belgrade testified today to the fading here of fears that the Middle East crisis might spark a general war.
Automobile output last month was the smallest for any July since 1952. It amounted to about 322,000 cars, compared with 337,000 in June and 495,000 in July, 1957.

A West Nigerian official said yesterday that he saw no possibility that the Nigerian Federation would fall under the influence of Gamal Abdel Nasser and the Arab nationalist movement when it achieved independence, probably in 1960.
WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 1 -- Westchester officials took action today to save the county "from becoming another Winsted." That Connecticut town was devastated by floods three years ago.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UPI) -A 19-year-old Texas girl, bitter because she had been locked out of the White House for ten days, made a futile try today to lock President Eisenhower in.
JERUSALEM (Israeli sector), Aug. 1 -- Many of the sixty-six Arab prisoners who escaped from a prison in northern Israel last night were infiltrators or terrorists.
Rear Admiral Henry C. Perkins, commander of the Third Coast Guard District, has announced several new assignments here.
A cooperative housing corporation bought at auction yesterday the last of the thirteen blocks the city had condemned on Feb. 28 for slum clearance in the Lincoln Square area.

MYSTIC, Conn., Aug. 1 -- Commodore Carl Hovgard of the American Yacht Club, Fred W. P. Lorenzen of the Stamford Yacht Club and Franklin J. Dickman of the American captured the major trophies as the twenty-seventh American Yacht Club cruise ended today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The index of average wholesale prices in primary markets rose 0.1 per cent, to 119.4 per cent, of its 1947-49 level during the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday declines in revenues and net income for the three and twelve months ended June 30 and for June. The first-half report attributed the declines to a combination of higher wage costs in June and a smaller volume of traffic as a result of the recession.

As of July 1 wage increases amounting to between 22 and 23 cents an hour automatically took effect in the steel industry under the terms of the long-term wage contract negotiated with the A. F. L.-C. I. O. steel workers in 1956.

WARSAW, Aug. 2 -- Negotiators of the Roman Catholic Church and the Polish Government were reported today to have made a hopeful beginning in their talks on the church-state crisis. These talks, at which two bishops are representing the church and two high officials the Communist Government, are continuing.
KALAMAZOO, Mich., Aug. 1 (AP) -- Midwesterners won three semi-final berths in the junior singles today in the national junior and boys' tennis championships.
LONDON, July 29 -- The British Labor party has just learned the hard way that in politics you never can tell.
INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 1 (AP) -- A divorcee traced a drug company executive to his new girl friend's apartment and shot him, then tried to kill herself by poison, the police said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -An American atomic weapon mounted in a missile was detonated miles above the Pacific Ocean today. It was a step toward creation of a defense against intercontinental ballistic missiles.
If you think that keeping up your home, your car and your clothing is costly, consider the Department of Defense's maintenance headache.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $24,806,984, for the first half of 1958, or $1.62 a share. This compared with $44,848,197, or $2.93 a share a year earlier.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- A United States spokesman said today that yesterday's report by the United Nations Observation Group in Lebanon had confirmed charges of illegal infiltration into that country.
MOSCOW, Aug. 1 (AP) -- A Soviet nuclear test brought larger temporary increases in radioactive fall-out to Japan than a United States experiment, a Japanese scientist reported today.
New Yorkers found their cup overflowing yesterday with blue skies and sunshine. The weekend promised everything they had missed last month.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -An Interstate Commerce Commission examiner recommended rejection today of the proposal by Eastern railroads to raise their rates on small freight shipments.
A record crowd of 194,418 Jehovah's Witnesses roared approval yesterday of a resolution laying the world's ills to organized Christianity.

A dance at the Benjamin Franklin High School on East 116th Street was thrown into turmoil last night by a dispute involving two 13-year-old boys. One of them fired a zip gun, narrowly missing the other.
The state convention of the American Legion heard two verbal salvos fired yesterday against the pacifist Jehovah's Witnesses movement.

MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 1 -- The Nassau County Commission on Collegiate Education will recommend that a community college be established in the county. James W. Carpenter, the commission's executive secretary, said today.

Elmo Roper's otherwise perceptive letter printed July 25 attributes confusion to President Eisenhower respecting the points of view of the United World Federalists, Inc., and the Atlantic Union Committee. While the President may have been inadvertently mistaken in identifying Justice Roberts' position, he left no room for confusion in the stress he laid on the impelling necessity for a world-wide system of law designed to achieve peace.

The Hartford Insurance Company of Hartford, Conn., and the Columbian National Life Insurance Company of Boston are studying a merger. Hartford would acquire Columbian, which would become a member of the Hartford Fire Insurance Company group. The acquisition would be effected through a stock exchange that would be tax-free under the Federal Revenue Code.
A swipe of a machete, rather than the customary snip of scissors, yesterday opened the new headquarters here of Avianca, the national airline of Colombia.

Directors of the Brown Company, manufacturer of pulp and paper products, have postponed action on the third quarter common dividend, normally payable Sept. 1. The company, in its mid-year report, indicated that, while a loss was sustained in the first quarter, it was slightly more than made up in the second quarter but not enough to cover the 30 cents already paid in dividends.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Parts of Kansas and Missouri today experienced the worst floods since 1951.
Anastas I. Mikoyan, First Deputy Premier of the Soviet Union, will appear on a filmed television interview here within the next several weeks.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 -- As August rolled around, the steam-roller named Yankees continued to flatten all opposition in the American League. At Comiskey Park tonight, Casey Stengel's front-runners crushed the White Sox, 7 -- 0, and roiled to their biggest lead of the year.

New York University has landscaped the corners of Sullivan Street at Washington Square South and at West Third Street. And the result is a pair of exquisite little gardens, with privet and plane trees, ivy and a cover of grass or Pachysandra to come.

Sales in July of the eight major department stores in the New York metropolitan area rose 7 per cent above the July, 1957, level. The increase compares with a rise of 3 per cent a month earlier and 1 per cent in May.
HONOLULU, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Hawaii, still mindful of the devastation heaped on Pearl Harbor Dec. 7, 1941, was jolted by the atomic age today.

LONDON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The Moscow radio reported tonight that the Soviet Union had protested to Italy against the use of Italian ports and airfields in the passage of United States forces sent to Lebanon.

Increased service to seamen in 1957 was noted in the thirty-sixth annual report of the American Merchant Marine Library Association. This public library of the high seas is headed by Mrs. George Emlen Roosevelt, who is chairman of the board.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The House of Representatives killed today the last big anti-recession bill on the program of the Democratic leadership. It would have provided $2,000,000,000 in loans to local communities for public works.

The Government of the free Federation of Malaya has now extended its anti-Communist "state of emergency" for another year. The special regulations will remain in force. The action coincides with the lapse of the time given in which Communist surrenders could be accepted. The "amnesty" is over. Less than five hundred terrorists have surrendered.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 1 (UPI) -- Greek Cypriote extremists ambushed a British Army patrol early today.

THE list of books published yesterday contained a fairy story for grown-ups. It is the Sleeping Beauty tale of the pioneer ranch house -- with its rough-shingled roof, shady verandas and informal, rambling floor plan -- that woke up to become a modern American palace.

GANDER RIVER, Newfoundland, Aug. 1 -- George (The Chief) Carpenter established his authority today by catching the first salmon in a party of six anglers. But he was still unable to prove his thesis that there were reasonably big salmon in the Gander.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Yama Bahama of the British West Indies withstood two first-round knockdowns and came back to score a unanimous ten-round decision over Joe Miceli of New York tonight. Each fighter Weighed 153 pounds.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange declined 6 to 27 points (30 cents to $1.35 a bale) yesterday. Commission houses sold far months in late trading.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Aug. 1 (AP) -- John Kasper was reunited with some of his radical segregationist supporters today. He pledged that he would continue his fight against race-mixing.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- House and Senate conferees and countered an unexpected deadlock today over the terms for renewal of the reciprocal trade program.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 1 (AP) -- Three white men were ordered held without bond today on charges of attempting to bomb the homes of two Negro families July 17.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -President Eisenhower told Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev today that he would "attend and participate" in a United Nations summit meeting on the Middle East and called on the Soviet leader to do likewise.

A new edition of "Mosby's War Reminiscences and Stuart's Cavalry Campaigns," by John Singleton Mosby, will be published by Pageant in September. First published in 1887, the work describes Mosby's formation of a cavalry unit under General J. E. B. Stuart and his guerrilla tactics against the Union Army during the Civil War.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- Ships using the Suez Canal will be asked to pay a 3 per cent surcharge on canal tolls beginning Sept. 15, Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold announced today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- A woman braved threats today to tell Senate investigators that racketeers had entered Detroit's laundry business.
HONG KONG, Aug. 1 -- Scientists from Communist China's Institute of Atomic Energy said tonight that United States nuclear tests in the Pacific had created an ill wind that was blowing China no good.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 1 -- Perfect weather, a clear, sunny afternoon and a cool evening blessed refugees from the heat of New York and music lovers from all over, who gathered here for the next to last week-end of the Berkshire Festival.

EUROPEAN scenes and art forms have inspired a group of hand-printed decorative fabrics and related wallpapers at Greeff Fabrics, Inc. This collection, entitled "Sojourn Abroad," was designed in Paris and is available through decorators at Greeff Fabrics, Inc., 4 East Fifty-third Street.
Three photographic displays showing aspects of life in the United States were presented yesterday to the Prime Minister of Ghana, Dr. Kwame Nkrumah, by two Camp Fire girls.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 1 -- President Francois Duvalier said today that the participation of Americans in last Tuesday's unsuccessful revolt here would have no effect on Haitian relations with the United States.

" La Parisienne," the new French import with Brigitte Bardot, set an opening-day record at the Plaza Theatre with a gross of $3,418, according to an announcement from United Artists. At the Victoria, which simultaneously began an English-language version of the import Wednesday, opening - day business was described as "tremendous," with a gross reaching $4,339.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- Although business was restrained before the long holiday week-end, the stock markets ended the week on a cheerful note. Small gains predominated in Government securities and industrials, and prices closed at the day's best.

The Northern Grant Corporation has purchased the five-story building containing forty-four apartments at 1685 Hoe Avenue in the Bronx. The sellers were Morris Karp and Bernard I. Sandford, realty operators.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The rate of military plane accidents is declining for the third straight year, but the United States is continuing to pay a heavy toll in lives and dollars.

NEWARK, Aug. 1 -- Superior Court Judge Gerald T. Foley signed an order today directing the New York Central Railroad to reinstate its non-rush-hour week-end and holiday ferry service from New Jersey to New York. It was suspended on July 17

BAY SHORE, L. I., Aug 1 -- Charley Dominy's S. P. D. needs only a fifth-place finish in tomorrow's final race to be assured of the Corry Trophy, emblematic of the Star Class championship of Great South Bay.
Can an unsophisticated baby bird from the country find happiness and companionship with a city cat six years its senior?
PARIS, Aug. 1 -- Wayne Powers, the G. I. deserter who chose love over war almost fourteen years ago, was sentenced today to ten years' imprisonment by a United States Army court-martial.
Post offices across the country dug themselves out from under a mountain of mail yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Arthur S. Flemming was sworn in today as the new Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

PSZCZYNA, Poland, July 27 -- The young Pole in the tan shorts shifted his knapsack and in a forlorn sort of way waved a little blue pamphlet at the driver of the truck. The truck whipped by and the boy by the side of the road looked disgustedly at the blue pamphlet.

RABAT, Morocco, Aug. 1 -- The National Congress of Moroccan Students, meeting in Tetuan, adopted today a left-wing resolution attacking the Royal Moroccan Army and demanding a constitutional monarchy.
NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 1 -- A near-record fleet of blue-ribbon racing and cruising yachts made ready tonight for the first squadron run of the New York Yacht Club's annual summer cruise.

THE cantaloupe that is arriving in abundance from California's Sun Valley and from North Carolina is especially sweet and juicy this year. Similar praise can be given to watermelon, which also is in good supply.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Aug. 1 -- On the theory that you can't teach what you don't know, 100 teachers have gone back to school this summer to learn about a new program of mathematics for high school students.
Under circumstances described as amicable, T. A. G. Hungerford has withdrawn as author of the book for the forthcoming musical "Sure Sign of Spring."
LAST night's Lewisohn Stadium concert was devoted to the music of Kurt Weill, with a concert version of "The Threepenny Opera" as the piece de resistance. The event attracted an audience of 9,500.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- Joe Kryla Jr., the 26-year-old Leewood Golf Club champion who was a newcomer to the tournament, gained the final of the Westchester Amateur championship today. In a thirty-six-hole test at the Pelham Country Club tomorrow he will face Tommy Goodwin, who first won the crown in 1935 and has taken the title three more times since then.
PARIS, Aug. 1 -- Premier Charles de Gaulle asked capital and labor tonight to join in constituting a fund to guarantee wages in times of economic crises.

" SEAMARKS," by St.-John Perse, is a tremendous poem of humanity's fate writ in the endless surge of the world's great waterways. Its form is in the classical Greek manner, its imagery is as vivid as the paintings of Delacroix. Almost alone among the obscurities of modern verse it revives the ancient spirit of mystery and splendor and wonder.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 1 -- Powerful United States Army reinforcements arrived in Lebanon tonight.

WARSAW, Aug. 1 -- To the cheers of 100,000 fans, Poland's national track and field squad put up a surprisingly strong showing against the United States today as a two-day meet started in the Tenth Anniversary Stadium.

Thruway officials have come up with some explanations of a highway phenomenon that has infuriated motorists: Why when the road is not being used to capacity at peak periods, do drastic traffic tie-ups occur?

FOR twenty years Dr. Francois Duvalier practiced medicine all over the rugged mountains and hot valleys of Haiti. Before his inauguration as the Republic's President last October, he had said he was sure he would win the nation's highest office because of the "popularity people attach to their physician."

PARIS, Aug. 1 -- With the showings today of Balenciaga and Givenchy, one can safely say that the oracle has spoken. We are in for short skirts, so what are we going to do with the extra yardage from Dior?

An unfortunate combination of circumstances appears to have brought New York's only private shipbuilding yard to the end of the road. Bethlehem Steel Company has closed the books officially on shipbuilding at its Staten Island yard; and at the end of the year the establishment's repair work will run out and the entire plant will be closed.

Leaders of the world's five great religions -- Christianity, Judaism, Islam, Hinduism and Buddhism -- will participate next week in a five-day congress on religious freedom at the University of Chicago.
HUNIS, Aug. 1 -- Louis Joxe, Secretary General of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs, conferred with President Habib Bourguiba for an hour and a half today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's note today to Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev:

Diethelm Keller (U. S. A.) Ltd., exporters and importers, leased a major part of the twentieth floor at 535 Fifth Avenue, northeast corner of Forty-fourth Street, from the William Waldorf Astor estate. The lessee is a Swiss holding company represented in this country by Emilio B. Knechtle, executive vice president. The lease was negotiated by Edward E. McNally and William C. Smiley of the Charles F. Noyes Company, Brokers.
The United States Plywood Corporation raised prices of fir plywood yesterday. Demand for the building material has been rising rapidly in recent months as a result of an upsurge in construction.
The United States Lawn Tennis Association yesterday called upon Ham Richardson, who hasn't shown much interest in Davis Cup tennis, to help get the American team into the challenge round.
ALBANY, Aug. 1 (AP) -Beginning today, motorists on the Thruway can buy insurance for 25 cents a trip against the cost of breakdowns on the superhighway.
Sharply reduced sales and earnings were reported yesterday by two leading manufacturers of radio and television products for the quarter and six months ended June 30.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., Aug. 1 (AP) -- A major breakthrough in missilery was announced today by Maj. Gen. Bernard A. Schriever, commander of the Air Force Ballistic Missile Division.
Twenty-five Polish refugees who defected from the liner Batory when it docked at Copenhagen, Denmark, a year ago, arrived here yesterday to live.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 1 -- Lebanon welcomed today the election of Gen. Fouad Chehab, commander of the armed forces, as the next President of the Republic.
Observers of the investment company field have been wondering how much of their assets the big funds have been holding in cash recently. Estimates have ranged up to 15 per cent.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 1 -Symptoms of anti-Semitism and xenophobia have appeared in Erlangen University, in northern Bavaria, according to reports published today. They were confirmed by Jurgen Krautheim, chairman of a university students' committee.
Offerings of new corporate security issues will continue at a slow rate next week as Wall Street's vacations reach their peak.
A further deterioriation in operations of the Studebaker-Packard Corporation was revealed in the semi-annual report issued yesterday.

FORT JACKSON, S. C., Aug. 1 (AP) -- Authorities at this Army Infantry training base said tonight that vaccinations he had taken just before he collapsed had not contributed to the death of Pvt. Hobart Brinsmade Jr.

WARSAW, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Harold Connolly and Olga Fikotova, the husband-wife pair of Olympic champions, today received thirty-day visas from the Czechoslovak Consulate in Warsaw. The couple plans to leave for Prague and a visit with Olga's parents after competing here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- A hypodermic syringe that spares the child was patented by a Virginia country doctor this week. The point of the needle is covered by the figure of a friendly little man, and the patient doesn't realize he's going to be jabbed.
Faith in the ability of prices to rise despite the course of earnings returned to the stock market yesterday and New York Stock Exchange issues added almost $1,500,000,000 to their market value.

MANNING, S. C., Aug. 1 (UPI) -- Clarendon County school officials said today that petitions had been filed by eight Negroes seeking integration of the public schools at the site of one of the five original cases in the 1954 Supreme Court ruling.
FORT LEE, N. J., Aug. 1 -Reports of extensive damage to the interior of the home of the slain gangster Albert Anastasia were neither confirmed nor denied by the police today.

The Sunday drive for the family is not really a thing of the past. While much of the pleasure may have been eliminated by superhighways and the plenitude of autos, there is no doubt that the family can avoid traffic jams, noise and worry by selecting the proper roads for the Sunday trip.
Three young men were standing on a Brooklyn street corner last week discussing the usual topic: girls, the future and military service.
Commodity futures on the New York exchanges were generally firm yesterday in quiet and featureless trading.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -Those seeking Alaska's two new Senate seats will not know how big the prizes are until the races are over and the terms of office are parceled out by a kind of Senatorial bingo.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (UPI) -- Ken Venturi, golf's fifth leading money winner for 1958 even though he hasn't won a tourney in three months, scored a five-under-par 65 today to set the pace in the delayed first round of the Gleneagles $50,000 open golf tournament.
Leonard W. Hall renewed his criticism of Nelson A. Rockefeller yesterday as an advocate of larger Government spending and higher taxation.
TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 1 (AP) -- Chris von Saltza, the 14-year-old California swimming star, tonight broke the world record for the 200-meter back-stroke with a time of 2:37.4.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 1 (Reuters) -- A revolt flared recently in Communist-ruled Tibet, according to unconfirmed reports reaching here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission planned a new action today against Bernard Goldfine and his Boston real estate company for failing to file a financial report due three days ago.

HAVANA, Aug. 1 -- Political violence flared here tonight. Three young men were killed and nine persons were wounded in a riot of political prisoners at the Principe Fontress Jail here late this afternoon.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 1 -- The bold bid of Bill Rigney's Giants to regain the National League lead met with a sharp rebuff tonight.

OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 1 -- Admirers of William Hartack -- and they are many at this seaside track -- had an enjoyable afternoon as the leading Monmouth rider brought home three good-priced winners today.

An insurance brokers' organization has accused the State Power Authority of paying "unwarranted and excessive" fees for the servicing of insurance awarded to a "favorite" broker without competitive bidding.

YVES ST. LAURENT has lowered the boom on every woman who is wearing shorter skirts. In his fall-winter collection for the House of Christian Dior, this 22-year-old maverick designer showed skirts that were a modest fourteen to fifteen inches off the floor.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- Lake Placid's only film theatre's showing of "And God Created Woman," starring Brigitte Bardot, has brought a six-month ban by the Roman Catholic Church against the theatre.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Two bills designed to offset Supreme Court decisions made further progress in Congress today. It appeared that the proposals had at least an even chance of getting through before Congress adjourned.

A break discovered early yesterday in a twenty-inch water main closed Broadway between Fortieth and Forty-first Streets. The basements of several big office buildings in the Times Square area were flooded.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- Britain has not wavered from her opposition to a five-nation summit conference on the Middle East outside the framework of the United Nations, it was learned authoritatively today. She will not agree to attend such a conference, it was said.

YONKERS, Aug. 1 -- Men in big cars, and sun-tanned women trimmed in fur, added to the plush decor tonight as Yonkers Raceway, the Fort Knox of Westchester County, began its 104-night harness racing meeting.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- Clearing all thirteen obstacles in record time was not quite enough to bring victory to Mrs. Arthur White's Blen More in the $11,275 Beverwyck Steeplechase Handicap today.

Joseph P. Day, Inc., realty broker with main offices at 7 Dey Street, has formed Joseph P. Day of Ohio, Inc., with an office in the American Building in Cincinnati. Bernard P. Day is the president of both corporations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The Federal Communications Commission censured four stations today for telecasting kinescopes supplied by the National Association of Manufacturers without identifying the sponsor or supplier.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 1 -- The local office of Hecht, Hill and Lancaster announced today the removal of Alexander Mackendrick as director of "The Devil's Disciple," now being filmed in England with Burt Lancaster, Sir Laurence Olivier and Kirk Douglas as co-stars. "Difference of opinion" was given as the reason.
STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 1 -- The fourth and final day of competition in the Eastern junior race week open regatta began with a fine sailing start today. It ended in a calm.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UPI) -Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, led a fight yesterday that defeated proposals to increase pensions for Congress and its employes.
High ethics will henceforth be the standard in the city's scandal-torn Bureau of Real Estate, its 200 employes were told yesterday by their new chief.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- President Eisenhower asked Congress today for an additional $25,000,000 for the Atomic Energy Commission.
An impending clash of Administration Middle East policies and Congressional moves to restrict imports came to light yesterday.
SOUTHAMPTON, L. I. Aug. 1 -- Enrique Morea of Argentina was beaten in the Southampton invitation tennis tournament today after having his opponent at his mercy in the opening set.
LONDON, Aug. 1 -- The gold and dollar reserves held by Britain as central banker for the sterling area showed another increase last month, but it was the smallest gain this year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- J. Edgar Hoover predicted today that the country's crime rate would rise 35 per cent within the next ten years.

Van Cliburn, the American pianist who won the International Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow last April 13, has been invited by the Soviet Union to give two concerts at the Brussels World's Fair Aug. 16 and 17. But the young Texan does not know whether he will be able to accept.
The Federal Government impounded 821 cases of Japanese tea yesterday for further tests of radioactivity.
JERSEY CITY, Aug 1 -- Mayor Charles S. Witkowski was asked today to set up a charter commission to determine the form of government best suited for this city.
The C. I. T. Financial Corporation is diversifying with the acquisition of the Picker X-Ray Corporation, maker of X-ray and radiation equipment.
DETROIT, Aug. 1 -- The Chrysler Corporation announced today that it would enter the small car field as the sole distributor of the French-built Simca in the United States and Canada.
Your July 30 editorial on the cost of shipping books overseas is timely. But you did not cover the shipping of used books overseas.

The rapidly rising tension between the Roman Catholic Church in Poland and the Communist regime of that country has broken into the open these past few days. The Communist regime has resorted to force, even at Poland's holiest shrine, to try to find evidence for its charge that the church is engaged in reactionary political activity.
PENDLETON, Ore., Aug. 1 (AP) -- Capt. Marion (Pat) Boling landed today at 11:52 A. M. Pacific Standard time in his single-engine plane, ending a record nonstop flight of 6,979 miles from Manila.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower returned from a twenty-day tour of Latin America today and promptly unveiled a three-point program designed to bind this country and its southern neighbors closer together.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -The United States will probably recognize the new regime in Iraq tomorrow, officials here said today.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 1 -- Los Angeles Musicians Local 47 and its president, Eliot Daniel, won today a week's delay on a contempt hearing that had been set for Monday by Superior Court Judge Bayard Rhone.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 1 -- The United States and Britain submitted today their formal request that the Security Council hold a special meeting Aug. 12 to take up "certain problems of the Middle East."
PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 1 (Reuters) -- Ninety-one South Africans went on trial here today in a converted synagogue on charges of high treason or offenses under the nation's anti-Communist laws.
WASHINGTON Aug. 1 (AP) -The Senate Antitrust Sub-committee voted today to start hearings promptly on the increase in steel prices.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The United States withdrew today a detachment of United States Marines sent into Cuban territory to guard the water supply for the United States Navy's Guantanamo base. The marines returned to the base.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) --Mike Stepovich resigned today as Territorial Governor of Alaska, citing his candidacy for the Senate from the about-to-be forty-ninth state.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UPI) -Senator Clifford P. Case, Republican of New Jersey, introduced a bill today to require top Federal officials, Senators, Representatives and candidates for office to file an annual report on their income and gifts.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The House Agriculture Committee voted unanimously today for a farm bill that would give the Administration more of what it had sought than a measure passed by the Senate.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Aug. 1 -- Moviegoers here are protesting against the rigorous South African censorship of "color" films before they reach Rhodesia.

HONG KONG, Aug. 1 -- Marshal Chu Teh has called for a strengthening of Communist China's national defenses and declared that the people of the world must be prepared to crush any attacks against them, "thereby wiping out for good the imperialist system."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- An Air Force construction officer denied today that he had criticized a House Appropriations subcommittee.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -Representative John A. Blatnik said today that many cigarette advertisments were misleading about the effectiveness of filter tips as a protection against lung cancer.
Price increases began spreading to a long list of steel products yesterday. The higher aluminum price announced on Thursday by the largest producer was matched by the rest of the aluminum makers.
BOSTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- NilsOlov Wisell, 11-year-old Swedish boy who had no kidneys, died tonight in Peter Bent Brigham Hospital where doctors had been considering a kidney transplant from his mother.
No summit negotiation can escape re-examination of the Palestine problem. In that hitherto insoluble question are joined virtually all emotional threads of the explosive Middle East.

President Eisenhower has joined Prime Minister Macmillan in inviting Premier Khrushchev to meet with them at a special session of the United Nations Security Council "on or about" Aug. 12 to deal with the turbulent Middle East. Since both Britain and the United States formally request a Council meeting it must be held, and both the President and the Prime Minister announce that they will be there waiting for him.

Louis E. Wolfson, the industrialist, has signed a consent decree in Federal Court here restraining him and persons associated with him from engaging in fraudulent transactions in American Motors Corporation common stock.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 1 -- The forty-seventh annual conference of the Interparliamentary Union closed today after a week of debates marked by East-West wrangling.

ROME, Aug. 1 (AP) -- A Christian Democrat deputy asked the Justice Ministry today if Italian legal requirements were met when Ingrid Bergman and Roberto Rossellini were married by proxy in Mexico in 1950.
GENEVA, Aug. 1 -- The East-West conference of scientific experts agreed today on the detection instruments to be put into a system for policing a ban on tests of nuclear weapons.
LONDON, Aug. 1 -- Britain recognized today the new Government of Iraq.
CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (AP) -Clearing skies and an outlook for warm weather depressed grain futures today on the Board of Trade.
Plans for a long-range medical program for West Berlin were outlined yesterday at a reception here for a group of four Berlin physicians and an architect.

Johnson Johnson, world's largest manufacturer of surgical dressings and producer of an extensive line of related items, had lower sales and earnings in the first six months this year than a year earlier.
Bryant Park lunch-hour fans and idlers enjoyed a big serving of Caruso al fresco yesterday.

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Aug. 1 (AP) -- National civil defense leaders mapped plans today for wide distribution of radiation - measurement devices to high schools and for the training of a million persons in their use.

In your editorial of July 27 you suggest that Representative Reuss' proposal to place responsibility for controlling inflation in the President's hands would "violate one of the most vital traditions of American monetary policy -- namely, the independence of the Federal Reserve Board."

Federal Judge Richard H. Levet denied here yesterday the request of the E. L. Bruce Company of Memphis, Tenn., producer of hardwood flooring, for an injunction against the Empire Millwork Corporation.
TENAFLY, N. J., Aug. 2 -Professionally, Dr. Virginia Apgar, an anesthetist, puts people to sleep. Off duty she tends to keep them awake with a new hobby -- violin making.

A WISE gardener has said of herbs that they are sweetest when bruised or trodden upon. The ones with lemon-scented leaves seem most delightful of all when they are brushed against in the garden. Lemon balm, lemon basil, lemon bergamot, lemon thyme (both the creeping variety and the erect, variegated-leaved type), lemon verbena and lemonscented catnip all have their own distinctive combination of herbal and citrus scent.

For many who will be entering college it represents -- whether they realize it consciously or not -- the last days of an old way of life, and the prelude to one that is challenging, exciting -- and a little frightening.

CAIRNS, QUEENSLAND -One of Australia's most fascinating and popular attractions these winter months is the Underwater Coral Gardens Observatory at Green Island near here. Built by an enterprising engineer, in partnership with a crocodile hunter, the Observatory is situated on the Great Barrier Reef.
