MOSCOW, Aug. 3 (UPI) -- Adlai E. Stevenson delivered a sermon on spiritual values today before an overflow congregation of about 2,000 Russians at Moscow's Baptist Church.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 3 -- Steel prices went up piecemeal last week. With all flat-rolled steel having advanced, and with some makers posting increases on other items, it was believed to be a matter of time before prices of all other products would be raised.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Aug. 3 -- Rear Admiral Liu Hoh-tu, a Defense Ministry spokesman, asserted today that the Soviet Union "very likely" would make the Chinese Communists start a war in the Taiwan (Formosa) area while world attention was focused on the Middle East.

Two anthologies of the literature of exploration are scheduled for publication this month by Oxford University Press. On Thursday will be issued "Australian Explorers," edited by Kathleen Fitzpatrick, Associate Professor of History at the University of Melbourne.

IN the world of new books the autumn season usually begins in the middle of August. During the six preceding weeks numerous volumes are published, but few of these seem very important to their publishers, to reviewers or to the reading public. It's an old American custom -- something to do with vacations, Labor Day and Christmas.
CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (UPI) -- Ken Venturi recorded his third straight subpar round today and took a three-stroke lead in the Gleneagles $50,000 open golf tourney.
MERRICK, L. I. Aug. 3 -- Three persons were burned here today when a twenty-one-foot cabin cruiser exploded while refueling at Nick's Boat Yard. The accident occurred at about 5:30 P. M.
WILTON, Conn., Aug. 3 -- This town has a new $60,000 "bridge to nowhere" on its hands.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 3 -- Argentines were urged today to restrict their consumption of beef.

Our preoccupation with the Middle East and a summit conference has fortunately not interfered with Secretary of State Dulles' trip to Rio de Janeiro. During the crisis Dr. Milton Eisenhower and his group of high Government economic and political experts went serenely ahead with their swing around the Central American countries and Panama, from which they returned on Friday.
The Salvation Army scored a notable victory over one of its historic enemies yesterday when it opened a community center in a building that used to house a tavern.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 3 -- A conference of teachers was told here tonight that students were not being developed to give their ideas and energies to humanity but rather to accumulate "a two-car garage and a membership in a country club."

FLEMINGTON, N. J., Aug. 3 -- Ch. Ann's Own Gay Knight of Arhill, black standard poodle owned by Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Wegmann of Ridgefield, Conn., was the best-in-show dog at today's second annual Hunterdon Hills Kennel Club event at the Flemington Fair Grounds.

Two police detectives held about 200 shouting persons at bay with drawn pistols in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn yesterday after they had arrested a young woman who allegedly interfered in their questioning of a narcotics suspect. Some in the crowd threw rocks and broke glass paneling in an apartment house that was used by the detectives as a refuge.

Vessel traffic in the Port of New York last month fell below the level of July, 1957, both in arrivals and departures, according to a monthly report of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York. The association listed 1,054 arrivals and 1,061 departures, declines of seventy-five and fifty vessels, respectively.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 3 -- The United States was expected to start consultations here tomorrow on arrangements for a summit meeting of the Security Council on the Middle East.
BERLIN, Aug. 3 (AP) -- West Berlin was angered today by another East German abduction -- this time of a statue.

TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 3 (AP) -- Sylvia Ruuska, 16, of Berkeley, Calif., tonight broke the American record in the 200-meter butterfly for her fourth title in the National Amateur Athletic Union women's senior outdoor swimming championships.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Nobody here professes to be happy about last week's steel price increases, but among economists there is perhaps less alarm and distress than in Congress.
MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 3 -- The 1958 contract bridge Summer National Championships continued here this afternoon at the Americana Hotel with large fields entered in three simultaneous events.
AMMAN, Jordan, Aug 3 (AP) -- Informed sources said tonight that Israel had canceled permission for British and United States planes to fly over her territory to supply British forces in Jordan.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- The Chinese Communist-Soviet communique issued in Peiping today provided diplomats here with no solid clues as to what the Soviet Union intended to do about a heads-of-government meeting on the Middle East.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 3 -- The Milwaukee Braves today dealt the Giants two more staggering jolts in San Francisco's bid to remain a National League pennant contender.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 3 -- Hamilton Richardson won the Southampton invitation tennis tournament today. His performance encouraged the belief that he will be ready for an assignment in the Davis Cup match with Argentina at the Westchester Country Club in Rye this month.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Doubt that the Soviet Union will accept United States terms for a summit-level Security Council meeting was strengthened slightly today by the communique following Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev's secret meeting with Mao Tse-tung, leader of Communist China.

Today is the 223d anniversary of the acquittal of John Peter Zenger on charges his newspaper had been guilty of libel, an acquittal won on the ground that what he had printed was the truth. For many years now it has been widely recognized that this event in our colonial history was an important milestone in creating our present treasured tradition of freedom of the press.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 3 -- Senator William F. Knowland challenged his Democratic rival today to a series of public debates from one end of California to the other in the fall campaign for the Governorship.

THE remodeling of two rooms originally designed for use by maids into one attractive guest room-study has resulted in a charming decorative effect on an entire area in the New York apartment of Mrs. Veronica Cenelli.

LONDON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Following is the text of a joint communique issued in Peiping today by Soviet Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev and Mao Tse-tung, Chinese Communist chief of state, as broadcast in English by the Peiping radio:
MOSCOW, Aug. 3 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev has spent the last four days in Peiping in consultation with Communist China's leader, Mao Tse-tung.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Aug. 3 -- The stock markets showed no decided trend last week. Because of political and business uncertainties, buyers were cautious and holders little inclined to sell.

News recently in The Times that the Fifth Avenue bus line is operating at a loss should surprise nobody. The public simply refuses to pay two fares to reach any give destination, and the Fifth Avenue line does not supply transfers necessary to bus riders.
The Long Island Rail Road has won a point with the Public Service Commission -- that Westbury is no longer a horsey enough suburb to warrant a horse-loading platform at its station.
NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 3 -- Columbia defeated her three rival America's Cup candidates off here today in the New York Yacht Club's annual race for the Caritas Cup.

BYRON GORDON MacNABB is Mr. Mac to thousands of rocket buffs on and around Cape Canaveral, Fla. But an equally apt name might be Mr. Missile. Nobody on or off the Cape is a better symbol of a new order of Americans -- the Missile Men.
NEWARK, Aug. 3 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner declared here tonight that he would sign into law a bill prohibiting the Sunday sale of clothing and home and office appliances and furnishings.

The usual story of teen-age ambition and enterprise involves writing sports for the local newspaper (see the games), a baby-sitting task (watching the shows), running errands or plain mowing the lawn. Few big companies are formed by teen-agers. But one is the United Parcel Service, started by James E. Casey, a teen-ager who stayed with his job as president of the company.
Traffic, mainly in the mass and not in movement, clogged the highways leading from Jones Beach and other bathing areas yesterday. Sudden rains drove thousands home at about the same time.
Five films are scheduled to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

WASHINGTON. Aug. 3 -- Secretary of State Dulles and a group of aides took off by plane for Rio de Janeiro today. Mr. Dulles will confer there with President Juscelino Kubitschek, Foreign Minister Francisco Negrao de Lima and other Brazilian officials.
CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The grain futures trade was practically becalmed last week on the Board of Trade.
I entirely agree with your editorial "The 'Doctors' on TV" of July 26.

With the prospect of a summit meeting imminent, it is apparently viewing reports from both side that preparations are being made for mutually condemnatory attacks rather than for a desperate attempt at reducing international tensions.
AMMAN, Jordan. Aug. 3 (AP) -- Twenty-seven Arabs went on trial today on charges of having entered from Syria with arms and explosives to overthrow the Jordanian Government.
TRENTON, Aug. 3 -- Bob Malzahn of Miami; Bob Marshman of Collegeville, Pa., and Bert Brooks of Paterson were the winners today in a triple-header automobile racing program at the Trenton Speedway.
Hashim Jawad, appointed by the new Iraqi Government as its delegate to the United Nations, affirmed yesterday that his Government still was bound by the provisions of the Baghdad Pact.

A mortgage loan of $2,250,000 at 6 per cent interest has been obtained by Pierpont Associates on the New York Dock Trades Facilities Building at 360 Furman Street, Brooklyn. The Sonnenblick-Goldman Corporation, mortgage brokers, arranged the financing.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Aug. 3 -- The need for a new north-south limited-access highway traversing Bergen County, preferably through the Hackensack Valley, is emphasized in a report by the County Planning Board.

More than 250,000 Jehovah's Witnesses heard their leader declare yesterday that "we know not the day or the hour, but the world's end is near." Thousands greeted the prophecy with applause. The huge crowd jammed both the Yankee Stadium and the Polo Grounds. Outside the ball parks Witnesses sat on railings, curbs and on newspapers spread on the sidewalks.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 3 -- The baseball campaign is settling down to the pattern the game's outstanding academic minds predicted it would take away back in April.

FIFTY years ago the town's late sleepers heard the clop-clop of the milkman's horse on cobbled streets after dawn. Through the day pedestrians dodged between big drays, moving vans and brewery trucks pulled by massive work animals.

BEAD curtains, now in their second year of revival, continue to be a popular decorating idea. This is borne out by the fact that, following a recent column devoted to various materials that may be used in making them, readers asked for "more, more, more."

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- By this time everyone knows that Casey Stengel has oil wells, real estate, banks and money. Until today, though, few were aware that the manager of the front-running Yankees had ulcers, too. He disclosed the ailment even before his Bombers dropped a 3-1 and 4-0 decision to the White Sox at Comiskey Park.

PELHAM MANOR, N. Y., Aug. 3 -- The New York Athletic Club, which had the largest entry, finished with the highest score today in the annual metropolitan championships of the New York Rowing Association on Pelham Lagoon.
Councilman Earl Brown yesterday accused Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. of "racist tendencies" and "treason to the Democratic party."
Sam Giammalva was watching big Barry MacKay and Alejandro Olmedo blast each other with service aces at the Merion Cricket Club and turned to the old-timer sitting with him.
In mid-January of this year the Federal Reserve Board announced that, effective Jan. 16, stock market minimum margin requirements would be reduced from 70 per cent to 50 per cent.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 3 -- Strict security measures are being taken by Brazilian authorities to assure the safety of Secretary of State Dulles. Even the details of his schedule here, beginning with his arrival tomorrow afternoon, are being kept secret.
A plot containing 15,000 square feet has been assembled near the Grand Army Plaza at a cost of $1,000,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 3 -- Eugene Frenke, for the last three years associated with Twentieth Century-Fox, will join Seven Arts Productions as a producer upon the completion, within the next few weeks, of his current contract.
The Presbytery of New York condemned the policies of Dr. Morris A. Jacobs, Commissioner of Hospitals, yesterday in the controversy over birth control.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Aug. 3 -- Although he finished sixth in today's third and final test, 17-year-old Vincent (Bizzy) Monte-Sano of the Larchmont Yacht Club won the Atlantic Coast Lightning Class championship.

The United Fruit Company, by harvesting bananas in Latin America, is playing a leading role in helping the economies of its host countries, a report issued over the week-end by the National Planning Association says.

The full significance of Premier Khrushchev's hurried and secret conferences in Peiping with Mao Tse-tung will undoubtedly become clearer over the next few days. But certainly the text of the communique issued yesterday must raise new trepidation about the chances of getting a quick and amicable solution to the Middle Eastern problems.

WHEN a cupful is not a cupful? All too often it would seem, judging by the inaccuracy of some of the measuring utensils that are sold here. Recently a reader, justifiably disgruntled, wrote that, when he tested a set of graduated glassware measuring cups he had been using, they proved to hold an ounce more than they should.

Rights to "What Shall We Tell Caroline?" and "The Dock Brief," a comedy bill that was presented successfully in London, have been tied up by David Susskind and Albert Selden. The output represents the initial playwriting attempt of John Mortimer, British novelist and lawyer.
WARSAW, Aug. 3 -- There are nineteen young Americans spending their vacations in Europe this summer who have been seeing, hearing and doing a lot of things not included in any guide book.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 3 -- The Screen Directors Guild of America threatened today to attempt to enforce a work boycott against Samuel Goldwyn as a result of the producer's dismissal last Sunday of Rouben Mamoulian as director of "Porgy and Bess."
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Aug. 3 -- The skippers turning out for the second half of the Echo Bay Yacht Club's weekend regatta today again enjoyed excellent competition.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 3 -- Intensive backstage negotiations were believed today to be close to resolving Lebanon's twelve-week-old political crisis.

A two-year study by the State Division of Housing shows that more than one-third of our 1,600 cities, towns and villages do not inspect new construction to assure safety, sanitation and restraint of fire hazards. There is even less inspection of older buildings. Many communities have no building code. Where there is a code enforcement usually is undertaken only in specific cases after citizens have complained of violations.
Bids will be opened this week for one of the most expensive sections of the city's arterial highway system.

ANKARA, Turkey, Monday, Aug. 4 -- The Ministry of Finance announced late last night that beginning today the Turkish lira would buy and sell for nine to one United States dollar. The Government said, however, that it would keep the official rate of exchange at the present 2.8 to $1, thus leaving unchanged the amount of Turkish lira involved in Turkey's foreign debt.
Thomas K. Finletter characterized the Eisenhower Administration yesterday as "complacent" and "callous" in its attitude toward unemployment.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 3 -- An all-Wagner program under the direction of Pierre Monteux brought the fifth weekend of the Boston Symphony's Berkshire Festival to a close this afternoon in a blaze of summer sunshine.
A boom in private housing and small-factory construction in Brooklyn in the first six months of 1958 was reported yesterday by Borough President John Cashmore.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 3 -- Boredom is the biggest enemy the United States Marines are fighting here. After that come flies and mosquitos.

PARIS, Aug. 3 (Reuters) -- Nineteen international oil groups have set up a joint company here to study and seek Government support for a gaint pipeline project linking the Mediterranean and the Rhine River, it was announced yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Boston broke out of its five-game losing slump today with a double-header sweep over the Cleveland Indians, 3 -- 2 and 4 -- 2. Ted Williams' two-run homer in the ninth inning won the opener. Pete Runnels' two-run double featured a four-run eighth-inning rally in the nightcap.
ZURICH, Switzerland, Aug. 3 -- Despite the stifling heat, stock exchange business last week, described by operators as "terrific," exceeded in volume anything known in 1958.
The rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration observed yesterday that "we are always looking for the presence of evil, seldom for the absence of God in human affairs."
I should like to call your attention to the significance for America and Americans of three news items in The Times of July 27.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) -- The General Services Administration will seek bids from private builders for construction of eight air route traffic control buildings for lease to the Government, it was announced today.
Pride was described in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday as one of the greatest threats to man's salvation throughout Christian history.

SHELTER ISLAND, L. I., Aug. 3 -- Curtis Jones of the Shelter Island Yacht Club won the Star Class competition as the Eastern Long Island Yachting Association's three-day regatta ended today. In three races, Jones finished seventh once and first twice for 9 points.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- An adjournment-minded Congress hopes to finish work this week on a reciprocal trade bill and an omnibus farm measure acceptable to the Administration.
The tea was tangy and the flanneled pageantry impeccable as international cricket made its second visit of the year yesterday to Downing Stadium, Randalls Island.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) -- Senator Clifford P. Case, Republican of New Jersey, said today that he had asked Sherman Adams to resign shortly after it was disclosed that Mr. Adams had received gifts from Bernard Goldfine.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Peter Collins. one of the Big Three of British sports car racing, died tonight of injuries received when he crashed his Ferrari in the German Grand Prix at near-by Adenau.
Compton Advertising, Inc., has resigned the $2,500,000 account of the Nehi Corporation, a soft-drink manufacturer.
The steamship charter market has return to the somnolent state that marked it prior to the latest Middle East crisis.

Dr. B. R. Sen, director of the Food and Agricultural Organization, has made an interesting and provocative proposal to the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations. He suggests that a "year," like the Geophysical one, be set aside for an international campaign against hunger throughout the world. United Nations agencies would participate, as well as many national and international organizations.
CHRIS SCHENKEL, who is seen before and after the Saturday afternoon racing telecasts over the Columbia Broadcasting System, has been demonstrating an intelligent and imaginative approach to his job.
One woman was shot yesterday after a quarrel with another woman in the Bronx. An airman who was passing by and who tried to stop the dispute was also wounded.
LONDON, Aug. 3 -- The stock markets were quiet last week and there was no marked movement in prices one way or the other.

ROME, Aug. 3 -- Returning from a week's trip to the United States, Britain and Wes Germany, Premier Amintore Fanfani said today that the West's approach to the Middle East problems was sympathetic and constructive.
Five turquoise and coral necklaces that once ornamented the costume of a Navajo Indian chief will be displayed, starting tomorrow, at the Museum of Primitive Art, 15 West Fifty-fourth Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Outlays for new construction in July set a new record for that month, exceeding by 3 per cent the previous July high set last year, the Departments of Commerce and Labor reported today.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Aug. 2 -- Qualified observers within the North American Air Defense Command expect Canada to raise the question of sharing United States nuclear air defense weapons at forthcoming discussions between defense officials of the two countries.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The West pledged $359,000,000 today in economic assistance to Turkey, its strongest and most stable ally in the Middle East.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 1 -- The release of a limited list of essential imports for which certificates will be issued at devaluated exchange rates sent the free market rate for dollars soaring today.
A candidate for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate recalled yesterday that he had started his business career in the Bronx by washing dishes at 17 cents an hour.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Secretary of State Dulles flew off to Brazil today in the midst of preparations for the proposed United Nations summit meeting on the Middle Eastern crisis.
Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev appears to have pledged to the Chinese Communist regime that its interests will be advanced rather than hurt by any summit meeting on the Middle East crisis.
At the end of 1956, non-white persons occupied 375,000 dwelling units in the metropolitan area, an increase of about 50 per cent since 1950.

ROME, Aug. 3 -- The almost complete skeleton of a four-foot-high manlike creature has been found in a coal mine at Baccinello in the mountains fifteen miles northeast of Grosseto. It is believed to be the earliest progenitor of man yet discovered.
Alexander P. de Seversky forecast yesterday the "destruction of our nation within three years" if present Government military policies were continued.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) -- The Senate Republican leader, William F. Knowland of California, said today that the control of the Senate next year could be decided by "one or two votes" in favor of either party.
Americans were warned in a sermon at Riverside Church yesterday that they "had better not strut their self-righteousness'' at international conference tables if they wish for peace.

Schweppes (U. S. A.), Ltd., American subsidiary of the British manufacturer of carbonated waters, will move about Sept. 1 to 445 Park Avenue at Fifty-sixth Street where it has leased offices through Cushman Wakefield, Inc., broker.

It may be recalled that the Wagner administration pledged itself to relieve the ever-worsening street traffic snarls in midcity. While some reforms have been made and engineering advances have been impressive, the administration still finds it more politically expedient to pay only lip service to some important relief measures.

Tobias Stone, who was censured and banned from international play for a year by the American Contract Bridge League, will seek relief in the courts.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 3 -- The Soviet Union has made a specialty of turning the riches of its folk songs and dances to modern account.
PARIS, Aug. 3 (Reuters) -- More than 36,000,000,000 francs ($86,400,000) will be spent on Paris' two main airports, Orly and Le Bourget, in the next two years.

Christians today tend to view Christ as "conventional, uninspiring and dull," the Rev. Kenneth Maguire said yesterday. This picture of Jesus, he said, fails to attract youth, the core of Christianity 1,900 years ago.

The Port of New York led the nation again last year in the value of ocean-borne foreign trade. But in tonnage the port ended 1957 in third place. Official returns for the full calendar year put the value of foreign commerce handled here at $8,700,000,000.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 3 -- No official Yugoslav comment was available tonight on the meeting in Peiping. Almost all ranking Government officials were out of town, either on Brioni Island, President Tito's summer retreat on the Adriatic coast, or on holiday.

"ILLWOO ouyay eboo oingay immingswoo oonsay?" At one time or another youngsters everywhere break out in streams of talk like this, usually to the delight of their contemporaries and the thorough irritation of their parents.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 3 -- Robert Murphy completed talks with leaders of Iraq's new revolutionary regime today and said he intended to visit Cairo Tuesday for a meeting with President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic.

The Most Rev. Geoffrey Francis Fisher, Archbishop of Canterbury, was defended yesterday by the Rev. Canon Samuel Wylie, associate secretary of the division of college work of the National Council of the Protestant Episcopal Church.

PIERRE, S. D., Aug. 3 -- Great earth-moving machines and sweating men, working under floodlights bright as a baseball park's, raced time and the river today to seal the Oahe Dam against the mighty, muddy Missouri.
William Hammerstein has been named producer of Arthur Godfrey's new musical-variety show, which begins next month over the Columbia Broadcasting System television network.
If Mayor Wagner wants to be considered for the Democratic nomination for the Senate, he will have to say so, Carmine G. De Sapio said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Everyone here remarked Friday on the different tone and style of the Presidents latest note to Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev. These were supplied by C. D. Jackson of Time, Inc., who was formerly the President's adviser on psychological warfare.

The Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation reported over the week-end higher operating revenues and net income for the three and twelve months ended June 30. Orville S. Carpenter, president, traced the gains to increased gas volume resulting from expansion projects and higher gas rates, subject to refund after Federal Power commission hearings.

Along Harlem's hot and crowded streets an odd and tempestuous political war is sweeping to a climax.
MOSCOW, Aug. 3 -- Three scientists from Nationalist China are not yet registered as delegates to the Fifth Assembly of the governing body of the International Geophysical Year here.
Five firemen were injured, one of them seriously, while fighting a three-alarm blaze and explosion yesterday afternoon in a Bronx ice cream parlor and restaurant.

ABOARD U. S. S. SARATOGA, with the Sixth Fleet, off Lebanon, Aug. 3 -- Carrier-based aircraft of the Sixth Fleet passed the 3,000-sortie mark for the Lebanese operation this week-end without having used a gun, bomb, rocket or missile.

Air Force generals on opposite coasts of the country kept in close touch yesterday in the wake of the first successful firing of a three-engined Atlas intercontinental ballistic missile from Cape Canaveral, Fla.

The summer series of concerts at Lewisohn Stadium came to an end with the eleventh annual Rodgers and Hammerstein program Saturday evening. (Tonight's concert, featuring Van Cliburn, is a post-season event.)
THE oldest active Federal judge in the country presided over the court that heard the Little Rock integration appeal in St. Louis today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI) -- The Labor Department reported today that there had been fewer strikes and man-days lost because of strikes in the first six months of this year than in any corresponding period since the end of World War II.
DETROIT, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The nation's auto makers so far this year have built 2,575,402 passenger cars, compared with 3,914,192 a year earlier.
CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 4 -- The United States Army began landing seventy-five tanks in Lebanon today. The tanks were brought across a beach south of the International Airport in small craft from the cargo carrier Comet, whose captain is Eiliv M. Norvik of Glen Cove, L. I.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Aug. 4 (AP) -- A Chinese Nationalist Foreign Ministry statement tonight said "the Khrushchev-Mao statement reads like an up-to-date implementation of the Communist blueprint for world conquest."
The Federal Housing Administration has prepared a booklet, titled "FHA Owner's Guide," which answers many questions that owners of new homes ask.
After nearly a month's tour of the United States, a group of Soviet students yesterday appraised certain aspects of this country's civilization.

MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 4 -- Mrs. Florence Thomas and Sam Katz, of Miami Beach, this afternoon led a field of 132 contract bridge pairs in the Life Master Pairs Championship, most important pair championship of the 1958 Summer National Championships.

HAMBURG, Germany, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Budge Patty of Los Angeles and Paris, lost to 21-year-old Warren Woodcock of Australia in the second round of the Hamburg tennis tournament today and then collapsed after the match.
RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 4 -- Prince Edward County won a tentative seven-year delay today in desegregating its public schools.

Following are recommendations made in a report yesterday by the Department of Education on long-term steps the department considers necessary to reduce the number of behavior-problem pupils in New York City:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- President Eisenhower exercised his veto power over Congressional appropriations for the first time today.

CARLSTADT, N. J., Aug. 4 -- The Meadowlands Regional Planning Board has received a favorable report on the possibility of using a gas pipeline's service road for a dike in the reclamation of the Hackensack Meadows.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The United Nations summit meeting, which seems to have divided Washington from Paris and London, and even Moscow from Peiping, is now beginning to divide the Eisenhower Administration.

The National Distillers and Chemical Corporation of this city has acquired the Kordite division of Textron, Inc., diversified industrial corporation. The announcement was made yesterday by Roy F. Coppedge Jr., president of National Distillers.
A new concept in calculating the cost of office space has been suggested by a realty broker whose specialty is commercial leasing.
It is vacation time, and one of the things women do in preparation for going away is to clean up their desks. The reason for this is as mysterious as most of the mysteries which surround them.

Morris Karp and Bernard Sanford have purchased the five-story apartment house at 503 East 180th Street, the Bronx, from a client of Perry Coburn. The property contains twenty-three apartments and three stores.
The thirty-third annual Music Memory Contest of the Guggenheim Memorial Concerts was held last night. But nobody won.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Aug. 4 -- Israel conceded today that she had withdrawn permission for Britain and the United States to fly planes over Israel to Jordan.
COOPERSTOWN, N. Y., Aug. 4 -- Baseball opened a regal new heroes' gallery at its birthplace today.
A comprehensive program to combat juvenile delinquency in the city school system was proposed yesterday by the State Education Department.

The results of the proxy contest for control of Unexcelled Chemical Corporation were blocked again yesterday by a management request in New York State Supreme Court here for an injunction to prevent a tabulation of proxies.
It now appears certain that "The $64,000 Challenge" will move from the Columbia Broadcasting System to the National Broadcasting Company television network on Sept. 25.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 4 (AP) -- A New York physician was on today's list of witnesses subpoenaed to testify next week before a Federal grand jury here on operations of a gambling syndicate at Terre Haute.

Second-quarter sales and earnings of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company (the 3 M company) showed substantial improvement over the first quarter, but half-year results failed to equal those of last year, according to the report released today.

Looking back over the past month's developments in the troubled Middle East one fact stands out above all others. A situation that began with revolution and murder in Iraq and was then followed by American and British troop movements into Lebanon and Jordan, plus highly publicized Soviet "maneuvers" near Iran and Turkey, has changed its character.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 4 -- The Government fears a new attempt momentarily to overthrow it. Political arrests are continuing. There is no indication when the curfew will be relaxed. The nation is under an incessant barrage of propaganda from two clandestine radio stations suspected of being operated on the Haitian-Dominican border.
Directors of the General Motors Corporation declared a quarterly dividend of 50 cents yesterday on the common stock, payable Sept. 10 to holders of record Aug. 14.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- A strange combination of political forces threatened today to prevent passage of farm legislation that moves a long way toward the position advocated by the Secretary of Agriculture, Ezra Taft Benson.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 4 -- Champagne must have run in Rossini's veins when he wrote the sparkling comic opera "The Count Ory," which the students of the Berkshire Music Center Opera Department performed tonight in the Theatre-Concert Hall at Tanglewood.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 4 -- The Thai Government proclaimed a state of emergency tonight in the six provinces bordering on Cambodia.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. rejected help from Communists yesterday in his fight for renomination in the Democratic primary next Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury indicted two communications workers today for contempt of Congress because of their refusal to answer questions before the House Committee on Un-American Activities in 1957.

Bowlers in the New York metropolitan area may soon be masters of discrimination and as choosy as any sports enthusiasts concerning their place of recreation. The number of new and improved lanes in the vicinity is reaching such a point that some proprietors are becoming concerned.

The promising Len Matthews of Philadelphia gained a firm foothold in the lightweight picture last night when he knocked out Steve Ward of Hartford in the ninth round of the main event at the St. Nicholas Arena.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The second round of the steel industry's selective price increase was endorsed today by the United States Steel Corporation and the Bethlehem Steel Company. The two biggest companies followed the lead of other, smaller concerns that last week posted higher prices for bars, rods, wire and tubular products.
INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Mrs. Connie Nicholas, divorcee, conferred with lawyers today and they moved to make a plea of self-defense in her killing of Forrest Teel, drug company executive.
The Coca-Cola Company in the second quarter this year showed a sharp gain in earnings over those of the first three months, but were slightly lower than the quarter a year ago.

The American Civil Liberties Union said yesterday that the Immigration and Naturalization Service had not given a fair hearing to a Polish seaman seeking political asylum in the United States. It asked a complete hearing on his plea.

PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 4 -- Princeton University's program under which specially qualified students are chosen each year to aid professors in research will celebrate its tenth anniversary in September.
EAST ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 4 -- A group of teen-agers is providing something new in treatment for patients at the Veterans Administration hospital here. Hospital staffers call it "morale therapy."

GANDER RIVER, Nfld., Aug. 3 -- Fishing gear in places such as this beautiful river becomes a problem, and an angler is likely to bring along stuff he doesn't need and leave at home things he does need.
Nelson A. Rockefeller formally opened headquarters for his campaign for the Republican nomination for Governor yesterday. They are in the International Building, 19 West Fiftieth Street.

After a recent trip along the Jersey seashore from Point Pleasant to Seaside Heights I could not help reflecting how fortunate we are here on Long Island to have Jones Beach, properly rated as one of New York's seven wonders. We owe a great deal to those who had the foresight of protecting from commercial desecration the natural beauty of this world-famous stretch of dunes.
DETROIT, Aug. 4 -- A business agent of the Teamsters Union was set afire and critically burned today by two mysterious assailants.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 4 -- Lebanon's President-elect said tonight that withdrawal of foreign troops was his foremost aim.
A harmonious chord has been struck between the sexes on the subject of high fidelity.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 4 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold is negotiating with the New York real estate firm of Webb Knapp for the construction of an office and apartment building for delegates.
Because of a fortuitous circumstance, Michael J. Walsh of 111-36 121st Street, South Ozone Park, Queens, will be a day student at St. John's University, Flushing, Queens, instead of a night student.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 4 -- The motion-picture industry is in "dire trouble" financially and "it is in need of help," the Motion Picture Industry Council has declared in an appeal to Congress for quick action on pending tax relief legislation.

LONDON, Aug 4 -- British exports to Red China totaled 7,046,501 (about $19,800,000) in the first half this year, an increase of 60 per cent over the first half of 1947, according to a report to be published here tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Federal Reserve Board today increased from 50 to 70 per cent the margin requirements for buying and selling stocks and bonds. The order is effective tomorrow.
The decline in corporate profits was checked in the second quarter, the First National City Bank of New York reported yesterday in its August monthly bank letter.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The House Commerce Committee said today that Bernard Goldfine had "no justification" for refusing to answer questions put by its special Subcommittee on Legislative Oversight.

The aid just announced for Turkey from the Western nations ($359,000,000, of which the United States is furnishing $234,000,000) was necessary and is deserved. This is a general proposition with which no one can or should quarrel, despite obvious reservations.

The nation's largest copper producer, the Kennecott Copper Corporation, announced yesterday that it was increasing its work week from four to five days at mining properties in Utah, Nevada, Arizona and New Mexico.

THE Italians have great fun with pasta. With whimsical imagination. they shape it into more than 150 different forms, such as little pipes, butterflies, needle points, turbans and little muffs. Some of these macaroni products are now well known in this country; for example, ravioli and lasagna strips.

MOSCOW, Aug. 4 -- United States scientists in effect told the Russians today to look in their own backyard for the remnants of Sputnik I's rocket carrier, the return of which they had angrily demanded from the United States.
Jule Styne, composer-producer, has allied himself again with the team of Betty Comden and Adolph Green. They will work on a musical production of "Subways Are for Sleeping."
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 4 -- The joint communique issued by Soviet and Chinese Communist leaders in Peiping has produced mixed reaction here.

Coppers and aluminums took the lead yesterday, as issues on the New York Stock Exchange made their best one-day gains since Nov. 27, 1957. This raised the aggregate market value by almost $2,200,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI) -- The Government announced a revised patents policy today on discoveries by private industry engaged in cancer research under Government contract.
WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 4 -- Westchester's parkways were called "slaughter highways" today by some county officials.

AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 4 -- Syria, on this beleaguered Hashemite kingdom's northern border, has closed the frontier to all travel. Syria is a province of President Gamal Abdel Nasser's United Arab Republic.

TRENTON, Aug. 4 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner today signed a ban on Sunday sales by stores. It prohibits the Sunday sale of clothing, home and office appliances and furnishings, lumber and building materials in eighteen of New Jersey's twenty-one counties.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 4 -- The Eastern grass court championships started on the excellent turf of the Orange Lawn Tennis Club today with Ashley Cooper of Australia and Richard Savitt heading one of the most attractive entries to gather here.

Six hundred and forty-six selected senior high schools in New York and New Jersey will receive radiation-detecting devices this fall. It is expected that 100,000 students in the two states will be instructed in their use ultimately.

Seventy-eight local housing authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration are planning the sale of temporary loan notes totaling $282,421,000 on Aug. 12 to finance the development of low-rent projects. The notes will come due from Nov. 7, 1958, to June 12, 1959. Major borrowers are as follows:

BEIRUT, Aug. 4 (AP) -- President Chamoun underscored today his determination to keep United States forces here and indicated he did not intend to resign. He said he would attend a Middle East summit conference if one Were held.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee approved by a 9-1 vote today a bill designed to modify a Supreme Court ruling that freed a confessed rapist who had been sentenced to death. The House of Representatives passed a somewhat different measure on July 2.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 4 -- The new Soviet Ambassador to Iraq Grigory T. Zaitsev, arrived today to resume diplomatic relations between the two countries, broken since January, 1955.
The Cunard Steam-Ship Company, Ltd., disclosed yesterday that negotiations were under way with the city for the construction of a $5,500,000 Hudson River pier.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 4 -- Secretary of State Dulles arrived today for two days of talks with President Juscelino Kubitschek.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- In baseball there is really nothing new under the sun or under the arcs. No matter what you see or hear today, you may be reasonably sure it has happened before. The names may change, the scenery may be different, but the format remains the same.
PARIS, Aug. 4 -- The composits loan to Turkey announced yesterday was the second large financial rescue operation this year. The first was the joint loan in January to save France from bankruptcy.
SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 4 -- Tom Munnell of the host Pequot Yacht Club captured the first race of the qualifying series for the Long Island Sound junior sailing championship today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI) -- The Senate approved today a series of bills aimed at liberalizing benefits for veterans and their families.
GENEVA, Aug. 4 -- The Soviet bloc delegation to the East-West technical talks declared today that no further atomic tests were necessary to establish the feasibility of detecting nuclear explosions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Anticipating admission of Alaska to the union and possible admission of other states, the House passed a bill today providing for the future design of the United States Flag.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The United States need not depend on Middle East oil supplies that could be cut off by enemy action, according to Senator Gordon Allott, Republican of Colorado.
The United States Court of Appeals yesterday unanimously reversed the Smith Act conspiracy convictions of six secondary Communist leaders. Then, in a 2-to-1 vote, the court dismissed the indictments.

It was with great interest that I read C. L. Sulzberger's column of July 17 on the Middle East crisis. As a leading analyst on foreign affairs Mr. Sulzberger's views always deserve the highest consideration.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company his canceled a major portion of its expansion project at Beatrice, Neb., that would have brought an additional 485,000,000 cubic feet of gas a day to the Chicago area.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Tuesday, Aug. 5 -- A man who worked on a Braille edition of the Scriptures became the Bible champion of the land of the Bible early this morning.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's statement today on signing an authorization bill for the Atomic Energy Commission:

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 4 -- The formation of Americans for Constitutional Action" was announced here today. Its founders called it an organization to "aid in the promotion and preservation of the American system of constitutional government."
SOUTH DARTMOUTH, Mass., Aug. 4 -- There was a complete reversal of yesterday's finish order among the 12-Meter sloops as the New York Yacht Club cruise headed east on its second squadron run today.

Almost every available chair was taken when the sixth series of open air concerts opened at Washington Square Park last night, and one could not see the grass for the standees. The Collegium Musicum presented works by Handel, Vivaldi, Mozart, Albinoni and Haydn; Fritz Rikko conducted.
The so-called unpredictability of Wall Street finds little support in the remarkable regularity of dividend payments by many American concerns.
Elliot H. Goodwin and John V. Lindsay, rivals for the Republican nomination for Representative in the Seventeenth Congressional District, reported new support yesterday.

THE woman who finds that she does not have enough clothes to get through the summer can turn to the transition dress. This dark, lightweight fashion can be worn from now until time to shake the mothballs out of the woolens.
ELIZABETH, N. J., Aug. 4 -- An ordinance banning the delivery of free newspapers, adopted in near-by Union Township in January, was upset here today by Superior Court Judge Walter L. Hetfield.
PARIS, Aug. 4 -- The ten-year prison sentence of Wayne Powers, United States Army deserter who hid for fourteen years in his French sweetheart's home, was reduced today to six months at hard labor.

ROME, Aug. 4 -- The world needs many more school teachers, an educators' report said today. They are almost everywhere badly paid, work harder than ever and are scarcest in mathematics and the sciences it added.
SIXTY MILLION dollars of baubles, bangles and beads made by one jewelry concern were bartered for the world over last year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The legislative log jam holding up aid-to-science education bills broke wide open late today both Houses of Congress.

GROSSETO, Italy, Aug. 4. -- (UPI) -- Prof. Johannes Huerzeler said today he had located the missing skull of what he believed to be one of the earliest man like creatures -- 10,000,000 or 11,000,000 years older than most scientists had thought possible.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 4 -- Europe is a melange of languages and the Brussels World's Fair is more so. It seems only natural that a festival of university theatre groups should be held here.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 4 -- Bold Ruler will go to the races no more.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Witch doctors in Southern Rhodesia have found a lucrative outlet for their mystic charms -- as resident charm suppliers to African soccer football teams.
ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 4 -- Turkey has responded to her new credits from the United States and Europe with a broad financial program to "restore financial stability."
A proposal that medical insurance coverage here be expanded to include mental health was made yesterday to Mayor Wagner.

About 150 fellow-workers at Bellevue Hospital thronged its synagogue yesterday for a service in memory of Mrs. Sali Speilman, a kitchen worker who was found smothered to death on July 27 in the psychiatric division.
THERE were no spectacular events or effects in "The Last Summer." the play on "Studio One in Hollywood" over Channel 2 last night.
School officials said yesterday the city was already moving in the directions urged by two State Education Department reports for preventing delinquency or coping with it in the schools.
Senator Jacob K. Javits last night urged the establishment of a Marshall Plan for the Mideast.

The New York Health Show will open at the Coliseum tomorrow. Under the leadership of New York City's Health Department the affair will be truly national in scope. More than eighty medical and public health organizations will take part in demonstrating the outstanding advances in medicine and public health during the past two decades.
Physical ills are compounded by housing ills for many of the city's elderly home-care patients, State Housing Commissioner Joseph P. McMurray told Governor Harriman yesterday.

A sharp rise in the status of China within the Communist world is shown by the wording of Sunday's communique on the meeting of Nikita S. Khrushchev and Mao Tse-tung.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 4 -- The United States Eighth Circuit Court of Appeals heard arguments today on a request that it overrule a District Court decision suspending racial integration at Central High School in Little Rock, Ark.
A Teamster Union local representing sanitation workers said yesterday it would be the first union to be recognized by the city for collective bargaining under the "Little Wagner Act."

Otto L. Nelson Jr., executive director for the construction of the Lincoln Square Arts Center, is quoted in The New York Times of July 29 as saying that the relocation of tenants from the area is "going ahead very satisfactorily."
Commodity futures prices closed generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading was quiet.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Treasury bill rate rose substantially this week, the Treasury disclosed tonight. The average interest rate on $1,700,000,000 of the 91-day discount bills was 1.165 per cent. This compared with 0.984 per cent last week.
The Nehi Corporation has selected an agency to handle its $2,500,000 soft drink advertising program, but it will not release the agency's name until the end of the week.
Opposition to proposed use charges on the Welland Canal in Canada is increasing among shipping circles and in industrial areas.
LONDON, Aug. 4 (Reuters) -- The Cairo radio reported today that an ousted Aden Sultan and a Kuwait cabinet minister conferred today.

ONE of the largest crowds in the history of Stadium concerts assembled at Lewisohn Stadium last night to hear Van Cliburn play the two piano concertos with which he won the International Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow last April. The official count was 22,500.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 31 -- Rigid and often irrational censorship has confused the reporting of the crisis in Lebanon.

Duquesne Light Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday slight gains in net income for the three, six and twelve months ended June 30, despite lower kilowatt hour sales. The Pittsburgh utility's June quarter sales trailed the year-ago level by 7.2 per cent, reflecting a drop of 16.1 per cent in industrial and 0.1 per cent in other sales. Residential and commercial sales ran 7.6 and 1.9 per cent higher, respectively.
Cotton futures closed here irregular, 24 points higher to 8 points lower, (a point equals 5 cents a bale) with the near months showing the most strength yesterday.
THE ageless story of the idealistic Young Man in love with a worldly Older Woman is told again with considerable skill by Albert J. Guerard in his new novel, "The Bystander."*

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- President Eisenhower signed legislation today authorizing appropriations of $286,000,000 for the Atomic Energy Commission. But he described as unsound and undesirable projects accounting for nearly $250,000,000 of the amount.
CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Grain futures resumed their general retreat today in slow dealings on the Board of Trade with corn leading the setbacks.

OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. 4 -- Edward Potter Jr.'s even-money favorite, Plion, stumbled at the start of the $28,300 Choice Stakes at Monmouth Park today and tossed William Hartack over his head. The second-choice Backbone came on in the stretch to win the mile-and-a-sixteenth feature.
Great tides and winds act upon the ocean of air that envelopes the earth, causing radical changes in the density of its upper reaches, depending on the season, latitude and time of day.
HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 4 -- The leader of the largest group in Finland's Parliament said today it was not the most important matter in the world to get into the next Government coalition.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI) -- The House gave quick approval today to legislation to set up a Federal Aviation Agency that would control both civilian and military traffic.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 4 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold reported today an increasing public interest in United Nations handling of the problems of outer space.

The election in Lebanon and the recognition by Western Governments of the revolutionary regime in Iraq have provided a temporary measure of stability in the Middle East, a region that is inherently unstable. But it is a lull, not an end; we have passed through the eye of the storm but more winds will blow.

As Mayor Wagner returns to the city from a California vacation he faces the fundamental question not of whether he might want to run for the United States Senate but of whether he keeps promises made and repeated to the people of New York.

LONDON, Aug. 4 (UPI) -- Record performances by Herb Elliott of Australia, Valerie Sloper of New Zealand and Gerhardus Potgieter of South Africa today enabled the Commonwealth to defeat Britain's men and women in a track meet at White City Stadium.
Idle United States-flag tanker tonnage has quintupled in the last year, the American Merchant Marine Institute reported yesterday.

YONKERS, Aug. 4 -- Arthur Brown's A. B. C. Freight Forwarding Corporation filly, Anna Dares, has been designated as the 6-5 favorite for the fourth annual Yonkers Futurity at Yonkers Raceway tomorrow night.

Twenty-two of the New York Rangers' thirty-five home National Hockey League games will be week-end dates. Muzz Patrick, the general manager, said yesterday that seventeen of the Madison Square Garden contests have been carded for Sunday nights at 7 o'clock.
Today's new film is "Law and Disorder," a British-made comedy starring Michael Redgrave, which arrives at the Baronet Theatre, Third Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.
The New York Board of Rabbis urged Mayor Wagner yesterday to rescind the unwritten policy of the Department of Hospitals that prevents the prescribing of birth-control devices in city hospitals.
A bronze plaque honoring John Peter Zenger, colonial fighter for a free press, was dedicated yesterday in a ceremony at the old Subtreasury Building, Wall and Nassau Streets.
Market Commissioner Anthony Masciarelli visited the merchants at the Havemeyer Street Retail Market in Brooklyn yesterday and told them he would try to keep the market going.

James T. Farrell, who recently made a study trip to Israel, has delivered the manuscript of a book based on that trip to Herzl Press. To be called "It Has Come to Pass." the work presents Mr. Farrell's impressions and observations of Israel and the people. The book is planned for fall publication.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 4 -- The United States, Britain and France reached a tacit understanding today that the proposed meeting of the Security Council on the heads-of-Government level should be held in Geneva, not in New York.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 4 -- The head of the Greek Cypriote underground declared a truce tonight with Turkish Cypriotes and the British regime here.
MOSCOW, Aug. 4 -- Premier Nikita S. Khrushchev has said that he opposes the sending of "volunteers" or regular military forces from other countries into the Middle East.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 4 -- Twelve days ago Ryne Duren was hospitalized in Detroit after being hit on the cheek with a pitched ball. Tonight the Yankees' bespectacled emergency man was back in his old job of firing bullets at rival batters. In this instance the rivals were the skidding Orioles, who were beaten, 9 -- 4.
Two teen-age girls admitted yesterday the attack on the two daughters of Iran's permanent representative to the United Nations in Bronx Park last May. Both girls were arrested yesterday in the Bronx.

The Bellanca Corporation, whose stock was delisted late in June from the American Stock Exchange because of irregularities in its year-and-a-half-long diversification program is apparently beginning another such expansion.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Senator Lyndon B. Johnson, the majority leader, said today that major bills still pending made it impossible to estimate whether Congress would adjourn in "two weeks, three weeks or four weeks."

GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 5 -Mrs. Alan A. Ryan of The Creek eliminated the medalist, Pat Tiernan of Wheatley Hills, 1 up, today in the first round of the Women's Cross Country Golf Association championship at the Nassau County Club.

A TAINTED hamburger got the blame for the recent and much-publicized stomach-ache suffered by Bing Crosby's son, Gary. With less attention from the press, many others probably have suffered similarly in recent weeks because ground meat is one of the most frequent causes of food poisoning in the summer.

By and large, moviegoers are a hardy lot. They have to be, for many of today's movies are ghoulier than ever! Skeptical? All one need do is consult the movie listings or, better yet, visit a theatre presenting such films as "Macabre," "Haunted Stranger," "Fiend Without a Face," "Beast of the Amazon," "The Mole People," "The Revenge of Frankenstein," "Curse of the Demon."
Cottton futures closed 13 points (65 cents a bale) off to 31 points ($1.55 a bale) up on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. The new October and new December contracts showed the most strength.

An increase in sales of 0.5 per cent in 1957 over 1956 in the average men's wear store was offset by a drop in net profit before taxes from 3.5 to 3.0 per cent of sales in the same period, according to a survey released yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The antitrust chief of the Justice Department told Senate investigators today that his division was giving "extremely close scrutiny" to the recent increases in steel prices.
PARIS, Aug. 5 (Reuters) -Seven oil companies announced here today that they were planning to build "as soon as possible" a two-million-ton-ayear refinery near Algiers to handle Sahara crude oil.

The State Education Department's report on New York City's public school treatment of the delinquency problem is, while critical, done in a gentle, humane manner. Nevertheless, Dr. James E. Allen Jr., the Commissioner of Education, finds that there is plenty wrong with the city's schools. The survey did not cover the whole school system; it limited itself largely to the schools most concerned with behavior problems.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development [World Bank] had net income of $42,000,000 for the fiscal year ended June 30. This compared with a profit of $36,000,000 for the preceding year.

BUDAPEST, Aug. 5 (AP) -Hungary's Istvan Rozsavoelgyi ran the metric mile, the 1,500 meters, in 3:40.3 to better his own world record in a United States-Hungary-Czechoslovakia track meet today. At the same time he presented a five-way controversy for international officials to solve.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 5 -- The Chinese Communists are still said to be running into stiff resistance from the Tibetans even after eight years of occupation.
Spanish-speaking persons in this area will be offered instruction in the rudiments of English through a new television program titled "Aqui se Habla Ingles," which means "English Spoken Here."

Ernest Hemingway, stating that the passage of time could affect the public's reaction to a writer's works, instituted court action yesterday to prevent Esquire magazine from reprinting three short stories he wrote in the Thirties.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The government conceded today for the first time that it could see no way out of the farm surplus problem with its multibillion-dollar annual cost to the taxpayers, for at least the next five years.
DETROIT, Aug. 5 -- Frank Kierdorf, a business agent of the Teamsters Union who was severely burned, hung grimly to life today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Navy selected the Intex Oil Company of Bakersfield, Calif., today to drill and operate oil wells in the Teapot Dome Petroleum Reserve in Wyoming.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Aug. 5 -- The Tito regime sent another note to the Soviet Union today in the running war of words over the Kremlin's abrogation of an economic agreement with Yugoslavia last May.

The landing of United States and British troops in countries of the Middle East has frequently been compared with the Soviet armed intervention in Hungary in OctoberNovember, 1956. Certain erroneous conclusions have been drawn from such a comparison.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Republican Congressional leaders began a drive today for adjournment by Aug. 16 after President Eisenhower handed them a list of bills he would like passed.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 5 -- In what the police called the most orderly election in local waterfront history, Frank Murray and his entire slate of officers were re-elected today by members of Local 1247, International Longshoremen's ssociation.
LONDON, Aug. 5 -- The stock market was fairly firm today and in most sections gains outnumbered losses.
AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 5 -The United States and Britain are becoming increasingly worried over the growing economic squeeze exerted against Jordan by her pro-Nasser Arab neighbors.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 -- Sears, Roebuck Co., the world's largest mail-order and retail merchandising organization, today announced that it was "considering" a public offering of $350,000,000 in long-term debentures next month.

MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 5 -- The contract bridge pair of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Sharp of Covington, Ky., outscored a field of sixty-eight teams this afternoon to take over the lead in the 1958 Life Master Pairs Championship of the Summer National Championships.

DETROIT, Aug. 5 -- Auto union members employed by the General Motors Corporation have voted by a margin of better than 10 to 1 for strike action, if necessary, to back up their 1958 bargaining demands.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Senate rackets committee, trying to link a $17,500 extortion to James R. Hoffa, found some of its Michigan witnesses recanting and hesitant today.

Texas Gas Transmission Corporation and subsidiary reported yesterday gains in operating revenues for the three and twelve months ended on June 30. Net income for both periods, however, was less than a year earlier due largely to higher costs, particularly gas purchases and operation and maintenance expenses.

ON its way to the Brussels World's Fair, the San Francisco Actor's Workshop has stopped off in New York with its production of Samuel Beckett's "Waiting for Godot." It opened last evening at the York Playhouse, First Avenue at Sixty-fourth Street.

Two executives of the MissouriKansas-Texas Railroad Company said yesterday they expected to recommend approval of a plan for an exchange of debentures for preferred stock authorized recently by the Interstate Commerce Commission. W. W. Deramus III, president, and Robert E. Thomas, chairman of the executive committee, said directors of the road would meet later this month.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Senate Commerce Committee approved today a new five-year program of loans and construction differentials designed to revitalize the domestic fishing industry.
A Brooklyn zebra, something generally not seen off a carousel, has become a mother at the Bronx Zoo. The father has been exiled from his family lest he hurt his striped offspring.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 5 (Reuters) -- The worst surge of killing in Cypriote history slid to a tense halt today after a sixty-day bloodbath in which 152 persons died violently.

Heavy short covering in the September position and a higher London market raised cocoa prices sharply on the New York Cocoa Exchange yesterday. Final to prices advanced 61 to 99 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 553 lots.
PARIS, Aug. 5 -- There was a strong "I told you so" sentiment in Paris tonight following what was considered the virtual burial of a heads-of-government meeting now.

The State Commission of Investigation announced the appointment of Joseph D. Milenky yesterday as its chief investigator. At the same time, the appointments of Justin J. Finger and Carl A. Vergari as assistant counsel on its legal staff were made known.
CHICAGO Aug. 5 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 5 -- The Security Council will meet Thursday at 3 P. M. to take up a Soviet proposal for an emergency special session of the General Assembly.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 5 -- The plucky American Ballet Theatre began a week's performances at the United States Pavilion Theatre at the World's Fair tonight on schedule.

KOUNTZE, Tex., Aug. 5 (AP) -- A District Court jury convicted Bryant W. Bowles, 38 years old, a segregation advocate, in the slaying of his brother-in-law and fixed his sentence at life in prison tonight.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 5 -There were no trains running in Mexico tonight as a rail strike continued.
THIS is an oddball year for giant tuna so far, all the way from here to Newfoundland; the fish are present but they won't be baited. It is so at Montauk Point and in Nova Scotia and in Newfoundland.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 5 -- Bob Turley provided the pitching and Mickey Mantle the pay-off punch tonight as the Yankees continued to make life miserable for the Orioles. Mantle's thirtieth homer of the season, a three-run Wallop off Connie Johnson in the third inning, made it easy for Bullet Bob to beat the Birds, 4 -- 1, and post his seventeenth victory.

Cities Service Company reported yesterday that its subsidiaries had chalked up new highs in first-half volume sales of petroleum products, exceeding the volume in the 1957 period by 6 per cent. Operating revenues and net income, however, trailed 1957 levels.
TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 5 (AP) -- Clyde Reed Jr., publisher from Parsons, won an overwhelming victory tonight for the Republican nomination for Governor in the Kansas primary.

The board of directors of the Smith College Club of New York, headed by Mrs. Edwin Cox, has selected the Dec. 2 performance of "La Plume de Ma Tante" as its annual theatre benefit. The review, recently presented in Paris and London, is scheduled to open at the Royale Theatre early in November and stars Robert Dhery.
DETROIT, Wednesday, Aug. 6 -- Gov. G. Mennen Williams won an over-whelming victory yesterday in a two-way contest for the Democratic nomination for Governor in Michigan's primary election.

New York City is planning to borrow $32,400,000 in the bond market on Aug. 26 to finance the building of new schools and to cover certain of the city's obligations to pension funds.

Another entry has been made on the formidable agenda of the Playwrights Company through the efforts of Roger L. Stevens, the busiest partner in the organization, who dotes on projects. The twelfth and latest in the series, as of yesterday, was "Listen to the Mocking Bird," a mystery play by Edward Chodorov.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Aug. 5 -- Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt, the defender; Mrs. Bruce McGhie, the medal winner, and two former champions were among first-round survivors in the thirty-third Women's WestchesterFairfield Golf Association championship today.

The Correction Department reported yesterday that it was investigating a report by an 18-year-old boy that he had been beaten by a correction officer Monday night as he was being taken in a van to the Brooklyn House of Detention.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The nation's retailers increased their inventories in June -- the first inventory increase in any sector of business this year -- the Commerce Department reported today.
The State Education Department's proposals for combating juvenile delinquency in the city schools received strong support yesterday from several school groups here.
The newsletter, a favorite tool of Wall Street brokerage houses, is winning its share of adherents along Madison Avenue.
