It is obvious that strong measures must be taken to salvage Indonesia's economy if the young republic is to survive. The condition of that economy, the latest reports from Jakarta state, is the worst since the advent of independence. Exports have continued to decline. Food production is inadequate and huge quantities of rice must be imported.

J. P. Morgan Co., Inc., as agent for a group of New York, Toronto and Swiss banks, has granted a $20,000,000 medium-term credit to Bayer Foreign Investments, Ltd., of Toronto. Terms of the loan agreement were not announced.

CHICAGO Aug. 5 (AP) -Ernie Banks; tenth-inning single chased home an unearned run at the expense of Johnny Antonelli for a 10-9 Cubs victory over the San Francisco Giants today. The hectic battle lasted three and one-half hours.
Stockholders of the Pennsylvania and New York Central Railroads, the No. 1 and No. 2, respectively, in the industry, may have terms of a merger proposal submitted to them before the end of the year.

ABOARD THE ILE THE FRANCE, at Sea, Aug. 5 -- This Europe - bound luxury liner picked up today a seriously ill young French crew member from a Liberian-registered freighter in a dramatic midAtlantic transfer at sea.

Mayor Wagner said yesterday that he was opposed to the prescribing of contraceptives in city hospitals, but that he would leave the decision to Dr. Morris A. Jacobs, Commissioner of Hospitals, and members of the Board of Hospitals.

A germ's eye view of life was displayed yesterday at the New York Coliseum, where a huge three-dimensional model of a human cell was put together. The model, resembling a futuristic nightmare, was a glowing jungle of weird shapes that formed a domelike structure large enough to hold forty persons.
NEWARK, Aug. 5 -- Two Guys from Harrison, a chain department store that is open Sundays, may ask a court to suspend the controversial Sunday closing law pending clarification of it.

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- The proposal of Nikita S. Khrushchev for an extraordinary session of the United Nations General Assembly was regarded here as an attempt to get the largest possible forum for a propaganda attack on the West.

The Commercial Credit Company increased its consolidated net income for the second quarter above the profit for the first quarter of this year and for the second quarter of 1957. But earnings for the first half dipped below the 1957 level, the semiannual report disclosed yesterday.

Attendance and buying were heavy at the fifty-third semi-annual Leather Show, which opened yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. About 5,100 buyers registered. The two-day attendance is expected to equal the record of 8,700 set in February, 1957.

NEWARK, Aug. 5 -- Bowing to an order by Superior Court Judge Gerald T. Foley, the New York Central Railroad today resumed its rush-hour ferry service that it curtailed July 15. Yesterday the Appellate Division of the Superior Court refused to grant a stay of Judge Foley's order of last Friday.
The financial interests of inventors who turn over topsecret military inventions to the Government were strengthened yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals.
What effect does an increase in margin requirements have on the stock market? The reaction in recent years has been a short-term dip followed by long-term gains.

Two new films open at firstrun theatres today. "The Naked and the Dead," Warner Brothers' film rendition of the Norman Mailer war novel, arrives at the Capitol. Paul Gregory produced and Raoul Walsh directed, from a screen play by Denis and Terry Saunders. Aldo Ray, Cliff Robertson and Raymond Massey head the cast.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -President Eisenhower's request for an increase in the national debt limit produced a sudden chorus of Congressional demands today for curtailment of Federal spending.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Israeli Government denied today that a Soviet protest had led to the withdrawal of Israel's permission for United States and British planes to fly across Israel to Jordan.

It is good to see that the American public, including Congress, is making progress toward economic literacy. During the past generation we have learned a great deal about the reciprocal nature of foreign trade and we are beginning to understand the evils of indiscriminate subsidies, be they subsidies to farmers or to users of the Post Office.
PORT AU PRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 5 -- Political arrests are being stepped up in an apparent attempt to stamp out all traces of last week's plot to overthrow the Government.
ROCHESTER, N. Y., Aug. 5 -- The Democratic state organization is counting heavily on its record of anti - discrimination legislation to swing votes in critical marginal areas in the fall.

E. Lawrence Goodman has been appointed a vice president of Stern Bros. He will be in charge of sales promotion and publicity for the department store chain's establishments here, in Paramus, N. J., and Great Neck, L. I.
License Commissioner Bernard J. O'Connell said yesterday he was determined to put Times Square gift shop auctioneers out of business.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 5 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves tonight combined home runs by Eddie Mathews and Del Crandall to beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 6 -- 1, and re-establish their National League lead at five games.

OCEANPORT, N. J., Aug. -- Searching, the 6-year-old bay mare bought by Hirsch Jacobs from the Wheatley Stable for $15,000 in mid-1955, won the $22,500 Matriarch Handicap at Monmouth today by two lengths. Mlle. Dianne was second.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 5 ((Reuters) -- The Indonesian Government announced today that the rebels had staged two major attacks on the west Sumatra town of Prapat, a former insurgent stronghold.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., Aug. 5 -- Mrs. Hobart Ramsey of Baltusrol and Willie Turnesa, a former United States and British amateur champion, captured the principal honors in the Metropolitan Golf Association's mixed-foursome tournament at the Upper Montclair Country Club today.

Last September, on the eve of the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund, the United Kingdom's credit position was more precarious than it had been in several years. The devaluation of the French franc had set up rumors in the international exchanges that Britain would find it necessary to follow suit. Predictions filled the air that West Germany would revise the official value of the mark upward.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -The Virgin Islands will soon have a native in the Governor's chair but the right to elect him to that office appears as remote as when the United States acquired the possession from Denmark.
MOSCOW, Aug. 5 -- The Soviet Union has abandoned the idea of a summit meeting on the Middle East within the framework of the United Nations Security Council.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI) -- Dr. Lawrence G. Derthick, United States Commissioner of Education, announced today that more than 600 teachers from the United States and fortythree other countries would take part in the 1958-59 teacher exchange program.

PARIS, Aug. 5 -- Gen. Raoul Salan, French military commander and chief civil administrator in Algeria, announced tonight that 3,302,000 Algerians had registered for participation in the referendum on constitutional reform scheduled for late September or early October.
The Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association yesterday became the first union of municipal employes to be recognized by the city as a bargaining representative for its members.

Linwood Park, an apartment development consisting of seven buildings and five acres of land at 500 White Plains Road, Eastchester, in Westchester County, has been sold by Weintraub Brothers. The buildings, containing 127 apartments, were erected in 1952.
The imminent firing of a succession of rockets to the vicinity of the moon has been made part of the United States program for the International Geophysical Year.

A shopping center containing a bank and ten stores at Ira Street and Jackson Avenue in Syosset, L. I., has been sold by Syosset Equities, Inc., the builder. The property has parking for about 100 cars.

BABYLON, L. I., Aug. 5 -The Island Heights Yacht Club crew, representing the Barnegat Bay fleet, captured the last two races today to win the area semi-finals for the women's national sailing championships.

Roaring engines squealing tires, the boom of crashing metal: These are the night sounds one hears in a dozen localities around New York. At Islip or Riverhead or Freeport on Long Island, or at Weissglass Stadium on Staten Island, when the midgets or the stocks race on Wednesdays or Fridays or Saturdays, nocturnal noises increase by many decibels.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 5 -- Secretary of State Dulles declared here tonight that the United States would have "no hesitation" in debating the Middle East crisis in an emergency session of the United Nations General Assembly.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Aug. 5 -- The Ceylonese Government's controversial bill to give some official status to the Tamil language was approved in Parliament today.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Steel price increases spread today, catching most of the items missed in two previous selective rises.

BARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 5 -- In time the new trend in commodious and utilitarian racetracks will reach Saratoga, and the time is not too remote. John W. Hanes, the president of the New York Racing Association, so informed a group of publishers and turf writers in the proper precincts of the National Museum of Racing today.

The Western Union Telegraph Company announced yesterday acquisition of an one-sixth stock interest in the Gray Manufacturing Company of Hartford, Conn. The transaction will be accomplished through an exchange of 20,000 shares of Western Union common for 60,000 shares of Gray.
The Air Force has proposed converting its only jet fighter unit in the city limits of New York into a medical evacuation unit.

A charge of juvenile delinquency was dropped yesterday against a girl arrested Monday in the attack on the two daughters of Iran's permanent representative to the United Nations. A felonious assault charge against a second girl was reduced to simple assault.
Lower New York was able to witness two tugboat parades yesterday instead of one as scheduled because of a mix-up.

Bloodmobiles of the Red Cross Blood Program today will visit the American Broadcasting Company, 7 West Sixty-sixth Street; the J. C. Penney Company, 330 West Thirty-fourth Street, and the McGraw-Hill Building, 330 West Forty-second Street.

A four-story building containing thirty-two apartments at 2002-04 Avenue J, corner of Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, has been sold by Abraham Pratt to the 2002 Avenue J Corporation. Assessed at $130,000, the house is on a plot of 110 by 100 feet. The deal was negotiated by Irving Bira, broker.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Federal Reserve Board, splitting its vote 4 to 3, denied today an application for expansion of a large bank holding company system in Minnesota. The application was from the First Bank Stock Corporation, which wanted to acquire control of a proposed bank, called First Eastern Heights State Bank, in a new shopping center on the outskirts of St. Paul.
TOKYO, Aug. 5 -- New agreements reached in Tokyo this week with India exemplify an intense new Japanese effort to expand economic relations with south and southeast Asian countries.
NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 5 -This city will attempt to prove this fall that teaching can be made a more attractive career.

A state commission reported yesterday that many Negro professional and skilled technicians had been prevented from working in upstate areas because of housing discrimination.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 5 (AP) -Senator Stuart Symington won renomination to a second term in a runaway in a quiet Missouri primary election today. Two opponents picked up only a token vote.
The Transit Authority has won the right to run eight-car BMT and ten-car IND trains with one conductor instead of two.
PARIS, Aug. 5 -- The Middle East situation was at the heart today of discussions between Mrs. Golda Meir, Israeli Foreign Minister, and French Premier Charles de Gaulle.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Officials here believe that the Iraqi revolution may not yet be concluded and that a fight for power may be in the making between "moderate nationalists" and "Pan-Arabic Nasser nationalists."
Senator Walter J. Mahoney told leading Republicans in Richmond County yesterday that he was in the race for the Republican nomination for Governor "with both feet."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -Victor Russell Hansen, Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Justice Department's Antitrust Division, left his hobbies behind in California when he took over the job in 1956.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -President Eisenhower gave his approval today to the House's science-aid education bill, a broad four-year program that would cost almost a billion dollars.
EDGARTOWN, Mass., Aug. 5 -- Vim added a Commodore's Cup today to the imposing collection of silverware she is carrying home to Oyster Bay from the New York Yacht Club's annual cruise.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Roy W. Johnson, head of the lunar probe program, said tonight that the first moon rocket would be successful if it got within 50,000 miles of the moon.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI) -- Officials of the International Geophysical Year announced today that a series of test explosions would be set off in Lake Superior to determine why the pull of gravity is stronger there than normal.

Stocks sold off yesterday on Monday's increase in margin requirements, rallied to set new highs since last August for The New York Times industrial and combined averages and then dropped as Russia's ideas for a summit meeting were made public.

Vernon T. Dow has retired as vice president and a member of the executive department of the Travelers Insurance Companies. He had been with the company thirty-nine years
CHICAGO, Aug. 5 (AP) -Grain futures slipped again today on the Board of Trade. At the finish, some contracts were close to new season lows.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI) -- Representative Thomas B. Curtis called on House investigators today to prove they had "clean hands" before the House acted on their demand for contempt action against Bernard Goldfine, New England industrialist.

The issue of The New York Times for July 4 contained an article descriptive of an interview given by Mrs. Russell Langdon, former second Vice Regent and Program Chairman of the Ellen Hardin Walworth Chapter, National Society, Daughters of the American Revolution, pertaining to her resignation from the society.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 5 -A United States Marine patrol was subjected to a heavy barrage in the Beirut area today, but it was a shower of apples, peaches, pears, plums, bananas, figs, grapes and flowers tossed by hundreds of smiling, cheering, applauding Lebanese.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -President Eisenhower urged Congress today to act on a bill to create more than forty new Federal judgeships.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 5 -- A new attempt to establish a motion picture Hall of Fame in Hollywood has been started by the studio publicity directors committee. Plans for the project are to be put before the advertising publicity heads of the major distributing companies in New York for approval.
TIME and three seventeenstory apartment buildings are casting new shadows on all that is old in Washington Square.
The likelihood of a strike of maintenance and repair workers against the New York Telephone Company was increased last night.
ROME, Aug. 5 -- Controversy over Gamal Abdel Nasser and the advisability of dealing with him marked tense foreign policy discussions here today.
Venezuela is attempting to renegotiate on a bank-by-bank basis a $250,000,000 credit it had arranged in June with a syndicate of commercial banks in the United States, Canada and elsewhere.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 5 -- The Franklin Institute announced today that Edward Longstreth Medals had been awarded to James Bailey of Hartford, Conn.; Price C. McLemore of Montgomery, Ala., and Dr. George S. Crompton, Professor Emeritus of Ophthalmology at the University of Pennsylvania Medical School.

CANNES, France, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Jack L. Warner, Hollywood motion picture official, suffered a skull fracture today in a car accident as he was returning to his villa from an all-night winning session at a casino.

Mrs. Katherine McLaren, charged with killing her husband Walter early yesterday, was held without bail in Felony Court for a hearing Aug. 15. The police said an argument preceded the shooting in their home at 500 West 134th Street.

A heroic German shepherd dog named Macok won a double award yesterday from the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals.

RIO DE JANIERO, Aug. 5 -Secretary of State Dulles told Brazil's President Juscelino Kubitschek today that the United States was eager for closer ties with Latin America so that cooperation for development of the continent could proceed smoothly.
GENEVA, Aug. 5 (UPI) -- An Austrian physician today held week-end boredom to be one of the chief causes of alcoholism among men and women busy at work the rest of the week.
Chadbourn Gotham, Inc., manufactures of women's hosiery, lingerie and men's hose, is expanding its operations into the men's clothing business.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI) -- The Administration's proposed new space program and the man considered in line to head it were attacked today by members of the House Space Committee.
YONKERS, Aug. 5 -- Spunky Hanover, a bay colt from Harold Large's Fiesta Farm, Garden City, L. I., performed strongly to win the $56,157.50 Yonkers Trot tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

Robert W. Krepps, author of many stories about Africa and the American West, has a book on each of those regions scheduled for publication next month. On Sept. 9 there will be "Earthshaker," a story about an American soldier of fortune who went to South Africa in the Eighteen Nineties in search of a cache of diamonds.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 5 -The trial of seven persons accused of giving shelter to former Premier Nuri as-Said when he fled from a mob in the July 14 revolution ended last night Five Iraqi men and two Iranian women were sentenced to jail terms ranging from one to five years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee approved a $3,518,092,500 mutual security money bill today. It acted after it had restored $440,000,000 cut from the program by the House of Representatives.
The 19,000-member Patrolmen's Benevolent Association served notice on Mayor Wagner yesterday that it wanted official recognition as bargaining agent for the city's patrolmen.

The Navy icebreaker Atka is now en route from Thule Air Force Base in Greenland to a spot 400 miles south of the North Pole. She is on the first leg of a hazardous journey to evacuate a group of Canadian scientists from their base there.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Aug. 5 (AP) -- Jennings Randolph, a seven-term member of Congress before he quit politics in 1947, held a large lead over former Governor William C. Marland tonight for the Democratic nomination to fill the remaining two years of the late Senator Matthew M. Neely's term.

Mayor Wagner closed the door firmly yesterday on the possibility that he would run for Senator this year. At the same time he served notice that he intended to have a voice in the selection of the Democratic candidate.
Capt. Thomas Simmons rang down the engines of the MooreMcCormack liner Argentina yesterday for the last time.

In 1926, the year she swam the English Channel, Gertrude Ederle became fondly regarded as a grease-smeared Venus. She rode up Broadway in a ticker-tape snowstorm and 2,000,000 New Yorkers acclaimed her, some yelling "Trudy! Trudy!" President Coolidge called her "America's Best Girl."

BRASILIA, Brazil, Aug. 6--Secretary of State Dulles and President Juscelino Kubitschek of Brazil agreed today on plans to organize a meeting of twenty-one American Presidents to promote programs to develop Latin America.
ALBANY, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Governor Harriman urged House passage today of the Kennedy-Ives bill.
Reports from various companies indicate that they are preparing for the fall selling season by reinstating advertising budgets previously pared because of the recession.
Dr. Leona Baumgartner, Commissioner of Health, cut a ribbon yesterday to open the New York Health Show at the New York Coliseum.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The Peiping broadcast reported today lent support to the conviction of senior State Department officials that Communist China has begun a campaign for representation at a summit conference of the big powers.

The salvaging of the sunken harbor tanker Empress Bay from the bottom of the East River will probably not take place until this week-end, a spokesman for the Army Corps of Engineers indicated yesterday.

PRINCETON, N. J., Aug. 6 -Universities should exercise a "gentle pressure" on graduate students to complete the Doctor of Philosophy degree in three and one-half years, Sir Hugh Stott Taylor, former dean of Princeton University's Graduate School, said today.

State and municipal long-term financing in the public bond market during July was the largest ever recorded for the month, the Daily Bond Buyer reported yesterday.
A seven-day, woldwide boycott against 12 per cent of the world's ocean tonnage is being planned by seamen's unions, Joseph E. Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, said yesterday.
Surrogate Joseph A. Cox directed yesterday that a $5,411,881 trust fund set up by the late Joseph Pulitzer, newspaper publisher, be divided among thirteen male descendants.

Makers of soft goods are highly optimistic for the second half of this year, a survey indicated yesterday.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Thirty persons were injured and fifty were arrested in rioting last night between supporters and foes of President Luis Somoza.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Bernard Goldfine put his case against being cited for contempt of Congress to the members of the House of Representatives today.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 6 -- This usually somber mountain capital was decked with flags today -- on the 420th anniversary of the founding of the city by the Spaniards -- as it prepared to celebrate the inauguration of Alberto Lleras Camargo as President of Colombia tomorrow.

The battle over a successor to the late Thomas J. Curran as New York County Republican leader increased in bitterness yesterday.

The New York Amsterdam News, Negro weekly newspaper, announced yesterday in an editorial its support of City Councilman Earl Brown in his race for Congress against Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. The editorial said:

AMMAN, Aug. 6 -- Israel's rescinding of the ban on the air-life was interpreted by well-informed circles as a concession to the United States and Britain in an effort to maintain peace in Jordan and Lebanon.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 6 -- Malcolm Anderson, champion of the United States, came within a stroke of following Ashley Cooper out of the Eastern grass court tournament today at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -Users of the new St. Lawrence Seaway began firing criticisms today at proposed fees for navigating the waterway when it is finished next year.

" History of Human Society," a series that will run to twenty-five volumes, is a joint publishing project by Alfred A. Knopf, Inc., and Hutchinson of London. It is expected that the first volume will be published in 1960.
A man described as a "shill" -- a false bidder -- for three Times Square auction shops denied vigorously yesterday that he was.
The Lord Mayor of Bristol, England, insisted yesterday that America was not named for Amerigo Vespucci, the Italian merchant-explorer.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Custom smelters rescinded yesterday the half-cent increase in the price of refined copper that they announced last Friday. This brought their price back to 26 1/2 cents a pound, the level quoted by the large copper producers.
An Air Force Thor-Able missile has recorded a scientific advance considered the key to radically improved "second-generation" intercontinental ballistic missiles.

Anthony A. Smith, an associate of G. H. Walker Co., investment bankers, has been nominated as a director of the Allegany Corporation, the holding company that controls the New York Central Railroad. Mr. Smith's nomination was disclosed yesterday in a proxy statement mailed by Alleghany for a special stockholders' meeting to be held August 28 in Baltimore.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The House Rules Committee cleared the way today for floor action tomorrow on the science-aid education bill.

HAVANA, Aug. 6 -- Bands of rebels are being heavily engaged by government troops over a wide area in three eastern provinces -- Oriente, Las Villas, Camaquoy -- according to reports reaching here today.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 6 -- The West German Government reported today that restitution payments to victims of nazism, to the State of Israel, and to the Conference on Jewish Material Claims against Germany totaled 4,500,000,000 deutschmarks ($1,071,000,000) as of April 1.
LEONIA, N. J., Aug. 6 -- One thousand persons jammed the gymnasium of Leonia High School today for a public hearing on the most controversial section of the Bergen-Passaic Expressway project.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI) -- President Eisenhower said today he felt fine and that his physicians had said he was in good shape. It's only his golf game that's giving him trouble.
NEW CITY, N. Y., Aug. 6 -- Assistant Postmaster William Madlener would like to see the name of this Rockland County seat changed.
PARIS, Aug. 6 -- The French Government maintained today that no settlement of Middle Eastern questions would result from a special meeting of the United Nations General Assembly.
A new obstacle was raised yesterday to a Hall-Mahoney coalition to block Nelson A. Rockefeller's selection as the Republican candidate for Governor.
The Borough of Queens has had a higher population increase in the last thirty-seven years than any other part of the city, according to a survey released yesterday.
LONDON, Aug. 6 -Anglo-American cricket rivalry, which lapsed several decades ago after a fitful series that began in 1889, is to be revived Aug. 24 at the Royal Artillery cricket ground in Woolrich.
SENTIMENT is not a commodity one usually associates with the Yankees, who currently are grinding the rest of the American League under heel.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI) -- A House-Senate conference committee agreed tonight on a compromise $39,602,827,000 defense money bill carrying $815,857,000 more than President Eisenhower had requested.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- President Eisenhower directed a special plea to labor today not to ask for excessive wage increases.

OCEANPORT, N. J. Aug. 6 -- Top-weighted under 124 pounds, Nahodah moved powerfully around the stretch turn to win the $22,750 Rumson Handicap by two and a quarter lengths at the closing of the fifty-day Monmouth Park meeting today.

DUBLIN, Aug. 6 -- Hugh Wiley of Towson, Md., and George Morris of New Canaan, Conn., won major awards in international jumping competitions today at the Dublin Horse Show. The Americans beat riders from Britain, Portugal, France and Ireland.

The Home Insurance Company and its casualty affiliate, The Home Indemnity Company, reported yesterday a first-half increase in consolidated assets of more than $24,000,000 and a $14,000,000 gain in consolidated policyholders' surplus.

A MILLIONAIRE dilettante in the art of politics turned pro -- that sums up the story of Mrs. May Preston Davie. That she has learned her work well was shown yesterday when she moved to hold temporary direction of the New York County Republican Committee through the primary and state convention period.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- A leading Senate Democratic spokesman on foreign affairs attacked the Eisenhower Administration today for conducting an "inadequate, outmoded and misdirected" foreign policy that had brought the nation to the brink of disaster.
Persons disenchanted with looking at Washington, Lincoln or Hamilton on their folding money might consider a possibly more attractive alternative -- looking at themselves.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 6 -- Sammy Davis Jr. has been signed by the "General Electric Theatre" for a dramatic role on TV in "Operation Little Joe," a drama planned as a special program for next season. The singer-dancer will have the leading role as an embittered American soldier in Germany after World War II.
Mayor Wagner yesterday reiterated his stand on prescribing contraceptive devices in city hospitals.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 6 -- The national doctor's strike erupted today into violence that has deepened the split over Peronism in Argentine labor ranks.
WARSAW, Aug. 6 -- Reports reached Poland today that important military and political agreements were made at the recent talks between the leaders of the Soviet Union and Communist China.
Roy Campanella, still paralyzed as the result of an automobile accident last January, will conduct a radio sports program titled "Campy's Corner."
EDGARTOWN, Mass., Aug. 6 -- Perfect sailing weather went out the scuppers today as the New York Yacht Club fleet laid over in this port before resuming its annual cruise tomorrow.

Consolidated net income of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation increased to $28,003,245 in the first half of this year from $21,676,116 a year earlier. The figures include earnings of the Motors Insurance Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary.
LONDON, Aug. 6 -- The Israel Ambassador, Eliahu Elath, asked Prime Minister Harold Macmillan today for arms and a guarantee of Israel's borders against indirect or direct aggression.

Explorer IV, the American earth satellite launched twelve days ago, has encountered radiation that appears to be 167 times more intense than the mysterious rays thought to have been discovered by the earlier Explorer satellites.

The three companies in Nationwide Insurance reported yesterday that all three had strengthened their surplus positions during the first half, despite operating losses by two. Nationwide Mutual, the casualty insurer, showed an underwriting loss of $203,000 during the first six months, but surplus increased by $2,600,000 to $47,246,000, as a result of investment income and increased valuation of securities.

Curtailment of nickel production adversely affected the earnings of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., in the quarter and six months ended June 30. Output was cut because of inventory buildup resulting from a drop in sales.

The opening sentence of your editorial of July 28 read, "Are we in danger of having our sense of wonder dulled by the rapidity of the march of science these days?" I would like to substitute the word perspective for wonder in your opening and had hoped that you would have done it for me.

Are people becoming inured to the recurring international crises? The Guaranty Trust Company of New York, in its latest survey of business conditions, finds that such may be the case noting that the economic impact of the latest Middle East flare-up has been mild.
STOCKHOLM, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Powerful bacterial poisons that kill cancer and offer some protection against atomic radiation were discussed today at a world conference on microbiology.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- President Eisenhower signed the compromise defense reorganization bill today and called for cooperation of personnel throughout the military establishment "to assure its faithful execution."

Responsibility for getting a desperately needed bill creating forty-six new Federal judgeships through Congress before adjournment rests squarely with Speaker Sam Rayburn and Majority Leader Lyndon Johnson.

CAIRO, Aug. 6 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser angrily canceled a meeting today with President Eisenhower's special envoy to the Middle East and then as abruptly invited him for talks during the evening. companied by Raymond A. Hare, United States Ambassador to Cairo. Also sitting in on the private and informal meeting was Dr. Mahmoud Fawzy, Foreign Minister of the Arab Republic, and Ali Sabry, President Nasser's chief political aide.
RHODES, Greece, Aug. 6 (UPI) -- The United States Navy summoned crewmen from shore leave and sent a destroyer speeding to a remote Greek island today to save the life of a 3-year-old Greek boy.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -The controversial question of who will pay for repairing the Suez Canal has been settled, so far as American users are concerned.

Paramount's "The Black Orchid" and United Artists' "God's Little Acre" have been designated as the two official entries from the United States at the forthcoming Venice Film Festival, according to the Motion Picture Export Association of America.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Nationalist Chinese regime here proclaimed a state of emergency today in the Pescadores and the Matsu Islands as a precaution against Communist attack.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, and Senator Relph E. Flanders, Republican of Vermont, fell into debate in the Senate today over Mr. Flanders' spotlighting of Israel as a source of Middle East turmoil.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Wheat futures scored their first price advances in four trading sessions on the Board of Trade today, but corn and soybeans continued their slide. Oats and rye were narrowly irregular.
Prices of cotton futures moved 2 points (10 cents a bale) off to 14 points (70 cents a bale) up yesterday. Trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was fairly active at times.
DAMASCUS, United Arab Republic, Aug. 6 --Syria is talking about new rail and road links with Iraq.

A floor in Canada House, the new office building at 680 Fifth Avenue at Fifty-fourth Street, has been leased by the Gulf Oil Corporation, which is expanding its executive offices here. The lease was negotiated by J. Jacques Juncker, vice president of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., renting manager of the building for Canada House (New York), Ltd., and Webb Knapp, Inc., the owners.

THE phrase, "Out of the Frying Pan," can have an especial significance in mid-summer. During the season of soaring temperature and high humidity, a skillet can be a cook's best friend, especially if affairs of business or beach must be concluded before the guests arrive.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 6 -- The wonder of the Saratoga Special today was that any opposition turned up or Christopher T. Chenery's undefeated First Landing. The Special, having its fifty-first running, is a winner-take-all event for 2-year-olds, at six furlongs.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 6--Lebanon's long political crisis was on dead center today.
ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Aug. 6 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission said today it would set off an underground atomic blast six times larger than past such explosions near Carlsbad, N. M., next summer.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug. 6 (AP) -- A Thor intermediate range ballistic missile, which will pack the main punch for the Air Force's first moon rocket, blasted toward space today in another test of guidance and power.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The House approved today a bill to force public disclosure of employe welfare and pension fund operations.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 6 -- Reliable sources disclosed today that the United States was planning to submit a broad political and economic program to stabilize the Middle East at the impending emergency session of the General Assembly.

Electric power production reached a record level last week of 12,619,000,000 kilowatt hours. This surpassed the previous high of 12,570,000,000 kilowatt hours produced in the week ended Dec. 14, 1957.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- President Eisenhower said today that the United States had "a very deep responsibility" for the independence of threatened small nations everywhere.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 6 -- Jamie Brickell of the American Y. C. held a 2-point lead for the Long Island Sound junior sailing championship after winning two of the three Pequot Cup series races held today.

The New York Mercantile Exchange announced yesterday plans for a revision of its trading rules. The exchange said that James Coker, an authority on commodity exchange operations, had been engaged to make the exchange's "operating rules and by-laws a model of modern simplicity and clarity."

SINCE the Shakespeare in Central Park is free, no one can complain that he is not getting his money's worth. But the "Twelfth Night," which opened in the Belvedere Lake Theatre last evening, is below the able standards of the previous work.

At a two-hour special meeting here yesterday the board of Penn-Texas Corporation voted to change the company's name and to further reduce the power of its former chief executive, Leopold D. Silberstein.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 6 (AP) -- A rookie right-hander, Carl Willey of the Braves, faced the Pittsburgh Pirates for the first time tonight and stopped them with a three-hitter as Milwaukee rolled to a 2-1 victory on Hank Aaron's two-run homer in the first inning.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 6 -- Apparently, as a concession to Elston Howard's bid to capture the batting championship, Casey Stengel advanced the Yankee catcher to No. 3 in the batting order against the Orioles tonight.
LONDON, Aug. 6 -- The stock market was again fairly buoyant today and prices continued to improve in most sections.

Installment credit delinquencies increased slightly in June, the installment credit commission of the American Bankers Association reported yesterday. Seasonal factors were thought to be the chief reason.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6 (UPI) -- Former President Herbert Hoover said today he was in favor of pensions for former Presidents.
THE jaded tourist who has been everywhere might head for Alaska if he wants to keep busy until outer space is properly routed.

CHICAGO, Aug. 6 -- A Chicago lawyer and a former Miami Beach beer distributor have developed a flourishing business with the aid of the Hobby Horse Nursery School, here. About three and a half years ago Emanuel Schwartz, whose business interests have included beer, real estate and clothing manufacturing, and Daniel Kipnis, the lawyer, decided to go into business together.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- The Israeli Government agreed today to a United States request for resumption of flights over Israel by United States Air Force planes carrying supplies to Jordan.
Ernest Hemingway sharply denied last night that he had expressed concern that reprinting three of his short stories about the Spanish Civil War might cause unfavorable public reaction.

A decline of only 93,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 178,715,000 barrels, compared with 178,808,000 a week earlier and 175,994,000 a year ago.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 6 (AP) -United States Steel Corporation, following the lead of Bethlehem Steel Corporation, increased today the price of plates, structural shapes and sheet piling an average of $4.25 a ton effective tomorrow.
LONDON, Aug. 6 -- Prime Minister Harold Macmillan will fly to Athens tomorrow to seek ways to extend the precarious two-day-old truce on Cyprus.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Aug. 6 -- Science and social studies teachers from thirty-three public school systems in fifteen states were told here today by a leading economist that the Soviet Union's spurt in science and economics would be overcome.
TRENTON, Aug. 6 -- The State Commissioner of Banking and Insurance ordered Blue Shield today to reduce its subscriber rates by 5 per cent by Oct. 1.

These menus, which appear each Thursday, use seasonally abundant foods and are moderate in cost. They are designed to strike a balance between appetite appeal and the convenience of the family cook. Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

The State of Vermont is planning to borrow $8,000,000 in the bond market to finance highway construction. A bond issue will be offered at public bidding on Aug. 19. Dated Sept. 1, 1958, the bonds will come due serially from 1959 to 1968.

When Joe Kryla Jr. attended Iona Prep about ten years ago, he told his dad that golf was an "old man's game." The elder Kryla did not take the remark too seriously. Instead, he returned to his New Rochelle home one evening with a large bundle under his arm.
Stocks used a slash in the custom smelters' copper prices as an excuse for a general sell-off near the close of yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange.

We are sorry to learn that some members of the House Space Committee are working energetically to block selection of Dr. Hugh L. Dryden as head of the nation's new space agency. Since 1947 Dr. Dryden has been director of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics, which is to form the nucleus of the new organization.
WHAT makes women buy? Janet Wolff, the author of a book of the same name, has the answer.

On Feb. 12, 1956, Mayor Wagner told a television audience that the city administration and the Port of New York Authority would "get together in the not too distant future" to discuss the possibility of turning over New York City's waterfront properties to the authority for modernization.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Aug. 6 -- Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt of Westchester, Mrs. Allison Choate of Apawamis, Mrs. Bruce McGhie of Whippoorwill and Mrs. John H. Bartol of Greenwich reached the semi-finals today in the thirty-third Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association championship.

In the face of the dangerous impasse between the Arab states and Israel it is to be expected that efforts will continue to be made to find a mediating position which can serve as a vantage point for a solution. All too often, however, the laudable desire for impartiality leads to a blurring of reality.
COWES, England, Aug. 6 (AP) -Prince Philip got off to his second straight poor start and lost his second yacht race in twenty-four hours today.
Mikhail Tal of Moscow gained his second consecutive victory in the interzonal chess tournament at Portoroz and led the field of twenty-one, according to a report received last night from Yugoslavia.

A blind man and his friend were arrested in Manhattan yesterday and charged with the illegal possession of narcotics. The police said it was the sighted man's practice to lead the blind man to West Seventy-second Street so that he could sell narcotics on the street corners.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI) -- The court-appointed overseers of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters warned James R. Hoffa today that they would crack down quickly if he resisted their clean-up orders.

French, British and Swiss interests and the Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation have joined in a project to develop bauxite deposits in French Guinea, a part of French West Africa, and to produce alumina.
PARIS, Aug. 6 -- The Government set Sept. 28 today as the date for a popular referendum on a new constitution for France.
DUBLIN, Aug. 6 (AP) -- No more human is Herb Elliott, a lanky Australian youngster who ran a record-smashing 3:54.5 mile here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- A lawyer and an accountant for James R. Hoffa testified today that they had had the use of $310,000 in Teamster Union funds at various times for private construction ventures. They paid 6 per cent on the money, more than half of which is still owed.

Directors of the Merritt-Chapman and Scott Corporation, construction and marine salvage company, reduced the quarterly dividend yesterday to 20 cents from 40 cents a share. The move caught Wall Street by surprise and the stock dropped 1 1/4 points to 16 1/2.
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Bob Bitner of Big Rapids, Mich., lengthened his lead at the two-thirds mark in the national target archery tournament today.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Aug. 6 -- Mrs. Walter Cooperstein of Harbor Hills, the defending champion, led the way into the semi-finals of the Women's Cross County Golf Association championship today. She scored a 4-and-3 victory over Mrs. William Renner of Hempstead at the Nassau Country Club.
DUBLIN, Aug. 6 -- Herb Elliott of Australia ran the mile tonight in 3 minutes 54.5 seconds.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 6 -- A 22-year-old Polish seaman, who managed to elude his ship's officers long enough to plead for refuge in this country, will have a second hearing in Federal Court tomorrow on his bid for political asylum.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- President Eisenhower accepted today the resignation of Mansfield D. Sprague as an Assistant Secretary of Defense, effective about Oct. 1.

Strike benefits paid by unions to members range from nothing to $650 a month, according to a survey made public yesterday by the National Industrial Conference Board. Information from unions with 11,000,000 members was given to the private research agency.
A reduction in prices by custom smelters lowered copper futures on the Commodity Exchange yesterday. Final quotations were 45 to 55 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) lower on 185 lots.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Robin Roberts pitched his 201st major league victory tonight, but he had to have help from Dick Farrell at the finish before the Philadelphia Phils defeated the Redlegs, 8 -- 5. Roberts was lifted in the last of the ninth after serving up two home run balls and yielding a single and a double.

It looks as though Middle Eastern affairs could now turn toward something more constructive than angry letters and mutual accusations. President Eisenhower's press conference yesterday was heartening in this respect. There is less tension in the air, and even though a meeting of the United Nations General Assembly will not solve many specific problems, it will provide a forum in which the United States as well as the Soviet Union can present their aims.
GENEVA, Aug. 6 -- The chiefs of the Western and Soviet bloc scientific delegations met in informal session today in an attempt to reconcile their differences over an atomic test detection system.

Harvey Sorkin and Lawrence Herman, realty operators, sold the five-story apartment house for a forty-nine family at 1272-78 Grand Concourse in the Bronx. The property is 101 by 105 feet and is assessed at $175,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Republican strategy aimed at getting a farm bill as close as possible to the Administration's wishes appeared tonight to have backfired, with the prospect that Congress would pass no farm legislation at all.

DETROIT, Aug. 6 -- The overwhelming victory of Gov. G. Mennen Williams in Michigan's primary yesterday was generally interpreted here today as a favorable omen for the Democratic party's chances for gains in the fall election.
Christopher Plummer has signed contracts for a starring role in Archibald MacLeish's epic drama of mankind, "J. B." He will be seen in the part of Satan, identified in the script as Mr. Nickles.
Aphrodite, the Greek goddess of love and beauty at the Metropolitan Museum of Art who disappeared from sight a few months ago, has returned to become a focus of attention again.

EUGENE O'NEILL is the hero of "Part of a Long Story,"* a memoir by his second wife, Agnes Boulton. Although their marriage lasted, in its fashion, from 1917 to 1928, the story centers, here, on the galvanic World War I years they spent in Greenwich Village, rural New Jersey and Provincetown.

In the story from Managua, Nicaragua, by your correspondent Paul P. Kennedy, published in The Times of July 28, reference was made to the "fraternal relations" existing between the Organizing Committee for Free Trade Unions of Nicaragua and the Inter-American Regional Organization of Workers (O. R. I. T.).
THE business of daily living is now facing thousands of brides who radiantly took marriage vows in June.

MOSCOW, Aug. 6 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev's move to put the Middle East crisis into the hands of the United Nations General Assembly marks one of the Soviet Premier's first serious diplomatic and public setbacks.

The possibility of a merger between two of the nation's biggest auto supply chains has come closer to reality with the acquisition of 1,256,000 common shares of the Western Auto Supply Company by Gamble-Skogmo, Inc. The latter now owns more than 41.7 per cent of the 3,005,472 outstanding shares of Western Auto.
A group of Americans carried flowers yesterday to a young Japanese woman on the anniversary of the day in 1945 on which the atomic bomb brought her and her townsmen great suffering.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Robert L. Kunzig, recently under fire in his current Federal job, was nominated by President Eisenhower today to be a member of the United States Foreign Claims Settlement Commission.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Two events that occurred today in Washington illustrate and dramatize the strange and contradictory mood of the capital.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -President Eisenhower said today that he had no plans for any action to head off further trouble over racial integration in the South when schools open next month.
MANILA, Aug. 6 (AP) -- A disciple of Mohandas K. Gandhi who walks through India soliciting gifts of land for the landless poor has been selected for the first award of the Ramon Magsaysay Foundation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 -- Hawaii's bid for statehood was approved by a 22-4 vote of the House Interior and Insular Arfairs Committee today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 6 -- Leigh Whipper, president of the Negro Actors Guild of America, today announced that he had withdrawn from the film "Porgy and Bess." He said his move was a protest against the removal of Rouben Mamoulian as director by Samuel Goldwyn, the producer, and his replacement by Otto Preminger.

MIAMI BEACH, Aug. 6 -- The contract bridge pair of Mrs. Helen Sobel of New York and Charles H. Goren of Miami Beach, came from far behind this afternoon to win the Life Master Pairs Championship, the blue-ribbon pair championship of United States tournament bridge.
STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 6 -- School officials announced jubilantly today that a solution might soon be found for the 334 sticking windows at the Walter R. Dolan Junior High School on Toms Road.

NEWARK, Aug. 6 -- The 1958-1959 concert season of the Griffith Music Foundation has been canceled because of the serious illness of Mrs. Parker O. Griffith, founder and president of the organization, it was announced today by her husband.

TOKYO, Aug. 6 -- Fresh appeals for the banning of nuclear weapons marked celebrations in Japan today of the thirteenth anniversary of the atomic bombing of Hiroshima.
HONG KONG, Aug. 6 -- The Peiping radio called tonight for a big-power summit conference in addition to an emergency session of the United Nations General Assembly.

Joseph E. Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, strongly reaffirmed his decision yesterday to develop a closer working relationship with two unions expelled from the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.
A COOLING breeze and whiff of sea air wafted from the East River into the Carl Schurz Park last night, where it mixed with soothing orchestral sounds.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- The General Assembly's meeting on the Middle East will be its fifth special session, and its third "emergency special" meeting under the "uniting-for-peace" resolution of 1950.
A diversified program has been planned for the eleventh annual Monmouth Fair. The two-day event will open tomorrow morning at 11 o'clock at Monmouth Park Race Track, Oceanport, N. J.

John J. Lamula, former Assemblyman and a leader in the Second Assembly District, announced his candidacy for the chairmanship of the New York County Republican Committee yesterday. The office became vacant July 29 with the death of Thomas J. Curran, county leader for eighteen years.
MOST of the television coverage of yesterday's meeting of the United Nations Security Council was provided by WABD (Channel 5).
In one of the most active sessions in many months, cotton futures advanced 2 to 96 points on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. The October and December, 1959, deliveries were strongest.

BARE - TORSOED riggers, tanned by broiling sun, toiled all this week in the east end of the Museum of Modern Art outdoor exhibition space in West Fifty-fourth Street to dig great stones out of the Japanese garden planted there four years ago alongside a sixteenth century-type Japanese house.
The Eastern Women's Headwear Association said yesterday it would oppose a union proposal that all overtime work in the millinery industry be abolished in the coming season.
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Bob Bitner of Big Rapids, Mich., became the national target archery champion today as James Caspers' record-breaking performance fell short.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Senate rackets committee members accused James R. Hoffa today of having packed his Teamsters Union offices with penitentiary products and penitentiary candidates.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Aug. 7 -- A Chinese Nationalist patrol of F-84 Sabrejets clashed with a dozen Communist MIG-17's over the Quemoy area this morning, Taiwan Air Force headquarters announced today.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 7 -- An official leave policy for United States troops is expected to be promulgated in the next twenty - four to forty - eight hours. It will bring approximately 2,000 servicemen into Beirut during daylight hours each day.

ROCHESTER, Minn., Aug. 7 -- Eleven of the 139 competitors in the United States Chess Federation's open championship, sponsored by the International Business Machines Corporation, had clean scores at the conclusion of the second round today.
NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 7 -- Two tankers groping through an early morning fog collided and burst into flames today at the mouth of Newport harbor.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- The General Assembly will begin an emergency special session on the Middle Eastern situation tomorrow afternoon at 5 o'clock.

ESPECIALLY convenient when the weather is torrid are dishes that can be prepared in advance and then reheated shortly before dinner. Two such dishes, designed especially for occasions when there will be company, are suggested here.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UPI) -- The House Commerce Committee approved a bill today that would provide a 7 per cent increase in pension benefits for 650,000 retired railroad workers and their survivors.
For the third straight week, the number of persons drawing unemployment insurance benefits in New York State dropped last week.

Consolidated Natural Gas Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues, net income and gas sales volume for the first half of 1958. James Comerford, president, placed volume during the first six months at 200,132,000,000 cubic feet, against 283,390,000,000 in the like 1957 period.

PARIS, Aug. 7 -- Michel Debre, the Minister of Justice, said today the proposed draft constitution was meant to establish political authority, France's fundamental need. This was the first defense of the draft text by a Government official.

MARC BOHAN, a much-praised French designer, has been hired by the House of Christian Dior to help Yves St. Laurent turn out Diot fashions for New York and South America, it was announced in Paris this week.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 7 -- Barry MacKay of the United States Davis Cup team was eliminated from the Eastern grass-court tennis championships today and the winning exploits of John Cranston were brought to an end.
ONE hundred antique dolls, representing one of the largest collections in the country, will go on display Wednesday at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street.
Bingo took a giant step yesterday toward becoming a legal form of entertainment in the city next Jan. 1.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 7 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru expressed concern today about events in India's Communist state, Kerala.
A union move to control the international shipment of recorded music was announced yesterday by Herman D. Kenin, president of the American Federation of Musicians.
STRAPS ride high, wide and handsome on fall shoes, which will be in the stores later this month.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Congress enacted legislation today providing long-term loans and equity capital to small businesses through state-chartered private investment companies.
WASHINGTON, Aug 7 -- The science-aid school bill won its first test in the House today.
RYE, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- Long Island's team retained the Stoddard Bowl again by beating Westchester and New Jersey in the annual triangular matches of the Metropolitan Golf Association today.

Anne Louise Germaine Necker, Baroness de Stael, of whom a dual biography was published earlier this year, is the subject of a second one entitled "Mistress To An Age." The author is J. Christopher Herold, editor-in-chief of the Stanford University Press.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals routed the San Francisco Giants, 12 -- 1, tonight with Sam Jones holding the Giants to four scattered hits.

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- Dr. Kwame Nkrumah, Prime Minister of Ghana, said today that if Ghana became a republic it would be a republic within the British Commonwealth. He made the statement just before he left for home.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- A bill that would subject any Federal Government-official or employe to suspension as "a security risk" -- whether he was in a sensitive post or not -- ran into trouble today.

As a former president of the New York Young Republican Club I have had the opportunity to work with, know and like both Elliot H. ("Pete") Goodwin and John V. Lindsay, opponents in the hotly contested Republican primary race in the Seventeenth Congressional District.
MOSCOW, Aug. 7 -- Adlai E. Stevenson acknowledged today that he had been unsuccessful in his efforts to get the Soviet Union to pay United States authors whose works are reprinted widely here.

Those City College students who agreed, after a recent session at Roosevelt Raceway, that they couldn't beat the races are wise beyond their years, for they learned in an evening what many of us fail to understand in a lifetime.

Past and future policy on the prescribing of contraceptive devices in city hospitals will be examined today at a meeting between, Dr. Morris A. Jacobs, Commissioner of Hospitals, and a Protestant group.

YONKERS, Aug. 7 -- Closing with a 29-second quarter, favored Speedy Pick of the Blue Hen Stables at Dagsboro, Del., triumphed in 2:01 1/5 in the $8,000 Westchester Handicap for pacers at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
Is it too late to halt the evident determination of the Administration to make "indirect aggression" a major issue in the impending United Nations talks?
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UPI) -- A new president has been selected for the 32,000-member Distillery Workers' Union, now on probation for failure to obey federated labor's clean-up directives.

Because of Premier Khrushchev's Peiping-propelled somersault on a summit meeting under the United Nations Security Council, the Council has called an emergency session of the General Assembly to begin today to deal with the turbulent Middle East. This session may yet reach the summit if President Eisenhower, Prime Minister Macmillan and Mr. Khrushchev attend, as they hint they may.
Facts can sometimes serve to confuse.
Want some noise? Engineers of the Radio Corporation of America can supply it. They have developed a device they believe can produce the world's loudest controlled noise.
CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department. of Agriculture follows:
Ilya Wolston, a nephew of confessed Soviet spy Jack Soble, interrupted a contempt of court hearing yesterday to plead guilty.

Foremost Dairies, Inc., and its subsidiaries had consolidated net sales of $204,888,848 in the six months ended June 30, exceeding the previous record of $200,016,746, set in the similar period last year.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 7 -- The new Republic of Iraq hopes to become a welfare state based on "practical socialism," Mohammed Hadid, Minister of Finance, said yesterday.

Rory Calhoun, 23-year-old puncher from White Plains, N. Y., faces 26-year-old Gene (Ace) Armstrong of Linden, N. J., a clever boxed, in a scheduled ten-round middleweight bout at Madison Square Garden tonight.

An agreement covering operations of Clupak, Inc., holder of a patent for the manufacture of stretchable paper, was signed yesterday by officials of Cluett, Peabody Co., Inc., and the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company, joint owners of the company.
PORT - AU - PRINCE, Haiti, Aug. 7 -- All commercial activity was suspended here this morning as thousands paraded in demonstration of support for the Administration of President Francois Duvalier.
Space-conscious Americans early yesterday were startled to see what appeared to be a rocket headed for the moon.

The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) reported yesterday consolidated net income in the first half of 1958 of $11,435,786, or $2.29 each on the 4,830,044 common shares outstanding. Earnings included a non-recurring profit of $3,081,044, or 64 cents a share, from the sale of oil and gas royalty interests.

SOUHTPORT, Conn., Aug. 7 -- Kevin Jaffe and the Noroton Yacht Club crew captured the junior sailing championship of Long Island Sound today after finishing the Pequot Cup series in a point-tie with Jamie Brickell of American Y. C.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 7 (UPI) -- Eddie Mathews broke up a pitchers' duel between Warren Spahn and Bob Friend today with a two-run homer in the seventh inning to help the Milwaukee Braves post a 3-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.
HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 7 -- This was a day when the red flag of the Soviet Union whipped in the breeze in front of City Hall along with Finland's blue and white.

Now that the need for the study of mathematics in the high schools is being widely discussed, the report recently published by the United States Office of Education, as described in The New York Times of July 23, takes on a more than ordinary aspect.
TOKYO, Aug. 7 -- Japan has decided not to send out any more ships for International Geophysical Year oceonographic surveys unless the United States suspends nuclear testing in the Pacific.
Three men asked the State Supreme Court yesterday to help them get rid of a $2,500,000 headache -- a fifty-six-pound aquamarine.
HOW would you, Mrs. Housewife, like a holiday from all headaches -- no cooking, cleaning or keeping watch on the youngsters -- and a two-week, cost-free vacation to boot?
MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 7 -- The most extensive road resurfacing program in the history of Nassau County was started here this week.

Stocks showed their resilience yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The opening failed to continue the final downward thrust of Wednesday's closing, and every major group closed with solid gains.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, Aug. 7 -- If the program Turkey arranged for her National Day at the World's Fair tonight was representative, her music is hardly in an advanced state. The most promising element was a young coloratura soprano named Ferhan Onat.

Lawyers for Louis E. Wolfson issued a statement in his behalf yesterday detailing the Florida industrialist's position in the stock of the American Motors Corporation. Leo Gott lieb of the New York law firm of Cleary, Gottlieb, Friendly Hamilton, in issuing the statement in Mr. Wolfson's behalf, explained that it was made so their client would comply with a consent decree issued on Aug. 1 by Federal Judge John M. Cashin.

Since November pedestrians have been admonished repeatedly to "Cross at the Green," and otherwise be careful when entering the roadways. During recent months policemen were assigned to particularly dangerous corners and warning leaflets were handed to violators. Now the city's safety education campaign has reached the punitive level. Beginning today, those caught "jaywalking" are subject to summonses, calling for a $2 fine.

Commodity futures prices closed generally higher yesterday in quiet trading on the New York exchanges. Cocoa, copper, hides, potatoes, zinc and cottonseed and soybean oil rose; sugar, tin and rubber declined and moves for coffee, wool and lead were mixed.
LIBERTY, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- A surgeon piloted his plane to New York today, picked up three pints of rare blood and then returned here to use the fluid in an operation on a seriously ill woman.
A motion aimed at winning a declaration that all wiretapping in New York State is illegal was made yesterday in General Sessions Court. Judge Thomas Dickens reserved decision.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., Aug. 7 -- The Parrish Art Museum here will be the beneficiary of Southampton's second annual horse show. The event will take place at the Myron Bonis estate on Majors Path on Saturday from 9 A. M. to 6 P. M.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Aug. 7 -- The Soviet Union's sudden withdrawal from the proposed summit meeting in the United Nations Security Council is regarded here as a diplomatic blunder.

MIAMI, Aug. 7 -- Five hundred and sixty contract bridge players this afternoon played the first qualifying session in the Men's Pairs and Women's Pairs championships of the 1958 Summer National Championships.
The State Power Authority is ready to go ahead with its plan for the permanent financing of the Niagara power project.

CAIRO, Aug. 7 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser and King Saud of Saudi Arabia are patching up their bitter six-month feud.

Myers Brothers, garage operators, sold the four-story and basement garage at 325 West Thirty-fourth Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues to clients of Levy Kornblum, attorneys. The garage houses 500 cars.

The consistently liberal decisions of the United States Supreme Court in the general area of civil liberties have produced a reaction in Congress which may have been inevitable but can and should be thwarted.
CHICAGO, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Most grain futures scored their first price advances of the week today on the Board of Trade, but they were small.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 7 -- The representative of the revolutionary Government of Iraq was seated in the Security Council without debate today.
A trend toward higher salaries in the agency field, but not for every position, has been found by Printers' Ink in its annual survey of salaries.

An intensive search for a plot worthy of Cole Porter's ministrations as composer-lyricist has ended. Cy Feuer and Ernest Martin, producers of Mr. Porter's most recent shows, "Can-Can" and "Silk Stockings," believe the desirable qualities are inherent in Rip Van Ronkel's "The Rascal and the Bride," which might be called "Baldazare," for the leading character.
